I missed this great two-disc set at the time of its release in 2006 on the obscure French label Rogue Art.  The 24 pieces by the Roscoe Mitchell Trio were recorded from December 2005 to February 2006 in Madison, Wisconsin, where Mitchell has lived for many years.Roscoe Mitchell (founder of the Art Ensemble of Chicago, early member of Chicago's AACM, performer, and composer) plays soprano, alto, tenor, and bass saxophones, flute, piccolo and percussion.  Harrison Bankhead plays bass and cello.  Vincent Davis plays drums and percussion.  Bankhead is a long-time Chicago musician who is perhaps best known for playing with the late Fred Anderson, and Davis has been playing in Mitchell's Note Factory since the 2002 Song for My Sister, so these musicians have a telepathic bond making possible instant communication, shifts, and movement.The pieces move through diverse settings, from energy music a la late Coltrane or Ayler, featuring Mitchell's astonishing circular breathing technique, to the slow, quiet, and meditative.  They range from 2'25 in length to 13'38.  I consider Mitchell to be one of the great late 20th century composers.  Each of these pieces, though, takes the unique structure as the basis for improvisation, and unlike some of Mitchell's other releases, like Far Side, few listeners are likely to think this is anything but jazz -- free jazz, avant jazz, jazz with ingenious composed structures, yes, but definitely jazz, the African-American tradition emphasizing improvisation.NO SIDE EFFECTS is strongly recommended to all Roscoe Mitchell fans!*** *** ***Rogue Art saves money on graphics and uses the same spartan white color with black-and-red lettering on all its releases.  Inside there are three color photos of the musicians, and a poem by Steve Dalachinsky.  Fortunately the excellent music makes up for the plain package.

This latest album from Henry Threadgill's Zooid is a 2-disc set from Pi Recordings, recorded in December 2014.  The lineup is:Henry Threadgill -- alto sax, flute, bass fluteJose Davila -- trombone, tubaLiberty Ellman -- guitarChristopher Hoffman -- celloElliot Humberto Kavee -- drums, percussionZooid is a quintet once again as bassist Stomu Takeishi, who played on the the last three albums, is no longer present.  Zooid continues to explore Threadgill's novel compositional/improvisational method, as explained on the Pi website:"Named after a biological term for a cell that is capable of spontaneous movement independent of its parent organism, Threadgill's compositions for Zooid assign a set of intervals to each player that serves as the starting point for improvisation. The result is a contrapuntal crazy quilt that materializes with a mysterious logic."The drummer Kavee describes Threadgill's system: "The spaces between the notes - the intervals in time and pitch - are the elements that we work with in our improvisations. His system generates a constantly shifting negative space - a mutating kaleidoscope of sound, movement and emotion that moves around its own axis."The basic approach remains the same.  What is different for IN FOR A PENNY, IN FOR A POUND is that the compositions are longer, and each is in the form of a suite, with sections punctuated by complete stops.  The players continue to mesh and interact beautifully, and each is featured on one of the long pieces:Disc 101 In for a penny, in for a pound (opening)  4'3602 Ceroepic (for drums and percussion)  19'3803 Dosepic (for cello)  16'00Disc 201 Off the prompt box (exordium)  3'3602 Tresepic (for trombone and tuba)  17'2603 Unoepic (for guitar)  17'57In the brief liner notes Threadgill explains that in addition to the four quintets featuring an instrument, there is a fifth quintet featuring sax and flute that is woven into the others.  Throughout each piece all five musicians take turns leading, and some drop out to leave subgroups -- the "featured instrument" does not solo continuously.  Each disc leads with a brief opening piece.  Every one of the musicians plays amazing solos and submerges as part of the contrupuntal ensemble with equal mastery.  There are lugubrious passages with no driving pulse, and other passages that swing like mad!  According to Threadgill, "[a]ll six sections together is one piece, the epic "In for a Penny, In for a Pound."Henry Threadgill, now 71, has been one of my favorite musicians and composers ever since I saw him and what was at that time his new band, the Sextet, at the Underground Fest in Chicago, the "afterfest" of the Chicago Jazz Festival, in 1981.His albums are of consistently high quality, and this latest is no exception.  He vanished from sight from 2001 to 2009, with no recordings, and thank goodness since then he has released four albums with this Zooid band.  Their live appearances are far and few between -- I would love to see them, but these great albums from Pi Recordings will have to do!

This is an excellent live recording of a 62-minute performance that I finally added to my Cecil collection. This was a short-lived Unit that fell in between the Andrew Cyrille years and the well-documented Unit with Ronald Shannon Jackson on drums and Ramsey Ameen on violin. Marc Edwards is the drummer here, the only recording he made with Cecil, and he does a fine job. I consider Cyrille to have been Cecil's best drummer, and Edwards doesn't cut loose the way Cyrille did -- he is more a backing drummer than a co-equal. This Unit is a quintet, with Jimmy Lyons on alto (of course), and two young players, Raphe Malik on trumpet and David S. Ware on tenor. Malik sounds great, soloing at length right out of the gate, very bright and extroverted. (He would continue with Cecil, playing in the Unit with Shannon Jackson documented on New World and Hat Hut.) Ware sounds fine as well, adding low register playing to the sound palette and trading rhythmic patterns with Cecil. Lyons is right at home - he had played with Cecil for 15 years when this recording was made, and would play with him for 10 more years before his premature death in 1986 at the age of 53.This was a summer festival gig, the Yugoslovian Jazz Festival in Lubljana. I heard a Cecil Taylor solo performance at the Chicago Jazz Festival in the late 1980s, and his playing is like nothing else. He comments in the liner notes here by Steve Lake that his music is "...about magic and capturing spirits." On June 18, 1976 there was some powerful magic in the air in Lubljana!(verified purchase from Other Music, NYC)

This Brilliant-style box (14 discs in cardboard slipcases with their original cover art -- no jewel cases) restores to print several great recordings of modern and contemporary music.  With the exception of the Messiaen recordings from 1966, everything else was recorded from 1980 to 1991.  There is no indication of remastering -- they are marked ADD/DDD.  There are five discs of Stravinsky and Schoenberg, arguably the two most important 20th Century Modern composers.  The other nine discs are less well-known contemporary music, including three discs of Boulez conducting Boulez.In the 1990s, Boulez signed with Deutsche Grammophon.  His vast output on that label is more expansive and more Romantic than his earlier recordings for Sony, for example "Boulez conducts Schoenberg", and Erato.  He also stuck mainly to the Modern canon for DG, and rarely recorded the sort of cutting edge avant-garde works of the late 20th century found here.Both Schoenberg discs here, including recordings of the violin and piano concertos and two orchestral works (the early "Pelleas und Melisande" and the late, serialist "Variations for Orchestra") are well worth hearing and have been available as a two-disc set from Erato and Apex:  see my lengthy review.  As for Stravinsky, the major find for me is the complete 46-minute opera "Le Rossignol" featuring Phyllis Bryn-Julson and John Tomlinson with the BBC Symphony Orchestra -- beautiful music, beautifully performed.  Also found on the same disc is the rare "Les Soucoupes" original version from 1914-1917, along with the better known version from 1954.  I am less impressed by the neoclassical "Pulcinella," the symphonic poem "Le Chant du Rossignol," and "L'Histoire du Soldat," an amusing miniature work of musical theater for three singers, a dancer, and a septet.  Patrice Chereau, best known for designing the modern set for the Boulez Ring at Bayreuth, is the soldier!Turning to the three Boulez discs, this 1981 recording of "Pli Selon Pli" with Phyllis Bryn-Julson is quite fine -- I haven't yet done a careful comparison with my favorite recording on Sony from 1969 with Halina Lukomska, also recorded with the BBC Symphony Orchestra.  It is clearly preferable to the more recent recording with Christine Schaefer and the Ensemble Intercontemporain, the recording Boulez considers definitive.  The disc of chamber works is interesting but rather light.  It includes the early version of "...explosante-fixe..." for flute and eight instruments.  The best find is the disc of vocal and orchestral works.  "Le Visage nuptial" and "Le Soleil des Eaux" for soprano, chorus and orchestra, both based on poems by Rene Char, are quite compelling and surprisingly accessible.  I find "Figures, Doubles, Prismes" for orchestra, from 1968, to be one of Boulez's more powerful works, sounding positively Xenakis-like in its fiercest passages.  No doubt this why Boulez never revisited or revised it -- it is somewhat out of character for him, as he has generally favored delicacy over ferocity.The Messiaen recordings, including "Et Exspecto resurrectionem mortuorum," are fine, but the recording here with the Orchestre du Domaine Musical is clearly surpassed by Boulez's later recording with the Cleveland Orchestra.  The recording of Berio's "Sinfonia" included here is the best-known version, and it has been widely available.  I have never been all that impressed with the composition myself.  It sounds quite dated to me, an attempt to be "hip" in a very Sixties style featuring the New Swingles Singers and a narrator.  For what it's worth, Boulez recently included it in a list of the ten most important works of the 20th Century.The disc of Eliott Carter performed by the Ensemble Intercontemporain is superb, a highlight of this entire set.  It features the incredibly vivacious "Concerto for Oboe," written for and performed by the great virtuoso Heinz Holliger.  "Penthode" (1984-5) was commissioned by the EI, and it is dedicated to the EI and Boulez. It is more austere than the concerto, but fascinating.  Twenty players are divided into groups of four, and as Carter explains, "...each group...has its own repertory of expressive characters embodied in its own special field of speeds and musical intervals. While the five groups oppose or combine with each other, one long continuous line is passed from one instrument to another, binding the first and third sections of the score together."  See my review:  Carter -- Ensemble Intercontemporain/Pierre Boulez.And that brings us to the reason I was quite excited to see this box -- three discs of contemporary music that have been out of print and unavailable for years:  1) Donatoni and Ligeti, 2) Kurtag, Birtwistle, and Grisey, and 3) Dufourt, Ferneyhough, Harvey, and Holler.  Along with the Carter disc and the Xenakis piece on the disc with Berio, this is a treasure trove of great contemporary music performed by the Ensemble Intercontemporain, led by Boulez:Harrison Birtwistle -- "...AGM..." for 16 voices and 3 instrumental groups (27'10)Elliott Carter -- "Concerto for Oboe" with Heinz Holliger (19'57), "Penthode" (19'25), and "A Mirror on which to Dwell" (18'40)Franco Donatoni -- "Tema" for 12 instruments (16'09) and "Cadeau" for 11 instruments (11'12)Hugues Dufourt -- "Antiphysis" for leading flute and chamber orchestra (18'14)Brian Ferneyhough -- "Funerailles," Versions I (11'11) and II (13'37)Gerard Grisey -- "Modulations" for 33 musicians (18'38)York Holler -- "Arcus" for 17 instruments and magnetic tape (19'35)Gyorgy Kurtag -- "Messages de feu Demoiselle R.V. Troussova" for soprano and chamber ensemble (25'52)Gyorgy Ligeti -- "Trio" for violin, horn, and piano (21'41)Iannis Xenakis -- "Jalons" for 15 instrumentalists (14'35)The Birtwistle piece, with a text constructed of fragments of poetry from Sappho, is quite unique and compelling, combining his distinctive drama-oriented style with a smoother sound that reminds me of Ligeti's microtonal writing.  This 1983 version of the great Kurtag piece, settings of 21 poems by Rimma Dalos, features the Hungarian soprano Adrienne Csengery.  It was recorded very soon after its original recording in Hungary, and Boulez's performances of it with Csengery and the Ensemble Intercontemporain played a major role in establishing Kurtag's reputation in the West.  I have not yet had the chance to do a careful comparison of the two recordings, but this one is excellent.  Pierre-Laurent Aimard plays Book One of Ligeti's "Etudes for Piano," and the "Trio" for violin, horn, and piano is also included.  For definitive recordings, I suggest the Ligeti Edition from Sony.Two of the best works here are those by Dufourt (of France) and Holler (of Germany).  They are both dense and powerful, and deserve to be heard by anyone interested in contemporary avant-garde music.  Dufourt, one of the original spectralists, explores shifting intensities with the flute moving through mysterious passages interrupted by ferocious ensemble blasts.  Holler's piece is a subtle and fascinating tapestry of interweaving acoustic and electronic motives, very different from his award-winning recent electro-acoustic Spharen (Spheres), which blends the electronics with and enhances the orchestra.  I have not always been impressed by the electronic elements of Jonathan Harvey's music, but "Mortuos Plango, Vivos Voco" for concrete sounds, featuring bells and soprano, is quite striking and impressive, created with computer processing.Ferneyhough's twin "Funerailles" for string sextet plus bass and harp are slower, more spacious, and more mournful, as the title suggests, than his typically frantic chamber music, though dotted with trademark quicksilver scurries.  The Donatoni pieces are both bright, light, and lively.  "Tema" features oboe, woodwinds and strings with unbroken forward rhythmic motion, like Mozart-in-a-funhouse-mirror.  "Cadeau" is more episodic, and features tuba, harp, and xylophone along with oboe.  "Jalons" by Xenakis is from his late period (1986), and while not as complex and fascinating as his Sixties and Seventies works, it is a nice addition here.  The Grisey piece is the fourth of six parts of his spectralist cycle, "Les espaces acoustiques," which can now be heard to greater advantage as part of the completed cycle.Five of the discs here were released as a set several years ago, and that collection is now rendered obsolete as it is all included here along with much else that had been left out.One thing that is not included, and it is mentioned in the liner notes in error, is an Erato disc of Daniel Barenboim leading the Orchestre de Paris in three works by Boulez, including "Notations 1-4."  The Complete Erato Recordings means everything with Boulez as conductor.  Another minor error in the 40-page booklet in English, French, and German is that the list of dates and locations of the recordings is not complete.  The 11-page essay by Maxime Joos comments on Boulez and his relation to the composers and works, but does not give very much information on the compositions in their own right -- the focus is on Boulez.This is a great reissue -- thanks to Warner Classics, which appears to be reviving the Erato imprint.

Vijay Iyer (piano), Marcus Gilmore (drums), and Stephan Crump (bass) here follow up the great 2009 album Historicity with an even better album in the same vein.  ACCELERANDO deserved every award it won for 2012 jazz -- it is another exciting rhythmic blend of modern jazz classics (Henry Threadgill, Herbie Nichols), the lovely Duke Elllington ballad "The Village of the Virgins," catchy melodic pop songs (Rod Temperton/Heatwave, Steve Ellison/Flying Lotus, Porcaro-Bettis/Michael Jackson), and Iyer originals.  (Iyer quotes "Cool" from West Side Story by Bernstein/Sondheim in his solo in "Optimism.")Iyer makes reference in the liner notes to how the world is accelerating:  "...rising inequality, populist revolution, economic crisis, climate change..."  This is music of the moment, and music that will last.  This is music that is rooted in the rhythms and history of jazz, and connects with the wider world of pop and progressive social change.For now it stands as the Trio's best recording, but their more recent Break Stuff (2015) on ECM is also excellent, a cooler, sleeker set with fewer recognizable pop melodies.If you haven't yet heard the Vijay Iyer Trio, what are you waiting for?

Pianist Vijay Iyer, with Marcus Gilmore on drums and Stephan Crump on bass, is updating the piano trio with exciting rhythms and a fresh mixture of modern jazz classics (by Andrew Hill, Julius Hemphill and Ronnie Foster), pop songs (by Bernstein & Sondheim, Stevie Wonder, and M.I.A), and original compositions by Iyer.This is vibrant, contemporary jazz, great for listening while dancing or sitting, but if sitting, some part of you is likely to be in motion!Iyer includes a quote from Gramsci's Prison Notebooks in the liner notes, and refers to the "Brown and Black Atlantic" of colonialism and the slave trade, so we know the music is informed by a radical political and social sensibility.My jazz listening has grown further and further from what's current, still rooted in the Sixties/Seventies free jazz/improv of the AACM (Roscoe Mitchell, Henry Threadgill) and Europe (Peter Brotzmann, Evan Parker), so I am quite happy to have discovered some great jazz being made by younger musicians!

THE SEER made all the best-of lists for 2012.  Now Michael Gira and Swans have astonished us all again by making another 2-disc album that is just as good!On first listening I found it hard to judge whether TO BE KIND was as good, or better than, THE SEER.  It took repeated listening to come the conclusion that THE SEER is less consistent -- Disc One is not as good as TO BE KIND, but Disc Two is better.  TO BE KIND is more consistent throughout.Swans, the band, is by now forged into a powerful unit.  I am quite sorry that I missed their recent Atlanta performance, which came during the madness of the end of the spring semester.Fortunately they will be recording another album before long, and hopefully they'll come back through.Gira and Swans cut through the shallow, superficial, plastic facade to the flesh and bone and electric soul of Life!

I was initially underwhelmed by this album, which made all the critics' best-of lists for 2012, but eventually I realized what everyone was raving about.  The thing is, though, THE SEER is not equally superb throughout.  The second disc is just amazing, so don't be too hasty to form your opinion after only hearing Disc One.  The opening track (Lunacy) is fairly light, and there is a clear minimalist influence.  Then Disc Two shoots us screaming into space on a dark, psychedelic voyage!Michael Gira's reformed Swans are more powerful than ever.  The more recent TO BE KIND (2014) is more consistent than THE SEER -- it's stronger throughout -- but it does not reach the same heights.The music of Michael Gira and Swans is raw, visionary and uncompromising.  His vocals remind of both Lou Reed and Iggy Pop, but the music is sui generis.  Listening is like plugging your mind directly into the black hole at the heart of the galaxy.

I never heard Swans in their original run.  I only finally caught up with them with THE SEER (2012), and then worked back to this 2010 album.  It took repeated listening, but the incantations worked, and I am now under Michael Gira's spell.Swans music stands where carnality and brutality collide with spirituality and cerebral metaphysicality.  It locks into repetitive riffs influenced by minimalism and rises to ecstatic heights like gospel.  Gira's lyrics are vivid and intense.This album has been surpassed by THE SEER and TO BE KIND (2014), but it's a great album in its own right.  The artwork by Beatrice Pediconi is stunning.(verified purchase from Decatur CD)

Snakeoil, Tim Berne's chamber jazz project, did not sound very appealing to me when it began a few years ago.  I never got past the soundclips until now.  I thought the addition of a guitar might boost the energy level, but I find this set to lack inspiration.  The one exception is "Embraceable Me," which builds very effectively to an energetic finale, with some lovely lyrical playing from the woodwinds along the way.Berne has always been a large-form composer, and to fully appreciate his music the listener has to be patient as the structure unfolds.  Solos tend to be secondary to the compositions, and that is certainly true with Snakeoil.I only recently caught up with the outstanding  Science Friction Live: The Sublime And...  album from 2003 (see my review), and it has all the energy and excitement lacking from this new release.  Ryan Ferreira, the newly added guitarist here, is not allowed to play the lead role Marc Ducret plays with Science Friction and several other Berne bands, but is restrained and subdued.Tim Berne, who studied with Julius Hemphill, has never been a traditional jazz player.  I wouldn't say Snakeoil's music is very jazz-like at all, though that is how it is categorized.  That's not a bad thing, I'm no jazz traditionalist.  Rather, it seems to me that Berne has tended to bring the energy of rock to his music, and I find that lacking in Snakeoil.So it doesn't swing, and neither does it rock -- to my ears it lacks a spark.*** *** ***I saw Tim Berne live in Tucson in 1997, a great concert at the Mat Bevel Institute organized by Zeitgeist Productions.  It was a duet with Michael Formanek on bass, and I only recently learned that it was recorded and is available as a CD:  Ornery People.  That performance made clear that Tim Berne can solo quite impressively on alto sax -- he's not only an innovative composer.

IN TIMES did not impress me nearly as much as the other Enslaved albums I've heard on the first few listens.  (Those are Below the Lights, Isa, Vertebrae, and Axioma Ethica Odini).  But based on those great previous albums, and the rave reviews on many metal websites, I didn't give up easily.  I persevered, kept listening, and then it started to sound better and better until it hit me that IN TIMES is indeed another great album from the Norwegian extreme/progressive metalists -- it helps to crank up the volume!One of the most immediately compelling songs is "Building With Fire," which features a galloping NWOBHM-style beat.  Herbrand Larsen's clean vocals struck me at first as not-in-sync with the band's sound, but that's one of the things that changed with repeated listening -- it sounds more and more right.There are sections in both "In Times" and "Daylight" that sound very Amon Duul II-esque to me -- Seventies psychedelia.  The passage in "Daylight" is quite striking, with everything dropping out except two guitars, evocative of a blissful utopia.  Eventually the band joins back in with power chords.  The black metal vocals of Grutle Kjellson, founder and bassist, are featured periodically throughout, but as with all their recent albums, black metal is only an element of the progressive sound, a point that seems to be lost on some reviewers who expect pure black metal.Another influence I noticed, and I may be wrong about this, but I think I hear the great Norwegian composer Grieg here and there in the mix, particularly the well-known theme "In the Hall of the Mountain King."  That would be fitting, as the vision of Enslaved has expanded well beyond the black metal of their very young early days!

"Gawain" was Birtwistle's fifth musical drama, and the first that he outright called an opera, with a libretto by frequent Birtwistle collaborator David Harsent.  It premiered in 1991, and this recording was of a slightly modified version recorded live by BBC 3 on April 20, 1994 at the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden.Elgar Howarth, the composer's close friend and colleague, directed the Orchestra of the Royal Opera House and the Royal Opera Chorus.  The principals, all superb, are Francois Le Roux (baritone) as the knight Gawain, Marie Angel (soprano) as Morgan le Fay, Anne Howells (mezzo soprano) as Lady de Hautdesert, and John Tomlinson (bass baritone) as the Green Knight and as the nobleman Bertilak de Hautdesert."Gawain" is much less ambitious than The Mask of Orpheus, and much more successful, at least as an audio recording (I have not seen either on the stage).  It is a fairly traditional opera, with strong singing roles for men and women, intrigue, seduction, virtue, and its absence.  Of course Birtwistle's music is not traditional, but the music of "Gawain" has strong links to Wagner, and is informed specifically by both "Gotterdammerung" and "Parsifal."The poet David Harsent drew on the 14th century narrative poem.  He transforms the Green Knight, who takes on the dual nature of both Green Man, representing the wild, untamed outdoors, and the moral values of the society -- its paternal and civic authority.  Harsent transforms Morgan le Fay from a marginal and evil character in the original to one both central and virtuous.  Core to the story arc is Gawain's realization that he is not the Hero of the story, a strong parallel to Siegfried in Wagner's Ring.I don't find "Gawain" to be as compelling as Birtwistle's more recent The Minotaur (see my review), but that is partly because "The Minotaur" was released as a DVD, and the visuals are stunning, including John Tomlinson as the ingeniously costumed Minotaur and the voluptuous Christine Rice as Ariadne.  But like "The Minotaur," "Gawain" makes powerfully effective use of myth, creating a timeless now.Clearly Birtwistle is a modern master of musical drama!This recording was reissued by NMC in 2014: Harrison Birtwistle: Gawain.

This is the NMC reissue of Sir Harrison Birtwistle's "Gawain," originally released by Collins Classics.  It was Birtwistle's fifth musical drama, and the first that he outright called an opera, with a libretto by frequent Birtwistle collaborator David Harsent.  It premiered in 1991, and this recording was of a slightly modified version recorded live by BBC 3 on April 20, 1994 at the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden.  The 36-page booklet includes commentary, a Synopsis, and the complete libretto.Elgar Howarth, the composer's close friend and colleague, directed the Orchestra of the Royal Opera House and the Royal Opera Chorus.  The principals, all superb, are Francois Le Roux (baritone) as the knight Gawain, Marie Angel (soprano) as Morgan le Fay, Anne Howells (mezzo soprano) as Lady de Hautdesert, and John Tomlinson (bass baritone) as the Green Knight and as the nobleman Bertilak de Hautdesert."Gawain" is much less ambitious than The Mask of Orpheus, and much more successful, at least as an audio recording (I have not seen either on the stage).  It is a fairly traditional opera, with strong singing roles for men and women, intrigue, seduction, virtue, and its absence.  Of course Birtwistle's music is not traditional, but the music of "Gawain" has strong links to Wagner, and is informed specifically by both "Gotterdammerung" and "Parsifal."The poet David Harsent drew on the 14th century narrative poem.  He transforms the Green Knight, who takes on the dual nature of both Green Man, representing the wild, untamed outdoors, and the moral values of the society -- its paternal and civic authority.  Harsent transforms Morgan le Fay from a marginal and evil character in the original to one both central and virtuous.  Core to the story arc is Gawain's realization that he is not the Hero of the story, a strong parallel to Siegfried in Wagner's Ring.I don't find "Gawain" to be as compelling as Birtwistle's more recent The Minotaur (see my review), but that is partly because "The Minotaur" was released as a DVD, and the visuals are stunning, including John Tomlinson as the ingeniously costumed Minotaur and the voluptuous Christine Rice as Ariadne.  But like "The Minotaur," "Gawain" makes powerfully effective use of myth, creating a timeless now.Clearly Birtwistle is a modern master of musical drama!

THE MUSICThis 2-disc set includes an overview of Lanegan's solo work on Disc One -- 20 songs, a full disc, ranging across his albums from THE WINDING SHEET (1989) to BUBBLEGUM (2004) -- and 12 unreleased tracks on the much shorter Disc Two, including one from the BLUES FUNERAL sessions of 2011, and a live recording from 2000.The songs on Disc One are organized as follows:Tracks 1-3 from Bubblegum (2004)Track 4 -- "Mirrored" B-side of single from 2004Tracks 5-9 from Field Songs (2001)Tracks 10-11 from I'll Take Care of You (1999) coversTrack 12 "Lexington Slow Down" from a 2003 EPTracks 13-14 from Scraps At Midnight (1998Tracks 15-16 from The Winding Sheet (1989)Tracks 17-20 from Whiskey For the Holy Ghost (1994)Given the amount of previously unreleased material, this is essential for hardcore Lanegan fans.  For those just discovering his music, it's a perfectly fine introduction, but no substitute for his best albums.  I recommend starting with Whiskey for the Holy Ghost (1994) or Field Songs (1998), and the very different, more rocking Blues Funeral (2012).THE PACKAGEBoth discs are in one sleeve of the vinyl LP-style cardboard case with and the 44-page booklet in the other sleeve.  All the lyrics are included, one song to a page, in Lanegan's cursive scrawl.  There are 8 photos of the Man in all including those in the booklet and those on the CD case.  The case is laminated, so it not only looks good, but is quite sturdy.Mark Lanegan has recently become one of my favorite artists.  This is a great set for Lanegan fans old and new!

Though it might come as a surprise to some, given the clear roots of YOB in Black Sabbath, this is intensely spiritual music -- a doom metal doorway to enlightenment.  The five long songs all have serious metaphysical lyrics printed in the single-sheet foldout, and the graphics feature a mystical diagram of overlapping triangles in a circle that reveals the path inward to infinity.  Scott Kelly of Neurosis, another intensely spiritual doom metal band, contributes vocals and lyrics to "Before We Dreamed of Two."  It is entirely appropriate that YOB has released their latest, Clearing the Path to Ascend (2014), on Neurot Recordings, the Neurosis label.Here is a lyric to give you an idea of the content:UPON THE SIGHT OF THE OTHER SHOREFire Burns Through DarknessUnseen UnveiledCome Bear To WitnessBelief Shaken To The CoreUpon The Sight Of The Other ShoreHeaven Speaks In RiddlesProphets Speak In TonguesThe Dead Speak In SilenceLove Smiles In SurrenderRed Eyes In DesperationA World We Cannot EscapeClutching Hate Like A WeaponBlood In Our HandsExpound The GospelBelief Shaken To The CoreUpon the Sight Of The Other ShoreMy interpretation is that "the other shore" is what buddhists call "nirvana" -- Enlightenment, Peace.  Catching a glimpse of it through experience brings the realization that an end to suffering is possible.I heard the more recent CLEARING THE PATH first, and now, seeking out more YOB music, I can say that ATMA is also superb!(verified purchase from a large brick-and-mortar bookstore)

I'm a big James McMurtry fan, but I can't get as enthused about this album as many others seem to be. The standout track is "How'm I Gonna Find You Now," which not surprisingly was released with an amusing video in advance of the album. It's an uptempo number with a rapid-fire vocal reminiscent of "Choctaw Bingo," and prominently features the banjo in addition to electric guitars.The lyrics throughout are outstanding, of course, more of the hardscrabble character-sketch vignettes we've come to expect.  But too many of the songs are in a slow, mournful mode (Copper Canteen, You Got to Me, Carlisle's Haul, South Dakota), and the streak of anger of great recent albums is missing.COMPLICATED GAME grows on me with repeated listening, but I don't think it's as good as his excellent run of electric albums from Saint Mary of the Woods (2002) through Live in Aught Three (2004) to Childish Things (2005) and Just Us Kids (2008).

I've always thought Mark Lanegan's voice is one of the best in rock, but I haven't kept up with his prolific post-Screaming Trees career.This is a great album I just finally discovered.  For the longest time there was a hole in my music collection for 2001 -- not for jazz or for contemporary classical, but for folk/rock -- zip, nada, nothing.  It was over a decade later that I finally discovered a few albums from that year that I had missed.  Now Lanegan's can join Chris Whitley's Rocket House as one of the best of that early-millennium interregnum.FIELD SONGS is a very strong set of songs, with fantastic, varied arrangements, all of course featuring Lanegan's great voice.  The two key musicians throughout are Mike Johnson, a frequent Lanegan collaborator, on guitars and keyboards, and Ben Shepherd, the Soundgarden bass player, on guitars.  While not entirely acoustic, this is folk and blues rock that doesn't get heavy or loud or rock out.I've been digging into Mark's back catalog based on his recent string of superb albums:  Blues Funeral (2012), Black Pudding (2013), and Phantom Radio (2014).  Don't miss them!Mark Lanegan is still making great music 14 years after this record came out.

I am belatedly catching up with this album as I track down more and more of Mark Lanegan's music.  His recent work (Blues Funeral, Black Pudding, Phantom Radio) is as good or better than anything he's ever done, and I began to wonder, what have I missed along the way?Some say he plays a secondary role here to Greg Dulli (Afghan Whigs), but it's Mark's contribution that keeps me interested throughout.  Lanegan authors two songs, Dulli authors three, and the other seven are co-authored.  This is the first music of Dulli's that I've heard, and while he combines with Lanegan to produce a compelling sound, I am not sufficiently impressed to seek out his other recordings.Mathias Schneeberger is great on guitar, and either or he or Mario Lalli sounds exactly like Richard Thompson in the solo on Lanegan's "Bete Noir."  I was sure it *was* Thompson until I checked the liner notes.  Schneeberger also produces, along with the Gutter Twins.The 12-page Sub Pop booklet includes several garish color photos, but no lyrics.Strongly recommended to all Mark Lanegan fans!

Thou is a sludge/doom metal band from Baton Rouge, Louisiana.  The band distinguishes itself from most of its peers by providing lyrics for the songs in the 8-page booklet, which would otherwise be impossible to decipher since they are sung in a hoarse, rasping scream.The band's vision is summarized in the credits/dedication:"This record is dedicated to the feral outlaws, avatars of Nature's undomesticated virtue, in eternal war with the wretched prison called Civilization."In the lyric to "In Defiance of the Sages" they say:"Destroy the past completely along with its abortive children: unauthentic present and rust-encrusted future.  Now, we will create ruins.  And after -- something new and unimagined."Primitivist anarchists, apparently, it's probably best not to think of what their daily life looks like -- I don't imagine they live off the land in the swamps of southern Louisiana, and they clearly use electric power from the grid for their concerts and recordings.  I respect their vision, while respectfully disagreeing about the wisdom of destroying civilization.The music would not be nearly as harsh as it is without the screamed vocals.  The huge wall of guitar, bass and drums slowly advances in simple chord structures, and much of it is quite warm and beautiful.  There are quiet passages toward the end, and female vocals that make me think of Wolves in the Throne Room, the Earth First!-inspired black metal band from Washington State.I picked this up on the recommendation of Brandon Stosuy, who runs the Show No Mercy metal reviews section of Pitchfork.  Stosuy picked HEATHEN as the best metal album of 2014.  While not quite that enthusiastic, I can appreciate Thou's powerful social and musical vision.

This is a great album from Dylan Carlson and company.Mark Lanegan sings on "There Is a Serpent Coming" and "Rooks Across the Gate," and Rabia Shabeen Qazi sings on "From the Zodiacal Light."  I'm a big Lanegan fan, so this makes "Primitive & Deadly" even better than it would be otherwise.  I'm not familiar with Qazi, but her vocals are excellent as well.  Both singers contribute their own lyrics.Earth is one of those bands that is hard to classify -- I suppose most would call this album doom metal, but it sounds more bluesy and less metallic than much in that category.  One of the music's most important characteristics is that it is VERY SLOW.  To me it sounds like a Western landscape.The cover art by Samantha Muljat looks very familiar to me -- could it be based on a photo of Hutch's Pool, up the trail from the end of Sabino Canyon outside Tucson?  It may be that the psychedelic scene is what triggers the Western association in my mind and ear.One of the best metal albums of 2014.

YOB's latest is on Neurot Recordings, the record label of Neurosis, the seminal doom metal band from Oakland.  This is perfect -- the two bands pursue a similar heavy and serious sound.YOB is:Mike Scheidt -- guitar and vocalsAaron Rieseberg -- bassTravis Foster -- drumsAcross four long tracks, YOB clears the path, focusing intention on ascending to enlightenment.  Assisting in this journey is the excellent artwork of Orion Landau.Scheidt's lyrics are weighty and thought-provoking, similar to the Neurosis lyrics of Steve Von Till and Scott Kelly.  His vocals alternative between a hoarse bellow and a clear clean tone, as well as a high tenor that sounds like a woman's voice.  He sometimes harmonizes with himself.  Scheidt's guitar lays down huge dark riffs, with a second guitar track over it in places, adding texture and complexity.This is the first YOB album I've heard -- I look forward to going back to their previous releases.Clearly this is one of the best metal albums of 2014.

Vindsval, the visionary mastermind of Blut Aus Nord, returns to his black metal roots with Memoria Vetusta III: Saturnian Poetry, planting the sound back on the Earth after forays into space on recent albums such as 777: Cosmosophy and the previous entry in this series, Memoria Vetusta II: Dialogue With the Stars (see my review).This is not raw, rough black metal though.  It is finely crafted with a huge, warm sound and majestic melodies conveyed by massed guitars.  The relentless drums drive the songs forward with powerful momentum, and the screaming black metal vocals are placed over the top, rather than submerged as on MVII: Dialogue.The cover art by Kristian Necrolord Wahlin is superb, a dark Tolkien-esque landscape.  The impeccable 12-page booklet includes lyrics, some in French, and some in English.  Included are poems by Baudelaire and Verlaine.Here is an English lyric:"By Her...By Me,I understand a being absolutely infinite,a substance consisting of an infinity of attributes,of which each one expresses an eternal and infinite essence.And from the One,substance of all things,emanates the Divine."One of the best metal albums of 2014, without a doubt!

I just discovered this Ohio band.  I've been listening to post-rock/post-metal for several years now, and based on this album it seems that the Trees are quite proficient and quite consistent -- they do what they do quite well.Their sound is earnest and majestic and tragic.  I don't find RED FOREST to be as powerful as the best albums by other similar bands -- Pelican's The Fire in Our Throats Will Beckon the Thaw or Russian Circles' Geneva (see my reviews of both) -- but it is certainly solid and worth hearing for anyone who enjoys instrumental post-rock/post-metal.One thing about the Trees and Pelican I find frustrating is that their cover art and song titles *and the name of this band!* very strongly hint at the theme of ecological destruction, catastrophic climate change in particular, without ever making clear that this is their intent.Wolves In the Throne Room and Agalloch, with vocals and lyrics, make clear their ecological message.  I hear one in this music as well, and I hope I am not just imagining it.  The interviews with ITTCT I've been able to find online shed no light on this question.(verified purchase from a large brick-and-mortar bookstore)

Several years back I was looking for a "Best of the Doors."  At that time the only set available was missing "Waiting for the Sun," one of the absolute best Doors songs, so I took a pass.I only now discovered this 2-disc set released in 2003 -- this is what I was looking for!I'm a Doors fan from way back, and for my purposes this LEGACY set comes very close to being the essential Doors collection.Disc One is an excellent selection from the first three albums -- THE DOORS (1967), STRANGE DAYS (1967), and WAITING FOR THE SUN (1968).Disc Two includes five cuts from L.A. WOMAN (1971) which are all great and the one track I want to hear from MORRISON HOTEL (1970), which is "Waiting for the Sun." (I've never understood why the song isn't on the album of the same name!)Unfortunately it does not include the one track I would want to hear from THE SOFT PARADE (1969), which is the title track.  But  it includes a vicious live recording of "Gloria."The long spoken word "Celebration of the Lizard" is for collectors only.I'm only docking LEGACY one star since it's only missing one essential track from across all six studio albums.

Whatever you think of Schnittke's symphonies, you cannot say that he just did the same thing over and over (as many have said, for instance, about Bruckner).  His First (1974) is a comedic, polystylistic, anarchic happening that openly mocks the solemnity of the classical tradition.  His Second  (1980) is ostensibly a religious choral symphony, though I doubt its appeal to the devout (see my review).  And the Third (1981), which he began years before, is his German Symphony, incorporating elements from across the entire span of German composers beginning with Bach.The Third is in four movements, but not the standard symphonic structure.  The opening (11'54) is a large, slowly building introduction that evokes the Rhine-music from the opening of Wagner's Ring (Das Rheingold).  Complete with waves, it builds to a great Wagnerian brass fanfare at the 3 1/2 minute mark.  After subsiding back to waves, there is another fanfare crescendo at the 7-minute mark, followed by an odd little tuba waltz, and then a passage of woozy folk melody with bells, leading to a final great fanfare at 10 1/2 minutes, and then a fade.  The entire span can be thought of as the emergence of the German Geist, a concept from the great German idealist philosopher Hegel.The Allegro (12'30) is the movement most commented on, "developed from the monograms of more than thirty German composers," according to the composer, from Bach to Stockhausen.  It is a lively, vivacious piece, quite out of character for Schnittke, though it ends on a tragic note.  It is Bach whose stamp is felt most strongly here, quoted at the beginning and again at the end.  Some might amuse themselves with trying to identify composers, but the music is strong without engaging in the exercise.The Allegretto (7'15) is a powerful piece of writing, beginning with a passage that sounds like the music of Giants from Wagner's Ring, and continuing through stormy Wagnerian and Beethovenian passages.  Also uncharacteristic of Schnittke in its forthright muscular energy, this is a  powerful commentary on the dark side of the German experience.  I wish it was longer.Finally, the closing Adagio (16'55) is clearly out of place in the standard symphonic form.  But Schnittke's vision of and commentary on all things German is a tragic one, and so the vast Mahlerian adagio has to come last, like Mahler's 9th Symphony and Bruckner's unfinished 9th.I do believe the proportions are not quite right, and that is the main reason I give Schnittke's Third Symphony four stars instead of five.  The outer movements are too long, especially the Adagio, in comparison to the very strong, compact inner movements.I waited for several years for Chandos to release a Valery Polyansky recording of this symphony with his Russian State Symphony Orchestra, as there seemed to be a complete cycle in progress.  But none have been forthcoming since the excellent Sixth Symphony in 2004 (see my review), so I finally picked up this recording by Erik Klas and the Stockholm Philharmonic from the Swedish BIS label.  The musicianship cannot be faulted in the slightest -- only the cover art!

I've picked up the occasional Sun Ra disc over many years, and I have not found them all to be of the highest quality.  Ra was prolific, and he documented himself when no one else would on his El Saturn Records!This 2-disc set, though, is outstanding, compiled by alto saxophonist Marshall Allen, who played with Sun Ra for decades, and has led the band since the passing of Ra -- 20 tracks selected with care from the vast discography, originally recorded from 1957-1978.The 16-page booklet includes meticulous information on each track -- who plays on it, when it was recorded, where it originally appeared.  The interview with Marshall Allen gives some good insight into Ra and the band.  There are five great black-and-white photos by Val Wilmer, including one of the band with singer/dancer June Tyson in whirling motion.When I saw Sun Ra and the band live at the Chicago Jazz Festival in the Eighties they had a fairly conventional big band jazz sound, just strange around the edges, with Ra at the keyboards, June Tyson dancing, and the "Space Is the Place" chant.  Ra had gone back to his roots as arranger for the big band leader Fletcher Henderson.  I recall that they played very precisely, like a hive mind -- insect big band jazz!Most of the music here "In the Orbit of Ra" is more unconventional, with lots of grooving rhythms and Pan-African exotica.  There is one track ("Reflects Motion Part 2") that features a smoking solo by tenor saxophonist John Gilmore, but for the most part it's more atmospheric than virtuosic.This is certainly a good way to hear Sun Ra, selected by the man who keeps the Arkestra going in the 21st century!

Listening to PHANTOM RADIO back to back with Blues Funeral, which I consider to be the best pop/rock album of 2012, it doesn't sound quite as good.  But in its own right it's one of the best albums of 2014, and after multiple listens it grows on me and I find its melodies in my head for hours.The first four songs are really strong:  Harvest Home, Judgement Time, Floor of the Ocean, and The Killing Season.  The rest of the album moves in a lighter pop direction by comparison until the powerful closing track: Death Trip to Tulsa.  At first I was not fully convinced by Seventh Day, I Am the Wolf, Torn Red Heart, or The Wild People.  Seventh Day features a "la, la, la" chorus which was initially jarring.  The Wild People struck me as lightweight (Lanegan is a dark bohemian -- isn't he "wild"? -- why does he need to go hang out with wild people somewhere else?)  Torn Red Heart, with a Jesus & Mary Chain sound, is a love song ("You don't love me...") that seemed out of character.But on repeated listening, PHANTOM RADIO sounds better and better.  Torn Red Heart and The Wild People have strong melodies that burn into the subconscious and bubble back up later.  The lyric to I Am the Wolf can sound cliched and over-the-top, but with Alain Johannes's guitar and Lanegan's voice carrying you along, it overcomes that reaction.As with BLUES FUNERAL, Lanegan's secret weapon is Alain Johannes on guitars, bass, keyboards, and production.  Jack Irons is the drummer.  As on that previous MLB album there are lots of Eighties retro sounds, mainly produced by synthesizer keyboards, but these are just the raw materials for something new.Lanegan is on a roll, continuing to make some of the best pop/rock music of recent years.(Don't overlook Black Pudding (2013) with Duke Garwood either!)

Barry Guy, bassist, bandleader, and composer extraordinaire, has been extensively documented by the Intakt Records label based in Switzerland.  This superb compilation is a Guy sampler across recordings on the Intakt label as well as Maya Recordings, the label of Guy and his wife, Maya Homburger, which is distributed by Intakt.  The oldest recording goes back to 1972, and the most recent is from 2006.As Guy explains in the liner notes:  "I have tried through the documented albums to create a scenario that suggests a compositional approach to the structuring of the musical fragments.  Through this selection of pieces I hope that the listener is tempted to search out these and other albums on Intakt Records and Maya Recordings where the full picture can be heard."He succeeds wonderfully in creating a compelling album from diverse sources.  By the time I discovered Barry Guy's music, his London Jazz Composers Orchestra had ceased to exist.  Intakt reissued the early LJCO albums, originally recorded for other labels, and issued several new ones through 1998.  But I could never figure which of the nine albums to hear first, and so I still hadn't heard any of them until now.Included here are the following LJCO extracts:Ode, Part 1 (9'04) from the album Ode (1972)Harmos (7'16) from the album Harmos (1989)Sleeping Furiously, Part 3 (5'15) from the album Three Pieces for Orchestra (1995)Double Trouble (6'27) from the album Double Trouble (1989)Featured are superb improvisers playing Guy's compositions, including Evan Parker, Paul Rutherford, Marilyn Crispell, Paul Dunmall, Barre Phillips, and many others.  Guy's compositions include powerful, melodic themes, which might surprise those who have heard only his playing with the free improv Parker/Guy/Lytton trio.  These excerpts make a strong case for the music of the LJCO, and there is plenty more -- nine discs worth.Guy includes three solo bass pieces from two albums:  Fizzles (1993), and Symmetries (2002).  The Parker/Guy/Lytton trio is represented with "Agreement" from the Maya album Imaginary Values (1993).  A Guy/Parker duet is taken from the Birds and Blades album (2001).Two other trios are included:  the Spanish piano trio of Agusti Fernandez, Ramon Lopez, and Guy from the album Aurora (2006), and the trio of Guy, his wife Maya Homburger on baroque violin, and Pierre Favre on percussion from the album Dakryon (2004).Finally, there is an excerpt from the first Barry Guy New Orchestra album Inscape-Tableaux (2000), a 10-member ensemble that replaced the LJCO, which became increasingly difficult to convene due to its size.  Since then the BGNO has released two more albums, and they are all excellent.I only own three of the many albums represented here in PORTRAIT, and so for me this is a great way to hear more of Barry Guy's music in a form compiled by Guy himself.  The great Guy/Crispell/Lytton trio is sadly not included, but I have all three of their albums, so it is others who will miss out, not me!  (I consider their best to be Ithaca (2004).)*** *** ***The package for this collection goes beyond what we come to expect.  The CD insert contains all the details on the recording and musicians for each track.  In addition there is an 88-page color booklet in English and German with essays and photos, including the album covers of all Guy's recordings for both the Intakt and Maya labels.BARRY GUY: PORTRAIT is essential for any fan of Barry Guy that doesn't already have all the recordings!

This 80-minute disc presents eight duo and trio improvisations from Free Zone Appleby 2004, presented as part of the annual Appleby Jazz Festival.  The recordings are from Ancient Space in St. Michael's Church in Appleby, England on July 25, 2004.The musicians are:Barry Guy -- bassEvan Parker -- soprano saxophonePaul Lytton -- percussionPhilipp Wachsmann -- violin, electronicsJoel Ryan -- live processingThe shifting line-up of players is organized with mathematical precision to result in a fascinating diversity of textures.  Four duos of acoustic players, each paired with Ryan's computer processing (Wachsmann, then Guy, then Lytton, then Parker) alternate with trios of the other three acoustic players without Ryan.The overall pattern of continuities and contrasts is amazing!Parker plays soprano exclusively, and his bright, darting sound is at far remove from the jazz tradition.  Lytton likewise is a marvel of diverse scrapings and knockings, none of which resemble a standard jazz drumkit.  The two string players provide a wealth of sounds, high and low, that are more or less recognizable as emanating from their standard instruments.The Parker/Guy/Lytton trio sounds great here, as do the trios with Wachsmann replacing Guy and Wachsmann replacing Parker.  The Parker/Guy/Wachsmann trio I find to be a special treat, as it can be contrasted with the Iskra 1903 trio of Paul Rutherford/Guy/Wachsmann.I am very happy to have caught up with this Psi disc nine years later!I have it filed under Evan Parker -- EP's duo with Ryan is 18 minutes long, the longest piece, and the electroacoustic dimension created by Joel Ryan can be seen as an extension of the Evan Parker Electroacoustic Ensemble -- but it is truly egalitarian, cooperative music that represents an ideal of human interaction.(verified purchase from Squidco)

TRANSIENT is the latest album from Neill Jameson and Krieg, and it is a powerful statement from a veteran practioner of U.S. black metal -- Jameson (aka Imperial) has been at it since the mid-Nineties, long before most listening to it today knew it existed.The current line-up is Jameson on vocals and acoustic guitar, A. Poole and D. Zdanavage on guitar, D. Sykes on bass, and J. Dost on drums.  The sound is immediately recognizable as black metal, but without the tremolo guitar one often hears.  This is a more bass-heavy assault, and it is warmer than the icy blasts you may have heard elsewhere.  There are significant doom elements, as well as electronic segments and psychedelic aspects.Thurston Moore and Dwid Hellion trade off with spoken word vocals on "Home," (the only lyric included with the disc), and while this provides welcome contrast, I don't consider it to be the best moment of the album overall.  Jameson's rasping, roaring vocals can't be understood, but that's fine -- they serve as another instrument, and it's the feeling that matters.  There are strong melodic passages, especially in "Ruin Our Lives," and this adds to the power of the 11-track album.Every review I've read speaks of its sense of bleakness, but that's not the impression I get at all.  For me it's much like Neurosis -- an implacable sense of stoic resolve and perseverence in the face of world that is very far from being a cheerful utopia.  (Krieg means war in German.)In short, TRANSIENT is an excellent metal album for 2014.

This Yep Roc set was compiled by John Doe himself (given name: John Nommensen Duchac), 21 tracks from his 8 solo albums since 1990.  It sounds fantastic, and certainly serves as great introduction to a superb body of music.  It is not necessary for a hard-core fan who already has all of those albums, but for the rest of us?  Awesome.Here are the tracks and the albums they're from, numbered by their sequence here:Meet John Doe (1990)5) Take #52 (unreleased version), 19) Dying to Get HomeKissingsohard (1995)7) Safety, 8) Love Knows, 20) Tragedy By DefinitionFor the Rest of Us (1998) reissued as For the Best of Us (2006)2) A Step Outside,Freedom Is... (2000)1) Telephone By the Bed, 4) Catch Me, 18) Beat-Up World, 21) SueltameDim Stars, Bright Sky (2002)11) Forever For You, 12) This Far, 14) 7 Holes, 16) FarawayForever Hasn't Happened Yet (2005)6) Hwy 5, 13) Twin Brother, 15) Worried BrowA Year In the Wilderness (2007)3) The Golden State, 17) Grain of SaltKeeper (2010)9) Never Enough*10) Poor Girl (solo acoustic version of the X song)I have five of the eight albums, and my recommendation for his best is Freedom Is... (2000).  There are 8 songs here from the three albums I don't have (Dim Stars, Forever Hasn't Happened Yet, and Keeper), and they sound excellent in this context -- there isn't a bad track!Doe has a great voice, he's a great songwriter, he always assembles a great band, and he is often joined by great female singers -- in X it was Exene Cervenka, and here it might be Kathleen Edwards, Neko Case, Jill Sobule, or Aimee Mann.Doe's sensibility combines romantic yearning and punk anger.  He has long been one of my favorites -- seeing him live in Salt Lake City in 2000 was awesome! -- and I hope this album serves to make his music known to a wider audience that doesn't realize what it's missing!*** *** ***The package is excellent, a vinyl LP-style cardboard fold-out with no jewel case.  The 24-page booklet includes all the lyrics and some nice photos.A career retrospective "this far" -- I look forward to more great music from John Doe, and I'm glad to know he's already in the process of making his next album!

When did Elliott Sharp, the avant-garde guitarist, start playing the saxophone?While not a virtuoso, at least as far as this album reveals, Sharp holds his own quite well in the context of a quintet playing 11 of his compositions.  He plays tenor and soprano sax and bass clarinet, with Nate Wooley of the U.K. on trumpet, the young Terry L. Green on trombone, Brad Jones on bass, and Ches Smith on drums.It has been noted that this is the most jazz-oriented music of E#'s long career.  It is not mainstream jazz, that's for sure, but some of it falls on the free jazz side of the free jazz/free improv divide in avant-garde improvised music.  Nate Wooley has years of experience playing with Eddie Prevost (AMM) and other leading British free improv musicians, and there are free improv passages that approach the speed and density of Parker/Guy/Lytton.But one of the chief characteristics of this set is the use of smeared horns, both trumpet and trombone, bringing to mind Louie Armstrong and Dixieland jazz as refracted through the post-free jazz sounds of Lester Bowie (Art Ensemble of Chicago) and Roswell Rudd.  The rhythm section is powerfully propulsive in places.  These elements represent the African-American free jazz influence.Overall, this is insouciant music with a quick, humorous sensibility.  "Blues for Butch," written I assume for the late Butch Morris, the NYC trumpeter and inventor of "conduction," is indeed a blues number, the closest Sharp comes here to the sound of his Terraplane project.  The last piece, "Cherenkov Light," is process music that unfolds slowly and eerily, sounding much like AMM.This is an excellent hour-long album that incorporates its free jazz and free improv influences into a compelling synthesis!(verified purchase from Squidco)

Marty Ehrlich is an alto saxophonist, a composer, a bandleader, and a professor of music at Hampshire College.  He worked closely with Julius Hemphill for many years, and carries on in Hemphill's tradition while developing his own body of music.  (See Julius Hemphill: The Complete Remastered Recordings for a great collection of Hemphill's music, in addition to his many recordings with the World Saxophone Quartet.)This is the second recording of Erlich's Rites Quartet, both on the Clean Feed Label.  (Unfortunately the first, Things Have Got to Change, released in 2009, is currently unavailable on CD and so I haven't heard it.)  Recorded in 2011, this is a great album with seven Ehrlich compositions and superb playing by:Marty Ehrlich -- alto and soprano sax, fluteJames Zollar -- trumpetHank Roberts -- celloMichael Sarin -- drumsThis is a variation on one of my favorite jazz ensembles -- a sax/trumpet/bass/drums quartet.  The twist here is the substitution of cello for bass, which follows Hemphill going back to the great Dogon A.D. (1972) album with Abdul Wadud on cello.  While informed by free jazz, this is not avant-garde music.  There is a mixture of up-tempo and slow songs, with strong rhythm and melody, rooted in the blues -- just solid, mainstream jazz.The title track, "Frog Leg Logic," gets things off to a hopping start with its catchy rhythm.  "Ballade" is tricky, because it shifts part way from a beautiful, sad ballad to a funky blues.  "You Can Beat the Slanted Cards" is another up-tempo toe-tapper with a tricky rhythm.  The lovely "Solace" features Ehrlich on flute.  The closing number, "The Gravedigger's Respite," is another up-tempo piece.Despite the fact that Roberts and Sarin are new to the group (replacing Erik Friedlander and Pheeroan Aklaff from the first album), the quartet sounds like it has been playing together for years.  Ehrlich and Zollar are magnificent throughout.The Clean Feed disc comes in a cardboard foldout like a miniature vinyl LP, with a plastic insert for the disc.  I realize this is relevant to fewer and fewer people as MP3s and streaming replaces the CD, but I remain old school for now.(verified purchase from Squidco)

Trio 3 first formed in the early Nineties (their Live in Willisau album, recorded in 1992, was my pick for best jazz album of the year for 1998), bringing together as equals and co-leaders Oliver Lake on alto sax, best known for his long tenure with the World Saxophone Quartet, Reggie Workman on bass, best known for playing with Coltrane on the 1961 Live At The Village Vanguard sessions, and Andrew Cyrille on drums, best known for being (at least in my opinion) Cecil Taylor's best drummer.This is the fourth and latest Trio 3 album on the Swiss Intakt label to feature a guest pianist (following recordings with IrÃ¨ne Schweizer, Geri Allen and Jason Moran).  This time it's the incredible Vijay Iyer, who is known for his speed, drive, and rhythmic complexity, but this is not a Vijay Iyer album, and here he blends magnificently with his elders.  (Workman was born in 1937, Cyrille in 1939, and Lake in 1942.  Iyer was born in 1971!)The pianist brings two compositions -- the opening "The Prowl," which opens with a funky bass line, and the moving "Suite for Trayvon (and Thousands More)" in three parts, a highlight of the album.  Workman contributes "Synapse II" and "Willow Song," a lovely ballad that followers of the bassist may have heard before.  Two compositions are by Lake -- "Shave," and the title cut, "Wiring."  The album closes with the latest recording of Cyrille's "Tribute to Bu," which he wrote for Art Blakey, the great drummer and bandleader.The great Amiri Baraka wrote the liner notes.  He died between the August 2013 recording and the album's release in 2014, and he will be missed.  The 12-page Intakt booklet also includes color photos of the musicians.  The cover art is by Oliver Lake.These master musicians have at their disposal the entire history of jazz.  This is post-bop, broadly speaking, and there are avant elements that some traditional jazz listeners might find challenging.  But this is not really avant-garde music -- it is solidly in the African-American tradition, with strong melody and swinging rhythm, up-tempo numbers and slower ones, including ballads.  It moves outside, but it comes back in!I haven't heard the other "Trio 3 + guest pianist" albums, so I can't compare, but in its own right this is an excellent album, sure to be one of the best of 2014!

This solo electro-acoustic concert was recorded at Cafe Teufelhart in Dachau, Germany on May 16, 2007.  Elliott Sharp (E#), avant-garde guitarist, composer, and electronics wizard, was 56 at the time.  For over 70 minutes, Sharp plays with incredible technical virtuosity.The music is frenetic, with great forward drive.  Classical and blues styles are most prominent in Sharp's playing.  "Dachau 1" (18'28) has Bach-like passages and is on amplified acoustic guitar alone.  My one criticism is that there are times when a figure is obsessively repeated before finally moving on.For "Dachau 2" (22'35) and "Dachau 3" (25'11) Sharp makes use of his laptop to electronically modify his own guitar, adding loops and other effects.  Exactly how he does this I'm not sure -- I'd love to see a performance!  "Dachau Encore" (7'28) is all blues, played with slide guitar, which E# has been pursuing for many years with his Terraplane project.He explains that "[o]ne might call the music a live remix of my various solo programs for electro-acoustic guitar.  Some of the themes are well-documented on the solo CDs 'Velocity of Hue' and 'Quadrature' -- others, unnamed, appear suddenly and then disappear after revealing their nature."As anyone would expect who is even slightly familiar with Sharp, this is cerebral, challenging music -- a far cry from Leo Kottke: 6 & 12 String Guitar!  Sharp takes us on a journey -- strap yourself in, because he takes us to places we've never been before, in wonder the whole way at the unexpected twists and turns.*** *** ***It is not entirely clear what the listener is to make of the album's title, or the choice of this particular concert to release as opposed to the others on the tour.  On the one hand it is a Concert IN Dachau, not a Concert ABOUT Dachau.  There are no vocals, no lyrics, and no obviously tragic aspects to the music.  On the other hand, the cover is forbidding, though totally abstract, and Sharp does address the location in the liner notes:"I was quite surprised when I found out from Steffen about the booking in Dachau as this is one of those place-names that have become synonymous with human atrocity...  As the Jewish son of a Holocaust survivor, performing in Dachau was especially resonant."So it seems that the terrible history was on Sharp's mind, and perhaps it should be on ours as well as we listen and ponder.He adds, and I feel compelled to add as well so as not to alter his meaning through omission:  "Despite the weight of the Holocaust, I'm angered in the way that contemporary Jewry acts as if they own all to themselves all of the suffering of WW2, all of the extermination, all of the death, and that it gives them license to do any brutality to the Palestinians who just happened to be living [some for thousands of years] in "their" Promised Land."He goes on to point out that there were other groups targeted by Hitler, and many other genocides in places including the U.S.S.R., China, Cambodia, Rwanda, and Iraq (the victims of the U.S. invasion and war).So perhaps this should *all* be on our minds as we listen.But if what you're looking for is music that expresses the unfathomable tragedy of war and genocide, I would recommend Shostakovich's  Symphony No. 8 instead.

The indefatigable Fred Anderson (1929-2010) was a fixture of the free jazz scene in Chicago for decades.  While not technically a founder, he was there very early in the activities of the AACM (Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians), founded in 1965 by Muhal Richard Abrams and others.  I lived in Chicago for the decade of the 1980s, and I used to hear Fred, usually with a trio, at least once a year at the annual Underground Fest, the afterfest of the Chicago Jazz Festival in August.  Fred's performance was invariably a highlight -- he was our very own Coltrane!His unique stance was leaning over with the top of his head pointed straight at the audience as he expounded seemingly endlessly and always totally compellingly on the tenor.  A couple of the best recordings of Fred are from 1979 The Missing Link and 1980 The Milwaukee Tapes, and while not perhaps in his prime at 50, he had more energy and his musical vision was stronger then than this and his other late recordings.  Fred's sound was his own, with a dark tragic tone, and his style was solidly rooted in the bebop of Charlie Parker, with elements of Gene Ammons and Sonny Rollins, but extended into the post-Ornette land of the free.What we have here is a 2-disc live recording at Johnston State College in Vermont on December 12, 2004.  Fred is joined by the top-notch rhythm section of Hamid Drake on drums, whose percussion career started playing with Fred from a young age, and William Parker, NYC bassist extraordinaire.  Compared to those Eighties performances I saw/heard in Chicago, this music is more varied, and less austere and serious.  Parker and Drake engage in all sorts of moves, incorporating funk and R&B grooves, which sometimes draws Fred into a more light-hearted style.The first disc is one uninterrupted 44-minute performance.  Disc Two is in three parts -- a 37-minute performance, followed by two shorter pieces of 13 and 14 minutes respectively.  On track 2, Parker plays the south Indian wind instrument called the nagaswaram rather than bass.  I am completely unimpressed by this, and so I prefer to skip this track.  However, what remains is easy to recommend with five stars!Fred Anderson was better documented in the last decade of his life than he had ever been, and this 2005 Eremite release was one of many albums issued in that period.  Hence I missed it at the time and am only now hearing it nine years later.Better late than never -- Fred Anderson is one of my favorite saxophonists, and this is a great late performance!

It looks like this will stand as Ornette Coleman's last music, barring posthumous releases.  He was 75 when it was recorded, live in Germany, in 2005.Most of the compositions are either taken from previous albums or are slightly modified versions of pieces from previous albums.  The new pieces, including the opening "Jordan," sound terrific.  Ornette's quartet is his son Denardo on drums and two basses -- Greg Cohen, well-known for his work with John Zorn, and Tony Falanga, whose bowed playing sounds like a different instrument from Cohen's, adding textural variety as well as another lead voice at times, bringing to mind the original quartet with Don Cherry on trumpet.Other than the unique two-bass instrumentation, there is really nothing new here for Ornette.  His playing will sound very familiar to anyone who has been following him for years as I have.  He still has that great, piercing cry on the alto sax, and a unique style of trumpet-playing as well.  What makes SOUND GRAMMAR better than any of his recordings since SONG X of 1985 (see my review) is the high energy level.  He and the quartet clearly rose to the occasion that night in Ludwigshafen!*** *** ***Ornette was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Music for this album, and we have the Pulitzer committee to thank for bending the rules.  As it turns out, the prize is awarded for new compositions.  The compositions on SOUND GRAMMAR were 1) not new, and 2) not even submitted to the committee!  Clearly the committee wanted to give Ornette the award -- they went out, bought the album, and gave him the award rather than any of the dozens of submissions.  As I see it, this is overdue just recognition for an award Ornette deserved for his pioneering music of 1959-1962, his Atlantic recordings.And while SOUND GRAMMAR is not on the same level as those great recordings, it is excellent and well worth hearing.I will miss Ornette -- he was a gentle, beautiful soul who was tenacious and uncompromising in his unique artistic vision.

Marc Ribot is known for two things -- his superb role as a hired guitarist on all sorts of recordings (such as Tom Waits: Rain Dogs and T Bone Burnett: The Criminal Under My Own Hat), and his role as an avant-garde guitarist and composer, a key player in the Downtown NYC scene for decades.Here we hear Ribot in an entirely different context -- solo guitar music, mainly acoustic, composed for films.  As Ribot explains in the liner notes:"This is an album of film music: some were pieces originally composed for movie scores, others for films I turned down but found myself writing for anyway, still others for projects that never existed outside of my head.  All have been transcribed/re-imagined as solo guitar pieces... ...The title and some of the compositions were also inspired by my experience preparing for a live accompaniment of the Charlie Chaplin film "The Kid" at Merkin Hall in January 2010 as part of the NY Guitar Festival.""Natalia" and "Requiem for a Revolution" were composed for "The General," a documentary film directed by Natalia Almada.  "Delancey Waltz," "Fat Man Blues," and "Bateau" were originally composed for the motion picture "Drunk Boat," produced by JD Foster.  "Variation 1," "Flicker," "Requiem for a Revolution," "Postcard from N.Y.," and "Sous le ciel de Paris" feature textured electronic soundscapes by Keefus Ciancia.While there is variety from track to track -- "Natalia" for instance is electric and "Fat Man Blues" is humorous -- overall, the mood is melancholy.  It is more folk than jazz, with evocative melodies that seem to transport the listener back in time to remembered scenes, some urban, some bucolic.This is warm, human music that communicates through feeling rather than through dazzling technique.SILENT MOVIES presents a little-known side of Marc Ribot's sensibility, and we are the better for it.

This is a recording from June 2002 in Chicago, a ballads session from Peter Brotzmann (alto & tenor sax), Joe McPhee (tenor sax, pocket cornet, & trumpet), Kent Kessler (double bass), and Michael Zerang (drums & percussion).  Ballads?  Yes, that was the concept informing this excellent meeting.  According to the liner notes, Brotzmann and McPhee first met in 1977, didn't play together until 20 years later in the Peter Brotzmann Chicago Tentet, which also included Kessler and Zerang.This is an excellent album, certainly for anyone who enjoys the music of either Brotz or McPhee.  It is rooted in the blues, in ballads expressing a deep mournfulness, but it is by no means traditional sounding.  It does lean more toward American free jazz than most European free improvisation.  It is more melodic and conventionally structured than many Brotzmann recordings, based on themes rather than being totally free.Six of the eleven pieces are by McPhee (Stone Poems No. 1 and 2, Something There Is That Doesn't Love, Alto Lightning in A Violin Sky, In Anticipation of the Next, and Pieces of Red, Green and Blue), three are by Brotzmann (Master of a Small House, From Now Till Doomsday, and Do You Still Love Me/Did I Ever?), one is by Zerang (Cymbalism) and one is traditional, brought to the session by Brotzmann (Blessed Assurance).The Swiss Hat Hut label was founded in the Seventies to document Joe McPhee's music, so in that sense this can be considered more a McPhee album than a Brotzmann album -- it's Brotz's only recording for the label as far as I know.In short, an excellent and unique session, one of the best of 2004, well worth checking out for any devotees of avant jazz/improv!(verified purchase from Cadence Magazine)

This is a recording of Peter Brotzmann's Chicago Tentet from early on, May 1999, at the Festival de Musique de Actuelle in Victoriaville, Quebec.  It was mastered and released the following year, 2000.  The group formed initially in 1997, and its first release was in 1998.  That 3-disc set won the Cadence Magazine readers' poll for Best Album of 1998.This is an incredible 37 minute performance with the line-up of:Peter Brotzmann, Mats Gustafsson, Ken Vandermark -- saxophones & reedsJeb Bishop -- tromboneToshinori Kondo -- trumpet, electronicsFred Lomborg-Holm -- cello, violinWilliam Parker, Kent Kessler -- bassHamid Drake, Michael Zerang -- drumsThere is great variety and contrast as the piece progresses, with plenty of room for the musicians to solo as well as play as part of the great roar of the full ensemble.Back on those early days, the Tentet improvised based on compositions like "Stone/Water," compositions that were basic structures, not fully notated scores.  Starting in 2006 or so the use of compositions was dropped entirely, and since then performances have been 100% improvised.If you have found this review, I'm pretty sure you already know you enjoy this type of music.  If so, rest assured that this is a great live performance!  I have yet to hear a bad Brotzmann Tentet recording, but this one is right up there among the best, a concentrated expression of everything that makes it so exhilarating!(verified purchase from the Jazz Loft)

This was the first recording by the trio of Peter Brotzmann, reeds; Peeter Uuskyla, drums; and Peter Friis Nielsen, electric bass.  Drummer Uuskyla produced the original 1999 Slask release, and this 2010 Jazzwerkstatt reissue is very welcome.  The three Peters -- Brotz of Germany, Uuskyla of Sweden, and Friis Nielsen of Denmark -- were recorded live at Bohus Sound Recording in Sweden.The music is entirely improvised.  As Uuskyla says in the liner notes:  "...[T]his music is very abstract.  No notes, no pre-arrangements or even pre-prepared structures, no nothing.  Just three music instruments..."  (The quote I've used as my review title is taken from Uuskyla's liner notes.)  This 2010 reissue adds a bonus track recorded live in Sweden in 2001 following 9/11/01, called "Nine-Eleven-Blues."This is a great set!  The first album I heard by this trio was Medicina (2004).  It features greater variety as the pieces are all compositions by the three musicians, and I think it is even better than NOISE OF WINGS.  But if you enjoy Brotz's energy music, this is fantastic.  No delicacy, little melody, just strong, intense expression.  Brotzmann plays tenor on five tracks, and clarinet and tarogato on two.The metaphorical theme for this album and this group is birds in flight, the "noise of wings."  These are no doves, or songbirds, but rather huge, enraged, prehistoric birds that feel the onset of climate change, and are not going quietly into the night of extinction!Brotz has many projects, many of them documented on Long Story Short (2013), and as far as I know this trio has not been recorded again since 2004, but it deserves to be!(verified purchase from Dussmann in Berlin)

The Free Jazz Quartet is a rather obscure British band that only recorded one album, Premonitions, in 1989.  The FJQ is Paul Rutherford on trombone, Harrison Smith on tenor sax, soprano sax, and bass clarinet, Tony Moore on cello, and Eddie Prevost on drums.  This 1992 live recording from Bristol, only retrieved from the vault and released in 2010, doubles their discography!  Both albums, both live concert recordings, are on the Matchless label run by Eddie Prevost, best-known from the seminal free improv ensemble AMM."Memories for the Future" is gentler than "Premonitions," which had a sense of urgency running through it captured by titles like "Red Flags," "Gathering Clouds," and "Tocsin."  Rutherford was an intransigent old-school communist, and the marxist element was apparent as well in the photo of the four band members assembled like a propaganda-style picture of Marx, Engels, Lenin, and Mao.  Here the militancy is gone, and what remains is the vision and embodiment of egalitarianism.There is no indication that the eight pieces are compositions.  All seem to be totally free improvisations, one ("Octavian Law") a solo by Prevost.  There is no "front line" and "rhythm section" -- all four players are lead players, taking turns initiating new turns and segments.  Rutherford and Smith lead off on "A Fertile Valley" with slow intertwining lines and are eventually joined by Moore and Prevost.
