4.5/5Dark Embrace is actually the 4th book in the Dark Paradise series by Angie Sandro. I actually had no idea because the cover looks totally different than the previous three covers (which I like a lot better than this one) and the first three books features a character named Mala. All of them featured Mala to my knowledge and Dark Embrace features her cousin Dena. I have not read the first three books in this series, and I was fine reading this one. There were a few moments where I wish I had a little more back story, but Dark Embrace can stand on itsâ€™ own. It felt more like a companion series rather than a continuation to the Dark Paradise series. But either way, I absolutely loved Dark Embrace!Dena is a great character. She is stubborn as a mule, but she is caring, compassionate and determined. And I appreciated how skeptical and distrustful she was of people. because holy cow, everyone in this book should not be trusted. Not even her. It is really hard for me to describe Dark Embrace, other than to say it is one fantastic paranormal mystery of a ride. You have this mysterious dark shadow that Dena seems to be the only one to see. And he seems to be kind of obsessed with her. And then you have all the people that seem to die around her. And then you have all the people trying to kill her. And it just keeps building. You learn one thing and three more mysteries and questions pop up.Angie Sandro did a really fabulous job telling Denaâ€™s story. I loved how everything was presented and how all the events unfolded. I so badly wanted something specific to happen in this book and it did. And when it did, I was whooping for joy. I want to see more Dena stories. I hope this is not the end for her. Now that she knows what is going on, I want her to get her romance on. Even though there was plenty of romantic action in this book, which I absolutely loved, I hope that Dena takes a little more time in the next book to enjoy her relationship.Bottom line? If you are a fan of mysteries and paranormal romances, Dark Embrace is a book that you cannot miss out on.*Disclaimer- I got a copy of this book for free in exchange for my honest review. I was not compensated for my thoughts.

4.5/5Lust is the second novel in the Allure Chronicles, a new adult paranormal romance series. Lust picks up right after Lure left off, with Daisy and Owen having just found each other and the bomb of what Daisy having allure essence in her really means. It was one doozy of an ending, but then again the end of Lust was also pretty gut wrenching. Alyssa why do you do this to me?? Ugh I just love her books so much. And the Allure Chronicles has to be one of my favorite series of hers.I love all of the characters, not only just Daisy and Owen, but Violet and Roland have special places in my heart as well. I was kind of hoping that we would see more of Roland in this book. Not because I dislike Owen. I really love him, I am just also intrigued by Owen and his connection with Daisy. Luckily, I have a feeling that I will be seeing a lot more of him in the next book. Wink wink.Lust takes all of the characters on a world-wind high speed journey to try and fix what is happening to Daisy. I wonâ€™t go into too much more detail about what exactly is happening because I love all the Allure history and characteristics Alyssa Rose Ivy explains in Lust. Things that I so want them to fix or find a workaround from because I love Daisy and Owens connection. I think there is something so pure and innocent about their feelings and the way they treat one another. I know that seems strange given everything you know about the series- the titles, the covers and the series name, but it is true! haha, they are just too cute together.Another exciting moment in Lust for me, was when mention of Energo was made! Alyssa, you master you. (for those of you new to Alyssaâ€™s books, Energo is a land in another two of her series- the Forged Chronicles and the Afterglow Trilogy.) All of her series and worlds are coming together and linking up! I absolutely love it. I want to see some kind of chart or map made of all of Alyssaâ€™s series lands and the creatures that live there. Someone please make that!Fans of New Adult paranormal romance need to read the Allure Chronicles. And it is great series to start with if you are new to Alyssaâ€™s works because it touches so many of her other series. Start with this one and then move off to any of the numerous other series that overlap. Comment below if you want suggestions for reading order, or more information about the other series.*disclaimer- I got a copy of this book for free in exchange for my honest review. I was not compensated for my thoughts.

3.5/5Undercover Empath: Kindred Demon is the first book in the New Adult paranormal series, Undercover Empath. I really like how well the covers of the series go together. They are almost identical but in different colors. And they are each really pretty. It follows detective Rose Hansen who can determine anyone's intentions with the slightest brush of her hand. It is a gift that Rose shies away from, but it is really useful in her chosen profession. I really enjoyed Kindred Demon. It is a super quick read, but I thought Rashelle Workman did a really good job with the paranormal elements in the story. They were very upfront and in your face. I also really liked the mystery surrounding Rose's parents and the bio facility that I am sure is going to play a much larger role in future books.Romance was not really in the forefront of this book. It was focused more on introducing the world and characters, and surprisingly, I was ok with that. because I could see some of the inklings of where the romance is going to go in the future and it made me very happy. I also think he is going to play a bigger role. There is more to meets the eye with him. I have a couple of ideas, but they each pretty different so who knows.Undercover Empath: Kindred Demon is a super quick read. Almost too quick. My main drawback with the story was that I wished it was a little more fleshed out. Don't get me wrong, there will be plenty of time for more character and plot development in future books, but I felt like this installment just flew by and there could have been a little more. Each book so far has been about 100 pages, so maybe they are more like longer novellas or serials. I was expecting full length novels, which is probably why it felt short to me. The second book is already out so I can get my instant gratification and find out what happens next, which is a big plus in my book, but the summary is the same as the first book. I think that should be redone, it was pretty confusing to me. I am really interested in following this story. I love Rose, I hope the romance turns out the way that I want and I can't wait to see what surprises Rashelle has in store for us next.*Disclaimer- I got a copy of this book for free in exchange for my honest thoughts. I was not compensated for my review.

4.5/5 gavelsThe Dreamer is the first book in a new, New Adult fantasy series, called the Dreamland Series. I loved this book. I found it to be well written, fresh, engaging and really creative. I loved the world within a world that Author E.J. Mellow created. The book starts out by Molly getting struck by lightening and ending up in the hospital. I thought it was funny that the doctor made an offhand comment that she might experience some weird dreams, which then sets off the whole rest of the story.Because Molly does experience some weird dreams. Dreams that have her questioning what is real and what isn't. Molly gets transported to the same, very strange looking world in each of her dreams. A world where she is a special person called a dreamer, and that she might just play a pivotal role in their society and survival. I don't want to tell you much more than that because I loved the way E.J. Mellow painted the picture. She did a fantastic job with her world building, and I want you to experience terra sominum (can't remember the spelling, and can't find it in my kindle) for yourself.And for my romance fans out there- you need to read the Dreamer. I love Dev and Molly so much. That is also the only reason that I knocked 1/2 star off. Because of Molly's "real-life" boyfriend. Who is also very nice (kind of like Dean in Gilmore Girls. He was nice, but kind of boring, when put next to Rory's other choices.) And it is really, really hard to compare to Dev. I want the other guy out of the picture completely, and until that happens I will be a little sad. I hope to see lots more Molly and Dev in the next book.And speaking of the next book, I already know it is going to be epic and action packed. So what does that mean for you? You need to read the Dreamer ASAP. This is a great find as a favorite series for me. I can't wait for the next book. I want it in my hands right now!*Disclaimer- I got a copy of this book for free in exchange for my honest thoughts. I was not compensated for my review.

4.5/5Dare is the first book in a new, new adult paranormal romance series, called The Nox. I have read, and loved, a bunch of T.A. Foster's new adult contemporary romances, but I have never read any paranormal book from her. So I was really excited to see about the Nox. Dare is the leader of the Nox, a group of panther shifters that protect the town of Sullen Grove. I really enjoyed the concept of Dare. The nox are formed of all female panther shifters that don't want to fulfill the destiny laid out for them by the council (the ruling body for shifters). Basically in shifter land, each female shifter is destined to a male shifter of some kind, and when they marry, or bond, the male shifter takes over their land and moves on to get his next wife. And then when the female shifter becomes pregnant with his cub, she loses all of her power to that cub. Totally not cool.Dare doesn't want to give up her territory, or lose her powers and ability to shift. She she gathers a group of other girls and tries to rebel, which is the set up for Dare. I love this idea and I also loved the more intricate details of the council and the bonding, which you will have to read to find out for yourself. I was fascinated by the way the magic worked with the shifters in this regard. T.A. Foster did an excellent job making Dare flow right along, and with making the nox her own. Not to mention is has an addictive romance. I love T.A. Foster's romances, and I was happy to see that this was was just as wonderfully satisfying as her contemporary romances. Dare and Zac totally melted my heart. I love the way they were so drawn to each other.And I have to say, T.A. Foster really surprised me with several of the plot twists. Normally, I am pretty good about pinning down what is going to happen in books that are not thrillers or mysteries. And I had my idea of how this one was going to end in my head for about the whole second half of the book. But holy cow, I was totally off base! And I kind of loved that. T.A. Foster, you continue to surprise me in all the best ways! The Nox is already one of my favorite new adult/adult shifter series.*disclaimer- I got a copy of this book for free in exchange for my honest thoughts. I was not compensated for my review.

3.5/5Tangled Webs is one of those books where it was love at first glance. As soon as I saw the cover I fell in love. (side note: this is a beautifully designed book. Each of the chapters even has black and white lace designs on the pages. A wonderfully intricate touch, I thought.) I knew I wanted to read it. And then as soon as I saw the summary, and found out that Tangled Webs was about a blackmailer in historical London, called Lady A who collected secrets, I was even more excited! How amazingly cool does that sound? And then the plot thickens. When I finished Tangled Webs, I liked it and I thought it ended in a good place for a standalone. But then I went on goodreads and saw that it is the first in the Tangled Webs series. Whaaa? Now I am very intrigued to see where Lee Bross is going to take the next installment. I honestly thought it was wrapped up as a standalone, but I am interested to see what is going to happen next. My mind is already spinning with possibilities.Arista is the mysterious Lady A. I really liked Arista. She is a survivor, but her years of fending for herself didnâ€™t make her overly hard and jaded. Sure, she was distrustful, but then again she is a blackmailer- so I guess it goes hand in hand with her business. But she wasnâ€™t corrupted to her core. She is still a good person, and I think Lee Bross does a great job of showing Aristaâ€™s softer side through her interactions with her friend Becky. I loved how protective Becky and Arista were of each other. I also really enjoyed Aristaâ€™s blooming friendship with Sophia. It was such a surprising treat that Sophia took Arista to the salons to see Voltaire. That was a great enlightenment element woven into the story. I hope we get to see more bits of history in the next book.There were a couple of little things that I wish I had seen more of in Tangled Webs. Not really things I wanted done differently, because I rather enjoyed Leeâ€™s writing and storytelling, but some elements I wanted to see more of. Like the secrets Lady A traded in, for example. I wanted to know what the actual secrets were. We got to know one about the first exchange she had and then we got to find out one at the end of the book, but other than those two there werenâ€™t any other big (or even little) secret reveals about her â€œcustomersâ€. I also wanted to see more romantic development between Arista and Grae. I love Grae to pieces, but it was basically instant infatuation between him and Arista. Donâ€™t get me wrong, I love the idea of them together, and I really liked their shared passion of travel and the sea, but I thought there was a really great opportunity for some building blocks to be laid between the two of them when Arista found herself staying with Graeâ€™s father and family by happenstance. We didnâ€™t really get that. I just saw Grae totally besotted with Arista from start to finish.Overall, Tangled Webs was a very good read. I loved the setting and the characters and the plotline was different than so many of the books I have been reading lately. Very refreshing. And while I do wish we got to see more in the way of slow build romantic development between Grae and Arista, as well as more secrets that Lady A collected, I think that these things will resolve themselves in the next book. I canâ€™t wait to see what Lee Bross has for us next.*Disclaimer- I got a copy of this book for free in exchange for my honest review. I was not compensated for my thoughts.

Jesse's Girl is the 6th standalone book in the hundred oaks series. The hundred Oaks series are each young adult contemporary feel good romances. In Jesse's Girl we meet Maya, who is the younger brother of Sam (from Catching Jordan.) Sam and Jordan show up throughout the book, which I am sure will be a fan favorite, but I haven't read catching Jordan yet. Please don't stone me. I have read Breathe, Annie, Breathe and I plan to read all of the rest of the books in the series. Someday. I liked Jesse's Girl even more than I liked Breathe Annie Breathe. Miranda Kenneally does such a wonderful job with contemporary romances. Her books just make me feel good.Maya is a tough cookie, but also one of the sweetest people ever. She wants to be a musician, but she has a little issue with stage fright when she sings solo. I liked that she wasn't this super talented, super amazing- no faults kind of girl. I really liked that she had some talent issues to work through. It made her seem more real. And I loved her with Jesse.Maya and Jesse each have their own trust issues, for their own reasons. But watching them bicker until they couldn't help but get along was just way too cute for me. Yes, even though they had a hard time initially trusting one another, once they moved past it, they were both so supportive of the other. And that was heartwarming for me to read about. Each one of them had multiple times where they could have reverted, but Miranda handled every road block wonderfully, in my opinion.Jesse's Girl is a great feel good read. This is the kind of read that I want to come home to after a long day of work, or a read that I want to pull out poolside. I really do need to read the rest of the series because I know that I will love them all. If you are looking for a well done young adult contemporary romance, try one of Miranda's books.*Discalimer- I got a copy of this book for free in exchange for my honest review. I was not compensated for my thoughts.

In case you're not familiar with Sabicas (1912-90), he was one of the greatest flamenco guitarists of the 20th century and a major influence on all his successors, most notably Paco de LucÃ­a.This album is a reissue of the brilliant Flaming Flamenco Guitar (1963).  It's one of Sabas's best.  Several items (including the famous MalagueÃ±a by Lecuona) are double-tracked, with one guitar coming out of each speaker â€” the best separation I've heard.CONTENTS:01) La MalagueÃ±a [Lecuona]02) AlegrÃ­as «Rosas y clavelesÂ»03) Siguiriyas Â«De la sierraÂ»04) Sevillanas Â«En la rejaÂ»05) Soleares Â«PasiÃ³nÂ»06) Gran jota de concierto [TÃ¡rrega]07) GarrotÃ­n Â«Mi GarrotÃ­nÂ»08) Guajiras Â«Recuerdo tropicalÂ»09) MalagueÃ±a Â«Noches de MÃ¡lagaÂ»10) BulerÃ­as Â«Fragua gitanaÂ»The total time is 35'44".

As Segovia's recordings inspired the classical guitarists of the future, so the seminal recordings that Julian Bream made for RCA between 1960 and 1980 produced a whole new generation of lutenists.In my view, although lute performance has moved on in terms of historical accuracy, these albums have never been surpassed for musicality â€” and, particularly relevant to the present context, rhythm.The "Dances of Dowland" LP was recorded in 1968, with the following contents:01) Earl of Essex Galliard,  4202) LachrimÃ¦ AntiquÃ¦03) My Lady Hunsdon's Puffe, P. 5404) Lord d'Lisle's Galliard, P. 3805) The Frog Galliard, P. 2306) LachrimÃ¦ VerÃ¦07) The Shoemaker's Wife, P. 5808) Lady Rich's Galliard, P. 4309) A piece without title, P. 5110) Sir John Smith's Almaine, P. 4711) Melancholie Galliard, P. 2512) Sir Henry Gifford's Almaine13) Dowland's First Galliard, P. 2214) Mrs. Vaux's Gigge, P. 5715) The Earl of Derby's Galliard, P. 4416) Semper Dowland, Semper Dolens, P. 9and a total time of 42'14".Its CD history is rather strange, since it was re-released twice, with different bonus tracks, all taken from the now-defunct Lute Music of Dowland LP:- Under the original title, plusâ€¢ Galliard To LachrimÃ¦ , P. 46 (after LachrimÃ¦ AntiquÃ¦, as appropriate)â€¢ Captain Digorie Piper's Galliard, P. 19â€¢ My Lord Chamberlain, His Galliard, P. 37â€¢ Resolution, P. 13â€¢ Mr. Langton's Galliard, P. 33â€¢ Sir John Souche's Galliard, P. 26â€¢ Piper's Pavan, P. 8- And (in the UK) under the title of Julian Bream Plays Dowland: Lute Music and Dances, plusâ€¢ Piper's Pavan, P. 8â€¢ My Lord Willoughby's Welcome Home, P. 66â€¢ Forlorn Hope Fancy, P. 6â€¢ A Fancy, P. 5â€¢ Farewell, P. 3You pays your money and takes your choice â€” or took it, since all of these are now apparently deleted.

Enrique de Melchor (1950-2012) was one of today's top flamenco guitar virtuosi, and the son of the famous accompanist Melchor de Marchena (1913-80).This is a book of transcriptions of his pieces (accompanied by a CD), as follows:Farruca Â«LimoneraÂ»Taranto Â«Candil mineroÂ»Fandangos de Huelva Â«MarismasÂ»Guajira Â«CafetalÂ»Colombiana Â«ZaralmondiÂ»BulerÃ­a Â«Danza de los GitanosÂ»Two of the selections here are from La guitarra flamenca, three from Bajo la luna, and one from Arco de las rosas.  However, if you haven't got these albums, you don't need to care, as all pieces are included on the accompanying CD.  The performances include other instruments, such as bass and synthesizer, which are not transcribed; if M. Faucher (the trancriber) separated the guitar parts unaided from all the accompanying clutter, my respect goes up a notch.  There are intelligent and perceptive analytical notes in Spanish, English and French.Enrique's toque moved a long way from his father's; the difficulty level here is frequently virtuosic.  It's certainly beyond my technique to play these pieces with authority at the speed of the recordings, and I would guess beyond most other prospective buyers', too.  But that doesn't, of course, mean that you shouldn't want to try.As to my rating: five stars for the quality of the transcriptions, two for the quality of the music, which to me seems rather sterile.DISCLOSUREI received a free copy of this item for review.

The Johnstons are seldom mentioned these days except as the starting-points for Paul Brady and Mick (then known as Mike) Moloney, but for my money they were one of the best groups ever for Irish traditional music; and all the material from the outer albums falls into that category*.  They understand their material perfectly, they're first rate instrumentally, and their harmonies are stunning â€” listen to "Fuigfidh Mise 'n Baile Seo", for example.Unlike the previous almost-twofer The Johnstons/The Barley Corn, this album contains all the tracks from it's constituent LPs.Those two are among my favourite folk albums of all time."Give a Damn" contains modern songs, and in my opinion is not nearly as strong.But at (as I write) the price of a single album, I have to give this five stars; just program out the tracks you don't like.*OK, "Ye Jacobites" and "Fhir a' Bhata" are Scottish.

This is a reissue of Festival Gitana, aka Flamenco Fiesta, recorded around 1960 on the Elektra label.Sabicas was one of the greatest flamenco guitarists of the 20th century.  His artistic name was a pun on his childhood nickname "Las habicas" â€” Little Green Beans, because he was always eating them.Los Trianeros are rather more mysterious: Enrique Montoya and Domingo Alvarado are quite well known, and Diego CastellÃ³n was Sabicas's brother.  But El NiÃ±o de Alicante was actually Mario Escudero, recording under this pseudonym because he was under contract to another company.As to the music, the guitarists are brilliant.  Unfortunately, the album is let down by the singers, both of whom were more at home in the greener pastures of "aflamencada" Spanish pop, and who here appear competent but undistinguished.  Still, if you're not as fussy as I am, it's quite a pleasant and atmospheric record.The total time is 37'50".

This is yet another re-release, under yet another title, of The Art of the Guitar, of which there are now so many versions as to overflow Amazon's maximum number of links.  See the original for my review.As I write, the cheapest version seems to be the bizarrely-entitled Classical Guitar, but of course this may change.

Although Carmen (1913-1963) was of course primarily a dancer â€” THE female flamenco dancer of the century  â€” she was also an excellent singer with a marvellous Gypsy voice.The guitarist Sabicas, for long her musical (and, some say, romantic) partner, was one of the greatest guitarists.  Together they made an electric combination.This 1959 album is one of the two they made together; the other was Flamenco!.This one is available in Europe in MP3 form (bizarrely retitled Les rythmes de Carmen Amaya), and bits of it have appeared in various anthologies; but as far as I'm aware, it's never been released in its entirety on CD.Some of the tracks feature the singer Domingo Alvarado, and four are guitar solos by Sabicas.  The album, which remains a classic, was made for a total of $1,200*.CONTENTS01) BulerÃ­a Â«Ritmos de Carmen AmayaÂ»02) Taranta03) Seguiriya04) SoleÃ¡05) Tiento Canastero06) SoleÃ¡07) Seguiriya08) RondeÃ±a09) SoleÃ¡ por BulerÃ­a10) AlegrÃ­asThe total time is 43'26".*According to Paco Sevilla's excellent biography of Carmen, p 338.

SÃ©rgio & Eduardo Abreu are my favourite guitar duo after Presti/Lagoya; I saw them at London's Wigmore Hall when they were 20 and 19, and they blew my mind out through my eyeballs.Confusingly, their first two albums were both called "The Guitars of SÃ©rgio and Eduardo Abreu": one â€” the present one â€” was on Ace of Diamonds in the UK (Decca elsewhere, I believe), and the other  on CBS.CONTENTSa1) Dowland: Sir John Langton's Pavan, P. 14a2) Frescobaldi: Fuguea3) Vivaldi: Prelude & Correntea4) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 159, L. 104a5) Bach: Lute Suite NÂº 3, BWV 995b1) Villa-Lobos: Prelude NÂº 1b2) Villa-Lobos: Study NÂº 1b3) Segovia: Estudio Sin Luzb4) Moreno Torroba: MadroÃ±osb5) Segovia: Divertimentob6) Ravel: Pavane pour une infante dÃ©funteb7) AlbÃ©niz: El puertoTrack a5 is by SÃ©rgio alone, and b1-4 by Eduardo alone; the remaining tracks are by the duo.Good though the solos are, I would have preferred an album entirely of duets; which is why four stars rather than five.The energy and bravura in "El Puerto" are stunning; by contrast, Sir John Langton's (transcribed for the duo from the solo for 7-course lute) is calm and utterly beautiful, an astonishing achievement for musician barely out of their teens.The stereo separation is good.The total time is 54'50".

I must make it clear at the outset that I don't possess this album, which contains 31 of the 91 tracks Paco has recorded in his seven basic (i.e. not anthologised) recordings for Nimbus.  I do, however, possess those seven albums (in fact, all of Paco's albums since his first in 1968), and since as I write no other review has appeared, I venture to add some information.I should also say that I contributed both booklet notes and a cover photograph to the Nimbus albums, so I refrain from comment on the quality of the music or the recordings.As far as I can make out, this selection comprises the following:4 tracks from Music of RamÃ³n Montoya & NiÃ±o Ricardo, 19874 tracks from Azahara, 19886 tracks from Encuentro (with Eduardo FalÃº), 19895 tracks from Misa Flamenca, 19916 tracks from Arte y PasiÃ³n, 19993 tracks from Flamenco Guitar recital, 20063 tracks I haven't been able to place exactlymaking well over 2 hours of music.At it's budget price (assuming it still is, when you read this), it's terrific value; unless your taste is specialised.If Flamenco Guitar is your thing, go for the double album of that name, which comprises Montoya/Ricardo and Azahara.If you prefer flamenco singing and the ambience of a live performance, you may prefer Arte y PasiÃ³n*.If you like the flamenco mass, then you can see it as well as listen to it.If you want music of Latin America â€” in which Eduardo FalÃº is certainly one of the greatest names â€” then most of this album will be of little interest.If, however, you have no overriding passion but like a lot of variety, then this compilation could well be ideal.  My only caveat would be the programming, which (for me) has far too many transitions of style; personally I would reprogram the tracks with the remote.*To this we may now add A CompÃ¡s, which I personally think is the better of the two albums.

This album (MGM E3214) was recorded in 1954 when Mario came to the US with Vicente Escudero, and is thus of course mono.  It is NOT the same as the 1962 ABC-Paramount one of the same title (ABCS-428); so if Amazon posts this review on the latter, just ignore it.It's full of youthful energy, and the material is quite different from that of his cousin (and later duet partner) Sabicas.  The contents are:01) Danza Mora Â«Danza calÃ­Â»02) Sevillanas populares03) AlegrÃ­as04) Martinete/SoleÃ¡/AlegrÃ­as/BulerÃ­as05) RondeÃ±a Â«Mi RondeÃ±aÂ»06) Tanguillo Â«Testamento gitanoÂ»07) Tientos Â«Tientos del amenecerÂ»08) Fandangos de Huelva09) Las tres hojas10) Zorongo gitano11) Zapateado Â«Repiqueteos flamencosÂ»12) Tientos Â«Tiento flamencoÂ»Transcriptions of tracks 1, 5, & 7 were published in Selected Solos for Guitar.

Although a biography of the Gabor sisters might seem to offer a lot of scope, this book is little more than a list of whom they slept with, interspersed with occasional separating events such as TV appearances, films, marriages and World Wars.  Although not without its interesting and/or amusing moments, it quickly becomes repetitious, and would benefit considerably by abridgement to around half its current size.It does, however, serve as a useful reminder (especially when the virtues of education and hard work are again being harped upon) of what can be achieved â€” in terms of worldly success, at any rate â€” simply by beauty, vivacity and charm in massive doses*.The day of the professional courtesan will not be over until these traits are no longer valued.  And when that happens, let's face it, the World will be a much duller place.*Assisted, possibly, by more than ordinary helpings of persistence and shrewdness.

James Tyler's credentials as an Early Music dude stretch back to David Munrow, and include a superb lute duo with Anthony Rooley that played to packed concert-halls in London in the '70s; a stint in the Julian Bream Consort; and a position on the faculty of the Southern California School of Music.This album with Musica Viva does indeed remind me of the said Consort; which, since that group only ever made two albums (decades apart), is very welcome.The contributors to each piece are shown on a spreadsheet in the booklet, which also contains extensive notes on the music.They are :a) James Tyler (6- & 7-course lute, cittern)b) Nancy Roth (treble viol)c) Niki Carras (renaissance flute)d) Joëlle Fancher Morton (bass viol)e) James Lidget (bandora)f) Keller Coker (cittern)g) Dirk Freymouth (lute)h) Nina Treadwell (lute)i) Inga La Rose (recorder)Several of the instrumental parts are missing in the original sources, and have been ably reconstructed for this recording.Since Amazon, as usual, doesn't specify the composers, I list the contents below:01) Richard Reade: Pavan 9 (abdefi)02) Robert Parsons: Replete for 3 Lutes (agh)03) Anthony Holborne: Holbornes's Farewell (aef)04) John Johnson (attributed): A Dump (ag)05) Daniel Bacheler: Daniel's Almaine (abcdef)06) John Johnson: Chi passa (ag)07) William Byrd: Where Fancy Fond (abdefi)08) John Johnson: La Vecchia Pavan & Galliard (ag)09) John Dowland: Captain Digorie Piper's Pavan (abcdef)10) Thomas Robinson: A Plaine Song (ah)11) Daniel Bacheler: Lady Walsingham's Conceits (abcdef)12) Anon: Pagingtoune's Galliard (ag)13) William Byrd: A Pavan of Master Byrd (abcdef)14) Anon: Galliard for 2 lutes after Laveche (ag)15) Daniel Bacheler: The Widow's Mite (abcdef)16) Anon: Squire's Galliard (ag)17) John Johnson (attributed): The Leaves be Green (ah)18) James Harding: James's Galliard (abdei)The total time is 54'18".

Exactly what the title says, together with notes on the composers, the music, and performance; a list of sources; a bibliography; and notes on the individual pieces.  All the pieces are Elizabethan, and in the "treble and ground" style: the trebles are printed in one booklet and the grounds in another.The pieces are as follows:Thomas Robinson: Passamezzo GalliardThomas Robinson: The Queen's GoodnightThomas Robinson: Twenty Ways Upon the BellsEllis Lawrey: The MarigoldeFrancis Cutting: Short Almain (Tinternell)Richard Allison: The Sharp PavanAlfonso Ferrabosco I: The Spanish PavanRichard Allison: The Spanish MeasuresJohn Johnson (?): The Honsok (The Hunt's Up)John Johnson (?): The Leaves Be GreenJohn Johnson (?):Passamezzo GalliardJohn Johnson (?): Greene Garters

Hey ho, another re-release with the title changed in the hope that you won't realise you've already bought it.This is Festival Gitana (Elektra EKL-149), released in 1960 (September 14, 2015 indeed!), and available on MP3 here (with the original cover picture) and here (both for cheaper, as I write); and with yet another title here and here.See any of those for my, and others', reviews."Sevillanos" (track 5) should be "Sevillanas".

Sabicas was well past his "NiÃ±o" days when he recorded most of this (although, of course, Ricardo was still "NiÃ±o" when he died at 67).It's yet another retitled grab-bag from Sabicas's prolific recorded legacy.  In this case all but two of the pieces come from either Flamenco Virtuoso (tracks 03-13) or Flamenco Fantasy (tracks 14-20).  Track 01 comes from El duende de la guitarra flamenca, leaving only track 02 (possibly) previously unavailable.I wish record companies would stop faffing about and just reissue the original albums.BTW, in case you should be wondering what "pucas" are (track 3), they shoud be "ducas".

World's Novelty Champions?  I've seen some deranged titles in my time, but none more so than this.Here we have five tracks from the interminably-anthologised Art of the Guitar.  See that album for my, and others', reviews.If these, and no others, are the exact tracks you want, I suppose it could be cheaper than buying them individually from Art.Apart from that, the whole exercise seems pointless.

Masters of the Spanish Guitar, eh?  And so they were indeed; but the music is all Latin American.This album is in fact a reissue of Romantic Guitars, albeit with the order of the tracks pointlessly shuffled.  The LP is a moderate rarity, especially in stereo.A re-release is thus welcome.  As well as the title, the cover has been changed, the revised one being a doctored version of that on Fantastic Guitars; but frankly, the original wasn't much of a loss.So: an album of Latin American favourites by two of the World's greatest flamenco guitarists, recorded around 1960.  It's not what purists would consider "authentic", but it is a lot of fun.The LP was released in both mono (Decca DL 8897) and stereo (DL 78897). Whether the MP3 samples are stereo I find it hard to decide: the channel-separation certainly isn't great, but then neither was it on the LP â€” although it was definitely there (which is more than I'd guarantee for Fantastic Guitars).

I saw Llan de Cubel for the first time at the Sebastopol Festival (in California), and they blew my mind out through my eyeballs. I bought every album they had on the spot, and I don't regret it.They're a six-man folk group from Asturias in Northern Spain, featuring pipes, whistle, fiddle, flute, guitar & bouzouki.  This is their fourth CD, and it's stunning. The first track is a hymn to a girl from Cabrales, with the most wonderful vocal harmonies, followed by a driving instrumental on the pipes.  The rest of the album never flags.P.S. The title of the MP3 version is mis-spelled, so there's no link to the CD version, which is here.

George Shipway (1908-82) was an excellent British historical novelist, whose strengths include a strong realism, and whose cavalry background made him well qualified to write about military matters.Most his his novels are more serious than this one, which he himself describes as "a diversion".The Club of the title (short for "Chilianwala") is for retired old buffers from the British cavalry â€” people very much, in fact, like the author himself.Written in 1971, when repeated strikes were earning Britain the name of "sick man of Europe", it's set in a (then) near future where a major clash between communism and fascism is becoming ever more imminent.Tongue clearly firmly in cheek in places, it details the Club's rather drastic solutions to some of the social problems.How much you like it may depend rather upon your own politics â€” or perhaps, simply whether you dislike extremism in all its forms.I very much enjoyed it, although I certainly didn't take it seriously.4Â½ stars.

This, together with Dr Chilesotti's Da Un Codice del Cinquecento, is one of sources that Ottorino Respighi drew on for his Ancient Airs and Dances.It consists of transcriptions into staff notation, for guitar, of lute pieces by the following composers, mostly 16th century:â€¢ Hans Newsidlerâ€¢ William Balletâ€¢ Simon Gintzlerâ€¢ Joanne Matelartâ€¢ Jacomo Gorzanisâ€¢ Francesco da Milanoâ€¢ Vicentio [sic] Galileiâ€¢ Julio Cesare Barbettaâ€¢ Fabritio Carosoâ€¢ Gabriel Fallameroâ€¢ Gio. Antonio Terziâ€¢ Simone Molinaroâ€¢ Gio. Battista dalla Gostenaâ€¢ Giovanni Battista Besardo [sic]â€¢ J.B. Besarde [sic]â€¢ Mersenne Marinâ€¢ Bernardo Gianoncelli detto il BernadelloAmong the pieces used by Respighi are Besard's "CampanÃ¦ Parisienses", the Bergamesca by Gianoncelli and the duet "Bransles de village".

Ida Presti and her husband Alexandre Lagoya formed what has been called the greatest duo in the history of the classical guitar. They were to the duo what Segovia was to the solo instrument: they innovated technically and musically and made something like fifteen world tours, inspiring nearly all the best modern composers to write for the medium, while at the same time generating an entire new body of transcriptions from instruments such as the harpsichord. They also inspired and taught several other duos who are now among the best in the World, including Ako Ito & Henri Dorigny and the Athenian Duo (Evangelos & Liza).  Their fame and impact were still accelerating when, on a tour of the United States in 1967, Ida Presti was taken suddenly ill and died. She was forty-two.Presti/Lagoya's early recordings were on French RCA, and most of these were issued as a 2-CD boxed set (7 43212 58662), now deleted. They then moved to Philips, for whom they re-recorded much of their repertoire.The complete Philips recordings in turn were issued on a 3-CD boxed set. That set, too, is now deleted; but, it is (happily) completely subsumed by the present L'Art de Alexandre Lagoya.This album appears to be drawn from the Philips recordings, most which are available on CD in the set mentioned above; but the Scarlatti Sonata, K. 87, L. 33 is a rarity: I'm unaware of any CD containing their recording.CONTENTSa1) Bach: English Suite Nº 3, BWV 808: Courantea2) Bach: English Suite NÂº 3, BWV 808: Allemandea3) Bach: English Suite NÂº 3, BWV 808: Preludea4) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 87, L. 33a5) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 380, L. 23b1) Granados: Spanish Dance NÂº 2, Oriental, Op. 37, NÂº 2b2-5) Marella: Suite NÂº 1 in D Majorb6) Debussy: Clair de Lune
This CD is the same thing as this one.  So I suggest you compare the prices; and I refer you there for my, and others', reviews.
This CD is the same thing as this one.  So I suggest you compare the prices; and I refer you there for my, and others', reviews.

This is the 1995 2-CD set of the duo's complete RCA recordings.CONTENTSVolume 101) Pujol: EvocaciÃ³n Cubana02) Sor: Andante Largo, Op. 503) Bach: Sonata NÂº 3 â€” Andante04) Lagoya: RÃªverie05) Lagoya: Caprice06) Falla: La vida breve: Spanish Dance NÂº 1*07) Falla: Fisherman's Tale08) Granados: Goyescas, Op. 11 â€” Intermezzo*09) Granados: Spanish Dance NÂº  4, Villanesca, Op. 3710) AlbÃ©niz: EspaÃ±a, Op. 165 â€” Tango*11) Carulli: Largo & Rondo, Op. 3412) Carulli: Serenade in C, NÂº 313) Presti: La Hongroise14) Diabelli: Serenade in D, Op. 83 â€” Romance & March15) Dowland: The King of Denmark's Galliard/Mrs Nichols Almaine/The Frog GalliardVolume 201) Handel: Sarabande in D, HWV 43702) Calleja: Preludes (3)03) Moreno Torroba: Nocturno04) Lauro: Venezuelan Waltz NÂº 305) Presti: Danse rythmique06) Bach: English Suite NÂº 3, BWV 808 â€” Gavotte & Musette07) Bach: Prelude & Fugue NÂº 17, BWV 86208) Sor: L'encouragement, Op. 34*09) Jolivet: Serenade10) Daniel-Lesur: Elegy11) Simonot: Suite of Royal DancesVol. 1, tracks 1-5 are solos by Presti, and vol. 2, tracks 1-5 are solos by Lagoya.  The remainder are by the duo.The pieces asterisked were re-recorded when they moved to Philips, and thus appear also on their Complete Philips Recordings, later subsumed into the 6-CD tribute to Lagoya, which also contains the Handel Sarabande.The total time is 138'05".THE MUSICMany of the pieces are (now!) standards of the guitar duo repertory, and really require no comment from me.  In each case, Presti/Lagoya's version seems to me the best, with one exception: Falla's Spanish Dance, in which Bream & Williams outdo even the superb performance here.â€¢ Pujol's piece is, unsurprisingly, a Guajira, in that style's characteristic hemiola (alternating bars of 3/4 & 6/8) rhythm.  Ida gives it an electrifying performance, demonstrating what a magnificent soloist she was before she subordinated that career to the duo's.â€¢ The two pieces by Lagoya consist of a beautiful romantic prelude, followed by a sort of scherzo.  "RÃªverie", in particular, is one of my favourite guitar miniatures.â€¢ Falla's "Fisherman's Tale" is a lovely quiet, meditative piece; and I'm unaware of any other guitar duo recording (although I have an ancient solo recording by Laurindo Almeida).â€¢ I love all of Granados's Spanish Dances, and again I'm unaware of any other duo version of this one (although Manuel Barrueco does an excellent solo job; in fact he plays the lot, a magnificent recording).â€¢ Presti's's "Hongroise" is a tribute to BÃ©la BartÃ³k.â€¢ The Dowland pieces are uninformatively labelled "Trois danses" on the track listing.  The duo's versions don't sound much like lute music, but they're good fun.â€¢ "Danse rythmique" is a cheerful, lively piece that makes extensive use of Ã©toufÃ©e.â€¢ Francisco Calleja was a Spanish composer from the start of the 20th century, best known for his lovely CanciÃ³n triste, recorded by Vicente GÃ³mez and others.  The three preludes are pleasant and tuneful, although of no great depth.â€¢ Jolivet's Serenade is more modern in vocabulary, although it doesn't indulge in the pings, bonks and graunches that were later to grace some of the repertory.  Dedicated to the duo, it "evokes, in his personal language, facets of countries in which the guitar is popular: Italy, Spain, France and the United States, home of Jazz".  It's the longest piece here, at over 12 minutes.â€¢ Yves Daniel-Lesur was (it says here) a member of Les Six, although you could certainly have fooled me.  His elegy (which he himself transcribed for the duo from the harp original) takes the form a melody over an arpeggiated accompaniment, somewhat after the manner of "Clair de Lune", although again with a somewhat more modern vocabulary.  I find it very attractive.â€¢ And finally, the Suite of Royal Dances was adapted by the composer from his music for the film Marie Antoinette.  There is no information on the individual movements.BOOKLET NOTESare in French alone.  They're fairly intelligent, but, somewhat disconcertingly, comment on the tracks in a different order from that in which these appear on the album.SHEET MUSICThe music of "RÃªverie", "Caprice", "Danse rythmique" (and, presumably, "La Hongroise") was published several decades ago by Ricordi; but I don't know if they're still available.

BACKGROUNDFirstly, I must say that I don't possess any of these 3 volumes of IDIS Presti/Lagoya recordings.  However, they appear to be drawn from both the early RCA recordings and the later Philips ones, and I do have CD sets of these.â€¢ The 2-CD RCA set (7 43212 58662), from 1995, seems to be a rarity.â€¢ The 3-CD Philips set, also long deleted, is listed second-hand by Amazon, but is something of a rarity as well.  It is, however, completely subsumed by the 6-CD set L'Art de Alexandre Lagoya.Although the IDIS albums have lists of the relevant composers on their covers, exact track listings are not obvious, so I think it worth giving those here that I've reconstructed from information elsewhere on the net.When they moved to Philips, the duo re-recorded several pieces from their RCA days.  The pieces asterisked, however, are definitely from those early recordings, and are thus (as far as I'm aware) not easily obtainable elsewhere on CD.For comments on the music, please see my reviews of the two "complete" collections.CONTENTS1-2) Bach: Prelude & Fugue, BWV 862*3) Bach: English Suite NÂº 3, BVW 808 â€” Courante4) Bach: English Suite NÂº 3, BVW 808 â€” Allemande5) Bach: English Suite NÂº 3, BVW 808 â€” Prelude6) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 380, L. 237-10) Marella: Suite NÂº 111) Carulli: Serenade in G Major, Op. 96, NÂº 312) AlbÃ©niz: Piezas caracterÃ­sticas, Op. 92, NÂº 1 â€” Danza13) Granados: Goyescas â€” Intermezzo14) Granados: Spanish Dance, Op. 37 NÂº  4, Villanesca*15) Granados: Spanish Dance, Op. 37 NÂº  2, Orientale16) Falla: El amor brujo, G. 68 â€” Romance del pescador*17) Debussy: Suite bergamasque â€” Clair de Lune18) Petit: Toccata19) Poulenc: Improvisation in Eâ™­ Minor, NÂº 12I make the total time about 72'39".

BACKGROUNDFirstly, I must say that I don't possess any of these 3 volumes of IDIS Presti/Lagoya recordings.  However, they appear to be drawn from both the early RCA recordings and the later Philips ones, and I do have CD sets of these.â€¢ The 2-CD RCA set (7 43212 58662), from 1995, seems to be a rarity.â€¢ The 3-CD Philips set, also long deleted, is listed second-hand by Amazon, but is something of a rarity as well.
