Three novellas, from the time just before WWII when the Saint was still living in London at Cornwall House."The Miracle Tea Party" details what happens when Simon opens a packet of tea he has chanced upon, and finds it stuffed full of fifty pound notes."The Invisible Millionaire" has him investigating a murder mystery.And finally, we have "The Affair of Hogsbotham".  I've never met anyone named Hogsbotham (although my grandmother apparently went out with someone â€” fortunately not my grandfather â€” named Shufflebotham).  Nonetheless, the pronouncements of a character of this name ("and with a face to match", according to Simon) are what lead the Saint unexpectedly into the third adventure, involving a bank robbery.Patricia Holm and the Simon's faithful manservant Orace figure prominently, having of course both been with him since the very first Saint adventure, Meet the Tiger.  And for those who have (perhaps) wondered what happened to some of the other characters in that opus: a close reading reveals that the "moribund aunt" that Pat has to meet in the last story can only be Aunt Agatha.I find myself re-reading the middle story less often than the others (although I'm not quite sure why), but the other two are well up to the usual Charteris standard of this period.P.S. For a list of all Charteris's Saint books, look up "Simon Templar" (section "The Saint book series") on Wikipedia.

Alexandre was of course half of the magnificent Presti/Lagoya duo, the greatest in the history of the guitar.  This is one of the solo albums he made after the unexpected early death of his wife, and the playing is utterly beautiful. The recording is excellent.The contents are:a1) Bach: Musette, Minuet & Marcha2) Bach: Lute Suite NÂº 3, BWV 995: Prelude & Fuguea3) Handel: Sarabande in D, HWV 437a4) Weiss: Fantasieb1) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 322, L. 483b2) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 481, L. 187b3) Vanhal: CantabileThe total time is 36'07".The LP, like all the French Philips Presti/Lagoya and Lagoya editions, comes in a beautiful gatefold cover.These tracks are also available on the 6-CD tribute L'Art de Alexandre Lagoya.

The list of composers identifies this album, which is actually entitled simply "Lagoya".The contents are:a1) AlbÃ©niz: Sevillaa2) Turina: Fandanguillo, Op. 36a3-5) Moreno Torroba: Sonatina in Ab1) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 391, L. 79b2) Scarlatti: Sonata, K. 77, L. 168b3) Sor: Waltz NÂº 6b4) Sor: Waltz in Gb5) Sor: Waltz NÂº 3b6) Schubert: MinuetAlexandre was of course half of the magnificent Presti/Lagoya duo, the greatest in the history of the guitar.  This is one of the solo albums he made after the unexpected early death of his wife, and the playing is utterly beautiful. The recording is excellent.The total time is 42'18".These tracks are also available on the 6-CD tribute L'Art de Alexandre Lagoya.

Willie Clancy (1918-73) was one of the greatest uilleann pipers of the 20th century, and a major influence on modern players such as Liam O'Flynn â€” and the editor of the present opus, Pat Mitchell.  The Willie Clancy Summer School was established in his honour in 1973.The first edition of this book was published in 1976, and reprinted in 1977 & '83.  The 1993 update "includes a table of all the triplets played by Willie on various notes.  Some typographical errors have been corrected and names have been added to a few 'unknown' tunes.  Some interesting photos that came to light have been included".PREFATORY MATTERFirst there is an Introduction, apparently by Pat Mitchell, of BreandÃ¡n Breathnach, then a preface by Mr Breathnach in Gaelic.  Next are an Introduction to the New Edition, the original Introduction, notes on the tunes, a section on Signs, Terms and Ornaments, and a discussion of the music, all in English.  These are followed by a table of crans and rolls, and another of the triplets and quadruplets used by Willie; then several photographs.THE TUNESThere are 152 tunes, "all, excluding airs, that I managed to gather together up to Christmas 1975.  My original intention was to transcribe the airs as well but this proved to be such a formidable task that I was forced to abandon it.  They will be published separately, it is hoped, at a later date".The tunes are taken directly from Willie's playing, and are printed clearly, along with his ornamentation, and expressions such as staccato marks.APPENDICESAt the end are diagrams of the range and fingering of the chanter, the tuning of the regulators, the tuning of the drones, and ornamentation for various instrument; a Discography; a Bibliography; Acknowledgments; and an Index.SUMMARYThis is a very thorough job indeed, and clearly has been a labour of love.  I recommend it unhesitatingly to all players of Irish music.

As Segovia's recordings inspired the classical guitarists of the future, so the seminal recordings that Julian Bream made for RCA between 1960 and 1980 produced a whole new generation of lutenists.In my view, although lute performance has moved on in terms of historical accuracy, these albums have never been surpassed for musicality â€” and, particularly relevant to the present context, rhythm.The "Dances of Dowland" LP was recorded in 1968, with the following contents:01) Earl of Essex Galliard,  4202) Lachrimæ AntiquÃ¦03) My Lady Hunsdon's Puffe, P. 5404) Lord d'Lisle's Galliard, P. 3805) The Frog Galliard, P. 2306) LachrimÃ¦ VerÃ¦07) The Shoemaker's Wife, P. 5808) Lady Rich's Galliard, P. 4309) A piece without title, P. 5110) Sir John Smith's Almaine, P. 4711) Melancholie Galliard, P. 2512) Sir Henry Gifford's Almaine13) Dowland's First Galliard, P. 2214) Mrs. Vaux's Gigge, P. 5715) The Earl of Derby's Galliard, P. 4416) Semper Dowland, Semper Dolens, P. 9and a total time of 42'14".Its CD history is rather strange, since it was re-released twice, with different bonus tracks, all taken from the now-defunct Lute Music of Dowland LP:- Under the original title, plusâ€¢ Galliard To LachrimÃ¦ , P. 46 (after LachrimÃ¦ AntiquÃ¦, as appropriate)â€¢ Captain Digorie Piper's Galliard, P. 19â€¢ My Lord Chamberlain, His Galliard, P. 37â€¢ Resolution, P. 13â€¢ Mr. Langton's Galliard, P. 33â€¢ Sir John Souche's Galliard, P. 26â€¢ Piper's Pavan, P. 8- And (in the UK) under the title of "Julian Bream Plays Dowland: Lute Music and Dances" (ASIN: B00004SNK9), plusâ€¢ Piper's Pavan, P. 8â€¢ My Lord Willoughby's Welcome Home, P. 66â€¢ Forlorn Hope Fancy, P. 6â€¢ A Fancy, P. 5â€¢ Farewell, P. 3You pays your money and takes your choice â€” or took it, since all of these are now apparently deleted.P.S. For a list of all Bream's lute recordings, see my So You'd Like To... Guide.

Five complete Saint novels, unabridged?  Not if the list of contents on the cover is accurate.The Saint Closes the Case (original title The Last Hero) and The Avenging Saint (Knight Templar) are certainly complete novels, and what's more, two of the best.  But "The Man Who Was Clever" and "The Lawless Lady" are merely two of the three stories in Enter the Saint, the other being "The Policeman with Wings".  The Saint vs. Scotland Yard (original title The Holy Terror) is not a novel at all, but three more "novellas" of the same kind.So this looks to me not like 5 complete Saint books, but 3.66.I do like the picture on the cover, though.If pushed to it, I would say that the best single-volume anthology of Saint stories is The First Saint Omnibus.P.S. For a list of â€” and discussion of â€” all Charteris's Saint books, see my So You'd Like To... Guide.

"Meet The Tiger" (later retitled "The Saint meets the Tiger") published in 1928, was Leslie Charteris's first book in the Saint Saga (even though Hodder & Stoughton later pretended that Enter the Saint was, presumably because they weren't the publishers of the former).It's a useful (though not infallible) rule of thumb that if a book doesn't hook you by the end of the first page, it's not going to.  Here are the first two paragraphs of "Meet the Tiger":'Baycombe is a village on the North of Devon coast that is so isolated from civilisation that even at the height of the summer holiday season it is neglected by the rush of lean and plump, tall and short, papas, mammas, and infants.  Consequently, there was some sort of excuse for a man who had taken up his dwelling there falling into the monotony of regular habits â€” even for a man who had only lived there for three days â€” even (let the worst be known) for a man so unconventional as Simon Templar.It was not so very long after Simon Templar had settled down in Baycombe that the peacefully sedate village became most unsettled, and things began to happen there that shocked and flabbergasted its peacefully sedate inhabitants, as will be related; but at first Simon Templar found Baycombe as dull as it had been for the last six hundred years.'Not the greatest opening Leslie Charteris ever wrote â€” he was to become pretty skillful later â€” but quite respectable for a young man of 21 in only his third book.  The character so introduced, of course, was to become the longest-running fictional hero of the 20th century.Even at this early stage, the Saint (plausibly from his initials â€” but you knew that) is a more well-developed, more travelled and certainly more eccentric character than his near-contemporary, Bulldog Drummond.  There are few of the wilder parts of the world which he has not visited, and few of those in which he has not had adventures.  He has won a gold rush in South Africa, and lost his holding in a poker game twenty-four hours later.  He has run guns into China, whisky into the United States and perfume into England.  He deserted after a year in the Spanish Foreign Legion (Drummond would have been horrified at the idea of joining, let alone deserting).Likewise Patricia Holm, the Saint's companion in so many later adventures, is a much more interesting heroine than boring little Phyllis Drummond, who exists only to be kidnapped and rescued â€” someone whom the swine have got, or might get, and nothing more.The elements of the plot are pretty much the standard stuff of the day: a debonair hero for the reader to identify with; a million dollars in gold stolen from a Chicago bank by a mysterious mastermind known as The Tiger; a gang of ruthless criminals; and of course a damsel in distress.  What separates this from the majority of such efforts is the way Charteris plays with these elements â€” tongue clearly in cheek, in places â€” and weaves a story that carries you along from first to last.  Some of the characters (Algy, for instance, or Aunt Agatha) are so skillfully drawn that you feel you'd recognise them if they walked into your local pub.Other characters that recur later include Simon's faithful manservant Orace, and â€” briefly, in Knight Templar â€” Detective Inspector Carn.From what I can make out, "Meet The Tiger" is very difficult to get hold of; but if you want to read the Saint books it's worth making the effort.  They're definitely best if read in the right order.P.S. For a list of â€” and discussion of â€” all Charteris's Saint books, see my So You'd Like To... Guide.

Meet the Tiger (later retitled "The Saint meets the Tiger") published in 1928, was Leslie Charteris's first book in the Saint Saga (even though Hodder & Stoughton later pretended that "Enter the Saint" was, presumably because they weren't the publishers of the former).Nevertheless, "Enter the Saint" is the book that introduces Simon Templar as he is in most of the books that follow, and as neither the cinema nor television has yet had the nerve to portray him:  he beats people up, robs them, blackmails them, even murders them, and gets away with it.  And the fact that his victims are particularly vicious thugs (Snake Ganning), dope dealers (Edgar Hayn), white slavers (Henri Chastel), war profiteers (Leo Farwill) and so forth â€” and that he gives a large chunk of his profits to charity â€” would not excuse him to a strict moralist.  The success of the Saint books for seventy years must mean that strict moralists are perhaps not as common as one ought to hope.There are three longish stories; a reference that may be presumed to be to Sir John Bittle (from "Meet The Tiger") dates the first at nine months after the end of that opus.To enumerate plot details would probably be superfluous.  Suffice it to say that Charteris was just starting to hit his stride, and that "Enter" introduces two of his best characters: the Saint's friend Roger Conway, and his perpetual adversary, Inspector Claud Eustace Teal.  Patricia Holm now lives with the Saint although (daringly for 1930) they aren't married, and Orace is still the stalwart retainer.A fine warm up to its sequel, what is possibly the best of all the Saint stories: The Last Hero (aka "The Saint Closes the Case").P.S. For a list of â€” and discussion of â€” all Charteris's Saint books, see my So You'd Like To... Guide.

This, the last Saint book to feature Patricia Holm, consists of nine short stories, each bearing a lady's name.  Various old adversaries also appear, such as Newt Haskins (from The Saint in Miami) and Alvin Kearney (from Call for the Saint).The stories are varied and interesting, except for the last one which is just plain silly.P.S. For a list of â€” and discussion of â€” all Charteris's Saint books, see my So You'd Like To... Guide.

1948's "Call for the Saint" marks a partial, but nonetheless welcome, return to the old (1930s) Saint from the sanitised and lobotomised G-man of the War years.In the first story, set in Chicago, the Saint works to find the brain behind a protection racket; in the second, he unravels the mystery behind the rise of an apparently talentless New York boxer.Both stories, unusually at this late date, also feature Patricia Holm and Hoppy Uniatz â€” the latter in particularly fine form.P.S. For a list of â€” and discussion of â€” all Charteris's Saint books, see my So You'd Like To... Guide.

Craobh Rua ("Red Branch" in Gaelic) deserve to be a lot better known than they are, being comparable in terms of musicianship with the best of other Irish folk groups.  After seeing them in concert, I made a point of getting hold of all their albums so far, which consist of:1990 Not a Word About It1992 The More That's Said the Less the Better1995 No Matter How Cold and Wet You Are As Long As You're Warm and Dry1997 Soh It Is2000 If Ida Been Here, Ida Been ThereTheir line-up on the present album is...Michael Cassidy (fiddle)Brian Connolly (tenor banjo & mandolin)Patrick Davey (pipes, flute & whistles)Aaron Jones (cittern, guitar & vocals)...the first two named being the nucleus of the group from its inception.All of the albums are good, but this one is my favourite owing to the inclusion of Aaron Jones, who is one of my favourite singers, on top of being a wonderful cittern-playerFor my money, too few Irish groups feature the tenor banjo: DÃ© Dannan definitely lost something when Charlie Piggott left, and now Barney McKenna's gone, too.  The sound of the banjo alongside the fiddle and/or pipes is wonderful, and Craobh Rua really drive.So full marks from me.The occurrence of so many locomotive-related titles in the instrumentals is due to their being composed by Patrick, who is a train-spotter (or rather, railway enthusiast).UPDATEThere's now also a 6th album:2014 I'd Understand You If I Knew What You Meant

Aaron Jones is best known as a member of Old Blind Dogs; but he first came to my attention as a member of Craobh Rua, with Claire standing in for their fiddler Michael Cassidy, who was indisposed.  It was that concert that decided me to seek out their duo effort.Aaron plays bouzouki* and guitar, and Claire plays fiddle, flute and whistle.  Both sing, and there are several guest musicians.It's an enjoyable album, with plenty of variety.  My particular favourite is "Saints and Sinners", but give the MP3 samples a listen and judge for yourself.The complete contents list (with medleys expanded) is:01) Flowers of Brooklyn/Tom McElvogue's NÂº 6/The Highest Hill in Sligo02) The Smiling Bride/The Night Before Larry Was Stretched/Larry Redican's03) Saints and Sinners04) La valse des pastouriaux/Tralalavalsen05) Across the Western Ocean06) The Road to Durham/The Crib of Perches/Tripping Down the Stairs07) When Fortune Turns Her Wheel08) Denis Ryan's/Guzzle Together/Paddy O'Snap09) Slip Jigs and Reels10) Peter Murphy's/Kitty Got a Clinking Coming to the Fair/The Bottle of Whisky11) Lament for the Kerry FishermanTrack 9, somewhat unexpectedly, is in fact a song.The total time is 47'52".*I should myself call it a cittern, in so far as there is a distinction, since it has five courses rather than four.

This is one of the greatest recordings of Flamenco ever made!Although Carmen (1913-1963) was of course primarily a dancer â€” THE female dancer of the century â€” she was also an excellent singer with a marvellous Gypsy voice.  Although they performed together for decades, she made only two albums with the amazing Sabicas on guitar (the other being "Queen of the Gypsies"); but they show what he was capable of as an accompanist: the rhythm the two of them generate (e.g. on the BulerÃ­as or the Jaleo Canastero) is nothing short of phenomenal.Tracks 3, 5, 6*, 8 & 9 are solos by Sabicas, foreshadowing the career which would for many years make him the World's greatest flamenco virtuoso.Carmen is the singer on most of the other tracks â€” fortunately, as she's considerably better than the rather mediocre Domingo Alvarado, who never the less performs adequately on the final one.I know of no album that's conveys the tripartite essence of Flamenco better than this.  A landmark recording.*Sabas's brother Diego plays 2nd guitar on track 6.CONTENTS01) BulerÃ­as  Â«Cuando pa' Chile me voyÂ»02) GarrotÃ­n03) Tiento a mayor y menor04) Jaleo canastero05) AlegrÃ­as06) Fandango de MÃ¡laga07) Colombiana flamenca08) Danza Mora  Â«Amenecer Ã¡rabeÂ»09) RondeÃ±a  Â«Lamento gitanoÂ»10) SevillanasThe total time is 39'52".There is also an MP3 version; but the record company appears to have made a hames of the product information, and it's under Sabicas's name, not Carmen's.  I'm unaware of any version on CD.

It was disappointing when this arrived and the instrument had loose parts in the protective bag. It appears the parts were not soldered correctly (after reading other 1-star reviews other buyers had the same experience). See photos below of the unattached parts. It's disappointing to arrive in this condition and I'm not taking a risk by replacing with the same brand and model. My concern is durability and after reading other 1-star reviews I see there are some quality issues. I've returned this item one day after it arrived.

I'm a fan of this case and as you'll see my attached photos, I own the black case and different design inserts. The red case is durable and one feature I really like is the  "snap" sound it makes when I insert my phone. I don't need to wonder if the case is secure because the snapping sounds tells me so. Between the black and red case, I prefer the black. The red is youthful and not as stylish. When I place the red case on my gold iphone (thought I could get a San Francisco 49er theme going) the case was nowhere elegant. I added the "fan red" inset shown in photo and it helped style the phone a bit more. But when I changed to the black case and "fan red" insert I found the results more pleasing than with the red case.Just as we each have our favorite drinks at Starbucks, we each have our favorite cell phone cases. I like the flexibility to create your own unique look with the OtterBox MYSYMMETRY. My favorite colors are the black frame and the "stripe pink tan" (first photo) or "practical diamond." What's your favorite combo design?

These notebooks were fresh out of the Amazon box when my teenagers immediately asked "Can I have them?" It's nearly impossible to please kids in this age group so I knew these are AWESOME composition books. I quickly saw the benefits of the cover colors... it's easier to organize classes or subjects. The cover material is durable and an improvement over the black/white traditional covers. These plastic covers are more water resistant and more comfortable too! They can be decorated with stickers and it looks really good with the solid cover. Creative kids and adults will like this added benefit. The size is perfect for backpacks or book shelves.The books do not lay flat when writing, so I had to hold down the cover with one hand and write with the other one. I tested this with my traditional black/white composition books and the results are similar.

Invisible: How You Feel Is Not Who You Are by Jennifer Rothschild is a book for women who struggle with feelings of worthlessness or lack of purpose. This book on significance is a case study on the relationship between Gomer and Hosea. It's well researched and the Biblical story is a background for modern application. Rothschild has a fun teaching style that is appealing to many audiences of every age group. Her method of turning ancient Scripture into modern teaching is impressive and commendable. It's a book about purpose and appealing to many women.If you've never studied the book of Hosea then you'll enjoy this teaching from Jennifer Rothschild. She speaks from the heart of a woman, wife, mother and friend. Many will identify with these roles in life and apply the message of significance and purpose right where they are.I'm giving the book four stars instead of five because this book is similar to Anonymous by Cindi Wood, or "The Invisible Woman" by Nicole Johnson. While the case study on Gomer and Hosea is different from these other two books, the theme of significance is similar and the message repetitive.If you like Jennifer Rothschild Bible studies then you'll enjoy her book "Invisible."I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€ LifeVerse Books is a participant in the Amazon Services LLC

The Power That Changes the World by Bill Johnson is a reflection of his preaching and teaching style. This book is easy to read yet salted with powerful thoughts between the pages. Each chapter applies a concept of POWER with an application for your community and world. Learn how to influence and lead through Biblical methods. Learn how to identify problems and apply power resulting in change.An important message in the book is how to be a light in a world of darkness. Another important message (and a favorite book quote of mine too!) is when Johnson says, "We are to reign with the heart of a servant, and serve with the heart of a king."I'm giving the book 4 of 5 stars because there is one chapter that I didn't like and I almost stopped reading the book. To write a fair review I continued reading past the chapter and discovered content worthy of praise. If you stumble on this chapter ...keep reading all the way to the back cover and be blessed. Another chapter elaborates on the blessings of God with the message "It is absolutely foolish and selfish not to pray for a life of blessing." Johnson then explains why blessings magnify favor and this may open the "prosperity gospel" theology debate.I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€ LifeVerse Books is a participant in the Amazon Services LLC

The product description says "Barlean's Organic Oils Joint Remedy Mountain Berry Swirl Supplement, 10 Pound" and I was curious why this product would weigh TEN POUNDS. This product is 11.2 ounces and not 10 pounds as advertised. The Mountain Berry taste is very sweet with 30 calories per recommended dose (two teaspoons). Two grams of fat per serving also! The first ingredient listed on the label is water, followed by an Omega-7 blend and other ingredients including "anchovy and/or menhaden."I'm not going to make a claim about the benefits for joint pain. As a member of Amazon Vine I am required to complete my review in 30 days and I think that is not long enough to experience the healing benefits. I have used the Barlean's Omega Swirl for more than a year (recommended by my naturopath doctor) and have noticed improved memory and focus from that product by the same manufacturer.I'm giving it 3 stars based on my past experience with the same manufacturer, but I cannot affirm the beneficial effects in just one month. The taste is not something I enjoyed, could be the xylitol flavoring.

At-A-Glance is one of my favorite planner systems so when I see their products I always stop and look inside the cover. Its more difficult to do this online- to estimate the weight, print size, cover texture. When the Meeting Notebook arrived my first observation is the texture of the cover. Its not smooth like most planners and have an appearance that resembles grey flannel. Concerned this strange cover might stain with a water spot, I did what any good reviewer would do and splashed some water from my CamelBack water bottle right onto this planner. Surprisingly, it did not stain or leave a spot! Very impressive!The cover is not study like most planners, so when writing on the Meeting Guide I found it helpful to put the pad on a desktop or flat surface.  The coil edge is white and my planner arrived with bent coils which I easily adjusted into their rightful place. I donâ€™t like the color or size of the coil edge. The paper resembles college-ruled binder paper, double-sided. An added bonus is a clear plastic pocket in the back of the planner. For professional use my personal preference would be a black cover or simulated leather cover, with a black coil. Others may prefer this more casual look of the gray flannel and white coil edge. Good design for the priceâ€¦I've never been disappointed in At-A-Glance products! I'm giving this one 4 stars instead of 5 because I don't like the color of the cover and coils.

For more than a year I've been using the older version of this product (De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker) and so my review is a comparison of the two versions. This new version has a deep cup tray, allowing for taller coffee mugs or latte cups. ON the older machine I would have to use a cappuccino cup to get espresso of the old one and then take it over to another coffee pot to get hot water.  With the new version (shown here) I can get espresso and hot water from them same machine. The new version (shown here) has a really easy to read "on" button which the older version does not have.Added features on this new version also include a cup warmer, a nice feature so I'm not adding hot espresso into a cold cup. Water heats faster in this new version. One downside is that the older version has a better steam-control knob and the new version (shown here) has only the on/off button for steam.Enjoy your espresso machine- make it a coffee day!

Bathsheba by Angela Hunt is a retelling of the Bible story in a fictional perspective. Historical characters are brought into modern storytelling and the author's imagination. In this fictionalized story, King David's wife is introduced in her family setting and then brought into the Biblical setting.If you know the Biblical story, lust and self-indulgence are key components of the message. Author Angela Hunt brings her readers just to the point of physical intimacy, using graphic imagery, and stops. She does not cross the line and keeps her bedroom scene imaginative.As a theology student I did find the fictional book stretching the imagination beyond the pages of Scripture. It's entertainment not theological.Fans of Angela Hunt writing will enjoy the book.I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€

While the book "Survive or Thrive" is written primarily for pastors, I found it to be an excellent and informative resource for ministry leaders too! The book is divided into two sections based on the book title. "Survive" covers topics such as hiding your real identity, avoiding isolation, thorn in the side and community. "Thrive" includes coaching, mentoring, counseling, friendship and more. Many concepts are derived from the PastorServe website and community. Transparency is woven throughout the book and Jimmy shares deep conversations.The book is written with the message of Christian love, while at the same time confronting and convicting pastors and leaders of their weak points. It's not a shaming or condemning book to read, and addresses hidden struggles. The target audience is primarily men and mens issues, where women are identified in their roles as "pastors wives" and how the men can minister at home.My favorite feature in the book is the chapter endings. Each one includes a set of very powerful questions:Reality questionsRewind and review questionsReflection questionsRemember questionsRespond questionsWhile many of the questions are personal for private journaling and mentoring, a few might be useful for team building your ministry staff. Many included related Bible verses for discussion.Also included in the book are infographics for emphasis and effectiveness. Use the book for individual study, mentoring, coaching or as the foundation to helping pastors in your community.I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€

If you're a follower of Hillsong Church and Hillsong United Music then you'll like the "Live, Love, Lead" book from pastor Brian Houston. This book is an encouragement for anyone in ministry or leadership. Houston sets the stage: "Living fully, loving completely, leading boldly- these are hallmark's of Jesus' time on earth. Whether you're taking baby steps or giant strides, walking on water or running on empty, wherever you are in your journey of faith, Jesus is the ultimate guide and companion."Using his own story as a backstage to the book, there are 20 chapters in this book including:** Life in the Faith Lane** Confident in the Call** Pioneering** Shame No More** The Narrow GateEach chapter begins with a verse from Hillsong Music, followed by a memory from Houston's life, and then his commentary. While the book structure resembles a devotional writing style (quote-personal story-commentary-action call) it's much longer and more informational than daily devotions. With 20 chapters I found the book required more time and it took me almost a month to read the entire book using my reading method of "one chapter per day."I've highlighted about one-fourth of the words from Brian Houston- he's a convicting author with a powerful and transparent message to share. While I do not know his church history this side of the ocean, I did find it fascinating to discover the challenges he met with Jesus on his journey of obedience and faith. Many of my Christian friends are also reading this book and enjoying it too!I gave the book four stars instead of five because it took me a LONG time to finish reading it! This busy #CaliforniaMom reads many books a month and this book slowed down my progress.I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€

Perhaps you know Laura Story from her beautiful songs? When you read her book "When God Doesn't Fix It: Lessons You Never Wanted to Learn, Truths You Can't Live Without" you'll have a deeper appreciation for the passion behind her words.  The book addresses the challenges of living and loving someone with chronic illness. Sharing her intimate and painful story, this book is a raw look into the challenges  and causes of mental illness. I saw many similarities in her story with my stepdad who struggles with multiple sclerosis and similar brain misfirings. The emotional rollercoaster family members ride in a journey of healing and acceptance is well documented in Laura's book and her music too!The book is encouraging and yet unfiltered truth. Woven into her story is the love of God that surpassess all human understanding. Recommended reading for anyone who loves someone with chronic or mental illness.I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€

My mother-in-law wanted a Bible for her birthday and when I asked what features she wanted I was given these instructions: "I don't want any 'thee and thous,' nothing heavy for me to hold, and easy to read." After extensive research I found the Holman Large Print Personal Size Reference Bible with Index. Unsure what color she would prefer, I ordered this Bible in all three colors: Pink, Teal and Purple. Her favorite (and mine too) is the teal color.The cover is soft and comfortable to hold. The font is large and easy to read, with ample spacing between lines, and red letters for the words of Jesus. Margins are non-existent and there is no place to write study notes because the columns are 1/4 inch apart.The front of the Bible includes a Certificate of Marriage for recording your "Holy Matrimony" and includes two signature lines for witnesses. Also included in the front ate two pages for births and one page for recording marriages and another for deaths. An attached ribbon is the same color as the Bible cover and can be used to mark your most recent reading location. The index tabs are color coded to divide the Old Testament and New Testament. A simplified concordance is included in the back of the Bible, along with eight colorful geographic maps.Each Bible color has a unique and pretty pattern on the cover. The pink Bible is more of a raspberry color. All three colors are beautiful. Size estimate is about 8.5 x 5.5 inches. I would buy this again for gifts, or donations to local nonprofits, women's shelters, and church members in need.

My mother-in-law wanted a Bible for her birthday and when I asked what features she wanted I was given these instructions: "I don't want any 'thee and thous,' nothing heavy for me to hold, and easy to read." After extensive research I found the Holman Large Print Personal Size Reference Bible with Index. Unsure what color she would prefer, I ordered this Bible in all three colors: Pink, Teal and Purple. Her favorite (and mine too) is the teal color.The cover is soft and comfortable to hold. The font is large and easy to read, with ample spacing between lines, and red letters for the words of Jesus. Margins are non-existent and there is no place to write study notes because the columns are 1/4 inch apart.The front of the Bible includes a Certificate of Marriage for recording your "Holy Matrimony" and includes two signature lines for witnesses. Also included in the front ate two pages for births and one page for recording marriages and another for deaths. An attached ribbon is the same color as the Bible cover and can be used to mark your most recent reading location. The index tabs are color coded to divide the Old Testament and New Testament. A simplified concordance is included in the back of the Bible, along with eight colorful geographic maps.Each Bible color has a unique and pretty pattern on the cover. The pink Bible is more of a raspberry color. All three colors are beautiful. Size estimate is about 8.5 x 5.5 inches. I would buy this again for gifts, or donations to local nonprofits, women's shelters, and church members in need.
