I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255: â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€

I reviewed the WHITE Humidifier. The device is compact and does not take up excessive space like the other products I have used. Our air is extremely dry with the California drought and we are having unusually warm weather, yet when we finally turned on the house heaters I wanted to add moisture to our home. After reading the user manual, I made sure to place the appliance away from electronics (big concern) and away from my shuttered windows. I filled the humidifier with regular tap water, though the user manual recommends distilled water to prevent "white dust" on the furniture. For product testing, I put the humidifier to the maximum setting- turned the knob all the way to the right. I checked the appliance every few hours and highly recommend this because one reviewer said her unit leaked! I ran the humidifier for TEN HOURS to see how long the water tank would last, and finally turned it off when my carpets were wet from moisture. The air was significantly improved: less coughing, less sneezing, and dry mouths were improved. I will continue using the device, however now that my product testing is complete I will use a MEDIUM setting and most likely switch to distilled water.

"JumpStart Your Leadership" by John C. Maxwell is a easy book to read and digest. You can read the entire book in just over one hour, or you can read the daily tips for three consecutive months.The book content was originally published in Maxwell's "The 5 Levels of Leadership book."As you read the book, it's obvious this is a summary of another book with larger ideas. This jumpstart concept is divided into 90 ideas. Each idea begins with a short paragraph and is followed by a leadership question for reflection. Here are some of the leadership questions from the book:>>> Write down one positive thing you can honestly say about each person on your team. Then take the time during this next week to compliment each person with it.>>> Consider a candid conversation you have had that did not lead to a positive result. If you could redo the conversation, what might you say differently to emphasize the personâ€™s potential and how you could help them reach it?>>> Are you avoiding a difficult conversation you know a team member needs? Why? What step will you take today to discuss it with them?These would be good journal prompts for leaders, or agenda items for a team meeting.The book is similar to a devotional in format and structure, however it's leadership-based and not faith-based.. Each day begins with a leadership quote, followed by a short paragraph based on Maxwell's book The 5 Levels of Leadership, and concludes with a journal prompt. It's very simplistic and easy to use.While seasoned leaders might find the book too basic, the audience is geared towards newer leaders starting their careers. It's basic material rather than deep wisdom. There were a few times I wondered if John Maxwell was the author or if the book was written by someone else, perhaps by an editor. For a deeper study, read Maxwell's entire book "The 5 Levels of Leadership" and use this as a supplemental action plan.

I have two medium-size dogs and both dogs love the Cesar Home Delights Wet Food. They enjoy all flavors and after using this product for about two months, I've observed a noticeable change in their fur! Their fur is much softer and less coarse, with a shiny coat we have not seen before. They are thriving on this pet food!There are differences in the "flavors" so test them out and see which flavor your dog prefers. I am able to split a container of the more dense flavors between two dogs. They each get one-half a container morning and evening, mixed with a small amount of dry food and sometimes warm water. You can feed them the Cesar Home Delights Wet Food without adding dry food or water; this is a personal eating habit for my dogs. Feed one full container if you are not adding dry food. The beef stew flavor is watery... less dense, so I need to give each dog a full carton of the food, morning and evening. There is a noticeable odor from the potato in the stew, so if your dog's "gas" is overwhelming, try a different flavor.I will continue buying this product...my dogs look beautiful!

Bring back the old formula for Joico Daily Care! Just like another reviewer stated, this one strips my hair and leaves it flat and without volume. The previous Daily Care had an enriching conditioner combined in the same bottle, and I was able to use a single product daily, I have normal hair type (not dry, colored or oily). I also ordered the "grey bottle color" here on Amazon and had the same results.I've talked with local beauticians and beauty supply stores and they as so confused with the color-coded bottles, name changes and re-branding of this company products.If anyone has suggestions for an alternative to this product please advise in comments below. I am looking for a product that can be used daily, add volume, and not strip my hair. Thank you!

Women's Ministry in the 21st Century: The Encyclopedia of Practical Ideas is a handbook for new and seasoned ministry leaders. As a founder and ministry director for online Bible studies, I was excited to buy this book and learn from it. The book was overflowing with ideas and bursting with creativity. There are almost 250 ideas for leading women in this book!  The book sections include:Friendship and FunServing OthersSpiritual GrowthTen-Minute DevotionsBible StudiesMovie Club/Book ClubCelebrations and EventsOutreachRetreatsLeader Helps (forms)While the book is primarily geared for local ministries, with a little modification and creativity some of the ideas could be implemented for online Bible study and women's groups. This is an interesting handbook primarily geared towards fellowship, social activities and outreach. If you are looking for a book on leading a ministry or teaching Bible studies, this would not be useful for that purpose.

The budget-friendly KitchenAid KCAS10OB Aluminum Nonstick 10-Piece Set Cookware - Onyx Black is designed for use on gas, electric, and induction cooktop surfaces.  I tested my cookware using a gas stove. Potholders are recommended, though I found the handles were not hot and I only needed potholders when I removed the lids.  The 10-piece set is a beautiful and slick Black Onyx color. Included items are:8-inch skillet10-inch skillet1.5 quart saucepan and lid3.0 quart saucepan and lid3.5 quart saute pan with lid8.0 quart stockpot with lidI found the pots were generously sized, yet they were not too large to fit in the cabinets.  They seemed to be slower to heat foods and appeared to use more energy, however I've been using Magnalite Professional for 20 years and it would be unfair to compare this well-priced product to a higher priced product. Please read the other Vine reviews besides mine to see if there is a consistency in the heating time. The pots were very easy to clean, and I liked the clear lids for viewing the foods as they cooked. I'm giving my review 4 stars because the design, comfort and price are awesome.The pots include a limited lifetime warranty, see instruction book for terms and conditions. Make sure you save your purchase receipt for any warranty claim. Shipping note: the box is INCREDIBLY HEAVY. My husband is a weight-lifter and he struggled to get the box from the front door into our kitchen. We finally opened the box near the front door and carried the pots into the kitchen, one at a time!Happy Cooking!!

I was unable to find blank 3 x 5 index tabs in the local stores, so I took a chance and bought this online. My concern was the thickness of the paper, since the 3 x 5 lined index cards I purchased at Walmart were much too thin. It turns out the Smead Card Guide was very impressive...more than I expected. Thick quality so the index stands upright in my file boxes. The card does not bleed through and using a black Sharpie marker, I was able to write on BOTH SIDES of the index card. This product is well-priced for the quantity and high quality...highly recommend this and I will be placing repeat orders.

Cinnamon tea is a personal favorite, and after drinking Harney and Sons Tea Bags, Hot Cinnamon Spice in a local restaurant I was glad to find it here at Amazon. My restaurant tea was served in teabag form (not the satchel bag that other reviewers have mentioned) and the flavor was pleasing. My friend and I both enjoyed the taste and we each reused our teabags for a second cup.I enjoyed it so much, I kept the outer cover of the teabag packaging to remember the name and brand, then ordered it here on Amazon! I've been drinking Good Earth Original tea for years, and it's no longer for sale where I live. Between the two, the Harney and Sons Tea Bags, Hot Cinnamon Spice is a more blended flavor, where the Good Earth Original Tea has a very distinct cinnamon flavor. I've also tried the Tazo Sweet Cinnamon Spice Herbal Tea and found it tastes like "bark" and was not pleasing. If you're a cinnamon tea lover like me..try this Harney and Sons Tea Bags, Hot Cinnamon Spice! Where I live in California, we also drink our tea iced in the summer months and cinnamon teas are fabulous over ice!

The Republic of Tea, Get Wellness Tea is an absolute necessity in my home! My family drinks this during the winter months, at the start of a sore throat or a cold. We notice a fast response and shortened symptoms, especially when combined with a spoonful of honey. Perhaps its the proprietary blend itself, or simply the concept of warm tea and honey...yet it does work. I've noticed when we run out of this tea and drink other brands off the shelf, that we start getting sick again! This is one item I want in my cabinets all the time. I've just reordered it again. Locally, I have to drive 30 minutes to the store that carries The Republic of Tea. I'm glad to find this on Amazon!The flavor is great..not medicinal, not too strong, and not too weak!

My family really likes the Bath and Body Works Lavender Vanilla Bath Soak. The scent is relaxing and not overpowering, it's soft and gentle. Added to a bathtub of hot water, the steam from the bath combined with the soft lavender smell is a perfect blend for relaxation. It doesn't require a large "portion" to create the desired effect, which is good when you're raising two teenage daughters and products like this are a necessity in the home! When the kids have a bad day at school they know that a calming lavender bath will make it easier to sleep at night. It does take a few minutes for the crystals to dissolve, so swirl the bath crystals in the hot water before you enter the tub. This would make a perfect gift for a friend or yourself.

I'm on my 4th set of these pens, I use them often for Bible study and classes at Liberty University. Mine have NEVER smeared and I've never had problems with them, even living in hot weather of California. What I like most is the visibility...they work great on the thin pages of my Bible and do not smear. I also like the erase ability feature... the thin Bible pages do not tear when I erase a mark. I lean towards the darker colors for underlining my Bible and text books: greens, blues, pink, red, orange, brown.My daughter is an artist and I bought her a set of these Japanese gel pens for Christmas. She thinks they're fabulous and uses them often, especially the fine edge. They work great on the thicker artist paper and the colors are vibrant.The pens are very easy to hold and the cap snaps to the bottom of the pen so you will not lose it. I prefer the darker colors because they are more vibrant and easier to see when the page is covered with many words. The eraser feature is a huge benefit...if you want perfect lines and a tired hand slips off the page, go back with the eraser and then redraw the line!

What Your Heart Needs For The Hard Days  by Holley Gerth is a comforting devotional book for women. The book includes 52 devotionals, one for each week of the year.  Each of the 52 devotions begin with a NIV Bible verse, then a personal story from Holley, and words of encouragement. She takes a hard look at her most difficult days, and rewrites them through a heart filter based on Jesus. Her beautiful writing style is conversational, as she shares her story and then encourages the reader to write down her own story. Journal prompts begins with "What My Heart Is Saying to You...." and end with "What My Heart Is Hearing From You." After 52 weeks or 52 days of journaling your heart, you will discover a heart makeover!Some of the Devotions Include:**  God Wants to Lift You Up When Life Lets You Down**  God Is Thinking About You Today**  God Will Give You Courage Not Condemnation**  God Won't Let You Fall**  God Doesn't Want You To Try So HardThe book assumes the reader is having a hard day (as the title suggests) and is written with the purpose to lift burdens and give hope. It would make a terrific book for a friend in need. Add to a care package with a box of herbal tea and give as a gift to someone you love.I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€

Good Leaders Ask Great Questions by John C. Maxwell is a basic leadership book. The focus of the book is in alignment with the title. Maxwell uses examples from his own leadership experience, sharing successes and failures. The common theme of asking questions is divided into to parts: Questions John Maxwell Asks and Questions Leaders Ask Him. Most emphasis is placed on answering questions from leaders, such as:**  What must I do to lead successfully?**  How does leadership work?**  How do I get started in leadership?**  How do I resolve conflict?**  How can I succeed?**  How can I successfully navigate leadership?The book is informative, yet some of his other books are much better. This book reminded me of a summary of coaching calls or perhaps a solution to managing coaching clients. The structure is repetitive and the book loses it uniqueness after the "Ask question" concept is grasped. I'm a huge fan of John Maxwell books, yet I found this one a bit too simplistic and geared primarily to new leaders.Maxwell's The 21 Irrefutable Laws of Leadership is excellent and one of the required books for my pastoral leadership class at Liberty University. Failing Forward is my favorite Maxwell book and I've recommended it many times to friends. I've read both of these books several times and they will continue to be reference books in my leadership library!I received this book free from the publisher. I was not required to write a positive review and the opinions I have expressed are my own. I am disclosing this in accordance with the Federal Trade Commissionâ€™s 16 CFR, Part 255 : â€œGuides Concerning the Use of Endorsements and Testimonials in Advertising.â€

The Philips Sonicare HX3631/06 Powerup Battery Toothbrush, Medium was rather disappointing. I found the motor noise very loud, my husband could hear it downstairs and thought I was drilling holes into the wall. The vibrations are very rough and the drawback to the noise and hard vibrations is that I wanted to QUIT brushing as fast as I could, to eliminate the loud sound and the harsh pressure on my teeth. The final frustration is the size of the bristles.,..they remind me of the toothbrushes I bought my kids when they were toddlers. The brush head is so small, that I found I had to move across my teeth several times...like brushing my teeth with a toddler brush. I've been using the Oral-B Pulsar 3d White Advanced Vivid Soft Toothbrush and in my opinion it's much better. Less noise, right pressure on my teeth, and good brush size.

I'm allergic to most eyeliners and even expensive mascaras- such as Bobbie Brown- so I stopped wearing eyeliner and eye shadows the past 5 years. When I saw the Jillian Dempsey Natural KhÃ´l Eyeliner, Rich Brown I was intrigued by the product description and decided to give it a try. Let me just say, I LOVE THIS. The product is easy to apply, even with my contact lenses on. It smudges into a beautiful eyeliner very easily, and has a smoky brown color that looks natural. The smudge tip of the brush is really effective. The product stays on all day long and does not smear or flake into my eyes (and contact lenses). The packaging was a tad disappointing, the box is flimsy and by the time it was delivered by US postal service, the box was crushed and ripped. The product inside was in terrific condition and I will definitely reorder Jillian Dempsey Natural KhÃ´l Eyeliners!

As a Christian Ministry leader, I found the #BEMORE book by Sandi Krakowski a pure delight to read! The unique format includes 77 different themes with proven and powerful techniques from Sandi. I purchased both the Kindle and hardcover book, and I love both formats! The hardcover is a beautiful cranberry red printed on high quality paper...PERFECT for gift-giving!The book is divided into five parts:Part One: Be More Connected to GodPart Two: Be More In Tune With YourselfPart Three: Be More Attentive To YourselfPart Four: Be More Engaged With Your CommunityPart Five: Be More Mindful Of Your WorldThe book structure is similar to a devotional, yet it's business oriented and instead of daily Scripture verses and prayer, the days are arranged by "secret number."  The writing style is energetic and positive, so the exclamation point is used frequently!My favorite feature in the Kindle version is the "Tweet this" quote and #BEMORE link. The book is interactive and fun with this added feature.I found the #BEMORE book enjoyable and easy to read. I like the structure and format, and chose to read a few "secrets" per day rather than plow through the book like a novel. It's a book I will reference again and again.*********************************10 Quotes from The #BEMORE 77 Secrets To Your Powerful Life book #TweetThisWhen we place too much value on what others have, we become dissatisfied with our own gifts and blessings. Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREOne of our biggest barriers to success is our tendency to prepare for failure. Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREWe forget who our God is and how great He is when the devil comes and brings his doubt and fear. Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREShutting out the devil's chatter and tuning in to God's promises will allow you to BE MORE. Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREAsk heaven to shut the door on the lies and deceit. Sandi Krakowski #BEMORESTOP doing things that war against your soul, and start doing more things that make you strong!  Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREWe have to do the work of a champion to live the life of a champion. Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREPerfection is overrated, and perfectionism is a sorry master to serve. Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREBoxes don't hold lives and cages aren't good places to store your dreams. Sandi Krakowski #BEMOREWhen we make right choices, no matter how hard it is, we will receive blessings. Sandi Krakowski #BEMORE**********Disclaimer: I purchased a Kindle AND a printed version of the BEMORE book by Sandi Krakowski. I was so excited by the book, I later asked Sandi to be on her "book launch team" and she agreed. :-)

I'm reading this fasting journal for the THIRD time and highly recommend it! The format is simple to use and begins with a summary of Biblical fasts: Esther three-day fast (Esther 4), Daniel 21-day fast (Daniel 10), Atonement fast (Leviticus 23), Battle fast (Judges 3), Lifting judgement fast (1 Kings 21), Healing fast (Isaiah 58), Dominion fast (Matthew 4).You'll want to read the "Fasting" book by the same author, to help understand these types of fasting.The journal begins with a daily devotion, a reminder of fasting tips from the related book, and thoughtful questions for reflection. The printed journal has adequate room for writing your responses, however if you are using the digital version then you'll want to write your answers in a composition book or notebook. The daily journal ends with a pray and then an action item.This is an excellent tool to follow when fasting. If you're choosing a 40-day fasting period, then follow this with "The Fasting Edge Journal" another 21-day journal by the same author.

I know this TV had some serious light-bleeding issues when it was first released. In fact, I'm assuming that the revamp is the main reason these were released to Vine - so that the fix could be noticed and the reviews could note that. We have had ours up for roughly a month with absolutely no signs of light bleed at all. However, without knowing when they other reviewers began to experience it, I will say that if that changes, I will update my review ASAP. For this price, there shouldn't be such serious flaws.Now, on to other parts of the review. The TV came extremely well-packaged (as it should). No signs of any issues there. Installation was a breeze, though my husband might argue that point simply because he's the one that had to hang the thing. Maths, you know. The instructions were easy to follow, and the videos on Sony's website were very helpful. I like that it has the option to hang or to sit on a cabinet, and we honestly didn't know which we were going to go with at first.Set-up was also a breeze, though longer than I would have liked. There were updates right out of the box, which is typical these days for electronics that hook up to an internet connection. No worries there - but the update felt like it took forever. So just be aware that if you're in a hurry, you might want to wait until you're not. But getting everything set up was extremely simple - once the updates were done, I had us hooked up to Netflix, Amazon Prime, Google, and several other places within a matter of minutes. All those are pre-loaded as apps on the TV - which is great, because we haven't had cable for years. Hate paying the prices. We used to have a Fire TV box, but that is now upstairs in the play room since it is no longer necessary down in the living room.The tv comes with two remotes - a standard one and a smaller, more compact one. I primarily use the smaller one, but it does take some practice to use well. The Teenager spend a full 10 minutes one day trying to figure out how to do something, and in typical Teenager style, just kept pushing the main button part. *sigh*The picture is, frankly, incredible. The first thing we actually watched once it was hooked up was 'Planet Earth', and simply - WOW. I have no hesitations about saying this is the best looking tv we've ever had. It truly is incredible. We haven't tried the 3D yet, but frankly, I'm not sure I'm even worried about it. With the size of the screen (also the *largest* tv we've ever had) and the Ultra HD, we're pretty content.The sound - is fantastic. My husband's biggest concern was that the sound would not be very high quality because of the flat-panel, wall-mount, whatever. However, it really does sound significantly better than we had expected. Which is good, because we haven't hooked it up to the overhead speakers yet. But the things we have watched so far have all had great sound, bass included.The only minor nitpick that I have found is that of Google Photos. I use Google Photos to back up all my pictures. I am logged into Google on the tv. However, you cannot just access your pics on the tv (for slideshow). No, you have to create a slideshow online, then access it on your computer or phone, then GoogleCast it to the tv. Pretty clunky, really. I'm *assuming* this is because Sony wants people to use its online picture service, but...it doesn't play very nicely with Google either. I would happily have copied pics over to Sony, but it was a pain.Overall, I could not be more pleased with this tv. If it weren't for the weird Google Photos functionality, I would happily give the tv 5 stars with absolutely no question. If anyone knows a better workaround (I'm fairly technologically savvy, but I'm no expert), I'd love to hear it. Even better would be if they would just fix it. But in the meantime, we are loving watching movies in glorious Ultra HD.

Our backyard has been having...issues. Come spring, we will be tearing out the troubled spots and replanting them with grass. Unfortunately, it's difficult to test this product during the fall in the PNW, as the deluge season has arrived. I'm anxious to try this and update later with specifics, but so far I have learned a couple of interesting things:1. This stuff is seriously *expensive*2. The coating takes up literally half the product - which means you're actually paying for only 20 pounds of seed.3. I didn't realize this when this was offered to me, but while this particular version is recommended for a wide swath of the US, it does NOT show up as premium for - you guessed it - the PNW. Oregon and Washington have their own blend. Had I known that, I would not have ordered this.As I said, I will be anxious to try this, but in the meantime, unless this stuff works amazingly well, I wouldn't buy it again simply because of the price and the fact that the coating takes up so much of what the buyer thinks they are getting.

What happens when you're 12 and the person you have always considered your best friend dies suddenly. You don't find out for two days, and - even worse - you never have the chance to say goodbye. Nor do you have the opportunity to apologize for your last act - meant with the best of intentions, but not received as such. When maybe you're a little different than the average 12-year-old girl, and you suddenly learn that a rare jellyfish is migrating north and the sting could be unnoticed. If you're Suzy, you begin to research that jellyfish in order to convince everyone - but mostly yourself - that things *don't just happen*.While the book is a middle-grade level book, the story contained within is appropriate for all ages. It is unique and absolutely beautifully written. Suzy has a voice that is all her own, but her struggles to accept the death of her friend and what that means for her own life, are universal. The book is divided into parts that have sections within them. Each part begins with instruction from Suzy's science teacher about how to do a scientific research paper. Then the sections alternate between Suzy's research and her remembrances of her friendship with Franny throughout their 12 years. In a sense, the book is a scientific research paper regarding love, loss, and acceptance.The characters in the story are so beautifully...human. As a parent, I know that "sometimes things just happen" has crossed my lips - and never have I appreciated that internal struggle that it could cause in someone who strongly appreciates order and reason. And yet...sometimes they do. Coming to terms with that can take years for some, and some never do. This is the beautiful tale of a girl who begins to learn that sometimes, things aren't what we want them to be, and change is just a part of life. An excellent book for a discussion of love and loss, and for any classroom, library, or home.

As a huge fantasy fan, and with a teenage son who also enjoys fantasy, I was intrigued by this game. After playing with members of the family, the overall rating is a 4. Two adults, the teen, and the almost-nine-year-old played together, and though everyone agreed the instructions were a bit complicated to start with, overall a great time was had by all.The bartering was one of the parts of game play that has the most potential to go either very well, or be the most competitive. Once a dragon is killed, the players involved in that have only 60 seconds to divide the loot amongst themselves. If there are four pieces of loot and 3 players helped defeat the dragon, who gets that last piece? Does one player promise to give extra to another next time? The kicker is - if the 60 seconds passes, then *no one* gets the loot. Players can choose to help other players, or they can choose not to.The card system was deemed a little confusing, but nothing overwhelming. It just took some time for everyone to understand how (and why) the cards worked as they did and what could be done with them. A few games in, and everyone was much more comfortable with the entire game.Yes, we had an eight-year-old playing with us, and while it was confusing in some ways, she really enjoyed it. As long as the competition isn't too cut-throat, I don't see any reason that other kids that age wouldn't be able to play as well. Ideally, I would say 10+, even though the game says 12+. And for 3-6 players, it would be a great game for a fun evening in with friends.

'Concussion' is the story of Dr. Bennet Omalu, the neuropathologist who discovered CTE - the disease that is damaging/killing football players at a rate that would never be allowed in anything else. Dr. Omalu, whose role in the discovery has been largely ignored/forgotten/whitewashed, came from Nigeria having little to now idea how big a role football plays in our nation. When he discovered CTE, and published his findings, he was certain that the news would be welcomed as a way to save future players. Instead, he got a fast and furious lesson in how big business (Yes, the NFL qualifies) can spin stories and take over the narrative.This book takes a look at not only his discovery, but at Dr. Omalu as a person. His upbringing, who he is as a person, his motivations, and his convictions. Interspersed between the what the author has written are bits in italics - the words of Dr. Omalu himself. It's an eye-opening look at what shaped the man who, on nothing more than a whim, autopsied the brain of Mike Webster to discover the cause of Webster's crazy. It's also a heart-breaking account of what happens when the NFL and its fans put their money and desire for entertainment ahead of the health and well-being of those responsible for that money and entertainment.The writing in places feels a bit...off. It's sort of like how a person inexperienced in English would write, with the very short sentences and awkward dialogue. However, it's not often and in the overall scheme of the story, it does not do any damage. It is an interested tale, as evidenced by the fact that the movie (with Will Smith as Dr. Omalu) is coming out this December. It's also a tale that needs to be told, for the sake of those who are putting their lives on the line for a billion-dollar entertainment industry, as well as for the forgotten man who has continued doing his best to help them.Look, I am a football fan (not fanatic). I have a team I follow, and I root for them to do well. But I also believe that these players, not all of whom have multi-billion dollar contacts, are going to put their future health and well-being on the line, then the NFL has a responsibility towards them that has been lacking. This book makes very clear the science, the attempts to negate the science, and the outcome if something isn't done. Now the question is - are people truly listening?

I have three cats, an older one and two younger-but-not-quite-kittens. Our prior cat stand, that we have had for ages, was one tier and was purchased when we only had one cat. So I was excited to get this and give it a shot.The biggest thing is - this thing is TALL. I'm 5'6" and it's taller than I am. What this means is that putting the last couple of pieces on (if you're my height or shorter) WILL require a stool of some sort. It's also got a fairly good-sized base, so make sure you have the floor (and wall!) space. On a similar note regarding the size - the top tier has not been explored by any of the cats, I think because their just not sure exactly how to get up there. Everything else has at least been checked out, but...not that one.Putting it together was fairly easy. A tip - separate the bolts beforehand, and make sure you're grabbing the right post number, as they're very similar. Also, double-check the size of the rectangle when it calls for one, as there are three that have slight variations. Overall however, it wasn't difficult at all.The box this arrived in is HEAVY. Seriously. I'm pretty sure the carpet covers lead...ok, maybe just a lot of plywood. But if you have lifting restrictions, you'd better have someone available to help you. On the plus side, it seems pretty stable and I think it will last for a while. The carpet is quite plush (the kids love how soft it is), and the sisal seems like it's on there pretty well.The only other issue I noticed is a quality-control issue. There are a few places where glue was used that it sticks up fairly significantly. Not something that most cats are going to want to lay on. And on one piece, where a bolt screws up into the top of it, the bolt actually extends beyond the wood when it's tightened in all the way. There is fabric over it, but...it shouldn't do that.Overall, I think this will be a great addition for the four-legged goofballs. The youngest has already been quite active on it, and the others are slowly getting accustomed.

Dog Breath. Not to be confused with Puppy Breath, which is associated with all things cute and fuzzy. Dog Breath, on the other hand, could be associated with unwashed feet, rotten milk, and teenage body odor. In other words - EW. This is the problem that the Fresh Breath Drops are attempting to remedy, and the jury is still out whether it actually does much.I have a dog and 3 cats, and they all drink from the same bowl. I put the amount of drops required into the correct amount of water and...wait. I don't sniff the cat breath often, so I don't worry about that. The dog breath, well...it's hard to ignore when they stick their muzzle in your face for attention. It may be that after a couple of weeks there was a slight improvement, but I'm not sure that the cost effectiveness is really there. It's definitely easy to use, and none of my pets had any issue drinking the water with the drops in it, but 9 pumps per bowl means that I'm going to be going through this stuff like crazy.So, overall you probably should ask yourself - are you ok with unwashed feet in your face? Is there something else more cost effective that would be a more long-term solution? It wouldn't hurt for anyone to give it a shot, but with 4 animals drinking from the same bowl here, it just doesn't make sense.

Mikey is a regular kid, even though his mother is a political wannabe, his older sister is in his class, his town appears to be the epicenter for paranormal happenings, and his best friend is partially a God. Oh, and he has a disabling case of OCD. But what happens when you are the ordinary kid surrounded by extraordinary happenings? How do you figure out how to be "normal" amidst the chaos?Patrick Ness has written a book with a unique perspective, but one that seems so normal for every teenager living. Finding the extraordinary that is within us all, when everyone else seems to be "the special one" can truly be a challenge - and that challenge doesn't end when high school does. The voice of Mikey rings so true, even though I'm so far out of high school that I now have a high schooler of my own. The writing is honest, and the occasional Immortal floating around just makes the struggle to find what is special all the more poignant.The story is also done as a sort of story-within-a-story. Each chapter begins with a synopsis of the current goings-on in the battle of the "indie" kids against the Immortals. For example, the book begins:"Chapter The First, in which the Messenger of the Immortals in a surprising shape, looking for a permanent Vessel; and after being chased by her through the woods, indie kid Finn meets his final fate."The rest of the chapter then goes on with Mikey telling his story outside of the supernatural one. Each chapter begins the same, with an update on the supernatural battle at the beginning, before Mikey carrying on. It was an interesting way to both set the tone of the chapter, compare the differences in the "ordinary vs. extraordinary" in Mikey's view, and (honestly) giggle a little bit at the cliche stories of the regular kid who becomes the hero.Overall, it was a fun and mellow read with a great message. It's not a beat-you-over-the-head-until-you-realize-my-point kind of message either, which most teens and pre-teens would respond to. It's just...a good story.

i was looking for a nice watch for my husband, as he will not buy one for himself and his old workhorse is about ready to be put out to pasture. When I saw this one, I thought it would be great. He likes bigger watch faces and it's not flashy. However, it has its pros and cons.First - it's a nice watch overall. It keeps excellent time and works well. The metal band is quite nice, though maybe not for everyone.However - the band is HUGE. Seriously. We took it to a local watch place to have some links removed, and after the guy took out 6, he said that he couldn't take out any more...and it's still too big for my husband's wrist. Granted, he's not exactly a tower, but...you may need to be to wear this watch. In addition, he likes to be able to see his watch at any time, day or night. This is not going to work for that. Any light absorbed eventually wears off, leaving the wearer in the dark.Overall, it appears to be a pretty decent watch. But do pay close attention to your wrist size, otherwise you'll have a watch that you just can't wear.

My 8-year-old daughter is a competitive gymnast. She spends, at this point, around 10 hours in the gym at practice a week. One of her heroes is Gabby Douglas - who happens to be in this book.The book is perfect for a comfortable reader. My daughter is in third grade and has no problem reading the stories. The colorful drawings are nice, though sometimes a bit distracting from the story itself. The book is broken into three parts: It's Not Easy Being a Kid, Family Matters, and Practice Makes Perfect. The first two parts each have five stories, the last one has six. At the end of the book, there is a Bibliography for anyone who would like to do further reading on any of the athletes mentioned in the book.This book would be excellent in libraries, classrooms, and for any parent whose child has an interest in sports. Many of the athletes dealt with difficulties as a child that would also be helpful for some adults to use to encourage kids who may be facing their own struggles. Overall, I would recommend this for just about any child who is interested in sports.

Frankly, I hate carrying a purse. I'd prefer to just grab my phone and keys and go. So when I was offered the opportunity to try this wallet case out, I said yes. And so far, I'm fairly pleased.There are several things I like about this case - the ease with which I can take my phone in and out, the slots, and the magnetic closure. The material is nice looking - while it lasts. The way it fits my phone, including the cutout on the back. The fact that I can just have a small amount of cash and a couple of cards and be ready to go.Things I'm not so fond of - The material tends to start splitting in spots. It's not very sturdy. The "buttons" on the side that are supposed to be for the power and volume are not very easy to find, even when you're looking right at them. I can't count the number of times I have turned the volume up instead of down - the finger feel is simply not there. The sort of cheapish feel overall.In general, if you're one of those people who loves to switch out cases regularly and like this style, then you'll be all set. I tend to prefer to find a case and keep it as long as possible, so while I like many of the options of this case, it won't last as long as I would like it to. Also, something to remember - you're very limited (by design) with how much you can carry in a case like this. If you're prone to have lots of cash (or change) or like to have every member card under the sun with you, then this type of wallet will not work for you.NOTE: This case was offered to me in exchange for a fair and honest review.

We go through a lot of water bottles in our house. I have a teenager, a gymnast, an adult who travels a lot and me. Frankly, I'm not sure I could count in my head how many we have floating around right now. So I was a bit hesitant when offered the opportunity to review this one. And yet, it has turned into my absolute favorite.The biggest thing about this water bottle, for me, is the ease of cleaning. The bottom screws off, the top screws off, and the glass insert just pulls right out and can go in the dishwasher. The outer plastic probably can as well, but since the glass part does, I just hand wash it and call it good. It goes back together just as easily, and the silicone seal at the top keeps liquid from leaking in between the two pieces.The flip lid is easy to open and close, and I really like the little slide lock. I often slip my water bottle into my bag when I'm taking my daughter to gymnastics in order to carry everything, and it drives me crazy when a water bottle spout leaks or pops open. Haven't had a problem with this yet.The opening is also big enough for ice! Huge. Seriously. Our weather this past summer has been ridiculously hot and any drink un-iced didn't stay cold for long at all.I've dropped this a couple of times, and no breaking glass. My teenage son does the dishes and hasn't managed to damage it yet. So I must declare that it's a good, sturdy water bottle. Really, I like this one so much I'm thinking about getting one for everyone in the house and getting rid of a few others that are not nearly as good. I couldn't be more pleased.NOTE: I was offered this water bottle in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I do not have fine hair - more towards the normal side. But I'm always looking to add a bit more body, particularly since I don't do a lot to style. Wash, add a conditioner, maybe a curl creme, and let it go. I *might* blow dry on occasion, but that's rare. So I was curious about this shampoo in my longish, wavy hair.It definitely has given me a bit of a boost, though nothing significant. The smell is nice, though it borders on somewhat strong. It does tend to fade, though. Cleans without feeling stripped, works well for my lack-of-styling needs.Overall, I like it. It's not AMAZING, nor is it TERRIBLE. It's shampoo - but if it helps my regular hair, then it would more than likely be even better for those with fine hair.

I have longish hair with a medium texture that tends to dry wavy and then slowly straighten over the next couple of days. Since I prefer the wavy, I was curious to try this. I have to say, I really like it.A huge bonus - it doesn't smell massively strong. That might seem strange to start with, but the last texture stuff I tried was STRONG. This smells pleasant, and it tends to just fade away. However, the waves have been lasting longer than usual. I'm on day 2 now, and I could easily have another hair-down day (if it wasn't going to be in the high 80's). And while the instructions say to use this after regular shampoo and conditioner, I didn't bother with conditioner and my hair still feels soft with no sign of damage. While I probably wouldn't use this without my conditioner regularly, I wanted to see how it did.Overall, I like this better than most I have tried and think this will probably be a staple in my limited supply of *stuff*. I'm pretty low-maintenance, so if something sticks, that's a pretty darn good sign.

I'm always curious about the sprays that are supposed to resemble in effect what the ocean does to one's hair. So when this popped up, I thought I would give it a go. I have medium texture hair, fairly long, wavy when I let it dry naturally. I'm badly in need of a haircut, so I tend to get less wave than I would like. In this, the spray did make a difference. My hair was soft, and lightly wavy in just the way I like for roughly a day-and-a-half. It was simple to use - spray, tousle, then I went to bed and let it dry.So why only three stars? I cannot tolerate the smell. Some stronger smelling products sort of...disappear...after a while. Not this one. The smell was long and strong - pretty much as long as the spray was working. I can't quite pinpoint what it is, and some may like it, but it was just too strong for me. It was sort of like wearing one of those cheesy "ocean-scented" candles around my neck for a couple of days.Sadly, as much as I like the effect of this spray, I will not use it again lest my nasal passages spontaneously combust. Kind of a bummer, really.

It's not often these days that a book, particularly the first in an apparent series, comes in at a whopping 580 pages. Even less often does the doorstop turn out to be quite such an excellent read. Both cases hold true in 'Twelve Kings in Sharakhai', the first book in The Song of the Shattered Sands series. Be warned, however - there is a lot going on in this first book. Try to read it too fast (even though it's compelling), and you'll feel like you just came out of a book coma.Ceda is a young woman from the slums of Sharakhai, a city in the desert. She is also a "pit dog", one who fights in the pits for her living. She has honed her skills because she has a goal - vengeance. Finding the one responsible for the death and humiliation of her mother, and killing him. The problem? The one responsible is one of the Twelve Kings - rulers of Sharakhai for the last 400 years. Human, all. They can be killed. But they were "blessed" by the Gods with their long lives and their grip on the city. They are ruthless, and they want everyone to know it. When Ceda goes out on Reaping night against the law, she starts a chain of events that she, nor the Kings, could ever have predicted.First - the heroine. Ceda is a strong, clever young woman. She is human, and has her faults. But make no mistake - she is truly an excellent main character. She is well-developed, and battles with the same conflicting emotions and issues that all people grapple with. Only in her world, there is magic, Gods exist, and Kings can live 400 years. As for the other characters, they have also been extremely well fleshed out. There's not a one that I couldn't picture in my head. No one is a cardboard cutout...all have good and bad, and make decisions that reflect that.The setting - incredible. The details that went into crafting this world are amazing. From the sand ships, to the creatures that roam the desert, descriptions of the city and it's different areas and inhabitants. There was a lot of work put into this, and it shows. However, the truly pleasant thing as a reader is that it's never dull or dry. Everything is woven into the story, in context, in a time that is fitting. There are no crazy-long passages there just to tell the reader all about something. The author allows the reader to get a feel for the setting, then bit by bit brings it more into focus.As for the story, it's done just as well as the rest. It's a unique take on medieval fantasy, with elements from today thrown in (carefully) here and there. And yet it all makes sense and works with the characters and the surroundings. The characters and the setting are woven together so well that sometimes it can be hard to tell where one ends and the other begins. It wouldn't be a stretch to say that, in some ways, the setting itself - the city and the desert - ARE characters.Overall, I was taken aback when I realized how darn big the book was. Then I groaned. Then I put it aside for a few days in dread. Then I started reading...and once I did, it was hard to stop. And when I *did* have to stop, my mind was figuring out when I could get back to the book. Yes, I finished in a book coma. I had to give my brain time to fully absorb what I had read before I could go any further. I am still mulling over details and thinking on the story - and in my mind, that is the mark of a great book. When it's done, and you're moving on, part of that story has permanently made a place in your mind and your heart. So it is with 'Twelve Kings in Sharakhai'.

My husband has issues with dry skin, depending on the soap he uses. His favorite has always been Irish Spring, but it really dries his skin out - particularly in colder weather. So when this soap came out, I was curious to see not only if it would help with the dry skin, but if the smell would be too strong, overtly male, or just plain old ick.So far, hubby likes it. He really likes the smell, and I have to say - I do too. I have been using the soap, and it's not a "manly" odor, more a fresh one. It's sort of like the smallest hint of baby powder with green grass/leaves. It's not heavy or overwhelming, either.The dry skin issue has been reared its head, either. Granted, it isn't the middle of winter, but the soap hasn't been making things worse, at any rate. I tend to have horrible dry skin issues, and I haven't had problems either.Overall, it's a nice, clean-smelling soap that does what soap should do.

Alexander the Great. He's a figure of power, a lesson from the past. But what was he *before* he was all that? What was his life like as a 16-year-old, before he became "the Great" conqueror? This is the question that the 'Blood of Gods and Royals' series hopes to answer. In 'Legacy of Kings', Eleanor Herman makes a good beginning.Speaking of the beginning - it's a bit on the slow side. Have patience and bear with it. There is a lot of history here, and five different people who need their own backgrounds, motivations, and lives. It took me roughly half the book before I really started to get into the story itself. This is to be expected, as this is just the first novel in what promises to be AT LEAST a trilogy.The characters are written as teenagers, but remember - teenagers in Alexander's time would have been far more...mature...at earlier ages than those we are familiar with now. They married young, had children early, and often died young. Frankly, even though this is a Harlequin Teen book, it felt like it could have been young adults as characters. Each character is written well, and all of them pulled the element of surprise at least once during the novel. In other words - they are not written as predictable wooden things, but as young people whose motivations still are developing and whose lives are in constant upheaval. Herman did a great job with this (speaking as someone who has a teen at home).While this is historical, it is also a work of fiction. The history is definitely interwoven throughout, but so is the fantastical - amazing creatures known as myths, Gods who may or may not still exist, and magic that is both feared and revered. Again, Herman did an excellent job weaving together the factual and the fictional.Overall, it's a very well done look (so far) at what might have been when Alexander was young and magic may still have existed. I look forward to recommending it to my friends and to reading the next book when it comes out next fall.

Generally, I'm a rag/towel kind of person. I detest extra waste. However, I am married to a "use all the paper towels as quickly as possible" kind of guy. So, I was thinking of these as sort of a happy medium between the two. The fact that these are at least minimally recycled and in waste-free packaging is what sold me on trying them.So far, we've used them for wiping up spills, cleaning stair railings (and with two active kids and boneheads who painted the railing white...), cleaning gymnastic mats and wiping counters. They've done excellently at every task. They are sturdy enough to withstand the heavier wiping (stair railings), don't fall apart with lots of liquid, and give a nice cushion for the extra icky tasks (cleaning cat vomit). The extra bonus is that, maybe due to the heavy-duty feeling, doesn't tend to waste these as much as the paper towels, which means he's using less waste than he otherwise might. It's sort of a win-win all the way around.So, while I still tend to primarily use rags or shop towels to clean messes, these have definitely earned a place in our household for those not quite as environmentally conscious as I am :)

These are for my teenage son, who generally lives in athletic shorts. I don't (typically) have a problem with that, but sometimes something a little bit nicer is required. This jean shorts fit the bill.He is 14, roughly 5'6", and weighs I'm not sure how much. He tried these on and they fit extremely well. A small gap in the back, but definitely nothing really noticeable. The length is great, and they are not too tight anywhere. He can move around freely with no issues.I'm not sure we've ever bought him Wrangler pants or shorts before, but I have to say I'm very impressed with the way these fit. I would certainly but these in the future!

My husband tends to be like the Otterbox cases for his phones, and they have been great. However, when I saw this option, I thought it would be worth a try, since his job often has him in unpredictable weather and situations. He's had it on his phone for almost two weeks now, and I have also been using one on my phone. We recently compared notes and decided we both agreed on the high and low points of these FRE cases.First the good - we tested the waterproofing, and I can say without a doubt that I would trust my phone in this with no hesitations. Whether on a boat, or simply hiking through wet woods and streams, this case will keep your phone dry. It's also fairly sturdy and seems to do well against the standard knocks and drops. The touchscreen works fine, even through the top part of the case, though there is often a slight lag.Now the downsides - the sound is not the greatest. The volume level on the phone has had to go permanently higher in order to hear clearly. Since my husband works on trains, that's a permanent bummer...the noise level is already pretty high. In addition, if you like to use your phone for music or watching tv/videos, the sound quality is somewhat affected. It's not terrible, but it's not as high-quality as what you get with standard cases or just the phone, either.So. Those are the pros and cons as we have discovered them over several days of use. For some, the cons may not be such, and this case will be a fantastic purchase. However, at this point, whether we will continue to use the cases is up in the air. I don't like the slight lag, and the husband really struggles with the restriction in sound when he's working.

Cookbooks are my weakness. I mean, books in general are my weakness, but I read cookbooks like novels. Niche cookbooks I don't often get, simply because I don't always have use for them. However, cookies - well, that's different. Who doesn't have a need for cookies at multiple points in their lives? So when this popped up, I was excited to get it.As a general rule, I insist on make a minimum of three recipes from any cookbook before I review it. I don't personally feel that any cookbook review can be truly relevant unless recipes have actually been tried. However, since this cookbook is ONLY about cookies, and there are only so many cookies I need floating around my house at any given time, I tried two recipes instead of three.The first recipe I tried was a twist on the basic Oatmeal Cookie recipe. Instead of using raisins in the recipe, I added (per instructions) cinnamon chips instead. The method was a little bit different than my general cookies, but turned out very good. They were soft and not overly sweet. Both kids gave them a two-thumbs up, though they did wish I had added chocolate chips instead :)The second recipe I tried was a twist on the Chewy Double Chocolate Cookies - the Chewy White Chocolate Chunk cookies. Again, the methodology was quite different from any cookies I've made before, but they turned out incredible. Very chocolatey and soft, a hit all the way around.One of the things I particularly liked about this cookbook is the fact that each recipe has multiple twists to it, allowing for a variety of flavors with one basic recipe. The recipes themselves are well-written, and the instructions are clear enough for even a novice baker to follow. And the pictures, well...they are mouth-watering.Overall, this is a handy cookbook to have around for anyone who appreciates good cookies. Bake sales, holidays, or just to have a batch in the cookie jar - this cookbook will cover all the bases!

This is designed to be given in addition to your dog's regular food - 1/2 pouch for every 25 pounds, I believe. As my dog weighs just about 50 pounds, we gave the entire pouch. He loved it - licked it all off the top of the food before deciding to finish his kibble. It does, however, somewhat resemble cat vomit in looks and texture.I can't speak to the probiotic nature of this, as I was only given one pouch to test and that is not enough to determine anything at length. But based on my dog's reaction, if your four-legged friend likes to have soft food along with their kibble, then this would probably be a good one to try. Gentle on the stomach (noticed no extra gas), especially the pumpkin and oat mixture.

I don't have many dishes for entertaining, so I was excited to get this tray. I must say, however, that - even knowing the size - it surprised me when it was unboxed. It really is large. My husband has been entertaining our daughter with stories about how big the tray truly is. Aircraft carrier, holding the entire country of Monrovia...you get the picture.The tray is well-made and heavy-duty. It has a really nice feel to it, and the color is gorgeous. Would be great for a smallish turkey for Christmas, as a chip & dip tray for entertaining...the possibilities are numerous. There isn't a huge well in the center, so very liquidy foods would probably not be your best option.Overall, it really is a lovely tray. I'm pretty sure I wouldn't have paid $40 for it, so whether that is reasonable for others I can't say. However, I'm sure I will be using it tomorrow to take treats to a potluck, so it will definitely get used.

People dead and missing at an old school that takes in students from the local asylum. One person in particular a "person of interest". One person who may - or may not be - two people residing in one body. Not two personalities, but two actual souls, living in the same body since birth. Is it possible? Or is she crazy and imagining the second one? And what happened two decades ago that left the school a shell and lives forever changed?'The Dead House' is not written as a standard novel. It's written almost as a case-folder, with interviews, diaries, transcriptions, etc. used to tell the story. There are some pictures, but unlike some of the "mixed media" novels, these do not hold a prominent place. It's mostly reading. The only downside to this particular format in this book is that every new thing has a date and time - and sometimes, there are multiple entries in one day. Trying to keep that straight could be a bit of a handful at times.I found the story intriguing, the idea of "is she or isn't she" crazy, on a topic that most would say was full-on nuts. The element of mystery was there all the way through to the end (no spoilers!), and kept me guessing. While I wish there had been more of a solid ending, I will say that it did fit the rest of the book.Overall, while this is definitely a young adult book, I did enjoy it and would recommend it to a teen that I thought might enjoy it as well. There is some violence, a little bit of it fairly graphic, so be aware of that. It also deals with something akin to witchcraft, so if that's a concern then this book may not be for you. However, it's a good read and worth the time.

Ghostman. The term conjures up something that isn't really there - doesn't exist as we would think of it. And in the second book featuring Jack - the Ghostman - Roger Hobbs proves just how elusive a Ghostman can truly be. This time, Jack has been contacted for help by his former mentor, the one who taught him just about everything he knows. The one who disappeared several years ago without a trace. She's in a tight spot, and only Jack can help her get out of it.While 'Ghostman' was a novel that I quite enjoyed, I wasn't able to fully immerse myself in 'Vanishing Games'. The writing seemed strange in spots. The biggest issue that I had was that Jack, the expert, suddenly didn't seem to know much about several of the weapons used in the book. This is a man whose life depends on having more knowledge than others and translating that knowledge into a capacity for problem-solving and disappearing. So it was jarring to keep reading how he wasn't familiar with something. There also seemed to be more violence in this book. Not that I have a problem with violence in a novel if it fits the story line, but it seemed to me that Jack used more brains in the first novel, and significantly less in this one. Definitely made for a less interesting story.Obviously, I liked the first Ghostman novel enough to seek out the sequel. I'm not sure I can say the same for this one. If there is a third, and I'm guessing there will be, it will probably be a toss-up as to whether I bother reading it. If I do - it may end up being borrowed from the library.

I love to feed my hummingbirds. I have a few that come by, where their presence is announced by the cat. I have two feeders up outside, one closer to the house and one out a little bit. The birds tend to prefer the feeder further away, so that feeder always empties first. So when I decided to give this instant food a shot, I did a test. I put my regular sugar mix in the feeder closest to the house and the instant mix in the feeder further away. My thought process being that since the birds gravitate towards the one further away, that might give the instant nectar a better chance. Unfortunately, that is not what happened.At the end of the second day, the feeder closest to the house was completely empty. The feeder further away from the house was still 3/4 full. I observed, several times, the hummingbirds fly up to the feeder, hang around a minute, then move to the other one to eat. I don't know why, but this food just is not their preferred food of choice. Having said that - hummingbirds are definitely birds of habit, so it's possible that over time they might decide that the instant nectar is ok. However, I'm really not sure. And since it doesn't take long to throw some sugar and water in the microwave to make their food, and it's far cheaper than the instant nectar, I think I will just stick with my regular method.

What if angels weren't exactly what we thought they were? They still answer to a higher power, but...it's not exactly a gracious and loving thing. Even worse? Those angels are in league with the demons - and they were spawned the same way.This is what Robert Brockway has brought to life in 'The Unnoticeables'. A world where it is possible to see angels and demons, and even to become a "chosen one"...at the expense of your humanity and that of many others.The book moves between an unknown narrator, Carey (living in New York in 1977) and Kaitlyn (living in Hollywood in 2013-14), and illuminates how their lives intertwine in unexpected ways.The story itself is odd, creepy, sometime scary, and absolutely fascinating. There are definite parallels that can be made between the angels/demons in the book and some religions, though I'm not sure if that is what the author was going for here. Outside of that, however - it's just a really good story. The pace moves quickly and the stranger elements are woven into the novel in such a way that I never found myself questioning them. It is fairly graphic in spots - death and sex are not strangers in this book. I hate spoilers, so I won't give any, but I will say if reading that statement gives you pause, then this *might* not be the book for you.I believe it was Chuck Wendig that said this book is "Deliriously unhinged in the best way possible...", and I would have to agree with that statement. I didn't find the book "hilarious" as noted by someone one, so I wouldn't necessarily be looking for laugh-out-loud funny. But it had amusing spots, always tempered by a bizarre sober (and sometimes less-than) reality.Overall, I wouldn't say it was an absolute favorite, but I'm glad I read it. It's certainly spawned from a mind and an imagination that has to have been called "overactive" many, many times. It's a great read, and one that I would recommend.

I have been wanting a *good* smoker for quite a while, but can't afford the usual suspects. So when the opportunity to try this one came up, I jumped at the chance. And I cannot emphasize enough how glad I am!First impressions - the thing is flipping heavy. This is not something you'll be moving around a lot, so make sure you put it in a place that really makes sense. We have ours in a nook on the covered back patio, so that it's protected from weather. If/when it starts to get cold enough to freeze outside, it will go in the garage. It also feels heavy duty. I was a little concerned that it might feel flimsy, but that is not the case at all. The door/latch feels very solid, the shelves are a good weight, and the smoker box is heavy-duty. There is virtually no set-up (other than unpacking and putting batteries in the remote), though a new user does need to do a burn-off of the inside of the smoker. Very simple to do, needs no water or chips. Plug it in, set it up and go!Our first attempt at smoking was a whole chicken. We used one of the recipes that came with it, and used the temperature probe method. Having tried those flimsy box smokers before with horrible results, I was a little bit leery of what would happen here. However, I can honestly say that the chicken turned into one of the best meals ever. We used apple chips, and it turned out smoky, juicy, and golden.Next - a small pork roast. Used our own rub this time, and again used the temperature probe. Delicious and not dry at all. It's easy to set for the temp. and the probe, and it alternates between the two on the display so you can get an idea of where things stand. You should preheat it (has a cycle for that) and it works well. I did, however, learn the hard way not to lean to close to the smoker when it first gets opened up...eyes full of smoke. I smelled delicious but couldn't see for a while.Cleaning is fabulous. I scrubbed off the rack a little bit, then stuck it in the dishwasher. Rinsed off the drip rack/water bin and called it good.Overall, I couldn't be more pleased. It's an excellent machine that is easy to use and works very well. My husband can't believe that we didn't get one earlier than this.

Everyone has magic, some but...well, their magic is "wonky". It doesn't do what it's supposed to do when it's supposed to do it. So instead of getting into a premier magic academy, Nory (whose father is Headmaster at one such academy) is shuffled off to her Aunt's to attend a school with a new Upside-Down Magic class. Question being - is doing it "right" really what is important?This book was originally intended for my 8 1/2-year-old daughter. She got into the first chapter, then...set it aside and didn't return to it. I read it (as one must to do a proper review), and could see why she might not be all that enthused for a girl who is working on reading Nancy Drew. The writing is just ok - nothing that truly drew me into the story (and I love to read excellent writing, no matter the age range). The story had a few things that annoyed me..for example, the authors took great pains to describe the students as "light-skinned", "brown, probably Latino", and "Asian-American", among others. Don't get me wrong - I think diversity in anything is excellent. However, particularly for kids, it should be natural instead of being so emphasized and spelled out. Show the reader, don't tell them. Another thing is that, honestly, the story probably could have been cut a bit and still retained its overall message. Reading how one student turned into a rock over and over again was...repetitive. Kids will feel the same way, as a general rule. Make the point, then move on. They are a smarter audience than many authors give them credit for.As for the message - it's a good one, but again, the book is not subtle about it. And the ending (no spoilers) seemed a little unrealistic to me. Or maybe just naive?Overall, for a beginning reader, it might just do the trick. But it would definitely be a book that I would recommend checking out from the library instead of purchasing unless it becomes a great favorite.

If you're into Asian horror, you'll like this collection of three shorts. I prefer the visual style of Miike and Park Chan-wook to Fruit Chan, but Fruit Chan's Dumplings was better in this version than in the full-length feature version. Cut is mindbending in true Vengeance trilogy fashion as one would expect from Park Chan-wook. Miike's Box is beautiful and haunting, with a very disturbing twist. If you're expecting extreme gore because of the title, Dumplings delivers the most, but it's not really about that.

This bra is cute and does make with the massive cleavage; however, the straps only shorten on the back part of the strap, not all the way to the front. As a result, those of us who are short with big boobs (5'3", 34DD) aren't able to shorten the straps enough. Because of that, I always felt a little "low" and like my breasts might fall out. Other than that, I liked it. If you're taller, give it a shot.

This is the worst movie I've ever seen that I'd still voluntarily watch. The effects are crap, the events in the plot are disjointed, the premise is ridiculous, and the people who made it don't seem to know the difference between China and Japan (and why is France involved?). And for some reason, I'll still watch it when it's on. It's the proverbial train wreck.

I'd love to agree with the reviewing masses but I'm afraid I just can't. This movie wants to be intellectual, but it just can't quite get there. The female lead's endless charm can't make up for that fact. It just makes the film come off as pretentious swill. And the comic relief of Zac Efron is forced at best. It's hard to be insightful through such a thick cloud of cliches.

My Merchandising major was full of statistics classes. It felt like I have either a statistics class or an accounting class every single semester. Stats was SO difficult for me at first, and I was really struggling. With my 4.0 GPA on the line, I couldn't risk getting a poor grade in the course. If you're in the same boat I was, you really need to read this book.This book covers all the stats basics - deviation, probabilities, factorials, chi squares, etc. She even takes you back through mean, median and mode and makes visualizing data in graphs and scatter plots simple. It's written in a really easy to understand, step-by-step way. I (almost) enjoy Statistics now!

If your child or student is preparing for the NJ ASK test and needs extra work in the Language Arts and Literacy portion, this is the way to go. Not only do they have lots of practice test questions (THE best way to benchmark and prepare for ANY standardized test), you also get access to the Lumos app with the book. Use it with your smartphone or tablet to work more conveniently - my experience has shown that kids respond really well these days to content delivered electronically. The book is in line with all the Common Core Standards, so you can be sure you'll be learning the right lessons to succeed on the test. Enjoy and good luck!

Microsoft Excel has long been my favorite computer program: as a Merchandising major, Excel is very necessary in completing any number of financial reports or analyses. Statistics in Excel, however, was a daunting and new task for me. Luckily, I happened upon this book and thought I'd give it a try to help me deliver my statistical analyses better using Excel.This book was VERY helpful in my use of Excel 2007 since I have always used 2003 in the past, and since I've gotten 2007 I've had some confusion. It gives step-by-step, helpful instructions so you can't possibly get lost - and believe me, if anyone could I could! It even helps you make the professional-looking graphs that set your worksheets and reports apart from your peers. After getting this book, I love using Excel in my work and school even more and feel better equipped to deal with the statistics work that's coming my way.

I used to follow Lianne's blog back in the day, and she always offered great tips. I'm really happy to see this book because it's definitely an area of expertise for her - she seems to know best how to pull off the natural look. Awesome stuff! Love seeing bloggers get some success!

Fast-paced with a wonderful cast of characters, The Marriage Pact by M.J. Pullen is an engaging novel about friendship and love.Marci Thompson has made a career of temp work, but her latest job has lasted much longer than her previous gigs. The other big difference on this job is her six month relationship with her married boss, Doug Stanton. Their romance is exciting and passionate but being â€œthe other womanâ€ is beginning to wear thin. However, Marci continues to remain hopeful Doug will finally leave his wife and fully commit to her. When her thirtieth birthday rolls around, her college friend Jake Stillwell reminds her of the pact they signed ten years earlier that if neither was married by their thirtieth birthday, they would marry each other. Marci has always loved Jake, but she is also heavily invested in her illicit romance with Doug which makes it very difficult for her to know which man she should choose.Despite being a bit self-absorbed, Marci is a likable and mostly sympathetic character. She is ashamed of her affair and despite knowing she should end their relationship, she lacks the willpower to make a clean break from him. She has a long history of avoiding conflict and her knee-jerk reaction when things go wrong is to run away. A snap decision brings positive changes for her life, but it is not until she is on the verge of losing what she holds most dear that Marci reflects on what she truly wants.The supporting cast of characters is well-developed and for the most part, likable. Suzanne is Marciâ€™s best friend and she provides her with unconditional support. Jake is very sweet and just like Suzanne, he is willing to drop everything to help Marci when she needs assistance. Rebecca is the least appealing of the friends since she is more concerned with pursuing her own agenda than supporting Marci when everything begins to fall apart.The Marriage Pact by M.J. Pullen is a charming novel with a realistic storyline. The characters are multi-faceted with true to life flaws and imperfections. An entertaining read that will leave readers eagerly anticipating the next installment in The Marriage Pact series.I received a complimentary copy for review.

All Dressed in White is the latest addition to Mary Higgins Clark & Alafair Burkeâ€™s Under Suspicion mystery series. In this outing, the cast and crew of the cold case TV show are profiling the unsolved disappearance of a bride who vanished five years earlier.Television producer Laurie Moran is about to pitch her latest ideas for the next episode in her popular television show when Sandra Pierce drops by her office in hopes of convincing Laurie to feature her missing daughterâ€™s case. Dubbed the Runaway Bride, Amanda Pierce vanished without a trace the day before her destination wedding and no one has seen or heard from her again. Despite a thorough investigation, the police could not say with any certainty that foul play was involved in her disappearance, but Sandra remains convinced Amandaâ€™s fiancÃ© Jeff Hunter murdered her for financial gain. Once all of the members of the wedding party and Amandaâ€™s family agree to participate in the show, Laurie, along with her cast and crew, head to Palm Beach to reenact the events leading up to Amandaâ€™s disappearance in hopes of solving the case.Laurie is no stranger to losing a loved one to murder and she understands better than anyone Sandraâ€™s need for answers about her daughterâ€™s disappearance. Laurieâ€™s preliminary research supports the theory that Amanda did not leave under her own volition but with a plethora of suspects, which includes not only Jeff, but his current wife (and Amandaâ€™s best friend) Meghan White, and Amandaâ€™s sister Charlotte, Laurie still has a lot of work ahead of her. New clues emerge after reviewing the security footage from the hotel, but there is still very little evidence as to the perpetratorâ€™s identity. During the course of the investigation, it also becomes apparent there are several members of the wedding party who are harboring secrets they are reluctant to have revealed.The pool of suspects is vast and the information that Laurie uncovers does not help narrow down her list or their possible reason for murdering Amanda. Jeff is a natural suspect since he stood to gain a vast fortune in the event of Amandaâ€™s death. His rather quick marriage to Meghan also paints him in an unflattering light but does that also make him a killer? Meghan also falls under suspicion considering her marriage to Jeff but Laurie also discovers the two women were quarreling in the days leading up to Amandaâ€™s disappearance. Close friend Kate Fulton is afraid a secret she is keeping will be exposed but does this have any bearing on what happened to Amanda?  Jeffâ€™s groomsmen are obnoxious and seemingly harmless but their actions are also closely scrutinized throughout the investigation. A surprise suspect emerges after the wedding photographer remembers his assistant was not initially questioned after Amandaâ€™s disappearance. News about the murder of a student from the same campus where several of the key players attended college piques Laurieâ€™s interest but is there any connection between that long ago homicide and Amandaâ€™s case?Intricately plotted with a fantastic cast of characters, All Dressed in White is a cleverly written whodunit. This engaging and fast-paced mystery will stymie readers as Laurie and her team investigate their latest cold case in hopes of discovering the truth about what happened to missing bride Amanda Pierce. Another excellent collaboration from Mary Higgins Clark & Alafair Burke that old and new fans of the Under Suspicion series are sure to love.I received a complimentary copy for review.

No one writes better historical novels than Brita Addams so it comes as absolutely no surprise that her latest release, Beloved Unmasked, is another brilliantly written and well researched gay romance. Spanning several years, this first installment in the Cherished One series takes place in New Orleans and features David Reidâ€™s journey from abused son of a prostitute to well-respected lawyer.Despite his humble beginnings and the abuse at the hands of his mother, David Reid (aka Picayune) remains optimistic and determined to make a better life for himself. He is well respected by everyone he meets and he is not afraid of hard work. He has people looking out for him who encourage him to get an education so he can take a different career path. Once he makes it out of the district and realizes his dreams, David never forget those who helped him and he remains loyal to them long after everyone has moved on.Growing up in the red light district, David is no stranger to sex, but he wants more than quick, meaningless sexual encounters.
