So, check that out if you are in a similar situation and need the download URL.Additionally, the serial number needed for activation is only on the Windows disk envelope. Not a huge issue, but something to know if you are a Mac person - don't go running off with just the Mac disk thinking you have all you need for installation. A second installation detail is that the downloaded folders make it look like you can just drag the PE folder to applications and get going, but it's actually just an installer program (which is the Adobe norm) so you need to be connected to the internet and then run the installer. By the way, downloading the installer itself is about 1.5GB. Not a huge deal if you have a good net connection, but if you have "standard" service you may want to let it download and run while you are doing something else for a while. :-)Anyways, I am giving Adobe another star for getting back to me quickly and accurately. Good support! And, I already like the program a lot. If you are coming from 10, like I was, it is quantum leap time!**************************I am sure I will like this latest update to PE after I get a DVD drive to use with my late model MacBook Pro. The last year or two if MBPs do not have optical drives built in so you have to either get an external drive or use one connected via some other Mac that has optical in your network.I will revise my review once I get it loaded. In the meantime, it would have been great to have a download option that I could enter the key on the box (that had the dvd in it) to activate with. Or ship the program on a USB stick.

I've tested both this bulk package and the shaker bottle of this product. The shaker was first, and it did seem to help out my lawn as far as the bottle lasted. I had downgraded it because it didn't cover as much area for me as stated on the package. With this bag, however, it does seem to cover its rated area. I used a Scott's drop spreader. The results seem pretty good. The area where the product was greener a couple days after watering than it would normally have been.Anyways, I like the product, I think it works. I will monitor the lawn and post if it seems to be changing.

I really, really like wristwatches. I have reviewed several for Amazon and always enjoy finding out how the watch industry is pushing back against the ongoing erosion of their principle value (telling time) by the smartphone (or even cell phones, for that matter). Principally, there seems to be two ways the watch players market:1. Provide a certain style that is unique to the watch. Watches are thus becoming more and more of a fashion item.2. Provide a functionality that a smartphone would have trouble duplicating. e.g. super ruggedness, certain types of telemetry).The Swiss Legend that I am writing about here has a style that incorporates the outdoors/diver look with a flashy blue color ring which is made of rubber. It is big; really, really big. When I wore it to work, the team had to take a closer look because it is so much larger than the "normal" sized Seiko that my daily timekeeper. The black, brushed metal band looks  rugged and also evokes a "tough" image. The blue rubber is showy, but not too showy - looks like it is from the current decade. I am told that really big men's watches are "a thing" so, this one certainly meets. It is the largest watch I own, and that includes an Invicta diver's chronometer. Anyways, if you like this kind of style, and the look of quality, this is a great watch. It looks like it might actually sell for a few hundred dollars. (street price is actually much less, usually).One negative is that the watch is not only huge, but it weighs a LOT. It feels like the case is a solid chunk of metal. It probably is. I think they could have cut the weight down by a third and nobody would think it was a cheap and light weight unit. It's funny, nobody made so much fun of the size or look, but they all remarked that this is a HEAVY thing to have on one's wrist all day.Functionally, I have to take a star off because it does NOT have instructions to adjust the huge band. If you are at all technically inclined, this is not an obstacle, but you need to have a small slotted (why not Philips head?) screwdriver to pull the links off the band. The instructions recommend that you take the watch to an authorized dealer for this work. Really? Anyways, I was able to size it correctly, but if you are not a handy person, you should budget for this as an issue.The watch has a nice, water tight screw on crown. So, it might actually meet its 100m depth claim, but I didn't test that. It certainly adds to the macho diver aspect.Another odd thing is that although the lettering/numbering on the face is nice and large, the date window is not. I think it should and could be about 2x the size that it is. (OK, maybe 33% bigger would be OK). It gets lost among the other numerals and marks and is hard to see for an old guy w/o classes.The watch is easy to set and runs accurately on its claimed Swiss movement. I checked this out because most movements of "better than crummy, but not super" watches are made by a Japanese company called Miyota. All the references to Swiss Legend say it's Swiss. In any case, it sets easily, keeps time well and doesn't feel cheap when you set it.With all the size, weight and such, I would have liked a little more function in the watch, but it's still a nicely done device. I rate it a solid 4.So, overall, I rate this a solid 4

I believe that the unit I received for review is defective. All the online reports for this speaker state that it has great bass range and sound really solid. My unit sounds like the bass speaker (woofer) is not working. The midrange/tweeters appear to be working fine. SO, I should downgrade the Bass Sport to a one but am holding off to see if Nyne will fix the issue. I called the support center first thing this morning (9am). It is six hours later and I have not heard back.Pros:Easy to pair.Controls work great with my iPhone 6The built in microphone works well with Siri, and presumably on normal calls, although I have not tried yet.Cons:The bass appears to be broken. The online support was not helpful (mostly help for BT pairing, which was already OK).  I tried to see if using the Aux wire would be better - it sounded the same.  I adjusted the source (iPhone 6) to full bass EQ and it made no difference. Then tried all the other EQ settings and found that only the treble and midrange EQ had an effect. The iPhone works fine with my other headphones and speakers.The phone support never got back to me.The "black on black" keys are hard to see - I'm thinking of painting the raised symbols with white paint or ink.I will update when and if Nyne attempts to resolve the problem. To me, support for a >$100 speaker is one of the reasons you might consider it instead of going cheap. So far, Nyne is not passing the support test.

Due to the amount of time I have to review this product it is not yet clear how much it will help my lawn here in drought ridden California. However, I can say that I don't think the coverage rating is correct. The bottle says about 1300sf and I got more like 900sf out of it. Of course, it is possible that I applied the product too thickly since it is a shaker bottle, but I tried to keep an even rate of dispensing according to my interpretation of the instructions. If it turns out that the pets where I did get the product in the lawn do great in the next couple weeks vs the I applied portion, I'll raise it up a star.

I recommend this product, but it does not quite live up to all of its claims.Because I have a fondness for Ahava products, especially their hand cream, I was excited to try their mud mask which claims to deeply clarify and purify your skin. Additionally, the product claims to provide renewed freshness and a smoother complexion. Although itâ€™s difficult to determine whether my skin was deeply clarified and purified, my face did feel fresh which usually happens after I cleanse with a wash cloth. As for a smoother complexion, Iâ€™ve too many age spots and freckles to have a smoother complexion, but my skin did feel smooth and soft after the mud mask. Contributing to the smoothness is probably the gritty material in the mask. Surprisingly, the instructions say to rinse after 2 minutes which probably prevents dryness and the reason why I would recommend this mud mask over others. However,  at my age of 54, mud masks are good for tightening up pores, but a smoother complexion was not in sight.

This is a slightly oversized dial watch with simple time and date functionality. The box it comes in is very nicely made and looks like it may have cost at least as much as the watch to make (e.g. heavy construction with a leather like - maybe actual leather - covering, etc.).It looks well made and feels pretty decent on the wrist, although the leather band arrives a bit stiff and will need breaking in. The band hardware is all sturdy looking and functional, and the case is similarly well appointed.I was able to "hack" the time of the watch, which makes me happy. One thing I noticed when I was doing this is that the action on the stem is a little "notchy" - it's not super smooth. This is typical of the kind of quartz movement inside watches like these, and I don't find it a problem other than to say that although this claims to be a multi-hundred dollar watch, it is not built that way IMHO. The quartz movement inside these watches is typically mass produced by companies like Miyota of Japan. They are reliable and keep good time, but they are not usually "impressive" in the feel of the stem action. In fact, the movement is a Miyota 2415, which works well, but is available as a part online for about nine dollars. To give you and idea, the similar Miyota time and date modules for popular men's watches like the Swiss Army line are about fifteen dollars or so. Now, these are single unit prices, so you can bet the Invicta brand group is able to get the movements for a lot less. The key takeaway here is, keeps time, does it at a good value price, is NOT a multi-hundred dollar movement. They put the money into the watch case, the styling, the box it comes in and the watchband. I am not hating on them for that, because it is a nice looking watch. If you don't need the marketing, it's a fifty dollar watch. This is why it sells for so much below list here - the actual cost of goods is not that high. Of course, this is typical of all things fashion - the value is not in the underlying material cost - it's in the image you are working to achieve.The good news about the movement is that it is from a reputable Japanese supplier, it is inexpensive to replace if that should need to be done later, the batteries are commonly available (i.e. 377) and it keeps time. YaySO, I am giving this a net of four stars because it works well (e.g. keeps time) and looks and feels good. I am taking off one star because there is no way they should be talking about this as a $285 watch. It's a very nice $80 watch that would be a good value if it sold for below $50. I would boost up the rating to five stars if the action of the crown was smoother and felt more "expensive" instead of the more tinny feeling it has. I would recommend it at the fifty dollar price, should it become available for that and the styling fits your taste.

After seeing my ma-in-law's iRobot Roomba in action, I figured I did not need to get a robotic room vac. It just seemed to me like they combined expense with a lack of flexibility and low vacuum power. This Neato D80 has completely turned my attitude around! I've used the heck out of it since it arrived. It was a key partner in helping me clean my son and daughter's rooms up for some guests. Using this little robo-vac, I was able to set it loose to clean the floor on its own while I removed the floor clutter and dusted the next room. It saved much more time than I would have thought previously. Also, it seemed to catch dust, hair and other dirt that our regular vacuum has trouble picking up.First test: My home officeMy home office has a hardwood floor and has about 120 square feet of floor space. The big test here was to see how it handled the thick 3'x5' Persian-style rug that sits on one end of the floor. I would have thought it would stall or get sent off track, but it absolutely handled going on and off the edge between the rug and the floor. The under-carriage raises and lowers as the vacuum comes near low obstructions like this and allows the vac to get over them. Also, it seems to memorize the room such that it can re-orient itself if it gets off track a little when going over obstacles. Oh, and it cleaned a bunch of dust and stuff that I absolutely didn't see before. Brilliant!Second test: Daughter's carpeted roomMy daughter is away at college now, but her dust, hair, etc. apparently still littered the floor of her room, even after the housekeeper went over it with our Kenmore upright direct drive bagless vac. In fact, it was a pretty surprising amount of dirt that the D80 picked up. I believe that part of this is because our housecleaner does not get under some of the obstructions that the D80 does. For instance, the D80 was able to go beneath the closet shoe rack, which has a low clearance. Also, the edge brush seems to do a better job in the corners then our housekeep's attempt to shove the big Kenmore into corners. Both of these factors probably contribute a lot to the difference in performance. In any case, the D80 navigated the bed, chairs and into the closet once I de-cluttered the room's floor. Very nice job. I re-ran the D80 twice to see if it picked up a lot more the second time, and it did not pick up appreciable extra dirt. Yay!Third Test: Son's RoomMy son is now out of the house and working full time in another city, but his stuff is still here, along with his last load of dirt. His room has a hardwood floor, no rugs, but it does have a loft bed with the resulting extra posts on the floor. Bottom line- worked great.This vac does come with an extra filter, extra brush roller, and a handy filter cleaner. You need to clean out the pleated filter that closes one end of the dirt container, and this would be a lot harder without the little comb-shaped filter cleaner too. In any case, I appreciate the extra parts.The vac is easy to use, too. You do not have to do a lot other than read the short intro brochure to use it. i thought the menu system was intuitive and worked well.My conclusion is that this is a fine vacuum and that if you want a robotic vacuum, this is an excellent choice.

My son has always like AXE branded products so I decided to check this all in one shower product myself. I can report that it is great stuff!1. The bottle holds a sufficient amount of product that I don't have to worry about frequent replacement, yet it is not so huge to avoid putting it in my gym bag.2. The scent it nice, but not so overpowering as to be obnoxious or room-filling.3. My wife likes it.4. My wife likes it.5. The suds are so effective that I can scrub my whole head and body with just a couple squirts from the bottle - I don't have to "hose" myself with this stuff.6. Washes off easy after cleaning.7. The valve does not easily accidentally open. Yet, it is easy to open when you need it to.Cons: NoneI got this bottle as a free evaluation unit, but I will go buy more when this runs out!

I've had to kill a lot of rats over the years. After having checked out many variations of traps, poisons, repellents, etc., I've become partial to the good old Victor wooden rat trap. So, when I had a chance to check out this new one - literally, a "better rat trap" - I was skeptical. This skepticism was quickly banished when I tried it out and bagged a big rat on the first use. These things are great and seem to trigger and kill more surely than my standby "rev 01, Mod 00" Victors. They are also easier to bait, set and then empty when sprung.Baiting: I had learned to modify my old traps to out a small cup of duct tape on the trigger to hold the bait. This forced the rats to more fully commit to the trap to get the bait. The new trap has a plastic bait cup already in place. I put some peanut butter and while peanuts in it with a lot less fuss than before.Trigger plate: the new design surrounds the bait cup with a trigger plate instead of having the bait holder and trigger combined. In the old design it was possible for a smart rat to carefully pick out the hair without triggering the trap. The new design forces the rat to step on the trigger to reach the bait. This seems to provide a much surer kill.Easy setting: the wire lever bar that you press to set the trap is MUCH easier to use than the old design. I can do it one handed. This is safer, because you never have to touch or get in the way of the kill bar.Easy release: using the one handed setting lever design, I was able to release the dead rat into the bag I was holding under it with my other hand. Also, I didn't have to get my hand close to the soiled prt of the trap. Sweet!I am making these my number one recommended trap. My next trap purchase, it's gonna be these. They cost more, but they're worth it!

These are a "value" level on-ear headphone. They are not particularly expensive, sound OK and have a working basic function microphone if you need to be able to talk on your cell phone while listening to tunes at work. They don't look or feel bad, but are clearly not a "premium grade" set upon close inspection.I compared these to my other on/over ear headphones (Bose QC 15) which is not a fair fight, but then again it's not like the Bose are "audiophile" gear, either. Not counting the noise isolation feature, and just the sound, these are listenable and sound better than Apple earbuds in most cases. Since many of you may have heard the Bose before, or are able to go to a local store and listen to them, I am including them in this review for reference.Pros:+ Good bass response.+ Satisfactory treble response (but not super stellar).+ Fold flat+ Built-in microphone in the cord and an integrated single button control for starting and stopping song playback or for beginning or ending calls.  - There is no built-in volume control.+ Microphone is legible (but not super high fidelity or anything - not as good as iPhone bud mic).+ Ear and head pads are decent, mid-grade pads. They feel comfortable for the price range.+ These are not sound canceling, but the sound isolation they give me is good enough for the office environment. It helps me keep out the chatter in our open office environment and does not let enough sound out to disturb the neighbors.Not so Good- The mid to high end frequency response is not so clear. I compared the sound to my Bose QC15, and the Panasonic are not even close to the definition and clarity. They are also about one tenth the price.- The amount of time I can wear these is about half the amount of time I can wear my Bose due to the pads and general fit. It's not bad, but the ear pads in particular are about half as soft and supple as my Bose, best case. Once again, good value, but not to be confused with higher end phones. Your mileage may vary, but these are a one or two hour headphone for me, and not a "fly across the Pacific" level of comfort.- The plug is right angle and does not extend far enough to clear some cases. For instance, I have an Otterbox Extender, battery backed case. The earphone access hole is too deep for the Panasonic plug to go through so I have to use an extender for the plug. I am including a photo of the plug end with a ruler to show how little case clearance it provides. They should have followed the Apple lead on this and made a skinny, straight body plug cover instead of the right angle one with tiny clearance. As it is, if you have a cover for your phone it is unlikely that this plug will fit all the way through it.ConclusionThese are a good, inexpensive over ear headphone. I would recommend them for decent listening on a budget or to let your kids use them. In the latter case, the bass response is good enough for most of them (I think) and the price is low enough you won't care so much when they lose or destroy them. They seem durable and they look good, too. If your budget won't allow you to pay more than $50 for a set of headphones, consider these.

This is the first time I have tried this style of coconut syrup. In the past, I have had coconut flavored,syrupy, pancake/waffle toppings, but not a product like this one that is apparently rendered from coconut sugars. They don't really say exactly on the table, which lists the ingredients as "organic coconut syrup".I would say that in general, I liked it, but don't love it. The syrup pretty much looks like classic "maple syrup" but has a taste that is somewhat different. The predominant flavor to me was the strong caramel taste. It is sweet and caramel, but I didn't taste so much of the "buttery" taste that the product description mentions. I compared it to some other toppings on my Belgian waffles and found it to be a solid contender. However, it is not a new "must have" topping for my starchy breakfast days.The bottle is convenient and the flip top stop works well. The inner seal was harder to remove than I would have thought it should be. I had to  work on the edges of the seal with my fingernails as well as using the provided pull tab.Overall, my family felt about the same way about it. Would definitely eat it if sitting next to the waffles or pancakes. If we run out, nobody is going to beg for more. If you get a good price on it, by all means by it, but if not, just do what you have been doing with Aunt Jemima, Log Cabin, etc.

I have mounted this industrial-strength fan in my garage to keep myself cool while doing projects during the summer and to help blow wood dust from sanding away from my work. In my experience so far, it is a great choice for this kind of use and all the parts seem heavy duty - I expect it to last a long time. In  fact, I would say that once installed, it is a five star unit, but the installation takes away a bit, especially if you are not experienced in assembling and installing this sort of equipment.The Good:* The fan came well packed and had no shipping damage.* Not only were all parts included and in good shape, but there were some extra pieces that are not mentioned in the instructions or description.  * Safety cable to guard against the mounting base or its attachment to the fan failing.  * Safety cable clamps (2pcs) so that you can clamp the ends of the cable where you need them. Much easier than a swage fitting - they use nuts and bolts.  * A cotter pin for retaining the large bolt that joins the fan to the mount.* When installed, the operatioon is very smooth. The fan has no vibration, the control has no dead spots.* It pushes a lot of air when you need it to and can also be easily regulated to a very gentle breeze.* All pieces feel like they are well made and of high quality.* The fit and finish is very good - did not need to trim or modify anything, which was a pleasant surprise.* The cords for power and the controller are both long enough to be useful.* The mount not only is very sturdy and made of heavy gauge steel, but it comes with the necessary lag screws for mounting to wood beams.The Not So Good:* Instructions. The instructioons are well written, but the assembly diagrams are so tiny that they are very hard to see. In order to understand them you pretty much need to stare at the actual parts and the written instruction while ignoring the diagrams because they are too small.* The instructions do not say what to do with the cable and cable clamps.* There is a step where you have to insert a large screwdriver in between the front and back fan guard cages to force them together, which would likely chip the paint if you did it that way. I used a plastic car interior pry bar to avoid this. It seems like they couuld have made this part of the design a little better. It is far from a deal killer, but it did make assembly harder than it could be otherwise.* The instructions call out torque settings for all of the nuts and bolts. I think it would be hard to access several of the nuts with a torque wrench. I ended up just guessing because I could not get my torque wrench to fit in the spaces with all the nuts and bolts. I ended up just making them all "tight". Now, this is not a huge deal, but it could be confusing for some. Also, if you need to get a torque wrennch on some of these nut/bolts it would have been great if they had made access just a bit better.* It would be nice to have just a bit more range in the tilt of the fan. It's OK, but it would be better if there was more vertical adjustemnt.I have included photos of the above issues. All that said, it''s excellent and I'm happy and more comfortable, having it in my garage this summer. It cools my two car garage down in a minute or two - fast!

This is the first plug cutter I've owned. Over the last thirty years of hobby level woodworking I have always used ready made plugs or caps when the need arose to cover a countersunk screw. My last project, an outdoor bench. required fifty or so plugs to match the rest of the quarter sawn cedar it's made from. I didn't even bother looking for plugs and found this CMT cutter here on Amazon. I read the other reviews and decided that having more waste in the cuts was better than having bad cuts to begin with. Glad I made that choice!CMT has a pretty good overall reputation and this relatiely inexpensive cutter should add to it. Althouugh the packaging says it is made in China instead of Italy as most of their other bits are, the quality was as good as I would have expected. It was well packaged and super sharp out of the plastic. After cleaning it up with a rag and some WD, I chucked it up in my old Delta 17-900 drill press and went to work. I set the RPM to the package recommendation and started cutting plugs. The cutter is designed to be used with a thin board laid flat on the drill press table (with proper backing board on top, of course :-). I was making half inch thick plugs by cutting all the way through a resawn board. As you cut each plug, you do NOT have to remove it when it is done. Cutting the next plug will push it out through the slot in the middle of the cuttter body. Thus, when cutting a series of plugs, the only one you should have to remove manually is the last one.I cranked out the fifty plugs I needed as well as a bunch of spares in fifteen or twenty minutes once I was set up. It is actually kind of fun in itself and the cedar plugs were very clean. They were also precise - withing a few mils using my digital calipers. I would guess that with the soft and spongy wood I was using, a few mils is as good as can be done because it compresses and rebounds easily. Perhaps maple plugs would be about dead on. In any case, the plugs fit perfectly in my project and I'm a happy guy with some impressive results to report.I don't know if there are better plug cutters, but if there are it would be immaterial to me because this one is so far above the bar I would not bother with the others!

This is the slickest non-stick pan we've had, and we've had many. For cooking dishes like fried rice, we can cut our use of oil or grease down by more than half. In fact, if we use the normal amount of oil for our previous pans, there is too much oil left on the food because it doesn't stick to the pan as much as it does the rice. The rice doesn't stick at all.I fried some sausage in it and they also don't stick to the surface at all. In fact, if you normally count on having a litttle friction on the bottom of the frying pan to help roll sausages around to cook all sides, this pan will require an adjustment in your style because it is so slippery compared to others. Whatever we cook with it comes out great and has the easiest cleanup we've seen in a while.We did attempt to make crepes the other day, and although the surface is great, the shape of the sides of the pan is not quite right for that. They are too steep and don't allow you to "angle in" to the edge of the crepe to flip it or remove it easily. For this we remove one star. This might not affect every cook, but we would have appreciated a slightly shallower side angle.The handle is comfortable to use and does not seem to get hot. It is also a brushed finish that gives you a good grip even when it has a spot of grease on it. This is much better than some others that have pretty, shiny handles that tend to require a serious grip to keep them from turning in your hand.The body of the pan is nicely finished on the outside and is made of thick aluminum. It spreads heat nicely. Additionally, the bottom of the pan is flat and does not rock around on the burner or countertop. The overall workmanship appears to be just great.If you care about this sort of thing, the packaging does say the pan is made in China. I would say that the quality is world-class, however, and you need to look at the origin mark to notice that it is from China. As I write above, no quality issues. Looks, works and feels great.If you don't need to edge crepes or pancakes off the bottom of your pan, and don't typically bake in it (e.g. "Dutch/German panckages") this is a five star pan. In fact, this is one of those cases where I wish we had half star resolution so I could give it a 4.5 star rating.

My son helped out on this review. He used the pan to fry a variety of items on his small apartment stove where he lives in NYC. Overall, he really likes the pan and has no hesitation to give it a solid four star rating. He was considering 5 stars, but can't quite get himself to go to that level.He likes the non-stick finish, which seems to be superior to Teflon coated pans he's tried. It is super slippery and allows him to use less oil or grease. This is part of the pan's sales pitch, and it seems to be true.He likes the nice sturdy handle. It is easy to grip and does not really weigh the pan down.He likes the weight of the pan - substantial yet does not feel like it is an exercise just to lift it up.It cooks well, providing even heat.Overall, we give it a solid four stars.

I've always liked Belkin branded cables because they are higher than average quality, ruggedness and have some amount of thought put into their design and marketing. This four foot cable is no exception. It works as advertised and does both data communication for syncing and is heavy duty enough to run a full speed, 2.4A charge for iPads and other Lightning ported devices that can use higher current.Pros:1. Works to both charge and sync my iPhone 6 as well as  my iPad mini 3.2. The 4 foot length is perfect for use to plug into my charger on the wall and the nightstand near my bed. Same with my desk.3. The fabric covered cable does not tangle easily and wraps nicely when I want to put it away.4. The gold colored unit I received complaints my gold iPhone 4.5. The connector covers at each end are fairly compact - almost as much so as the Apple original. I had no trouble fitting the Lightning end into my Otterbox commuter case.If you can get a good price on these, or even pay a few dollars more than the bargain basement or no-name cables, go for it.

I bought this form my wife's new iPhone 6+. I already had an iPhone 6 with an Otterbox Defender case. This left me sold on the protective ability and overall quality of Otterbox, but it turns out I really disliked a few of the features of the Defender (hard to scan finger sensor, built in less than great screen protector, seals that you have to move to use the ports, etc.). I knew these would make for a bunch of unhappy wife moments, so I decided that for her use it would be better to give up a bit of protection for the phone in favor of ease of use. To me, the Commuter hits this on the head. It eliminates the annoying "mil-spec" features of the Defender and still protects the phone. Additionally, it does not make the phone too thick to comfortably handle. And, since it does NOT have a built in screen protector, you can choose a replaceable, high quality screen protector that you can actually replace if it sacrifices itself to save your phone. Additionally, there is sufficient clearance around the home button/fingerprint sensor to allow ease of use.If you don't need the extreme protection and dust seals of the Defender, I heartily recommend this case - no complaints from the user!

Over the last few years, I have put on my share of screen protector products. It started with the Palm Pilot devices (remember those?) and now on to my latest toy - the iPad Mini 3. I've done good jobs and bad, but by now I would rate myself as pretty competent at getting a bubble free protector application done. That said, the Tech Armor screen protector products, including this one, have become my favorites. This is because they make it relatively easy to do a nearly invisible screen protector application.First, the instructions are well written and there are great supplements online.Second, the protective film that covers the screen protector product is well labeled so that you can identify which part to pull off first and which side faces the screen, etc.Third, the quality is high. After getting the protector in place, I really like the feel of the TA products on my fingers. I don't "baby" my iDevices, so the screen protectors are often called upon to actually protect. Unlike some others I've used, the TA products do not easily scratch or abrade. They are very, very clear, and still allow great sensitivity on the touch screen.Adding to all the above, the pricing on Amazon has been good, and you get multiple pieces of protector with each kit (as well as cleaner cloth and smoother). Solid value for the money even if it were not so totally better than the no-name brands.There are a lot of screen protectors out there, but when asked (I am my tribe's tech-nerd) I always recommend Tech Armor.

I asked my acne-prone son to try these out and see if they helped the face on his skin. His summary pronouncement is that he likes the Proactiv+ product and felt that it helped reduce the number and severity of existing blemishes on his face. It did lighten some of the darkness and scarring on those blemishes, but it was not a "miracle" cure. He has used many other similar products (e.g. Acne Free, etc.) and says that this one would be in the top group. That said, he also would probably not buy them at their nominal price of over forty dollars for 15 pads. He would be interested if they were about half that. If they cost fifteen dollars a package (one dollar a pad) he would definitely buy them.Other than that, they are pleasant to use as well as convenient. And, once again, they did have a noticeable benefit for his tough acne issues. It would have been a five star product except when considering cost and the shortfall, in his opinion, of the skin lightening effect.

I would not have thought that a mono speaker system would be all that useful to me, but this one is actually very interesting and useful for working out in the yard, the garage or cleaning up the kid's rooms while listening to my iPhone. In all cases, I could just put on some headphones, but when working in the yard under the sun, or in the garage with the occasional need to put on my face and hearing protection, it's easier to just have a speaker. I'm also not usually doing critical music listening at those times - usually podcasts or background music. So, that is the use that I have for a speaker like this one.The speaker I actually received for review looked much different than the one in the product description. I think it is a different model, actually. I have attached a photo to this review that shows it is clearly more compact, and is colored white and black.I was easily able to pair the speaker with my iPhone 6. The unit comes partially charged (it has a built in battery) so I didn't have to plug it in to get started. I have a test for BT pairing. If I need to use the manual, it is too complex. Out of every ten BT items that I check out, maybe one of them ends up needing a trip to the manual in order to get pairing going. I evaluate a fair number of units, so your experience may differ, but in my estimation this unit is on the easy side for pairing. This is common to a lot of "one way" BT devices where you are just sending an audio stream from your phone, pod, pc, or whatever since there is no real need for passwords (the data is just going out and there is no reverse stream into the device).In order to keep the device compact and packable, the ends of the unit collapse into the middle and reduce the height of it by about half. Additionally, the instructions, and my actual listening, show that the bass response of the speaker is much better with the ends extended. That said, it still functions fine with the ends collapsed. With the ends extended I rate the sound as "better than a transistor radio of old". When the ends are retracted, I call it "the same as a transistor radio of old". Or, perhaps better in each case since we don't have to worry about radio reception from a distant or variable source. The BT signal reception was clean when sourced from my iPhone 6 up to the rated 30' clear distance.The controls are simple. there is an off/on switch that also selects between a wired audio connection and BT. There is a separate "pairing" button that is used for first time connection to your device. There are two hardware connectors on the unit - an audio in port for a 1/8" mini jack cable and a micro USB connector for charging the internal battery.The speaker comes with a handy strap/cord that I used hang it from in the garage and kitchen. I found that this yielded the best sound output vs. setting on a counter or other flat surface. If you want to optimize the sound a little bit, you can experiment with turning the speaker direction and stabilizing it with whatever McGyver-esque contraption you want to come with. In general, I decided that this was not the point of this unit, however. The goal is to provide better and more powerful sound for your phone when you are away from better sound systems, and it does this well.Overall, I like this speaker and continue to use it. I would like it better if it were the black or charcoal color all through as shown in the product photo. This is especially true of the grill, which is white painted metal. I also think it would be good if the hard white plastic midsection of the device I received could be available in other colors and that it would also be beneficial to have the middle have a bit more of a "grippy" texture. These are very minor issues to me, however.So, why not a five star? I guess it comes down to the few issues above, albeit minor as they are, and the fact that I just like the speaker, I don't love it. Not quantifiable, but that is it. I have Apple products in part because they possess a certain design style, and this speaker does not support that, really. It has a sort of "the engineers felt they were done" look, and although that is not hatable, it is not lovable to me, either. If you find it on super sale, though, I think you'll be happy.

Before receiving this steam mop as an evaluation item, my wife and I had not considered getting one. We have been blessed by being able to have a housecleaner come in once a week and mop the kitchen floor, which is vinyl. Although the floor is "clean" when she is done, I had a theory that "steam cleaning" would remove some dirt that mopping with detergent could not reach.To test this, I used the steam mop after the most recent visit by our house cleaner. Our kitchen floor is almost twenty years old, so there are some spots of surface wear that remain dirty looking even after normal mopping and/or scrubbing. The steam mop did not change the appearance of these spots and areas. It did do a good job of picking up a bit more dirt than the normal weekly cleaning. I am posting some photos that show the rough floor before and after as well as the floor mop itself after steam cleaning the entire kitchen floor.To sum up this test, the floor didn't look a lot cleaner when done, but the mop did show that dirt had been picked up. It probably has a bit more dirt than would be expected because there was a lapse between when the initial cleaning had happened and when the steam cleaning was done, but I did take a look at the mop mid process after cleaning non-trafficked areas. It does pick up a little extra dirt. Now, this may make me seem like a slacker, but the results didn't make me feel like this is a must have item at this point. If you have toddlers on the floor, maybe, but we are two middle age folks whose kidsOK, so far so good.The next thing to look at is how the mop itself picks up the dirt. I have included a photo that shows the mop after all the cleaning. It really concentrates the dirt in the middle near the steam port. Perhaps this is not a super critical issue, but since you can't really wring the mop out mid-job very easily (my version of easy does not include removing a dirty, velcro attached mop head, washing it out somewhere and re-attaching it) I think it would be great if the mop applied pressure and steam in a more distributed pattern that essentially spreads the dirt pickup on the mop more, thus increasing its capacity. This may not be a deal-killer, but I just thought it was not what I would have expected.On a more general note, although I have not had it long enough to speak to durability, the unit seems to be fairly well made. It is a compromise between durability and weight, it seems, so by no means would I call it "rugged", but it does not seem fragile. The assembly took about 10 minutes out of the box, but this was mainly because there are two sub-boxes and a lot of parts included. You need to pull this stuff out and sort it. I would say this took up more than half the time. The actual assembly just takes a couple minutes. You click in the handle, the mop head frame and then cover that frame with the mop. The electrical cord is heavy duty and a nice length that can wrap around the hooks on the handle. A nice Velcroâ„¢ strip comes with the cord, but it was inexplicably unattached to the cord itself. There is a small loop in the material that is supposed to be fused around the cord, but it was just fused to itself and thus the strip remained loose after un-doing the cord wrap. Not a deal-killer, but an odd thing to put in a heavy duty Velcroâ„¢ strip and then waste it. You would expect to use this to bundle the cord if you use the mop as a hand-held steamer.If you are still with me, my next test will be to use the hand wand and mop on my barbecue. This will come later as I need to get the unit greasy again. Although I am not valuing the floor experience so much, I have a theory that this will be the miracle tool to remove grease from our stainless steel BBQ and the range hood in the kitchen. I will amend the report when this is done.Conclusion: This seems to be an OK steam mop. It has a few issues as noted above, but not killer ones. My rating reflects my lack of enthusiasm for steam mops in general as much as it does for this one in particular.

When I had just started working a few decades back, I had thought that Social Security was a long, long ways off and that it would already be bankrupt by the time I would need it. Wrong, wrong, wrong. I lived that long and iso did SS. When I had a chance to review this book, I thought it would be helpful to strategize my exit from the active workforce in a couple years. This has proven to be true.Like all "Dummies" books, this one is logically divided into topical sections that allow you to pick and choose which sections to read and when, rather than forcing you to read all of it in sequence. I chose to work on the aforementioned timing of retirement strategy. The section on this topic can show you how to avoid losing more than 30% opportunity of you do it wrong. It also has clear explanations about survivor benefits and how to maximize your return.Overall, i highly recommend this book if you are about 60 and need to look ahead to the next few years. you will reach eligibility in the next two years and depending on your situation it may or may not make sense to start collecting. this book and its tables will show you what to do.I heartily recommend this book

This is my favorite hand cream! There are a lot of assorted hand creams on the market, but the Ahava brand has had my vote as the one to get for the last 16 or so years that I have been aware of it. It originated in Israel and really does use "minerals from the Dead Sea". Whatever actually goes into it, it has always seemed to help heal my skin as well as keep it moist and pliable. It does this without making my fingers greasy feeling or causing me to leave smudges all over any shiny surface. This "Water" version seems as good as the rest of the variations I've tried, and comes in an assortment of different sizes. This one is a smaller "travel" size that is within the TSA rules for liquids carried aboard aircraft.In addition to keeping my hands, which I wash a lot due my hobbies of woodworking and gardening, Ahava has been helpful in soothing body rash that I occasionally get from the heat or allergies. I can often use it in place of over-the-counter hydrocortisone products. Your reaction may be different, but I think it is a good trade-off to be able to use something like this cream vs. hydro if you can (hydrocortisone can cause problems if you use it too much), so I always try to remedy skin issues with Ahava first, before moving on to "medicines".Finally, if you are a manly man, like myself, you will like the fact that the packaging is not too flashy or feminine and the scent is relatively neutral. It's great stuff!

So far, I have been OK with this bag, but don't love it. Aside from the color (Vine reviewers don't get to choose color), the surface of the mesh is a little rougher than I'd like, so it occasionally hangs up on some items, which takes a second or two to correct. Not a deal killer, but not perfect.I'd also like the pockets to be slightly (perhaps an inch?) deeper than they are, as well as maybe just a tad wider (1/2") which I would sacrifice one of them to accomplish on the average.Other than that, very serviceable and seems durable so far.

My big test of this unit was to see if would reduce the amount of pollen in the air in our home. We have had a very tough allergy season this year and both my wife and I have struggled with sneezing, runny nose, itchy eyes, etc.The unit came packaged very nicely in a doubled cardboard container with nicely made foam pads in each end. It was undamaged and easy to remove. All the elements of the packaging will go in my recycle bin.It installed easily with one small exception. The unit comes installed in the unit, but it is not removed from its protective packaging. The instructions/installation guide make no mention of this. I noticed it when I turned the unit on and found that the output was very weak at any setting. The good news here is that I found that the filter door at the rear of the unit is easy to remove, the filter packaging comes off easily once you know you have to do it, and the re-installation process is not at all challenging. It's just an odd omission to not inform the user that the filter needs to be removed from its packaging while the instructions DO have lots of lawyer crap informing me of all sorts of ridiculous or inapplicable cautions from the company's indemnity boiler plate.In use, the unit works very nicely. I put it on about halfway and let it run for an hour using the timer feature just before going to bed. It is not loud at that setting, so I can sleep with it as "white noise". It would be a bit too loud for me to do this at the full setting. The controls all work well and are easy to understand, which is good because the instructions are not very detailed.This brings me to another gripe about the instructions. I can guess what the ionizer and the UV functions are supposed to do, but I'd rather have a bit of instruction about their deployment. The instructions don't really do that. They just say how to turn the functions on and off. The web page for the product has some hints, but since they went to the trouble of creating a paper manual, why not include fifty words each on the two interesting functions? For instance, why or when would you use each one? Does it preserve or tax the filter more? etc. None of that is available.The only real functional issue for me, other than the instructions, is that the timer function has a granularity of one hour. I think that is a bit coarse and would like to have it be something more like fifteen or thirty minutes. This isn't a killer issue, but I think that it feels like an oversight since the controller seems like it would easily have the smarts to add that flexibility.By the way, it did help to clean the pollen out of the air in our bedroom and give us a better sleep.In the end, it would have been five stars, but since the instructions are funky and the timer only gives me hours, I am taking off one star, but would still recommend this to anyone looking for this level of air filtering appliance.

I have a pretty good selection of hand tools in my home arsenal. In addition to the usual selection of shears, I have sets of metal snips (L, R and S), diagonal cutters, end cutters, bolt cutters, etc. So, when I had the opportunity to review these Wiss multi-purpose shears, I was actually a bit hesitant to add one more thing to the tool box. I am glad I decided to do so.I tried cutting a variety of materials with these shears. One of the ,most treacherous, IMHO, are those heavy duty plastiic fruity holders from Costco. They are big, thick, and take up too much room in the recycle bin. I have previously cut them with a utility knife or scissors, but using the Wiss shears feels way more secure and seems to keep the sharp edges of the plastic away from my hands better. The compound cutting leverage really makes even the reinforced or folded parts of the plastic cut easily.Another test was to take a coat hangar wire and make a bunch of cuts and bends in it. I used both the bending holes and the wire cutter feature for this test. The bender works well and allowed me to both straighten the coat hangar (I personally think this is a difficult test vs. curving wire) and make some bends for S-hooks. The one slight fault I would give the bending holds in this task is that the edges of the holes are sharp enough to nick the wire a bit. Keep in mind, these are steel coat hangars, so copper wire would get more nicked. I think a very slight relief of the sharp edges with a small dremel grinding stone will take care of it. The cutting was totally easy and the steel wire did not damage or dull the cutter edges. The compound grips made it very easy.One fault of shop shears is that they tend to be good at cutting heavy material, but not thin or flimsy sheets of material like cloth or paper. These had no trouble at that end of the spectrum. I even cut some loose thread at the end of the shop towel with no issue.There is a neutral issue you should be aware of - these are pretty big shears if you have petite hands. I take a men's medium glove but have relatively short fingers compared to other guys my build (5'7" 180b, bench press 220#) which I would call slightly more than medium (YMMV). I think if you have smaller hands than mine, these would be fatiguing to use for a long time because the handles would be too big. They are, however, well designed for a cushion grip if they fit. The lock works well to keep them closed and compact when not in use.There is one small defect - smell. These are made in China (what isn't?) and although they seem to be made to high standards of fit and finish, the rubber used in the handles has the characteristic "Harbor Freight rubber" smell. I you are a tool person, you know what I mean. A strong solvent smell that is standard with HF tools. It has weakened by about half in the five days I've had them out of the plastic packaging, but is still present. I'm OK with it, but I know that some other folks are more sensitive than me and you'd want to know about it. For this, the plastic packaging that you would want these shears to use to open and the too sharp bending hole, I remove one star.In conclusion, I like this tool and will move my metal snips lower in the "grab" order. They are more versatile and seem to work better in general, which is an unexpectedly good combo. I would definitely recommend these to someone looking for these capabilities.

A great place to put your "elevator pitch"I've always found that explaining the business of my company ends up involving drawing on napkins, hand motions and too-detailed discussions. Some of it would just be a lot easier if I had a small drawing ready to show. Maybe a few drawings and a photo or two. These cards are perfect for that. They give me enough room to put the normal business card information in decent sized type, add a QR code, and then three sides of elevator pitch. I can also put in one side that has my name in big letters so I can slip it into a name card holder at conventions. All with one card. I still keep my single piece cards around for casual hand-outs, but these are so good for that "next level" contact.And, they print nicely, separate cleanly and all the other things Avery is famous for.

We received this item as a Vine reviewer and gave it a good run to check it out.My wife and I are "Asians of modest height" and have to get chairs to reach the upper shelves in our kitchen and other places in our home. Also, when reaching behind, underneath or around furniture to get fallen items, our relatively short arms are challenged to get there and back. Now that we have the "PikStik" most of these problems are easily solved. We particularly like the following features:1. The rubber jaws are grippy and have enough spring in them that we can grab relatively delicate items and not crush them, but still hold them securely.2. The jaws rotate and lock securely at two positions, 90° from each other. This gives a lot of flexibility at to how we grip the stick and squeeze the trigger.3. It is well made and sturdy enough for our use. The heavy duty plastic grip and handle go well with the aluminum shaft to provide strength without excessive weight.4. It has a hangar hole so we can put it up on the wall next to our broom, dustpan, etc.No real negatives at all. I used to have a "Harbor Freight Cheapie" and this one is a huge step up.So good, I would have paid for it had I known it existed.

This unit replaces an RCA brand #WP2UWR that had only one AC outlet and two USB plugs. Compared to that device, this one is a clear winner.Pros:1. No hum or whine from the internal circuits. The RCA, as well as other combo units I've experienced, makes a humming/whining noise that is noticeable and bothersome to me. This RND power station is quiet.2. Two AC as well as two USB outlets. This is greater capacity, and that is not counting the pull-out micro USB plug.3. This RND station is compact as stated in its description. It is compact enough that it leaves one of the two plugs on the wall plate open for other use (unlike the RCA and others), thus giving up to three AC plugs off the same wall plate in addition to the 2 + 1 USB.4. Looks like it is well built.5. The micro USB pigtail can be neatly stored when not in use. Part of the overall clever design.6. The AC plugs on the back are interchangeable, presumably for international AC use. (Although, it does not come with any plug other than US).7. 2.4 Amp is better capacity than the usual 2.1 Amp found on other similar units.8. Has  little ledge on top to hold a cell phone while it is charging.Cons1. I would have appreciated a micro USB to Apple lightning converter, but this is a minor complaint and I would not take off a star for it.2. The unit secures to the wall socket by plug friction alone, so you need to support it with one hand while removing any AC plug from it to keep the whole unit from pulling off of the wall. Once again, i don't think this was in the design spec and it's not a big hassle, but would have been nice to have a screw to hold it onto the wall plate.SummaryThe RND Compact Power Station now owns our kitchen wall socket near the phone!

I make a lot of PowerPoint presentations for my job. Additionally, our small company does not have enough money to pay for outside video production, so I produce our short demo and product vids - to low standards. I had hoped that this book would give me some pointers to improve my work, and, actually, that is not what it is really for. Writing for Visual Media looks like it was written to be the textbook for a college level overview course.Virtually all topics regarding writing for all visual media types from film and video to web pages and mobile devices are covered at some level of depth. It's over 400 pages of dense text describing how to architect stories for commercials, movies, corporate pieces, ads, web pages, etc. It gives you a suggested method to construct stories for various types of media and messaging. There are chapters for each media type that lay out a path to get our story line and find a suitable construct.I found the text to be solidly written and arranged in a way that made sense once I started reading it. Also, the different media types are addressed in separate chapters, so you do not have to read the entire book to receive some benefit.I would be somewhat critical of the lack of graphics in the book. There are a few diagrams and photos, with the emphasis on few. I think it could have benefitted by including a few sample story boards, and more diagrams and flowcharts than it has.This is not a casually approachable book, but a good reference for crafting text for visual media. You will have to spend time with it to benefit, but depending on the depth you want to get to, it could be worth it.

This is a slightly more deluxe than average USB 3.0 hub. It performs well so far, and the things I like about it include:* It uses a switching power supply, which means it is much more energy efficient than a cheaper analog supply. Of course, if it was a poorly made switcher, it would hum and introduce noise, but this one is quiet and has sufficiently high capacity to power the peripherals I plugged into the hub.* There is a power switch on the hub so I can easily power it down when away from my desk. Since the above power supply is a switcher, powering down the hub also powers down the supply and reduces power consumption to near zero.* The transfers are appropriately fast as I would expect, although I admit I didn't do a rigorous test. My laptop is older and I have a PCIE34 card in the side to get it to perform with USB 3.0. (Macbook pro, circa 2008/9).* The hub and power supply are black and look good.* The LED pilot light is not too bright or obnoxious. It comes on when the power is on and off otherwise. No crazy flashy lighting effects or super bright and distracting "on" light.ConsNone so far. I suppose if it breaks down, I will report later.

My wife likes to use reading glasses for close up work (reading, nails, computer, etc.) when she is wearing her contact lenses. I asked her to test these Foster Grants (a brand from my childhood - a few years ago ....) when they came up in my Vine queue.Overall, she really likes these relatively high-end, non-prescription reading glasses. The highlights are:* She really likes the look and the apparent quality versus cheaper drugstore models.* The lenses are clear and do not have wavy distortions of any kind. They do not stress her eyes.* The frames have spring loaded hinges to keep them from being damaged if the earpieces are flexed out, as happens when you take glasses off quickly.* She tested them doing a variety of close hand-work such as painting nails, reading books, the laptop, and her iPod Touch's tiny screen. No problem - these are an enabler.* Although it is implied above, they are comfortable and she can wear them for a long time without fatigue.Be aware of:These samples were rated at +2.75 diopter. She would normally only use +1.25 to +1.5 power reading glasses. Her input is that although these were fine, if she had her choice she would get these in the correct diopter. You should check that out before you buy and make sure you get the correct power of lenses.Conclusion:These are now my wife's best reading glasses. They could be yours too.

I've been a Nespresso fan for years. Our family first encountered Nespresso during a trip to Europe back in 2010 and have had a machine and the OEM capsules ever since. Despite the big lead of K-cups in the US, it seems that Nespresso has become more and more available (the machines were at Costco this Christmas!). The capsules were always the expensive, but great, OEM, however. Now, I had a chance to test a less expensive alternative to the Nespresso (What I keep calling OEM) capsules.The Aldecoa "Intense" capsules taste more like a "6" to me rather than an "8". That's not bad, but it is not quite as fully intense as I would have expected. The flavor is more like the dark or strong ratings you come across in K-cups. The crema on top is much better than a premium K, but not what I have come to expect from Nespresso. It just doesn't have that fully smooth and satisfying fullness. All that said, it is not hateful. It is still better than most of my K-cup experiences. It's just not as good as Nespresso (I realize there are lots of Nespresso choices - I've had most of them), and feels like "less for less $". That said, I will still drink all 40 of the sample I was given. It's "good enough" to drink.The material that capsules are made of is some sort of plastic vs. the metal construction of the Nespresso. The good about this is that they don't dent from casual fumbling or dropping on to a hard surface. They seem to give a tighter fit in the machine when closing the chamber, which is a neutral for me, but could be a negative for others. The cardboard box the capsules come in is a plus for me because it is far easier to keep on a shelf than the Nespresso tubes. Additionally, there is no need to slide the capsules down the tube, which is how I end up fumbling and dropping them. So, packaging is a plus.When the capsules are brewing in the machine, there are some differences that may or may not explain some of the way the coffee comes out. The OEM brew typically takes longer than these (maybe 1.5x as long?) and has a period of 10-15 seconds at the end where there are a bunch of drips coming off the spout into the brew cup. These Aldecoas do not do that. They brew relatively quickly and then cut off cleanly. This may seem like a plus (brews faster and cleaner at the end), but I think it is why the crema is not well formed.SO, in the end, I would consider these if they are available at half price vs. the OEM and drink them as a "goes with food" option for coffee. I would also use them in espresso mixed drinks where the coffee is not standing on its own so much. For a more satisfying espresso experience, I would still go with the many Nespresso flavors and deluxe aroma, crema, etc. This is not a direct replacement for that premium priced experience, which, I am reminded, is still a lot less expensive than going to Starbucks :-)

Update 1/26/15Had some more folks taste this sauce and came up with some other attributes. I thought it was important to get some opinion from folks who have more snack counter nachos than I do.* Guest tasters liked the smooth texture of the sauce. They thought that it really was superior to other more "gloppy" or chunky sauces that they had had.* One commented that it didn't have that "canned" taste that many snack counter versions have.* The thickness of this sauce is a little less than some others and this was viewed as a real plus for getting it successfully on to a chip and into ones mouth.* It does not become glue like after sitting for a couple minutes.* Many disagreed with the the "bland" judgment and said it was more cheesy than I had thought. BTW, I tend to favor really strong flavors, so this is not surprising to me.* We served it with other condiments - Pace Picante sauce (medium), Stagg's chili. It went fast.* I forgot to mention in the original review that there is a sticker on the top to help you pull the lid off after using a can opener on it (vs. sticking a knife or your finger under the sharp edge). This is a nice feature and worked quite well to prevent getting that nasty steel can cut.* We had nachos for 30+ with plenty of sauce left over.***** Original review below *****So, if you just have a family of four and like spicy food, this may not be the way for you to go. It is fairly bland tasting, but makes a good base for spicing it up to something you would like afterwards. It does not, in my opinion, come out of the can ready to go. Rather, since it is about a gallon of sauce, it is a cheese base for you to put together nachos for a larger party or in a restaurant. Like the label says, "basic cheddar cheese sauce".We used ours to make nachos for the social meeting time after the church service, and it was fine for that. Especially after we added some tabasco, peppers, vinegar, Worcestershire, etc. to taste. Smooth, heats easily and, did I mention, you just have to open one can for  pretty good size group.BTW, I felt it was more "American/Velveeta" cheese flavor rather than cheddar.

I had a bunch of papers in my office that needed to be laminated so it was really fortuitous that my Vine review queue ended up having these Fellowes branded laminating pouches in it. I fired up my generic, cheapie laminator ("GBC" brand) and got ready to clean up some of my wall postings a bit. The first thing I found is that this 200 pouch package does not come with a sleeve to pass the sheets through the laminator with. Most other packages of material that I've purchased in the past from vendors like Royal and others had a sleeve. This is nothing more than a hinged folder made of cardboard, so I cut up a FedEx envelope to make my own substitute. This worked fine, but I thought it was a missing feature for this pack of pouches. Those sleeves don't last forever, and I would expect to definitely wear one out within a 200 piece package of consumables. I removed one star for this. Additionally, I found no instructions of any kind on the package referring to temperature setting, compatibility, etc. Not a huge deal, but I thought there should have been something there instead of nothing.All that said, I found that everything ended up working fine with my jury rigged setup. The results were well bonded, bubble free and clear. I didn't test water resistance, but I did check out the "wipes clean" claim by using a dry erase marker on some of the laminations. This erased with no smudges.If they included the lamination sleeve and still left out the instructions or heat specs, I would give this a five as a product. And, if the price is good, you would still do well to get them because you can always just make a sleeve like did, presuming moderate handiness. :-)

I think these are a decent value. They are not as nice as the 3M Command equivalent, but if you use them within their capabilities, they seem to do well. I tested mine on a smooth surface (semi gloss enamel paint) and found that they hold at least 1 pound (the package spec.) in two directions. The first is pulling down vertically. The second is pulling away from the wall. My guess is that it would take about three pounds or more pulling straight out to pull it off the wall. If I can find my fishing scale, I will measure it directly.The release feature worked fine on the smooth finish, and I also regret the fact that replacement adhesive does not appear to be available. So, down one star for that.The removal tab is very visible with these hooks, and although that might be convenient, for me it means these are going to be used in closets, laundry room and the garage. I would say, not for the home kitchen unless you're a bachelor and and engineer :-)The hooks are a bit less adhesive on a textured, flat finish wall. I could still get them to stick and give me about a pound of resistance, but not tons more. I would not put anything two pounds worth on the hook with these on a flat, textured wall. I have not had them fall off, but it is not confidence inspiring and I was able to pull the hook off the wall along with the adhesive with perhaps three pounds of force. That would make this a bad way to hang a wall plaque or ceramic object in your living room or office.So, what am I using them for? Keys, wires (I have a lot of USB, firewire and LAN cables at home), small flashlights, scissors and other small and light tools. I am not putting them up on rough surfaces, but always using smooth surfaces. I clean the surface with Formula 409 cleaner first to make sure it is fully degreased to get the maximum adhesion. Finally, let the adhesive sit for an hour after attachment to give it time to "set up". If you follow all these directions, you'll have better results than otherwise. Or, you can just pay up and get the "Command" version ...All that said, if your use fits the above profiles, you should be able to get good use out of these for a relatively attractive price.

This honeywell HCE323V ceramic heater is a luxuriously designed heater that has a remote control, motion sensors, and programmable modes.Timer - 1,2,4,8 hours. Great if you want to leave it on during the night or turn off some  time during the night. I would do something similar during the day, maybe to keep the room warm while I'm out for short time.Motion sensor - will stop the heater from functioning if an object is close. Excellent if an object or person gets too close.Tip over safety - if the heater is not upright on a click sensor, it will not function.Three modes of heat - low, medium, high. The low setting does not allow temperature adjustment. Medium and high does, though.Oscillation - 180 degree movement to ensure proper heat direction in the room.I'm impressed with the heater's capabilities. The remote control is a plus. Control mode, timer, power.Recommended.
Another goodie from Aveeno.Gentle, smells neutral, and lathers well. The hints of oatmeal is relaxing.Worth a look.

This ergo-comfort dog collar has a nice design and materials.Though the inside lining is comfortable and built well, I found the collar to be a bit thin. I'd wished it'd be maybe half an inch wider.Still a plenty good collar for consideration.

The PDP AG 9 is a wireless headset built for xbox one. It intends to provide booming and balanced sound, clear chat transmission, and a comfortable headset for gaming sessions. In those three areas, the AG 9 lives up to the bill with some (possible) annoyances.Sound - lots of power, bass, explosive, and pleasing for games I've played (tomb raider, nhl 16, destiny). Comparable to the sound quality of Creative and Corsair on PC gaming headsets.Microphone - The microphone is detachable and inserts into the headset with mini jack. It must be firmly inserted and not have any wiggling room. It is not a flip up and down style nor is it concealable when not in use. I found that microphone quality was decent. I am audible in xbox chats. It sounds like I'm far away from the microphone when it in fact I'm basically about to eat the mic. I wished plantronics made mics for PDP. I didn't experience any connection or audio transmission issues.Design (comfort, build, battery life):Comfort - The highlight of the design. Cushioned well on the earcups and headband. I wear glasses and can still get a fairly comfortable session (1+ hours). The earcups are huge and fully cover my ears.Build - Durable, well built. I love the green LED lights on the earcups. The left speaker button has a few commands: 1) Hold button to power on 2) Hold button to power off 3) hit once to mute/unmute. There are dials for the volume and game vs chat volume.16 hours of battery life is somewhat of a stretch but a decent estimate nonetheless. I experienced about 13 hours, mostly with tomb raider (no mic) and madden(consistent trash talking). I wished gaming headsets would come with like a city vs highway MPG type of estimate. Maybe something like battery life while using mic vs battery life without using mic.One really annoying (but maybe not to you) quip: whenever the headset is having some hiccups (delay in transmission), low in battery, or is not in range, there is a very loud beep. The volume of this beep is NOT something you can change. Please inform if I am able to. I wished it was more of a doot doot, instead of a BEEP BEEEP HONK.It seems there are some lemons (mostly regarding the microphone) out there. I suppose I'm a lucky one (knock on wood). This wireless has been great so far and the microphone has been fine. At its best, the AG 9 serves the xbox one gamer quite well with great sound, a decent mic, and excellent build and comfort. At its worst, it seems some have experienced subpar/non functional microphones.

This value set does exactly what it intends to: cut hair at reasonable cost.Comes with 9 guide combs, scissors, cleaning brush.The clipper head is built well. It feels heavy in the hand but will probably not survive a 5 foot drop.Worth a look.

I've been in my current position for more than 3 years now. The beginning was up and down: promising, steady, but quickly went sour when a significant event occurred in my life. My work began to suffer and I disappointed myself and my colleagues. I have since improved my well being and reputation at work, but there is still much to be done.The parts the book that seem geared towards my hardship is being resilient and acing every interaction. Using science and relatively up to date research, the examples stick much better than someone who is just telling you to believe them because it's good for you. There is some credibility.Whether you're starting your career, stuck in a rut, or just looking to take yourself to the next level, this is a good supplement to your life.

The base and the magnetic base are well built. The silicon sucks onto almost anything in your dashboard well. It won't grab onto perforated or grainy surfaces very well. Python for Kids is an excellent python beginnerâ€™s tutorial. This book aims to introduce the python language and engaging kids to immediately learn this language. The writing style is concise, has the tone of an elementary school teacher, and is also great for adult beginners like myself (sometimes the best way to learn is reading kids/children books for the subject matter).Hereâ€™s the structure of the book: 1) Introduce the project for the chapter 2) Go through each block of code 3) Flush through some tips 4) Summary of the points covered for the projectWriting style â€“ the writer assumes you know nothing about this subject. I like the conversationalist style and dummed down(pun intended) style. In between the coding, I enjoyed some of the humor as such: â€œMake sure you know the flow (and go with the flow, too).  It is very easy to just stop at a section, trying it out on your computer, and then continue.Project content â€“ of the 10 projects, two are geared to getting you started â€“ setting up your coding environment and some pointers to getting started. The rest of the projects will cover topics like dictionaries, functions, loops, classes (shivers), list,  and modules(os, random, string, etc.).As an adult beginner, I thoroughly enjoyed this book. I think your child (or yourself) will too.

Excellent pack. The recycle feature is a bit of a gimmick, but it's a start, right? I assume the recycled part is the shell casing not the actual cells.Has held a good charge. The pack I received expires 2027.Worth a look.

Needed a spray that would be a good in between washes. This spray will definitely NOT replace or be an alternative for car washing.If the car is a couple days post car wash, this is ideal.
