This works fine for our 2010 Ranger.  It seamlessly integrates with our Pop & Lock 2310 tailgate lock.  This Diften is the closest handle we've found to the original Ford part.  The plastic was molded straight so it installed and operated easily (a problem that i had with less-expensive handles).  The handle even looks nice.  From my limited experience this handle seems worth the few dollars more than the less-expensive aftermarket alternatives.

I've tried this on several small engines that were developing carburetor problems.  It helped clean out a 2-cycle leaf blower somewhat - at least it got to the point where it would idle, but had no effect on high-speed.  It had no effect on gunky Honda GX-31 4-cycle (I had to get a new Honda carb), and minimal effect on a Craftsman Gas lawn mower.  In all cases, I followed mfgr. directions for use.  Perhaps it would have worked better as a "conditioner" rather than de-gunker.  Who knows.My unscientific hunch is that this is no more effective at de-gunking than Marvel Mystery Oil and Sea Foam, both of which have been around for nearly a century, have a proven track record of not doing damage, and are considerably less expensive.  I thought I'd try MIABGT as an experiment to see if it would be more effective than MMO and SF.  My non-scientific conclusion is that it isn't.
works as expected - no problem at all to install and set up.
didn't work for me.
Works just fine.  Doesn't cut easily and stands up to the dishwasher.
works fine; fits the SL1600 fine.  These are pretty simple devices so one wouldn't look for much other than fit, finish and continuity.  I bought 2 and they were both fine as shipped
works well for me to maintain flora balance.  Pro-15 has more enzymes than the Pearls products, so one PRO-15 is the equivalent of a few different Pearls.  I take them daily and have for many months.

Great lubricant for plumbing applications. We use this instead of the Leslie's pool lube for greasing o-rings, faucet parts, etc.  The difference is that the molykote is stiff stuff and the viscosity does not diminish with use or exposure to non-pressurized water.  Read: the moly stays in place and remains slippery.  It's relatively expensive, but works better for me.
works just fine in a plastic desk lamp fixture.  The lamp color is  a bit yellow for my taste, but it was so hard to find a replacement bulb that we decided to take what we could get.

I replaced two Sioux Chief arresters (one of  which failed) with these on our front loader.  The SC failed after only 5 years or so.  It's a pain to pull out the oversized front loader and install new arresters, so I decided to go up scale with these IPSs.  I have no previous experience with them, but i figured that you must get some value for the extra money (homeowner's dilemma?).  They look well made, and silence the pipes more than the SCs even when new.  If they last, I'll be quite pleased.note: I ordered 2 from Amazon.  The first one came in 2-3 days.  The second one took over a month.  Apparently there's a glitch or two in the supply chain management.

Like some of the other reviewers, i was drawn to these when Radio Shack stopped carrying their counterpart.  These do not have the sound quality of the Radio Shack ear nipples - the sound is tinnier (hence 4 stars).  That said, these are way cheaper ($2 vs $6 each), so you get what you pay for.  For those who want comparison to RS, note that the cords are 2' longer on these and the mini plug is inline rather than L shaped..If RS still made theirs, I'd rather pay a few bucks more for them for the sound quality.  However, these are good enough. I only go through 1 or 2 of these a year, so I'll update this post in 2020.  :-)

NOTE: This is an evaluation of the Amazon ad, not the product.  Explanation: The photo is a Respironics Remstar M Series, but these filters are used with the older & larger CPAPs (e.g., the Remstar Plus).  These filters will not work in the CPAP in the photograph!  The text part of this ad is correct (incl. the measurements).  I have both the M and Plus, so I speak with first hand knowledge.For the Remstar M Series, search "Respironics Remstar M Series, M Compatible 12 UF 2 Foam filter" on Amazon.  They currently sell for $10.98/dozen.

Seem to be well constructed @ a great price point.  I used to buy Nelsons, but at this price I can afford to put a new set on the garden hoses every year.I can't speak to the durability as I've only used for a few months.  If problems develop, I'll update this post.

This worked just fine with my new Selle Royal Classic Gel saddle. I placed the inner rail lamps on the rail (they held snugly) then squeezed the pole clamp with channel locks as I pushed the pole clamp down in between the rail clamps.  Just took a few tries. The tightening rod in these Velos are square except for the threading which makes the tightening very easy as you can tighten either side independently, alternating back and forth.  The last clamp I installed (a few years ago i must confess) required two wrenches.  This method is slick.  I have a 250lb frame and this clamp is secure enough to keep the seat tight for me.

This is a comfortable seat.  I've used it for a few weeks and it works fine for me (250+lbs@6').  I use this on my gas-powered pedal assist bike so I'm sitting down on it more than I would on a pure pedal-powered bike.  I have a Schwinn gel on my e_bike, which also works fine, but this one is softer fwiw.  Note that this seat does not come with a seat clamp.  I used the Velo Seat Clamp for standard rail saddles ($5 incl shipping at this writing) which worked fine.

great shelf supports.  fit into new 5mm holes snugly.  There's not a lot of difference between shelf pins, but these are as good as any other spoon styles that i have had.  the brass color is uniform in appearance.  the thing i liked most about this vendor and Amazon was that you could select quantity - all Prime.  I got the box of 50@$8.99 (18c each) incl. shipping, but 25@$5.99 (24c), 100@16.99(17c), and 200@$31.99(16c) are also available.  Box of 50 seemed to be the optimal price point.To put this in perspective, Superclosets also offers a bag of 20 in dull bronze for $2,25 w/$1 shipping ($16c each), so you have a variety of price competitive options.

Great little  bag.  I gave these to my grown kids as presents for their ipads, etc.  They all like it and use it regularly.Typical Tumi quality.  I've been buying Tumi products for 30 years (when Boyt went under - a long time ago).  i've had their computer roller bags, soft sides, suit bags, back packs with rollers, and they've all held up well.  They're pricey, but if you are a road warrior you can't afford to have a bag fail while traveling.  In the few (pre-Boyt/Tumi) times that happened to me overseas, it cost me more money in my time to find the replacement than the bag was worth.  Tumis have never failed me.  But then neither has Briggs and Riley - and their quality product line is considerably less money.I got this on sale for slightly over $100 - a very attractive price for a Tumi.

I've had several Waterpiks over the years, and they all worked as advertised.  This version is no exception.  I've had this one for over 6 months with no problem.  The WP-660 has seven interchangeable nozzles which i guess is a benefit.  I've only used the general use tip.  and if that should wear out, there's a replacement included.  There's also a tongue cleaner, some brushers, a tip for braces, etc.  I've never used any of them.Features that I appreciate: 10-setting pressure control.  I typically use 9 or 10.  Reservoir is for 1min+.  I use warm water and Listerine mix 2 times daily.Weaknesses: tip eject button is too loose.  a few times a month i shoot the nozzle into the basin by accidentally hitting it.  The water switch to control flow is way too stiff and hard to use when the handle is wet.  They should have reversed the stiffness on these 2 buttons.  This cost 1 star on my rating.All in all, this does what it claims.  Recommended.

This is a good replacement for any 3/8 by 2" rapid fit tub stopper.  Frankly, I've never had one that wasn't acceptable as there isn't much that can go wrong.  There's a rubber plug a threaded tip and an internal lock (the part that wears out first for me).  There are several stop/strainers that are incompatible - the easiest way to replace is to bring the old one to the hardware store.  As i have replaced dozens of these over the years, i knew that i needed this size so Amazon saved me thinking about it.  Unfortunately, Amazon didn't carry the brass version that i wanted, but it is a drain for my hot tub so i can live with stainless.

Fine replacement for 650E OEM filters.  Note that as other reviewers have mentioned, the cartridges are now black (not white as pictured).  I have no idea what the difference is.  My 650E seems to work the same with either varieties.These are expensive for what they are.  I have noticed that the "replace filter" light seems to come on every 6 months or so.  The last two times i didn't think the filters were all that soiled - e.g., you could see light through them at the folds.  This next time, I'm going to reset the 650E and try to get a few extra months out of the filters.  If this turns out to be a bad idea, I'll update this review.Expensive but seem to be effective.p.s. one thing i should add.  I subscribed to the Blueair reminder system.  When Blueair sends me announcements of filter discounts, Amazon also has the discounted price.

I had no idea what this show was going to be about when I began streaming it, but something about it caught my eye. I really dislike procedural crime shows for the most part, which is what Longmire more or less is. However, it's presented in such a unique fashion, and exectued so perfectly, it instantly got me hooked. I blasted through the first 2 seasons in no time! The casting is brilliant, with every character being richly portrayed, for all their strengths and weaknesses. The setting is stunning and one that has rarely been utilized in television. I love watching these characters struggle to maintain law and order in the vast wilderness of Wyoming. In addition to the individual crimes that present themselves each episode, there are also a few long-arc stories that are teasingly developed over the course of the season, done so in a manner that engages the viewer's curiosity, but gives them just enough to stay satisified (no long, long periods with no answers but just more questions). Longmire is one of my new favorites shows!

This game lives up to its reputation for being insanely, diabolically difficult. However, you shouldn't let that deter you. Cooperative board games are only fun if they're challenging, and this one certainly fits the bill! What I love most about Ghost Stories is the richly presented theme. It really puts you into this Halloween-style atmosphere, and it gets your imagination going as you and your team of monks attempt to battle back these terrifying creatures. You really do feel like you're experiencing an "onslaught", and you have to pool all of your resources, special abilities, and brain power to survive. Ideal with 4 players, I recommend playing multiple monks if you have any empty seats at your table. That makes for a process that is much easier to follow, it's more fun, and as an added bonus - you're more likely to survive with additional monks there to help you!

Power Grid is an excellent tabletop game, rich with strategy, unique in concept, and masterful in execution. At first glance, it looks a bit intimidating, in terms of how complicated it will be to learn the ins and outs. But don't be fooled! People with a moderate amount of experience playing strategy games will pick this one up in no time at all. It's really fun to play, requiring a lot of brain power, which keeps you stimulated and engaged. The components are top notch and high quality, with excellent artwork that enhances the game's fun factor.

Another amazing entry in the Fables saga! Willingham continues to surprise me with the new life he can breathe into these ancient characters, utilizing clever storylines and twists that you won't see coming. Boy Blue is the surprising star of this volume (though Jack's role in the first two included issues bears mentioning), and the revelation of the Adversary's true identity (and mission) is a shocker that you won't see coming.

I am very wary whenever approaching a fantasy-themed comic, because they are incredibly formulaic, generic, and boring. Fortuantely, this first volume of Pathfinder, collecting issues 1-6, delivers something not often seen in the realm of fantasy comic - a fun, entertaining story, beautifully delivered with vibrant artwork and excellent dialogue. Pathfinder is not immune to the tropes of the fantasy genre, and you will definitely see many of the typical stereotypes, such as the brash fighter, the surly dwarf, the lowly goblin cannon fodder, and the awakening of an ancient evil that can only be confronted by the well balanced party of adventurers that happens to include a fighter, rogue, soceror, wizard, and cleric. However...What prevents Pathfinder from becoming another boring fantasy romp is the execution itself. Sure, these characters are based on stereotypes, but they are instilled with such wonderful personality and unique quirks, they persevered and won me over. Furthermore, most of them have unique quirks that make them interesting. For instance, the elderly wizard may seem terribly cliche... if not for the fact that he started studying magic remarkably late in life, only after his status of privileged statesman fell apart. What really makes these characters come to life is their interactions with one another. They have excellent chemistry, which is brought to life with their dialogue, adventuring, and team combat.The other thing that helps Pathfinder so much is the outstanding artwork. It's bright, colorful, and pencilled with great skill. It brings the characters, monsters, and story to life, and it has a great capacity for capturing "motion"- when characters are involved in combat, the intensity of their movements is evident, further enhanced by their richly drawn expressions and features.I have no familiarity whatsoever with the Pathfinder universe, but I found this graphic novel to be a fun, worthwhile read that stirred my imagination and kept me captivated throughout.

Another outstanding entry in the Fables series by Bill Willingham. It was a delight to watch Snow with her very, very strange 6 (or is it 7?) new children, as she begins the journey of being a mother in the weirdest place on earth. The introduction of the babies' grandfather, the North Wind, was executed very well, as was the murder mystery that cleverly plays out over the course of this story arc. My favorite part, however, was the retelling of Bigby Wolf's time assisting the U.S. Army durring WWII, involving a siege on a Nazi castle and a downright awesome monster mash featuring the Wolfman Vs. Frankenstein in a throwback to the classics.

I got this game free with the month's PS Plus bonuses. It sat on my PS4, unused, for several weeks. I didn't think I would have any interest in the game - but I was wrong. I fired Rocket League up last night, and I was immediately delighted. The thing that instantly makes this game a 10/10 is that it actually features COUCH CO-OP PLAY! Not only that, but it's incredibly fun! We were sitting in the living room last night, laughing uncontrollably, cursing at the TV screen, and having a blast. Rocket League reminds me of the old days, when you could sit together with your firends and family and play fun games on the same console, on the same TV, in the same room. The best single word for this game is: FUN! The concept is simple, the physics are genius, and the results are hilarious. I would have gladly dropped $60 for a game that delivers this much couch co-op play - I can't believe I ended up getting it for free!

I think this is the best collected volume in the Fables series thus far. It featured plenty of action, intrigue, and surprise. The story is fast paced and engaging, featuring many, many fables from all corners of this comic's universe, including the big guys and the lesser known ones, as well. Perhaps most impressive of all is the fact that Willingham is willing to make major sacrifices by offing certain characters (though some of these will undoubtedly return via the magic of fables). My favorite part of this volume, however, is the growing relationship between Bigby and Snow. These characters are very well done and I'm enjoying watching them grow to know one another and care for each other. I can't wait for volume 5!

Superb shoes, on par with the Kayano series, also from ASICS. I would have a tough time rating one above the other, honestly. Both offer all day comfort, excellent durability, and top notch build quality and style. Whether you're a hardcore runner or somebody who just likes their feet to feel good, this very expensive shoe is a very wise investment!

I came upon the Fables universe by playing the excellent "The Wolf Among Us" game on PS4. I was immediately captured by the charming nature of the characters, from the big ones like Bigby and Snow, all the way to the little guys like Flycatcher and Collin. Playing that game is what got me interested in looking up this first collection of the Fables comic, and if you're a similar fan of "The Wolf Among Us", you will not be disappointed. It's similar in nature, featuring Bigby's hardboiled detective adventures as he interviews legends from a plethora of tales, with Snow White by his side, the both of them trying to retain order in the madhouse neighborhood of NYC that is Fabletown. I love the dialogue in this series, which develops the characters with excellent depth, as well as moving the story along at a perfect pacing. Finally, this volume deserves credit for being a credible murder mystery of moderate complexity, with enough clues sprinkled throughout so that the reader can solve the case on their own (if they're possessed of the ambition to do so - as well as a little luck!).

Of all the possible genres, I think comedy is by far the hardest one to tackle. To write something that others will find funny is extremely challenging, but Ionia Martin pulls it off with this book. Plundering the Romance Novel is somewhat without peer, insofar as I cannot think of any similiar books by which to compare it (and I have read many, many books). Rather than reminding me of any books I might have read in the past, it actually calls to mind classic satire/parody movies, such as Space Balls, Blazing Saddles, and The Princess Bride, and that is some very good company to be around. I felt sort of like I was reading a Mel Brooks screenplay or something, with the outlandish, over-the-top characters lampooning themselves with hilarious self-awareness as they smashed their flip-flops and boots through the fourth wall, accosting the sensibilities of the reader while pursuing fortune, romance, and cheap wine suitable for bathing. Comedic entries are somewhat rare when it comes to novels, so this treat will be greatly appreciated by anybody hungry for humor!

I am Invincible's #1 fan, so I was happy to see this miniseries spinoff in the Invincible universe. After all, it means more time spent in the whacky world filled with unique, downright bizarre characters and storylines. As such, I enjoyed it for what it was - a short distraction within Invincible's dimension, highlighted by OctoBoss' trademark horrendous grammar. Although the ramifications of the story are ultimately meaningless in the longterm for Invincible, it does manage to develop some further character detail for fan favorites like Brit and Yeti. However, I would only recommend this book if you are already a diehard Invincible fan - otherwise, you'll be completely bewildered by Kirkman's spoof-style take on superhero comics, and you'll be left scratching your head and mumbling beneath your breath as to what the heck you just read. Start with the core Invincible series instead, and for those of you who are all caught up, this is a decent addition to the universe, though not as good as Tech Jacket, Brit, or Invincible Universe.

Though this game does not in any way look like a "next gen" title (at best, it looks like a decent PS3 game), that doesn't really matter, because it's just plain fun to play. The mechanics of this game work wonderfully, particularly the hand-to-hand combat and the driving, which has perfect, arcade style physics that fit the wonkiness of the premise. I love that this game lets you do all the fun stuff you want to, without punishing you for doing so or making the game harder to play if you cause a ruckus- that's the way I like open world games, to encourage freedom and wackiness at all moments. The story of this game is also awesome, as is the voice acting, although its serious nature creates a very odd contrast to the totally goofy gameplay.

I love this book. The best way to describe it is COLORFUL. The jungle island in which our hero battles dinos, mammoths, madmen, and monsters is a vibrant, beautifully realized world in which the artists of this book excelled. The story is campy, fun, fast paced, and downright awesome. It plays out in a similar fashion to Indiana Jones, King Kong, or Noah Wylie's Librarian. Jungle Girl was a great find I stumbled upon, and this omnibus collects her entire adventure. Here's hoping there's more to come!

I'm a big fan of tabletop games, fiction, and mysteries, and this game successfully blends all three of those things into a unique and enjoyable experience. It has elements of the "Choose Your Own Adventure" books many people in their 30s grew up with, as well as the "Carmen Sandiego" games that were so popular in the 80s. One of the best things about this game is how well it works when played cooperatively. This is the ONLY way I would recommend playing Sherlock Holmes, as it creates a fun, exciting dynamic where everybody gets to contribute and be part of the team's successes and failures. The team brainstorming and deduction is incredibly fun, as you attempt to unravel these well written mysteries and solve the questions posed to you by Holmes. Conversely, playing in competetive mode leads to looooong periods of silence and thumb twiddling while you wait for the others follow their leads and read the respective clues (and the more players you have, the longer those idle periods become).There's nothing else quite like this game out there. It's a ton of fun (especially for people who enjoyed Carmen Sandiego and are fans of modern shows like Psyche), the scenarios are excellent, the writing is detailed (putting you right into Victorian London), and the components are top notch. The only bummer is that there are only 10 cases, but I still think this is a solid value, and I remain hopeful that there will one day be expansions!

There is something about this game that keeps drawing me back. I find myself thinking of it when I'm at work, and I can't wait to get home to continue Geralt's quest for a couple more hours. It's weird... the game is a little slow for my liking, and I find the interactions between quest points (random encounters in the open world) to be rather sparse. Yet, I find the world of this game utterly compelling. It's a fascinating place, beautifully realized, and I just want to keep on exploring it with Geralt. I haven't yet been able to wrap my head around all the crafting and inventory details, but that hasn't impacted my enjoyment. Although animations aren't the best I've seen, the combat is very much enjoyable, thanks to the inclusion of magic with Geralt's superior swordsmanship. I don't think I would recommend this game to people who have nevery enjoyed RPGs, but if you're a fan of the genre, this might be the last game you need for a long, long time.

In short, this is the best guide I've ever seen in my 35 years (25 of which have been spent gaming). The quality is simply outstanding, with a durable cover, superior binding, rich colors, thick pages, and crisp text. In terms of content, this thing is loaded beyond all reckoning - you'll probably never read the entire thing (it's over 500 pages!), but everything's in there if you need it. In addition to comprehensive quest directives, glossarys, and guides to crafting, I particularly enjoy all the supplemental stuff that covers the many characters of the series. As a newcomer to the Witcher, I found this most useful and interesting. As a final bonus, there's an awesome smaller book (about 90 pages, I think) that is included. It features unique binding and a bunch of additional content to further flesh out the universe of the Witcher. Even if you don't think you want to use the guide to help you with the game, I would recommend this book to anybody who is a fan and wants to get even more out of the Wild Hunt experience.
Does the job just as it should. Works perfectly and it's priced fairly!

Volume 2 of the new TMNT series doesn't suffer the sophomore slump. Rather, this title picks up right where the last one left off, firing on all cylinders. Just as in the first volume, the artwork and writing are executed at a level of near perfection, fitting this series just the way it needs to appease both newcomers and turtle lifers. I particularly loved the parts of this volume that occur in feudal Japan, and the artwork portraying the ninja clans and their battles is amazing. I thought the idea of tying these ancient feuds into the turtles' current struggles was a brilliant idea. Sure, the reincarnation theory that Master Splinter is advancing is downright absurd, but the comic is about teenage mutant ninja turtles... so anything goes, and this is hardly the craziest thing that has happened in the sewers of NYC. Personally, I like it!

This is an amazing reboot of the TMNT comic series, and I think they hit everything right on the head. The artwork, story, and dialogue all work perfectly, serving as an ideal point for both newcomers and old school fans of the turtles. I particularly enjoyed the imagination and detail that went into the origin of the turtles and Splinter as they busted out of the lab and into the sewers - and in the process, meeting their first nemesis, Old Hob. Let the slicing and dicing and pizza munching begin!

This is another outstanding tale from Jonathan Hickman. For anybody who has ever been a fan of weird science shows like Warehouse 13, Eureka, or Fringe, you will get a kick out this. The premise- that the group of genius scientists who assembled to create the atomic bomb were actually more preoccupied with their "special" projects is a fun one. However, this is also a very twisted tale... from Oppenheimer's evil twin to Einstein's inconceivable secret, this is an alternate history that is very dark indeed. The art style is bizarre... I would describe it as "shaky", and at first glance, I was not particularly impressed with it. However, once I began reading the book, I realized the art matches the story perfectly: it's a neurotic thrill ride, capable of inducing naseua even as it delivers entertainment.

When I first read the synopsis for this series, I was not interested in the slightest. The premise, that of a world approaching the apocalypse, under siege by the Four Horsemen, seemed kind of cliched to me. I'm happy to say I was completely wrong! This comic is incredible. First, let me compliment the writing. The story is completely unique, and it truly stands out in an over saturated market of "me too" apocalyptic tales. The writing is downright eloquent for any medium, and without peer among comics. Both the dialogue and the descriptions is perfectly written, and I oftentimes found myself going back and reading passages two or three times - something I nearly never do when reading comics. It's almost poetic in nature. And the alternate history timeline that Hickman has created is fascinating and exciting.The artwork is the perfect match for the writing. I love the renditions of all the characters, especially Wolf and Crow. Those characters have transforming abilities that must make them extremely challenging to illustrate, but they are brought to life on the page like magic. They are so convincingly portrayed, it adds to their aura of power and mystique.I liked Volume 1 so much, I immediately ordered Volume 2 and 3 and subscribed to the series!

Needless to say, if you've made it all the way to Season 9 of this show... you probably like it. There have been many, many funny moments in this show's history, but I think this season they did the impossible and turned it up a notch! Outright hilarity is the rule of the day as The Gang Saves The Day and/or Gets Quarantined. And let's not forget Stifler's role as Country Mac! Awesome!

Somehow this movie slipped under my radar when it was released at the theater, so much so that I didn't even recognize the title. When my son showed up with this from the Red Box, I was thinking, "What is this garbage? Some direct to DVD animated silliness?" I sat down to watch it with him, and was delightfully surprised. This movie is really, really funny (and I typically prefer the hard R stuff like "Horrible Bosses" and "Team America"), and I was thrilled to see such big roles from some great actors, like Steve Carell. There is some stuff in here that will definitely embarrass and possibly enrage more squeamish or conservative parents, but all things considered (this is the age of the internet, people! Your kids have already seen horrible, horrible things!), this movie is pretty tame. Personally, I thought Dick Van Dyke's profanity in a book shop full of little kids and parents was classic stuff in the making. Ultimately, this is a Disney movie, so we have the requisite amount of sentimental, tear-jerking, manipulative plot points, but it all works well and makes you pull for this wacky family. Also, I have to say, the rendering of high school life, office life, and family life is pretty spot-on, though obviously told through the lens of exaggeration for the purposes of entertainment. Two thumbs up!
Extremely well built. Nice materials, built to last, and it works perfectly every time. Also, it's priced pretty darned competitively. What more could you ask for?

This is the best Roku unit available, and quite possibly the best streaming player out there. I've been using Roku players since the original debuted, and they've come a long way. Please don't try to save a few bucks and get one of the lower end ones (I tried the Roku Stick, and I had to return it, it was so bad). This thing is SUPER fast, which is a big deal when you just want to get into Netflix and watch a little streaming. It's designed really intelligently, it never fails, and I love the headphone jack in the remote control, which works flawlessly. The headphone jack is a MUST for when you're working out. Now that I use that feature, I don't know how I ever functioned without it!

Every time this game was described to me, I thought: "That sounds terrible! Why is Persona 4 so popular?"Well, now I know. It's impossible for me to adequately explain why, but this game is absolutely amazing. I'm 35 years old, and have no interest in high school, but for some reason, P4 makes taking on the role of a high school student FUN. I absolutely loved the characters in this game. I loved going to class, going to the food court. Heck, I even loved studying and taking exams. Weird, right? The developers of this game must be straight up geniuses, to make such mundane things so fun.My least favorite part, ironically, was the combat and "dungeon delving" (if you could call it that - it's really weird). However, it's not really terrible. It's just that the gameplay in the school and town was so much fun, I wanted to get back to that as soon as possible. The characters are so amazing, I grew to care for all of them, and I already miss being in their world!
For the most part, this is a great case. However, it is a budget priced unit, so don't expect it be as nice as an Otter Box or Life Proof. Dollar for dollar, however, I think I'll take this one.

I can pretty much guarantee this will be the last Vita card I'll ever have to purchase. With the size of the typical Vita games, it will be pretty hard to use up all 64GB, even with the 24 free ones I get each year from my PS Plus subscription. It's only a shame this card didn't come out earlier in the Vita's life! If you're going to purchase one, I recommend spending a little more and getting this one- that way, you won't have to worry about upgrading down the road.

Did not fit in the printer as promised. Was not an exact replacement, though they looked the same. When I used an official Epson unit, I experienced no such problems. These cartridges are priced low, but since they don't work, it's money and time wasted.

This issue is quite a bit slower than the previous three, in terms of action. It is, however, just as engaging when it comes to story. There are several exciting new revelations in #4, not least of which is the return of Warren/Archangel, who seems to have forgotten who he is, and taken up the notion that he is, in fact, a real angel. As ludicrous as it sounds, evidence is presented that he might actually be able to resurrect the dead...? Deathlok makes an interesting cameo, but the most startling bit of story here is a young Apocalypse, apparently created from the DNA of the big guy in a lab somewhere. Unaware of his origins or true potential, he's a troubled young man, to put it mildly. But Wolverine seems to have no plans of informing the youngster of his true nature, instead opting to wing it and hope for the best, Logan-style. But is this wise? Well, probably not, but we'll find out in due time!

Having not kept up with the X-Men in recent years, the character of Quentin Quire is a complete mystery to me, and I was glad to learn more of him in this issue, as well as catch a glimpse of his impressive psychic power. Kid Gladiator is another character who I was not familiar with, and I'm enjoying my exposure to him in this comic. Like Quire, he's brash and arrogant, yet those traits seem to work for him in his free-spirited, destructive lifestyle. I also like Broo, the alien student who looks a bit like E.T. There's obviously a huge culture gap between the world he comes from and our own, and the results of this discrepancy are hilarious, such as when he invites enemy monsters ("brother omnivores") to accompany him to the snack machines in a failed quest for friendship.I'm only three issues into this series, of course, but so far this is one of the most exciting Marvel books I've read in years. Not only is it intelligently written and superbly illustrated, but it's a real page turner - I loved seeing what would happen next, as Wolverine battled a giant earth monster and Beast desperately labored in his lab for a solution, doing his best to ignore the rising tide of lava. Oh, and the X-Men get a new member in this new issue... an utterly bizarre one that you will not be expecting!

This is the comic series that is making the X-Men feel fun and fresh for me again. There have been so many story lines and spin offs and rehashes, it's hard to keep them straight. But this series, so far, has been unique and entertaining. This issue was just as exciting as the first one, and there is a remarkable amount of creativity put on display here. The writers came up with some nutty ideas, and the artist brought them to life brilliantly. The pages are filled with vibrant, exciting panels that depict a massive battle for the survival of Wolverine's new school (on its very first day of existence, of course). There are some CRAZY monsters in this one, and I loved the way they were brought to life on paper. And it's the little things that really make it excel - things like Iceman's impressive display of power and (my favorite moment) when two stuffy pencil pushers get transformed into a Yeti and a Sauron... totally bizarre and hilarious!

This is a great expansion for the Legendary base game, and you get a lot of content for your dollar. Five new heroes are added, those being the Fantastic Four and the Silver Surfer. Each of these characters can hold their own, and they each have a unique set of abilities that matches their comic personas. They're well balanced, though the Silver Surfer leans a bit toward being obscenely powerful (as he should be), but that's okay, because it's fun to add his cards to your deck. The villains and masterminds are likewise superbly implemented, and they are a very colorful and diverse set (Moleman's subterranean followers and Galactus' interstellar flunkies). The new abilities, like "focus" and "burrow" are great additions, and they are not complex, making it very easy to learn them quickly and implement them in the game. Last but not least, the artwork deserves special kudos. In my opinion, this expansion features the best illustrations of any cards in the Legendary universe.

When I saw this series, I was thinking "Oh no, not ANOTHER X-Men spin off!" To my surprise and delight, this is a really enjoyable, unique take on the franchise. Mind you, I haven't been keeping up with the X-Men, so I have no idea what led up to the current state of affairs (as it begins in this issue). But with the interesting premise of a new school for mutants being formed, not by Professor X, but by Wolverine (with Kitty Pryde serving as head mistress), this is shaping up to be a fun story.The dialogue between the characters and the artwork complement each other really well, making for a smooth flowing comic that is exciting and engaging. It kept me turning the pages to see what would happen next, as a stressed out Wolverine (complete with suit and tie) tries to assure the education authorities that his school is on the up and up (while all sorts of shenanigans are happening all around them, of course). The table was amply set with all sorts of characters, conflicts, and villains, and this will almost certainly turn out to be a really wild ride. How many days of being a head master can Wolverine survive before he snaps? Time will tell!

This is a fantastic graphic novel, carried by the strength of its characters and the humor with which they investigate their wacky assignments. So many comics attempt to be super serious, mature, and/or gory, and Atomic Robo is none of the above. Instead, this comic goes in the polar opposite direction - and it succeeds wildly.Atomic Robo is the star of the show, of course, and within this Tesla-built mechanized detective/warrior/comedian beats a surprisingly human heart. His dialogue is always spot-on, and his jokes are always the perfect blend of cheesiness and uniqueness. The way in which he is artistically depicted matches his personality perfectly, and his big ol' eyes are wonderful for conveying his emotions. He is perpetually upbeat and ethically sound, yet he doesn't come off as preachy or corny. Rather, Atomic Robo seems like the kind of guy you would love to sit around and drink a few beers with (or go on adventures with). In fact, Atomic Robo recounts the time he convinced one of his fellow soldiers (a human one) that robots could get drunk, and challenged him to a drinking contest. Mind you, Atomic Robo does not have a mouth or any way of drinking, so this was quite a feat.The adventures that Atomic Robo sets out upon with his band of Action Scientists are exciting and varied. Thanks to his essential immortality, he has a vast number of experiences that have spanned generations, making for a fantastic collection of tales. Whether he's battling giant ants in the desert, or walking pyramids, or Nazi war criminals, Atomic Robo is guaranteed to have some exciting feats to keep his readers entertained!

In the afterword of this issue, the artist writes a short essay titled, "How Many Superheroes Can You Fit Into One Comic?" Well, it seems like he's truly committed to figuring out the answer to that query, because this issue is CRAMMED with colorful characters, stretching from panel to panel, from one end of the page to the other. It's a bombastic, visual thrill ride, and a true treat for Invincible fans. Mr. Liu's dragon rampage is a sight to behold, as is the massive alliance that is formed to take him down (the afterword credits massive get-togethers like Infinite Crisis and Secret Wars for his inspiration). We also get an insight as to the workings of Cecil Stedman's mind, and see a rarely glimpsed softer side (it really exists!) of the cranky old director.

Over the course of its 16 issue run, this has been one of my favorite Hulk stories of all time. The journey that Hulk and Banner went upon truly lived up to the title of "Incredible". The initial concept of separating Banner and Hulk and letting them live as two separate entities was a fascinating premise, and the results were unpredictable, exciting, and oftentimes disastrous. There was so much to love in this series! Boatloads of unique monsters, epic battles, intense psychological investigation, the secret city of Bigfoots, Atlantis, a Russian space base... you name it, it was probably in here. The creativity was on full blast for this series, and it was one wild ride.

For those of us that can't enough of the fantastic characters in Invincible, this comic is a godsend, as it basically double the monthly content we can get our hands on. It was a great way to get our Invincible fix while it lasted (hopefully, they'll bring this one back soon!). The story, art, colors, and personality of this comic gels with the Invincible universe perfectly. And that particular universe is so thickly jammed with interesting, fun characters, it's great to have an extra outlet where we can further explore their stories. In this first issue, the world has been torn asunder by the tomfoolery of Dinosaurus, and we get to watch as the earth's heroes struggle to put things right (if even just a little bit). As if that wasn't enough, we also get a taste of two other majorly interesting storylines that beginning to emerge: the death and resurrection of Kid Thor and the emerging dragon monster that is about to bust out of Mr. Liu's aging body.

This is the conclusion to the 2011 Incredible Hulk series, and I have to say, it was one wild ride, truly living up to the title "Incredible". It's one of my favorite Hulk stories of all time, and the breadth of craziness that has been created on paper has truly been astonishing (and satisfying). My only complaint is that the final showdown between Hulk and Doom never actually happens, and we have to try to be satisfied with him simply smashing up a bunch of Doombots. I'm not sure why that decision was reached, particularly when this is the end of this particular run. Doom's motives are also never fully explained, leaving a rather noticeable gap. However, I loved this series overall, and the highlight of this particular issue was the surprisingly funny dialogue between the Doombots as they pondered the existential dilemma and cracked wise with one another.

I ordered the medium and it fits perfectly. It looks way better on than in the picture. The way the blue is contoured it makes me look thinner. I am 5 foot 8, 140, and the medium is great in the sleeve length and is very form-fitting.It was 30 here yesterday (dry, high desert cold) and the jacket worked great with a hat and gloves. Anything colder and you'll need to layer more on.

I love trivia games but usually find the questions too simple. This game is not simple. While it is true that most of the questions seem to be about popular culture, at least they are interesting (mostly).We played with 7 people, and the game is only set up for 6, but that didn't seem to matter. Everyone loved it, even the people who didn't get any correct answers. That is what makes the game so different: answering questions isn't necessarily the way to win, but gambling on who else MIGHT or MIGHT NOT answer the question, is.There is one small flaw and one of our smarties figured it out pretty quickly. If you put your counter on the very last spot every single time you will have the best odds of getting the right answer. You won't get the highest points, but getting to listen to all of the other players' answers ups your chances of getting it correct.Anyhow, everyone really liked this game and wanted to play a second game immediately. I would say this is for adults as many of the questions are dependent on life experience or education (some geography and history questions, for example).We will definitely play this a lot.

I received a sample of this product to use and provide an objective review.I've used coconut oil for years in my soap making. Only recently have I started to use it in cooking. This coconut oil is the mildest smelling of any I've ever used. It has a fresh, buttery taste that is a bit heavier than olive oil and, in my opinion, better for foods like eggs and potatoes.  You will notice that it has a slightly different odor as you heat it, but you can't taste it in your food. Nice stuff!

This is fantastically smooth chocolate with a pleasantly bitter flavor.  It is a very, very buttery flavored chocolate and you only need a very small piece to feel sated.Wonderful stuff and, supposedly, very good for you, too!

This is one of the few products I've purchased this year that I actually researched. It seemed like many of the machines on the market were no longer being manufactured and I can only assume that is because of the danger that is inherent in having a trimmer with so much exposed cutting area (I can see people hurting themselves and others, very easily). That said, this is a must have tool if you have a lot of yard, but not enough to justify the 'real deal,' like a brush hog. The price was what decided me on this machine. Several of the companies who specialize in this type of cutter offer machines that look more substantial, but the price is three times more.I used this machine with extreme prejudice. I mowed down wild sunflowers (at the end of the season, when their stalks are like wood) tumbleweeds, three foot grasses, burdock, and an assortment of other tough plants/weeds. The only thing it wouldn't cut was welded wire fencing (oops!). That broke the cutters, but they are easy to replace. I bought the big roll of Cyclone cutter and it is a great deal.For the price, this machine is a steal and it is very well-built and easy to use.

This is my second expansion, the first being Seaside. The two expansions are very different in concept, and I find that I like Hinterlands much better. It doesn't have all the extra parts and pieces you get in Seaside, but the cards are so good you don't need them. This is a nice game that doesn't focus too much on the adversarial potential of the game.I would highly recommend this as a first expansion to people wanting to throw a little spice into the original game. These cards fit great with the original.

I hadn't read a Cornwell book for at least ten years and couldn't recall why. This book reminded me pretty quickly.The author is clearly a skilled hand at writing an interesting and well turned-out plot. The characters, however, were often hard to swallow.I realize there are a ton of books in the series before this one, so I've missed a lot. But that's not the problem. The problem is that I just didn't like any of the characters. Everyone was just a little 'too'. Not only is the niece an unbelievable Einstein-esque genius, but she's also beautiful, fiery, et cetera. But that's okay because Aunt Kay is a doctor, a lawyer, a colonel, an astronaut, one of the founders of the Impressionist  School (okay, so those last two I just threw in, but...)Yes, a lot of stuff about the characters has taken place in the preceding two dozen books (something around that, anyhow) so I don't know all the ins and outs of the characters' pasts. That doesn't matter to understanding their motivations, Cornwell is a pro and does a good job filling in the backstory. You don't need to read the other books to get a good idea about who is who and why they're the way they are. I just couldn't bring myself to care.Anyhow, although I found the characters hard to take, the dialogue was good and the pacing was enough to keep me plodding to the end, which is. . . surprise. . . a setup for the next novel, which I don't plan on reading.

We play a lot of the European-style games (Catan, Dominion, et cetera) so this was a fun 'Americanized' version of a strategy game.I've never watched the show but that didn't seem to make a difference as to how much fun it was. The only downside of the game is that it is a 3-4 player. We either seem to have the two of us, or more than 4, so it isn't as expandable as a game like Dominion.Anyhow, lots of fun, also lots of little pieces...

This is a good thermometer with a somewhat ponderous twist-- you need a smart phone to use it. I don't have a phone, so we downloaded the appropriate app on  my husband's iphone 5.Yes, the thermometer works well and stores data, but to what end? I'm guessing I'm the wrong market for this. If you have kids and they're all sick, or a chronically sick person, this would be awesome to track their temperature. For average use it requires too much technology, in my opinion. It would be nice if there was a way to tell temp with and without a link to a phone.Anyhow, I'm sure that gadget-mad people will really like this. I'll stick with the old-fashioned method (at least the digital thermometer that doesn't require a link)

These are both durable and adjustable. You cut them back for furniture legs that are smaller. I used them under my sleigh bed on pine floors and they were perfect to keep the bed in one place and also to protect the soft pine floors.These were given to me to use and provide an objective review.

This is a great substitute for my 10 year-old I-pod, which will no longer hold a charge. I am technically challenged, so this was a nice simple set-up for me. The sound is fine, although not as loud as the I-pod. I think for the price you can't go wrong.This is nice and much lighter than a phone, more pleasant to take when I am out walking.Product sample provided for review.

This is wonderful stuff! I started using it after I quit making my own and this is the nicest, most natural alternative I've found.Great lavender smell and lip balm itself is smooth and light. It doesn't leave a weird, waxy feel on your lips, either.

This is a very attractive-looking planner, nicer than the at-a-glance plastic coated books. That said, this is not nearly as resilient. I've been carrying it in my bag for a week and it is already looking scuffed. That isn't a big deal to me, just as long as it doesn't get so battered it falls apart.This is the second planner I've looked at this year, both by at-a-glance. I think it is interesting that each has a different way of presenting the full month calendar. This one starts the week on a Monday. The last started the week on a Sunday. I prefer the more traditional (although less intuitive) Sunday start, just because I'm accustomed to it.This is a great book in that there is a lot of space for each month and each day -- the daily calendar is great and has plenty of room to jot notes if you don't have an hourly schedule to keep. I also really like the two bookmarks, especially the elastic one that keeps the book closed.The pages are more of a cream color than stark white, which makes the planner look much nicer somehow. The only reason I dinged this a star is because I believe it will not hold up particularly well to being shoved into a briefcase and taken out dozens of times per day.

I think a person's evaluation of this book will depend a great deal on what expectations you have going into it. I am a lawyer and have taught US history on the college level, so I have a fair understanding of The Supremes (as my Con Law prof used to call them) and their place in American history. As such, I didn't expect any great revelations from Mr. Urofsky, and I wasn't surprised or disappointed by his book. That said, I did find the book a very elegantly written general overview of some of the most important cases in Supreme Court history.To me it is obvious dissent has been a major factor when it comes to developing American domestic policy -- just as it is in any long-term political relationship. The Founding Fathers considered dissent such a critical part of American politics that they drafted the Constitution in a way that wouldn't hedge or direct dissent (hence the lack of any reference or provision for political parties in the document). I think the history of the Court, and how it has developed over time and created its place in the federal government is covered very well in this book.Mr. Urofsky is eloquent on most of the subject matter and excessively interesting on anything that touches on Brandeis, which apparently is his real subject of expertise (or one of them ?)Anyhow, this was a nice refresher for me and got me thinking about cases I haven't given much thought to since law school. If you want a very readable account of the Court's history and how dissent has shaped the Court, this is a pleasurable read.

This is the tenth book I've read by this author. I really appreciate her sense of humor -- and her metaphors are the most hilarious in the HR business. I've started to notice a bit of a trend, in every one of her books other than the Marquess book and the Duke book, and that is a distinctly anticlimactic ending. This one had that in spades.I really liked both characters at the beginning, but there was a serious 'huh' factor when this prickly French prince (anyone who has read anything about the French aristocracy would find the depiction of Phillipe even more disbelief suspending than usual) becomes as tame as a pussy cat within mere pages. I needed a little more between him hurling vases and him calling her by her first name.All that said, I do enjoy so much about Long's writing. Very, very humorous and good characters that just sometimes lose their way. I thought Seamus was the most interesting, or perhaps Olivia's poor fiance, who probably has some hard times coming in the next book.

I did not hate this book, but I didn't love it, either. I'd probably give it 3.5 stars, but I'll round up because I thought the writing was quite well-done.The style and pacing of the writing is a bit hard to get into, but by the third or fourth chapter I began to get the rhythm of the book.I think my main problem with the book is that the characters were not particularly well-developed. That said, this is the sixteenth in the series and I suspect a lot of the development has happened over the prior books.This is an interesting historical period to have a detective novel and the author deftly handles the relationship between the two leads as well as the political difficulties of that existed at the time. I'd read another book by Janes, but I'd go back closer to the beginning of the series.

I've been using at-a-glance planners for years, for my business. This is the first one I've had with this particular cover.I still like the lay out of the book -- lots of space to write everything on each day and not cluttered up with useless information, but the soft cover and spiral binding are annoying. The book won't shut until you force it closed and the soft covered arrived already bent on two corners and now looks like somebody has chewed it after only a few trips in and out of my bag. This is a desktop planner only and not nearly resilient enough to survive being shoved into briefcases or bags. That probably wouldn't bother me if the thing would close without the spiral sticking each and every time.

These towels are nice and thick for a kitchen towel. In fact they take a washing to be more absorbent. Make sure to shake them out when you pull them from the dryer because they wrinkle. Even if you do that the edges wrinkle and if you want the 'like new' look you'll need to iron them.The design is okay, it is fairly innocuous, although the color combos are a little 2000s when everyone had a kitchen with Florentine tile.

I ordered these thinking they were AA's. I was surprised when I saw how big they are. Luckily I read some of the other reviews and saw it was worth trying them in a few items. They didn't fit in two of my flashlights, but fit in the one I really wanted re-chargeables for.I keep waiting for them to wear down to review them, but it has been weeks and they are still working great. I use the flashlight most nights to do my final walk-through on our small farm, so they get daily use.Anyhow, this is an interesting twist on the old-style batteries. Make sure the appliance you're purchasing them for can accommodate the larger size.I was provided with the batteries to use and test.

First off, many Americans without Indian food experience might know these as yellow split peas. They're very similar to the green, but lack the grittier, almost chalky texture of the green. I used these in a recipe from Madhur Jafre's cookbook (the first one, I think) called, unimaginatively enough, Chana Dal.Anyhow, they cook like lentils but take much longer. Her recipe called for 1.5 hours and these took at least 3. I'm at high altitude, so that probably accounts for much of the time increase.These don't absorb as much of the stock/sauce as lentils, but they are nice tasting in their own right and very substantial -- I couldn't eat more than a half cup of the prepared dal.I was provided with the product to use and test and give an objective review.These were tasty and clean, I didn't bother washing them.

This is a fine little chopper for garlic. I would not recommend it for nuts (too small, what's the point) which is what the company that sent me a sample recommended.Anyhow, this makes a nice little bowl of garlic and is as easy to clean as any chopper. The pieces store neatly in the unit, so you don't need to worry about losing them in your junk drawer.I modified this review to a five star because I realized I use the press more and more often -- I've actually come to prefer it over the conventional press.  If you are in the market for your first press, this would be a fine investment.sample provided for review

I was intrigued by this product, having heard about proactive for years.Well, it's basically just salicylic acid, just like any number of other cleansers and foundation creams. I noticed immediately the same results -- mild reddening, with no marked decrease in blackheads, or the more annoying cysts that are far too deep for this medication.Anyhow, this is the same thing you can buy for much cheaper in other over-the-counter acne creams. It was unrealistic to hope for more, but the price of the item seems to require that hope.

This is my first backpack of this type (not the kind you carry books in). I'm planning to take a two week trip, and this seems like a perfect size. I won't be camping, so I don't have to worry about carrying a bunch of equipment.I'm 5'8" and the pack fits well on my torso. I feel like this bag would be fine as a unisex bag, depending on the person. The pack is lightweight but still feels sturdy and after I loaded it with clothing, a few books, a dob kit, and water it seemed to distribute the weight in a way that will stay comfortable for a full day.There are lots of little pockets and storage areas if you are the kind of person who can keep your stuff organized... I tend to be the type of person who just dumps everything in the center of my handbag, so I do like the fact that the main section of the pack is open and not subdivided into useless sections.

I've been using Wilton food coloring for twenty-five years.I have at least 20 jars of coloring. These new tubes are far easier (and less messy) to use than the old tub-style.I use the colorants for glycerin soap. It is true that you can match colors fairly accurately. The way the colors are dispensed is just like the old fashioned grocery store food coloring, but there are more hues and they are far stronger.The best thing about these is that they won't dry out as quickly as the little tubs. I live in the high desert, where everything desiccates so fast the tubs just don't last. My mother just threw out Wilton tubs from the late 1970s that were still usable (although kind of a scary texture) because she lives in a humid place.This is a great set with lots of range. I won't throw out the tubs, but I'll be reaching for these, first.

This rug is an attractive pattern but not very sturdy or good at resisting dirt. The rug was already unraveling along the bound edge when I took it out of the box. The texture is a very low pile that shows dirt really easily. It sat on the kitchen floor for only two days and the white part of the rug already looked a bit grey from shoes, dirt, et cetera.You wouldn't want to use this at an entry way, maybe it would be best near a bed, somewhere you wouldn't wear shoes. The texture is very synthetic, and wouldn't be particularly nice on bare feet.This is the kind of product you buy, use for a short while, and then send to the landfill, something I don't particularly like to contribute to.

I hate giving less than three stars to a book, but I can't avoid it in this situation.The writing in the book starts off overwrought and never lets up. The way the author describes her characters and their emotions, (I'll get to the dialect issue in a minute) and the general description of the setting (weather, countryside, et cetera) swings from saccharine to hysterical melodrama over and over and over again. Instead of feeling empathy (or sympathy) for the lead character, whose child has died, I just felt annoyed by her. The way Charlie is depicted lacks any subtlety and I quickly became tired of being bludgeoned by her tedious personality and by about page 82 I started to skim paragraphs and expedite the experience, just to see if the ending irritated me as much as the rest of the book. It did.I lived in Louisiana and Texas for 23 years and people don't sound the way they do in Young's book.  It grated on me and I had to put down the book frequently before I threw it across the room.I'm open to the supernatural, weird, unexplained, et cetera, but this just didn't give me a creepy feeling (except for some of the super sweet dialogue and internal dialogue) or make me wonder or question or anything.I'm going to stop this ranting and end with a disclosure: I regularly read people like Palahniuk and Gischler, so maybe I'm not the intended market for a book like this -- maybe I expected something too edgy and new. Still, I read my share of sappy chick lit. I've also read several other books recently that I would put in a somewhat similar genre as this book (elements of supernatural, romance, mystery) -- books by James Oswald, Stephen Marche, and (not yet out) Sophia Jaff -- and they all pulled the elements together in a much more convincing and enjoyable manner.

This book is more of a 3.5 stars, but I rounded up to 4 because I'm a sucker for the genre.I've only seen the first half of the movie Avatar, but this book did have some similarities. That said, the concept of using remote bodies was still fun to read about. This book won't provide any big surprises, there are no genre- shaking moments, but the story is told in a way that captivated my interest and had me reading late into the night.I think Golden does a great job with the action sequences, but a lot of the dialogue is kind of stiff. Also, the some of the characters tended to stretch my suspension of disbelief pretty thin. There could be a bit more nuance when it comes to all the characters, just to make them more convincing.I am also not a fan of the big, awkward, info dump, which happens in several places and is not effective. The first one is near the beginning of the book and really put me off for a while. It's a blurb-type of description of the future that does nothing to enhance the story as most of the details in that particular dump come out later, more neatly stitched into the story.Anyhow, I enjoyed this book in spite of my few gripes. I'd read another by Golden, which is always the highest praise I can give any author.

I was surprised at the quality of this corset.I had a corset made to my measurements 10 years ago and it ran about $450. For considerably less money this corset is a steal. I'm 5'8", 38 28 38 and the large fit fine, the lacing open about an inch, with room to make it either bigger or smaller. The corset is boned in a way that makes it feel like it will be able to support for a good, long time. There is a flap at the back, beneath the laces, that makes sure they won't cut into your skin.If you've never bought a corset and are considering investing in an expensive one, this is an excellent way to get an idea of how they fit.I received a free sample to try and review.

This is my second microplaner, as the first finally broke after a decade of use. This one feels slightly more substantial than the last one I had and this has a much larger planing surface.If you've never tried one of these you are in for a treat. They make grating things like lemon peel or ginger a real pleasure. I've never used it for big grating projects like potato pancakes and think the result would be too fine (not to mention tedious to do). I've used it on a whole nutmeg, but you don't want to use too small of pieces as a knuckle grating would not be fun.This has a good heft, balance, and feel to it. A pleasure to use.

These are very pretty lace curtains that are priced appropriately. They're not blinding white, which adds to their appeal, in  my opinion.  I put them on a pair of French doors and they offer privacy while allowing light.I have two other sets of lace curtains, one very expensive and one mid-range, and these curtains are comparable in the way they feel and drape.

â€œHand on the Line â€“ Challenging Men to Follow Godâ€™s Callâ€ is Steve Wikinews's personal testimony of pursuing God with reckless abandon.The book is packed with powerful analogies comparing the disciplines required for success in the sports arena with those comparable spiritual disciplines and the cost of discipleship after becoming a follower of Jesus. He also discusses the similarity of camaraderie and the sense of community among team members and the common sense of brotherhood, unity, and shared devotion among Christian brothers who experience a mutual faith in Christ.I especially like the â€œChalk Talksâ€ feature at the end of each chapter in which Steve asks the reader to consider â€œpointed questionsâ€ regarding handling routine matters like stress, disappointment, or failures. These questions follow the progression of Steveâ€™s own faith journey with more probing questions of trust, commitment, finding Godâ€™s will, and an honest appraisal of personal  spiritual progress, counting the cost of obedience, and investing your life in Godâ€™s service. These questions become an excellent resource tool and can easily be adapted for mentoring, discipleship building, or for menâ€™s Bible study groups.Wisniewski is an advocate for a strong emphasis on the mission of evangelism as evidenced by a bold natural â€œoverflowingâ€ witness. The book is well written, deeply spiritual made up of stories, truths and insighs from â€œfootball and faithâ€ with practical personal life applications for men of every age and faith. Steve is open, genuine, sincere, and exemplary in his Christian walk.â€œHand on the Line â€“ Challenging Men to Follow Godâ€™s Callâ€ is a book I plan to recommend to my sons, my brothers, and my friends. It is a powerful testimony of finding and following Godâ€™s destiny, unique purpose, and life calling.A complimentary copy of this book was provided for review purposes. The opinions expressed are my own.

Principles, Practice, and Application of Spiritual MappingC. Peter Wagner in â€œBreaking Spiritual Strongholds in Your Cityâ€ alerts the reader to a new trend toward a movement of the Holy Spirit in preparation of the body of Christ for an unparalleled advance of the Kingdom of God. Wagner maintains that we are in a â€œnew seasonâ€ for reestablishing the Gospel of the Kingdom and that we are seeing a paradigm shift with an emphasis on the dominion mandate and apostolic church government.The book is divided into three parts, the principles, practice, and application of breaking the strongholds in your city. George Otis, Jr. presents an overview of spiritual mapping. Cindy Jacobs examines nine strongholds that need to be broken down if we are to experience a fresh awakening in our cities and throughout the nation. Kjell Sjoberg explores the concept and principle of spiritual mapping for prophetic prayer actions.Harold Caballeros, Bob Beckett, and Victor Lorenzo discuss the practice of defeating the enemy, community deliverance, and evangelizing a city dedicated to darkness. Mark McGregor and Bev Klopp specifically report on the results and application of mapping and discerning in the city of Seattle.Reflection questions are included with each chapter. These questions help the individual reader assimilate the material and are an important resource for group discussion and classroom applications.C. Peter Wagner is highly recognized for his leadership in the fields of church growth and spiritual warfare. The other contributors are known nationally and international for their impact on world evangelism and revival ministries. Their writing is clear, informative, authoritative, and the principles proposed have been proven effective.This new edition of â€œBreaking Spiritual Strongholds in Your Cityâ€ is an important resource for pastors, lay church leaders, and adult Bible class teachers in churches throughout the cities of our country.A complimentary copy of this book was provided for review purposes. The opinions expressed are my own.

In his book â€œReceptivity â€“ Tuning in to Godâ€™s Voiceâ€ evangelist Daniel K. Norris proclaims a life changing message which prepares the reader to actively pursue, identify, and hear the voice of God. He challenges the reader to move beyond being apathetic, lukewarm, and complacent to become an uncompromising radical believer and follower of Jesus.I was captivated by Danielâ€™s powerful stories of miraculous ministry, select testimonies from thousands who received the message of salvation, and physical healing. I was also inspired by examples of spiritual mentoring and passing on the revival message to generation after generation to young evangelists as exemplified by Leonard Ravenhill, Steve Hill and now through Daniel Norris to another generation.My spiritual eyes were opened to new insights and a clearer understanding of listening for Godâ€™s voice through seeds of truth while becoming more receptive to His Word. Daniel draws lessons from Jesusâ€™ parable of the sower for keys to dying to self, becoming a selfless sower, and how to establish a mindset for drawing near to God.Danielâ€™s writing is well articulated and spiritualy anointed; a must read for those fully receptive to hear and respond to the voice and will of God. â€œReceptivityâ€ calls on the reader to tune in to Godâ€™s voice.A complimentary copy of this book was provided for review purposes. The opinions expressed are my own.

Eric Chester interviewed over 25 top business leaders to determine how they â€œignite passionâ€ in their people without burning them out. â€œOn Fire at Work â€“ How Great Companies Ignite Passion in Their People without Burning Them Outâ€ is a compilation of the information he gleaned through these interviews. The information has been narrowed down to seven categories which todayâ€™s employers look at as the seven cultural pillars: Compensation, alignment, atmosphere, growth, acknowledgment, communication, and autonomy.Chester uses case studies, models, and stories to explore and compare each of these pillars in depth. His assessment and sage advice of the non-negotiable character traits of potential employees is an example of his sensitivity, astuteness, and expertise in the field of behavior leadership, human resources. His writing is clearly articulated and powerfully focused.A unique and stimulating feature titled â€œIgniters, Flamethrowers, and Burnout Extinguishersâ€ provides thought provoking questions and related exercises which help the reader keep on target, assimilate the concepts and visualize how to incorporate and apply the principles and examples introduced within the chapter.â€œOn Fire at Workâ€ is a timely and practical resource for the corporate manager, HR professional, for business leaders in large corporations or small businesses, and is filled with important strategies and concepts for implementation, that will insure excellence in recruiting, training, and retaining high quality employees.A copy of this book was provided for review purposes. The opinions expressed are my own.

A Magnificent Adventure in a Fantasy World â€“ Combining Myth, Magic and HistoryAward winning author David W. Tollen incorporates fantasy fiction, myth, and historical fact introducing a new generation of readers to the origins of the Western world in his book â€œThe Jericho River â€“ A Novel about the History of Western Civilization.â€When William Gallo, a noted historian, falls into a mysterious comma his son young Jason deciphers a few words and phrases from his fatherâ€™s mumbling that seem to be an ongoing dream revealing an obsession with history and mythology related to one of his earlier expeditions.The same night Jason has his own dream. When he awoke he found himself transported back to the time of the ancient civilizations of Sumer, Babylonia, and many others with origins in the Middle East. He has been sent on a rescue mission to relocate his fatherâ€™s being, free him, and return with him to the present. The adventures that follow take Jason along the Jericho River from Sumer to Egypt, Crete, and Babylon.Jasonâ€™s search takes him on a time line that parallels his father William Galloâ€™s notes from his outline of history; which introduce the reader to an accurate chronological history of Western Civilization.Tollen has a unique flare for adding pageantry, magic, and mysticism to historical fact, with a fast moving plot, and vivid characterizations. This is an introduction to history for a new generation of teenagers, with a fascinating twist for adult fantasy enthusiasts.A complimentary review copy of this book was provided for review purposes. The opinions expressed are my own.

Award winning author, Inbali Iserlesâ€™ book â€œFoxcraftâ€ is a fast moving action packed, adventure, novel for the eight to twelve year old reader who enjoys animal stories, fantasy, and magic. This is a book with will stimulate the readers imagination, involve their five senses, teach them the important values of trust, the importance of community, determination, and perseverance.Young Isla, a young fox, becomes separated from her brother Pirie and her family when their den bursts into flame and they have to flee their home just on the outskirts of the lands occupied by the furless (humans). While in search of her family Isla is faced with crisis after crisis. She quickly puts into practice the survival techniques leaned earlier from her family.The reader will learn right along with Isla the cunning of Foxcraft, the secrets of the elders, and the survival techniques of Foxlore. A helpful glossary provides interesting insights into the uniqueness of the fox, their keen alertness to signs of dangers, and other instincts are presented throughout the story line in a way that will insure the reader is entertained and informed. The inclusions of the magic of the mystical add to the imagery of the book. â€œFoxcraftâ€ is an exciting, memorable reading experience. Quality reading for students in grades three through seven.

In his book â€œA Way Through the Wilderness â€“ Growing in Faith When Life is Hardâ€ Rob Renfroe reminds the reader that â€œlife is hardâ€ and that we can grow through these times of aloneness, feeling devastated, and â€œbereftâ€ of Godâ€™s presence.  He shares beautiful stories of individuals, examples of how they have become strong through hardship; enabling them to bring meaning and hope to others.Renfroe introduced new insight into the wilderness experiences of familiar Bible personalities: Abraham, Moses, David, from the Old Testament, and Jesus and the Apostle Paul in the New Testament. I especially appreciated the way he emphasized that Jesus died to make us holy and that Godâ€™s purpose in our lives is to make us more like Jesus, more concerned about our character than our comfort. And that, these barren times prepare us for spiritual battles (temptations) in self-centeredness, materialism, and discouragement; producing humility, motivating us to lives of giving rather than accumulating.â€œA Way Through the Wilderness â€“ Growing in Faith When Life is Hardâ€ is written with the warm sensitivity of a pastorâ€™s heart; inspiring, encouraging, and motivating without being â€œpreachy,â€ or â€œjudgmental.â€  Renfroe offers hope, healing, and purpose to the hurting.

â€œJust Show Up â€“ the Dance of Walking through Suffering Togetherâ€ is packed with concrete, suggestions, supportive ideas, and meaningful information for reciprocal friendship during hard times and suffering. Authors Kara Tippetts and Jill Lynn Buteyn team up to share their story of a deep meaningful friendship throughout Karenâ€™s life and death battle with cancer.Kara and Jill explore the concepts of the long good-bye, the ministry of silence, and the gift of presence. They express them from two viewpoints, that of the giver and that of the receiver. Theirs is a story of nurturing friendship through pain and tiredness, insecurity and doubt, of unfathomly hard days, and the beauty and of being surprised by joy on a good day.Careful consideration of the discussion prompts, are included for opening honest dialog in a group setting or for individual contemplation and will add to the personal impact and value of the book for individual readers; and immense help for anyone experiencing the process of anticipatory grief.Anyone who had or is going through the suffering of a friend or loved one will find solace, comfort and support throughout the pages of â€œJust Show Up â€“ the Dance of Walking through Suffering Together.â€A complimentary copy of this book was provided for review purposes. The opinions expressed are my own.

Letâ€™s Learn About the Lordâ€™s PrayerBy Catherine DeVries, Illustrated by Ryan JacksonDavid C. Cook, 4050 Lee Vance View, Colorado Springs, CO 80919978-0781412698, $ 10.99, 2015, 12 pagesReviewed by Richard R.
