Hard to describe but it just sounds complete.There are two slowish song on the album, Afloat and Time Travelers.  I would say Afloat is good is good but not my favorite moody/slow song.  Travellers is very nice with acoustic guitars being the most prominent instrument.Overall, a beautiful album that will take many listens o fully appreciate what went into making this.  It is much more complex than earlier material but it does not get cloudy or give up the magic that has made Riverside such a great band.  Looking forward to "hearing" the music now that I have gone through a full listening of it.

I was so excited for this album as Dead Letter Circus has become one of my favorite bands.  The Catalyst Fire is such an incredible album so I was either expecting a complete dud or some kind of miracle with this album.  What I got was completely different.  If this was a different band, I would say that this is a great album.  For DLC, I would say it is a solid effort worthy of praise but falls a bit short to their last release.  The first single (While you Wait) that was releaesd before the album came out left me scratching my head as it just sounded way different from what I was used to.  Thankfully, that sound is not the dominant sound on this album but it probably was the best "single" type song.The album starts oss a little weak in my opinion.  Nothing stabds out until you get to the 4th song "The Lie We live".  That is when things get better.  Y A N A has to be one of my favorites right now as is Show Me.  I really can't stand the song Silence beacuse of the part where backround vocalists are singing "Liar".  Annoys me!  After that, the albums gets strong again and finishes out on a high note.Overall, there is something lacking in this release and what I am coming up with is something to do with the vocals.  It sounds like Benzie is using a more controlled voice in most of the songs.  He is focuing more on singing (like when he does a lot of acoustic stuff) and is not letting his voice hit all the ranges (which can sound wild at times) like on earlier albums.  Here We Divide and The Cure are examples where his signing just sounds more passionate.  However, his voice is still very strong on this album and it does, at times, show some of his range.  The weird thing I am hearing in the mix is when he signs at a higher octave, he reminds me of Jon Anderson from yes.  The Lie we Live is a good eaxmple with both the sound and delivery of the vocals.  Good thing I like Yes!This remains in my current playlist and it is soemthing I will continue to go back to.  I think any DLC is something my ears will enjoy for a long time (or at least until the new Riverside release on 9/1).  Can't wait to see how their newish lineup continues to develop on future releases!

This is a fun Nerf gun.  Not my favorite and not the best shooter by any means but its unique design makes it fun to shoot.  This uses a standard pump action and trigger type shooting so no batteries are needed.  It comes with 4 magazines that can be easily rotated using the secondary double loop trigger.  This is not something to be used for accuracy or distance shooting but more for closer combat.  During my testing, I was seeing a big range among the darts.  I had a few shoot straight downward at first but after several rounds, that seemed to stop.  On average, I was getting about 36 to 40 feet where the majority of the darts were landing.  They were scattered in about a 3 foor radius.  The shortest shots were coming in around 25 to 30 feet and the longest reached about 50 feet.  We have other nerf guns that easily shoot 70 feet so this one is one of the shortest we own.Weight wise, my 5 year old was able to use it with just a little effort.  My 8 year old had no issues.  We had some minor jams from time to time but I think that was user error and not the guns fault.  Overall it shoots pretty consistently without major issues.This is not something you would buy as your main battle gun but it is definitely a cool gun to own.

I just added this to my desktop PC which has reached its capacity on available USB ports.  Like other Trendnet devices I have used, this setup easily and works great.  I simply plugged in the power supply, plugged the USB cord into the one remaining open port on my PC and not I have 10 additional ports that all work great.  My Iphone is usually very picky about where it charges but it has zero issues on this adapter.

Been taking these for about 3 weeks now and I honestly don;t feel any different yet.  The good news is that I haven;t had any side effects from these pills.  And strangely, the "taste" of these pills (not that I am chewing them!) is rather pleasant.  A kind of earthy flavor is left behind in my mouth that is quite nice.  Weird!I plan on taking these until i run out and then will decide if I want to keep taking them or not.  Without feeling any benefits from them, I am not sure they are worth it.

I've used the regular Cetaphil for years...like over 15 years.  It is my final step before I shave every morning.  When I saw that Cetaphil came out with a wash specifically for men, I had to try it.  This wash is not like the regaulr one.  First, it foams up a lot more than the other cleanser.  The ingredients are completely different so I am not surprised.  Second, there is a rather strong smell that this wash has.  I can't explain what it smells like.  Something between a "man smell" and medicinal.  I don't like it at all and the smell lingers for quite some time.The face wash does clean very well but it leaves my face a bit dry compared to the regular formula. The claim is it keeps your face hydrated but I didn't feel that at all.  I actually felt like I needed to apply after shave balm on my face to get some hydration back.The good news is that I haven't had any negative reactions to the soap.  But I don't see me using this every day like I do the original formula.  I don't know whay Cetaphil came out with a men's only product as I don;t think it was needed.  I will stck to my usual routine.

This sligshot is really fun.  we just got this yesterday and my kids had a blast playing with this.  It is very different from all the other nerf guns we have because it does not use a trigger.  It uses a very simple pull tab attached to a strong band that acts just like a sligshot (hence the name).  Like a few other nerf guns we have, this is a single loader but that doesn't take away from the fun of it.  In fact, every single loader we have tried has never had a jamming problem.  They shoot everytime.Accurace seems to be pretty good from about 15 feet.  After that, too many elements can interfere with it.  We couldn't get a good read on overall disctance because it was very windy outside.  I don;t think this will break any distance records for nerf guns but it is definitely not the shortest one.  I would say 25-40 feet will be average.My 5 year old was able to operate this without any issue but I found the overall design a bit uncomfortable with the grip.  From a "game" standpoint, this is not something you would want to carry on you.  Due to the single shot and ability to only hold one other dart, it is not practical as a main weapon.  Where it would be good is in a hiding spot where you can get that "last shot" when your main weapon runs out of darts.  My kids tend to put a lot of their single shot guns around the yard for this purpose.At the price point for the slingshot, it is something worth having if you collect all the nerf guns.  But again, this is not a good option for your first or primary gun for use in battles.

I mixed feelings about this nerf gun.  First the good stuff.  My kids really enjoy playing with this gun.  Mostly in its pistol/handgun style.  Ok, now that bad stuff.  First, we have had some issues with the slide sticking in the open position and my kids can't close it.  They think it is jammed.  It takes me a bit but I can push it forward hard enough to get it unstuck.  Second, with the extended barrel, the range is awful  Darts tend to shoot straight downward after maybe 6 feet.  Without the extended barrel, it is Ok but nowhere near the range of our other nerf guns that can reach 40 to 60 feet.  This gun is maybe 10 feet with accuracy then maybe another 10 to 20 before it finally falls.  Finally, in the holster setup, the holding of the gun and the trigger are just awkward to use.  Too bad it couldn't somehow transition to some kind of real holster.  It is more of a box gun when it is in the setup.So far, my kids have kept this in the pistol setup and find it fun to use even though range stinks.  If it wasn't for my kids enjoying it, I probably would have rated this 2 stars.

My wife was so happy when she saw these!  She is an art teacher (high school) and she actually uses this type of scissor in her class.  Due to limited budgets, her orders are usually the bare minimum so if a single item gets broken or stolen, that means someone in her class has to go without that items.  Unfortunately (and rather scary) scissors are on that list.The quality of these scissors is on par with what she normally buys through the school so no complaints there.  The holder itself is small enough that it doesn;t take up a lot of space.  And the color options are also very nice especially if you have young kids doing projects at home.  My wife tends to host arts and crafts parties for our kids and friends so this product gives a nice variety to make both boys and girls happy.Overall, these scissors will remian at our house for those arts and crafts moments.  Hopefully my wife won't need to dig into these for replacements anytime soon at her school but it is nice to have that option so no child goes without something at school.

My wife uses grocery store bought reusable bags which are made from recycles plastic.  They generally last a few months before they start to break down and require replacing.  They cost her around $10 for a set of 3 I believe.  When I got these canvas bags, she stated how great these were compared to the ones she normally uses.  Overall, these are heavy duty bags, look decent and hold a lot more weight than the recyled plastic type we have been using.  For the price, the 3 pack is less than what 2 canvas bags sell for around my area.  Very happy with these and they have offcially made it into the weekly shopping ritual

I finnaly applied this pest cntrol this past weekend and so far it seems to be working.  Every year around this time I do my usual spraying around the foundation of my house to keep the ant population in control.  I normally use an Ortho product that needs to be applied only once a season.  So I can't comment on how long this stuff lasts but at least it works initially.A few things1.  This did not kill on contact for me.  I had a lot of black ants (non-carpenter ants) that were crawling on my brick steps.  I sprayed them and they easily walked around for close to 5 minutes.  However, within that time, I could see them slow down and finally die.  So it works, just not instantly for me.2.  This stuff smells! - When I opened the bottle, the smell was overpowering.  After I sprayed it, I could even smell it in my house a little.  This is not a friendly type product that smells like lemons, it is a pesticide.  But it works!3. The bottle made 2 gallons for me.  Enough for my foundation and a few other areas around my property using my sprayer.  The size of the concentrated bottle makes it easy to store and dispose.  Very happy with the packaging.As long as the ants don;t return within a few weeks, I will continue using this.  The size of the bottle is the big selling point for me as long as it works.  Keeping fingers crossed.

I've used Cyberlink products for years.  Mostly the Power director software for editing home movies.  A few of those versions I've owned came bundled with power DVD but this is the first time I have every used a standalone product like this.  Other than older versions I have through my other bundles, the only other video software I;ve used on my current desktop is windows media player.  Compard to that, this software opens and plays everything much more quickly.  All f the videos I have on my computer fall into either backed up DVD's (so quality os not HD), HD videos shot with various camcorders using 1080 and up to 60fps and some videos taking on my Iphone.  Windows Media Player can play most of them fairly well with maybe the exception of the 60fps ones where I get some choppy type playback at times.  PowerDVD plays those fine.I haven't played any 4K material yet as I don;t have any on my computer so I can;t comment on that.  One of my friends works for a compnay that is at the forefront of 4k technoligies so I will hopefully get some stuff from him to test through his company's website.The big question is who will buy this?  This is expensive software for most people and it basically only does playback.  Sure, it does every single format out their so you reduce the hassle of downloading codecs or whatever but most people simply watch YouTube or play back basic DVD's or Blue Rays on their computers.  And most computers will come with software that support their drives.  I think the biggest benefit of this software will be the 4K support but we are still so early in adotping 4K standards that this software will only be needed by a small percentage of people today.  If you are feeding a home entertainment system through a PC then this software is very nice to have.  Again, not sure a large percentage of people do this as most use standalone players or game systems but there are some that have the full HTPC setup.I will post back once I have a chance to play around with 4K video.

It's been a while since my college days with a red Solo cup but I got a bit nostalgic while using this the first time.  Granted, this is a bit more upscale than the Solo cup but at least it brought back some memories!  The claim here is that the design will somehow keep a beverage cold for up to 8 hours.  There is absolutely no way I will be able to test this claim as a beer will last, on average, maybe 8 minutes when I am drinking one!  With that said, I actually haven't used this for alcoholic beverages just yet but I have used it for various water based drinks such as water and water with artificial sweetner/flavor packets that are probably doing more harm to my body than beer is.  What I can say is that the 16 ounces of liquid that I put into this cup remains cold from beginning to end.  I usually add some ice, then water from my fridge which somewhat dissolves the ice and by the end, the ice is still there.I would say that the design with the stainless steel is keeping my beverage cold throughout it's life cycle.  Perhaps one day I will find a beer that will require a full 8 hour drinking session to complete a 16 ounce bottle.  If I do, I will gladly test the 8 hour claim on this party cup.  But for now, I will be happy sitting around my pool drinking from this and remembering my young days back in college.

This cleaner did not work at all for me at cleaning vinyl siding.  In the past I have used a few products similar to this have that have done a great job of cleaning my siding.  The downside has always been the strong presence of bleach in those products.  USing them means you have to be careful when spraying it so you don;t ruin clothes or get fumes up your nose.  This Scotts one does not have the strong odor of bleach but, unfortunately, it did not clean any of the mildew off my siding.Now, to be fair, the bottle does state that some scrubbing might be necessary.  I did not do any scrubbing at all but simply sprayed it on, let it sit and then rinsed off.  Nothing came off.  I will try and upload some before and after pics if I can find the old review page where you can upload.One additional item I did not like.  I could not find a way to get a strong stream that is capable of reaching high on a house.  Other products I've used have the ability to shoor the water almost to the top of my 2 story house.  This barely shooter 6 feet.  And to rinse, you have to remove the bottle completely whereas other ones I've used have the ability to pass water through and use the bottles powerful stream to rinse.  Not here.Overall, I can't recommend this product at this time.  I will give it another shot to see if scrubbing works any better but that still puts this product at a disadvantage over others on the market.

These are excellent sheets to use in kids' rooms for their creative activities.  Sticking them on the kids walls have given them the ability to expand their art time beyond the classroom or their normal kitchen table area.  Dry erase markers wipe off as easily as they do from standard dry erase boards I've used and they seem to last longer than 20 times that is stated on the packaging.

These glasses are awesome!  I own several pairs of safety glasses, mostly for shooting, and these are so much better than anything I have owned.  They are comfortable an completely surround the eyes so nothing can fly in there.  The lenses are super clear and makes outdoors in sunshine easy to see with no glare.  My kids out them on and love them so I will be picking up a few more sets of these for them so they can play their nerf gun battles in a safer way.  I also plan on picking up another pair for use in my yard with weed whacking.  Great glasses!

I love Werther's Orginals.  Have for years ever since my mother gave them to me the first time.  Was eager to try these new soft caramels.  They did not disappoint one bit.  They have a taste somewhat like those bullseye candies with the caramel wrapped around the white sugar center.  But these are much more creamy, less sticky and don't have that white sugar center.  These are pure caramel.  My kids wanted to try them and then they basically stole the rest of the bag from me!  A big hit in our family (sans the wife who hates caramel).

Wow!!  These things smell like blueberries!!  My dogs went a bit nuts when I first opened these.  They are used to eating greenies but they went crazy when they smelled them.  So thumbs up to another great Greenies product.  Did I mention how strong these smell?!

I've used Scotts EZ seed many times to fix bare spots and areas my two beagles have destroyed.  As long as you follow the instructions and rake and break up the soil where you plans to use it, you will grow grass.  I have a sprinkler system so I usually run them in the early morning, a short time if mid afternoon and then in the evening for areas where I've used this.I have also tried other brand patch seed which has worked well but I find the Scotts to have less weeds and grow a bit faster.  My issue with my dogs is not so much the urine killing the grass but the dogs digging.  So it is a constant struggle for me.

This is the first coloring book that we have tried that works alongside an app to show the picture in a more animated 3d type way.  My kids were excited because it is Skylanders.  They love everything to do about Skylanders.  When we first got it, my 8 year old tried getting the cryons out and proceeded to rip the main cover.  Great start.  My wife told me we have other Crayola books like this and it happens frequently. Perhaps Crayola should rethink how they package the crayons.My youngest started out on a picture using the "special" color crayon that is the main color that the app uses to add the live action type look in the app.  while he was doing that, we downloaded the app onto our Ipad and opened it up.  It was a bit tricky at first as the directions did not provide us with what we were seeing in the app.  So each step was rather useless.  Finally, after a lot of trial and error, we got the special crayon to be recognized and we saw the first picture my kids colored.  They loved what they saw and then proceeded to color every picture in the book.Since the first day of coloring, my kids have not gone back to use the app at all.  It was like they were now done with it.  I suppose that is Ok as these books are priced very low.  It's not like spending $50 on a video game that they never play.  We may look to get some of the other versions of this but I don;t see it as anything more than one time use....just like other coloring books.

This is one of the btter tasting freeze dried meals I've had.  I'm not surprised as the issues I've had with other ones tend to be with the main food item in it like steak whereas this one if mostly rice and vegetables. The chicken in it is small enough to not overpower the taste but I find the chicken actually tastes pretty good anyway.  This is a multi person size portion (it says 2.5 but I would say more like 2 people max) and would be great to throw in a backpack for you and someone elese when hiking.  I will stock up on this flavor.

I guess these are a different flavor from other Greenies we have been using for years.  Regardless,  I get the same results with these as I do the older style.  One of my beagles will jump around like crazy for these and my other one could care less until the other is done with hers and then he will taunt her with his.  The good news is that they still provde a way to keep our dogs breath smelling better than the usual "hey, I just ate poop outside.  let me lick you now".  We have tried other brands but these seem to be preferred by our dogs.

It's OK.  This is one of the larger portion packs so you can feed up to 3 people.  Realistically, it will feed 2 adults.  The steak is a bit chewy and the flavor has a fake taste but it is not terrible.  I found a bit of hot sauce added (a staple for any zombie apocalypse) made this taste much better.  It will not be my first choice to eat when camping or in an emergency but I've had much worse than this.One downside is the amount of water it takes to heat.  This requires 1 3/4 cups of water.  Most I've had require 1 cup so this one requires additional heating of water if you are using something like a jetboil.  The larger Jetboil will do up to 2 cups I think (I don't have the large one) as would most camping travel kettle pots but if you travel very lightly, your water boiler might not be big enough.

Been using this for a over a year now and it is very good lotion.  Our house has forced hot air heat so it is always very dry.  We use this on hands, elbows and feet.  Dries pretty well and doesn't leave your hands too slippery.  There are no ingredients in it that my wife is a allergic to so that is a big plus!  we keep a bottle in the upstairs bathroom and one on the first floor.

This is not my favorite Boomco gun but still fun.  Unlike the others I have that use an internal spring type system to shoot the darts, this one uses a pump action.  First, it is super easy to pump so even small kids can easily shoot with it.  The nerf style pump guns require a bit more force so I would say BOOMco has an edge for kids that don't have a lot of strength.  The accuracy is OK from short distances if you pump it carefully and slowly.  Otherwise, it can go anywhere.  But the side effect of this is you don't get much distance or speed on the dart.  If you are trying for distance, you need to angle to gun up higher to produce a higher arc than the spring loaded ones.Overall, it is still a fun gun to shoot and for the money, it is something BOOMco fans should add.  It is very small and light so pretty much anyone can use it.  Just don't rely on this for your main "battle" gun since accuracy is compromised over longer distances and the fact that it is a single shooter that requires a reload after each shot.  It will be good for the last ditch effort!

We got this along with one for our 2nd grader as a way to keep our boys challenged a bit during the summer months.  Our youngest is going into kindergarten next year and hasn't had any real homework to do so this will be a nice entry into doing more formal at home activities.  Our plan is to have both boys work on their activities together to hopefully keep them motivated.  The activities in this book seem to be a lot of fun and less like standard homework packages we've seen with our oldest boy.  Keeping fingers crossed that we can keep our plan in place and our kids will continue to learn throughout the summer.

Our oldest is currently in 2nd grade and has been given the thumbs up from his teacher on his academic skills.  We've been told we need to keep him challenged as he tends to finish his work very early and can get bored easily.  This activity book is something we are looking forward to use this summer to keep his mind active while not in school.  I'm sure he won;t be too happy but the activities look fun and don't seem as bad as his current homework (which is a challenge to get him to do).  We also got one for our youngest who is going into kindergarten so our plan is to use these as regular summer activities. we have a plan in our heads that this will work.  Hopefully this plan works!

This is my second Boomco gun.  We have another one that uses a rotary type handle to reset the gun which has been very fun to use.  This one uses a cartridge that holds 6 darts but I believe you can buy bigger cartridges that hold more.  I appreciate the idea behind the cartridge and my kids love the way it works but I do find it a bit "off" sometimes when you place the cartridge back in after reloading.  If you don;t push it down far enough you may go too far making one of the darts not shootable since it is past the firing pin.  Not a huge deal and I'm sure we will get the hang out of it eventually.Like out other gun, this has great range and can easily shoot 60 feet as we have tested this in our backyard.  Some people don;t like the "drinking straw" type material of the darts but I find them totally fine and they seem to hold up well.  The included target is the only thing we can find that these actually stock to.  But my kids hardly use it as they would prefer to shoot any other things than just the target.The value of the Boomco guns in very good.  We have many Nerf guns as well which get expensive.  I find the Boomco works just as well as the nerf guns and my kids don't have a preference as long as they are having fun.  If cost is an issue, these are an awesome substitute for Nerf.  I just picked up two sets of 40 darts (2 different colors) that I'm sure my kids will love.  I have a feeling we will probably upgrade our guns to some of the bigger ones that Boomco offers as my kids like them that much

I tried two different version of these breakfast packs and this was not my favorite. The other one was the eggs with has brown, sausage, pepper and onions.  That one was pretty good.  This one is simply eggs with bacon bit.  First, I don't like having to drain the excess water.  The other pack I did not have to that.  Second, after following the directions, the eggs were still hard and a almost chalky tasting.  I got through about half before I was done.  Salt and pepper helped a bit but I don't see me getting this flavor again.  I will stick to the other one

I am in total shock with this album.  Been a fan of Steven Wilson for years but mostly with his non-solo projects.  Porcupine Tree remains one of my favorite bands and I've been thoroughly disappointed with most of Steven's solo work and collaborations since he put PT on hiatus.  The last two solo releases left me underwhelmed due to their overly progressive and somewhat disjointed sound.  A lot of his work has been non-accessible lately so you truly have to believe that he can do no wrong to love it.Hand.Cannot.Erase breaks that streak for me.  The first track started and I was immediately thinking it was going to be the same.  But all of a sudden the entire sound seemd to change and I was blown away with it.  I'm not a music major so not sure on the right terms but this album has a different tone than his last few.  While the subject matter is rather dark, I don;t get that anxious feeling from the music like I do with his other solor stuff.  This is a pure pleasure to listen to.As I prgressed through the album, most of the first few songs continued with this.  And the woman singer on the album is fanatastic and brings another dimension to the sound.  There isn;t one song that I dislike.  A few towrds the end have their "Steven Wilson" moments but all of them have parts that are incredble.I am glad I didn;t discount this album before I gave it a try.  It has ben a wonderful surprise.  Definitely his best solo work and best work since PT.

I keep a few cases of these in my house for emergency purposes.  Living in the northeast, esepcially in 2015, we get hit hard during the winter and frequently lose power.  These are used for quick and easy to make meals during those times as we usually can still boil water on out stove.  I also bring these when I go camping as they pack easy and don;t take up much space.This was the first ever breakfast version I tried.  The packaging is basically air packed so it has no evtra bulk compared to the other mountain house ones I usually get.  Once opened, you simply add a cup of boiling water, stir, wait about 5 minutes and you are ready to eat.  I am usually the type of breaksaft eater that prefers my eggs separate from everything else so this was a bit different in that it is a medley of stuff all thrown together.  Surprisngly, I enjoyed it.  It doesn't have a terrible salty taste like you would get from things like raman noodles.  This is pure dehydrated food so you get real food.  At first I thought the eggs didn't fully rehydrate as I was getting some addtional "texture" but then I realized that it was the has brown pieces.  It became a good combo.  The eggs tasted like eggs you would get at a buffet (vs. home cooked farm fresh eggs) and the peppers and onions were not overwhelming.The portion size was plenty.  I was not left hungry after I was done.  I will probably add this to my current storage but I want to try a couple of other breakfast ones first as I am not the biggest pepper and onion fan.  And I want bacon!

This is a great assortment of different size staples that has worked with both my manual staple gun and electric staple gun.  They load esily in both my guns and I haven;t had any jams.  Not much else to say as they work as they are supposed to.  Will definitely get these again.

These are a great way to introduce little ones to the alphabet.  For toddlers not quite old enough to really start reading, they act as a fun "toy" by letting them stick them on a fridge or other magnetic surface.  It also gives them the visual aspects which will become familar over time.  Qulity of these wooden magnets are great and should last a long time.

We get a lot of deliveries which means lots of cardboard boxes.  These scissors work awesome on cardboard so it helps during the breakdown process for recycling.  I still prefer a utility knife but these are a bit safer to use when kids are around....I think!.  These also work great on denim as we have used them to cut up old jeans to make into chew toys for our beagles.They are light, comfortable and the protective sheath that comes with them holds nice and tight when not in use.  The closest pair of scissor I have ever used that cut as well as these are the Cutco ones we have that can cut through a penny.  But they are heavier and don't have a serrated edge like these do so they get hung up a bit more on tougher material when it starts to bunch..

This is probably the best tape measure I own.  I usually buy cheap ones from Harbor Freight so this is like 10 steps up.  The built in pencil marker is very useful.  No more forgetting to bring a pencil to make a mark since this is built in.  The lead replacements are the typical ones you can find at any hardware or office store.  Very nice and rugged tape measure!

I've been reading a lot of negative reviews about the sound mix but I find the mix to be awesome on both my home theater systems.  I have a 5.1 and 7.1 system in my house.  Nothing fancy at all and probably similar to what others have and the surround mix is great on the blue ray.  The concert is probably my favorite other than Score.  Hearing them play with a symphony again is just awesome and this one is special since a few of the band actually went and/or taught at Berkley.The only negative about the disc is lack of any extra content.  A behind the scenes is always fund but was not included here.  And while Mike Mangini is ridiculously good on drums, I do miss Portnoy as he brings a different type of vibe when he plays.

I bought these twice for my two beagles.  Both times, one of the chews was broken in half.  This is the only reason I don;t give it 5 stars.  However, it does allow me to get a "2" treats per dog rather than an odd amount.  My beagles love these and they last longer than any other chew we have tried including 12" bully sticks.  There is no smell with these either which is great.  The part that my dogs love the most is when these get chewed down to a smaller size.  You can put these in the microwave for about a minute or so and they will expand to rather funny shapes and sizes.  The end product looks like a big cheese ball/puff that now becomes much more edible/chewable for the dog.  Like a popcorn ball of cheese.  My dog go nuts when they smell it.  The cooked smell is actually quite pleasant.We have tried a few other brands of these but this specifc package seems to be of better quality overall so that is why I ordered this a second. time.  I will keep ordering from them.

This thing saved me from a nightmare time when changing dishwashers.  The store wanted $280 to install my new dishwasher (plumber and electrician were supposedly needed).  The electrical was not really needed as I can do that but the plumbing part scared me.  I needed to go from a solid copper pipe connection to a flexi hose style which meant cutting off the old copper pipe and figuring out a way to connct the new flexi hose.  Thankfully, a friend of mine told me about these where you simply push it onto the copper end with no need to solder it.  The flexi end just screwed onto the other end and it was done.  No leakes, easy to use and it gave me a secondary shutoff on case the primary one fails for some reason.  This makes basic plumbing stuff easy!

I bought one of these for each of my beagles.  They are about 10 months old and already wore out their cheaper collars.  I bought this one from Amazon and another one from a local pet store (mom and pop shop).  These are a nice thick collar that provide a bit more strength compared to thinner styles.  The material is nice and heavy and has a refelctive nature to them for anyone who walks their dogs at night.  I also bought matching leashes that go with the collars and they have the same reflective nature to them as well.The clasp on this collar is very strong and easy to use.  I feel that it is more secure then the plastic one on the smaller collars we had.  The loop for the leash is very big which makes it easy to hook, especially when you have eager beagles jumping around to go outside.  The leashes has an awesome latch that works well with the collars.  If/when these collars wear out, I will most likley replace them with the same ones.

This is my first experience with these patches.  The material seems to be much thicker/heavier than the other ones I use.  They are very soft and do a great job getting the barrel clean.  Compared to other brands I've used, these just seem to be a much higher quality.  I am finding that I don;t need to change patches as often when cleaning as these absorb more.  I use them with Ballistol as my main cleaner/oil for my guns and they are doing a great job.  I will definitley get these again as they are much better than the bulk brand I bought last time.

This Axe spray smells pretty good, goes on dry and seems to work very well at keeping me dry.  I usually don't like spray ons due to how long they take to dry but this is so dry when it is applied, there is no waiting.  When spraying, there is little to no smell.  However, within a few seconds, the smell comes out.  Not too strong like other Axe products but definitely more noticeable that others I use like Degree.  This is easily in my top 3 for antiperspirants right now.

I use 3 in one oil on my Jeep for various suspension components as well as assistance at lossening rusty bolts.  My usual go to is PB blaster but there are times when I can't spray it in my garage and properly air it out due to weather outside.  So 3 and one is my go to.  This brand seems to be a little thinner than others that I have used which means dripping it on a joint end can be a little messier.  However, one benefit to it is for the few greasble joints I still have where 3 and one oil is needed (vs. a standard grease gun).  A few of my control arm joints use a very small screw that comes out so you can add oil into the joint.  The recommneded oil is a 3 and One.  It usually is difficult to do but the thinner viscocity of this oil makes it easier to fill.  Not sure how well it will hold up over time if these joints went ungreased but I usually don't let them go too long so I doubt it will be a problem.Everyone should keep something like this handy as you never know when you will need help breaking a rusty bolt free.

This is the second crank radio that I own.  I few years back my wife started a "survival pack" for me as I like to take camping trips where there is little to no cell service, electric, water, etc...  My first one is a Kato radio that has crank, solar and a/c capabilties for charging.  It also has HAM radio access which is essential for a true emergency.This radio does not have solar or a/c ways of charging it so you are stuck with just a hand crank.  However, the radio charges very quickly and gives you about 10 minutes of use with just a minute of cranking.  My other radio requires significantly more cranks to get that kind of charge.  The directions claim that a full battery will yield 2 and a half hours of use which is amazing.  And 1 minute of crank will give you about 30 minutes of flashlight use.  Again, that is amazing.I would give this 5 stars if it had HAM radio.  I can overlook the solar since most of thise cheap solar panels on electronics require "perfect" days to actually charge.  As a standalone radio for use while camping, this does a great job.  I was able to easily find plenty of radio stations at my house which is usually hard so the antenna seems to work well.  But, for true emergencies, I would prefer to have HAM access since it's those operators that tend to give the best updates.  And in some cases, the only updates.Overall, for the size, it is a great radio for anyone that camps or just wants music/radio access if the power goes out.  The flashlight is "OK".  Nothing great but I wouldn't expect a full blown flood light for a device this small.  It is good enough to use for walking in the dark to avoid tripping over stuff directly in front of you.  Similar to an smart phone flash when used as a flashlight.

We have the LeapPad 2 for both our kids.  Our youngest is almost 5 and he uses his more than my almost 8 year old.  This rainforest game seems to be a good fit for his age.  The game so far is similar to a lot of the console type side scrolling games (with also the ability to climb various things).  He is only through the first level which has multiple sub levels to it.  The goal is to find the largest rodent during your journey.  You run, jump and climb while collecting diamonds/jewels.  Along the way you will find various animals/reptiles and the game will ask you a bunch of questions about what you just found.  It is a nice way to teach young kids some of the main characteristics of mammals, reptiles, etc...So far the game is a bit repetitive but there are a couple of fun things thrown in like levels where you shrink and ride a dragonfly to get through a certain area.  Overall, my youngest son enjoys the game and hopefully he is learning a bit along the way.The game runs fine of the Leappad 2 with no noticeable lag or issues that I've seen.  This is another great game for kids to play and learn.  Not many systems offer that these days, especially as kids get older.  Hopefully as my son progresses in the game, it will keep his interest.  So far, so good.

My oldest son has had a set of the Magnatile building set for a while now and has always loved it.  My youngest son is always taking them to play with and build his own stuff which aggravates his older brother.  Sharing them has worked but it always results in one of them getting mad because they don;t have enough tiles to finish something.  This set seemed like a good option to get for my younger son for his own set.  They are a different brand from what we already have so I was very interested in comparing quality.It is a very nice set that is actually larger than the original Magnatile brand set we have.  The building options are basically limitless.  Like our other set, the magnets in the tiles are very strong and hold together nicely.  They are much higher quality than some of the other brands we have tried but probably equal to the Magantile brand  The plastic on them is so strong that I don't worry about them being stepped on.  A very nice set overall and I would definitely buy this brand again assuming pricing is in line with other quality sets.

Average people dealing with normal problems find themselves living a nightmare. Tess and her ex-husbland, Nick are trying to co-parent their daughter. The relationship is uneasy but fairly cordial. However, when she sees him on a street in Boston, she thinks he ignores her, and it makes her furious.Frank is battling alcoholism and the loss of his dream of being a crime reporter. He thinks he may have found an out when he meets his violent double in his own home.When it turns out that Nick is in New Hampshire not Boston when Tess saw him, she wants to investigate. Her friend Lili agrees to help her, and it becomes even stranger when  Lili also finds that she has a double. Their search leads them to an elegant townhouse on Beacon Hill where events begin to spin out of control.If you like ghosts, paranormal, and horror movies, you love this book. Seeing your double can be frightening, but when evil surrounds you, it becomes a nightmare from which you can't wake.The plot is fast paced and cleverly written taking advantage of the idea of doppelgÃ¤ngers with a new twist. The characters feel like real people which makes the horror stronger. I enjoyed the book, but unless you're a hard core horror fan, I wouldn't suggest reading it when you're alone on a stormy night.I received this book from St. Martin's Press for a review.

Even on Christmas Eve, a farmer's work continues. Casey lives on a farm with her animal and equipment friends. They're all looking forward to Christmas: decorating the farm, making cookies, putting up stockings, and preparing for the celebration.On Christmas Eve Casey still has to feed the animals, and when a fence needs mending she has to take care of it. On top of all the work, Casey feels ill and falls asleep before the preparations for Christmas are complete. It could be a very disappointing Christmas, but Casey has good friends on the farm.I love stories about farms probably because I grew up on one and live on one. If you don't live on a farm, it's hard to envision how much work has to be done every day to keep the animals fed, the equipment working, and the fences mended. This is a good book for children. It shows them a different way of life, unless they live on a farm.The book has a good message about the importance of friends and family. The illustrations are cheerful and the text is easy for older children to read, or to read to younger children.I highly recommend this book for part of your Christmas collection.I received this book from PR by the Book for a review.

When she was seventeen, Ally made a mistake. Now she has a beautiful daughter to show for it. While taking care of her daughter, Ally managed to finish college, get a graduate degree and is now teaching at Brown. Amid all the responsibilities of teaching, including a difficult boss, and taking care of her daughter, Ally hasn't much time for romance, or sex.One day she's feeling completely frazzled with responsibilities when Jake, a student, comes into her life challenging her to have some fun. Ally is attracted, but sends him away afraid of how it might affect her daughter and perceptions of her on campus.Ten years later, her daughter is grown up struggling to make her own way when surprise, Jake shows up as her daughter's date.This is a book you'll enjoy if you like romantic stories without too much explicit sex. Ally is likable. If you're a single mom, you'll empathize with her dilemma of raising a daughter, being a professional, and putting her sex life on hold. Jake is the kind of almost too good man you'd love to know, and Lizzie has her own rebellious charm.The plot is a bit thin. There are no major catastrophes. Instead the challenges revolve around a single mother trying to let go of her grown daughter. and the daughter trying to find her own way.I received this book from Dutton, Penguin-Random House for a review.

When his father dies, Pete is left trying to manage Java Jive and hold down his regular job. Recruiting his ex-girlfriend, Juliette, as the new manager seems like a perfect solution. Juliette had her own cafÃ© before her fiancÃ© ran off with her cash and forced her to close.Juliette is experienced, but she's not totally ready for the fact that some of the staff, particularly the cook, just don't want her there. She's planning to get around the staff problem when the cook turns up dead, and she's afraid that she's the primary suspect.The plot is amusing and fast paced. It's fairly easy to figure out what's happening, but there are twists that keep it amusing. The setting in a coffeehouse is realistic and makes a good background for the unusual characters that populate the novel.Although the antics are amusing, I found Juliette too adventurous and naïve. She jumps to the conclusion that she must be the principal suspect and drags Pete along to help her solve the mystery before the police do. I did love Gertie, Pete's grandmother. She is a completely delightful character who makes you glad you're reading the book.The book is a fast amusing read with a mystery that takes some thought to unravel. If you enjoy the Evanovich books, you'll enjoy this novel.I received the book from Alibi for a review.

Written by ten-year-old Theresa Seidltz, Countdown to Christmas tells the story of her family's Christmas tradition. Each night from the first of December, the family sings, Come of Come Emmanuel, reads a Bible story, and hangs an ornament on their small tree. The ornaments bear the likeness of the person the story is about. As the family progresses through the Bible from Adam and Eve, to Abraham and Sarah, Saul and David, and Jesus, the tree becomes adorned with the people who helped shape Judaism and Christianity.The stories in the book are short, each being one page. They're suitable for an adult to read to younger children, but older children could read them for themselves or read them aloud to younger brothers and sisters. Each story is accompanied by a drawing introducing the characters. At the end of the book, the family places the final ornament for Jesus and sings Silent Night. The paper ornaments are included in the book and could be used for many years.I highly recommend this book. It's a good way for families to be together to enjoy the religious aspects of the Christmas season. It's also a good time for parents and children to talk about the Bible stories and what they mean in their own lives.I received this book from PR by the Book for a review.

Dr. Amens is a practicing psychiatrist who was one of the first to use SPECT scans in diagnosing and treating patients. SPECT scans were originally intended for research purposes. Using these scans to diagnose patients mental problems was innovative and controversial. I found it fascinating because when I did research in the mental health field there was always the nagging feeling that the diagnosis categories were too broad. It would have been helpful to have a basis on which to make specific treatment suggestions. However, much as I admire Dr. Amen for using this technique, I recognize that it isn't perfect.The book is written at a level that makes it relatively easy for the average reader to understand brain function. The SPECT scans included in this book make clear where the brain defects are located and are a useful adjunct to the text.Problems with the brain come in a variety of guises from ADD, to anxiety, Alzheimers and schizophrenia. In addition there are brain injuries such as concussion and problems stemming from tumors and other abnormalities. Dr. Amen goes into each of these areas, explains which parts of the brain are affected and suggests treatment plans. Although he does use psychoactive drugs, he also uses talk therapy, natural substances, and understanding you life's purpose.I highly recommend this book if you are interested in learning about brain function. Some of the exercises may even be helpful in giving you a better understanding of your personality and functioning.I received this book from Blogging for Books for this review.

Women helped to form the Judeo-Christian culture, and the Bible is filled with their stories, both good and bad. (Wicked can mean both very bad and very good. Sometimes that's confusing.) However, in the stories from the Bible there's no confusion about who was evil and who was good. The stories range from Eve in the Garden of Eden and Jezebel, the wicked queen, to Deborah, Ruth and Esther.The author tells the stories in narrative form giving thoughts and actions to the characters. Of course, no one can know today what these women thought, but reading the stories like a novel is fun, and it makes you wonder about the underlying basis of the stories. I couldn't help thinking about the role Adam played in getting them expelled from Eden.At the end of each story the author goes into a short description of the culture of the times. I found these very interesting, and they added depth to my understanding of the context of the Bible stories. There is also a section giving questions that can be used in group Bible study. However, reading and thinking about these questions can also provide greater depth to the stories, even if you're doing it on your own.I highly recommend this book. The stories are well chosen to display the importance of women in the Bible, and the narrative presentation is easy to read plus it raises additional questions about these women and their role in the Bible.I reviewed this book for BookLook Bloggers.

Lucy Ailling loves her job. She works for Sid, one of the most respected antique dealers in Chicago. Most of her work centers on keeping Sid's inventory and meeting customers, but Lucy has a side line. From her earliest childhood, she has lost herself in books feeling that they are more her friends than the people she knows. Now she finds old editions and sells them from Sid's shop. The problem is that some of the editions may not have the provenance she provides.At the opening of the story, Lucy meets James, a promising young attorney. They become romantically involved, and through James, Lucy meets his grandmother, Helen. When Lucy's sideline begins to unravel, Helen hires her to be her companion on a trip to England where Helen must deal with her own secrets. Visiting some of the sites famous for the BrontÃ« novels and the places where the BrontÃ« sisters lived, a friendship is born and both ladies realize that they must redeem past mistakes.The book is filled with sensual descriptions. If you want to experience England through the senses, you'll enjoy this book. I found the Lucy's character somewhat bland. She's very focused on her conman father and the gift he gave her for the love of books, but he gave her other gifts as well, and Lucy isn't very good at distinguishing helpful from disruptive. James is a good foil for Lucy, He's kind and loving, but I didn't feel that his personality added much to the story except to put Lucy in touch with his grandmother. Sid, while being a good role model, seems to leave Lucy too much to her own devices thereby setting the stage for the problems that follow.I enjoyed the book because I love literature and because it was refreshing to read a romance that didn't require numerous bedroom scenes.I reviewed this book for Thomas Nelson.

Karen Vail and her fiancÃ©, Robbie Hernandez, are enjoying a quiet date. Hearing two gunshots, they rush into the street where they stumble across the body of an FBI agent. Karen sees the perp running away, shoots, hits him and causes a major explosion. This incident pulls Karen into an undercover assignment linked to terrorists trying to take over the United States and Europe.The historical link is the Codex, an ancient scroll that could change the history of Judaism and Christianity. The terrorists want the scroll, but so does the US Government. Looking for the scroll and trying to root out the terrorists take Karen and her team from the US to Europe and to the Near East.The book is a fast, paced-action thriller. The action sequences are very well done and there are many of them. However, some parts of the novel are disappointing. Karen Vail, the FBI Profiler who has been featured in some of Jacobson's previous novels, is not as forceful as usual. Some of her internal monologues are simplistic and detract from her mission.I was also disappointed in the role given the Codex. I love historical mysteries and looked forward to this one, but the Codex turned out to be a subplot. We get glimpses of it from time to time, but it plays a minor role in the action.The part I most enjoyed was Jacobson's discussions of terrorism. It's worth reading the book to become involved in how terrorist networks perform in western countries. The book was enjoyable, but I wish the balance between the historical mystery and the present day terrorist activities had been more equal.I reviewed this book for Net Galley.

nkie, the oldest, is in love with Franklin and doing everything she can to have the first baby, but when she discovers that he has a wife, all bets are off. Tommie, the youngest, is still with Blue, but he seems to be in love with his ex-wife which strains their relationship. Livy is smarting from her husband's affair. Now when they have sex, it's on her terms and steamy.The story tracks and intertwines the lives of the three sisters. In addition to sexual adventures, there's stalking, death threats, and cheating. It makes for a lively, fast paced read. If you enjoy romance that has more than just bedroom scenes, you'll enjoy this book. The sisters are all different. The author has managed to make each one a realistic character.The author has included some culture references that make it seem like he's working too hard to raise the book above the level of a quick read. For me, it didn't work. The story is about the sisters. He does a good job portraying them and how they react to the difficult situations in their lives. You may not agree with how they solve their problems, but it works for them.I reviewed this book for Dutton.

Churchill was a man uniquely suited to the role he played in WWII. He was a warlord and a statesman, a unique combination that gave him the personality to lead his nation through one of the worst periods in world history. The question this book seeks to answer is: What made Churchill that way?Three periods of Churchill's life are the focus of the book: war, empire and peace. In the section on war, the author highlights Churchill's experiences during the Boer War and the war in the Sudan. Here he saw the horror or modern warfare against the traditional tactics of earlier generations. It gave him a dislike for scientific warfare, but also the realization that the challenge must be met. He also realized that more than a soldier he had to be a statesman to affect the outcome of world conflict. This section was my favorite and has lessons that we can help us today.Churchill believed in democracy. People should be allowed to rule themselves, but he was also a staunch supporter of the empire. The empire gave Britain status in the world that Churchill was loath to lose.In peacetime, he was less successful in leading the country. Being a firm believer in constitutionality, he disliked Socialism. Although it cost him political office, he staunchly criticized Socialism believing that it was bad for the country.This is an excellent book. Not only does it present a comprehensive look at the events that formed Churchill and how he used his experiences, it gives us lessons for today that we should understand. I highly recommend the book.I reviewed this book for Booklook Bloggers.

Twain's End is a novel, but based on  extensive research done by Lynn Cullen. Mark Twain was an exceptionally talented writer, but his real life persona, Samuel Clemens, was far from the kindly old man telling marvelous stories. In fact, he was irritable, crotchety, and difficult. He was also a womanizer.The story is told largely from the point of view of Isabel Lyon, his longtime secretary, whose extensive diaries gave Cullen the picture of the Twain household. Lyon came to work for Twain when his family was in tatters. His wife was fragile and ill, his daughters and his finances out of control. Isabel managed to turn things around and fell in love with Twain. When his wife died, she thought that marriage might be in the offing. Twain, however, had other ideas.Twain was  fond of young girls. One of his special favorites was Helen Keller. He supported her through a crisis in her writing career and enjoyed her company. I found the portrait of Keller and her relationship with the Macys one of the most interesting parts of the book. Her original teacher, Annie, Sullivan, was married to John Macy. Together the three of them formed a literary partnership.If you enjoy well researched historical fiction, I highly recommend this book. The characters from Twain to Helen Keller present an intimate portrait I would never have suspected. The character of Isabel Lyon is based on her diaries where she is clearly unhappy, hoping for more of a relationship with Twain than he offered. I found her thoughts circled constantly on the same topic and made it difficult to like her, although I felt sorry for her.The settings from Twain's mansion to the streets of New York capture the flavor of the era and enhance the picture of the characters and their lifestyle.I reviewed this book for Net Galley.

Kara Cooney called her book, The Woman Who Would be King, a social history because she takes the liberty of imagining what Hatshepstu thought and felt. The book isn't fiction. It's a well researched narrative about the reign of a remarkable woman by an Egyptologist who has studied the period extensively.A woman pharaoh was unknown in Egypt before Hatshepsut. Other women had ruled for more or less extensive periods of time as regents; however, she ruled as the senior pharaoh with her stepson, Thutmose III, for twenty-two years. The period of their joint reign was marked by prosperity and extensive influence in the ancient world. There is no indication that she denied power to Thutmose III, rather it appears that they had a mutually agreeable arrangement.In addition to the portrait of Hatshepsut, Cooney gives a detailed picture of what life was like for a royal princess. It reads almost like a good novel and enhances our understanding of Hatshepsut without taking liberties with her thoughts or feelings.I thought Cooney did an excellent job of pointing out where she was taking liberties with the historical record. Her ideas about Hatshepsut's inner life make the book more readable, but she also gives the reader a chance to view the facts. The book has extensive notes that allow the interested reader to go more in depth and to test Cooney's conclusions.I highly recommend this book if you enjoy reading about ancient Egypt. It's very well written. The pace is good. You may find it hard to put down.I reviewed this book for Blogging for Books.

Elia, a lit student, is infatuated with Cameron Beck's masterpiece, Secrets of Odysseus. The book is a compilation of poems Beck wrote to his mysterious muse, but no one knows who she is. Elia is determined to find out. She desperately wants to know what love is and Cameron seems to have the answer.In a coffee house one night before the end of term, she thinks she hears Beck read a new poem. The poem is left behind when the poet vanishes. Elia rescues it and now is determined to find Beck. The search leads her to a remote Caribbean Island. The islanders have befriended Beck and resent the stranger's intrusion, but she persists.This love story is told from several perspectives. Elia is the protagonist in the present day, but we also see Cameron. In the past, we see him and his lost love. Usually, I find stories told in two time periods don't work well. However, in this case with the secret of lost love as the thread holding the story together, it works well.Elia is a delightfully naive character. She is desperately searching for the meaning of love, but she is also capable of determination to see her adventure through to completion. Beck is a more nebulous character. We glimpse his total infatuation with his lover, but in the present day he is more subdued yet willing to part with his secret to the right person.The characters who inhabit the island: Isabella, the island matriarch, Fatty, the medical doctor with a drug habit, Paco, the cantina owner, and Falcon, the pilot, are extremely well drawn. Each is unique and each fits the setting perfectly. They were some of the best parts of the book.If you enjoy an adventure wrapped in a romance, you'll enjoy this book.I reviewed this book for PR by the Book.

Although FDR left no detailed memoir giving the reasons for his political decisions, Daniels has captured his words and used them in the context of events to give us a picture of what FDR thought. The book opens with a brief view of Franklin's early life, but the concentration is on his political career. While I had read several biographies of Roosevelt, this is the first one to go in depth about his early office holding. I found it instructive in light of his later political ideas including the New Deal.I also found it fascinating to read about how FDR was able to control the information about his polio and was able to act as normal as possible. It's enlightening to see how he overcome his affliction.On the positive side, this is a very detailed, perhaps definitive, look at FDR. Because there is so much detail from quotes to actions to what other historians have said about him, it is a sometime difficult book to read. However, if you're interested in a comprehensive history, this is it.On the negative side, because the book is crammed with historical detail it is sometimes hard to read. I enjoyed it, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you're interested in becoming immersed in FDRs life.The book ends before the US enters WWII. Although the transitions seems rather abrupt when you've been following the history closely, it leaves you wanting to go more in depth into the next segment of FDRs career.If you enjoy history, this is an extremely well done book. I highly recommend it.I reviewed this book for Net Galley.

Wes Avery, a tail gunner during WWII, is a good man. He loves his wife and daughter and works hard at his Texaco Station not far from McCoy Air Force base near Orlando, Florida. His wife, Sarah, has not been the same since her hysterectomy. Now with an approaching hurricane, she is withdrawing from reality and popping pills.His daughter Charlotte is in her senior year of high school. She's caught up in being selected as a member of the homecoming court and falling in love with Emilio, a Cuban refugee boy. Avery likes the boy well enough, but Sarah doesn't want Charlotte associating with him. This creates tension in the family and raises the specter of the family secret.As if the approaching hurricane weren't enough, Avery notices the buildup of aircraft, including U2 stealth aircraft, at McCoy. This is the start of the Cuban Missile Crisis. Everyone is worried, but it affects Sarah especially.The description of Florida at the time of the Cuban Missile Crisis is excellent. For anyone alive at the time, it will bring back memories; for younger people, it provides a glimpse of what life was like at the time.Wes Avery, the main character, is well done. He's struggling with a family situation he doesn't understand, trying to manage his gas station, and keep his fear for his family in check. The other characters, Sarah and Charlotte, felt sketchy. Sarah is a fairly typical wife and mother caught in the trap of too many pills and a harrowing time. Charlotte makes only fleeting appearances except for the beginning and end.I enjoyed the book for the glimpse of history and recommend it for that reason. Some of the plot didn't work for me. The family secret seemed to be dragged in at the end, and the conclusion wasn't satisfying.I reviewed this book for BantamDell.

Brueggemann's thesis is that it is necessary to deal with the human rights issues before the Israeli-Palestinian conflict can be resolved. He uses the Bible to trace the history of the claims to the land Israel now occupies and tries to draw conclusions about the legitimacy of Israel's claim and the counter claim of the Palestinians.Although he discusses the conflict in terms of the oppression of the Palestinians and the idea that the Israelis are the chosen people of God, I didn't think he did enough in depth discussion to prove his points beyond a superficial level that most people are familiar with.The topic is relevant to the political situation today. I was interested to see how Brueggemann would address the fact that Israel is placed in an extremely dangerous situation and that the Palestinians have religious and secular ties to Israel's neighbors.Although the book makes some good points, I was disappointed in the shallowness of the presentation. For me, the more relevant discussion today is the terrible human suffering wrecked upon the region by ISIS. The book was interesting, but I thought it was naive in the context of the situation in the Middle East today.I reviewed this book for Net Galley.

The stories of seven women living out their Christian faith in difficult circumstances are awe inspiring. I was pleased that Metaxas picked women who chose to do what they felt called to do as women. They didn't try to be men or compete with men. They used their female strengths: love, giving, mothering, and compassion. They didn't plan to be heroines. They did the work they felt God called them to do.I was familiar with some of the women's stories: Joan of Arc, Rosa Parks and Mother Theresa. I hadn't heard of the other women: Susanna Wesley, mother of John and Charles Wesley; Corrie ten Boom, who suffered in a concentration camp for helping Jews during WWII; Hannah More, who worked with Wilberforce to abolish the slave trade; and Saint Maria of Paris, who served the poor in spite of her eccentric ways, marriages, and collisions with church doctrine.Each woman had a story to tell and Metaxas did an excellent job of bringing them to life in a short biography. I found each one easy to read bringing out the highlights of the woman's life and showing them as real people with severe problems but living out their faith.I highly recommend this book for both women and men. Everyone can learn from the example of these extraordinary women.I reviewed this book for BookLook Bloggers.

Georgia, Alice, and Charles have been friends throughout their four years at Harvard. Graduation is almost there when their lives are disrupted by the murder of a classmate, Julia Patel. Rufus Storrow, a professor and house master, is intertwined with the three. He and Georgia, the beautiful daughter of a famous photographer, have an affair, but try to keep it hidden to preserve Storrow's job. Charles, an ambitions, middle-class, young man, has been in love with Georgia since freshman year, but she sees him only as a friend. Alice, a brilliant, unstable girl, has been best friends with Georgia, but she's jealous and after the murder leaks the information about Georgia's affair.Storrow and Julie Patel were locked in a dispute about what was appropriate for the professor to teach.  Because of the disagreement, he becomes the focus of the murder investigation.The characters in this book are very well drawn and in the beginning pull you into the story. We learn of the murder in the prologue, but it takes well over a third of the book to get to the event. Meanwhile, the author explores the backstory on each of the characters.I enjoyed the beginning of the book, but quickly got tired of waiting for the murder and detection to start. Even after the dead girl is discovered, the plot goes back to the friends and the professor and we get only small peeks at the process of trying to solve the murder.Instead of solving the crime. The book continues to cover the lives of the characters for years after the incident. If you're taken with the characters, that may be rewarding, but it your want a resolution to the murder, it's disappoint.I reviewed this book for Blogging for Books.

A distraught Lady Jane Grey seeks help from her friend Charles Lennox. Prue Smith, a former of housemaid of Lady Jane's, has been found dead in her new place of employment. Prue's employer believes she committed suicide, but Jane isn't convinced. Charles, an amateur detective in the habit of solving mysteries whether the police appreciate it or not, agrees to take the case.When Charles visits the dead girl's room, he discovers telltale signs that point to murder rather than suicide. Her employer is adamant that she killed herself and insists that Charles leave the detecting to the police, but Charles is not so easily put off.There are both positives and negatives in this book. On the positive side, the characters are delightful. Charles and Lady Jane are likable as is Graham, Lennox's loyal manservant. The setting is true to life and showcases both the period and the lives of the characters. I couldn't stop reading it was such fun to be immersed in the period with likable characters.On the negative side, it you like a mystery that is difficult to solve and has lots of unexpected twists, this isn't for you. The plot is absurdly easy to guess. The facts are laid out in the first quarter of the book. The problem from then on how the author tries to divert your attention. I liked the book, but as a mystery it was disappointing. Luckily, the characters and setting carry the book.I reviewed this book for Net Galley.

Sumner Jackson, a renowned surgeon, head of the American Hospital in Paris, hates what the Nazis are doing to his beloved Paris. An American, he grew to love Paris after marrying his Swiss wife, Toquette. They and their only child, Phillip want to do everything they can to aid the Allies.Sumner uses his position in the hospital to smuggle British and French fighters to Spain and then to Britain. Toquette becomes involved in the French Resistance. Living on the Avenue Foch where the other houses had been commandeered by the Gestapo, makes becoming involved in the Resistance an extremely dangerous activity and the Jacksons and their son paid the price.Seen through the eyes of the Jacksons from their vantage point on the Avenue Foch, this book shows the horror of the Nazi occupation of Paris in vivid colors. Many of the beautiful mansions that had been commandeered by the Gestapo were used as torture chambers to encourage people to turn in their neighbors and locate any Jews in hiding.The story is particularly poignant by, in addition to telling the story of the Jacksons, following the career of Gestapo agent Knochen, Dr. Bones. Knochen is a charming, learned individual who loves Paris, but he wants the power to form it in his image. The contrast between the Jackson family and Knochen is startling.If you're interested in WWII and the Nazi occupation of Paris, this is one of the best books I've read. The author uses this true story to present the horror of living in a city controlled by psychopaths who delight in torture and murder. It's not an easy book to read, but I highly recommend it.I reviewed this book for Blogging for Books.

Veronica Speedwell is an unusual young woman for Victorian times. She collects butterflies, going on extended expeditions to strange places to find her specimens and collecting romances along the way. She has never known her parents being brought up by two spinsters to whom she is not related.Veronica attends the funeral of her last adopted aunt. Now she's on her own and eager to get started with her life, but when she returns to the cottage she shared with her aunt, she finds a man rummaging through her things. Undeterred, she plans to pursue her journey, but narrowly escapes being kidnapped. A mysterious German baron befriends her and takes her to stay with his reclusive, naturalist friend, Stoker. Stoker and Veronica immediately begin a verbal sparring match that is rather delightful to listen to.Before the baron can tell Veronica what is going on, he's murdered. Now Stoker is stuck with his difficult roommate and together they decide to try to solve the mystery.The characters in this book, Veronica and Stoker, are very well done. I loved their verbal sparring and the fact that both were extremely independent. Veronica was quite unusual for a Victorian lady. The plot is full of twists that keep you guessing and the conclusion is quite unexpected. The Victorian setting is well done and makes a perfect backdrop for the action.I thoroughly enjoyed this book. If you like historical mysteries with a bit of romance, you may enjoy this book.I reviewed this book for Net Galley.

Many books have been written about the political factors leading up to WWII and the Holocaust, but The Black Earth is remarkable in the way it pulls history,  social conditions, and political theory together to create a picture of the factors allowing the Holocaust to happen.One factor was Hitler's severe racial hatred. His plan was always to exterminate the Jews. Another was the destruction of the identity of the state in areas like Poland and Eastern Europe. When the state was dissolved, citizens lost their identity as members of the larger group, and there was no organization to protect them. Snyder recounts the history of how this came about as part of Hitler's plan and the devastating consequences.However, the book also has a hopeful section. The author recounts numerous stories of non-Jews hiding Jews, or helping them escape. It reinforces the idea that people to people contact is important in enabling people of all political and religious groups to show compassion to those in need.The final chapter is something I believe everyone should read. We like to think we have put the Holocaust behind us, but there are factors in the world today which could tip the balance and return the world to something resembling that terrible time. When people fear global catastrophe, they can become rapacious trying to secure their own survival with radical action and become less amenable to political solutions. It's something for all of us to think about.I highly recommend this book. It puts into perspective much of what led to the Holocaust and cautions us against complacency.I reviewed this book for Net Galley.

Christians are familiar with the Sermon on the Mount, but this book takes it one step further. Schuller breaks Bible passages down into sections and devotes a chapter to each section. The substance of the chapters is familiar from the Beatitudes, to the Lord's Prayer, but Schuller has brought the sections into everyday parlance.Each section contains theological theory, but also examples from the author's own life. There are also explanations of what the ancient Hebrews would have understood some of the passages to mean. I found this particularly fascinating. In the section on marriage and divorce. Schuller goes to some length to explain that women were considered almost like property. At the time, a husband could divorce his wife for almost any reason from adultery to putting too much salt in his food. If the woman was divorced, she had few options to keep from starving to death, one of them being prostitution. If she was given a Certificate of Divorce, at least she had a clean reputation. This makes sense of some of the ideas in that section that seem out of step with our modern era.I encourage every Christian to read this book. It's easy to understand, almost like chatting with an old friend. While each chapter discusses different verses from the Sermon on the Mount, the prevailing image is that Jesus is trying to encourage his followers to believe with their hearts, not to blindly follow the law. That's an excellent lesson for today as well.I reviewed this book for PR by the Book.

Familiarity with your camera and lenses to the point where you don't have to think constantly about the technical details, leads to more creative photos. This is what Peterson suggests. Play with you camera and lenses. Lie on your back and look up, climb a tree and look down, use different lenses to capture the same scene and evaluate the differences. He includes an exercise that while time consuming is designed to accomplish this.In addition to his suggestions for developing an intimacy with your camera, Peterson covers the basics for taking outstanding photos: design, composition, light, and a short section on Photoshop. The text in each section is easily within the scope of beginners as well as more advanced photographers. I found the use of several examples of the same scene taken from different perspectives the most useful part. Peterson discuss each example: what's good, what's lacking, and why he chose to experiment with another perspective. Necessarily, this leads to a certain amount of autobiography, but I found it fascinating. It's instructive to see how a professional thinks about his compositions.Whether you're a seasoned photographer, or more importantly, a beginner, this book gives you something to think about. Most seasoned photographers should know the contents of the text very well, but the glimpse of how another photographer constructs his shots is illuminating.I highly recommend this book. I enjoyed it and felt that I learned a great deal. I'm not a professional, rather an enthusiastic amateur, but I plan to try all his exercises. I'm sure they will help me to feel more at ease with my equipment.I reviewed this book for Blogging for Books

Gwen Marcey, a forensic artist, spots her dog, Winston, digging in her yard. She races from the house to make him stop. When he relinquishes his prize, she's shocked to discover that it's a human skull with a bullet hole in it. Relying on her artistic sense and forensic skill, she decides it's the skull of a young girl. The local sheriff isn't sure, but when Gwen and Winston find the rest of the body, he knows he has a problem on his hands.Finding the first body leads to the recovery of the bodies of more young girls on the farms through the rural Montana county. Eerily, the first body reminds Gwen of her teenage daughter Aynslee.
