I guess they never thought of providing a variable size board which is a pity.The version I'm reviewing is v1.1, and it has some questionable permissions like getting your accounts' info, read phone state, and get a list of running tasks. The first two could be related to Playphone which bills itself as a social gaming network but in truth just another game marketer & big data collector, but the latter is completely unnecessary. To be fair, this game didn't access the Internet during my testing & ran fine offline, but there is no guarantee that it will never do it. Why would you want a third-party network like Playphone when most if not all users already have access to Google Play or Amazon GameCircle or both? I definitely would like to see it removed together with those permissions. As a saving grace, at least this game exits cleanly.This is an average game, with some unwanted permissions & component, and overpriced at $1.99.

If you've missed this the first time when it was free, get it now. (Or risking having to wait for the next time it goes on sale for a dollar.)This is a puzzle game that puts you in a surreal Escheresque environment, and you have to guide the protagonist Princess Ida past each chapter to see what's it all about. An excellent example of immersive gaming experience, it's best that I don't reveal any spoilers so that you could explore it like a babe in the woods.I didn't bother to write a review when I first bought this game, nor the last time when it was free, because there were plenty of reviews praising & recommending it already. I downloaded it today to see if there are any new content* and, yes, there is a new chapter called "Ida's Dream" which you can access via the + icon on the top center of the main screen. (The right icon is Settings, the left Credits. To exit the game just use your Back key.) Unfortunately, I don't think we will be seeing any more new free chapters, because they're offering "Forgotten Shores" (8 new chapters) as an In-App Purchase for $1.99.This game does contain Flurry although it seems to have been disabled. It also runs fine offline and exits cleanly. So, like I said, get it! I can't say you will definitely love it, or even like it, but it most definitely deserves your checking it out.* The version I bought & played was v1.6.15. This review is for v2.3.0.

Looks like someone took a look at 2048, decided not to produce another clone but instead give it a new twist by making shapes instead of adding up numbers, and ended up with this.It's an endless game but if you played until there are no more moves, you might not want another go. It's BORING.  Each slide that doesn't result in merging of blocks will generate a new block and, several times I found myself left with only two blocks, slid to merge them, then having to slide them meaninglessly to another side just so a new block will appear (but you don't know where). Those Power-Ups are actually a necessity because there are no undo's and no support for detaching merged blocks; you can't move some of them so you could in a sense use them as stop posts but sometimes they just get in the way.There are no ads nor IAP's. It does have Flurry and Chartboost but they seem to have been disabled. In fact, it doesn't even seem to be accessing the Internet; but then again I never clicked on any scoreboard or "More" buttons, so it really shouldn't be. Unfortunately, this game does NOT exit cleanly. It will continue to use the CPU in the background. Considering that almost all Android devices run on batteries, this is an unforgivable oversight.You could download and try out this game while it is free, but be warned you might find it boring once the novelty wears off. Noodlecake should've made it free and improve the game based on user feedback before charging for it. Definitely not worth its regular price of $1.99.

This app will continue running in the background after you quit it using the Back key. I have no problem with an app being cached in memory, ready to be restarted without having to reload it from storage; but an app that will continue to use the CPU in the background after "exit" is not acceptable. This game was still using as much as 11% of the CPU half an hour after I quit it & is a battery drain. Get this fixed right away!

Yep. Pretty much all you have to do is keep your finger pressed on the 'Accelerate' button, go as far as your vehicle will take you, go back to the garage to buy upgrades, then try again. Undemanding, unapologetic destructive fun. Skills & strategies not required. Contains no malware, no IAP, and exits cleanly. Requires the Internet permission but runs fine offline.-  While the prices for the better vehicles seem steep, don't worry. You will earn more the further you progress. You should be able to ride on the ultimate vehicle with everything maxed out in or before the final part.-  The next-step-up vehicle is always better than your current one. Make upgrades to your current vehicle, but switch to a better one as soon as you have enough money.-  The Fuel & Boost upgrades are the cheapest, but they won't help much by themselves. It's better to distribute your money on different upgrades.-  The only exception is the Gun upgrade which I regard as a waste of money. You can't choose when & where to shoot, and ammunition is limited. You can just skip this upgrade for all the vehicles.-  It's not necessary to fiddle with the 'Head Down' & 'Tail Down' buttons on the left because your vehicle will hardly flip over. In fact, I feel sometimes it breaks the stride. It might help a little in the final part of the route though.-  In the final part of the route - Exodus Drive - when you should have already maxed out every upgrade, if you can't complete it you might want to release your finger from the 'Accelerate' and/or 'Boost' button while your vehicle is in the air to conserve fuel.-  Once you've completed the Story Mode, the Halloween Mode and the Championship Mode will be unlocked. The former requires you to destroy pumpkins along the route, the latter is just trying to better your time in reaching a checkpoint under a limited budget. Interesting variations, but not half as fun as Story Mode.There is quite a bit of self-promotion in this game, not least plugging for their sequel Earn to Die 2, and a pop-up will ask you to rate after reaching the first checkpoint; nevertheless, those minor annoyances are not enough to dissuade me from giving this game a 5. Well worth its regular price of $1.19.

This app is designed like your grandpa is building a clubhouse for you, and you will be helping him with certain small chores. There isn't much to 'learn' from this app other than perhaps some of the tools' names, and it's not really a game despite having to help put some broken pieces back together (6 or 7 different broken items at most I think); it's just a simple interactive experience.While this app might be amusing for 2 & 3-year-olds, it lacks challenge for older kids. The activities are too simple: you tap a colour paintbrush to paint a piece of furniture, no brushing with your finger; similarly, tap on the dotted line to cut a board, no swiping required. I'm pretty sure my 6-year-old niece would rather play something else after 10 minutes with this.You needn't worry about unsolicited components with this app though. The only questionable component is Flurry, but it seems to have been deactivated. This app asks for the Internet permission, but probably only uses it if you tap on the 'More' button to see what else Noodlecake has to offer. Anyway, it runs fine offline, and exits cleanly too.For a dollar this app gets a 4.5 rating from me.[Added]  Sad to see another superficial but sensationalistic review that is misleading. You CAN return to the main menu any time within the game by pressing the house icon on the top right.

While the words 'matching' 'colour' 'blocks' & the way it looks suggest something similar to Collapse!, Matchblocks is nothing like it. This is just a rather dumb exercise in tapping. You look at the colours on the fallen blocks, then tap the corresponding colours on the colour bar below to eliminate them. There are also bonuses in the form of circles, and you have to tap on them to get them; sometimes tapping the number of times indicated on them. Blocks & bonuses fall from the top & stack on one another to form a messy heap. There are four game modes which differ in playing conditions, but are essentially the same.This game contains code for Chartboost (for ads, not analytics this time round), PlayHaven, Google ads, etc., which are likely leftovers from the free version, but seem to have been disabled. It does access the Internet perhaps for the latest game info, but runs fine offline. There is a 'more games' button, and a scrolling 'rate me' on the main screen, but aren't terribly intrusive. It exits cleanly too.I'm sorry but I found this (paid) game to be incredibly boring, making the latest free-to-play Noodlecake game Brickies seems like a revelation in contrast.

Cryptogram Puzzles is a simple code breaker game in which letters of the alphabet are scrambled. Your task, as an Alan Turing wannabe, is to  find out which letter represents which.On your first run, you will be greeted with a EULA (End User License Agreement), the release notes for the latest version, and then some instructions. It is not often we find apps & games that do this, but I welcome such a move and don't find them intrusive. You will not be bothered by them on subsequent runs. On the main screen, you can set the background theme, the difficulty level, the type of quote/proverb to use, etc., or simply press 'New Puzzle' to play. The games are not timed, but the app does keep score and, not only is it difficult to achieve a perfect score, but it's equally hard to get a positive score!  A negative score will be added every time you entered an incorrect guess, or when you used a hint, so you really have to think before entering anything. (I did get a perfect score for a proverb because it had a lot of 'the's & 'is's but I don't think I can repeat that feat often.)  Unfortunately, there is no way to turn off scoring, so you'll just have to ignore it. If you want to quit during a game but want to save your progress for resuming later on, the game supports saving it. When you have completed a game, however, you will not find a convenient "New Puzzle" option; instead, you'll have to go back to the main menu and select 'New Puzzle' from there.The difficulty levels - as far as I could see - differ in the amount of feedback the game gives you. For instance, 'Low Difficulty' will indicate whether your entered letter is correct or not in real time, but 'Expert' difficulty will not - and you would have to press 'Check' manually to see if your answer is correct.In the main screen, you have the option to enter a 'Custom Message' and the game will encrypt it for you. You can then pass your device to a friend or family member for them to solve. Therefore, you are not restricted to the phrases chosen by the developer, and that for me is a nice touch. I just wish the game would allow us to save our own messages for re-use.This game can be considered to be free from malware. There are the usual Amazon stuff, and I believe its Internet Access Permission is primarily used for Amazon Insight, but the game runs fine offline. There is also a Quit button, but which did not perform a clean exit during my testing. It was still using the CPU intermittently although - to be fair - not much. Still, if the developer is reading this, I hope you will fix it in an update. I suspect something to do with saving the game's data on KitKat but don't quote me on that.All in all, despite the minor quibbles that I've mentioned, the game is still good value for a dollar, and deserves 5 stars.

I have bought & completed Amazing Breaker over two years ago, and I still have fond memories of it. In a nutshell, you slingshot different weapons to destroy the beautiful sculptures in each level, and you are required to destroy a certain percentage of them in order to pass and unlock the next level. You can do bank shots (bounce your weapons off the wall), switch the top two weapons available to you, etc. As you progress, you will soon realize choosing the ideal order of weapons, applying the right force & angle will be the key to success. I can tell you that all levels are solvable, and you should be able to achieve 100% total destruction for the majority of levels!There is no IAP, and no malware to be wary of. It asks for the network access permission, which I believe is for the now-discontinued Scoreloop gaming network, but otherwise runs just fine offline. It exits cleanly too.It has been quite some time since I've played this game and this, the latest Amazon version, seems not as smooth & a bit too easy to misfire. I'm not sure if it's my phone because after all I've gone through two different ones during the period. Moreover, this version doesn't seem to be as new as the one in the Play Store, so there is the odd chance it might not run on the latest exotic device. Please try it yourself, preferably on another device if it doesn't run for you.I highly recommend this game. It's great value for a dollar, and it's like an early Christmas present when free. There are other free but ad-supported games similar to Amazing Breaker, so do look around if you find yourself wanting more after completing this one! ;)

Similar to the items you can buy from a dollar store, you wouldn't expect any quality despite there might be the occasional odd bargain. Velocispider is like that: move left & right and keep shooting. Nothing new, nothing exciting, but good for killing some time before you move on to another game.Control is limited to tilting only, so don't expect being able to make sharp reversals of direction. The graphics are blocky, the music noisy. Levels have to be unlocked by completing their previous ones. If you get hit 3 times, or get all your eggs snatched away, you die. You can replay a level for as many times as needed until you pass. Sometimes, dying is actually a good option when you're low on lives & eggs.There is IAP to unlock all levels for another $0.99. It exits cleanly by pressing your Back key in the main screen. Contains code for Google ads, Chartboost, Playhaven, etc. although they seem to be inactive and - most importantly - it runs fine offline. Actually, you should play it offline if you don't want to see pop-ups asking you to rate them or try their other games.[Addendum]Well, having met my limit on level 17. This game is done for me.It looks like there are only 20 levels which is rather short (unless you want to count the endless retries until you pass them all). In conclusion, 3 stars is about right.

[Added] Revised rating from 4.5 down to 4, because sometimes the game becomes unresponsive, or slow to respond, or just plain acting weird! Even forced closed too! Same problems before & after reboot on KitKat 4.4.4. They might not be persistent, but still often enough for me to leave a bad taste in the mouth. Also, the "try our other games" pop-up on game start is quite annoying. You already have a banner, you really shouldn't stick another one in our face like that!!![Original] Word to Word (WTW) is a simple word-pair matching game. Words can be matched based on a number of criteria, and so it isn't as straightforward as spotting associations between words, but also how to pair them so each word is matched with another with no orphans. For instance, both "full" and "able" could be matched to "bodied" to form a compound word, but one of them needs to be matched with another word. You start by picking a word from EITHER side, then pick one that you believe is its match on the other side. If the words are completely unrelated, usually you won't be able to select the second word; but it sometimes get it wrong as in 'tea' & 'break'. If they have something in common, the game will let you select it *but* they might not be the correct pairing for solving the puzzle. Sometimes, the game will tell you "the last pair can't be matched" and you have to try other combinations, but it seems the game isn't always so attentive to your mismatches.The puzzles aren't timed, and you can pick any puzzle to play without having to unlock them in turn. The puzzles you have completed will have a bright yellow star on them, while those in progress a smaller brown star. This Mega Pack contains the basic Smile Pack with 40 puzzles, and the Mega Pack 1 with 400 more for a total of 440 puzzles. There are 5 other Mega Packs, each with 400 puzzles, available for in-app purchase at $1.99 individually, or $4.99 for all 5 (2000 puzzles). There are no hints in each puzzle, but I don't think anyone would need them even with the occasional new slang words like 'pwn' which I believe hasn't made it into all mainstream dictionaries yet. The developer's choice of words & their perceived relationship isn't always perfect, and sometimes debatable. Despite all that, the difficulty of the puzzles is only average (well I checked the "last" puzzles in the packs), and I would expect the average player to complete each puzzle in around 30 seconds, give or take 20.WTW is basically free from malware, although it contains Chartboost (could be strictly for analytics only) and will access the Internet. However, it runs fine offline. A 'Please Rate' pop-up appeared after puzzle #8 but, after I pretended to do so (tapped "Rate It Now" then simply press the Back button to return to the game), it never reared its head again all through the remaining 32 puzzles & more. It also exits cleanly - something which I believe the developer added in after others complained about its absence in previous versions.440 puzzles might seem a lot but I am sure some of you will be able to breeze through them in an hour or two; thus I think $1.99 might be a *little* bit overpriced. Moreover, although they don't bother me, the self-promo material on the main screen & the rate-me should be tucked out of sight accessible only if the user (parent) allows it. The same goes for Chartboost. As a result, my rating is actually 4.5.

The first thing you will notice is that there are NO instructions nor explanations. There are 4 courses, each with 18 holes. The four buttons with clubs above the courses' name are for specifying the number of players, so you can pass the device around for local multiplayer games. For each hole there is a par (naturally), but also a maximum number of strokes; if you exceed the latter, you'll be shuffled along to the next hole. NO NEED to, and NO WAY to, keep trying until you can get the ball into the hole - unless you are okay with replaying the whole course again & again till you make it. Swipe anywhere on the screen to change direction of your shot, then press down on the green Power button on the lower right to adjust the power, and let go to strike it. If your ball goes out of bounds, no additional penalty is added other than the shot you took.I "finished" the whole game in less than an hour. I am not saying I "completed" it because I didn't. While I was able to achieve below par for the first two courses, I got "shuffled along" quite a number of times during the last two courses. There were quite a few holes I didn't actually "complete". However, I have no interest to replay the game & better my score, and here's why:-  The first course (Rookie) is dead easy. The second (Journeyman) more challenging. But the third (Masters) & fourth (Jinxed) are simply too contrivedly difficult. There are disappearing & reappearing segments, portals, moving objects, etc., and the way the developer combines them make them more frustrating than challenging.-  You cannot pan, rotate, or zoom in & out to see the course and, more importantly, the hole. Every time you begin a hole, the camera will pan around in a fixed fashion. That's all the view you will get.-  There is no indication of the power you used in your last shot, and I can accept that; after all, not all mini-golf games provide such a feature. However, the direction of your shot is always reset to point to the direction of the hole (even when it's out of sight) and completely unrelated to the obstacle right in front of you. Now the game doesn't support FINE adjustments of direction, so it can be quite frustrating when you got the direction right but not the power in your last shot, then everything got reset.-  Once you pressed down on the Power button, it will just keep on cycling through the power levels, and you CANNOT ABORT the shot. Neither can you further adjust the direction. Timing plays a crucial part in most of the holes in the last two courses and, since Power + Shoot are tied together instead of separate steps, you need as much dumb luck as trial-and-error when a shot calls for both precise power and exact timing.Mini Golf Mundo contains no malware, it contacts the Amazon servers but runs fine offline. and it does exit cleanly. Nevertheless, it is not as enjoyable as it could be, and not worthy of 5 stars even for $0.99. Since its regular price is $1.99, I will only give it a 3.(* The above review is for v1.2.1, and I hope that EnsenaSoft will be making improvements to future versions. I had bought 2 games from them already & I know they should be capable of producing a more decent game than this current version.)

The graphics are beautiful, but they don't look sharp enough even on a 5.5" 1920x1080 screen, and becomes a slight problem on cluttered hidden objects scenes. The mini-game is too small, not even using half the screen's width.I have come to expect a few good hours of entertainment from each Artifex Mundi game, and this seems no exception. Apart from the self-promo material, it's free from malware, runs fine offline, and exits cleanly. I'd say it's good value when on discount but, for its regular price of $4.99, the graphics should be better, or at least suggest that this game is best played on a tablet!

There is debate on whether RAM Booster & Task Killer apps are actually useful, but only two things are for sure: (1) ALL of them will tell you they are useful, and (2) they themselves will drain your battery by constantly running in the background. True Booster v1.1.4 wants you to feel they are truthful & honest by telling you what "other boosters won't tell you", namely: (1) certain apps will turn themselves back on after boosting, and (2) constant boosting can drain your device. Well, while some boosters do neglect to point out these facts up front, I don't think any of them denies them.True Booster told me, after its initial analysis, that I had 61% battery remaining, 44% RAM (1.3GB!) free, and 42% storage (24GB!) free which it considered to be all "Normal", but still it flashes its "Boost Needed" button. Really? OK, I'm not going to knock it for that; but then you know what? Killing tasks was NEVER a sophisticated process (you could do it yourself by clearing your recent apps menu), but NOT KILLING crucial tasks is important in order not to ruin your system. You can manually select which running apps to exclude if you use True Booster's "Boost Now", but its "Auto Boost" will only allow presets of "All", "Top 5 Data Consuming Apps", and "Top 5 Battery Consuming Apps". There are NO WHITELISTS with which you can exclude apps that you know should remain running!! BIG FAIL!!On the other hand, True Booster wants to know your location & read your low-level system logs. Let me tell you there is ABSOLUTELY NO NEED for those permissions to boost your system! They are NOTHING BUT POTENTIAL PRIVACY HAZARDS. I suggest you read True Booster's privacy policy to see what they can collect & disclose.If you have a rooted device, there are many apps that could do what True Booster claims to do - and more. If you don't, no need to despair. Check out CCleaner for storage/cache cleaning, and Greenify for auto-hibernating apps that you feel shouldn't run in the background. The former is free; the latter as good as free. If you want something all-in-one then check out Clean Master* which I believe is the most downloaded app of its kind & is also free. Just for the record, I am NOT affiliated with any of the above. I had used them (otherwise I won't be commenting on them) but, apart from CCleaner which I'm keeping around as an alternative, I am using other PAID apps instead because they suit me better for one reason or another. What I would never do, however, is pay $1.99 for a commonplace booster app with dubious permissions like True Booster.*  The current version of Clean Master in the Amazon Appstore is v5.9.0 and also requires the read low level logs permission. The latest version in the Play Store is v5.9.7 and does NOT require it.

Coffee Mahjong is simply another mahjong solitaire game with a coffee theme. The background and the tiles are all coffee-related pictures; even the somewhat zen-like background music has coffee dripping sound LOL. They might be visually pleasing for coffee addicts, but personally I find them to be so-so.In this game, the blocked tiles just seem to be coated with a layer of chocolate, but you can still make out what they are. There is also a hint button, so together they help to make playing less frustrating I suppose. What I cannot understand is why they designed the game to be 15-minute sessions. Once you start playing, the timer will start counting down (if you switch to another app, the timer will pause), and you try to get as high a score as possible within that time frame. A new game will always start out from Level 1 AGAIN, and you don't get to choose which level to play.This game seems to be free from malware. It asks for the Internet permission, but as long as you don't tap the "More Games" button in its main screen, I don't think it will access the Internet. Anyway, it runs fine offline. When you have finished playing the game, be sure to tap the "Quit" button in the main screen to exit; pressing your device's Back key won't really quit & this game will continue to run in the background draining your battery.

Rotate It!, as its name implies, requires you to tap and "ROTATE the pieces until all ends are closed"; in other words, CONNECT the pieces until there are no more "orphan" pieces, but only PIPES with CAPPED ENDS. There are usually more than one pipe in a level, and a pipe might have more than 2 capped ends.You can play in the Zen mode, which has a timer but it's only for reference; or you can play the Challenge mode where the timer counts down and you have to finish before time runs out. You also have 3 backgrounds to choose from, and the option to turn the grid on and off. The music is relaxing, but you can turn it off too if it's not your cup of tea. You are not required to complete a level before attempting the next, you can pick ANY level you like; and completed levels will be shown in dark cyan just so you know. This game requires no special permission, has no IAP or self-promo material, and doesn't use the Internet. It also exits cleanly too.All the levels are played on a 13x7 grid, but earlier levels which don't use up the whole grid won't automatically zoom in to show only the playable area; making the pieces seem unnecessarily small especially on phones with small screens. That shouldn't be a problem for most people though, as with the lack of a hint system because I think the average player should be able to solve all the levels given enough patience.I think Rotate It! offers good value for a dollar, and recommend that you try it out.

dock it - saga!, like Flappy Bird, is a game that will polarize opinions. Some find its simple gameplay addictive, others might find it monotonous.All you have to do is look for openings & stick the dots to the rotating big circle, like pins to a pin cushion, or spokes to a wheel. As you progress, the big circle will be rotating quicker & already have more dots attached (less room for your dots). Call it brainless if you like, but it might help you to focus & improve your eye-hand coordination.There are two modes: the Classic mode with dots & a big circle, and the Space mode which is just a cosmetic change with you firing modules at a mother ship instead. You have to pass one level before the next is unlocked, but there is the option to skip the current level if you failed it; you can also go back and play an earlier (and presumably easier) level if you wish.This game is free from malware and IAP. It does connect to the Amazon Web Services server behind your back, but you can play the game offline. It also exits cleanly telling Android that it wants to quit, and that in my humble opinion is what every responsible app should do.dock it! is almost identical to the free but ad-supported game aa, minus the questionable permissions.

Motivated Moms (MoMo), in a word, is another to-do list manager. You have to pay $1.99 for this "full version", and $7.99 (currently $4.99 on Mother's Day discount for a limited time) for a one year subscription for "preplanned tasks and backup of your customizations".You are requested to register & keep an account with the publisher to enable syncing across devices. You can use the app without registration, but boy it will remind you what you are losing out every time you enter the app. While I am not against subscriptions as a business model (and I have paid for a few active subscriptions myself), it all boils down to whether it is NECESSARY (such as *free* news app that you pay to remove ads) & whether it's WORTH it. I doubt very much MoMo's preplanned tasks will fit everyone's needs, or that such tasks change much over time to warrant a subscription.* What is wrong with or so difficult about entering YOUR tasks YOURSELF? Then too, why can't MoMo use our Google or Amazon account to "save & sync our task data"? Or make backups to cloud storage? Sorry, but MoMo doesn't even backup locally, so you risk losing all your data if your device crashes & require a factory reset.On the surface MoMo seems to work as described. However, there are many areas that I found strange or inadequate, such as:-  No reminders (pop-ups, alarms, etc.) for individual tasks, or at least no way to customize them.-  No support for postponing a task.-  Option to use color assignments for tasks but no way to change them. In fact, not much you can customize about the interface!-  Puzzling choice in that you can choose a repeat period of every x weeks, but not every x days or months or years.-  Repeat tasks are based on scheduled dates only, and cannot use completed dates as reference.-  If you change your mind after choosing Selected Days/Weeks/Months, tapping 'Cancel' will not direct you back to the 'Pick Due Date' screen; instead you have to select None or Not Weekly/Monthly.-  There seems to be a bug that when you edit an existing task, a duplicate with the modified data will be created instead.-  Bible Reading as a standalone default task!? (At least you could turn it off.)-  No support for task priorities, sub-tasks, etc.MoMo seems to be free from malware but it does contain Flurry, although I'm not sure whether it's still active. It can be run offline, although you might be reminded of that every time as it tries to communicate with its servers. Moreover, it will remain running in the background when you "exit" the app; that is actually desirable if it has a functional reminder system to remind you of overdue tasks. *IF*.There are MANY to-do list and task managers in the market. Popular ones such as Any.do & Todoist ask for subscriptions too, but they are more powerful & customizable than MoMo. If you want only simple checklist types, you can use your calendar (and Google Tasks if you use their calendar), or check out the many free alternatives. I strongly advise users to compare alternatives before buying this. I'm not even ruling out the possibility that you *might* find MoMo to be perfect for you but, for me, MoMo simply doesn't justify its price for the casual user nor the demanding one.*  Why is the "Ability to add unlimited custom tasks" touted as a feature? Surely the ability to enter tasks relevant only to us, and enter as many as we want, is a BASIC requirement for ALL task managers!!  LOL

As far as I can see, the only strategies involved are:-  capture the nearest islands (because they take less time for your troops to get there);-  capture neutral islands first;-  capture the biggest islands first (because troops will grow faster on a larger island)Other than the above, it's just a matter of tap, tap, tap because the AI (enemy) will pause between successive attacks, but you don't have to; or wait for the enemies to fight it out then capture one of their decimated islands; but if there is more than one enemy & both start out with more troops than you, you better hope they fight each other instead of targeting you because there is no way you're going to survive - strategies or no strategies.Graphics are crude and, while you can turn off the sound through your device's Menu button, there isn't much you can customize. You can't, for example, set the speed of troop deployment to be faster. Well, at least this game is free from malware, doesn't use the Internet, and exits cleanly, but I must say it's VERY AVERAGE (some might even find it boring), and certainly not worth $2.99!

This is in essence another room escape game, although sometimes you try to get in rather than get out. There are 15 levels (rooms), but the first level is a tutorial, so there are actually only 14. But there is a Secret Room the access to which I believe depends on you having collected all 15 gems.* In each level there is a gem lying about. If you realize you had missed one later on, you can always go to previously completed levels to find one. I don't think you need to go through the whole level again. For example, I completed Level 5 before I realize I didn't get one in Level 4; so I went back & found it sitting on the window sill. No need to "replay" the whole level.The graphics, for me, is a notch better than other prolific room-escape publishers. Early levels are not very difficult but looks like later ones would present more of a challenge. If you are stuck, help is available via walkthroughs which the game will lead you to the relevant one on YouTube. The game contains no malware and, although it does use the Internet, it runs fine offline. This game by itself is quite decent as a matter of fact.Unfortunately, I have to deduct two stars from its rating. First of all, there are too much self-serving info in the game. You see "More Games" & "Rate Me" almost everywhere (-0.5). A "Rate Me" will pop up on entering Level 4 which I got rid of by pretending to rate, only to find out later on that it seems to be hard-coded to pop up whenever you go into Level 4. The other major annoyance being that this game does NOT exit cleanly! It remains running in the background consuming on average around 2% of the CPU!! (-1)  This game will give you an hour or two of entertainment, after which there is very little replay value, so I think $0.99 is a more fitting price than the $1.99 it asks for (-0.5).*  As another reviewer had discovered, you don't really need to collect all the gems to access the Secret Room.

This is just a collection of (public domain?) wallpapers gleaned from the Internet. I counted 39 which actually isn't a lot given the different tastes of millions of users. The collection here is OK; nothing exceptional or exclusive; quite a few I've seen floating around the net for ages. You can set any one as your device's wallpaper, or share it. That's it. Not much in terms of functionality. The wallpapers are NOT high-resolution ones and, since there is no 'tiling' option for Android wallpapers, they have to be 'expanded' to fill a high-resolution screen, and lose some of their sharpness in the process.This 'app' contains Google Ads, but it seems to be disabled. It asks for the Internet permission, but doesn't seem to be using it & runs fine offline. There are no IAP's or self-adverts (nor should there be!), and exits quite cleanly using the Back key.I have to be blunt and say you'd be better off visiting one of those wallpaper websites on the Internet instead of relying on this app. At least they have more choices & have new content added regularly. The majority of them offer downloads for free, so there's no reason at all why you would pay for an 'app' such as this one. Even for free, as it is now, it's likely not worth your time.

Everything about this game is SIMPLE. Simple game mechanics, simple gameplay, simple graphics. Whip Swing is like a cross between Hanger & Flappy Bird, without the broken limbs of the former, but with the same one-dimensional challenge of the latter.Personally I did not find this game interesting, if not a bit boring. You cannot decide where to attach your whip (always 45° to the right only), and the playing field is not tall enough. Unless you're a die-hard fan of Flappy Bird & its ilk, it's likely you won't like it too.At least this game does not contain any malware, except the usual Amazon components. Although it asks for & uses the Internet, it runs fine offline. Promotion for other games & social media links are tucked away in Settings, so that's good; as is also the clean exit it performs. It's just a pity the game itself is too simple to make it worthwhile.

The first thing you'll notice about Deep Under the Sky is its beautiful, high-def graphics. A colourful razzle-dazzle which, by itself, would make an attractive live wallpaper. In the midst of this visual splendour we have a hairy alien jellyfish that is trying to fill the alien land with its progenies. To do that, you will help it launch little jellyfishes and guide them to nests to plant babies. The game is played using just one button, but I found that you can tap anywhere on the screen to represent tapping the button. Each tap will perform different actions depending on what's in store (lower left), like different cartridges in a magazine (think Angry Birds with different birds lined up but in a fixed order). In the most simple sequence, the first tap on the button will launch a mini jellyfish, then the next tap will explode it (to impregnate the nest); Of course, in later levels, we have other actions like jet propel the jellyfish, hold down the button to roll it on the ground or swing it (grapple), etc.The game is played in 'discovery' mode. That is to say you don't get to see the whole playing field, but only parts of it as your little jellyfish moves around. There are little arrows that point out the directions of the nests, but they are only approximates and won't tell you whether there are obstacles in the way; so you'll have to discover the exact locations of the nests yourself.There are 4 Chapters and each has 20 levels, so there are plenty of exploring as well as seeding to do. There are no time limits, and you have an endless supply of little jellyfishes. You are not required to complete one level before you can play the next; you can choose any level of any chapter to play, so there's less frustration & wastage when you can't finish a level. If you collect all the bonus stars (2 in each level & you'll have to discover their locations without hint), you can unlock the "hardcore DARK MODE". Apart from a stunningly beautiful dark theme, you now play as an alien squid, and you have to directly hit each seed pod to impregnate them. Challenging yet difficult!The game is free from malware and - although it asks for the network permission - it doesn't seem to be using it & runs fine offline. It also exits cleanly. And, despite its heavy graphics, it didn't make my phone especially hot to the touch.Deep Under the Sky might not be as unique as Sarah's previous game Incredipede, but it's distinctive enough & not just another "me too" game. I'm not sure why, but currently it's cheaper in the Appstore ($2.99) than the Play store ($3.99); for $2.99 it's 5 stars from me.[Addendum]Having now completed the game, I must say it's well worth its price. Level design is good, and you won't feel one level is simply the clone of another with minor changes; Perhaps the names they gave to each level reflect its layout design, but I was too busy playing to verify that LOL. Timing (when & where to perform an action) is very important, and you should also take into account the behaviour of each action (releasing your finger while rolling to jump up a bit, or letting it swing 360 degrees until it turns the other way, etc.).I have encountered no bugs when playing this game, although it could do with some changes to the interface. For instance, the game seems to have its own idea which landscape direction to lock itself in, and doesn't respond to device rotation. Also, you can't choose another level when you start the game; you can only play your last-played level but, once inside it, you can back out & choose another level. Having said that, they are not that annoying to negatively affect your enjoyment of the game.Last but not least, I would like to go on record & thank the developer for helping me get that elusive star in Chapter 2, Optio. Cheers!

This is a SURVIVAL game. As the night guard of Freddy's Pizza Parlour, you have to survive 5 nights (think of them as increasingly difficult levels) without being scared to death by one of the haunted toys (Animatronics). You don't leave the monitor room; they'll come and get you. Directly in front you is the entrance, and you tap on the square to flash your flashlight at it; on either side are two vents, and you use the light switches to see if anything's there. You will also make use of the CCTV's to monitor movements (the pull-up menu on the bottom right) and, when they do come into the room to face you, put on the mask (the red arrows on the bottom left) to ward them off.I cannot offer any detailed advice right now because I have only played the original. I'm leaving this sequel for the evenings (I feel it's best played in the dark) when I have at least 7-8 minutes (that's approximately how long each night is) of uninterrupted time. This isn't just my preference, it's also a necessity because you can't pause the game during a 'night'; the Back key will quit the game altogether, and tapping 'Continue' will take you to the same night but reset to the beginning.The game is free from malware, and doesn't need any special permissions including network access. Don't worry about the Google Ads code as it's just a leftover from its demo version. The game also exits cleanly.This is a game the appeal of which relies heavily on its immersive experience. While nothing to rave about, the somewhat grainy graphics & the crackling sounds all contribute to the eerie ambience. Some might find the game boring, or not for the faint-hearted; but love it or hate it, you'll just have to download it, try it, then decide for yourself.

This is another plain Hidden Objects game. It doesn't pretend to be an adventure game, nor has any storyline. It has a theme (Irish in this case) with background pictures (scenes) relevant to that theme, and you are to find all the listed objects for each scene within the time limit.The graphics are sharp & crisp, but the scenes require panning up & down to see the whole picture. Apparently the developer didn't think of taking advantage of higher resolution screens, as panning was required even on my 2560 x 1600 tablet. There is a zoom button, but it only supports one level of zoom: zoom in & zoom out, and doesn't support pinch-to-zoom.There are 3 game modes: 'Chill' is simply 'Traditional' with no time or hint limits. It says there are 3 levels per scene, which are 'Find by Picture', 'Find by Word', and 'Collector' in which you are to find multiple instances of an object. It seems the scenes in these two modes are different (16 scenes in all) so it won't feel too repetitive. The third mode 'Adventure' requires you to find objects by word only, but some of the words are scrambled and some have missing letters. The whole game isn't difficult at all and, despite the time limit in 2 of the modes, not very challenging. Why? Because there are NO PENALTIES FOR RANDOM CLICKING. You could just tap, tap, tap to find all the objects. And if you have played through the 'Chill' & 'Traditional' modes first, you'll probably be able to guess what the scrambled words & words with missing letters are.This game is free from malware, although it does communicate with the Amazon servers behind your back. However, it runs just fine offline. There are no In-App Purchases, although there is a game-controller icon on its home screen which would take you to see (and buy) their other games. This game also exits cleanly by pressing the Back button, although I wish when we are playing a scene it would take us back to its home screen instead of terminating the game.As mentioned above, there are certainly areas that could do with some improvement, not least by randomizing the items; for it seems - in this version anyway - the items to find for a scene always remain the SAME, thus reducing the game's overall replay value. I would rate this game 4.5 but, since its regular price is only $0.99, I'll round it up to 5.  Happy St. Patrick's Day!

The basic criteria with which we measure how good a Hidden Object game is always how well the objects are hidden. They shouldn't be too obvious, while on the other hand not too obscure or tricky; the latter I mean when an object that had eluded you was finally revealed, you would feel it was your own oversight & might even applaud the developer for hiding it so cleverly, rather than curse that it was for instance so fuzzy or placed on a same colour background that made it near impossible to spot. Unfortunately, this game has quite a few of those frustratingly hidden objects. The levels that require you to find objects by their silhouettes especially could do with some improvement.The graphics are in general OK, although the objects have varied degrees of clarity. The storyline... well, just cobbled together to forge some kind of link between the different levels, and not at all interesting. The Match-3 mini game after completing every 5 levels is dull, and not very accurate when recognizing the direction of your swipes.All in all, and I'm writing this only after I have completed all the levels, if you are looking for an inexpensive fix for your Hidden Object addiction, I guess $1.99 is a fair price considering the total number of levels included. If you are after a quality game, however, this game (or these 3 games) isn't it.

[Please note this review has been edited to reflect my progress, but the game's verdict remains the same]Game mechanism is similar to Little Galaxy & TA: Little Red Riding Hood: Tap to hop from one rotating planet to the next. Game objective, however, is different - you are not trying to reach as many planets as possible, nor is there a "destination" planet; instead, you just try to collect all the stars that lie between the planets. There is no time-limit, and you won't "die" because it all happens in a wrap-around playing area.While ORBB doesn't have the beautiful graphics found in the other two games, its minimal yet adequate visuals do not detract from its simple yet engrossing gameplay. You might think this is relaxing game, but there is no shortage of challenges such as having to collect certain stars in the right order as introduced in Phase 3, having to contend with anti-gravity as in Phase 4, and purple planets that disappear after one jump in Phase 5. They are just not as frustrating and - having completed the game - I can report that all levels are solvable*.This game contains no malware or anything that you should worry about. It does use the Internet but seems primarily for Amazon services. If you are paranoid, you can always disable your Internet connection; this game runs fine offline. It doesn't have an exit button nor does the Back key work to quit the game; you'll have to press the Home key & swipe it off your Recent Apps menu. Anyway its CPU usage seems minimal while in the background. I saw the "Rate Me" prompts only twice through all 60 levels (after completing 2-5 & 4-15) which, to be fair, weren't too frequent but I do wish they would tuck it away in the main menu & let the player decide.In summary, the game itself deserves a 5 for its regular price of $0.99. I would have taken half-a-point away for the lack of a clean exit & the rating reminder, but I am quite happy to round it up rather than down because of its solid play value.* In the later stages where both wormholes & anti-gravity are at play, you might find yourself caught in a loop. I encountered it only once in 5-14. Simply replay the level. If the screen becomes blank on starting a new level, exit the game and restart. No harm done.

The version I reviewed was 1.4.0, and it did NOT seek my location. It doesn't even ask for any location permissions. Period. It has Google ads, Flurry, and In-App Purchase code, but none of them are active. I believe they are leftovers from the free version available in the Play Store, and this Amazon paid version should for all intent & purpose be considered as SAFE. It does use the Internet such as for accessing the Leaderboard, but it runs fine offline.The game doesn't perform a truly clean exit, as it still intermittently uses the CPU as a cached process in the background; but the usage is minimal & it'll be cleared out when you run out of memory anyway.The game itself is simple - in both senses of the word. One touch control to gather speed when traveling downhill, or when landing from the air. Your goal is to travel for as far, and as long, as possible beyond the 30-second initial timeframe. The graphics is equally simple too. Kind of like Flappy Bird.The game is quite bland, without variety and short of excitement. It's certainly not something I would pay for. However, if you liked Flappy Bird, you might want to try this while it's FAOTD; at least it's safer than the free version!

This is the third Mobest's Escape games we got as FAOTD in a month. I must confess I'm getting more tired writing reviews about them than playing them LOL.As expected, the usual tap, tap, tap. Find clue to unlock the next clue. Repeat, until you eventually get the room key. This game is, chronologically speaking, released earlier than the previous two FAOTD ones, and it shows. All 15 stages (actually 14 because the first one was a tutorial) has only one main room - no side rooms; and the app will remain ACTIVE in memory when you press the Back key to exit (probably some wise guy's idea so you could always return to where you were in the game). Just remember to swipe it away in your Recent Apps list when finished with it. The game is clean (please don't blindly trust the "scanner" apps out there). It uses the Internet, but works fine offline (with the added benefit that its self-promos won't show nor work!)I would say the whole game in general is of medium difficulty, except for Stage 3 which is a walk in the room (I mean park). The usual graphics, neither better nor worse than the other Mobest games. If a more detailed window pop up when you tap an item in your inventory, it means either you have to tweak it in some way (try tap on different parts of the item) or you need to combine another item with it (although sometimes the combination is automatically done for you when you find the 2nd item). If the Rate-Me prompt comes up (after level 4 for me) just press 'Rate Now' instead of 'Skip' then Back key to return to the game.For $0.99 it's another inexpensive entertainment that will help kill an hour or two.

Who could forget Missile Command? It was the only game in the arcade that used a trackball when we were kids!  Missile Defender is the modern touchscreen rendition of it.  Personally, I find touching where you want your missiles to go is more fun than using a trackball (and definitely a mouse or joystick). Heck, it even supports multi-touch! (Although only two simultaneous touches as far as I could see.)If you are new to this game, its 3rd screenshot pretty much explains everything.  At the bottom you have your buildings (5 visually but they count as 12) & trees, which you have to protect them from enemy missiles & nukes dropped from the sky. (The UFOs aren't threats in themselves but they drop missiles too.)  Enemy attacks come in rounds (nights) between which you can take a breather and perform repairs & upgrades. You start off with a fixed number of repair points, and you earn more from completing each round, and you use them to repair damaged buildings & trees, or upgrade your missiles.  You can also get 50 repair points by (agreeing to but not necessarily) rating this game. I was prompted once after Night 11, so it was not too annoying.Trust me when I say you should upgrade your missiles as early as your repair points allow. The enemy's weapons will become increasingly faster, so you need all the upgrades.  There are 4 types of upgrades: increase the explosive area, missile capacity, duration of explosion, and missile speed.  Start off by upgrading each & every type, then gradually concentrate on those more suited to your needs.  They cost 15 repair points each initially, increasing with each level, until the maximum level 6 which would cost you 115-120 each.  While you might find yourself running out of missiles (which cannot be replenished during a round) at level 1, it's likely you have more than enough once you reached level 4-5; but I advise maxing out the other 3 upgrade types.The game, or rather the campaign, only ends when everything has been destroyed, although there is the option to start a new game (campaign) from the main menu. This game exits cleanly, and remembers your unfinished campaign.  All the upgrades you've made, and all the repair points you have accumulated during a campaign, however, gets reset when you start a new campaign.  That sucks, and you can see why the developer designed it that way because this game has In-App Purchase for repair points ($0.99 for 200 points & $2.99 for 800 points)! This is the chief reason why I am deducting a star from its rating.This game also asks for the Internet permission, and do uses it behind your back. However, it seems the website it's trying to reach is no longer operational LOL. It also has a slew of analytics, ads, and payment components, but they don't seem to be active and could possibly be just leftovers from the free version.  All in all, I don't see anything to be of major concern here except for the IAP.  To be absolutely safe, just play the game offline & disable IAP in your Appstore settings.[Addendum]After Night 30 the enemy fire comes thick & fast and, even after maxing out your missile upgrades, it's pretty much down to your reflexes & strategy (e.g. spraying a "shield" across the top of your buildings) to see how long you last. I've survived 40 Nights & I've only got average reflexes. And of course I didn't buy any repair points. A new game starts from the beginning when enemy fire is tame, so you've got time to accumulate & use points, just like how your ship in a shooter game picks up upgrades which won't carry over to a new game; it would be nice if they did, but not really essential. My advice is: instead of relying on whimsical & partial reviews from certain "Top Reviewers", always test out a FAOTD yourself! (Unless it's said to be harmful & you don't know how to protect yourself.)

The Kâ€™3 is a great drive thatâ€™s been working well for me to use with my Android phone and tablet.DESIGNThe drive has a nice metallic design and is very slim. Itâ€™s definitely unobtrusive when plugged into a computer. While not as small as the PK Paris Kâ€™1, it isnâ€™t much bigger. It has a brushed metal look to it, and definitely feels durable and of high quality. One one end is the USB 3.0 port, and on the other end is a micro USB connector. There is a cap that covers the micro USB connector, along with a string that goes through both the flash drive and cap, so that the cap wonâ€™t be misplaced when the micro USB connector is used. The USB 3.0 end has a slim profile without a â€œbodyâ€, so it is just the connector that makes up the drive.SPEEDTransfers speeds on this flash drive were quite fast. In my tests, I got an average of 117 MB/s for read, and 35 MB/s for write on USB 3.0 ports in a MacBook Pro. Itâ€™s a very fast drive that lives up to its claims. Note that if you use this with a USB 2.0 port, your speeds will be limited by that port, so you wonâ€™t get these results.USAGEI use the Kâ€™3 mainly to transfer files between my Android tablet and phone from my computer. Itâ€™s especially useful in my school and work where the Internet is spotty, so I cannot always rely on that to transfer my files. Luckily, with this drive, Iâ€™m always prepared.Overall, I have really enjoyed using this PK Paris drive. Itâ€™s been working great for me and I highly recommend it.

This is an EXTREMELY small drive Iâ€™ve been using for about 1 and a half years; itâ€™s been working great for me and has lasted extremely well.DESIGNThe best part of this drive is how small it is. Itâ€™s the type of drive you can leave plugged into your computerâ€™s USB port at all times, if need be. Itâ€™s the same size as those â€œnanoâ€ wireless adapters for wireless keyboards and mice. Itâ€™s so unobtrusive that Iâ€™ve come to not even notice it in my computer.Another thing I love about the design is that it matches my MacBook Proâ€™s finish perfectly. See the picture Iâ€™m attaching to this review for how the drive looks when plugged in. This is definitely what distinguishes it from other drives on the market.SPEEDTransfers speeds on this flash drive were comparable to what PK Paris advertises. In my tests, I got an average of 125 MB/s for read, and 56 MB/s for write on USB 3.0 ports in a MacBook Pro. Itâ€™s a very fast drive that lives up to its claims. Note that if you use this with a USB 2.0 port, your speeds will be limited by that port, so you wonâ€™t get these results.USAGEI use this drive (64GB size) to expand the storage on my computer. I can move larger files over to it when I need to make space on the hard drive in my computer, and if I ever need to transfer files to a friendâ€™s computer, I can do so very quickly because the drive is already in my computer. I see these as the best uses and features of this tiny drive, at least for me.If I ever need to unplug this drive, it comes with a small lanyard I can put through a hole on the drive itself and attach to a keychain. This is definitely something that can be easily misplaced due to the small size.Overall, I have really enjoyed using this PK Paris drive. Itâ€™s been working great for me to expand the storage on my MacBook Pro for the past year and a half, and it has a design I absolutely love. I highly recommend it if you are looking for such a flash drive.

This Kâ€™lip USB drive is a great drive with a unique design and features that make it one I love to use.DESIGN/USAGEThe Kâ€™lip has a name which matches its function; it has a carabiner clip built in to the drive that makes for easy attachment to a keychain. I sometimes even attach it to my belt buckle. It is indeed waterproof, and in my tests I was able to dunk it in a bowl of water and still use it afterwards. Of course, the practical application of this is if the drive gets wet in the rain, or falls into a puddle, or other similar situations. I find this a very useful feature especially for a drive that you plan to keep on a keychain. Itâ€™s also solidly built - the drive feels very solid during my use, and I donâ€™t feel that it will break or get damaged in any way, even when I toss it on my keychain with all my keys.Keep in mind that because of the carabiner clip, the drive is a little larger and will stick out quite a bit in a computer. However, I personally donâ€™t find this an issue; I like the fact that it has the clip so much that it doesnâ€™t matter to me.SPEEDTransfers speeds on this flash drive were quite fast. In my tests, I got an average of 132 MB/s for read, and 58 MB/s for write on USB 3.0 ports in a MacBook Pro. Itâ€™s a very fast drive that lives up to its claims. Note that if you use this with a USB 2.0 port, your speeds will be limited by that port, so you wonâ€™t get these results.Overall, I really like this drive, and I highly recommend it if you are looking for an easy to use and solidly built drive.

When it comes to Apple Watch docks, thereâ€™s tons on the market. The bottom line: The Basecamp Dock has a beautiful design and is solidly built, but takes some time to set up.WHATâ€™S IN THE BOX?Basecamp dock3 different sized silicon pads2 white â€œanchorsâ€ - plastic nutsAC wall adapterI received a pre-production unit, and the company informed me that the only differences between my unit and those that will be commercially sold are:silver finish on exterior will be more polishedThe nightlight will be smoother and brighterMy initial impressions of the finish is that it looks like a very high quality product, even in my pre-production unit. I can only guess that it will improve with the final version. The silver matches my silver MacBook and my friendâ€™s silver iPhone, but I do wish that Basecamp was made in multiple colors - maybe a Space Grey, Gold, and Rose Gold to match the latest iPhone colors.INSTALLATION:I recommend following the detailed instructions iNZeyo Labs provided to install the cables in the dock. To install the cables inside the dock, you have to open up the bottom and place the excess cable inside. Unfortunately, this means unscrewing 4 screws on the bottom - sort of a hassle, and it does take time. I wish the bottom was snap-in, or removable without having to unscrew it. While many individuals with iPhones have multiple cables, most people with an Apple Watch have only one charging cable, so installing and removing the cable (if youâ€™re traveling, etc), would take some time and be an annoyance. It would have also been nice to include some extra screws, in case these are lost.The Apple watch magnetic connector stays secure and snug to the adhesive backing on the dock. The groove for the cable running down the dock also fits it quite snugly, which is nice. However, when you reach the poles on the inside of the dock I found that the regular size Apple Watch charging cable - 2 meters - leaves a lot of excess and has to be wrapped many times around the posts inside the dock. I was left with pushing some excess cable around the posts even after wrapping it many times. It did work and I was able to close it, but it just took some time.When installing the iPhone lightning cable, you can use one of two white â€œanchorsâ€ to hold the cable in place on the dock. The difference in the two anchors is the height that the connector protrudes out of the dock - a little higher is better for thicker cases. Any cable that has a lightning connector bigger than the Apple OEM cable will not work with these anchors, so make sure you use one of the original Apple cables that came with your iOS device, or purchase a 3rd party one with connectors this small. Here are two 3rd party cables that are as slim as the original Apple ones: [Apple MFI Certified] iXCC ® Lightning Cable 3ft (Three Feet) Element Series 8 pin to USB SYNC Cable Charger Cord for Apple iPhone 5 / 5s / 5c / 6 / 6 Plus /6s / 6s Plus, iPod 7, iPad Mini / mini 2/ mini 3, iPad 4 / iPad Air / iPad Air 2(Compatible with iOS 9) [White] or [Apple MFi Certified] Kash TechnologyTM (Lifetime Guarantee) 3ft iPhone 5 & 6 Charging Cable [Premier Series] Lightning Cable (Rapid Charge Technology) 8 pin to USB Sync Cable & Charger [Compatible with iOS 7 & 8] for Apple iPhone 5 / 5s / 5c / 6 / 6 Plus / iPod 7 / iPad Mini / Mini 2 / Mini 3 / iPad 4 / iPad Air / iPad Air 2 (4x 1m / 3.2ft Cord) (4 Pack) [Frustration-Free Packaging]The grooves for lighting cable are like a winding path or road on the inside of the dock, and I found it was a little difficult to place it in these grooves. I also found it necessary to pull the cable as tight as possible so that the lightning connector stays snug and does not move around when docking the phone. The posts for wrapping the lightning cable were better spaced than the Apple Watch cable posts, luckily.CONNECTIVITY:Both cables plug into the inside of the dock to two USB connectors. There is a 3rd USB connector on the exterior of the dock so as to have a free USB port to connect other peripherals. I really like that this was included on the Basecamp dock. After plugging in the AC wall adapter, I found that all the USB ports on the dock worked great to charge my iPhone, Apple Watch, and other USB peripherals at decent speeds.STABILITY:The dock stays still and doesnâ€™t slide around due to the rubber feet on the bottom, but when pulling my phone out of the dock, I have to hold down the dock to keep it from lifting up. Iâ€™ve seen this problem solved with microsuction on the bottom of other docks to keep them stuck to the surface. Itâ€™s a slight annoyance on the Basecamp dock, but certainly not a deal breaker.I found the dock can actually hold my iPad as well. While it isnâ€™t as stable as when my phone is docked, it certainly holds it properly. The charging speeds through the dock for my iPad were slower than charging it through the Apple OEM wall charger, but thatâ€™s expected considering this was meant to be an iPhone dock.NIGHT LIGHT:As I mentioned at the beginning, my pre-production unit came with a nightlight that will be slightly different than the final version. Straight from the company:â€œWe modified the nighlight to make it a lot better. It is an even light now rather than the style you see in the unit you have where you can see some of the individual lights underneath.  It looks much nicer and is what the final product will have.â€In addition, the final version is supposed to be brighter. I found it to be decently bright already in my version, and the dimmer function also worked quite well. However, it took a hard press to turn it on initially, which I can see being an issue if you are trying to control it while lying down in bed. Iâ€™m hoping they also fix this in the final version.Overall, I find this to be a well-designed dock, and apart from the annoyances with installation, I do recommend it. Itâ€™s a solidly built product and works great on my nightstand.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest & unbiased review.

This is an excellent case that protects my iPhone 6 quite well. It's slim, yet feels like it adds a decent amount of protection.It has a snug fit, which I personally like because I feel like my phone is more secure in this case than in other cases. Plus, it adds to the feel of its slim nature.Cutouts are properly placed for the camera, vibrate switch, and sleep wake button.The look of this case is one of high quality, and it certainly feels that way, too. The genuine leather is nice; just make sure it doesn't get wet.Overall, I really like this case, and I highly recommend it if you are looking for a slim, high quality case for your iPhone.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

Iâ€™ve watched my friends use the fitbit or similar devices for a while, so I was excited to try this product.The design is sleek, and the bracelet can easily be cut to size.  The instructions are written in small print, and do not fully describe the bluetooth pairing process.  It is much easier to follow if you combine both the instruction manual and the instructions in app.  First, I turned my device on.  It was still in the shipping mode, as described in the instruction manual, so I had to press and hold the button for about five seconds.  The display said â€œHello!â€ and showed 0 steps.  Then I downloaded the TransHealth app on my phone.  You can also use another bluetooth enabled device.  I set up an account on the app and entered in my height, weight, etc.  Then I clicked on the person symbol in the top left corner, and clicked on device.  I pressed and held the button on the bracelet for about six seconds, until the pairing symbol came on (shown in instruction manual).  From my phone, I clicked add device, and it detected the bracelet.  That was the most complex part of using the bracelet!After that, I just wear it, and periodically all the data the bracelet has collected transfers automatically to my phone.  To view different measures, you simply press the button to rotate between the views (including time).  I have found the results for my steps, calorie burning, and sleep patterns to be highly accurate.  I especially love tracking my sleep, as I never really realized how much I wake up every night.Each charge lasts about 8 days for me, and I like the usb charging design that is built in to the bracelet (no need for additional cords).  I did have to be careful to not to wear it while baking or brushing my teeth, as it will sometimes falsely judge movements as steps.Overall, the device is really well designed and is a cool addition to my fitness/health regime - set up was slightly complex as the steps were not laid out in the manual,  but after this hurdle Iâ€™ve loved it!I received this product as a sample in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

Pros:- Physical aspects/ergonomics: the cartridge fits snug into the machine, so no problems with that. Pros:- Physically, the cartridge fits perfectly into the machine- Prints have no streaks and the color (bl) is evenly printed out- Clean and crisp prints; there are no blotches of toner occupying random small regions of the paper (an issue I've had in the past with previous generic cartridges)- Packaging is good, not sloppy (which I've also seen in the past with previous generics). 7:30 Mins I've posted a better quality version of this video review on YouTube, because Amazon limits the size of the videos: http://youtu.be/KPX3ElpdbVwCheck out my video review for a rundown on how these headphones have been working for me. The bottom line: they provide excellent sound with great bass, and although the 3D surround effect sounds strange with music, it works well for movies and TV shows. Also, the battery life is amazing.With premium headphones such as these, you expect the packaging to look great when you first open it, and these headphones are no exception. The headphones are presented very nicely inside the box, and when you first open it, you'll see the instruction booklet in an envelope on the side, and the hard carrying case on the other side.The instructions are extremely detailed, and I highly recommend reading them, especially to understand how to turn on and off the 3D surround effect using the buttons on the headphones (this is what I refer to with the features that aren't too intuitive - more on this to follow).The hard case is well organized and everything easily accessible. Some might not like the fact that the headphones must be placed inside the case in a specific orientation due to the pre-set grooves, I personally like it because it ensures the headphones remain in one position and don't get jostled around while in the case. On the other half of the hard case you will find a mesh pouch that holds the microUSB and 3.5mm audio cables. The microUSB cable charges the headphones, and the 3.5mm audio cable allows the headphones to be used with non-Bluetooth devices and also if the headphones run out of battery.The headphones themselves look quite nice - I really like the red and black look of the model that I am reviewing. The red color pops and has a metallic glossy look to it. On the top is the UFO logo, and on the left ear cup you'll find the Bluedio logo. The right earcup features most of the controls, including a large multifunction button which lights up when the headphones are turned on, volume up/down buttons, and forward/back track buttons. The forward and back track buttons double to control the 3D surround effect, which I'll detail next.The 3D surround effect is an interesting feature. While I didn't have a good way of describing it in the video, I think the best way I can think of to describe it is that the highs and mids become crisp and clearer (think dialogue in movies and tv shows) and the bass appears to go into the background - that is to say, it gives a 3D appearance of a subwoofer present inside the headphones themselves placed behind the listener. Hopefully that gives a good idea of how it sounds, but feel free to ask me questions in the comments for clarification. The 3D surround effect is turned on by holding down the next track button, and is turned off by holding down the previous track button. Whenever this feature is toggled, the sound fades away for a brief second and you will hear a short tone to indicate this.The headphones are quite comfortable, and as a student, i found no issues with using them for 8-10 hours a day while studying in the library. Being wireless headphones, I often found myself leaving them on for long periods and forgetting they were there. They don't look that large on my head either, and fit very well. Note that these are over the ear style, so these surround the ears rather than push directly on them.Bluetooth pairing was quick and simple, and the headphones paired easily with my computer, iPad, and iPhone. I was able to use these at a 30-foot range maximum, which I found useful when I was sitting on my couch and watching TV and using these headphones for audio from the TV.Audio quality - excellent. These headphones sound like the price tag they come with, with clear highs and mids and bass that packs a punch. It is bass heavy, so keep that in mind if that's a specific thing you are or are not looking for. I found no distortion at higher volume levels. I recommend burning in these headphones for 30-40 hours for even better sound.Battery life - these headphones took 2.5 hours to charge, which is quite fast compared to other Bluetooth headphones I have used. As I mention in the video, I can go 2 days or more without charging these headphones. They lasted about 20 hours for me in terms of audio play time. For the average user, you will not be disappointed by the battery life.Overall, these are an excellent pair of headphones and I highly recommend them.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

When it comes to laptop stands, there are many options out there. All will raise monitors or laptops to comfortable heights, but some have sleeker designs and offer more functionality than others. The Laptuk Pro is an extremely well-built monitor stand that features two shelves for storing a laptop, keyboard, and other peripherals. In this review Iâ€™ll highlight my experience with it for the past few weeks. The bottom line - itâ€™s my new favorite monitor stand.DESIGN:This stand is quite solid - itâ€™s heavier than you would expect, which I personally like, because it can hold a lot of weight as a result (35 lbs according to Macessity). The aluminum gives it a sleek look that matches Appleâ€™s products decently well. Itâ€™s not a perfect color match to Appleâ€™s aluminum color, but itâ€™s close enough that you wonâ€™t really notice the difference (see the picture comparing it to my MacBook Proâ€™s color). On the front are the two shelves for storing equipment. The sides feature openings to allow for connecting cables, etc, when a laptop is docked there. The left side also features the 4 port USB 3.0 hub on the lower shelf. The back of the stand has a notch thatâ€™s about an inch inside of the extent of the rest of the stand. This notch functions to keep cables coming down from the monitor in an organized fashion. The bottom of the stand has four plastic â€œfeetâ€ which wrap around the edges of the stand and protect the desk surface from metal contact. I do think that Macessity put a lot of thought into designing the Laptuk Pro, and it functions quite well for the goals in mind.USB HUB:The 4 port USB 3.0 hub plugs in via an included USB 3.0 Type A to USB 3.0 Micro B cable. There is also a power adapter for the hub, which helps if the hub is filled with multiple devices that require a lot of power. Speeds were quite good, and matched what I get through my MacBook Pro with USB 3.0 ports. I personally like that the hub is on the side because it keeps my cables and other USB peripherals out of the way, and most importantly, out of sight.OTHER THOUGHTS:Hereâ€™s how I use the stand in my setup. I have my 22â€ Acer monitor on top, my MacBook Pro on the upper shelf, and my Satechi Bluetooth Smart Keyboard on the bottom shelf. The two sides, being open, allows me access to all my ports as well as my CD drive. On the top of the stand, I can also place things like my Logitech Bluetooth Mouse and other accessories or decorative items.I find the stand extremely sturdy and functional. I recommend this if you are looking to elevate your monitor and store your laptop, keyboard, and other peripherals underneath.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

It also comes with a lifetime warranty.Itâ€™s a great microSD card and I highly recommend it.I received the 32GB version of the card as a sample in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

The Silicon Power Slim S60 Solid State Drive is a great drive to upgrade any computer. I had the pleasure of upgrading my MacBook Pro with this drive. My goal is to write this review to better inform those who are looking to upgrade their Macs to a faster system with a solid state drive.The driveâ€™s appearance is very sleek, and is one of the slimmer ones out there at 7mm. It is also lighter than other SSD drives out there at  Installing it was relatively simple on my 13â€ MBP. I simply opened up the bottom case of the computer, removed the old hard drive, transferred 4 pegs to the new SSD, and placed it back in. I then installed OS X 10.10.4 Yosemite as a clean install on this drive.In terms of the performance the average consumer will notice with this drive, Iâ€™m extremely impressed. My computer boot time, from cold start to usable, went from around 3 minutes and 30 seconds to less than 30. All my apps and programs load up almost instantaneously. My computer feels brand new. Programs that have typically slowed down my computer, like iMovie or iPhoto run smoothly with no hiccups on this drive. Also, a big plus is that my computer stays relatively cooler with this drive in place.Speed Tests:Silicon Power advertises the read/write speeds of this drive at 550 MB/s and 500 MB/s at its max, respectively. Itâ€™s important to note that real-world tests wonâ€™t typically come close to these maximum values for ANY drive. In my tests, real-world speeds were quite fast, with sequential read coming in at around 465 MB/s and write at 402 MB/s. For the average consumer simply looking to upgrade their computer, these speeds are excellent and will definitely do the job.It also supports TRIM, which is now supported in Mac OS X 10.10.4. It can be enabled through a Terminal command line, and you can find this through a simple google search. I found after enabling TRIM, the drive seemed snappier upon boot up. TRIM will also help in the long term with keeping the drive just as fast - I will update my review if I notice any changes after a few months of use.I highly recommend the S60, and from reading other reviews, Iâ€™m sure you will not be disappointed in the long term, either.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This 10 port USB Hub is perfect for anyone who owns a lot of USB peripherals, wants some stand alone charging ports, and likes Apple-like aesthetics.
