Iâ€™m someone who falls under all of these categories, and Iâ€™m happy to say the Satechi hub meets all these qualifications.In one hub, you get 7 USB ports (hopefully plenty for plugging in USB devices into your computer), and 3 stand alone USB charging ports that can be used even when the hub isnâ€™t plugged into a computer. This is because the hub is powered. The hub power also ensures that any device plugged into the hub portion has enough power to be connected to the computer.The design of this hub matches the Apple wireless Mac keyboard quite nicely. The aluminum is nicely finished, and the blue LED indicating power to the hub stands out. It has some weight to it, which I personally like because it keeps the hub in place even with cables coming out of it. The ports are nicely spaced, and I had no troubles plugging in regular sized USB cables and normal sized flash drives in all the ports. Users might find some troubles if they have a really thick or big flash drive, but I havenâ€™t had an issue with any of the ones I own.For me, I use the hub to plug in multiple external hard drives with pictures and movies on them. I also use the hub as a quick way to charge my phone and tablet when I have them on my desk. One port is 2.1A, and works well for my iPad Air, charging it from dead to a full battery in about 4 hours. The other two ports are 1A, and charge my iPhone 5S from dead to full in about 2 hours. The ports can of course be used to charge any other devices capable of USB charging, too.Itâ€™s a great hub, and I highly recommend it.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

The Satechi Aluminum USB 3.0 HDD/SSD Dock looks great alongside Apple products with its aluminum finish and is very useful with the variety of ports it includes.The dock comes with a power cable, short USB cable (2ft), and instructions. I wish the wall power plug wasnâ€™t so large, but it is nice that it has a light on it to signal if there is power coming from the outlet.The aluminum look of this complements my MacBook nicely, and itâ€™s relatively light, too. I like that itâ€™s compact and doesnâ€™t take up a large footprint on my desk. The cover folds down to allow a 3.5â€ drive to be docked, itâ€™s spring loaded so you donâ€™t have to worry about replacing a cover to keep from dust getting in if a 2.5â€ drive is connected.I tested this dock with USB external drives, flash drives, SDHC cards, and both 2.5â€ and 3.5â€ hard drives and 2.5â€ solid state drives. In all cases, speeds seemed to be quite fast. The USB 3.0 and SD speeds were on par with what I get straight from my MacBook Pro. All the hard drives that I docked also had fast speeds, although they were slower than what I get if I were to connect the drives internally in my computer. This is just a limitation of the speed of USB 3.0, vs SATA III connections.Thereâ€™s a convenient on/off button at the back which is pushed in/out, so I can press it without having to turn the dock around to turn it off. A bright blue LED on the front signals when the dock is on and has power.Overall, I really like this dock, and I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for such a product.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This is a great Air mouse combo keyboard thatâ€™s been working great for me.WHATâ€™S IN THE BOX:Air Mouse C120microUSB cable for rechargingnano size 2.4 Ghz adapterI think itâ€™s a little misleading that in the product description, it says that it runs on â€œWiFiâ€. This mouse/keyboard does not connect to WiFi networks; rather, it is wireless in that it uses a nano size 2.4Ghz USB adapter to receive a signal on the computerâ€™s end. This is how most wireless mice and keyboards function nowadays.The misleading description aside, what I really like about this mouse is that itâ€™s plug and play, truly. I plugged this into my Windows 8.1 computer, and without having to download any drivers, I was up and running in a few minutes.The air mouse is quite accurate, and the top button on the mouse side controls when the gyroscope is on or off. By turning the gyroscope off, you can â€œresetâ€ what the mouse considers a center point, and from there, you can move up, down, left and right to move the mouse. Of course, the gyroscope on/off button is also useful when you switch over to the keyboard side.Speaking of the keyboard, it is small (considering the size of the device itself), but I found the keys responsive and easy to press. I do wish there was a windows button, but apart from that, all the buttons are present and work great.The Air Mouse is the size of a small remote, and looks quite sleek. Itâ€™s easy to hold, too. Charging it using the included microUSB cable was very easy, and took about 2 hours to charge to full when I initially received it. I havenâ€™t had to recharge it yet, so suffice to say the battery lasts a long time.Overall, I find this Air Mouse and keyboard a pleasure to use, and I highly recommend it.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

The Trace Pro has been working great for me for the past month. Iâ€™ve been using it whenever Iâ€™m getting ready to leave from a bar to make sure Iâ€™m safely underneath the limit. Iâ€™m male, and the Trace Pro is small enough that it fits well inside my pocket. Itâ€™s smaller than my iPhone.I like that the LED is bright enough to be read both during the day and at night. The mouthpiece was easy to install with the instructions, and I had no issues using it.This has been generally accurate as far as I can tell. To compare its accuracy, I used a BAC calculator website that has you input your gender, weight, number of drinks, and time elapsed, and outputs an estimated BAC level. The results of the Trace Pro were almost always equivalent to the website, and when it was off, it was off by at most 0.004. I can say with certainty that it is very reliable. When I say reliability, I mean how often I can count on it to give a reading, which has been upwards of 9 out of 10 times. Occasionally, I will get an error and will have to retry, but this is rare.I do wish this had a rechargeable battery rather than taking AAA, but it was nice for the company to include batteries. Iâ€™ve yet to replace the batteries, and Iâ€™m still at 3 full bars.Apart from the rechargeable battery, Iâ€™ve found this to be very useful, reliable, and accurate, and I definitely recommend it.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

These in-ear headphones offer well-balanced sound and come with lots of useful accessories.WHATâ€™S IN THE BOX:S0 In-Ear headphonesHard carrying caseShirt Clip1 set comply foam tips S-4006 sets regular silicone eartips (2 of each of small, medium, large)1 set silicone bi-flange eartips1 set silicone tri-flange eartipsInstruction ManualWarranty Card (a 12 month warranty is included with this product)IN-EAR FIT:The included Comply premium earphone tips provide the best fit in my experience, so I recommend using those. However, if you donâ€™t find these work best for you, there are 6 different pairs of silicone tips (in Small, Medium, and Large, 2x pairs of each), 1 pair of bi-flange eartips, and 1 pair of tri-flange eartips. I think itâ€™s safe to say that you will be able to find the right fit for you with these headphones, which is crucial when using in-ear headphones.After finding the right fit for me, I found no issues with comfort with these headphones. As a student, I often spend 5-6 hours at a time studying with music, and the Brainwavz S0 did not feel uncomfortable at all.SOUND QUALITY:Brainwavz describes the sound on their packaging as a â€œbalanced sound signature with each part of the sound spectrum represented accurate and clear.â€ I would say this is very much true of these headphones. The bass is not overpowering like I have seen with some other headphones, and highs and mids are crisp and clear. At higher volume levels, there is no distortion. I like using these to listen to rock and pop genres, as well as for movies and TV shows.OTHER NOTES:The headphones have a 51â€ flat-design cable, which is plenty of length for me. The flat design ensures no tangles or curling of the cord. The included carrying hard case is small and compact. Itâ€™s a little thick, but it fits all the tips and the headphones very neatly. Another cool thing Brainwavz included is a velcro cable wrap for the headphones. The cable wrap sticks to the inside of the case, so it stays in place even with the case open. I thought this was a nice touch.Overall, I really like the Brainwavz S0. While some, especially EDM listeners, might find a lack of bass response, I thought it was plenty, and added nicely to the balanced nature of the sound produced by the S0. I highly recommend these in-ear headphones.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

This humidifier is great on the go (I like using it in hotel rooms), in a smaller bedroom, or in an office or cubicle.The humidifier comes with a USB cable and 2 filters. Installing the filters was pretty easy, and it fit quite snugly over a regular 20 oz water bottle that I had lying around. Most disposable water bottles will work well with this, and in my tests, knocking over the bottle did not result in any water leaking out.It is super quiet; I honestly couldnâ€™t hear it at all unless I listened for it and sat less than a foot away from it. The mist that comes out is light and unobtrusive.It worked well for me in a 10x12 foot room, as well as at some hotel rooms Iâ€™ve stayed at recently. I could notice a difference in humidity levels in these rooms after having the humidifier on for some time, but in a larger room, it didnâ€™t seem to make much of a difference. Keep this information in mind if you are wondering if it will work in your size room.Overall, this portable humidifier is working great for me, and I highly recommend it.A sample was provided in exchanged for an honest and unbiased review.

This is a decent battery pack and charger thatâ€™s been working well for me.The battery pack has a rubber texture and features 2 USB ports that are â€œsmartâ€ ports, meaning they adapt to the device that is plugged in. A smartphone requires a different amount of power than a tablet for charging, and Sharkkâ€™s battery pack will adapt to this. What I really like is that the wall prong is built right into the battery pack. This makes recharging the pack, as well as using it as a wall charger extremely convenient.Essentially, all you need to bring along with this battery pack is a charging cable for your device. Re-charging the battery pack itself is built right in, so this pack has maximum portability. There is a single LED that changes colors based on the charge capacity of the pack (red=0-35%, green=35-75%, blue=75-100%). The LED is very unobtrusive and dim, which is good because it wonâ€™t be distracting, but bad because itâ€™s difficult to see, especially during the daytime.Shaking it requires a decent amount of force in practice, which I personally wasnâ€™t a fan of. It is advertised as â€œmotion activatedâ€ which was slightly misleading for me, because I thought this meant you would simply have to wave your hand past it to turn it on. On the contrary, you must move the battery pack itself in order to activate it.Recharging the pack from empty to full took about 2 hours, and with it, I was able to charge my iPad to about 60%, and my iPhone 2 full times. This is what I expect from a 5000 mAh battery pack.Overall, this has been working great for me. I really like that the wall prongs are built right in, and that it has 2 USB ports. Shaking to activate it is nifty, but gets a little annoying in practice. Apart from that, I highly recommend it.A sample was provided in exchanged for an honest and unbiased review.

This is a well-built coffee grinder thatâ€™s small, easy to use, and most importantly for me, easy to clean.This coffee grinder has got a slim shape, and is small and compact. Thereâ€™s a black top container that holds the whole beans to be grinded, and a bottom glass jar thatâ€™s clear and easy to visualize how much has been grinded already. The handle crank is silver, along with the locking screw.To add coffee beans, you have to unscrew the locking screw and remove the top lid. Itâ€™s slightly annoying to have to unscrew this each time, but Iâ€™ve gotten used to it. The handle crank is very easy to turn, and I also liked that the locking screw made it easy to adjust the coarseness of the coffee grounds.Cleanup is pretty easy with this. All the parts easily separate which makes it more efficient to wash and clean. The ceramic burrs are easy to clean, which Iâ€™ve found to be an issue with some other manual coffee grinders.Interestingly, Iâ€™ve also been using the coffee grinder to grind spices, and it works very well for that, too.Iâ€™ve been using this grinder as a multi-purpose tool, and itâ€™s been working great for me. I definitely recommend it. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

For me, easy to use and install network drives have been hit or miss. Theyâ€™re insanely useful, especially for someone like me who has lots of downloaded movies and tv shows stored on flash drives and hard drives. This Cable Matters wireless hard drive dock manages to do it quite well through the mobile apps and through the computer interface.Setup was relatively straightforward, and I found the directions easy to follow. One thing to note is that the network that pops up is differently named from what it says in the instruction manual (Wi-Fi Dock vs codetek-028e) - luckily I donâ€™t have too many WiFi networks around so it was easy to guess which one to choose from, but this might not be the case for someone who lives elsewhere.Streaming videos and music through my computer worked quite well in my tests. There was a slight loading time, but apart from that, playback was smooth and without stutter. Note: I used a Mac to test this.The mobile app MyAirDisk was easy enough to download and get started using, and I found it to be just as pleasant to use as the computer interface. Accessing files was easy on my iPad, and videos and music streamed very well.I can confirm the dock works for both 2.5 and 3.5 inch drives, as I had spares of both lying around. It also fit a 2.5 inch SSD I had, and that was nice.The direct network connection worked even faster than the wireless connection, as was expected, and the dock worked great as a wired dock through a USB connection. I find this handy to use when reformatting hard disks, which I do a few times a year.Overall, I highly recommend this wireless drive. Itâ€™s been working great for me for my purposes, and Iâ€™m sure it will for you, too. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.

This is a nifty product that has been working great for me, and was very easy to set up. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.Note, you should check that your house and internet connection match these requirements for the doorbell to work (courtesy of the Carolyn over at the friendly Skybell customer service):-- Do you have at least 1.5 mb per second upload speed at the doorbell site? If you're not sure, you can download the OOKLA Speedtest App (available on Android and iOS).If you donâ€™t have sufficient signal strength, youâ€™ll need to move your router closer to SkyBell or use a Wi-Fi range extender-- Do you have sufficient power at the doorbell site? SkyBell requires 10-36 VAC 10 VA. You can test this by using a volt meter and testing the leads at your front door. (Please note thatSkyBell will not work with a wireless doorbell chime.)-- Is your router compatible with the 2.4ghz wireless standard? SkyBell requires a 2.4 Ghz wireless router connection with its own SSID. SkyBell will not work on a 5 Ghz wireless standard at this time. If you have a dual-band router, you must segregate your wireless channels and connect SkyBell to the 2.4ghz channel.-- SkyBell also requires that N-only routers be set to b/g or b/g/n settings and not â€œN-Onlyâ€-- SkyBell is not compatible with Samsung phones sold by T-Mobile.As long as these requirements are met, you should find it works great.Setup was quite simple, and as outlined in the instruction manual, all I had to do was remove my doorbell and plug in the same wires to the Skybell unit. The included hardware, as other users mentioned, were difficult to use, and I ended up not using it, but your experience may vary.After installing it, syncing it to my existing network was also easy. Iâ€™m lucky that my router is just on the other wall of the doorbell, so the video feed came up very quickly on my device. Of course, loading times were a little quicker over WiFi versus 4G or LTE.While the video feed quality is mediocre, I found it was adequate enough to get a good picture of who or what is outside my front door.The notifications to my phone are quite quick; within 1 second of the doorbell being pressed, I got a notification on my phone. After 2 more seconds, the feed was loaded and I was able to see who was on the other side.I found Skybell particularly useful this past weekend when my family and I were on vacation, and I wanted to check if packages had been delivered to our front door. I simply pulled up the feed every few days, and I was able to see the entire front porch to check on this. As other reviewers have mentioned, the camera angle is decently wide, which is quite nice. I have a porch that is about 7 feet wide, and Iâ€™m able to see my entire porch in the view (my doorbell is approximately centered on the porch).Apart from the video feed quality, Iâ€™ve been having a great experience with this doorbell. I definitely recommend it for anyone looking to try one of the next greatest things that most importantly works great.

This is a well-made selfie stick that has an adjustable phone holder. It extends to about 38", and collapses to a compact 10" with the phone holder on the end.The phone holder itself is adjustable and fit my iPhone 5S, a friend's iPhone 6, as well as a 5" iRulu U2S Android phone quite well.Even at the full extended length, it stays relatively stable, which is something I've noticed to be an issue with some selfie sticks on the market.Overall, I definitely recommend it.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review. Thanks for reading!

This is a great desk mount clip for holding smartphones. I use it essentially as a "dock", and I mount it to my desk that is 1.5" thick. The mount clip has foam on either side, and doesn't damage my desk as a result. You should be careful, however, that you make sure the foam pieces are contacting any surface that you attach it to, rather than another portion of the clip.The gooseneck takes some force to adjust, which I personally like because it means it stays in place when it needs to. When I use my phone with this, the mount doesn't move around and stays firm. It is very flexible if you need to adjust it, and I was able to use it in many different orientations and positions over my desk.The phone holder portion is another clip which has rubber on either side. It doesn't damage the phone as a result, and it also holds it in place quite well. My iPhone 5S fit well inside here, as well as a 5" phone that I tried. It seems to hold a lot of different sizes, and should work well for most people's phones. Note that tablets do not fit inside this mount.I do wish the mount clip expanded a little more to be able to acommodate thicker pieces. My bed, which is 5" thick, was not able to work with this phone holder.Overall, this functions well, and I recommend it. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.

4:47 Mins This is a great 4G enabled unlocked Android smartphone by iRulu. Check out my video review for a full rundown of how this phone works. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.DESIGN:This 5" phone has a gorgeous 1280x720 display, which is astounding for a budget smartphone. It has a gold casing with the lock button and volume rocker buttons located on the right side. It's slim and has a great feel to it, even with it's larger 5" size. The display runs edge to edge with a slim gold bezel surrounding it. I really like the look of this phone.HARDWARE:Removing the gold cover reveals the insides of the phone, with the removable battery taking up most of the space. This phone will take a micro SIM card along with a microSD card for expanding the space (up to 32 additional GB, according to iRulu).SOFTWARE/USAGE:On board, this Android 4.4.2 smartphone comes with 16GB of space, with 12GB of usable space. It's very snappy due to the Qualcomm quad-core processor inside, and I had no issues with lag or crashes while using this phone.4G speeds on AT&T are great, and call quality was good, too. I get good AT&T service in Chicago, and users' experience might vary depending on their area's cell signal. What I can say for certain, though, is that the iRulu U2S will not be the limiting factor in cell service strength.Callers mentioned that I sounded clear and easy to understand in both speakerphone and regular mode. The speakerphone projects quite loudly, and I found it pleasant to use.As I mentioned before, the display on this device is quite nice. The screen is clear, and texts and colors pop. While it won't compare to a retina display, or a display on a Samsung Galaxy phone, it certainly is tough to beat at this price point for an unlocked smartphone.The camera's decent on this device; The back-facing camera takes pictures at 13MP, and it works really well as a regular smartphone camera. The front facing camera is rated at 5MP, and worked well in my tests for video conferencing, etc.The battery takes about 3 hours to charge fully from dead, and it lasted me on average 11-13 hours a day. In other words, full day battery life! This was with moderate usage and at 50% brightness. When I used it for heavier processing tasks such as playing games or watching videos, I got around 9 hours.I hope you enjoy the review, and I apologize for my terrible skills at Temple Run 2! Hopefully the video gives you a good idea of how this phone works. I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for an unlocked Android smartphone; it's been working great for me.

This is a review of the 6ft MFI certified cable in black. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.In testing lightning cables, I always test 4 things:--MFI certification (does it actually work and not give that annoying error message?)--Durability--Charging Speed--Sync capabilityBut before I get into these categories, Iâ€™d like to highlight a unique feature of this cable; that being the velcro strap. With a 6ft long cable, management is crucial. Luckily, Macally has built this management right into their cable, with a velcro strap that hangs off of the USB connector end. It holds strongly, and makes tidying up this cable a breeze.MFI CERTIFICATIONThis cable is indeed MFI certified. In testing this with both an iPhone 5S and iPad Air, I found no issues or error messages displayed when plugging it in. I tested by plugging it in 20-30 times per device to ensure this wasnâ€™t just a one time thing.DURABILITYI have found this cable is very durable. In my tests, I slightly bent the cable with my hands to test the connector ends durability, especially at the points where the cable cord begins, and I found it held up well. Next, I kept the cable heads bent with some force for about 24 hours with a book to simulate the cable being bent for long periods of time in a bag or purse, and it survived! It didnâ€™t even show any marks to show it was bent, and in a few hours, it was back to its original shape.CHARGING SPEEDI compared this to the OEM lightning cable made by Apple, and I found no differences in charging speed with this one versus Appleâ€™s official one. It charges just as fast in both a computer USB port as well as using the Apple wall charger adapter.SYNC CAPABILITYI synced both my iPad and iPhone on my computer using this cable, and overall, it worked quite well. My computer recognized the devices right away, and transferred content over relatively quickly when compared with the Apple official cable.Overall, this is a great cable that I highly recommend, especially if you are looking for a longer cable that has built-in cable management to keep it neat when not in use. This is a great buy.

The Ivation Boomering Bluetooth Speaker is a high fidelity bluetooth speaker with some neat features. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.WHATâ€™S IN THE BOX:Boomering speakerAux cablemicroUSB charging cableinstruction bookletThe speaker has a great, rugged design that is â€œsplash proofâ€. I indeed did get some water on the device (to test this), and it continued to work fine. I wouldnâ€™t recommend using this in the shower, as it is not waterproof, but itâ€™s nice that it has some water resistance. The top panel has NFC pairing (which I was not able to test), a play/pause/call button, volume up down, a power button, and a â€œmodeâ€ button, to switch between bluetooth, aux, and microSD mode. On the right side is a hanging loop for going around a backpack, loop, etc. Opening up the right side reveals a silicone panel that houses a USB port (for using the speaker as a battery pack), an aux port, a microUSB port (for charging), and a microSD card slot.Bluetooth pairing was quick and easy, and I got about 20 feet of range in my tests before it began to cut out. The sound quality over bluetooth was great. I found bass to be present and slightly heavy, with mids and highs crisp and clear. Some users might like the extra bass with this speaker, while others might not; it depends on personal preference.The microSD card slot works great for playing MP3 files loaded onto a card. I find this useful if I want a set playlist to play through the speaker while using my phone for other tasks. The Aux connection also worked well to play music with no issues.Charging this device took about 2 hours from a dead battery. Whatâ€™s neat is that this speaker can be used to charge other devices; it can act as a battery pack. It was able to charge my iPhone 5S about 1.5 times before the battery on it died.Overall, this is a well designed speaker with decent sound, and combined with the microSD and power bank features, I definitely recommend this product.

The Ivation IVA400 is a great waterproof shower speaker with awesome sound. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.This speaker has a cool design. Thereâ€™s a hook at the top for hanging on the shower head, which makes it very easy to put in the shower. The front two speaker grills give a glimpse at the actual speakers inside, which I found to be a nice touch. There are controls for power, volume up/down, play/pause, previous track, next track, and start/end call.Bluetooth pairing was quick and easy using this speaker. Bluetooth range was about 30 feet in my tests, and quality was clear in both music and phone calls. Callers also mentioned that they could hear me clearly through the speaker, mentioning that the phone call sounded like a normal speakerphone through my iPhone.Sound quality through this speaker was astounding for a waterproof speaker. I was impressed by the bass, treble, and mids, too. The speaker did not distort at higher volume levels, and gets quite loud. I found it was enough to use in the shower with the water running, as well as in a room with about 5 or 10 friends. I am truly impressed by the sound through this speaker, and it makes it a pleasure to use.I also did a waterproof test by putting it in a sink of water while music was playing. While the sound became muffled (through water), the speaker continued to play music. I use it all the time in the shower without fear of water (or soap) getting on or into the speaker. If the front speaker grill becomes filled with water droplets, it can muffle the sound coming through. To fix this, I simply use a towel or washcloth to dab the water out of the grill, and then it is good to go. (Note: the muffled sound is simply due to the water obstructing the sound - it does not affect the speaker itself).Battery life at about 50% volume level was about 8 hours in my test. Charging this speaker can be done through the microUSB port on the back using the included cable. Charging the speaker from a depleted battery to full took about 3 hours. The back port has a silicone covering to prevent water from getting near the ports. Also present is a USB port for charging devices through the back of the speaker - i.e. the speaker can act as a battery pack.Iâ€™ve been using this speaker for the past few weeks, mostly in the shower, and I love it. The sound quality is great, Bluetooth has awesome range, and the speaker is indeed waterproof. I highly recommend this speaker to anyone looking for a waterproof speaker that does not disappoint.

With the Bluetooth Button Series, Satechi has created a set of products that are convenient to use, and in turn, make smartphones more convenient to use.WHATâ€™S IN THE BOX:Bluetooth Button (either media button, home button, or shutter button)CR2016 batterybutton mount (for steering wheel, bike, or selfie stick)audio port keychain attachment3M sticker (for a more permanent placement of the buttons)DESIGN:These buttons have a sleek look, and being black, match the interior of many cars. If you choose to hang them from a keychain, they are small and easy to carry around. The back is a brushed metal, while the front has a flat look and feel to it. The buttons offer great tactile feedback when depressing them. The included steering wheel (or bike) mounts are easy to install, and look almost like rings that have a space for the bluetooth button on top. My car is a Honda Fit (09), and the buttons fit well on my steering wheel. On the side is a hole for looping the keychain attachment, and there is also a depressed reset button for enabling bluetooth pairing.The media button has 5 buttons in one - play/pause in the center, volume up (up), volume down (down), previous track (left), and next track (right). The shutter button and home button each have a single button on their panel.USAGE:The included CR2016 battery is said to have a battery life of 2 years, and while I cannot attest to that, i can say that so far, the battery works great. To save battery life, the buttons do go to sleep after a period of inactivity (10-15 minutes in my tests).Bluetooth pairing is done by resetting the button. There is a small reset button which is depressed, so it requires the use of some pointed object (such as a pen tip). After pressing it in, the buttonâ€™s LED light flashed, indicating it was in pairing mode. Pairing was as simple as finding the listing under my phoneâ€™s bluetooth settings and connecting. After this initial pairing, all I had to do to repair was wake up the button by pressing it once, and it instantly connected to my phone.MEDIA BUTTON:The media button is by far my favorite, and probably will be for many users. It comes in handy for converting my car to have steering wheel-mounted controls, which is something I have always desired. I find that the buttons are easy to depress, but in the winter time, with gloves on, it is difficult to do anything but press the center in, which plays and pauses the music. Hitting up, down, left, or right are difficult with gloves, due to the small size of the button, but are easy to press using just fingers. The bluetooth connection is instantaneous, so changing the track or playing the music happens almost simultaneously to the button press.HOME BUTTON:The home button is useful for activating Siri on an iPhone. It functions exactly as the home button on an iPhone does, so holding it down for a few seconds activates Siri. Overall, it works great for this purpose.SHUTTER BUTTON:The shutter button is useful for taking selfies or other pictures using a smartphone camera. I found I was also able to place it on a selfie stick using the included mount adapter, which made my selfie stick wireless. Another use is for recording videos of oneâ€™s self using the shutter button as a remote. It also works just as well as the other buttons in taking the snapshot instantaneously.Also included was a 3M sticker for making a more permanent placement of each of the buttons. It was easy to apply and stuck quite well to my carâ€™s dash. Note that it is difficult to remove, and should be used as a more permanent option.Overall, I have to say Iâ€™m very impressed with the Bluetooth Button Series by Satechi. They are a series of buttons that work very well when connected to my smartphone, and I definitely recommend them to anyone who might have a use for such a bluetooth device.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.

With the Air-Fi Touch, MEElectronics set out to create a wireless headset that was elegant, offered high fidelity sound, and had innovative controls. In this review, Iâ€™ll highlight my experience with this pair of headphones. Overall, I have to say Iâ€™m very impressed.WHATâ€™S IN THE BOX:Air-Fi Stereo Bluetooth Wireless HeadphonesMicro-USB charging cableHard shell protective carrying casestereo audio cable (for wired use of the headphones)User ManualDESIGN:These are a very elegant-looking pair of headphones, and itâ€™s definitely something to highlight. The glossy black finish is accented by a gold color, which gives these headphones a look of sophistication. On the top is the MEElectronics logo, and on the inside of left earcup is the Air-Fi portion of the logo. The left earcup has the main touch panel, a multifunction button, and a stereo input jack for wired use of the headphones. The multifunction button can turn the headphones on/off, play/pause, and answer/end phone calls. Also on the left earcup is the microphone for making calls. The right earcup has the microUSB charging connector, as well as an indicator light.USE:After charging the headphones fully, I used them for the first time. The Multifunction button turns them on. For initial pairing, or for pairing a different device, I kept holding down the multifunction button past the initial â€œonâ€ tone, until I reached a second tone, which indicated it was ready for pairing. After finding the listing on my phone, I was connected in seconds. Bluetooth range was about 30 feet in my tests, which is on par with other headphones in a similar price range.I was initially skeptical of the touch panel, but in practice, it worked quite well. A summary of the functions:Swipe up - Volume UpSwipe down - Volume DownSwipe right/forward - Next TrackSwipe left/backward - Previous TrackIt took some getting used to, but after adapting, I found it very convenient to use. It worked quite well with the bluetooth functionality. A small note: it doesnâ€™t work if the headphones are used in wired mode.Wireless headphones are meant to be worn for long period of times, so comfort is a key feature. The Air-Fi Touch do pretty well; I was able to wear the headphones for about 4 hours before they started to hurt my ears. If you study all day, or wear headphones at work, you might find you need to take these off after a period of 3-5 hours. Apart from that, though, they feel very comfortable. The on-ear design is not too tight and the earcups are made of a very soft material. They are also adjustable on both sides, as is the case with all on-ear headphones.Charging the headphones is done through the included micro USB cable (a universal cable type), and is indicated by a red light which shuts off once fully charged. Charging took about 3 hours in my daily tests with plugging the included microUSB cable into my computer. A huge plus of these headphones is the advertised full day, or 24 hour, battery life. I was blown away in my tests, with a whopping 28 hours, and I can definitely say that MEElectronics made good on their claim. This is more than lots of other bluetooth headphones Iâ€™ve tested, and I was very impressed. If the headphones do happen to die, the included stereo cable can be plugged in to use the headphones in wired mode. Wired mode does have its limitations - you canâ€™t use the microphone or the touch panel.I found phone calls to be more of a novelty feature than anything else with these headphones. Calls sounded clear on my end through the headphones, but callers mentioned that I sounded distant and on speakerphone when using the built-in speaker of these headphones.SOUND:Sound quality on these is very balanced. The bass is a medium level, but is definitely present. Highs and mids are crisp. If anyone is looking for bass-heavy headphones, these probably arenâ€™t the ones. I am a big fan of a balanced sound profile, so I like how these sound, but as with many things, sound quality is often a personal preference. One thing I really like about these headphones is that thereâ€™s very very minimal sound leakage (only present at higher volume levels), and they do a decent job at blocking out noise. While they are not noise-cancelling, the nature of the earcups is such that it blocks out some ambient noise.The sound I perceived from wireless mode vs wired mode was about equal. In other words, you wonâ€™t find a decrease in sound quality if the battery dies and youâ€™re forced to use them in wired mode.ACCESSORIES:These headphones come with a hard shell carrying case, which fits the microUSB and stereo cables, too. The headphones fold up compact and are easy to transport.SUMMARY:Overall, these headphones are well-designed, sound great, and offer amazing battery life. While the sound profile and comfort may not work for all users, I think for most, it will exceed expectations. I give these a very strong recommendation.A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.

This is a review of the TT-DL01 model in Piano Black. This is a stylish looking lamp with a sleek glossy black finish. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.WHATâ€™S IN THE BOX:- Lamp head plus flexible support beam - the arm of the lamp- Metal base - heavier to keep the lamp weighed down- AC power adapter- user manualThis is one of the slimmest boxes Iâ€™ve seen for LED desk lamps. This is useful if someone needs to transport it later on. Everything is packaged very neatly and in an organized way.The lamp has a nice stylistic design, and looks very sleek when set up. As other reviewers have mentioned, the base is relatively small, and wonâ€™t take up much desk space. In my case, I use it on my nightstand, where space is crucial.Another great addition to the lamp is a USB input port near the base. This is useful if using the lamp at a desk to quickly charge a phone or tablet, or even at the bedside to charge your phone at night. I personally use it for the latter; it works well for me to charge my phone at night.The lamp has four brightness settings, and is touch-controlled. The touch control worked very well, and I found that there was enough of a difference between the three brightness settings for me to use all of them for different tasks. I used the brightest when doing work (Reading Mode), the second brightest for reading (Study Mode), the third brightest for reading at night (Relax Mode), and the least brightest for right before bed (Sleep Mode). Within each of these brightness main settings, you can adjust the individual brightness of each one using the minus and plus buttons. A 1 hour sleep timer is also present on this lamp, which I use in Sleep Mode to shut off automatically while I am trying to fall asleep.In summary, this is a well-designed lamp with features such as a USB input port for quick access to charge a phone, tablet, or other device. I highly recommend it!

The Omars 4ft white Lightning Cable is MFI certified and charges well, albeit with larger connectors. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.This is a great cable made by the company Omars. Iâ€™d like to highlight the durability, charging capability, syncing capability, and MFI certification in this review.The cable is quite durable. The cable showed no fraying or permanent marks from bending it after a week of use. During my testing, I put the cable through more â€œextremeâ€ measures by bending it with considerable force, and Iâ€™m happy to say this cable held up well. I had no qualms with tossing this in the bottom of my bag; Iâ€™m confident that with time, itâ€™ll continue to hold up to normal wear and tear.This cable charges both my iPad and iPhone quite well, with charging speeds equivalent to what I get with the original Apple cable. Of course, charging speed will vary depending on what you are charging through (wall adapter versus computer USB port, for example). Syncing capability also worked well - I was able to sync music and movies using this cable to both my iPad and iPhone.This cable is MFI certified, and after testing it with 5 iOS devices, I am comfortable with saying that Iâ€™ve verified this. Not once did I get the error messages you typically see with cables that are â€œpretendingâ€ to be MFI certified.My only wish with this cable is that the connector ends were slightly narrower. Theyâ€™re definitely thicker than the original Apple cable, which might make it tough to plug into devices with thicker cases.I do like that this cable is 4ft long, which makes it 1ft longer than the OEM Apple cable. This extra length helps me in a lot of situations, especially when I use it to charge my phone on my desk.Overall, this is a solid cable that charges well and is MFI certified. I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for an extra lightning cable!

As YA fare goes, this book's plot lifts it to 5 stars. It was written in 1962, apparently, and the new translation from the Dutch is coming on 25 August of 2015.It's the story of a squire (Tiuri) on the eve of becoming a knight who does NOT become a knight because he makes the fateful decision to answer a call for help. One thing leads to another when you answer calls for help in knightly times, and before long, this 16-year-old kid is on a quest with unseen (and eventually seen) enemies all around him (but with unexpected friends as well).It's sweet, actually. So "old school" it will remind you of the type of book about knighthood you could not put down as a kid. You know. Books by Howard Pyle, maybe, illustrated by N. C. Wyeth. It all brings back a simpler world of good and evil, don't you know. An antidote to the gray confusions in our time, it is, and the descriptions aren't bad, either. But the plot's the thing. Honest.Memory Lane, anyone? I suspect young reluctant readers and fans of all things medieval will love this

In this book, you will learn, in the first 50 pages or so, how your mind works. Specifically, the authors take some familiar learning styles -- visual, auditory, and kinesthetic -- and look for the various patterns they can be placed in to match your style. Thus you could be a VAK Pattern (Visual, Auditory, Kinesthetic or an AVK Pattern (Auditory, Visual, and Kinesthetic), etc.Once you self-test, there's a description and, if that's you, then you know how you work as a piece in the puzzle of collaboration (at work, at school, or wherever). Yes, the descriptions are a bit like reading your Zodiac or maybe your Briggs and Myers results (remember them?). Now you're ready for the book's sections: Thinking About Thinking (sounds like metacognition to me), developing your thinking talents so that they work together with others', practicing inquiry, working with your own mindset (and others'), and so forth.Of course this book works best if all members of any given group play its game and "discover" themselves and how they can get the most of their own style and the styles of those around them. That might be tricky, unless it's one of those "group" days businesses run now and again. Lots of quotes from various gurus and like-minded books in this field, so if this is your kind of stuff, you should eat it up. If not, forget the collaboration and know thyself by passing.

We live in a new age of weird diseases and symptoms -- many traveling under the "auto-immune" banner. People by the droves go to their primary care doctors and complain of stomach and digestive ailments (bloating, food allergies, abdominal pain), light-headedness, fatigue, skin rashes, eczema, rosacea, and worse. Their doctors, in turn, follow the protocols of their training and order up standard tests in search of something physical. The tests come back negative. Now doc is beginning to wonder if he has a hypochondriac on his hands, and the patients either persist or resign themselves to pain and misery, becoming depressed as symptoms continue to plague them. Sometimes more tests are ordered, but seldom is a solution found. It's a bad scene all around. Welcome to the world of microbes, the artful dodgers (at least when it comes to standard medical tests).If you fit the description above, you should be reading Dr. Chutkan's latest book. She talks about "dysbiosis," a widely prevalent but seldom diagnosed condition where the microbial community in your body is way out of whack -- low on good bacteria and high on pathogens (bad bacteria) due to a host of modern-day causes: the accumulated ravages of antibiotic treatments, alcohol consumption, stress, diet (specifically lack of enough fiber, vegetables, fruits, fermented foods and too much sugar, carbs, processed "food," genetically-modified food), antacid use, NSAID use, birth-control pill regimes, chemotherapy, and artificial sweeteners.As patients feel sicker, doctors unknowingly feed the flames by prescribing more pain medication, antibiotics, etc., to try to alleviate symptoms and show their patients that they are "doing something." Vicious, meet circle. The misery continues.Well, if all politics are local, all health is in the gut. That's right. We are the microbial profile we feed on a daily basis. And while "feed" mostly means the mouth, it also includes the skin. Dr. Chutkan sees it as a twin mission: living dirty and eating clean. That means we do ourselves no favors by constantly cleaning our hands with hand sanitizers, applying skin products and soaps with anti-bacterial elements and good-bacteria killing chemicals (go ahead, read the ingredients, see if you have the slightest idea about what you are slathering to your skin and scalp on a daily basis... didn't think so).The best part: Chutkan offers practical tips on turning it around -- what you should eat and what you should not eat. Watch out for corn, soy products, and sugar especially. They kill the Good Army and arm the Terrorist in your gut flora. They are almost all GMO-made monstrosities by now, thanks to companies like Monsanto, which have their profits (and yes, Big Pharma's, too, because sick people drive profits) to watch after. Certain bacteria (bad) thrive on sugar and artificial sweeteners and will hijack your body's eating preferences. What we call a "sweet tooth" is actually a type of bad bacteria clamoring from your gut for more of what they need to survive (that it makes you sick means little to them, they are out for themselves and haven't a clue that they will die with you).Chutkan also offers some basic day-to-day living advice, too. A little dirt is a good thing, as is being outside (or opening windows and letting the outside in). Remember when you were a kid? Always outside, barefoot and dirty, exercising through play and interaction with others? Compare to the present, where we spend so much time in our antiseptic, air-conditioned houses, take showers every day, shellack our skin with mysterious products, clean our homes with even more mysterious, bacteria-killing products. Recipe, meet disaster. Patient, meet doctor (yet again): "Doc, I feel miserable and I don't know why." Doc and Conventional Medicine don't know why, either.As to the book itself, yes, it is somewhat repetitive at times and not a narrative wonder or anything, but I 4-star it for its contents and importance. Chutkan even devotes a chapter to the hardcore cases. Here she discusses fecal transplants, the latest frontier for people who cannot turn around their severe conditions through diet and lifestyle changes alone. Feces from healthy patients with the correct microbial profiles are transplanted into the intestines of the sick patient with miraculous results (just look the other way and get over your aversion, I guess). It's been a life-changer for people with relentless conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, pouchitis, infectious diarrhea, etc. Animals don't eat other animals' feces for nothing. Nature is often instructive (and gross). It's squeamish patients who often choose not to heed such lessons.Finally, and not least importantly, the book ends with 95 pages of "microbiome solution" recipes, mostly for dishes that will feed the good and suppress the bad bacteria that live within you, but also for homemade household cleaners and skin lotions/shampoos. Food for stomach, skin, and soul.Yep. Brave New World (which looks suspiciously like our grandparents' Brave OLD World, before the corporations and chemicals started to hijack our willingly sheep-like lives). Advice: Buy or check out of the library. Then fight back against bad bacteria and bad businesses that will shed no tears over your slow and protracted demise.

Well-written, above run-of-the-mill YA piece. A bit confusing with the number of friends and beboping around (chapter-wise), but overall, a satisfying, character-based read about middle school girls who agree to be friends forever (yeah, right) and give it the old middle-school try.Lots of friend drama, a sexting fiasco (though the book is tame and middle-school safe), and even a mild romantic storyline. Occasionally, even a great line (writing-wise), such as one about pull-down attic stairs being like a tongue extending to the floor. Not much of a plot, but some forward progression in the "whodunit" sexting drama.Second Rebecca Stead (When You Reach Me was the first) I've read. Seems a dependable choice and, no doubt, will be a "best seller" in my classroom library this fall.

Towers above my previous blender, which had an ice setting but seemed to engage in death struggles to break the ice up. Not the case with the Jamba. With this, the Ice is crushed. And fast.Now that THAT'S out of the way, a few particulars. The Jamba has four pre-programmed buttons that each behave in their unique ways. Ice crushing gets you low-to-medium pulses steadily up and down for a minute. Whole juice setting purees fruits and veggies by slowly ramping up from slow to high in 55 seconds. Smoothie setting? It pulses five times like it's thinking about lift-off, then ramps up to high for 45 seconds before stopping on its own. And finally, the Soup setting, which I have not used. According to the manual, not only does the blender run for 5 mins, 45 secs, it actually heats the soup to just below the boiling point. I'm a bit leery of that.Good news: Documentation claims all plastic used is BPA free (though no plastic is good plastic when combined with heat, thus my hesitation with soup mode). The blender is made (where else?) in China. It has a manual mode in addition to the four buttons so you can choose pulse, stop/start, and speed (with the center dial). The top center comes off to pour stuff in, and it even includes a "tamper" to tamp down stubborn produce through the top, much like some juicers on the market.All in all, one capable blender. If it has one weakness, it's sound. Honestly. This baby is loud. So if you're thinking of dialing up a smoothie before work at 5 a.m., either forget about it or expect some rise-and-shine company from your grouchy family wandering into the kitchen mumbling: "What WAS that?"

If you don't write out a lot of plans, a smaller weekly planner like this is perfect. It's 8 1/2" by 5 1/2', has a faux suede-feel cover, and follows an academic year (July 2015 to July 2016) organizational pattern. Each month gets its own two-page spread with squares for writing down major events, followed by weekly planning where each page is divided into four days (allowing 11 lines to fill per day in each quadrant on the page).The beginning of the planner features a 3-year reference page with full calendars for 2015, 2016, and 2017. The end of the planner offers two pages for contacts, 10 pages for notes, one page with all twelve months called "event calendar," one page with holidays and what day of the week and day of the month they fall on in 2015, 2016, 2017, and 2018, and finally a time-zone map.Works. The only caveat is size. If you write a lot or have lots of plans, they may not fit in this size planner. Know thyself. Plan before buying. It's that or write tiny....

Looks like a flat brown tire. A bit sticky to the touch. Taste decent, though nothing to sing from the mezzanine about. Contains coconut and almond in addition to dark chocolate chips, though none of these are distinguishable to the sight (just part of the flat-tire mushy blend, is all). Packs 200 calories (80 from fat) for a single bar. That's 8 g. fat, 2 g. saturated. Sodium at 180 mg (why?), fiber at 5 g. (decent), and -- here's the biggie -- sugar at 11 g. (so if you're aiming for 25 g. sugar a day or less... the recommended... be aware).Of course with a title like "Health Warrior Chia Protein Bar" you're probably wondering most about the protein. It offers 10 g. or about 20% daily recommended. Here come the "free's": soy, dairy, and gluten free. And yes, Virginia, it's 100% vegan and Non-GMO verified. As it contains oats and quinoa, not sure it passes muster with our friendly Paleos in the crowd. Overall, a satisfactory treat. Not much to look at, but OK enough taste, and it brags it packs 2,000 mg of Omega 3, so there you go.

Barbarian Days: A Surfing Life is more the subtitle than the title -- that is, a surfing life. To break it down further, it is more life than surfing, as it follows William Finnegan from youngest years to the present day, from continent to continent, from schools to jobs, from here to eternity. Is there a lot of surfing in that life? Yes. Is there a lot of life -- maybe too much life -- in this book? Yes again.Meaning, I felt that 464 pages was a bit much. Surprising, considering Finnegan is a New Yorker writer (that is, if you subscribe to the notion that journalists, more than novelists, are more likely to stay on point and cut to the narrative bone). There are enjoyable descriptions of the ocean and the surfers who like to ride it spread throughout the book. There are also lulls where I kept looking deep for incoming swells.Admittedly, I may not be the best judge. I have never surfed in my  life. Thus, I came to the book with romanticized notion and hoped for lyrical passages you'd expect from a real writer's writer. You know. Hemingway Hangs Ten. But really it was more matter of fact. Well-written, yes. Just overwritten, content-wise. In need of the famous editor Maxwell Perkins, maybe.That said, if you are interested in the autobiography of a New Yorker writer whose greatest love has been surfing -- almost 500 pages worth -- you'll likely enjoy this journalist's tale. At least his life is more exciting than most -- certainly more exciting (and accomplished) than mine. Hat's off, then!

Good weight. Not too heavy. Swivel cord at base is excellent. If you've ever ruined an old iron cord like I have, you'll appreciate it. The handle is non-slip -- a good thing! Measuring cup, added but unexpected, is a nice touch. Cord is 8.5 feet, longer than my last iron, and cord length counts. If you watch TV while you iron, a long cord provides optimal viewing (just keep an eye on the dress shirt, too). Self-cleaning, anti-calcium feature, though too soon to tell, will be great, esp. if you use well water (hard water). Overall, a flat-out can't complain, even if it's not the Cadillac of irons.

Shusterman uses pirate ship metaphors to try to describe a boy with a mental illness. Here the captain, the parrot, the crewmen, the navigator, etc., all become doubles for real-life people working to make this boy better. This makes for a truly bizarre read, so if it's some semblance of plot you value, forget it at the get-go. Not sure how younger readers will take to this, especially if they enjoy plots and page-turners. This one stumbles along as the boy struggles with paranoia (among other things). If you hang in there, you can appreciate what Shusterman's about, but appreciation and enjoyment might diverge, depending on the readers.

Pretty neat, indoor/outdoor product for those who need to secure something. You will get two rolls of tape for a reason -- one is the male tape, the other the female tape. Thus, to use properly, simply remove film to reveal sticky side and secure it with all the black nubbins facing out. Now cut a piece of the OTHER roll at the same length. The black nubbins on roll #2 will press into the outfacing ones of #1. Voila, as they say In France. You're fastened!

This product is especially good for owners trying to increase protein in their dog's diet, which might be for exercise reasons or for purposes of losing weight. It goes by the same principle as human diets. High carbs/grains is more likely to put on the pounds than high protein. If gluten is your worry, this is also a good product to go with, but ultimately it's the dog that makes the call. Does he or she like it? Ours does. Not a ravenous, got-to-eat-now, as with doggy treats, but an eat-with-gusto deal. Good enough!

I'm old (-ish). Well, I was until this week, anyway, when I read in the news that you're not middle-aged until you hit your head on 60. This new rule (clearly made by a Boomer) means I'm young again. Ponce de LeÃ³n can go pound sand (in a swamp -- a tricky business).All kidding aside -- and despite my newfound youth -- in teaching parlance, I'm still old (-ish). You see, I've read a lot of teacher books by now. And I've been to umpteen professional development seminars where I felt I knew as much as (or, sadly in a few cases, MORE than) the presenter.So, when I stumble upon a book that teaches me something AND teaches me HOW to teach something, I take notice. TEACHING ARGUMENTS is one of those books. It goes beyond logos, pathos, and ethos (Chapter 6 in this book), taking the teaching of argument to another level (the mezzanine, maybe). It's clearly written. And the ethos of the author is impressive. This young lady (Boomer effect strikes anew) knows her stuff.True, the book's target audience is high school teachers, but as an 8th-grade teacher, I always look at 9-12 stuff and say two things: "I can modify some of this and outright use some of it as is." Then, a fan of talking, I say a third: "My kids can do this because some Russian dude whose name I constantly misspell -- Vygotsky, maybe? -- says it's heady but not so heady that the handies can't reach it."Actually, he didn't say that, but I'm not so good at translations, so there.Back to the book: You can start with the last chapter (I did) because it's all about "Aristotle's Guide for Being a Good Student." Useful in September, it stresses "habits" over "abilities" because good academic habits are the great equalizers. They level the playing field.Then I reversed to Chapter 1: "Starting with Open-Minded Inquiry" before moving on to Chapter 2's practical "From Comprehension to Critique." Chapters 3, 4, and 5 come in a bundle, as they say of communications these days. They are, in order, "Fostering a Deeper Understanding of Occasion, of Audience, and of Purpose." Then it's the EPL chapter you'd expect first (or maybe I would because that's what I know and teach -- poorly, I now see).Yes, I could have waited until September to implement some of Fletcher's ideas, but I figure, why rob these great kids of some of the skills before they go off to high school, so I've been using some of the stuff the past week or so -- with good result, too! We read a NY TIMES opinion column by David Brooks and played "the believing game." In a few days, we will revisit the same, only this time we'll be playing "the doubting game." My kids are used to the "one-and-done-as-quickly-as-possible game" when it comes to reading, so this is a nice change. A good habit, thank you.One mark of a good teacher book is the size of the appendices with all of the handouts and examples. Seeing a long one is like a full stocking on Christmas morning. Unpack it slowly and enjoy! So yes, it's been Christmas In April reading this. (Who says April is the cruelest month? T.S. Eliot can go pound sand with Ponce!)Meaning? The book has a solid theoretical foundation BUT is loaded with practical ideas. Fletcher doesn't stint when it comes to sharing. Now, if I can only get Jennifer Fletcher to run seminars and barnstorm her way East! It's been a while since I went to PD and actually learned something. Remember, I'm old, but only in an -ISH kind of way.

As the subtitle explains, this book is wisely meant for both parents AND teachers -- and not just of youngsters, but of kids all the way through middle and high school. While a lot of the advice on reading is practical, it is also, per Willingham's trademark calling card, based on research. Thus, some of your cherished beliefs may be up for revision (all rewards and praise work -- they don't; all aspects of technology work against reading -- not true). In other words, nothing is cut and dried, and research likes shades of gray, so read up on it.The book is organized by age of the child, with parts dedicated to "Birth Through Preschool," "Kindergarten Through Second Grade," and "Third Grade and Beyond." There's information on decoding, comprehension, the all-important background knowledge, fluency, and yes, motivation. At the end of each chapter, Willingham offers a "Keeping It Simple Summary" with bullet points of very basic highlights to remember. Notes are inserted at chapters' ends (vs. book's end) as well.The best part? The book is practical. There is advice for both parents and teachers on optimizing odds that Johnny and Suzie will grow to be recreational readers. No, not nerds who read instead do cool stuff like the Internet and gaming, but kids who realize that reading is another pleasure of life to go beside those electronic pastimes -- a different pleasure in life, too. One with its own distinct rewards. At just under 200 pp. with plenty of pictures, it's a fast read. If you care about reading, worth your dime. Or your hold at the library.

PIRATE HUNTERS is more than just "the search for the lost treasure ship of a great buccaneer," it's history, biography, and psychology rolled into one page-turning tale. Ostensibly, this is the story of two treasure hunters, John Mattera and John Chatterton, who descend upon the Dominican Republic in search of the pirate Joseph Bannister's ship, THE GOLDEN FLEECE. In a battle against two British war ships, the GOLDEN FLEECE went down in 1687, where it has rested in peace ever since. Author Robert Kurson uses the natural story lines built by hunters racing other hunters for one of the most elusive of prizes, a genuine pirate wreck (records for pirate ships were not kept by pirates and their sympathizers, making finds all the more challenging).In addition to the history propelled by the mystery, the false starts necessary to reach an actual strike, and the underwater (and above) descriptions built for suspense, the author stops the narrative to explore the background of both treasure hunters -- Chatterton's as a medic who risked his life repeatedly in Vietnam, and Mattera's as a boy growing up as part of the New York crime families network in the 60s and 70s. Both are diverting tales, though the reader, appetite whetted, longs to get back to the Dominican and the hunt for a great pirate ship.Also leavening the narratives are historical accounts of Joseph Bannister, the British captain turned rogue (and how often does THAT happen?) who took on his countrymen and fought them to a draw against incredible odds. For readers, the derring will do nicely and the reading is pitched once it comes to Bannister. Kurson also takes time to educate readers on pirates, on their love for democracy far in advance of any Founding Fathers, on their strict system of "justice" despite an undeniable love for money, liquor, and women.For instance, neither "Aarghhh!" nor "Shiver me timbers!" were ever uttered by pirates of the Golden Age of Piracy (1650-1720). Instead, they were the invention of 1950s movie screenwriters. Among invocations the real pirates said: "Eat what falls from my tail!" "Damn your blood!" "I'll cleave your skull asunder!" "I'll cut you in pound pieces!" and "I come from hell and I'll carry you there presently!"There's also an interesting ledger of what pirates were compensated for body parts lost while in brave battle: e.g. 600 pieces of silver or six slaves for a lost right arm, 500 pieces of silver or five slaves for a lost left arm, 100 pieces of silver or one slave for a lost eye or lost finger, etc. There were also set punishments onboard for stealing from a ship's plunder, cheating fellow pirates, sneaking a woman on board (trouble!), cowardice, insolence, disobedience, or anything else impeding the ship's primary purpose -- to steal (and spend as quickly as possible, for as Kurson points out, buried treasure is another myth and would be considered laughable to "spend it today, if not yesterday" pirates of the time).So go ahead, indulge the kid (or Capt. Kidd) in yourself. Read a rip-roaring tale about a real pirate who's little known and deserves to be better known. Yes, on small occasion the narrative waters grow choppy and slow, but for the most part the sailing is so smooth that Roger and most everyone else will grow Jolly reading it.

This 60 x 84 polyester tablecloth looks and feels more like linen than a synthetic fabric.  The open-weave detail at the white and tan border gives it a slightly dressier look. Haven't washed it yet, but it looks like the care won't be an issue as it is machine-washable. Instructions say machine-wash cold separately using the gentle cycle. Tumble dry low and low iron gets you through the cleaning process. Up to 8 people can break bread sitting around this tablecloth. Alas, made in China.

With WEIGHTLESS, Sarah Bannan takes a calculated risk that both pays off and doesn't -- she uses the first-person plural point of view. Thus you have "We this..." and "We that...." What iss the point in that, you ask? Is she just showing off, you wonder? Not exactly. By using the "group-think" of teen tribes (cliques to you) and by emphasizing the modern-day role of social networks (online, cell phones, tablets, etc.), Bannan is out to show us just how impersonal and singular a group of people can become -- often to society's detriment.In this case, a new (and of course good-looking) girl moves to Alabama from New Jersey. Within the first week or two, she is dating the hunkiest (and of course star-jock) guy in the school. All eyes are on the new couple. All tongues are wagging about them. And the online buzz is relentless, right down to a "Top Girls in Our School" type list (haven't we seen this before?), to which New Girl zooms to the top (can you say, "Surprise"?).The down side, as you might have guessed, is how predictable and stereotypical this narrative is once you get used to the "We" business. If you've read a lot of YA situated in high schools, you're in for both "more" and "of the same." The book also gets off to a slow start. As it approaches the 100 mark, the pace picks up a bit. Possibly teen readers will embrace it despite the predictability. They might just get into the pack mentality of swarming jealousies, love interests, pettiness, and hormones. For me, a simple reader of YA fare for classroom library purposes, this was just a bit too much "not again." High marks for the creative use of POV to emphasize technology's dark side, but lower ones for the story itself.

I recommend these bags as an addition to cheaper sandwich-sized bags for items you need sealed a bit more effectively. That said, I have not put this bag through its paces by filling it with leaky-type fare, making it do a few Wallenda-style flips in the produce drawer, sentencing it to Dante's 9th circle in the freezer, etc. So if you want to know how it holds up to RIGOROUS treatment, find a better scientist (experimenter, reviewer, what have you).Me, I'm just an ordinary Joe saying these are slightly bigger than sandwich bags and are great if you need room to park a REAL sandwich on generous slices of bread with ample additions of meats and cheeses and lettuce and tomato and mustard and so on and so forth. Also keep it on hand for stuff you don't want to spill. Obviously a zip top like this will fare better if a full bag of cherries or fresh blueberries tumble. With the fine-line press and seal cheapies, you store at your own risk

Sometimes star ratings are insufficient things. Sometimes ratings say as much about the reader as they do the book. In this case, I will confess to my own subjective nature as a reader. The BOOK OF SPECULATION is a book of plot. Sheer story. Fun, maybe, if you love books that are escapist in nature. To an extent, I like that, too. But I crave deep characterization and description as well. Here, all the writing seems a prop for the plot -- and a bizarre plot it is.The story involves a line of mothers who are "mermaids" in that they work for circuses and can stay underwater for great lengths of time (no fins to speak of, so if you're a Daryl Hannah fan, apologies all around). Trouble is, these "mermaids" drown. Always. And on the same day. Always. Sound like a plot waiting for a climax? You don't have to listen carefully to know the answer is yes. Thus does one Simon Watson, librarian by trade, come to a quest to rescue his sister after his mother has drowned in the manner mentioned above. Back and forth the chapters alternately go -- the present with Simon and his race against this mystery, and the circus-situated past which slowly builds the background to the curse Simon is up against. You may never look at a horseshoe crab in the same way again (not that you look at horseshoe crabs all that often, but if you do).A nice ride. A bit hokey. Breadth over depth, but I know that there are many readers, unlike me, who take to storybooks like this like horseshoe crabs take to the sea. So mea culpa for the stars. Ignore them. Look in the mirror. If you don't care about the other stuff and just want a Scheherazade-of-the-Sea tale (mermaids need apply), jump in! The water's fine! If you think your subjectivities look suspiciously like mine, however... well, let the dice roller beware.

If you're a hypochondriac, steer clear. Otherwise, steel yourself and have a look-see at surgery from the other side (assuming you're not a neurosurgeon reading this). Henry Marsh is a British brain surgeon and a writer with a clear, straightforward style -- not only his diction, but his personality. With each chapter named after a different (and terrible) thing that can go wrong with these miracle devices we call our brains and our bodies, he delivers anecdote after anecdote of actual cases he's experienced over the years, some ending happily, many not. What's refreshing is his human voice. Being seen as savior or demon (often depending on outcome of surgery) is no easy way to make a living, as readers will see.Still, Marsh is not one to hide behind his vaunted profession and overly-romanticize it. In fact, he admits that errors happen. Things go wrong, even during routine operations. In one frightening case, he let a junior surgeon begin a rather straightforward procedure and an error causing permanent disablement occurred. Rather than falsify records as many doctors do (and easily can, considering the patient is out and you're only surrounded by members of your team, the medical brethren), Marsh owned up to it. In his view, hospitals deserved to be sued in some cases -- a man like this should at least win a settlement to help with the obvious ordeal lying ahead. Still, settlements or not, mistakes don't stop guilt from hounding doctors. At least doctors who care.Despite all of the gloom and doom, there's an education to be had in this book. You can learn a lot about the brain's function and effects on other parts of the body. All pain is signaled by the brain. Hemispheres matter. Location and size of tumors matter. Some tumors are "sticky" and become problematic because they adhere too much to the brain. Others, more luckily, almost "pop" out with little coaxing -- like Teflon, even. One never knows until one goes into the brain, which on more than one occasion sounds as much the "last frontier" as outer space, especially when reading Marsh's graphic descriptions of the "landscape" in there.Here's an excerpt showing Marsh's typical tone and overall humanity: "My outpatient clinic is an odd combination of the trivial and the deadly serious. It is here that I see patients weeks or months after I have operated on them, new referrals or long-term follow-ups. They are wearing their own clothes and I meet them as equals. They are not yet in-patients who have to submit to the depersonalizing rituals of being admitted to the hospital, to be tagged like captive birds or criminals and to be put into bed like children in hospital gowns. I refuse to have anybody else in the room -- no students, no junior doctors or nurses -- only the patients and their families."The type of doctor you could put your faith in? I should say so. An education not only on the brain but on dying? That, too. The doctors know what's going down, and you will, too, once you read all of these cases. Sometimes no operation is the answer. Sometimes hope is your enemy -- bound only to prolong your suffering when palliative measures would be so much more humane.Overall, a compelling document. Moments of humor, dark and not, rails against bureaucracy and government, and snapshots of people like you and me... always hoping the best from life, sometimes receiving the worst from it. In a word: fate.

Talk about broad! Talk about abstract and literal at once! The subject is "rain" and the slant (if you can call it that) is its "natural and cultural history." With such a huge topic, Cynthia Barnett has her work cut out for her and, overall, she pulls it off with aplomb. Yes, this could have been an encyclopedic-style book, but Barnett has a way with words and instead steers toward story. Well, stories. Multiple.The problem with such Herculean tasks as this is deciding what to write about. Rain is one big (and leaking) tent. Where to begin? Where to go? It's like herding cats (and dogs, to coin an idiom mentioned in this book). Barnett starts, logically enough, with the earth's beginnings, with comparisons to both Mars and Venus, to water's role in these planets' evolutions. From there she moves to early civilizations, how they dealt with too much and too little rain. Reining in rain, no easy task, has been high on man's to-do list for centuries. Some civilizations (the ancient Assyrians, for one, and then the Romans and the Byzantines) were better at it than others.If there's a small negative to the book, it's the choices that the author is forced to make. What should she include? Leave out? Discuss at length? Mention briefly? With decisions like that, she's bound to please some readers and disappoint others. She dwells on "rainmakers," for one -- the quacks and charlatans who made money by fooling people into thinking they could call on the rain and bring it down for farmers and others -- at a price.. Some used ordnance (explosions in the sky = rain, as was believed by many a Civil War veteran, including Joshua Chamberlain of the 20th Maine). Others used chemical soups that would emit all matter of highly-visible gases floating to the heavens. But all depended on coincidence and "rainy seasons" to bail them out. To me, this got a little old fast, but Barnett covered more than one such character.Then, in the "Writers on the Storm" section, Barnett gets into writers, composers, artists, who all tapped into rain for their material. To me this was more fascinating, and I could have read another hundred pages on it, but Barnett moves on sooner rather than later. It was not surprising to learn, however, that "bad" weather induces higher artistic output -- that is, many famous writers got more work done when living in a rainy climate vs. a sunny one. Being cooped up? Yes, but the mood, too. Rain has its wiles and will not be denied.Among other topics touched on are scents of rain, how the U.S. is enamored with "rain scents" in many cleaning products while the Europeans (esp. Irish and English) prefer "sun-fresh" products, Thomas Jefferson (who foolishly built Monticello on a hill, far from the river and more easily-tapped water supplies), strange rains (frogs, eels, mud, etc., falling from the skies), and the high electrocution rates of church bell ringers before folks figured out that water plus high places during thunderstorms equaled shocking finishes.Overall, highly entertaining, if jumpy and uneven in spots. Given the task taken on (rain's "natural and cultural history"), Barnett more than held her own. Holds up to "front to back" reading or to leisurely dipping while reading other books.

At approximately 180 pages, GOD HELP THE CHILD is an exercise in brevity. After a somewhat confusing start, it launches into the story of a black child, Lula Ann, who is unwanted due to her excessive darkness. In fact, her father suspects her mother of having had a darker-skinned lover and leaves her. But the mother is innocent. Horrified, but innocent. What she's not innocent of is loving her child. Lula Ann is left to feel the wrath of a mother who feels singled out by the gods.Lula Ann grows to be statuesque, eventually cashing in on her blue-black loveliness by becoming a model and adopting the name Bride (she wears white clothes only for contrast). She falls for a man named Booker, a man with his own baggage. And, key to everything, Bride gets the living Hades beaten out of her when she tries to help a woman she put behind bars so many years ago.All of this takes exposition at the start, where you'd expect it. What's odd, in so short a book, is how exposition enters the scene again 3/4ths through, only this case to chronicle Booker's past. This "intermission" staggers the book's flow a bit. And, stranger still, when it all wraps up, the reader feels as if everything has not been said. Some readers may like this effect, actually, but I felt less invested in the characters because of it.I also feel that Morrison hits her stride when "showing" through description, action, and dialogue, and stumbles when telling, such as with the stretches of exposition. In the end, it all feels a bit uneven, unfinished, unconvincing, even. That said, I cared enough to see it through. Thus the 3-stars. It's one of those books that has its 2- and 4-star moments. Thus, the law of averages. If you like experiments -- and 180-page novellas are risky in their way -- give it a try. There's no faulting Morrison for her ambition, anyway.

Some reviewers have been taken aback by the taste of this product, so I'm guessing many of them mix it with water and make it a meal. Me, I use nutritional shakes as the foundation for smoothies where I dictate the taste via add-ins.
