How to describe White Reaper... Well, if you took a punk garage band from the seminal era of the genre, threw them into a time capsule, opened it today and gave them instruments - you would have White Reaper. It's driving, unapologetic, energetic and just rough enough around the edges to be intentional. More than anything it's just fun. Having a bad day, or just feeling a bit down? Throw this on the turntable and crank it, you'll be hopping around in no time.Vocally there's a nice grind to the mid-ranged vocalists sound. Guitars are full on fuzz distortion. Drums are frantic and fevered, beats are frequent and pounding. The Bass line, while driving, is not overpowering - it compliments the rhythm guitar as it should. You'll find keyboards sprinkled throughout adding a nice dynamic, almost moog-like, in its execution and sound.This album specifically, is a debut EP through and through. White Reaper throw everything they have at you. My only complaint is that it's too short. The Clear Pink vinyl is beautiful. It reminds me of what it would look like if you melted down strawberry Jolly Ranchers and made a record out of them.Overall, great stuff if you're looking for a "fresh" vintage rock sound and A LOT of energy.

I've had several portable battery packs. Everything from the tiny "sticks" to the large "bricks". I've always preferred the bricks because you get one charge out of the stick and then you have to charge the stick again, essentially negating its purpose other than doubling your battery life. While the bricks are great because you can keep coming back for more, they're hardly portable. Generally, I keep one in my car and check on it now and again.The HP Slim is really the best of both worlds. Not quite a stick, but not far from it. It's light, compact and sleek. It also charges to devices simultaneously which is more than I can say for some of my bricks.It has everything you expect; charging input, two USB charging outputs, an LED indicator and a GO button to start the charge. It's a simple device and that's exactly what it should be.

I wasn't sure what to expect with this when it came across my vine. I enjoy going to thrift stores and finding old frames to bring back to life. Typically I use a small foam brush or my airbrush. While my airbrush is top of the line, it's really made for larger jobs of one color. When I saw this come across the vine, I grabbed it.I assumed that I needed to use my air compressor with this unit, but I was wrong. The large back end of the sprayer is a powerful fan that propels the medium. Fill up one of the included reservoirs, plug the sprayer in and pull the trigger. It works flawlessly. The spray head is easy to adjust for the fan or round patterns. Clean up is a breeze as the whole front of the sprayer can be disengaged. No worries about getting motors or electronics wet.It lays down a clean coat. Not sputtering or changes in flow rates that I've noticed so far. Absolutely thrilled!

My wife and I have been wanting to garden for awhile now. Living in Chicago, though, you really only have a 3-4 month window and when spring rolls around, time just seems to get away from us. When I saw this come across the vine, I thought it would be a perfect tool to jump start our gardening aspirations.Setup looks daunting, but it couldn't be further from it. I'd say 10 minutes and you'll be finished. Instructions are very easy to read and everything is put together very well. It's smaller than I imagined, so finding some counter space was a non-issue. Even fully extended, the light doesn't touch the bottom of my lowest cabinets. The noise emitting from the aerator is louder than I had anticipated, but it's not in excess of what you would expect from a fish tank.The included pods types aren't my first choice in gardening, but I planted them anyway just to familiarize myself with the process. They make empty pods if you want to plant your own seeds which I like as I hate using proprietary items as, when they discontinue the product, everything becomes useless. I plan on researching other nutrient mixture recipes to eliminate the reliance on that element as well. The bottle of nutrients included will last quite awhile though.My primary qualm is that this unit doesn't utilize LED lighting. I would think that the target demographic are those who are a little more environmentally conscious, so the inclusion of a bulb you throw out every six months is a little off the mark. I wouldn't think that the cost difference would be that significant, but I'm not a product designer - so what do I know?Overall, it's a great little device - especially if you live in a region that experiences long periods of inclement weather. You can use this to start plants as well, prior to transplanting in your garden, to ensure they get a good head start. I imagine this would also be great for kids in terms of getting them into gardening and teaching them the value of self-sufficiency.

So many concerns are raised with this watch. First of all Swiss Legend is owned by Evine Live (a home shopping channel, formerly ShopNBC). Which raises concerns about the quality as it was essentially created to make people think they were getting awesome deals on supposedly top quality merchandise. Secondly, they're located in Hollywood, FL (not Switzerland). "But the watch says Swiss Made!" you cry out. Yes, it does. The guidelines to claim that a watch is Swiss made is that 50% of the value of its parts must be made in Switzerland. Value meaning the assessed value of the parts comprising the watch, NOT the MSRP. So you have a decent quality movement from Switzerland and a bunch of low value parts from other regions of the world and it's still considered Swiss Made.Secondly, for a woman's watch, this thing is clunky. My mom loves the look of the watch, but says its too heavy to wear daily. She reserves it for when her and my dad go out. There's not much elegant about it aside from the finish. The dial is big, the crown is big, the watch is thick.Third, seemingly every retailer that offers Swiss Legend has them consistently 60-80% off the MSRP. What this tells me is that this is a $200 watch that the manufacturer purposely suggests an outrageous MSRP so that stores can mark it way down and consumers will assume they're getting a super luxury watch for an unbeatable price and make the impulse buy without further research.Ok, so why am I still giving it 3 stars? Because Swiss Legend has done very well at producing a watch that looks far more expensive than it is. If you're wearing a watch as a status symbol, you won't find many who would question the extravagance of this watch. The Rose Gold colored finish (the case and band are actually Stainless Steel) is very pretty and authentic looking. The mother of pearl grey face could have a slightly greater luster, but is still pretty in its own right. It's HEAVY which most will equate to a quality watch.Also, it works and works well. There are no functional flaws that I have found thus far that would cause me to dissuade anyone from purchasing this watch to use as a watch. For the time being it functions just as it's intended and everything feels solid.Overall, my only qualms with this watch are the morally questionable nature of Swiss Legend's claim to Swiss Made, as well as their MSRP and markdown practices. More importantly is that this doesn't really have the hallmarks of a woman's watch. I assumed it was a men's gold watch from afar, prior to closer inspection. It's just too big and heavy to appeal to the majority of its target gender. However, there has been no reason for me to question the quality and functionality of the watch and it's definitely a head-turner.

Was shocked when I saw this come across the Vine. I remember the classic Stanley thermos designs from all the factory workers when I was a kid. A growler though?I love growlers, every time I hit up a new brewery I have to leave with at least one of their growlers full of beer. The glass growlers are great, but by the time you get them home (or to a party or BYOB restaurant) the temp has already risen considerably from the tap. With this growler however, it'll stay "tap-cold" for hours. I poured four 12 oz cans in the growler, sealed it and left it on the counter in my kitchen (approx. 68 degrees Fahrenheit via central air) for 15 hours. The temperature before sealing the growler was 43 degrees Fahrenheit, 15 hours later I opened the growler and took a reading of 45 degrees Fahrenheit. 2 degrees isn't too shabby at all considering, in a standard growler, it would have been room temperature long ago.It's like a little beer time-machine. Close the lid and time stops, carbonation stays as well as the cold. I'm thrilled with this growler.

Currently we have a Red Devil steam mop and a Black and Decker cordless stick vacuum for the kitchen and hard surfaces. While they work great, it's annoying to go over everything with the vacuum and then go over everything again with the steam mop. The Bissell Symphony Pet seemed to offer the best of both worlds.Fill up the reservoir and give it a minute or two to get the steam going. Then vacuum just as you would with anything else. I was skeptical at first - wouldn't the steam just blow the pet hair around or soak it to a paste? Nope, it picked up all the dirt and pet dander with ease while steaming and disinfecting.Overall, this does the job in half the time I'm used to and I couldn't be happier.

We try to cut back on disposable products in our household. These seemed like a great way to assist in that.I initially thought that these would have some sort of valve to release the seal. In fact, these are actually just rubber circles that you push down in your dish to create a seal that then peal off using the tab on the side. The operation is simple.However, the simplistic operation minimizes the overall application. Because you're not sucking any air out, the pressure when pressing down must remain even and uniform. This eliminates the possibility of non-round containers. It also means that the containers you use must be slightly smaller than the circumference of the lid you're using. This means that some of my larger mixing bowls are going to be too big.Overall; it's a good idea, it's simple, it's enviro-friendly. However, it's simple design ultimately inhibits its overall functionality.

I got this for my new charcoal grill. It'd been about 3 uses since I gave it a good scrub so after I cooked, while it was still hot, I filled this with water and went to town.First thing to note, I assumed that this was a clothes iron style steamer where you pour water into the reservoir and steam shoots out openings in the bottom. This is not the case. You fill the reservoir and then when you're ready to use it, you turn a release knob. Water droplets come out the bottom and as they hit the grating and hot surfaces of the grill it creates an overall steam effect. I was disappointed at first but it does seem to aid in the process and I appreciate not having to plug it in.The brushes work very well and took off the grease and ash very easily. I don't have a neglected grill to try it on, so if you're wondering if it'll strip off years of abuse, I can't say how effective it'd be. I can definitely say that it will continue to maintain a grill that has been previously maintained handily.My only complaint is that without the unit creating steam, it can be a pain for non-gas grill users as you either have to clean the grill immediately after use (while all that delicious food taunts you) or you have to fire up some coals just to clean it. Not a deal breaker, just something to think about.

Poo-Pourri's biggest hurdle is that it has all the  makings of a gag gift. I'd seen it in stores and boutiques before, chuckled to myself and kept walking - never actually taking the ornate little spray bottle seriously.It came across my Vine and so I figured, what do I have to lose? My wife was thrilled when the tiny bottle arrived, she had thought of buying it in the past, but didn't want to be the lady buying the poo-perfume. We have a large house whose fundamental flaw is that it was built over a century ago and has only a single bathroom on the ground floor - right next to the kitchen, no less. So in the morning after I've cleaned out my tank, so to speak, she either has to wait for the odor to dissipate and risk being late for work, or brave the toxic fumes whilst she completes her morning routine.My concern was that this would be a "masking" scent. Like fields of vanilla and mint...after a herd of cattle came through and left their best work behind. But no, I have a fairly acute sense of smell and try as I might, post-loaf, I was unable to smell my leavings. It passed the wife's nose-test, her sense of smell is even better than mine. The scent smells clean and natural, not overpowering chemical or floral.Much to my surprise, I believe that Poo-Pourri will become a bathroom staple in our home.

I've been using PNY products in PC builds/upgrades for about 15 years now. I've always had good luck with the hardware, it's affordable and stable. The other virtue is the PNY lifetime warranty. I had a MOBO go rogue and fry a bunch of peripherals about 10 years ago, my RAM and VGU were both PNY. I emailed them about what happened, sent in the dead equipment and before I knew it, replacements were at my door without any hassle.I swapped out the 4GB in my Dell Inspiron 2320 (While it is technically a desktop, it's an all-in-one running off a Notebook mobo). The boot time is noticeably faster and, while it'll never be a serious gaming PC or graphical workhorse, it now has a spring in its step that makes it more of a joy to use.Overall, PNY makes reliable, affordable, well-performing hardware and this RAM set is no exception. Make sure you research whether your motherboard is compatible with these sticks as well as the amount of memory they provide. If you only have a single slot to work with, PNY offers a single stick 8gb for the same price.
Charmin is our go-to toilet paper in my household and the ultra strong lives up to the expectation.Still nice and soft and the rolls are standard size so they fit perfectly on a standard holder.

Super soft fabric and a cute designs drew me towards this floor mat. It comes wrapped nicely with a bow which makes it ideal for gifting at a baby shower.One thing to keep in mind is to look at the measurements in the item description because without a point of reference, the item picture makes it look larger than it is. I read the measurements so I wasn't disappointed.

Extremely easy to put together. It seems to holed the attention of my little nephew, but I think most things do at his age.The interchangeable disks are neat and easy to swap out. I like the retro 70s feel of the design even though that wasn't their intention.As to whether or not it is excersizing his vision as it claims, who knows. It can't hurt though!

This is our go-to toilet paper in our household. I learned sometime in college that the toilet paper is one of those necessities that you should spare no expense on. At around a buck per roll this is super soft and nice and thick. I've never had issues with it tearing or leaving a lint trail (neither are enjoyable experiences).Honestly, my only qualm would be that the Mega Rolls don't fit all that well on the standard holder without an extender which usually means that it sits on the back of the toilet or the sink ledge until the diameter has whittled down a bit. Obviously I could just buy the standard roll or get the extender so that's more my own fault than an issue with the product.

I was intrigued by this little "baby command center" when I saw it come across the Vine. I figured I'd test it out with my friend's son (2) when we babysit and see how it goes.He was instantly enthralled with the device. The lights and sounds hypnotized the child immediately. The thing I like about this toy is that it combines touch screen technology (teaching them to operate things that don't give tactile feedback) as well as physical objects to manipulate (teaching them to use object that do give tactile feedback).He liked the ball chute, but beyond that mostly stuck to the touch sensitive bits as they're the ones that provide the light and sound.All in all, it kept his attention, so I'd call that a success.

Friends who have children swear by MAM as they were one of the first brands to be BPA free.These are very easy to clean, which is a big plus. The designs on the side are very cute as well. My nephew had no issues with them. They work very well!

Friends who have children swear by MAM as they were one of the first brands to be BPA free.These are very easy to clean, which is a big plus. The designs on the side are very cute as well. My nephew had no issues with them. They work very well!

I requested this toy on a whim. I saw Inside Out in theaters and thoroughly enjoyed the film. I figured this would be a fun addition to my various toy/collectible displays.First of all, Sadness was my least favorite character. Mostly because I find that the overly mopey people I've come across throughout my life do not mesh well with my upbeat and laid-back nature (I'm sure many of you can relate.) However, this figure is pretty adorable.It's shockingly well made. The sweater is actual fabric and it is quite soft. It's the little touches like that that really make a great toy in my opinion. She has a button in her stomach that - when pressed - causes her to slouch and play a phrase from the movie. The sound quality is crystal clear and spot on with the audio from the film. Also included is the Long Term Memory Retrieval guide. This is a plastic clam-shell that opens and closes. All the colors and prints are crisp and clear. Her hair in real life (while plastic) is colored much better than the product image would lead you to believe. She stands about 7" tall and her arms are articulated at the shoulder.Overall, this is a great toy for a Pixar or Inside Out fan! I fully expected a 3 star product, but my expectations were exceeded.

Got this for when we babysit my nephew. It's super easy to put together which was an immediate win. The cups that come with it are pretty adorable and perfect for rinsing. The perforated (yellow cup) creates a shower effect which is fun. There aren't really any grooves which makes cleaning it super quick and easy. The design is super cute. Overall, great buy!

Nothing like a sleep companion and night light in one. Silicon is super soft. Flipping it turns it on and off, although this feature can be a bit finicky. Light is bright although the red glow is a bit forboding. All around fantastic idea!

My nephew is a big fan of Batman (I'm sure there are a lot of others out there who can relate) so I grabbed this so he had something to play with when he visits. You can tell his is aimed at younger fans of Batman. The colors are brighter, the forms are a bit more cartoonish and exaggerated and...well... Batman's riding a T-Rex... The veteran comic book reader in me dies a little bit every time I look at it, but - alas - it isn't for me, so I will steel my resolve and suffer through.Sparing you from a rant involving the use of popular IP to breath life into other IP (i.e. Jurassic World and Batman)... The toy is solidly built. There's a trigger on the underside of the tail that deploys the cannon and seat from the CybeRex's (rly?) tail. Batman can then shoot large discs that look like re-purposed Batmobile hubcaps at his foes, i.e. the Joker. When the cannon is deployed the CybeRex's mouth opens which is kinda cool. There's a rib cage (ha, get it? RIB... CAGE...anyway) that can hold the Joker so Batman and CybeRex can traipse through the Gotham streets to drop him back off at Arkham so that he can break out in time for next weeks wacky adventure.Getting to the point, my nephew loves it. It's easy to use, it's Batman and Dinosaurs (what more could a six year-old boy want?) and it shoots things. My only real complaint (other than my nerd continuity issues) is that it's pictured with the 'roided out, battle-axe wielding, Joker (SMH). I realize that this is probably some attempt at showing size comparison, or how to use the CybeRex, but it makes this look like it's part of the playset. I read the description prior to ordering, so I knew that it didn't actually come with the Joker, but I know not everyone does that, so don't expect the Joker to be included.Overall, for thirty bucks, it's a decent toy. You get the CybeRex and a Batman figure with two discs. My nephew likes it a lot, which is the reason I bought it.

I've come across this game a few times in my life at various locations. For as simple as it is, it's extremely addictive and fun. Great for something to do while drinking on your patio with friends.What I like about the Viva Sol version is the quality of the products. When I've come across this game in the past, it's been a rusted hook sticking out of a rotten board in the back of a seedy bar or in an Amish village. The presentation of the Viva Sol version will make it look more like a recreational game and less like a rusty hook and filthy bit of thread randomly sticking out of your patio.Set up is easy. Easier if you have an electric screw driver/drill. Can you drill holes? Yes? Then you will have no issue setting up this game.Overall it's fun, something to do outside during summer get-togethers. Twenty bucks is reasonable for the quality.

I used to drive across country a few times a year. I got in the habit of being very prepared an stocking my car with tools, lighters, blankets, etc to ensure that I was prepared for any number of emergencies. I don't drive more than 30 miles nowadays, but I still can't resist a good car gadget. Most of them go in my wife's car (whether she wants them or not) to ensure that she's prepared for any issues during her commute.The Maxic Compass intrigued me instantly. A little white box that can jump-start my car? You've got to be kidding me. I snatched it up eager to test it out. Left my light on overnight to drain my battery (I have a full size Forney battery charger in the garage, so I wasn't worried if the Compass didn't live up to its hype). Plugged the jump adapter into the box (couldn't be simpler) and attached the alligator clips to the battery terminals. The read-out on the digital display said OK and sure enough, started right up.It has several features that protect you, the battery and the unit. The most common you'd probably see is the NG readout on the digital display. This means that the battery is fine and it will not force current to it, which is great if you don't want to deal with a melted car battery. I do think they could've used something other than NG because, if I'm someone who hasn't read the manual, NG means nothing to me. Other than that, it's extremely straightforward, easy to operate and user friendly.It has a nice carrying case that holds all sorts of adapters for cellphones/etc as well as the unit and the jumper cables. It easily fits under your car seat or in your spare tire.The unit has a flashlight built in and USB and cigarette lighter outlet. You can charge your phone, etc. It seems to hold its charge very effectively, I haven't had it for more than a month so I can't say how long it lasts but I would think quite awhile.Overall, this is a phenomenal device to have in any car. Great for kids going off to college, wives and husbands alike. You never know when you're going to be stuck somewhere and it's surprising how few people keep jumper cables in their cars these days.

I've been using a Fitbit One for awhile now and a Fitbit Zip prior to that. I appreciate the additional functionality and the recharging of the One over the Zip and have been very happy with it. I know that most people's reservations with the Fitbit and other high-end activity trackers is the price. A hundred bucks is a substantial amount of money to take a chance on something. I figured I'd try out the Pivotal Living Tracker 1 to see how much (if any) of a difference there is between them.First thing you'll notice is the price. Fifteen bucks is dirt cheap for an activity tracker (not to be confused with a simple pedometer). The app is included as well as a year subscription to their service (the app, message boards, etc). Each year you'll have the option to renew for twelve dollars and your renewal gets you the newest version of the tracker. Not a bad deal at all.How does it fair against its competition though? Well, pretty well actually. There seemed to be no disparity between the numbers in comparison to my Fitbit and the Pivotal. I prefer that the Fitbit tracks stairs as well. I had no issues with it syncing to my phone. The battery life is about half the Fitbit One, lasting about a week to the Oneâ€™s two. The App UI is clean and easily navigated, very user friendly over all.So, should you buy this? Well, if youâ€™re looking for an activity tracker for your child that wonâ€™t make you homicidal when they lose it, this is a good choice. If youâ€™re interested in an activity tracker, but not sure how much use youâ€™ll get out of it, this is a low-cost/high-gain option as far as trackers go. If you are serious about fitness, there are enough options on here that may work for you, but there are other trackers out there that offer a more robust dataset.Overall, itâ€™s a solid tracker on the cheap thatâ€™s user friendly and doesnâ€™t look like it came out of a cereal box.

I had a Nerf slingshot about twenty or so years ago. Mine had the little yellow balls that didn't shoot well. This slingshot uses darts and is far more accurate.Assembly is pretty easy. The elastic cords snap into the base on the side you're pulling so hopefully they're secure. They're not long and the tension isn't high so I don't think there's opportunity for serious injury.It comes with two darts which isn't very much ammo. There are only clips for two darts so if you have extra ammo, you'll need big pockets or an ammo belt accessory.Having a clip-fed mechanism would've been more beneficial and I'm surprised (with so many clip-fed Nerf weapons) that they didn't implement it in this slingshot.Overall, it's light, accurate and easy to use. One star removed for the lack of ammo included as well as lack of ample ammo storage.

It's two-fifty per refill on the Pentel Site. The Society for All Artists (should be Society for Con Artists) is ripping you off, which leads me to question the name further... Clearly you're not FOR me if you're charging a 400% mark-up on top of six bucks in shipping.The Color Brush and refills themselves are a five star product all day long. It's an absolutely phenomenal tool that any inker should have in their arsenal. Just make sure you know the MSRP and/or buy direct from the manufacturer.

I had two pens I used for brush work. The first is the Pentel Arts Color Brush (with a black cartridge) which has a large tip and nylon bristles. The other was a Copic Multiliner SP BS (aptly named). The Copic was decent for finer detail work, but the felt tip would rapidly fray, meaning either replacing it (like 3 or 4 bucks) or dealing with it. Finely I was fed up and began looking for other alternatives.I often saw this at the art supply store I shop at, but the lack of detail in the description and the crappy image of a girl on the front always made me pass it up. The image makes it look like its just a pointed felt tip... After researching, I realized that this is just a smaller version of the Color Brush and uses the same nylon bristles. SOLD!After going through two cartridges pretty quickly, I can say that this is easily one of the best pen purchases I've made. The nylon bristles are just the right balance of stiff and soft. It holds its point extremely well (as does the color brush). The amount of control and line variance achieved is just phenomenal. If you do ink work you absolutely need this. Even if you prefer using a standard brush and well, this is invaluable to have on the go for sketching and roughing out your ideas or even quick touch ups if you don't feel like cleaning brushes to just do some quick line work.It's solidly constructed. My single qualm is that the ink cartridges can go pretty quick if you're doing some serious work. They're not outrageously expensive, but I wonder I may just try some Speedball and an eyedropper or needle to refill and see what happens.Overall, this is an amazing brush pen and I cannot recommend it enough!

I wanted a diaper bag that was a little more unisex than many that I've seen. The SWIFT caught my attention as it has a very unassuming look to it and includes the changing pad.The inclusion of the changing pad and the way it integrates into the bag itself is wonderful. No extra pocket space is lost to it.The construction is great. I love that it uses clips instead of Velcro to hold the flap closed. The changing pad folds up very nicely and zips securely on the inside flap. There are two pockets on the outside perfect for bottles or puff containers. A mesh pocket on the inside of the flap works well for ointments and odds and ends. Two diaper pockets are on the inside compartment with plenty of room in the compartment itself for clothes, jackets, etc.Everything is really well put together and it seems like it will last. It's lightweight and not at all bulky. I  extremely happy with this bag.

I got this case for my wife as she upgraded to the Galaxy S6 shortly after it was released. Although three "bumpers" are included, the only color she was interested in was the Black Sapphire.First impression out of the box was that the bumpers do not have a metallic finish that they appear to in the product image. They are pretty basic colored plastic. The Black Sapphire probably should've just been called Black. There's no shimmer to it, it doesnâ€™t have any special tinting or anything, it's flat black plastic.The rubber housing has a much cooler design on the interior of the case, but you will never see it again once your phone is secured. Once on the phone, it fits well, seems secure and is flush with the camera.The bumpers look fine on the phone, however my largest gripe is the poor design of the side buttons. The buttons on the bumper are flush with the plastic. When I was trying to increase her volume it would increase and instantly decrease because the pressure was depressing both volume controls simultaneously. The power/screen lock button works sometimes and not really others, because you donâ€™t feel the button presses itâ€™s difficult to know when youâ€™re actually pressing the button.Overall, the original price point of thirty five is ridiculous. If anything they shouldâ€™ve let you choose the case you wanted (instead of three different colors â€“ two you are never likely to use) and charged twenty. Even with the current price of fifteen, the design is flawed. Iâ€™ll be looking for a new case.

We don't eat a lot of frozen foods in my house, but when we do have them on hand they tend to sit due to the amount of time it takes to preheat an oven and then the amount of time it takes to cook something once it's preheated. I thought the 5-minute pizza oven would be fun to try.Out of the box it is mostly assembled. It's definitely nice looking and if you have a stainless steel kitchen, it will fit right in. However there are some glaring issues. First there is a tray for cooking and a tray for catching crumbs. Neither are labeled and the set up instructions are a blurry picture of the oven with the door open and arrows pointing to parts. The tray for cooking is painted a primer color and has holes drilled in the corners with a raised circle around the diameter which led me to believe it was crumb catching tray. The crumb catching tray is a nice flat piece of metal which led me to believe it was the cooking tray. I was tipped off when the actual cooking tray wouldn't fit right and I scraped some of the finish off of it. It seems they could've just labeled it or provided a better diagram in the pamphlet.The tool that pulls the tray out is supposed to be affixed to the side of the oven. The instructions state to use the included mounting screws to attach it. Once again, no pictures, no idea what I was looking for. I had to go tear through all the packing to find a little pouch with four little black plastic inserts packing taped to the underside of a piece of cardboard. Then most of them didnâ€™t even fit in the hole they were supposed to go in. The holes are too large and the plastic threads on the mounting screws arenâ€™t even all the same size.The tool that pulls the tray out is worthless for two reasons. The first, you have to angle it in such a way that your hand gets very close to the hot surface of the door. Even then it doesnâ€™t do a very good job of latching on. Secondly the pan warps when it gets hot which makes it impossible to actually pull the tray out of the oven. I just gave up on it and started using an oven mitt.In terms of cooking, itâ€™s the only reason Iâ€™m not giving it a one star rating. While it doesnâ€™t actually make a pizza in five minutes (Technically it does it in ten because you have to turn it on for 5 minutes to get the pan hot enough) thatâ€™s still better than a 40 minute average for most pizzas (including oven pre-heating). The food is delicious and there really isnâ€™t a difference between the pizzas and frozen snacks that Iâ€™ve cooked with this versus an oven aside from the speed. Itâ€™s really impressive.Overall, the oven is a mixed bag. While it does its job exceptionally well, design flaws mar the overall package and experience. While the sleek design will make it look at home in the nicest of kitchens, at a hundred and fifty bucks, the cheap design flaws just are not acceptable. If frozen foods are a staple of your household menu and you can live with using an oven mitt instead of the included tool and circumvent the flaws in the instruction manual, this may be a great buy after all.

I had an idea for a novel I had been kicking around for a while. My intention was to create a graphic novel, but I figured I had to write the story anyway, so I decided to write it as a straight novel to begin with. I had started it once a year and after tweaking sentences repeatedly I would eventually just give up. I read some online articles, seeking some guidance, but found most of them to be off-putting as they were overtly pretentious. Seemingly written by "successful" authors - that I'd never heard of - and read with the undertone of, "You're not going to be a successful writer, but I'll throw you a few bones for humor sake." What I was looking for was something simple, digestible and motivational.I found all of this in No Plot? No Problem!Chris Baty isn't writing as a member of some elite novelist club, taking time out of his busy schedule to bestow a few nuggets of wisdom laced with discouragement. He is a man, passionate about writing and â€“ more importantly â€“ writers. His words are empowering, removing the finger-locking intimidation of the blank page.Sit down with the intent to force out a masterpiece in a single go and youâ€™re going to end up with a headache and little more than a blinking cursor. Follow Chrisâ€™ stress-free methods and youâ€™ll be melting your keyboard as your fingers blaze across it. The most surreal part of the experience was when I felt that I was merely watching the story play out in my head, recording what I saw, instead of consciously attempting to figure out what would happen next. This serves as a testament to Batyâ€™s method. Writing my first full-blown novel (53,000 word first draft in 28 days) was an absolute joy! Editing on the other hand, was a little less-so, but it came as no surprise as Baty describes editing as a daunting and time-consuming task in the book.Overall, I canâ€™t say enough good things about this process. I am thankful for this book and Chrisâ€™ guidance through the process. I have finished my novel and begun submitting it. Even if it never sees commercial print, I am filled with the satisfaction achieved in writing my first novel, and I can guarantee that it will not be my last!

I work long hours and get up early in the morning, so making Breakfast and Lunch as simple as possible is always a pro in my mind. Generally I "graze" throughout the day on nutrition bars, sunflower seeds, dried fruit, applesauce etc. My go to bars have been the Bel Vida bars as I find them (fairly) nutritionally sound and filling.As a vegan, I'm familiar with the Vega brand and the only thing that has kept me from trying them in the past is the price tag. I figured I'd give the All-In-One meal bar a shot to see if it's worth adding to my daily grazing routine.The taste is outstanding. It's always a gamble with nutrition bars, but the Vega Chocolate Cherry Almond is fantastic. My wife felt the chocolate was a little "grainy". I can see where she'd feel that way, but I didn't mind it.In terms of overall â€œfullnessâ€ after eating the bar, I would say itâ€™s moderate. I feel satisfied, but not full. I think the Bel Vida bars have more fiber which contributes to them filling me to a more acceptable degree. Iâ€™m 6â€™3â€ and 200 lbs, so those with smaller frames may find this meal bar to fill them more sufficiently.The compact size makes it easy to throw into your briefcase or shoulder bag.Overall, Iâ€™m a fan of the Vega All-In-One Meal Bar. At over three dollars a bar (four dollars if you go off the MSRP) I still donâ€™t know that itâ€™s worth the cost. It really just depends what your budget is and how much nutrition you typically get from other sources. If the price doesnâ€™t make you flinch and youâ€™re looking for a great nutritional meal bar (especially if youâ€™re vegan) this is just about as good as it gets.

I've been using a Bissel for years. It started to lose its effectiveness a year or so ago, so I took it apart, cleaned it up and replaced the belts and brush. While my Bissel's performance seemed to improve, the reviews for this Eureka were so full of praise, I had to see what all the fuss was about.Out of the box, my first impression was that the parts seem a little cheap. Everything is plastic for the most part. Then, when I stopped to think about it, I realized that I don't beat the crap out of my vacuum when I use it, so who cares if it's lacking heavy metal parts that make it more difficult to maneuver the vacuum?Assembly was quick and easy.In terms of performance, I was blown away. Or sucked away? Either way, the suction is phenomenal. You can see the carpet lift as you go over it. I had vacuumed the week prior to using this vacuum and was shocked at how much it still picked up. We had a corner where our dog used to pee prior to being housebroken where the carpet had become coarse from overly shampooing and treating with cleaners. A little carpet powder and a few passes with this vacuum and itâ€™s just as soft if it ever was. I cannot recommend the performance of this vacuum enough.In terms of the construction. Itâ€™s a solid unit with mostly plastic parts. Iâ€˜ve rammed a few couch legs and sideswiped an entertainment center or two (I may lack a certain finesse when I clean, Iâ€™ll admit it) and all the parts are still holding strong. Considering thatâ€™s about the extent of the punishment I expect a vacuum to receive, Iâ€™m not concerned with its longevity. The advantage of the plastic parts is that the unit is unbelievably light and a joy to maneuver around your living space.Overall, for the price and performance, youâ€™re not going to find a better vacuum out there.

I've owned my share of bluetooth speakers. My chief complaint with those this small in stature has always been that the peak volume leaves much to be desired and the low range is barely existent.I'd never heard of the brand RND, but decided to try this model out anyway.Aesthetically, it's a nice unit. Glossy black finish, the light up touch controls on the top are a nice touch, overall it's small and sleek. My one complaint is that, when charging, there is no indicator light. I'm assuming its being charged because the battery has never run out on me, but I'm not sure when it's charging, or when itâ€™s completed its charge.The batter life is ample. I can get an 8 hour shift out of it, no problem.Sound is impressive for a unit this size. The max volume is much better than similar sized units I have used. You're probably not going to be able to use it to DJ a party or anything, but it's still more than adequate for standard use. The low end is also impressive. There's apparently two speakers in the unit and the enclosure is well designed so that the bass reverberates well and projected clearly.Overall. This is the best unit around the fifty dollar mark that Iâ€™ve used. Aside from the annoyance that is the absence of the charging light, this is a quality product.

When I first saw this, I was excited to see if it could fill the need to have a simple, small, portable device that could be used for quick informal sessions to capture the rough ideas without all the hassles of plugging in and dragging a ton of equipment with you. I wanted something for small groups or when Iâ€™m trying to work out ideas quickly.Out of the box, it's a quick set up. There are all of the usual pieces that one would expect. Chord to use USB for power, batteries, and connectors to use the recorder with a microphone stand. Foam muter for the microphones if needed. If you have any familiarity with these types of devices (mine is limited) you'll be recording in no time.After a few hours of use, I found that the device filled the need - it's light and portable. Great for quick recording of ideas or working out song parts (I used it mostly to record guitars).  Keeps the chords and hassle down to a minimum.  To this end, one of the best (and worst) parts of the device is that you can control it (sort of) from your phone.On the surface, it's a great idea - I wanted the device to almost disappear - so as I was recording, I could quickly use it - but when I wasn't, it wasn't in the way or needed elaborate set up/tear down. A quick download from the app store, and you have an app that will control most of the functions on the device. This really increases the usefulness - you can control it from across the room. No need to touch it to switch modes or inputs. This is a great feature.However, there are two major drawbacks to the app. First, it covers MOST functions - not all. I'm sure these are "buggy" issues that can be fixed, but simple commands - like deleting or clearing tracks - aren't available on the app. You have to be on the device. In full disclosure, the instructions clearly advise you to learn the device prior to using the app, even though they are supposed to be mirrors. Would have saved me some frustration as I spent a lot of time looking for functionality that wasn't on the app. I would have known that, had I started with the device.  The second (and this is minor), the phone can only be connected to the device. So it removes your ability to connect to the internet when you are controlling the device. It saves you the trouble of hooking in to a router with the device, but, if like me, you are constantly using the internet to find things, answer questions, etc, it's a little bit of an irritant.The only other negative I've found is that it's not as intuitive as it could be. Again, I'm by no means a professional when it comes to recording devices. However, almost anything that I wanted to do, I could do. It just took me a lot of looking and guessing through menus to find them. Not the end of the world, but a little bit of a nuisance issue in the beginning.Overall, the device filled a need for quick recording and portability.  I found myself working more on what I was playing than being focused on the capture process. Seems like the kind of device that you can throw on the table next time friends come over and easily capture the spirit of what was played, to be cleaned up later. Sound quality was good, but not professional - but that's to be expected from a handheld. I was not disappointed. Plenty of inputs - from the built in microphones to 2 quarter inch / xlr's. Gives you a lot of options, though again switching between these input sources requires a little bit of work. I will not use this for everything that I do, but for what I wanted it for, I will use it constantly and am pleased with the results so far.

I have an iPhone 5 that this obviously will not work with. However, I have a Galaxy S Blaze that I no longer use. I thought it would be nice to repurpose the Blaze as a thermal imager.Wrong. According to the Play Store, the App is not compatible with my older version of Android. My Galaxy Tab doesn't have a micro USB. My advice would be to make sure you can install the app prior to buying this item as the item description makes no mention of compatibility (or incompatibility with Android OS versions.)I downloaded the App on my iPhone 5 to at least give you a review of the ease of use and overall design. My first impression is that they seem to want a lot of information for a thermal imaging camera. The first request is your location (denied), the second is access to my photo library (pretty sure you canâ€™t detect heat in pictures already taken â€“ denied), the last was access to my camera (probably need that â€“ allowed). Next they want you to sign up and login. Why do I need to sign in to a thermal imager? Nope.Regardless of signing up you still need to accept the Terms & Conditions. The bit in the Terms & Conditions that I enjoyed the most is the part where Seek has irrevocable, perpetual, world-wide etc etc etc license to do anything they want with your User Content (photos) include â€œReproduce, fix, adapt, modify, improve, sellâ€¦.etcâ€ So if they want to take your images and Photoshop them to make them look better than the camera is capable of to sell units, they can.The Privacy Policy states â€œWe may also enter into agreements or arrangements with third party good or service providers who agree to receive your personally identifiable information from us for purposes of cross-marketing or making offers to you of Third Party Providersâ€™ products or services. You agree that we can provide your personally identifiable information to Third Pary Providers, subject to the requirements in this Privacy Policy.  All Third Party Providers have entered into agreements with us where they agree to not disclose your name and email information to any third partiesâ€ So, weâ€™ll sell your information, but the people weâ€™re selling it to pinky-swore that they wonâ€™t.Good thing no one reads those things, huh?The point is, I never agreed or signed in. Thatâ€™s a lot of red tape for a device that is just supposed to take some heat-map pictures and not worth it for me for the one time Iâ€™ll probably use it. Whether you feel itâ€™s worth it is up to you.

Like many people, I was irritated that all of my PS3 bluetooth headsets did not work with the PS4 including a very expensive 7.1 PGL Turtle Beach set. I refused to invest another few hundred dollars into a compatible headset. Up until this point I was using a pair of Turtle Beach earbuds designed for portable gaming as they were relatively comfortable compared to the earpiece included with the PS4. Although, anything that doesn't feel like you jammed a rock in your ear is comfortable in comparison.I saw the PDP Afterglow set and was drawn in by the abundance of cushion, the wireless feature, the "boomless" mic and the stand/charger setup. The price was fair and so I took the leap. While this is compatible with both the PS3 and PS4, I will be referencing the PS4. There should be zero difference in performance or setup however.Set up was simple. Plug the included USB cable and Digital Optical cable into the PS4 and into the stand. Turn the headset on, but depressing the button on the left "can". Both the stand and headset should glow blue. If you haven't already, go into the sound settings on your PS4 and follow the instructions, changing a few settings. Youâ€™re done. The sound/chat will output through the headset and the sound will also still output through the TV.The headset is very comfortable. The padding is firm and ample and I experienced no discomfort or overheating during hours of play.The sound is rich and full. There is a hint of surround sound, but not nearly as dynamic as my more expensive headsets. I didnâ€™t expect much as these are marked as stereo only. So based on how they are advertised, they perform very well. There are only two sound options, normal and Deep Bass. The Deep Bass through off the balance of the sounds so, unless maybe youâ€™re listening to just music, I would leave it set to normal.The lightshow is pretty, you can select several colors or have them cycle through the colors repeatedly. Iâ€™m not generally one for flashy tech, but you can turn the light off and theyâ€™re not overly gaudy.So why the two star rating? The boomless mic is garbage. I tried multiple times to use it whilst playing Warframe with friends and they were unable to hear me. At one point I heard them discussing that they thought I was â€œAFKâ€ but didnâ€™t say where I was going. Such a letdown! These wouldâ€™ve easily earned a 5 star rating with the price, presentation, sound performance and comfort taken into consideration. But I have zero use for a headset if no one can hear me.

My wife has been looking for a food processor for a while. We weren't sure whether to go with a large do-it-all model or something more compact. Ultimately, we decided on this small glass bowl chopper. Mostly that decision was because it reminded me of a motorized version of a manual chopper we have.It was larger than anticipated. Setup is a breeze out of the box. It works wonderfully. My wife was making a casserole and she quartered a whole onion and threw it in the chopper. Almost instantly the onion was obliterated. She was pleased because she has apparently become more sensitive to the hateful onion vapors lately.My concern with getting a smaller unit was the ability to chop efficiently. It had no issues, the motor is very powerful and the blades are very sharp. The other advantage is the sound. Itâ€™s very quiet. I would say it produces less noise than our hand held coffee grinder or our blender. It only takes a couple bursts to achieve the desired result.Two things that I wouldnâ€™t necessarily consider cons, but just observations. Because of the size, the blade armature is mostly blade, so be very cautious when cleaning it. Lastly, I really wanted to be able to toss all the ingredients to make pico de gallo in at once so I could have instant pico (itâ€™s the little things, ya know?) Unfortunately, while the glass bowl is ample, itâ€™s not ample enough for instant pico unless youâ€™re settling for a very small serving.Overall, Iâ€™m very happy with the purchase and I donâ€™t think weâ€™ll be in the market for another food processor for some time.

I purchased this album via iTunes after watching the film. $10 for 31 tracks was a deal and I loved the sound of the fictional band the Soronprfbs. I went in with the expectation that, because the Soronprfbs were credited on the bulk of the soundtrack, they had recorded full length/studio versions of the songs and mixed them properly for the soundtrack. I was largely mistaken.I don't think this was an unrealistic expectation, mind you. Films like: Scott Pilgrim vs. the World, Suck, Get Him to the Greek and the TV series - Flight of the Conchords all feature soundtracks will full-length studio recordings by the actors as the band even though they were featured only in bits and pieces in their respective films. All of those soundtracks are great and well worth the purchase.However, the Frank soundtrack is a missed opportunity in this regard. Allow me to break down the tracks into categories to assist in illustrating my point.Tracks that are just random snippets of partial songs or speaking from the movie:1. Jon's Crap Songs2. Ginger Crouton (they try to sort of add an ending to it, but not very well)4. Lay an Egg11. Idiot Shriek13. Again14. Jon's Song Changed by Frank and ClaraTracks that are just instrumental intros/outros/transitional generally less than a minute:3. Welcome to Vetno5. Frank's Dawn Chorus8. Work Begins in Ernest12. The Holiday Makers17. Viking Funeral18. Just Like Paris Texas19. Sxsw22. The Music's Sh!t23. #FindfrankTracks that could be considered full length Soronprfbs songs:7. Lone Standing Tuft9. Creaky Door15. Secure the Galactic Perimeter16. Broken21. Frank's Most Likeable Song...Ever (I'm reaching a little here because it's 34 seconds, but well worth it)25. I Love You All26. I Love You All (Credits)27. All Broken (Credits)28. Tuft (Credits)29. Frank's Cacophony30. Stop Sign31. I Love You All (Radio Mix)Tracks that are full length songs, but not really performed by the full Soronprfbs10. Be Still (Don's Song)20. I'm Just Me (Personally, I really dislike this song)24. Lighthouse KeeperSo, that being said, there are twelve tracks that are actually what I was looking for. Look again though and you will see that I Love You All appears 3 times on the soundtrack, Broken appears twice and Tuft also appears twice. This takes the total unique track count down to 8. As I mentioned, Frank's Most Likeable Song...Ever is 34 seconds and hilarious if you've seen the movie, but hardly a song in its own right. Frank's Cacophony is not nearly as digestible as the other songs and Stop Sign is easily dismissed.In my opinion, if you're looking at this album, you may want to cherry pick the individual tracks:15. Secure the Galactic Perimeter26. I Love You All (Credits)27. All Broken (Credits)28. Tuft (Credits)Let me close by stating that the actors in this film did a phenomenal job creating this music. Michael Fassbender's vocal quality and range blew me away. If he ever fronts an actual band, I'll be first in line for the album. This fact only makes the lackluster presentation of the soundtrack that much more disappointing. If the soundtrack had been in line with the 4 songs I recommended, it'd be five stars all day long. However, there is enough "filler" that I'm forced to give it 3 stars as a whole.

I decided that I wanted to get a power washer for odd jobs around the house. I was primarily looking for something that I can clean my siding, clean the garage floor/driveway and wash my car with. I selected the AR Blue Clean because of all the positive reviews and the affordable price tag.I've never owned a pressure washer before, so the thought of setting it up was a little intimidating. I was relieved to see that it is mostly together out of the box and following the clear instructions made it a snap. First impression, this thing is built solid. I'm a big fan of the metal braided hose. I'm a bit of a clutz and notorious for not putting things away properly, so the durability of the hose should definitely add to the longevity.I love the included "wand" attachment. This makes washing your car a breeze. Reminds me of the quarter-fed do-it-yourself bays at the carwashes when I first got my license. I'll be saving all sorts of money without having to take both our cars to the carwash.I'm thrilled that it has a detergent tank. This makes washing the cars and windows even better considering I don't have to hassle with the buckets and sponges first. I'm not sure if the detergent tank has been fairly common among pressure washers in the past, so this may not be a major revelation for anyone, but I certainly appreciate it.There's a myriad of nozzles included to handle any job. Although I don't necessarily feel like the holes hold the nozzles very firm. Maybe I'm just being paranoid.The hose reel and cord wrap are great, I have a small(ish) garage so it's nice that I can keep all the necessities with the washer and still use minimal space.Overall, I can't attest to any professionl or industrial applications for this pressure washer. However, as an average homeowner using this for various odd cleaning jobs, I couldn't be happier. The price point is great, and (so far) the quality is very impressive!

I do various art projects throughout the year and so I thought this would be a nice set to use with metal. On first inspection I was very satisfied with the weight and overall construction of these bits. They are smooth, precise and have a nice weight to them. On the inside groove are all the diameters listed so it's very simple to know which bit you require and how far to drill.I was pleased that the 2 smaller bits clicked right in to my Black & Decker VPX screwdriver. The 3 largest bit fit perfectly in my standard hand drill. The largest did not, but I assume that is for more industrial drills. While the bits are weighty, they did not throw off the balance of the screwdriver or the drill.I used these on aluminum, don't usually work with anything more substantial than that and they tore right through. Each time leaving a perfectly round, clean hole. There was some slipping on the surface of aluminum cans, but that's not altogether surprising as they are curved and slicked with the label. Overall, this is a quality drill bit set and I'm anxious to try some tougher metals in the future.

I used to be in a band during my high school years. While that never really panned out, I still like to play the guitar every once and awhile. I thought this would be a cool little device to record myself to see if I look as ridiculous as I think I do and maybe record a few covers.Set up is super easy. You open the box and plug the included lightning cable into your phone and then into the device. Launch the app (Impact by Focusrite, downloaded from the appstore for free) and you're ready to go. You can plug your instrument directly into the audio jack or you can just use the microphone if you're using a piano or acoustic guitar, or would just rather use your own amp/effects pedals/etc.Once you're done you can edit, upload to social networking sites, etc.The sound quality really impressed me. I like the app, it's actually ridiculously user friendly and easy to edit your videos. I was a little concerned at how cumbersome video editing on a phone would be, it's not, the app is great!The other feature I really like is that it runs off your iPhone's battery. While, yes, it does drain your iPhone faster, I appreciate that I don't have to carry around a separate cord or be situated close to an outlet. You can just throw this in your guitar case or bag. It's very small and light.My only qualm is that the slot that your iPhone sits in will not accomodate the extra bulk from a case. So when you want to use this, you need to remove your phone from its case. It's not a deal breaker, but it is annoying.Overall there are two reasons you should be looking at this:1. You're a singer/songwriter who's looking for an easy way to make videos showcasing your talent.2. You're a performer who's looking to critique your performing abillities.

Currently, when I use a sketchbook, I use Copic Multiliner SP pens and Copic Markers. While the pens alone lay down perfect/even lines on the cheapest of paper without bleed-through, the markers do not. I generally keep a backing board with me to slide under the paper I'm working on. The back of the page looks like a unicorn yacked all over it, but it keeps the next page clean. Honestly, I never use the back of pages anyway.However, I recently started experimenting with quills and calligraphy pens (namely Pilot brand) and those go through standard sketchbook paper like it's a coffee filter. Which is understandable, sketchbooks are really just made for sketching (i.e. dry media) but it's still annoying. I remember seeing the RendR brand in my local Blick store so I swung by to pick it up.First impression; "You want HOW MUCH for a 48 page sketchbook?!?!" Yeah, they're expensive, but if you're used to using professional quality art materials, you're used to throwing some serious money down for them. I felt like if it solved my issues, it'd be worth it. I bit the bullet, grabbed one off the shelf and brought it home.Sat down got out my pen and touched it to the paper. I sat, watching in disappointment as my .5mm dot quickly spread into a .75mm starburst. You've got to be kidding me... I flipped the paper over, nothing had bled through. So, while it does what it says, there is zero excuse in my book for feathering like that. Art is about controlling your medium with precision and this paper does not allow you to do that, at least not with quill ink.I got out my trusty Multiliners. No feathering and no bleeding. Great! Unfortunately, regular "cheap" sketchbook paper does neither with the Multiliners so no big deal there.The real test was for the Copic Markers. I started coloring in a few quick sketches, layering and saturating. Surprisingly, no bleed and no feathering. The back of the page is free from single-horned-pony bile and completely dry.So what's the verdict? Well, I guess you need to ask yourself, "What am I going to use this for?". Copic Multiliner SPs (and I assume their trailer park cousin; Micron) and Copic Markers are safe. Pilot calligraphy inks are not. You may want to read other reviews if you have something else in mind.Honestly, if the Copic Markers had bled or feathered this would be a one star all the way. The price is pretty excessive and it doesn't perform as well as it'd like you to believe.

The back of the page is free from single-horned-pony bile and completely dry.So what's the verdict? Well, I guess you need to ask yourself, "What am I going to use this for?". Copic Multiliner SPs (and I assume their trailer park cousin; Micron) and Copic Markers are safe. Pilot calligraphy inks are not. You may want to read other reviews if you have something else in mind.Honestly, if the Copic Markers had bled or feathered this would be a one star all the way. The price is pretty excessive and it doesn't perform as well as it'd like you to believe.

Currently, when I use a sketchbook, I use Copic Multiliner SP pens and Copic Markers. While the pens alone lay down perfect/even lines on the cheapest of paper without bleed-through, the markers do not. I generally keep a backing board with me to slide under the paper I'm working on. The back of the page looks like a unicorn yacked all over it, but it keeps the next page clean. Honestly, I never use the back of pages anyway.However, I recently started experimenting with quills and calligraphy pens (namely Pilot brand) and those go through standard sketchbook paper like it's a coffee filter. Which is understandable, sketchbooks are really just made for sketching (i.e. dry media) but it's still annoying. I remember seeing the RendR brand in my local Blick store so I swung by to pick it up.First impression; "You want HOW MUCH for a 48 page sketchbook?!?!" Yeah, they're expensive, but if you're used to using professional quality art materials, you're used to throwing some serious money down for them. I felt like if it solved my issues, it'd be worth it. I bit the bullet, grabbed one off the shelf and brought it home.Sat down got out my pen and touched it to the paper. I sat, watching in disappointment as my .5mm dot quickly spread into a .75mm starburst. You've got to be kidding me... I flipped the paper over, nothing had bled through. So, while it does what it says, there is zero excuse in my book for feathering like that. Art is about controlling your medium with precision and this paper does not allow you to do that, at least not with quill ink.I got out my trusty Multiliners. No feathering and no bleeding. Great! Unfortunately, regular "cheap" sketchbook paper does neither with the Multiliners so no big deal there.The real test was for the Copic Markers. I started coloring in a few quick sketches, layering and saturating. Surprisingly, no bleed and no feathering. The back of the page is free from single-horned-pony bile and completely dry.So what's the verdict? Well, I guess you need to ask yourself, "What am I going to use this for?". Copic Multiliner SPs (and I assume their trailer park cousin; Micron) and Copic Markers are safe. Pilot calligraphy inks are not. You may want to read other reviews if you have something else in mind.Honestly, if the Copic Markers had bled or feathered this would be a one star all the way. The price is pretty excessive and it doesn't perform as well as it'd like you to believe.
