I feel that my early faith in Mr. Tabor's growth as a novelist has been well -rewarded, and I shall be looking forward to his next offering with even more anticipation and enthusiasm.

Yasuko Hanaoka is a single mother just trying to get ahead.  She's finally working a more respectable job and raising her teenage daughter, Misato, as best she can.  Her sleazy ex-husband, Togashi, is making that difficult.  As much as she tries to distance herself, he keeps coming around, extorting money in order to go away.  This time, however, the altercation becomes physical when Misato hits him.  He attacks the girl, and both mother and daughter wind up in a life-or-death struggle that finds Togashi strangled on the floor.Panicked, the two are discussing Yasuko turning herself into the police when a knock comes at the door.  It is Ishigami, the smitten teacher who lives next-door.  It seems he *will* do anything for Yasuko--including move bodies.  And so a plot is hatched.  Ishigami is much more than a high school math teacher.  At one time, he was a bona fide mathematical genius and it seems he's still got a talent for logic and strategy.  Will it help them all get away with murder?Enter "Detective Galileo," the nickname of physicist Manabu Yukawa.  Yukawa earned his moniker helping out the police on occasional cases.  He's got Holmesian intellect and observational skills, though considerably better people skills than the famed detective.  And, back in their college days, he and Ishigami were friends and rivals.  While Yukawa is not officially on the case, his personal connection draws him in.  But rather than working with Detective Kusanagi, for the first time he seems to be following his own agenda.  Thus begins a high-stakes chess game between two brilliant men.  Says the physicist:"When an amateur attempts to conceal something, the more complex he makes his camouflage, the deeper the grave he digs for himself.  But not so a genius.  The genius does something far simpler, yet something no normal person would even dream of, the last thing a normal person would think of doing.  And from this simplicity, immense complexity is created."I'm not generally a huge fan of police procedurals, but this one had a lot going for it.  At the very top of the list is the plotting.  The cat-and-mouse aspect to the investigation kept tension ratcheted--especially as readers knew exactly how the murder went down from the novel's opening pages.  But each of these men had surprises up their sleeves, and the dÃ©nouement was a thing of beauty.  Also, this was largely a crime of self-defense (apparently not a big concept in the Japanese legal system, as it was never brought up once as a mitigating factor), and therefore the perpetrators were quite sympathetic.  As a reader, at times it was hard to know who to root for--and that's just interesting.  This was definitely not a black and white crime novel.Character development is a little trickier.  I always have some trouble getting a feel for Japanese characters simply due to cultural differences.  And whatever the culture, Ishigami is not your average Joe.  I liked Yukawa quite a lot, but can't say that I feel he's a wildly unique creation.  At least not yet.  Author Keigo Higashino has had a second Detective Galileo mystery published in English, Salvation of a Saint.  As I was reading, I thought to myself, This must not be the first novel in the series.  But checking Wikipedia, it appears there were only a series of short stories featuring the character prior to this novel.  Additionally, there's a third novel in the series not yet released in America.  Based on this introduction, I'd be very open to further investigations.

...The openings of his novels are always grabbers.  In The Cloud, protagonist Nat Idle is waiting to catch a late-night train when an enormous drunken man staggers into him.  They both crash to the ground, with Nat very nearly thrown to the tracks in front of an oncoming train.  A near-death experience instead becomes a nasty crack on the head, and a kind passerby rushes to assist.  The drunk takes off, with a paper falling from his pocket as he exits.  Nat's ready to write the incident off, grateful to have gotten off relatively lightly--until he picks up the paper the man dropped.  His name is on it.  This was no accident.That is merely the beginning of another of Idle's investigative adventures.  For a medical journalist and blogger, he does seem to become embroiled in some dark stuff.  This story involves a technology designed to help kids learn to multi-task that may be causing a far more serious side effect.  And yet, as intense of the plots of these novels are, at their heart they are character-driven, and none more so than this latest installment.  Character absolutely drives plot, but in this case, prior knowledge of the character from his debut in Hooked or Devil's Plaything would be helpful.  Nat sustains a head injury in that opening scene.  It affects him.  He's not himself, and I think that will be appreciated more by readers acquainted with the character.  Nat's funny, friendly, flawed, and fallible.  He'll go after a story like no one's business.  But in The Cloud, he's altered.  And he's something of an unreliable narrator, which makes an already convoluted mystery that much more mysterious.Mr. Richtel, incidentally, is also a journalist.  By day, he writes about technology for the New York Times.  He, in fact, won a Pulitzer Prize for doing so a few years ago.  My point is, the man can write.  His prose has an effortless readability, a sense of fun, and frequently rises above what one expects to find in a thriller.  The novel moves swiftly, as events take place over the course of just a few virtually sleepless days.  Furthermore, by the time all is revealed, the elegance and intricacy of the novel's plot will become apparent.  Oh, I had suspicions along the way.  Some were right, many were wrong.  But once I knew the truth, it was all so clear.  The clues were salted everywhere.Richtel didn't learn about character development, pacing, and plot on the day job.  I'm not sure where he learned the tools of his trade, because in this novel especially, he eschews literary convention while at the same time embracing certain genre tropes, for instance a beautiful and mysterious woman straight out of a detective noir.  Tropes are tropes for a reason, and Richtel has his fun.  But it's where he diverges from convention, notably with this novel's conclusion, that things get really interesting.  I can't discuss the choices made without spoilers, so I'll simply say that Mr. Richtel wrapped up his mystery in a way that was unexpected, unconventional, sophisticated, and satisfying.And aside from solving the mystery, Mr. Richtel has taken his protagonist into uncharted territory.  The tale comes to a complete conclusion with no annoying cliff-hangers, but Nat evolves so much (and so believably) in this novel that I'm now consumed with knowing what the next chapter in his life will bring.

I love letters--both writing and receiving them.  It's a lost art, and an intimate form of communication.  Perhaps it is these feelings that make me especially receptive to the epistolary novel.  The obvious has only occurred to me recently, but I flat-out love them.  Where'd You Go, Bernadette?; The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society; and The Lawgiver were all favorite reads within the last few months.  Epistolary novels have an unusual structure.  For me, it's just an exceptionally interesting and non-linear way to tell a story.The other thing is, our voices come alive in our correspondence.  Within the first few pages of Frances and Bernard, I'd fallen in love with both of the titular characters.  I could hear their voices so clearly through the letters they wrote.  They were funny, intellectual, literate--no wonder these two hit it off immediately when they met at a writers' colony in 1957.  Frances is a novelist, not yet published, and Bernard, a poet, with a bit more of a track record.  The book follows their correspondence for just over a decade.According to the novel's jacket copy, these two are loosely based upon Flannery O'Connor and Robert Lowell.  May I be honest?  I don't know a thing about these literary progenitors.  I'm sure an intimate knowledge of O'Connor and Lowell's history and work would have added untold richness to my read.  However, my ignorance detracted nothing as far as I can tell, and made their story feel completely fresh and unexpected to me.Truthfully, I'm rather surprised by just how much I liked this debut.  It should be noted that a significant percentage of Frances and Bernard's correspondence with each other deals with matters of Catholicism and faith--not my favorite subject matter.  For me, this tale was ALL about the two central characters that were so beautifully realized by Carlene Bauer.  What is the nature of their connection, and where will it lead?  Bernard writes to his best friend:"You have posited that she may have, your words, a thing for me, but I don't think she does, and I am fairly sure that I don't have one for her.  I kept looking at her from different angles and examining my response.  Various types of affection flared up in her presence, but not romance."Don't expect the typical boy-meets-girl tale.  Later he writes to the same friend, "...she knew me when I was at my most Bernard and I knew her when she was at her most Frances."  I ask you, who wouldn't want to be known like that?

Robert Pobi's second novel, Mannheim Rex, falls firmly within the territory of a literary genre I coined.  I call it "trashy underwater fiction," (TUF) and have ever since I was the editor of a magazine for scuba divers.  There are many subgenres of TUF: killer marine life, mermaids, talking dolphins, undersea city, etc.  Mannheim Rex is of the "lake monster" subgenre.  And I ask you, how can you go wrong?  There's a lake, and you have a monster.  It almost writes itself.Well, let's give credit where credit is due.  I think Mr. Pobi had a hand in this.  After the requisite mysterious fishing death, the novel opens in the New York apartment of a hugely successful horror novelist.  If you stretch your imagination, you can probably think of a real-world counterpart.  Not yet forty, Gavin Corlie has realized the kind of success most men only dream about--but that can't bring his wife back.  Unable to move past his grief, he knows something has to change.  Almost on a whim, he buys a house upstate on Lake Caldasac.There, Corlie begins to find some measure of peace, and begins to make friends--first with Finn, a handicapped thirteen-year-old boy, and then with the local doctor treating him.  But Finn also introduces Gavin to the mysterious goings on at the lake.  The two of them join together on a quest to uncover the truth and to hunt a lake monster.Now, this is all pretty familiar territory to aficionados of TUF, but Pobi's having fun with the genre tropes.  He'll win no literary awards, but I've seen writing that's far worse.  The plot was fairly predictable--especially the identity of the mystery monster--but some scenes (like a certain basement sequence) elevated the material briefly.  The characters were a mixed bag.  Corlie was enjoyable enough, but Finn drove me nuts!  I wanted to punch that little handicapped kid!  He was so annoying.  Also, in addition to the threat in the lake, the novel features a second antagonist.  This character was COMPLETELY over-the-top.  It was actually a little hard to believe what I was reading at times.  The novel's pace was okay, a somewhat surprising fact given the book's inflated 540-page length.Mannheim Rex isn't literature, but if you're reading this review, I don't think that's what you're looking for.  You want to know the best thing about lake monsters?  They can turn out to be almost anything.  I'd not encountered this culprit before, and despite some predictability, Mannheim Rex is a welcome addition to my trashy underwater fiction shelves.

Have you ever seen an ad or read a description of a new product and thought, "Yeah, I gotta try that."  That was the case here.And overall, I was quite impressed with Quaker Real Medleys Cherry Pistachio Oatmeal.  It's a quality product, with generous amounts of fruit and nuts--and not little tiny pieces either.  "Medleys" is a good name because these cups are full of both flavor and texture, and it all blends together nicely.  This sure isn't the bland, flavorless instant oatmeal I grew up with!  The portion is generous.  The packaging, while not compact, is convenient for preparing and eating the oatmeal.  I made mine with low-fat milk rather than water, adding a little extra richness.My only criticism--and this is merely a matter of taste--is that I found the cherry pistachio flavor to be somewhat sweeter than I would prefer.  It's quite sweet, and frankly a little more sugary than I'm generally up for for breakfast.  But if you've got a sweet tooth or are looking for a little AM energy boost, I'd recommend giving Quaker Real Medleys Cherry Pistachio Oatmeal a try.

MicroMachines were made by a company called Galoob, and they are plastic, about half the size of a Hot Wheel. Kids love them because they can take them anywhere since they are so tiny. The company was bought out and sadly dismantled by their largest competitor in the late 1990's, so to find them in their original packaging is rare, as there is already a booming market in used individual cars. The MicroMachines line of toys were hugely popular in their time, and well known for their tiny scale miniature size. After about 15 years or so, they could not withstand against the competition of cheap import copies that flooded the market trying to exploit the popularity of these toys.Each miniature vehicle car would only be an inch and a half long or so. This set includes a tiny Gas Tanker Truck and 1949 Mercury, a towtruck plus 2 tiny mechanic figures . The company also made playsets to use the cars in. You might also like the Heavy Haulers set, the Mass Transit set, or the Public Servants set from Micro Machines.

I bought this book about 5 days ago for my son who wanted to read it on his Samsung Galaxy 2 Tablet, with the Kindle App. He also reads books on the Kindle app on his phone, and I do the same. We were disappointed to find out that the video extras that are part of the digital copy of the book did not work on any of these devices. Yesterday we bought the same book on Google Play store, and the audio/video function works fine. I have never had any trouble before with a book on Kindle, but then this is the first one with audio and video. Interestingly, there is not a refund or return function for this product on my orders page, so we are stuck with it. Perhaps Amazon will notice and fix the app in a future update.As for the book, he loves it and would recommend to anyone. He really likes the extra videos.

This is a short and small 64 page page mini booklet with black and white photos from 1973, reprinted from the original 1968 edition. It is 7" x 5". The series of books among collectors are valued today from $3 on average up to $9 for a perfect mint unread copy. If you see copies for more than that, keep shopping.It is part of a series of 21 titles known as the "Garcia Outdoor Library", or Garcia Fishing Books, and they have titles for both fresh and salt water fishing. The books were written by different authors for the series. One of the best books in the series for starting out as a freshwater fisherman is "Introduction to Freshwater Fishing" by Milt Rosko. Milt wrote 4 books for the series, and Mark Sosin wrote 5 of the titles. There were about 3 titles in the series specific to freshwater Bass, and some were specific to a type of fish such as trout, or a series of fish such as pan fish. The only difference with the newer editions was a new cover art painting, both the original and reprint art were painted by Ken Rice. Since Garcia made the famous Ambassadeur reels, Mitchell 300 reel, Abu-Matic reel, Fly reels, Pak Rod, Conolon fishing rods, and Garcia lures, every booklet features one of their products on the front and rear endpapers, the rear of the book usually lists about half the books in the series. Garcia also produced the much larger (8.5" x 11" and 80 pages), more collectible "Garcia Fishing Annual" during this time period.They are nice nostalgic books, pocket size to fit in your vest or tackle bag. Most of the information in each book holds up well today, most changes in fishing are in the modernization of equipment/tackle more than technique. As a collector of vintage fishing equipment that likes to use what he collects, I find even much of the old stuff still works well. For example I use a couple of vintage Garcia Mitchell reels, their 300 and 308 models that were made in France.There was also a series of eight (8) Garcia Shooting Books for hunters, and one (1) Garcia book on backpacking.

I needed a call blocker, as the one built in to my phone maxes out at 25 numbers. Somehow telemrketers have been calling, even though I am the Do Not Call list. I tried this app in my Samsung phone. I have not been happy with it. It freezes up, and often have to Force Stop. It crashes at the worst times, and I have deleted it from my phone. Still looking.

A short little book that touches on the history and culture of barbershops. Nice little stories about individual barbers and shops. Some entertaining stories, and fun stuff. I enjoyed it and it left me wanting more. I think the book is going in the right direction, but I would have liked more. But then I am a fan of old barber stuff, and this may be just right for the casual reader. No pictures, but has a few old drawings from barber school textbooks.

I get a lot of junk telemarketer calls. My phone allows me to auto-reject numbers, but only 25 of them. I have already had enough of these call me that I needed a way to blacklist some other numbers. This app was very easy to install, and simple to set up. It needed a few permissions, but nothing that was out of bounds with what the app is supposed to do. However, it does force close quite a bit on my phone. In order to add a number to be blocked, you have to open the app, then manually type in the screen to this tiny little box, where you can barely see the numbers. Another problem it after using for a month, now it says I had to be logged in the Amazon Appstore in order for it to work, which never was an issue before. I deleted the app and will keep looking for another.

I bought this bag in early 2010. I really prefer using a soft sided tackle bag after trying a few different things over the years including hard tackle boxes and boxes with stacks of trays/boxes inside, and this is the first new one I have bought in a long time. My last bag was an old soft duffle bag I had re-purposed, this bag is actually designed for fishing. I looked at many bags at Amazon.com, auction sites and fishing gear sites before choosing this bag. For one thing, tackle boxes and bags have gotten very expensive, so price was one of my considerations in choosing a new tackle bag for fishing. For the price this bag was really affordable compared to other bags I looked at. Once I chose which bag I wanted, the best price was here at Amazon, especially with shipping.I fish with bait, lures, flies, and the fish I seek out are trout, bass, perch, kokanee salmon, catfish and bluegill. I wanted a tackle bag that would hold everything but my rod, net, and lunch. But with this bag I can still strap the net to the outside of the bag, and slip my lunch and thermos inside so it exceeded my expectations, without carrying a big monster bag. If I break my rod down, I can strap it to the top as well. I also looked at the type of bags that come with nice big Plano style tackle boxes for lures inside, but the boxes always fill the entire bag and they are too big for me. I already have plenty of boxes, prefer to handpick my boxes, and I use a variety of smaller Plano type boxes and fly boxes. Each box is dedicated to different varieties of fish or types of fishing that I can switch out before a trip as I need them. Another reason I do not like to use big tackle boxes, is that just one careless bump or kick from me when its open and my gear is dumped everywhere. I planned to buy a bag in a reasonable size because if I have a bigger one, it is too tempting for me to load too much stuff and then its gets heavy. I fish from both the shore and boat, so I needed a bag I could carry back and forth. I found this one to be very comfortable when its full in size and shape, and the padded strap and handles helps.It has a padded shoulder strap, and it still leaves my hands free. It also has 2 short handles for carrying by hand. This one is just the right size for me. It has a waterproof nylon interior, and a hard interior bottom to maintain the shape of the bag. The bag is waterproof, whichj does not mean you can fill it with water, it means if you splash it the inside stays dry and the water does not harm the bag. It seems to resist stains and tears very well. It still looks new after heavy use this year.FEATURES: It came with a bunch of adjustable velcro dividers for the main interior compartment that allow you to lay out the inside any way you like. I used about half of them. It has a clear pocket on the interior lid for papers and electronic devices. The exterior of the same lid has a cable net to hold your coat, gloves, hat, rod tube or a net. The strap D-rings have room to clip items on. It has nice exterior pockets all the way around, the back side is one long mesh pocket that runs down the whole bag. It has a tool pocket one the front that has 3 elastic mini compartments inside, a big area, and another zippered area, exterior bandolier type things, carabiner clips, and a small zippered pocket for your license. One side has a mesh water bottle pocket on the side with a strap, D-rings and a pocket with a velcro lid. The opposite side has a large pocket, that for me fits 8 bottles of bait. It has a comfortable padded shoulder strap that clips onto D-rings, it and the dividers were bundled inside and had to be installed, which takes a few seconds at most.SIZE: Measures 16 inches long x 12.7 inches wide x 16 x 11.2 inches tall. Very light, it weighs just under 1 pound.PICS: I added 4 pictures of my bag to this page in addition to the 1 picture Amazon has, so you can see the top and the back of the bag, interior, pockets, the handles and padded shoulder strap. I almost didn't buy this bag for the previous lack of good pictures here. I posted my pics with the bag empty and also with my gear loaded in it, it was hard to get a realistic feel for the size and capacity with the sellers pic so I hope this helps you figure out if this is the type of bag for you or not.NOTE: I see the seller at this page copied over my pictures from another page at Amazon. Same bag so no problem.Everybody has different tastes in fishing gear, this one works great for me and was affordable compared to similar bags.UPDATE: December 2011. It is now two fishing seasons that I have used this bag. It has proved to be very durable, no problems with zippers, straps, or pockets, no tears. The material still looks new. It has proved very useful, and I am still impressed and glad I bought this bag.

This is a Micro Machines floating toy boat set. It makes for a great bath or wading pool toy. It goes perfect with the Exploration Sea floating playsets from the same company, such as Micro Machines Tex's Drill Dock, Tiger Shark Landing, Lost Treasure Pirate Lagoon, Off-Shore Riggers Set, or Gator Island. You might still find these on Amazon with a search.The boats and vehicles from Micro Machines are micro sized, tiny collectible toys about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels. This set is similar to the #1 Shark Hunters set of vehicles from Micro Machines,but in a different color scheme. This one includes the big shark, the submerging divers shark cage with hook, the floating pontoon helicopter with turning blades that can pick up the shark cage, and the deep sea fishing ship with turning radar . Each has moving parts.The company that made this was bought out and closed by a major competitor in 1998, this rare toy was made in 1997 and is now a "vintage collectible toy".

Each has moving parts.The company that made this was bought out and closed by a major competitor in 1998, this toy was made in 1997 and is now a "vintage collectible toy".

This is a Micro Machines playset, one of the few that actually floats. It is a based on a secret bayou swamp island. It makes for a great wading pool toy or bath toy. It is a playset, and you can buy the accessory boats to go with it such as Micro Machines Exploration Swamp Ambush, Shark Patrol #2 Collection, Pirate Marauders #3 or Exploration Treasure Hunters #1 Collection. The boats and vehicles from Micro Machines are micro sized, tiny collectible toys about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels. This set includes a lagoon between two floating island with a bridge between the islands. A bayou canoe is included that really floats. The island is loaded with features such as a removable water cup to work the water features, like the working water wheel and rainwater bucket with spout. It also has a bayou shanty, working drawbridge, a falling tree trunk, quicksand platform, hollow log tunnel, a boat dock, a canal, and 2 alligators.The company that made this was bought out and closed by a major competitor in 1998, this toy was made in 1997 and is now a "vintage collectible toy", but there are still some collectible sets out there for sale.

This is a Micro Machines floating boat set. It makes for a great bath or wading pool toy. It goes perfect with the Exploration Sea floating playsets from the same company, such as Micro Machines Tiger Shark Landing, Lost Treasure Pirate Lagoon, Off-Shore Riggers Set, or Gator Island. You might still find these on Amazon with a search.The boats and vehicles from Micro Machines are micro sized, tiny collectible toys about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels. This set includes a Pirate Frigate, the Jolly Roger Submarine, and the the Sailing Yacht that they capture. Each has moving parts and floats.The company that made this was bought out and closed by a major competitor in 1998, this toy was made in 1997 and is now a "vintage collectible toy".

This is a Micro Machines floating boat and airplane set. It makes for a great bath or wading pool toy. It goes perfect with the Exploration Sea floating playsets from the same company, such as Micro Machines Tiger Shark Landing, Lost Treasure Pirate Lagoon, Off-Shore Riggers Set, or Gator Island. You might still find these on Amazon with a search.The boats and vehicles from Micro Machines are micro sized, tiny collectible toys about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels. This set includes a Salvage Barge, a Seaplane and the Retrieval Submarine. Each has moving parts.The company that made this was bought out and closed by a major competitor in 1998, this toy was made in 1997 and is now a "vintage collectible toy".

These tiny scale miniature military toys are very hard to find now, company went out of business in 1999. They made very small scale, but nicely detailed miniatures. This set includes 2 soldier figures, an M1A1 Abrams tank with a rotating gun turret and gun that raises. Next is the M270 Missile Launcher, the launch raises and pivots like the real thing. Last is the great AH-64A Apache attack helicopter, the rotor spins. Great looking addition to your MicroMachines army. Pair these with the Micro Machines military playsets for an awesome display. Some collectors have been snapping up the remaining unopened packs that are left out there, but I like to open them.

This is a Micro Machines playset, one of the few that actually floats. It is a based on an oceanic sea park.It makes for a great bath toy. It is a playset, and you can buy the accessory boats to go with it such as Micro Machines Exploration Shark Patrol #2 Collection  or Micro Machines Exploration Treasure Hunters #1 Collection. The boats and vehicles from Micro Machines are micro sized, tiny collectible toys about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels. This set includes a shark toy, and you can put him in the tank and look at him through a built-in scope. It has a sea gate that opens and closes to the shark tank. Also has a skiff boat that floats, and a covered port for the boat and a mooring dock. There is a diving platform that can be moved up and down.The company that made this was bought out and closed by a major competitor in 1998, this toy was made in 1997 and is now a "vintage collectible toy".

Another nice set of Micro Machines cars, plastic vehicles that are highly collectible at 1.5 inches long. The main 5 cars in this set are car show type customs of classic cars, with names like Bel-Aero (a Bel Air); the Rivv (a Buick Riviera), Low Rider ( a classic Impala); Fleetliner and the Starlighter. Also in this set is a classic VW Beetle convertible, a Range Rover, an MG Bradley, a concept car, and a 280Z.  This is a rare set, since the Micro Machines company went out of business in 1999.

Wonderful little book by famous children's author and illustrator Hillary Knight. This book was produced in a tiny gift version in 1963. It is only 4 inches tall, but its big in character. This book was also sold as one of 4 books in the "Nutshell Library" slipcase set. I really recommend this book, the best of the 4 in my opinion. Very charming rewriting of the classic song "the 12 days of Christmas" in a mouse version, as a firefly in a fir tree fits their size much better than a partridge does.

This Batmobile is from the live action Batman movie in 1989 and was in toy stores that year. It is smaller than it looks here, 7" long. This is very old school, great item for collectors. The remote control has a cord that runs to the car, and has forward, reverse, and turns in reverse. The popular feature back then was that the rear turbine lights up. Made by Toy Biz. It takes AA batteries. Very hard to find one of these in original packaging anymore.

This book is an incredible item for collectors of Walt Disney history books. It was published in 1997 in a small run and has not been republished since, and is now extremely rare. This is a limited edition of only 750 copies, signed by the author. It is a hardback binding that is published without a dust jacket. (There is a more affordable version that came in a plastic slipcase. It is huge and thick, one of the heaviest books I have ever owned. It comes with a laid-in insert reproduction of a inter-office envelope from the Walt Disney animation department and a report to Walt inside. It also has a laid-in insert reproduction of an employee organizational chart of the Walt Disney company at the time.This is one of the few books written by an upper management employee who worked on animation, live-action film and television, and even overseas for Walt. The author dealt with Walt at a very different level than an animator would, so this book is quite different from other insider books about Walt or the studio. Harry Tytle brings a very different perspective to his book. He was a producer for Walt Disney Studios, and worked alongside Walt on many projects over the years. He worked his entire career through to retirement at the company, working on film and television projects. This book has very unique stories I have never read anywhere else. I really enjoyed stories about his trips overseas with Walt, planning meetings, problems with staff and directors, and the studio's interaction with film stars like Annette Funicello. I highly recommend to anyone interested in the history of the behind the scenes decision making process at the studio. Good luck finding a copy now, as this book is now rare as hen teeth.

The slogan for the very tiny scale miniature toys was "Think Big, Play Small". The Micro Machines vehicles were about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels, and the company made great playsets like this one to go with them. The playsets usually offered 1 free vehicle included, this one has 2, each about 2" long. This set is huge with collectors, made for a limited run in 1997 and long gone. The wildcat  military toy is about 12" long rolls like any toy vehicle, but then opens up to reveal it carries miniature vehicles that are about 2" long. It has fold down ramps to drive in and out, a vehicle and cargo elevator that works, retractable landing gear, spinning propellors, opening nose cone, and more.

I am a huge Micro Machines collector from way back. Micro Machines are tiny toys, scale miniatures that were made by the Galoob company in the 1980's to when the company closed in 1998. Their toys are still huge with collectors and there are still some unopened toys out there. The little packs of vehicles can easily sell for over $50, and some playsets can sell for $200. This set is from the highly collectible military Battle Zones series, it features an Asian river delta environment, with a river going through two high ground points. There is an underground bunker with firing slits, a pagoda style building that falls apart as if exploded at the touch of a button, rotating launcher with firing missile, an ammo depot, stairs running up the hillside, fold down ramp, a bridge, and an underground cave you can drive in. The whole playset can be split to make a different environment, a jungle beachhead for landing craft. A PT boat is included, about 2" long. The entire playset is about 12" long.Many collectors buy the playsets to display their miniature vehicles or to take pictures on them. There are tons of Micro Machines vehicles to buy as accessories, or you can buy a bunch of different playsets and build a big battlefield. Their slogan was "Think Big, Play Small".

I am a huge Micro Machines collector from way back. Micro Machines are tiny toys, scale miniatures that were made by the Galoob company in the 1980's to when the company closed in 1998, but their toys are still huge with collectors, and there are still some unopened toys out there. The little packs of vehicles can easily sell for over $50, and some playsets can sell for $200. This set is from the highly collectible military battle zones series, it features a canyon  with a dam, a bunker, dual rotating guns, a firing missile, fold down ramp, and roads that cross the dam and goes through a tunnel. There is an area at the top of the dam that holds real water on top of the toy, and when you hit a button the dam blows up and water spills out. The concept is that the B-52 drops a bomb on the dam, blowing it up.In the box is 1 vehicle, about 2" long, it's a B-52 Bomber plane. There are also two figures of pilots. There are tons of Micro Machines vehicles to buy as accessories, or you can buy a bunch of different playsets and build a big battlefield. Their slogan was "Think Big, Play Small".

Micro Machines are tiny toys, scale miniatures made by the Galoob company. The company closed in 1998, but their toys are still huge with collectors, and there are still some unopened toys out there. The little packs of vehicles can easily sell for over $50, and some playsets can sell for $200. This set is from the highly collectible military battle zones series, it features a canyon with a bridge crossing it, and both sides are fighting over the bridge. There are hidden tunnels under the cliffs to drive thru, each side has a firing missile, one side has a watchtower, the other side has a button that blows up the bridge. A guard station on one side has a security gate that goes up and down, and it has a sandbag position, and a hidden control base. In the box is 1 vehicle, about 2" long, it's a Sheridan tank. There are tons of Micro Machines vehicles to buy as accessories, or you can buy a bunch of different playsets and build a big battlefield.

This listing is a hardcover souvenir book that you could purchase for only 1 year at the Disneyland Park, as it changes slightly each year and is republished with the new year on the cover.  It was only sold in the Disneyland Park and not in any stores. Disneyland has been producing a hardcover book every year for some time, and most years there are only slight changes made from the previous years. But when a big Anniversary date comes, they change the title and cover to reflect the special occasion for that years edition. New attractions and attractions that are under construction are usually shoe-horned into the last few pages each year. There are some brief articles scattered through the book, as well as picture captions. The book is made up of full page and half page color photos of attractions, buildings, and people having fun in the Park. The older ones are getting harder to find. The problem with the listing on this page, which was created by a third party seller, is it does not tell you which year is being offered.  Communicate with the seller before buying to make sure it is the one you you want. There are separate listings here at Amazon.com for the 25th anniversary, and the 30th Anniversary books if you are looking for specific years.These books have the best quality pictures, binding, and page paper available. On another note you will note it lists Marty Sklar as the author. He is currently the Vice-President of "Imagineering" for the Disney Company, but he wrote the articles and helped oversee the creation of the earliest versions of this book back when he was a junior employee.IMPORTANT NOTE FOR COLLECTORS: The true first edition of the book is quite rare and collectible as it was published in a small amount. It was printed in 1965 by:"Mondori Printing in Verona, Italy". You can go to the bottom of the last page and look for their name to confirm if you have this valuable copy. It has the lettering for Disneyland logo in blue on the cover, with the castle under it and the striped umbrella in lower right corner. The first edition version from Italy has better quality reproduction of the images.They sold out of the first edition books much faster than they had planned for and so Disneyland printed a second edition that year. The second edition version has red lettering for the Disneyland logo, but same picture of the castle below, and it was produced in a larger volume in the states.

The slogan for the very tiny scale miniature toys was "Think Big, Play Small". The Micro Machines vehicles were about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels, and the company made great playsets like this one to go with them. The playsets usually offered at least one free vehicle, this one has a tank in the typical 2" size. It features a mountainside that is open to the back revealing an underground base. It has a mountain top radar dome, that pops open to show a hidden rocket launcher.  A  secret rock door opens to drive down the road to a drawbridge. An exploding wall opens to reveal another pivoting cannon. The rock face has realistic bullet holes, and a flip-up section of roadway allows you to mimic a blast. The secret base under the mountain has a control panel, antenna, and working elevator for your tank, and a secret waterfall exit.

Another rare micro toy from the past, this one from 1989 and was even hard to find back then. It has 3 vehicles from the movie "Back to the Future II", including the DeLorean with the modified engine, future taxicab, and future police car. These are really tiny, about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels car. Very cool micro toy for your collection.

This set has 3 Micro Machines vehicles from the Star Wars movie, "The Empire Strikes Back". They are a TIE Starfighter, an Imperial AT-AT, and a Snowspeeder. Very tiny, about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels. Rare set made in 1993.

I am a big fan of micro toys. Amazing to see these Micro Toys here, they made them in the early 1990's for only about a year. This Tiny Collection Playcase opens like a makeup compact. On the outside it has an image of Aladdin and Jasmine. On the inside is has a miniature city of Agrabah on the bottom half when open, the top half is Jasmine's chambers with tiny furniture, and her balcony. Also a tiny Aladdin figure with an attachable magic carpet. Also a figure of Jasmine. If you connect the carpet to the tower and twist the tower it looks like the carpet is circling the tower. This makes a great toy for plane or car trips, or something to keep kids busy for awhile. Also see the other Disney Tiny Collection toys in the series such as the Aladdin Agrabah Marketplace, Pocahontas Home, and Cinderalla Stepmother's house. Other playcases in the series include Pocahontas, Mickey & Minnie, and Beauty and the Beast.

This is a rare fanzine to animation, especially Disney from the early 1990's. This is Vol. 2, No.4 Aug/Sept. 1991 in their strange identifications system of issues. The publication is long gone, but sorely missed now, and collectors are carefully hoarding their copies.In this isse we have an article with interview of Chuck Jones; a behind the scenes look at the Walt Disney animation studio in Florida; and an interview with the great Disney animator Ken Anderson, and much more.

This is an intersting Micro Machines knock off, of a scene from Back to the Future. Micro Machines were made by Galoob, and were wildly popular in the late 1980's to late 1990's when they were bought up and subsequenty shut down by a major toy company competitor. But while they were around, they were quite a number of import companies that made very similar micro sized toys, including this company, "Micro Cars". Nice 25 plus year old item for collectors.

These are Micro Machines, tiny plastic cars about 1/3 the size of a Hot Wheels.  They stopped making these in 1996 or 1998.  The hot 1960's cars in this set are: 1965 Corvair, 1960 Imperial, 1965 Lincoln Convertible, 1969 VW Volkswagen Beetle Convertible Bug, and a 1962 Thunderbird Convertible.

This is kind of like a Micro Machines set for Disney in a way. The Disney Company released a line of toys through Mattel called the Disney Tiny Collection, a set of very tiny figures with detailed homes. This version has Pocahontas and a Powhatan home. It has a secret lookout in a tree. The home opens up to show neat tiny details including the cookfire, baslet, pottery, wall art and more. Ladders take you to different levels of the house. push the basket and raccoon Meeko pops up. Character figures include Meeko, John Smith, Pocahontas, and Nakoma. There were other toys in the series including Aladdin Marketplace,  Cinderella Stepmother's house, Beauty and the Beast, and more. Hard to find now, they made these briefly in 1995, for one year only.
Reprints of Disney comics in a small pocket size. Has the classic Carl Barks story, "The Sunken City", and a Junior Woodchuck story with script by Barks.
This has the Carl Barks story "The Midas Touch", a Junior Woodchuck story with script by Barks.  7 other stories. I use these to introduce the younger family members to the great Barks.
Has the Carl Barks story, "Tralla La", plus 12 more stories. Has 2 Junior Woodchuck stories with scripts by Barks.

I  first read this book in High School, and fell in love with the collection of short stories. Authors include "Collecting Team" by Robert Silverberg; "The Gnurrs Come from the Voodvork Out" by R. Bretnor;  ; "Drop Dead" by Clifford D. Simak; The hilarious "The Sheriff of Canyon Gulch" by Poul Anderson and Gordon R. Dickson; "A Martian Odyssey" by Stanley Weinbaum; "The Blue Giraffe" by L. Sprague de Camp; "Grandpa" by James H. Schmitz; "The Hurkle is a Happy Beast" by and Theodore Sturgeon.

This is the special Book-of-the-month Club edition of Black Beauty. It is a very beautiful version of the book, with a turquoise cloth boards, grey spine binding and gold gilt lettering. The pictorial dust jacket is very classy looking. And it has the illustrations by artist Lucy Kemp-Welch illustrations, 18 full color plates plus the black and white illustrations on almost every page. By far the nicest version of this book ever made. This children's classic by Ann Sewell was first published in 1877, and its popularity has never faded. It is essentially an autobiography of a horse, told in the horses words. As the horse suffers one bad owner after another, the hose meets other horses along the way before finding the owner that will love her.
Great early book on passive solar heating for homes, from experts. Photos, floorplans, energy saving ideas galore. Part of my off the grid library.

This is part of the Micro Machines Exploration Earth and Exploration Sea collection. Rare and made in the last 2 years that Galoob was in business. Very imaginative scale miniature toys. Lifted Jeep is very cool, This goes good with the Timber Trails playset, the Rumble Mountain, or the Big Blast Geyser.

I disagree with the hysterical review from someone that obviously bought this before they bother checking something out before they buy.  First of all, this was created to be a collectors edition, is clearly labeled "Limited Edition". It is from a company that made these scale model miniatures, known as Galoob Micro Machines. The set is rare since the company went out of business in 1998, so the toy listed here is already over 20 years old. They are called "Micro" because they are small, and are made for people that collect scale miniatures. The listing describes the toys as "Approximate size of each vehicle is 1.5 inches long. Approximate size of unopened packaging is 8.5 x 7 x 3 inches". Sounds like Amazon was upfront about the size of the toys to me.For aircraft collectors, even finding a toy pack that includes a blimp, a hot air balloon, and an airplane in the same set is pretty neat. Finding it mint in package is even better. So if she can get it "anywhere" for $10, I'd like to see it. In fact it should be posted here with a link to it so we can all buy it. People need to pay more attention before they click "buy" on anything. The only review that reviewer has ever written as of this date here is negative, and that is what is wrong with society these days... quick to complain slow to compliment. I applaud Amazon for selling these old toys for people like me that collect miniature collectibles.

Another nice Micro Machine scale miniature from this military line. The company went out of business in 1998, but the toys can still be found for collectors. This set has the A-10 Thunderbolt, also known as the Warthog. This model has working retractable landing gear. It has 2 figures, a pilot and a special forces sodier. It has a KIVF Infantry Fighting Vehicle with treads. And last is a spy plane, a XB-70 Valkryie.

This is actually a made for television episode of "The Wonderful World of Disney" television show that played on Sunday nights from 1953 to 1983.  "Run, Appaloosa, Run", originally aired on the TV show in 1967 (season 14, episode 7) after serving as a theatrical featurette in July 29, 1966 along with the Main Feature at the time, "Lt Robin Crusoe". First release to video was in 1986. It's a story of Mary Blackfeather, a Native American girl of the Nez Pierce tribe who trains horses and performs as a trick rider. The Nez Perce are known for developing the spotted horses. Mary adopts a motherless colt that is rescued from a mountain lion by the family's herd dog "Silver", raises her and names her "Holy Smoke". Mary is eventually separated from her horse when she is forced to sell it at an auction to help her tribe raise money as horse sales are the basis of the tribe's economy in the film. The horse passes from one unworthy owner to another before he and Mary are reunited. They find each other again at a rodeo, and then land up joining in the historic annual "Suicide Relay Race", at Hells Mountain during the Omak Stampede. This is known as the roughest horse race in North America, dreamed up originally by the Nez Perce, consisting of a two horse per team relay of very rough terrain including jumping and swimming elements. Worse yet there are no rules and riders try to knock other riders off their horse. The herd dog "Silver" is amazing, and performs very well. This film is unique because it also features the famous rodeo clown Wilbur Plaugher playing himself, and many Native American actors. The movie was credited by Time Magazine at the time for a surge in popularity for Appaloosa horses. The Official Disney Encyclopedia Disney A to Z, on page 478 incorrectly lists the colt as "Sky Dancer", and in all fairness it is rare to see mistakes in that book.The terrific cowboy singing and narration is by Rex Allen, and the title song he performs, "Ballad of Appaloosa" is written by Bobby Wayne. Fun and exciting adventure film for the whole family. Filmed in Technicolor and directed by Larry Lansburgh, who also wrote the original story, photographed and produced the film. Lansburgh had a long career of making Disney animal featurettes from the 1940's. Later he wrote and produced, a terrific theatrical feature film for Disney, "the Littlest Outlaw". I recommend this for horse lovers, and fans of old Disney television.

MicroMachines were made by a company called Galoob. That company was bough out and dismanteled by their largest competitor in the late 1990's. The MicroMachines line of toys were great, and well known for their tiny scale miniature size. A car would only be an inch long or so. The company produced some wonderful Star Wars toys including this rare model from 1997. A series of busts or heads of different characters was produced, each with a miniature playset hidden inside. This version was Yoda. When open it reveals a scene where Luke Skywalker receives Jedi training from Yoda in the swamps of Dagobah. It includes 6 tiny figure including Yoda, Luke, Darth Vader, R2-D2. Also the X-Wing Starfighter that Luke sunk in the swamp is here. A secret feature is when you press down on Yoda's ear, the dual between Luke and Darth Vader is animated.

Micro Machines are small scale miniatures. This model was made only in 1989 in a limited edition and is extremely rare now. This is a playset of a drill dock offshore oil rig. It floats in water so can be used in the bath or the pool. The boom rotates around, There is a crane to lower the smaller boat into the water, the you can use the fuel nozzle to fill your boat. There is a lever that pumps water out the top like a gusher. The radar dish can be spun around.I know a bar in an oil town that has this on the shelf for decoration even though it is a toy. There is a boat hook to dock the boat. A helicopter landing pad is on top.Separately you can buy accessory vehicle packs for this playset, from the Sea Exploration sets of vehicles from Micro Machines, including Micro Machines Exploration Sea #2 Off-Shore Riggers Set. All in all very fun and very hard to find toy.

I really enjoyed this movie, so much that I saw it again the next day. The film did a good job of showing the daily hustle of life as a criminal defense attorney and the bit players that all profit off of the cases. Terrific acting, cracking good script, realistic dialogue, and a good suspenseful story.  The directors pacing and visual look of the film kept my attention throughout the movie.  I can't say much more as it is really easy to ruin this movie by revealing the details.

Enough has been said about this movie by much better qualified reviewers than me, but I will chime in with something brief. This is the true story of the Bielski brothers in WWII in Belorussia, whose parents were killed by the Nazis. The brothers then organized a resistance group of Jewish fighters who helped hundreds of Jews escape Warsaw and villages in the region. Excellent production values, costumes, effects, and story but the actors make this movie.

If you are looking for the story of how Genghis Khan swept across the tundra and conquered much of the known world, this isn't it. It is a great movie, it is a prequel of sorts. A dramatization of Genghis' brutal life as a boy up to the time he took over the Mongol horde. Great production values, excellent acting, glorious battle scenes, incredible panoramic scenery, spot-on costumes and artistic design, and a mesmerizing story. I only wish they had kept going and told the story of what he did once he united the clans into one big army.

Spoiler alert here, and by the way the whole movie is spoiled. I should have pushed the off button on my TV, but I stuck it out. You know, this was one of those movies I really wanted to like. It had some good actors, clean production values, great representation of the 1970's NASA. And it had potential, conspiracy sci-fi and horror rolled into one. But someone forgot to write a script. What do you get when you have a NASA lab, and bad guys. But you never figure out who the bad guys are... First they are NSA, then CIA, then a rogue former NASA official, then aliens; no wait maybe they're angels; no wait they are from another dimension, maybe demons... Aaaarghh. All that is bad enough, but they never do answer the question. And why the heck do they have people make a choice of a gateway, telling them one is the path to salvation and the other is to hell, and then start all over again. Why do they kidnap people and put them in these water transportation gates that simply send people back to their house again? And what is the difference between people they call test subjects and people they call employees? Be assured you will have tons of questions that are tantalizing and fun, as you wait for the big payoff..... that never comes!

This film was made by and for HBO. I had picked it up used at Amazon and then let it sit on shelf for over ayear before I finally watched it. It was more fun that I had expected it would be. This is not a dark and serious drama, oh to be sure it treats the subject of war and death with the reverence it deserves at times, but the movie revels in the character of Pancho Villa. At one moment a dark brutal man, next a fun loving trickster, then he is exceedingly generous and concerned for the welfare of others.  The story is mostly dramatization, quite the opposite of a documentary, but they do not pretend otherwise. We do not have enough source material to draw on to get a better picture of the events, and the real Pancho Villa films have been lost to history.The movie is very loosely based on the story of an American film company reciving an offer, by the Mexican revolutionary general Pancho Villa, to film a real life battle. This would be the first time in history a battle was to be shown on film to the public. The general somehow felt that the theatrical presentation of the Mexican conflict could cause America to consider lifting its embargo on his ability to buy American guns. The battle footage is well enough received that the company determines to return with actors and crew to flesh it out into a movie. Villa needed his side of the story told, as the Rupert Murdoch of the day in the form of WR Hearst and his newspaper empire, was editorializing and spinning the news to affect public policy and demonize the General.The film is very well made, the battle scenes exciting and authentic, costumes, sets, vintage vehicles are all very authentic. The actors take their roles seriously and a great effort is put forth to make this as believable as possible. Antonio Banderas is mesmerizing in the tough role of Villa, one hand gentle and friendly, raging the next moment. Alan Arkin has a role that could have been more developed, but he gives it much more than the role called for. The rest of the cast tries to keep up as best they can, but they are not as bad as some make it sound here, just outclassed.All in all it was a pleasant diversion for the evening.

VIVITE Daily Cleanser is a hit in our house, we use it in the shower daily. It is very gentle and cleans really good, breaking down makeup and grime. It is unscented, I have extremely sensitive skin and it does not bother me or have any allergic effects.Your face feels good after using it. Now the same company makes a "hydrating" daily facial cleanser as well, but that one has a chemical smell I don't like and is very hard to rinse off. We were using another brand before switching to Vivete last year, that is just as good but had gotten too expensive for us. This product is cheaper here than it is at our dermatologist.

This is a toy made by MicroVerse, similar to Micro Machines. The figures are only half an inch tall.  It is called the "Goosebumps A Night In Terror Tower Micro Playset", and ties into the popular book and TV series. It was made in 1996, and is pretty rare now. . Brother and sister Eddie and Sue figures, as well as evil executioner figure.  The castle opens up into a playset loaded with creepy features and details including ghostly apparitions, secret passageways,  a spring loaded mechanism for the executioner, escape chute, Terror Tower, revolving fireplace, turret drop tunnel, trap door capture pit, underground dungeon cell, sewer escape route, and gallows. Fun for Goosebumps or horror fans.

Nice rare collectible from 1996. Micro Machines was a brand of scale miniatures, really tiny plastic toys. For the original Predator movie, Micro machines licenses a few different sets of vehicle and figure packs, and a playset. This is set #3, it includes the Predator Spaceship, Anna figure, Predator Alien figure, Thermographic Dutch figure, and Guerilla Truck. The truck is about 1.5 inches long.

There are few sequels that stand up to the original novel but City of Blades is just as gripping as the novel that started it all, City of Stairs. You must read the first book before this, however, as it doesn't work as a stand-alone. For those who loved City of Blades, many characters are back here, especially....wait for it.....Sigrud who features prominently here (can I hear a collective hooray?). While our main protagonists shift in this book, the superior world-building and twisty plot remains. The themes were darker in this book, which seemed appropriate given the hard look at war, those who lead us into war (and why), and why people follow them into war and carnage. Frankly, it was these dark questions that made the novel more compelling for me than the first. Philosophically, it made me think while still keeping the plot moving along...it didn't get dry and boring with musings at any point.Highly recommend both books....start with the first please!

I admit it: I was suckered into this novel chiefly due to the comparisons to Daphne Du Maurier. When will I ever learn that these comparisons to classic authors rarely, if ever, match the hype. So it was with The Gilded Life of Matilda Duplaine, the story of a small-town-boy-done-good journalist who meets the reclusive, uber-wealthy daughter of a Hollywood scion and falls in love. I'm still not sure why he falls in love....it happened so quickly and without much a foundation so I never made that leap of faith a good plot requires. But because I couldn't really believe in the love-story portion of it, the rest of the protagonist's actions - which are based on this "deep love" - never held true for me. Much of this stemmed from my waiting for the Du Maurier-like writing to appear, which of course it never did. I really wish publicists would stop hyping new authors by comparing them to established authors....it does them such a disservice. Let them stand (or fall) on their own laurels, please.If you don't have any preconceived expectations of this novel, you'll likely enjoy it far more than I did. It's not even comparable to Fitzgerald or Du Maurier so don't be expecting that kind of book. Take it on it's own and you'll do better than I did.

Lauren Oliver is the author of some very popular Young Adult books (the Delirium Trilogy probably being her most popular) so I was interested to see what she could do with the sometimes-difficult Middle Grade genre. Curiosity House (the first of a series) is an almost too-cute "mystery" for young readers featuring four child-protagonists each of whom is a part of Dumfrey's Dime Museum of Freaks, Oddities, and Wonders. Orphans, Sam, Philippa, Thomas, and Max each have their own "talent" (such as contortionist, etc) that contributes to this circus-like sideshow and each are outsiders. When a shrunken head - one of the Dumfrey's Museums oddities - is stolen, the children are determined to bring it back. Ultimately, the story was less about the shrunken head mystery than the children discovering things about their own unique pasts.The story was competent and engaging throughout....my 7 year old lost interest but my 9 year old enjoyed it so I think that's around the cut-off age. It was easy to follow the plot and to keep the characters straight as well. Ultimately though, nothing stood out about it. When I asked my 9 year old if he was interested in buying the subsequent sequels he said, "Not really, there's so many other books I want to read instead." So that's why I gave it 3 stars.....he liked it, but not enough to keep reading the series. This could be because he's more interested in books with a more fantasy-motif (dragons, etc), but I understood his ambivalence with this one. I thought the same as he did: a decent book but not a series to get us hooked.

I'm comparing the Nuyu to the Jawbone UP. I've been wearing one on each wrist for two weeks now and feel reasonably competent to offer up some of the differences (keep in mind the UP is about $50 more expensive than the Nuyu). There are some major differences between the two. The first thing that I loved about this Nuyu is the fact that it acts as a watch too. The UP is just a bracelet with no time or other displays on it (you get your display of your stats/activity on the phone app). So I loved the idea of dual functions. Unfortunately, it didn't work so well in practice. You must swipe your finger on the Nuyu to display the time (the screen is normally black to save battery life). Turns out, I'd have to "sweep" my finger over it about 5-10 times to get the right spot to bring it to life, gah, what a pain. But once you do bring it to life you can see the time, swipe again to get your calories burned, swipe again to see steps taken, etc. The Nuyu is different also in that you don't have to recharge your device all the time. It has a single battery that lasts months and then you replace it when needed with a simple small battery available at grocery stores.The next thing I noticed a couple of days into wearing both devices is a HUGE discrepancy between devices on how many steps I had taken in any given day. The Nuyu was nearly DOUBLE what the UP was showing.....in my heart of hearts I knew the UP was correct, but the Nuyu made me feel better about myself, lol. The Nuyu, just like the UP, has a downloadable app to set goals, track your progress, etc. Where the UP has an advantage is that it allows you to set various alarms, etc, so that the bracelet vibrates and alerts you. Nuyu has nothing of the kind although it does come with different holders beside the wristbands so you can attach it to your shoe or whatever. Both the Nuyu and the UP phone apps are equally good and user friendly.All in all, I'd say the UP is the better buy for your money. But if you really, REALLY want a fancy pedometer (which is all these things  really are) and are tight on money, I suppose this would be an okay substitute. But my advice would be to save your money and wait until you can afford some of the better fitness trackers out there. The UP is good, but there are even better ones out there that combine all the really useful features.....wristwatch, GPS, alarms, etc.

This YA thriller is competently written and tries to incorporate social media to make itself very relevant. The story revolves around a teen girl who is desperate to find a kidney donor for her brother. When she finds herself invited to a private social site called NEED, she's given the opportunity to actually obtain a kidney for her brother....of course, the entire things turns out to be quite nefarious and this is where we get our thriller element to the story. Charbonneau is a competent and veteran author of previous well-received YA novels. This one requires you to *really* stretch your credulity, though, which is why I knocked off a star. Frankly, I just didn't buy the whole premise and think most teenagers are smart enough to think the premise of the social site NEED was silly, but if you can employ your imagination better than I did, you'll likely enjoy it. I just happen to think teenagers are much smarter than the ones in the book. But it's been 20 years since I was a teen so what do I know? hehe

My 9 year old son and I read this together and I have to say, The Vanishing Island is about perfect for him. When the main character Bren Owen, eager for adventure and travel in the year 1599, steals away on a ship he gets more adventure than he bargained for. The author uses an alternative history, which I thought was fantastic. We got to stop and talk about the real historical events and how they really played out as opposed to what is happening in the book. The action keeps up throughout the novel and we never reached any boring lull in the story...it also sets up nicely for the next book. If you've heard that this book is a bit violent and gross, YES, that is true....just the kind of thing 9 year old boys eat up and ask for more (some people might have children more sensitive to this kind of thing....read other reviews too before deciding....but my child loved it the same way he loved the Jurassic World movie). Every household is different so it's up to you....I was fine with it because we are READING.My son was thrilled to learn that this is the first of what will be a series (we love a good series).

TRIGGER WARNING: This book is about mental illness and suicide. Just be aware that the subject matter might be upsetting for some.Hamilton's book is her own personal story: her husband's descent into mental illness and his subsequent suicide. It's heartbreaking, but honestly written. Given the honesty and emotional rawness of what she is sharing, it would be difficult to find fault with the book. Every reader is going to approach this book differently: some may not have any experience with what Hamilton relates, while others will be intimately familiar with both the despair of her husband or the despair she encounters. I encourage everyone to approach this with an open heart in order to understand that as horrifying as her experience has been, she is not unusual....millions of people in our country struggle with varying forms of mental illness. By and large, we fail them. Every day. But listening to Hamilton's story may encourage empathy in readers and that makes the book worth it right there. Because what we need most of all in this world is more empathy. I applaud the author for opening such a private and heartbreaking wound for public consumption.

Hilton adds to the Elizabeth I canon with a work that strives to view her remarkable reign in the context of how Elizabeth viewed herself: not as a female ruling England, but as ruler who transcended gender. This was no small feat to achieve given the gender bias at the time and various examples of fellow female rulers (ie, Mary, Queen of Scots) who failed spectacularly in this endeavor thereby strengthening gender bias when it came to royalty.It helps to be familiar with the players and their roles (William Cecil, the Earl of Leicester, Duke of Norfolk, etc) because Hilton doesn't hold the reader's hand. She doles out facts and figures quickly and it might be difficult to keep up if you're unfamiliar with the court of Elizabeth I. If you're new to the life of Elizabeth, it might behoove you to do some reading up on her life ahead of time (consults with Dr Google should manage this) to give you the basics.While I'm not convinced this biography brought anything new to the table, it is well written enough and has some fresh interpretations that make it a welcome addition.

This GRE prep guide was much, much better than the one I used and I'd recommend it over others I have worked with, especially when you factor in the tons of additional questions on the website which this book gives you access to. The layout is logical, the prep test is as rigorous as the exam itself, and the answers that are given are very clear and concise. No one wants to waste time studying....you want the best study prep in the shortest amount of time (efficiency). Use this.

If you have school-aged boys, you'll know that zippered hoodies are a staple in their wardrobe. We go through so many of these but the problem is that I often have a hard time finding one under $40. Egads. So STX has a great price point here.....the hoody is of medium thickness (not too hot when they get to school, they can wear it all day), zips up the front, and has two deep pockets so stuff doesn't fall out every time they sit down. Sturdy fabric, gets softer with each washing. If you want to save a little, order these.

Three points of view, each told in first person narrative, is difficult to pull off but Buckley manages the technique very, very well in The Good Good-Bye. Arden and Rory are cousins, young women just graduating from high school and heading off to college. Their fathers are brothers and the two families have grown up together very close (maybe too close?) and the girls are like sisters to each other. Arden's mother Natalie and Rory's father Vince own their own restaurant together....although Natalie married Vince's brother, she and Vince have a "past" that won't seem to go fade away, but their relationship, both as brother and sister in law *and* as friends and former more-than-friends, crumbles when Vince makes a risky, expensive investment that fails and financially dooms both families. Arden and Rory, both just ready to jet off to their respective universities, are told that expensive colleges aren't going to be viable right now....they'll have to attend a lower-tier state university instead. Just until the families get back on their feet (will they?). But a bad situation gets worse when Rory and Arden wind up severely injured after a mysterious dorm fire. Both in comas, both in the ICU, the families are traumatized. Police are wondering whether the fire was really a homicide attempt. Questions are flying and the answers are only slowly revealed as Rory, Arden, and Arden's mother Natalie each tell pieces of the story in the alternating chapters that ensue. Pieces of backstory are thrown around helter-skelter and it's up to the reader to put the puzzle together....it keeps you reading, that's for certain. What could have been a horrible mish-mash is instead a mysterious, compelling novel about the fracture of families and secrets kept. It's quite well done and I do recommend this book!

As a general rule of thumb, I prefer Epson printers for an all-around good at-home printer. The XP-830 is up to Epson's good standards with just about every feature the standard, at-home user would need. It copies well, the fax is easy to use, good print quality, etc. Wireless works perfect and is so easy to set up even my completely non-technical husband could do it just a few minutes. I glanced through some of the other reviews here and everyone has pretty much nailed all of the technical specifics for those who want those.But as with all of the Epson printers I've owned over the years (mostly because I want to try the latest and greatest, not because they die on me), I'm taking off a star for one very practical reason: their feeder trays are low quality, flimsy pieces of thin plastic that are awkward (at best) to pull out and put your paper into. For a company that builds very high quality at-home printers, this continual oversight with every model I've tried just irritates the heck out of me. In the case of this XP-830 it's even worse: the feeder trays are located on the front of the machine underneath the output tray and the pop-out LCD touch screen. In order to refill your paper in the feeder tray, you have to maneuver your fingers around the LCD screen that's in the way, UNDER the output tray which automatically pops itself out every time the printer is turned on, and actually lift up on the machine (hoping you're not lifting up on a part that is breakable like the touchscreen or plastic output tray) to try to slide out the flimsy feeder tray where you put your paper. Good grief. The next Epson printer I try is going to be a rear-feeding version to see if that is any easier/better.Anyway, if you can put up with the exercise in frustration over getting the paper in the feeder, the rest of the machine is just excellent. We don't print a lot of photos in our household, but instead rely on our printer for various school projects, work related things, etc. It's a quiet printer that prints relatively quickly with good quality. The ink lasts about average for home printers and I wish the printer would continue to print even when you KNOW you've run out of magenta or whatever (Canon printers keep printing even after you run out of an ink color which helps when you're in a pinch), but I plan around that and always have spare ink tucked away since the printing gods have declared that you will only run out of ink when it's an important, time-critical thing you need printed and it's 11pm at night. So plan ahead.Overall for the price point, you're getting a good printer.

I know serious readers aren't supposed to judge a book by it's cover, but wow. LOOK at that cover. It's one of the most beautiful covers I've seen in years and I'm not ashamed to admit that it played a big role in my giving this book a chance. I'm happy to report that the inside is worthy of that cover. For a young adult genre novel, The Emperor of Any Place is a remarkably sophisticated novel with layers upon layers of themes. Ostensibly the story of a young Toronto teenager who has just lost his father, a just-found old book reveals another layer of narrative that takes us on a journey to an island in the Pacific during World War II. It is, in essence, a book within a book that is easy to follow (unlike many others that have attempted this technique) and leads Evan on a voyage of discovery: who he is and where he came from. Very highly recommended

Prior to reading this novel by Melanie Benjamin I thought I knew quite a bit about Truman Capote. Turns out, I was wrong. I've been a fan of Benjamin since her novel "Alice I Have Been," which was a surprisingly intense and compelling novel that once I started, I couldn't stop reading. The Swans of Fifth Avenue proved to be the same: I didn't want to put it down. I was, at first, not near as familiar with Capote's inner circle of New York friends as I thought I would be....there were several names that were unfamiliar to me and I had to look up. I'm glad I did as it helped sweep me into the narrative of Capote's life. This is one novel where googling people/times doesn't ruin the book at all. Capote's decline with alcohol and mental health issues were riveting to me and I felt that Benjamin dealt with these subjects very well....remaining true to the story but still retaining some dignity with her writing. It was a fascinating time period with a very influential group of people who would influence literature and society for years to come. Well worth your reading time!

As an admirer of Cullen's last historical novel which centered around Edgar Allen Poe, I was eagerly anticipating her newest novel about the quintessential American Mark Twain. I wasn't disappointed. Cullen's novels *are* novels...they are historical fiction. But what makes Cullen's novels better than most of this genre's writers is her exhaustive research that she adeptly works from. It's not too often for an author to have the ability to make this kind of thing fascinating without resorting to gross distortion of the facts, but Cullen is consistently able to do just this. This novel takes us to the latter part of Mark Twain's (or Samuel Clemens, his legal name) life. Using his relationship with his secretary Isabel Lyon, Cullen takes us into Twain's personal life which was much darker than any of us probably imagined it would be and much to the average reader's (like myself) surprise, it turns out that he was not a very good person. But that doesn't make the novel a disappointment....in fact, just the opposite. Cullen brought Twain - and his family - into a very real light for me. Like most historical people, he was neither evil nor truly heroic. He was human. And presented here in all of his frail "human-ness." Worth the read if you've never read any of her work before and I also recommend her novel about Poe, as well. Nicely done.

This is a very large tin of chocolate-covered caramels. Half of them are milk chocolate and the other half are dark chocolate (I prefer the dark chocolate ones) and each are individually wrapped. They are slightly larger than a comfortable bite-size (hard to talk when you pop one in your mouth, haha). I like the Hershey's caramel because it's soft yet not so sticky as to leave caramel residue all over your teeth. These are perfect to toss one in your kid's lunch box or offer one as a treat. Left open on the counter, I will eat way, way too many. For your chocolate/caramel friends or family, this would be a great gift.

This novel was a no-go for me from the very beginning. Normally, the concept of two women who as girls spent a brief time as victims of the same kidnapper and how their paths cross again and why would fascinate me. Unfortunately, the way it was written didn't fascinate....it bored me. I wasn't invested in either character and the kidnapper himself was even more boring. I couldn't figure out why this happening (what writing technique was causing this) and the only thing I can pinpoint here is that in an attempt to keep everything and everyone "mysterious," the author didn't give me ANYTHING interesting to attract my attention or create investment in a character (any character, please!). No fascinating tidbit, foreshadowing, details from the past...nothing. As a result, I was bored to tears and didn't even want to keep reading....in fact, I kept putting the book down to read other ones. Perhaps other readers will find it more interesting than I did. I'm the first to admit that there are times a person's reading mood can dictate how much effort they are willing to put into a book....and this book didn't do anything for me. Maybe your luck will be better.

This is a difficult book to review because Karin Slaughter is clearly a very talented and popular author and has been for years. She is a name that is guaranteed to sell books even outside her popular series (this is a stand alone novel). By writing a stand alone novel like Pretty Girls, it gives her a chance to write outside whatever limitations are imposed by her regular series. So I'm not sure if we should be surprised that given the opportunity, the author might choose to take some chances and write something that pushes the edge. Given the popularity of the Scandinavian writers who push the envelope with their dark mystery/thrillers infused with both physical and psychological violence (usually directed at women), it seems natural that an author like Slaughter might want to give that a shot, which is what she does in this novel. Exceedingly graphic/shocking violence abounds....so often, in fact, that the shock value is greatly diminished by 3/4 through the book. There's no question that Slaughter is a very good writer, it's just the content that might make some readers uncomfortable.
