There are no problems with the plot line or characters not being developed...as I said, she is a good writer. And if you enjoy the darkest Scandinavian writers and their race to come up with the most twisted/disgusting crimes committed against women, odds are you might enjoy this one, too. So give it a shot. But if you do not care for the graphic stuff, you'll want to skip this.

This is my first experience with Bose speakers and I now understand what all the fuss is about....I had no idea that sound could be this impressive in your own home. There are four components that come with this system: your speaker bar (goes in front of your TV and is 36 3/4" long for anyone who wants to measure before purchasing), what they call the Acoustimass module (goes along the wall in any front third of your room), the small console which controls everything, and the smaller SoundTouch wireless adapter. Also included in the box is your remote control (batteries included) and an audio calibration device which you'll use to optimize/personalize the sound to your specific room.Set up took less than 30 minutes, it's that easy. Directions are very clear and simple. You may mount the sound bar on a wall or you can simply place it in front of your TV which is what I did. An HDMI cable is included to connect your TV to the console (there are alternative directions if your TV is older and doesn't have an HDMI connection). You then connect your peripheal entertainment devices such as your Blu-Ray player, Roku, DVR, game box, whatever, to the clearly marked HDMI connections on the rear of the console....presumably you already have HDMI cables for those devices so they aren't included with this system. The SoundTouch wireless adapter is then plugged into the console and turn it all on...just don't nearly blow out your windows with the volume up like I did. The wireless adapter is very cool and everything is Bluetooth ready....I was immediately playing music from my iPhone. There are directions that lead you to download the SoundTouch app which allows you to stream internet radio, Pandora, all sorts of services as well as set up specific playlists, etc.All I can say about the sound is that it is incredible. Even though I've somewhat gotten used to the superior quality over the past few days, I *still* jump occassionally when a door closing on a movie/tv show sounds so dang real that I think it's someone coming through my own front door. There is such a depth of sound that is created between the sound bar and the Acoustimass it is amazing. If you'd asked me whether I thought a good home theater sound system was worth it a month ago, I probably would have said no....because I had no idea what I've been missing out on all this time. You don't have to be a speaker/sound aficionado to realize that this is like the difference between watching a movie in black and white versus Technicolor. I won't deny that it's a vanity purchase...no one *needs* this kind of sound....but it sure is a treat to have it. Bose is all they are cracked up to be. Highly, highly recommended if you are in the market.

New York Times' writer Scott Shane does a fine job of profiling the people and events that led to the US drone strike, ordered by the President, that succeeded in killing US-born Islamic terrorist Anwar al-Awlaki. More than just the events themselves, the book is especially about the larger questions of our government's latest predilection for drone usage. Wherever you fall on the topic Shane provides a very comprehensive look at how this has occurred and why...all framed around the events leading to Anwar al-Awlaki's death. I didn't interpret any of Shane's writing to be telling me what conclusions to draw - something I very much appreciate in my non-fiction - rather, he brings up various points (ethical, historical, and otherwise) that hadn't occurred to me before and certainly made me re-examine my own position on the usage of drones and who we target and why. I didn't see Shane as trying to convince me of anything. He just provided the context I needed to look at it in ways that other people, depending on what interests they are protecting, might see things. The narrative moved along quite well and I never felt bogged down or bored with any details. It is just plain good writing. Highly recommended.

This is the first Amy Stewart book I have read but I can see that I'm going to have to order her previous books seeing as I enjoyed this novel, loosely based on an actual event which Stewart tells you all about at the end of the book. Stewart took the few known facts about the incident in which the Kopp sisters' buggy was hit by Henry Kaufman's automobile in 1914 and used her delightful imagination to fill in the blanks. She creates utterly charming characters out of the three sisters, but it's Constance that is our protagonist as she determines to write a wrong done by the not-very-nice Kaufman. This leads to quite a few discoveries and events, not all as benign as a buggy accident. The character development is so charming that this might border on a cozy mystery (or at least a mystery-type book where the characters are eccentric/independent enough to keep the reader coming back). And the story ends on such a note that I could easily see this becoming a longer running series. I enjoyed it as much as any Maisie Dobbs book and indeed will be more interested in a sequel to this than the next Jacqueline Winspear installment. If you enjoy books with a strong, smart female character set in a historical world, you'll like this. Try it.

I dislike writing negative reviews but if you treasure your book-allotment money like I do, you'll want to be warned that this book really isn't worth purchasing. I always try to think of other readers who might like the book before I smack it with less than 3 stars (because usually with books, one person's trash is another's treasure). In the case of Bradstreet Gate, however, I can't think of who might think this was worth it (it's possible, I suppose, but unlikely). It's biggest flaw is that nothing really happens throughout the book, while it's billed as a mystery/low-key thriller ala Tartt's fabulous The Secret History and the opening portion of the book seems to read like that: a handful of old college classmates from Harvard and a murder of a student back in their college days. It seemed to be setting up for a delicious plot of who did what and why and maybe even a tasty twist at the end. But it went nowhere. The plot followed this group of former classmates around the globe in the years after the murder and their graduations, but that's it. What's worse, as the pages turned and the plot really went nowhere, I ceased caring or even maintaining interest in any of the characters. Perhaps the story was just billed erroneously by the publishers, but aimlessly following these characters about wasn't worth my reading time. I'd like to say your mileage may vary, but I doubt it.

Perhaps because I'm not a huge fantasy reader (only the really, really well-known authors such as Rothfuss or Abercrombie), I didn't have as many problems with this novel. A friend who was reading this at the same time as I had a lot more issues with this novel, but he reads hundreds of books in the genre each year. I, on the other hand, don't read enough of the genre for the whole elves, orcs, and ogres to be old-hat for me. The novel contains a lot of extremes: very bad versus very good (it's allegedly based on a game, but I am wholly unfamiliar with it) and has a LOT of characters in it. Because of that, it took me quite a few chapters before I finally was able to tease them apart but once I did that, the story flowed well for me. The story is set in a world called Urth ("What on Urth?" snicker...), ruled by an not-so-nice Kothite Emperor for the past 3200 years. They are near-immortals. But a dramatic prophecy threatens the Kothite rule over the myriad of other races on the planet (or world, or whatever Urth really is) involving a Sleeping King. There's also a love story thrown in the mix, although it didn't make or break the story for me. Ultimately, I think fans of fantasy are going to find more to be picky about - and well they should! - but for those who aren't very well-versed in the genre it goes a bit smoother for us.

I was actually quite surprised with the softness/quality of this shirt, which I got for my husband to wear this fall/winter. The initial washing didn't seem to shrink it much (if at all) and it fit perfectly. The flannel is extremely soft after washing and this has only increased with each subsequent was (at least 10 so far). No iron, just pull it out of the dryer and hang. My husband doesn't usually care for the shirts I get him, but he's been wearing this a lot so Wrangler has a winner here. I'll be buying one or two more for him in different colors. Excellent buy.

Larson has synthesized a tremendous amount of research into a compelling narrative of Rosemary, the Kennedy daughter who was hidden away by the family as a result of her mental deficiencies. The Kennedy's were clearly a product of their times. Reading this fascinating book, it's difficult to indict them for what we now know were tragic mistakes. From Rosemary's horrifying birth (I had no idea that what happened when she was born was commonplace at the time!) to her later unfortunate lobotomy, medical personnel honestly thought they were doing the best they could by her. Author Kate Larson writes Rosemary's story very well....I enjoy biographies that, while well-researched, don't bog the reader down with minute details or try to slant the information presented. She tells a story here providing the facts, not editorial, allowing the reader to come to their own conclusions about the decisions made. The book includes photographs as well and is a quick read at 320 pages. I probably read it even faster than I normally would because the narrative was so well done and interesting. If you have any interest in the Kennedy family, who was probably as close to American "royalty" as one can get, I'd highly recommend picking this one up. I think it's especially relevant today given that we are becoming more and more aware of our societal failings with mental health.

The dreaded 3 star review....ugh. I really expected to love this book when I heard through the bookish-grapevine that it is told using one of my absolute favorite devices: via letters, notes, diary entries, police reports, psychologist sessions, etc and so on. It's nice to see something different rather than a straight narrative. I was also anticipating loving the main character: Carly/Kaitlyn are multiple personalities. Carly is in control during the day, but at dusk Kaitlyn emerges. Both are fully aware of the other's existence and communicate via notes left for the other to find. This was just such a great premise I couldn't wait to start reading! And then......nothing. That's not to say nothing happens, but rather that I felt utterly nothing for Carly/Kaitlyn. The author wasn't interested in really exploring their condition (it was just a means to forward a plot), instead focusing on bringing in supernatural elements....well, what is this going to be? A mystery crime story or a Stephen King? An expose of multiple personalities or a creepy love story? Honestly, it's difficult to put into words because I'm not quite sure why this sure-fire format and subject matter became uninteresting and boring other than to say that the book was trying to be too many things and failed in all of them. Ultimately neither character/personality was interesting to me. By the mid-point of the book I was having to force myself to pick it up again in order to finish.Maybe others will get better mileage out of this. It just fell flat for me. Sorry. :(

A good cozy mystery evokes a sense of place and presents memorable characters. As I turned the last page in this fabulous debut to a new series, there was no doubt that the author provided both of these in spades. Set deep in Louisiana the story centers around Crozat House, an old Southern plantation house that has been turned into a B&B by the Crozat family. Maggie, their daughter, finds the house filled with an eccentric cast of guests....this eccentricity of the characters makes the novel utterly funny and charming, despite the fact that two guests turn up dead. Local law enforcement is no help whatsoever due to old family feuds, so it's up to Maggie to snoop her way to the culprit. When you have a cozy mystery this good, the murders (and their solving) are just a vehicle for a good cast. Not only are the guests comical, but Maggie's own family: her grandmother utterly upstages them all here. It really is a delightful read....I don't read too many "cozies" as they are called, but I will continue to be a fan of Ellen Byron and this series. I hope the series enjoys the success it richly deserves.

I think the family saga subgenre is making a comeback and I, for one, am grateful. The Dust That Falls from Dreams is very much a family saga. It's a historical fiction saga set in England presenting the story of two intertwined families, the Pendennis's and the Pitt's, neighbors whose lives intersect throughout a period of vast social change. We begin with the death of Queen Victoria and sweep forward though the Great War....love, tragedy, death, marriage, war; all of the elements required for a good family saga page-turner. I rather enjoyed the characters, none of whom particularly took center stage....I'm not sure any were meant to. The characters are merely a vehicle for showcasing the period and social upheaval occurring at the time. Overall, I enjoyed the story. It wasn't on par with a saga like The Thorn Birds (where you really connected and became invested in the two main characters), but it was a good solid story. I'd recommend it.

I'm giving this product three stars because while it did utterly nothing for me, it clearly has for other users and I'm taking into account the possibility that I'm just not the consumer the product is targeting. By that I mean that my workouts are not hard and intense....I'm simply a fast walker who hits the road every other day for 5 miles. I don't run, I don't life weights, I don't hit the elliptical machine. So I'm wondering if perhaps I experienced no results (nothing bad, nothing good) simply because I'm not an intense workout person. Additionally, I showed the product to my best friend who happens to be a doctor and she made fun of me for even trying it. Take that for what it's worth (just an opinion). I suggest you read other reviews, especially the ones who detail workouts similar to your own before making a decision. Good luck!

I'm writing this review as a consumer who had zero experience with photo editing software, so if you're already very familiar with how to use this kind of program my review probably won't help you. But for anyone out there who is also a newbie at this kind of thing, I'll tell you how my foray went as I finally sucked it up and decided to learn how to use this kind of program.Like a lot of people I know, I'm one of those folks who takes tons of snapshots with my phone and then never does anything with them. As a result, I have hundreds of pictures of my kids, family, vacations, etc just stored there in my phone/cloud and the most "editing" of them I ever do is with the chintzy editor that comes in my phone (you know, crop it and add a cheap filter...not exactly professional stuff here). Trying to do something with all of these photos has been on my "to-do" list forever and I thought Corel's program might be just the thing I needed to get on that. Not as expensive as Photoshop, but I was pretty sure I didn't need all of the professional features. I was definitely right about that....this program was nearly overwhelming when I first installed it. (Install is fast and easy, by the way, with just a CD and then you register your product....takes less than 5 minutes.) When I first opened up the program, I had really not a clue how to apply any feature. Playing around with it yielded little results so I sucked it up and went to Corel's website where I found a bunch of easy tutorials (they are short videos on how to use various features). Now I was on the right track. I imported several photos to start (scanned one just for practice and the rest from my phone). By practicing with the tutorials on their website, I was able to start using some of the features....there are hundreds. While things like cropping or applying filters are easy to do, other features such as touching up a photo using things like Burn Brushes took a tutorial to figure out. I'd venture to say that 90% of the features I wouldn't have known were even there without the tutorials.One feature I was really looking forward to using was their "Magic Fill" tool and I thought I'd talk about that specifically because I would venture to guess that most people would be interested in using it for their photos. It allows you to remove things from photos and then the program automatically "fills in" the now-blank spot with background from the rest of the photo. (A handy alternative to the old-fashioned, time-honored tradition of cutting people out of photos, lol.) Alas, it didn't work as well as I'd hoped which is just a limitation of the program. It works when the background to fill in is some repetitive pattern (ie, the sky or grass or concrete), but not if you're cutting out, say, a person in a crowd. It fills in what the program sees to be the background, but it doesn't always visually work....in other words, there are a lot of times where it just looks fake.Aside from that, I've been learning all about creating different layers and applying them. Some of the other features like skin-smoothing, and the ability to auto-wrap text within a selected area work nicely (especially for making your own images like cards, graphics for social media, website graphics, etc), others I'm still learning. So if you are just now getting into the whole photo-editing thing, this is a decent program. I'm sure there are still more features I haven't even discovered yet. Just be aware there is nothing to hand-hold you through the process of learning to use the program, you'll have to be pro-active and get the tutorials, there are some You-Tube videos out there....just do a Google search and plenty of things come up. Take the time to learn to use the features and you'll probably get a lot out of this.

For those who had a problem with the ball being too small to fit the chair, I had that issue at first too. Then I figured out that the ball will keep inflating bigger until it does fit. Problem solved there. As others have said, it's quick and easy to put together and nice that it comes with all the necessary tools to do it (a small wrench to secure the metal part) and the ball air pump. I can only award it 3 stars though because once it's all put together, the chair is too darned short (close to the ground) to sit at anything except maybe a low coffee table? I thought it would be great for my 2nd grader's desk but when she sits on it her small desk is level with her forehead, hahaha. So mostly she ended up just taking the ball out of the chair and playing bouncy ball with the dang thing. Not it's intended purpose, I'm sure.

While I enjoyed Kubica's debut novel The Good Girl, it wasn't a huge stand-out for me (although many readers absolutely loved it). But it was a decent debut and I'm always looking to see new authors get better and better with each turnout. So I didn't hesitate to read her new novel here, Pretty Baby, and hoped it would surpass The Good Girl. I can't really say that it did, although it was an entertaining read. Kubica uses multiple points-of-view to tell her stories, leaving blanks that keep you guessing until the end. In Pretty Baby, she uses three main characters - Heidi, her husband Chris, and Willow - to weave the story of a wife who altruistically brings a young homeless teen mother and her child into her family's home. Who is the "bad guy" here? Hints dropped all over the place as things unravel and it all comes down to character motivations....think you have it figured out? Maybe or maybe not. I whipped through this in a day and although it isn't the perfect novel or high literature, it does keep you reading just to figure out if your guesses about the characters are correct. All in all, I'd rate this the same as The Good Girl....I was hoping for more depth, but it felt rushed to me and like some things were glossed over. I'm okay with that overall. And I'll read her next book as well hoping that eventually she really digs deep (less commercial) and hits a home-run.

I know I shouldn't be reading a series out of order, but I couldn't resist the premise of this book. Although I dearly love the psychologically twisted plots of the Scandinavian thrillers that seem to have become so popular in the wake of Steig Larsson's hit series some years back, I hadn't yet read a Karin Fossum novel. The Drowned Boy immediately drew me in with a fairly simple premise: did the young parents of a child with Down's Syndrome drown their own son? Fossum focuses more on the psychological than action which was not only appropriate for this novel, but is a feature I prefer in my crime books (less gruesome action and more focus on the scariness of some people's minds). The plot, therefore, might seem to move more slow than you are used to if you normally read more action-packed novels. But it is no less intense and frightening. I'm officially now a Fossum fan and am returning to the beginning of the series to read them all. Very recommended if you enjoy novels that have more emphasis on characterization than shoot-em-up action.

It's a classic game and I'm glad Hasbro still make it. I have memories of playing this as a kid and thought it might be fun for my kids (7 and 9). Well, maybe kids have changed. They liked it for about the first 15 minutes and then.....meh. Sigh. Not Hasbro's fault, my fault for raising two kids who don't understand the awesomeness of OPERATION. I would give it a full five stars had Hasbro not changed the pieces you are operating on....they updated the pieces to be cutesy things like a watch and a cell-phone (son: "Why are we removing a cell phone from his body? That's dumb.") and things like that instead of body organs, lol. So much for inspiring young surgeons of tomorrow, haha.Anyway, pretty much still the classic game you remember with updated pieces to remove from the body. Enjoy.

It occurs to me that there are probably such a wide variety of review ratings because I think your experience with this neat little device is going to vary depending on what you want to use it for. I simply wanted to connect an upstairs guestroom, which had little to no wi-fi reception due to our router being located way downstairs. Bam...this handy device solved that problem in less than 20 minutes (time it took me to figure out how to set it up....I made it way too complicated, by the way, this is plug-and-play type of stuff here). Now I will say this: while it works great, the speed is slightly - just enough to be barely noticeable - slower than we get downstairs with our normal wi-fi. But I am completely okay with this. It's still more than fast enough to handle streaming movies, etc. And that is more than I expected to get. I'm happy and would recommend this gizmo if you don't expect over-much from it.

I consider myself something of a vacuum expert. With two children (three, if count my husband which I frequently do) who seem to suffer from memory loss when it comes to TAKE OFF YOUR SHOES INSIDE!!!, I live with a never ending barrage of dirt, pine needles, and heaven knows what other awful outside stuff being tracked inside constantly. Every day. You can only fight it with a vacuum. So as you can probably imagine, I've been through countless vacuums. And I'm here to tell you, most all of them are meh at best. Most of the vacuums I've gone through have been mid-price ranged Dirt Devils and the like, although I do have one 5 year old Dyson here that was supposed to be the be-all-end-all of vacuums that turned out to be no better than the Dirt Devils (and a pain in the heinie to clean the canister, to boot, so it doesn't get used much at all).Enter Electrolux. I've had it for 15 days now so I can only give a preliminary report, but holy moly guacamole: THIS is a vacuum. I went into this with a fair amount of skepticism....oh sure, put a fancy brand name on it and charge 5x as much....but in this case, you get what you pay for. This vacuum cleans like you would not believe. So did we get that part out of the way? It cleans like crazy....wow.Okay, so it has features. Normally, I couldn't care less about extra features because I don't tend to use many of them. But Electrolux had someone just like me designing this darned thing. First of all....a handy switch *on the handle* to switch from hardwoods to carpet. Thank you. Couldn't be easier or make more sense. Next, the attachments (slim nozzle for getting into places like your sliding glass door casement where it gets so yukky and the duster for your baseboards) are in the darned handle. Takes two seconds to switch to them. And the suction on the Electrolux is so good that the attachments WORK. (Did I mention that this vacuum works?) There are two other attachments that come with the vacuum that don't store on it - another hardwood floor attachment which is optional and an upholstery one - although because they aren't stored on the vacuum I probably will lose them, ha.Now for one of my biggest litmus tests: cleaning it out. The canister couldn't be easier to clean. Quick and easy to dump in the garbage can plus you can see from the outside of the vacuum when it's getting full and needs to be emptied.Add to all of this how quiet this thing is (especially on hardwood floor setting) and you'll love it so much. I'll update the review to let you know how it's holding up over time because that is the failing of most vacuums in my opinion, but this thing is amazing. And worth it.

As a huge fan of Jane Smiley it was inevitable that I would follow this trilogy through to the end with this final installment, Golden Age. If you haven't read the previous two novels, I highly suggest you start there and not treat this as a stand-alone novel (although I suppose it *could* be read as such, I just don't see the point). Covering the final years of the Langdon family from 1987 to 2020, Golden Age wasn't as fulfilling as I'd hoped but I should note here that I didn't find the previous two novels as fulfilling as I'd like, either. I just kept reading and hoping that this final novel would bring me that love that I've found in Smiley's previous work. Alas, it was not to be.Competently written, I simply never connected with any of the characters enough to fully engage with the saga. This is probably more my problem than the author's. As we enter this last novel, the Langdon family has grown quite a bit with descendants so there are quite a few more characters than in previous novels. While I didn't have a problem with that per se, again I didn't really connect with any one of them. I think I enjoyed the second novel the best of the three, to be completely honest.If you've read any of Smiley's work, you're probably familiar with her style of writing (one that won her a Pulitzer). If not, I'd suggest reading her prize-winning A Thousand Acres first and if you enjoy it, then perhaps give this trilogy a try.

I can't say enough wonderful things about Scholastic's Branches books. They are just the perfect transition from children's picture-type books to reading chapter books. My seven year old daughter is utterly horse crazy so she was smitten with this story of a girl who visits her grandmother's ranch to find a "wild" pony named Jewel. Both of them get to do a lot of growing up together. The chapters were just short enough to keep her attention, the vocabulary challenging yet not so difficult to make her give up. It's lovely to see a first grader reading chapter books on her own....infuses such reading confidence! Highly recommended (I recommend nearly all the Branches books....just find one to suit your child's interests and buy them, you won't regret it!).

From a parent's perspective, I enjoyed Moore's novel about a San Francisco family with three daughters, the eldest preparing - and expected to attend - her father's alma mater, Harvard. The incredible pressure and decisions this leads to is presented in a humorous/serious light, if you've ever experienced that in a novel before. Although there are witty moments, the seriousness of what may be lost in terms of family and true happiness in the never-ending quest for perfection and high goals is an always-present theme.Recommended for parents everywhere (and teens, too, as they start entering the world's competitive rat-race), this is an enjoyable novel that has a lesson to teach and is worth the read.

These are just the perfect size....large enough to be noticed but small enough to fit snugly right on my earlobe. The blues compliment each other very nicely. They can be worn with a dressy/work outfit or just to dress up a casual bluejeans outfit. I don't have a sensitivity to any kind of metals, but these are sterling silver for those who are sensitive to fake metal posts in their ears.Very pretty. First day wearing them I received three different compliments. :)

I might be writing this review from a different perspective in that I have little to no biblical knowledge to compare David - the subject of Brooks' new novel - to. Aside from a vague familiarity with the whole David and Goliath reference, my knowledge of this apparently well-known biblical figure was pretty much zero going into this book. And I am perfectly fine with that because it meant I wasn't going to be persnickety about the details in this work of fiction.So from that perspective, I have to tell you that I very much enjoyed the book (despite a slightly slow beginning). Despite a soap-opera quality, which I'm going to assume wasn't of Brooks' doing but taken from her source material (ha), she still manages to give *some* dignity to this lurid tale of a very flawed man trying, and often failing, in his roles as father, husband, ruler. Ultimately I would say that it is Brooks' writing that saves this novel from being just another lascivious historical fiction novel which it probably would have been in anyone else's hands. Brooks handles lurid scenes with a deft touch - enough to keep you on the edge of your seat without letting it all get tacky.As noted, I can't speak from a religious person's point of view or imagine how they'd view this novel. But as a non-Christian with little knowledge of the religion, I found it highly entertaining. Recommended.

This turned out to be an excellent wireless dog fence if you use it as it's intended and follow the instructions properly. The instructions say that it takes about an hour to set up and that was true for me (1 hr 20 minutes). The fence works in a radius (circle). There are no wires to bury or anything like that. You simply set up the main controller on an exterior wall - it plugs into an outlet - which will be the center of your radius of your fence area. You can set up the radius to extend anywhere from 40-400 feet out from controller. It's important to note that the signal from the controller cannot go through metal objects, other outbuildings, clumps of trees/landscaping or thick thinks like that. So you need to be aware of this when setting up your radius or the fence won't work properly for you.Once you've got the radius set up correctly, there will be a "trigger zone" for your dog that your dog will encounter first which beeps their collar before they run into the boundary. The kit comes with a plethora of small little flags to put around your trigger zone....these are for training your dog. There are explicit training instructions for your dog in the manual and it is important to use it!!!! It's not fair to just set up the fence and let your poor dog try to figure it out on his/her own...crikey. The training, the manual will tell you, should take about a month. Please, please, PLEASE follow through on this is you want the fence to be successful. We are over half way through the process and it's working wonderfully. I'm not giving up even though we're successful now because we need to solidify this training.Please read the product description carefully before buying. Know your property to know if this will work for you. Check out their website where you can see the product manual online....by reading the manual you will know right then and there if this will work on your property. If it will (ie, line of sight issues from the controller), then ask yourself if you are 100% committed to doing the month's worth of training. If you are, make the investment and you'll like this product. But if you are looking for a "quick fix" to your dog's roaming issues that you want stopped yesterday, go buy an fence you bury instead.

Contigo makes a good (read: non-leaking) product as a general rule of thumb....I've bought at least a dozen for my kids over the years to replace those that have gotten lost, smashed, one run over by the car in the driveway (oh yes, stop laughing), etc and so on. This one showed up on the doorstep and has the good autoseal top that requires the child to push a button when they drink to unseal the opening allowing the liquid to flow through. Once they understand that part, they're in business. There's no straw so no sucking on it, they have to tip it up to drink just like a regular cup. In that sense, it's a "big kid" cup. And it's not a thermos in that it isn't designed to keep drinks cold or anything like that.But all of that aside, I've used these for years. My daughter, who is 7, still loves them. She takes them to school because they won't leak in the backpack. We take them camping, in the car, etc etc. I love them. Contigo is the best for NOT LEAKING. I think we've tried every design they have by now, lol. Dishwasher safe (I don't know if they say they are or not, but I've always tossed them in the dishwasher and they are no worse for wear), they don't get moldy, hold up well to just about any abuse (except being run over by the car, see above). You can buy them knowing they are not going to leak.

It's really, really rare that a hair care product earns 5 stars from me....I mean, it really has to work. I tried a sample size of this stuff recently, never expecting anything really great out of it. Like most of you, I've spent probably hundreds of dollars over the years on stinking hair products looking for something that really does stop frizz or make dried/damaged hair better. Some products might work a bit, but nothing is really a "miracle" cure. My stylist and I have a deal: if either of us ever find something that really works, we'll call each other immediately. Well, I called her today about this product. I used the sample over the course of a week just to be sure it wasn't a fluke, but this stuff is AMAZING. I have colored/processed hair that even my stylist says "I'm sorry, this is the best I can so until the ends grow out." It is typically coarse or brittle due to damage on the bottom 4 inches or so from the bleaching/coloring. It's not horrid, but I miss my normally soft hair! This brought it back...not kidding. And I don't even have to use it every day. I use it after washing my hair (which I do every 3-4 days because my hair is very thick), let it air dry and then use a flat iron or curlers or whatever to take out frizz and that's it. Don't have to use any kind of curlers/irons/whatever again until I wash my hair again. Hair is silky, smooth, soft for the duration. Can't believe this stuff does what it says. And I really couldn't believe the price when I came over here to Amazon....wow. Totally worth this price! Try it....trust me.

4.5 Stars. Ancient Appetites, although marketed as a Young Adult genre novel, turned out to be more heavily slanted towards the "adult" than the "young." Personally, I loved the book but I'm always mindful of the target marketing group when I'm reading these books and it's heavy violence reminded me of Pierce Brown's Red Rising Trilogy in the sense that those excellent books are also sold as Young Adult and I see them as very much adult books. But what do I know?Anyway...someone called this Steampunk Ireland and I liked that description very much. The filthy rich Wildenstern family is a violent bunch who don't seem to have problems bumping each other off for control of the family wealth and power. When young Nate finds himself the heir following his brother's "accidental" (yeah, right) death he's likely now in danger himself even as he sets about finding who was responsible for his brother's death. Because this is steampunk-ish, there's a lot of interesting world building going on and I loved that part of it. McGann gives us a fascinating other-world Ireland with mechanical animals and a Victorian time period. It's a great set-up that fires the imagination.As I said, a lot of violence. I'm a mom and personally, I don't really limit what my kids read as long as they are talking to me about what they are reading. So I would be okay with my younger teen reading this, but I can understand if other parents might feel otherwise. If you think you might not, maybe you should give it a read first. Otherwise, older teens....high-school age or so.

I rated this book at 3 stars, which by Amazon's standards means "It's okay." That about sums it up. There is nothing spectacular about this story of a family disintegrating in the wake of a father's affair. I'm certain we are meant to feel something here....a connection or sympathy or something (anything) for one of the characters. Perhaps for the children who stumble upon the evidence of their father's infidelity at such a tender age. Perhaps for the wronged wife. Perhaps even for the faithless husband himself....he must have had reasons, right? But nothing ever happens that bridges that gap for the reader. We read about a family falling apart, but nothing is there to make us connect with any of the characters. It's downright frustrating because the author can NOT have meant for this to happen.I don't often say this but if you're determined to read this you *must* get this from your local library. Please don't waste money on it.

The Cartel was a lengthy, but riveting, saga of the Mexican drug trade and one DEA agent's obsession with bringing down a Mexican drug cartel and it's leader. I really quite enjoyed it and was hooked (pardon the oblique pun) from the very beginning. While the story line of DEA agent Art Keller and his nearly personal vendetta against the El Federacion cartel leader Adan Barerra kept the plot moving, it was the history of the drug cartels in Mexico that fascinated me more than anything else. This was the first novel by Winslow I've read and since I've finished it I've received quite a few recommendations to read his previous work, The Power of the Dog. I was impressed enough by this novel to order his previous book and look forward to reading that, too. If you like reading about the intricacies of the US drug wars wrapped within the plot of a thriller novel, you'll like this book.

There aren't too many stellar YA series these days not specifically geared towards teen girls. The Shattered Sea trilogy, however, is an exception to the rule these days and I highly recommend these books. If you're not familiar with this author, he normally writes adult fantasy novels (and darned good ones, I might add). This trilogy was his first foray into the Young Adult world and I'll admit I was skeptical at first given that his adult books are heavy on the violence - although I must say that it is always integral to the plot. I wasn't sure if he could pull off the plot of a Young Adult novel without all of that explicit violence and still keep a riveting story. Result: he can. In spades.It's difficult to give a specific plot review to this finale of the trilogy without giving away spoilers (for this and the two previous novels). What I can say without spoiling anything is to tell you that new protagonists are introduced - just like the second book of the series - while familiar characters still reappear and are important to the plot even if they aren't necessarily center stage anymore. It's a neat trick. The author continues his fantastic world-building in this novel and admittedly, I'm sad to see this trilogy come to an end....I don't want to leave this world. Frankly, I'm torn between wanting the author to write more about this world or return to his adult fiction worlds and write more there...it's a tough call and I wish we could clone him. He really is one of my favorites.I mentioned earlier that one of the best parts of the Shattered Sea trilogy is that it isn't YA targeted at teen girls....I'd like to clarify that this doesn't mean teen girls won't love his work. As a female, I certainly did. I simply meant that this is a series of books that both genders can appreciate and enjoy. Abercrombie does a remarkable job creating strong male *and* female protagonists....I'm impressed with both.For anyone who appreciates a good fantasy novel with some clear good versus bad and some not-so-clear good versus bad (moral dilemmas abound)....these are books for you.

Just in time for the next academic year (2015-2016), this is a nice academic planner for students or for parents with kids in school. It runs from July 2015 through June of 2016 so you can get a head start or keep track through summer school this year if you need to. It's divided by months and each month starts with a "At a Glance" double page (facing pages) with a monthly overview with the monthly calendar. There are 6 lines for each day of the month here so you can note important reminders and holidays are pre-filled in. The following pages are larger spaces for each day of that month where you can fill in detailed schedules...there are AM and PM columns (8 lines per column).In the back of the planner there are several pages for Contacts, more for Notes, and then one full page divided into months labeled Event Calendar so you can jot down big important events like graduations, recitals, plays, whatever. There is also a laminated Holiday List with dates for 2015-2018 in the back of the planner.The pages are NOT replaceable, but I prefer these kind of planners as the spiral binding is easier for this left-hander to write in. ;) It's light, fits in my purse, yet is still big enough to fit all the stuff I have to write in there (I've got two kids in elementary school....I've got a LOT of stuff to keep track of). The pink bird motif is continued throughout the inside of the planner, by the way....really quite cute.

If you're looking at this product, you probably have purchased one of the seemingly hundreds of varieties of the ubiquitous Nerf Guns for one of your kids and are looking for something along those lines. All kids love those Nerf Guns, ha, I know mine have and own several. I thought this might be a good addition to their disturbing "arsenal." As it turns out, although I rarely pay attention farther than yelling to "KEEP IT OUTSIDE DARNIT!!!", in this case I actually noticed that the Nerf Slingshot is far, far inferior to any of their little Nerf guns.To begin with, the slingshot only comes with 2 darts. Come on, Nerf....what a blatant and cruddy bait-n-switch scheme. Anyone who has any experience with Nerf guns knows what I'm talking about here. How many darts do your kids lose? How many do your dogs eat? Even if the slingshot came with 10 darts, we'd still buy their dang extra packages of darts so to come with a mere 2 darts is cheap and cheesy. Lessens my opinion on the company in general. I don't like being manipulated that way.Next up...the accuracy is joke. I don't expect anything quality here out of a toy, but it would be nice to be able to hit the broad side of a barn. Which is apparently not possible with these.Last, there is no handhold or grip over the plastic part that you hold while pulling back on the sling shot. OUCH. After about 2 pulls, your hand hurts from the plastic digging into your hand. Did anyone over there at Hasbro even test these things out before releasing it?Save your money and get one of the many, many models of Nerf guns instead. Or if you really want a slingshot, find a different manufacturer because Nerf/Hasbro missed the mark here.

I have unfortunately had the sad privilege of observing several church plants not survive. I also have seen two churches have to close their doors and sell their buildings. None of these were churches that I served at, but they were within our district when I served on the District Board. The two churches that had to close their doors and sell their buildings feel under my responsibility. It was heart wrenching.Just recently I met with the board and congregation of a small church that was seeking to try and find a pastor. They courted our church plant as a possible merger, but then decided it wasn't for them. The differences in church style were to much. This church has plenty of cash on hand, a building in very good repair and paid for but no full-time or part-time pastor. They are now down to less than twenty people. It is only a matter of time before they close their doors and sell.So, this book was one of interest for me. I wanted to read what Thom Rainer thought about churches that had died. This is a very short read but probably one of the most fact filled and direct little books that I have ever read.Thom looks at 14 churches that died. He found twelve similarities in the churches and he dissects those similarities in this book. I found his points correct and almost uncannily familiar to what I had experienced. His most direct observation was that all of these dying churches did not think they had a problem and did not think that they would die. They were in denial of their illness.Probably the main point I found was that each of these churches had become inward focused. They stopped looking outside their walls to see their communities and to meet those communities needs. Instead they were more concerned with staying warm and comfortable in their own little world, well fed and satisfied with life. They forgot the Great Commission. They forgot the marching orders that Jesus gave His church after His death.May we never forget those orders. At the end of this booklet after he has dissected what caused the death of these churches Thom gives several suggestions for diagnosis of your church and then remedies to help your church regain it's health and not find that they have a fatal disease.May you find the truths of what you need to help your church not succumb to a fatal illness

This intriguing story is written in two time periods. One time period is the growing up phase of Grace Blades life where things were anything but normal. The second time period is Dr. Grace Blades life as a Psychologist.Grace Blades was born to a family of dysfunction. Her dad drank way to much and abused his wife and daughter at times, her mother was an escapist who tried to stay out of her husbands way. Grace was left to fend for herself most of time. Due to a tragic circumstance both parents die and Grace is placed in the Foster Care system where she goes from home to home until a final destination secures her destiny.Grace is brilliant, a genius, and learns by just reading and absorbing. At her last stop in the Foster care system she is introduced to Malcolm who is a Psychologist specializing in children and he feeds Graceâ€™s appetite for learning.While in her last Foster Home Grace observes a set of three children who come in and appear as totally dysfunctional. A death happens, then another and Grace is left on her own.But Malcolm and his wife Sophie come through and bring Grace home to their mansion and raise her as their own.Grace using her intelligence to the max graduates from Universities with a PHD in Psychology and sets up practice.She then comes in contact with a young man who eventually is murdered. This sets off a mystery that Grace is bound to solve and solve it in a way that no one would imagine. As the daughter of a Murderer does she have a part of her father in her that leads her to harsh judgment and action?Well, read and find out. It is very interesting. I think at times it slows down a bit too much and has too much detail that is unnecessary, but all in all it is a fun read.Enjoy!

Mark DeVine writes a very intriguing account of how a dying Baptist Church in the Kansas City area turned to the Lord for direction in how to keep this 150 year old church alive and start it growing again. Was it to bring in a new pastor? Was it to merge with another church in the area? Or maybe was it time to call it quits and close the doors?Mark was teaching Theology at a local Seminary when he became the part-time preaching pastor at this church. His first thought was that the church had the viability to continue and to start growing again, but that it would take a God thing to make that happen. So he started to pray.After a couple of years he approached the church leadership about merging with another church. They agreed and sought out a partner. Four different churches were interested. But after a long process and a vote to merge the other church selected in the process ran aground with some problems of their own and the merger did not happen.Demoralized the church basically hunkered down again but kept praying for God to bring a good solution. They didn't want the history or ministry of the church to die. That is when Mark started conversations with Darrin Patrick about The Journey in St. Louis taking over a church in Kansas City. With some prayer and direction from God that happened. A small dying church of 80 people within a year had grown into a growing church of 600 people. How does that happen without killing off the old congregation? Well, that is the topic of the book.Read and see what God can do when a people of God are willing to let go and let God do His thing.

Simple installation. First you put the battery (CR 232) in the transmitter (Doorbell) and then two double "A" batteries in the receiver, the batteries are supplied with the product. Once you have the batteries in the devices you then follow the instructions to synchronize the doorbell with the chime unit. This is simple and takes maybe three or four seconds.You will want to install the doorbell on the outside by your door. There are screws included to attached the bracket, or there is double sided tape that is also included. I used the screws to attach the bracket. It took less than 30 seconds to install the bracket and clip the doorbell into the bracket.The receiver has two options for your installation. You can either hang it on a wall using a screw and securing the mounting section, much like a picture, or you can use the stand that is supplied with the unit and stand the door chime up on a table or shelf. We chose to use the stand and have it on a shelf unit near the front door in the living room. We liked the idea of being able to move it around.Then you select the chime that you want. There are ten different chimes. Two Christmas ones, the birthday song, regular chime and then a couple of songs. You thus can change the chime to suit the season or your own desire. It is very easy to do, you just push the chime button until the selection you want plays, then let the button up and it is set.There is a volume control that gives you three volume settings to suit your desire.All in all from unpacking to inserting the batteries and installing the doorbell it took me maybe five minutes to complete everything.I'm very satisfied with the device and like the different ring tones.Enjoy!

Raisa Jordan is a DSS agent in Israel who has come to take over the task of an assistant resident officer for the embassy. She is just on the job when her predecessor is killed trying to exchange information with Palestinian terrorist. What was he trying to do and why? Her task is to find out and report back to her superior what was going on. But as she delves into the mystery she uncovers several other major threats that need to be addressed before the Secretary of State shows up for a peace conference with local politicians. Along the way she will meet a U.S. Federal Judge who is in Israel to find medical treatment for his daughter. But he just happens to have had a hand in freezing the assets of a terrorist group that is front an center in trying to stop the peace process.Is he the one they are targeting? Is the Secretary of State the one being targeted? Or is it other politicians that they are after?Along the way to finding these answers Jordan will also uncover someone she feels is an counter agent within the Israeli Secret Service. Is this man trying to destroy the peace process? Does he have ulterior motives for the things he is trying to accomplish? Is he really a double agent?All these questions make for a good story that is told in a direct and powerful way by Chris Goff. For her first novel into this genre she appears to have hit a solid double or maybe a triple. You are sure to enjoy it.

Ruchti gives us a booklet that tells stories, it tells stories of how Jesus mended the broken people that he met while on the earth. It gives evidence that Jesus was all about mending the hurt, the pain, the illness and the crippling injuries that people had, but he also was about healing them emotionally and spiritually as well as physically.She tells the stories of people today and how they appear tattered by the effects of abuse, neglect, poor self-esteem, etc. Then she compares them to the Biblical stories and explains how they can be mended. She also takes into her discussion comments about art, everyday objects and how they also appear to give credence to the thought of how things can be tattered but then mended.I found the book a quick easy read. There is no major deep theological discussion. There is no exegetical breakdown of the scripture that she brings to bear on the topic of the Wounded Soul. There are stories. Now, while there are no deep theological debates lets understand that stories are things that bring healing. Jesus dealt with a culture that was basically a story telling culture. Thus people that were healed will be people whose stories can be told around the evening fire, household table or at bedtime. They would bring peace, understanding and healing to those who heard the stories and took comfort from knowing that God understands us and desires to mend us.So, simple, direct, comforting, caring and filled with hope for those who feel that life has tattered their lives and they might not be able to go on.

I appreciated this book by C. Stephen Evans, a Professor from Baylor University. As a Philosopher I at first was apprehensive to read his book. I have not appreciated the work of Philosophers in the past and have often found their work hard to digest and understand, they tend to be a bit lofty and wordy.But C. Stephen Evans does a great job of writing in words that every layman will understand and be able to digest. He makes very good logical conclusions based on the evidence that he has studied and gathered together for his work.His main task in writing this book is to talk about â€œThe New Atheism,â€ as it is being developed in our culture today. Here are the main tenants of his book in his own words; â€œI take it that the major complaint (though not the only one) of the New Atheists about religion is that faith is intellectually baseless. In this book I try to give a clear case that belief in Christian faith still makes sense and thus answer that criticism.â€ He further states, â€œSo the book answers a major charge of the New Atheists make not by responding to their specific complaints but by showing how a thoughtful Christian might â€˜give a reason for the hopeâ€™ that faith embodies.â€I believe that he develops his topic well, he addresses many things that we as Christians are facing in our world today and helps develop answers that we can use in talking with friends who doubt Christianity. I took a long time to work through the book, not because it was difficult, but because I was outlining each chapter and framing my own conclusions and arguments (arguments in the good sense) that I could use with those who are living in this modern world of the New Atheism.I recommend this book to Pastors and lay people alike. I believe that it will become a major book to help us work through how to talk and build relationships with those who are out in the culture today stating that Christianity is archaic and thus dying.This book makes me almost want to go back to school and study Philosophy, but alas I am a bit to old for that, but not to old to learn something new from a great writer such as C. Stephen Evans.

It is truly interesting to see the disparity in reviews of W.E.B. Griffin's new book. Either you love it or you hate it. Frankly, I enjoyed the book very much, so why only 4 stars? Well, because I don't think it is his best work. But it is worthy of your reading if you are a W.E.B. Griffin fan.Homicide Sergeant Matthew Payne takes us on a wild ride of several days through the labyrinth of murders going on in Philadelphia. It provides the reality of a city out of control in regards to gun control, criminal activity, drugs, gangs and crooked politicians. Some of the police are not the best either. But Payne is one of a kind, diligent, thorough, competent and not corrupted by any of the enticements that crooked cops can fall to.He is trying his best to bring about a change to the city. But he is basically the "Dirty Harry" of the Philadelphia Police Department, although they like to call him Wyatt Earp. While he has been taken to task for his willingness to shoot bad guys it is not because he shoots first and asks questions later, it's because he identifies himself and then if necessary pulls the trigger. All of his Office Involved Shootings have been declared appropriate by Internal Affairs. But the crooks would like the public to think otherwise.The book starts with Payne in trouble, then it backtracks a couple of days to give the build up to the story, then comes back to the beginning at the end of the book. I think it draws you in, gives you many facts and details and keeps you interested throughout. I'm not quite sure what the one and two star reviewers were looking for, this is truly a W.E.B. Griffin Police Drama.Enjoy!

Alex Hawke has a problem, someone wants him dead. That someone is Russian, but is it Putin's men or a break off group that Alex made angry by destroying their coup? Whatever the case they are not just trying to kill Alex but the are also after his son. This makes things complicated as you try to figure out how to protect a six year old boy. But with Nell by the boys side he is safe. Nell being a special operative that has training and brains and just happens to be the woman that Alex loves.Alex also gets a call from Putin wanting him to make a visit. During that visit Putin gives a demonstration to Alex about a new military weapon that will revolutionize the world of warfare. It is a colorless, tasteless liquid that packs a powerful punch, more than that of a nuclear explosion.What is Putin doing with that? Probably preparing to start WWIII and bring Russia back to the status of superpower and not just any superpower but the number 1 superpower.Can Alex keep his son alive? Can he defeat the overly megalomanic Putin from doing his worse? Can he save the world?That seems a bit overly dramatic, but it is most likely the full course of the story.Ted Bell does a great job of building the story, building the characters, keeping you guessing about certain subjects and riveted to your seat as he takes you on a wild ride of politics, warfare, terrorist and assassins.Enjoy!

I really enjoyed this true life adventure. This young lady became a "hiker" early in life taking several major trails and enjoying the wilderness. Then after a harrowing beginning to her life away from home at college she set out on the walk of a lifetime. Not many people are willing to attempt this journey, an especially to attempt it alone.Aspen sets out to conquer the continental trail of the West Coast from Mexico to Canada. She will hike through the desert, through mountains, across snow covered fields, ice fields, etc. She will hike in extreme heat and then in below freezing weather.Her journey was a cleansing of her soul. It was an adventure that she needed to regain her confidence and trust in herself and her abilities. I enjoyed reading about her adventures and the encounters that she had on the trail. I don't think I could ever imagine a life of hiking like this. Her story is riveting in so many ways and you will cheer her on and wish you could encounter some of her adventure and be glad that you didn't have to face some of the struggles that she did.The only other nature book that I enjoyed this much was a book on the life of a Forrest Fire Watcher who manned a Fire Tower in the mountains that kept him and his dog away from civilization for six months of the year. Both stories filled me awe for the accomplishments that someone can make when they set their minds to it.I hope you enjoy the story as much as I did.

I have often fought with screen protection films to get them on my iPad, iPhone or other devices and get all of the bubbles out. I just don't seem to have good luck with those.So, I wondered about these privacy protectors when I order them.I was very pleasantly surprised. They are actually a thicker item than film, they do not bend or flex, they are sturdy. Yet they are very thin.You use the cleaning wipes that they send with the screen protector, then peel the backing off the protector and place it on top of your iPhone 5s screen. It adheres to the clean surface and you rub it a couple of times to make sure the fit is good and there you have it, you are done.Being sturdy and a bit thicker than the films I have used in the past I wondered about the sensitivity of the touch screen after you have applied the protector. The sensitivity is perfect. It still sense your finger or a stylus without any wait in time or without any missing beat at times.This particular "glass" screen protector is tinted so that it is Anti-spy Privacy. The tinting of the screen dimmed the brightness a bit but it was not too restricting. Now, people looking from across the table or near you can't see your screen well at all because of the tinting, but you see it just fine. So, it does its job if you wanted a product that protectors your view from others.I am completely satisfied and happy with the product.Enjoy

If you want to add a little bit of bling to your iPhone 5 this is a nice item. It is a metal cast frame that goes around the edges of your iPhone 5 or iPhone 5s. There is a bit of bling on the facing of the frame to ad some bling to your phone. In my case it is a 'gold' fleck type of coating that ads a bit of class to the phone.There are openings for the headphone jack, the charging cable and the speakers, as well as the sound on/off/vibrate button on the side of your iPhone. For the top Power button and the side volume buttons they have a nice flex touch on the frame work that is sensitive to your pressure and thus depresses those buttons on the iPhone 5 for you.The top clasp seemed a bit flimsy to me at first because when the frame is not on your phone it didn't click together. But once the frame is on your phone when you clasp the top part of the frame together it clicks into place and holds very snugly.All in all to add bling to your phone this is a nice item. It would not appear to me to add much in the way of protection from damage if you drop the iPhone, although the metal frame would add some cushion if your phone hit on it's corner or edge.Enjoy

We enjoyed the movie tremendously. It seemed like a cross between Men in Black and James Bond. The Kingsman are a secret order of men and women dedicated to the protection of the Kingdom of England and her sovereignty.In this particular movie we have the standard Evil Villein who is wanting to take over the world, mainly by brining the population under control by designing a weapon of mass destruction that is neither Nuclear Weapons nor Biological Weapons. Instead it is a system of weapon that will bring people to a boiling point of loosing control of their ability to reason and instead respond to everything with anger.Our Hero is one of the men of The Kingsman who is doing his best to unwrap the truth about this evil plot while at the same time trying to recruit the next Kingsman to replace another who has died in the line of duty.The story line is very plausible given today's technology. The men and women in the service of their country is also plausible and the way they go about their work is very gifted and unique just as the Men in Black and James Bond would do.The only frustration I had with the movie was the use of vulgarity as a standard way of daily dialogue. Really? Can't people talk without so much vulgarity?Well, other than that we enjoyed watching the movie.

This is a great story book for our young granddaughter. The pages are heavy construction, i.e. they are thick like cardboard, so they are holding up well even with the rough handling that a toddler gives the book.The drawings are very nice and they hold our toddlers attention very well.The short comments/lessons are good and allow a good jumping off point for us as we read the book to our toddler.BUT, my main reason for really liking this book is the hefty pages, most of our other books for our toddler have regular weight paper and they tend to get bent or torn pretty easily, so I was really grateful for the design of the thick heavy pages that can take a huge amount of abuse and still look great.

We set this 4 position holder in a utility closet near our washer and dryer. It was easy to install and does a very adequate job of holding our broom, mop and duster. None of these items weigh very much so they are held just fine with no slippage. I can't say whether it would hold up with something heavy you might try to hang from it. The design is for a standard broom or mop handle.We are completely satisfied with the product and it has met all our expectations.

I love these bars. The combination of the Dark Chocolate and nuts with a tiny bit of sea salt is perfect. The taste is great and they are perfect for a mid morning or mid afternoon snack that is healthy and filling.These are a bit more expensive than a regular granola bar you get at the grocery store, but they are much more nutritious than most granola bars, at least that is my opinion.Good product, good price, nice to get them delivered directly to my home.

The pants fit perfectly when they came. It saved me the hassle of going to a clothing store and having to search the racks for the right size. Normally I have a problem with the length because my waist and length combination don't seem to be one that the manufacturer sends to the stores very often. So I have had at times to settle for an inch longer than I want and that was a bother.But ordering online has proven to be a blessing as I get the right waist size and the right length.

We have been having quite a few deer come to our backyard area where I have bird feeders, so I decided to purchase this feeder to put out corn for the deer. We have a mother and two fawns coming.The feeder is a Plastic design that is light weight. It has holes in the bottom portion to allow moisture to drain if any gets in and to allow some airflow so that there won't be any mold build up. There is a top that clips down over two plastic holders to keep out the moisture when it rains and keep some critters out. BUT, this is a poor design on the top feature, the clips don't provide a good hold. I eventually drilled a small hole through the brackets to allow the cotter pin to go through the lid as well as the brackets. This has kept the raccoon from opening the top.My only other dislike was the fact that the unit did not come with any straps to attach the feeder to a tree or post. I had to provide my own. Luckily I have some good straps in the barn so that wasn't a problem, but I would have thought they should have provided those as part of the product.Still, I like the unit and it is serving it's purpose quite well.

The woodpeckers and other birds love this product. I have great success in attracting two different types of woodpeckers to our outdoor feeders using these suet packs.Getting a box of suet for a good price is another positive. You don't have to drive to the home center to pick them up they get delivered to your door.If you have Amazon Prime it is even nicer since there is no added shipping cost.They come packaged nicely in their container box, with shrink wrap around the entire package. Then each individual Suet Pack is also in it's own container. I will purchase these online again for the foreseeable future as they work well and come quickly.

Nice product, easy to install, holds up to 15 pound planter without any problem. I have not tried anything heavier.Comes with the screws to attach to your fence, house, deck, etc. If you need screw anchors for drywall you will have to supply those yourself, it does not come with that.

I enjoyed this novel very much. As a Christian novel I was interested to see how the author would handle the subject of a young woman of 37 years of age who had never been married now being faced with maybe finding the love of her life, but in a man 17 years her senior. That is quite an age difference and even more interesting since Mitchell Sanderson's children would be contemporaries of Suzanne Bloomer. How would they take their fathers interest in a younger woman.So there are several topics the novel covers that I think are handled very well and they are:1. How does a single adult survive in a church of married couples with lots of children, where the pastor seems to forget when he preaches that he has single adults as part of the mix?2. How does a young woman contend with the memories of being bullied by other teenagers because she was a bit outside the realm of the popular group?3. How does a young woman set behind her the non-loving environment of her home upbringing?4. What about Christian School Teachers at Private Christian Schools and the paltry salaries they are paid. How does a gifted single adult woman teacher survive on that salary and what about retirement?5. What about eating disorders? Suzanne is very petite and some would call her skinny, that drives her nuts, does she or does she not have an eating disorder?6. What about the fact that Christian couples take advantage of a single woman in her thirties when it comes to baby sitting, assuming that the "old maid school teacher" should do it for no pay?7. What about re-marriage for a man who has lost his wife to cancer? But more than that, what should he do when he is attracted to a woman 17 years his younger?8. How will grown adult children of Mitch Sanderson deal with their fathers growing attraction to Suzanne Bloomer?These and many other subjects are really at the heart of the book. Suzanne has always wanted to be married, she has always wanted to have children of her own, but at no time in her life, so far, has the opportunity come about that she could marry.It hurts her very much that her best friend takes great joy in telling her all about her children and all about her desire to have more and how being pregnant is so great. Then comes mother's day and Suzanne is beat up by the sermon and the desire of others to have her babysit so that husbands can take their wives out to dinner.I thought the book handle all these situations really well, taught good Biblical lessons and wove a good romantic story into the mix.I'm sure you will enjoy reading about a rich older farmer who comes into the life of a thirty something (almost 40) old maid teacher who is poorer than dirt.Enjoy!

While this is Volume 2 in a three volume set it must be noted that this is the last volume being published. Volumes 1 and 3 have been out for a while. This project was taken on by professor's from Dallas Theological Seminary, thus the views are Protestant Conservative Evangelical. Most pastors will know that for decades the major Systematic Theology work from Dallas Seminary has been Lewis Sperry Chafer's 8 volume work. So, why a new three volume series?Well, the answer is found in the introduction for the series, the writers are wanting you to Know God and to do that you must Know About Him. So that means that as a Christian layperson or professional you need to study Theology. But the study of Theology can seem like a daunting task for the layperson. Here is what the introduction states as to why this series of texts;  "Exploring Christian Theology differs from other mini-theologies in that it strives to present a broad consensus, not a condensed systematic model of one evangelical teacher or protestant tradition.......Treat each volume as a simple primer that supplements (not supplants) more detailed treatments of theology--that complements (not competes with) intermediate and advanced works."So, what we have is an attempt to give a more readable version of a Theological Text for the layperson. This is not meant to take the place of a more systematic approach to theology, as it states it is to supplement and complement other works that your denomination might use.So, with that in mind I took up the task of reading through Volume two with the understanding that it was not a comprehensive look at the theological topics that it was going to tackle. I also liked what the author's had to say in that, "since this is not a systematic study you can pick and choose the topic you want to read without working through the text from beginning to end." That is good because most laypeople will have certain topics that they want to delve into without having to build upon them from one to the next.Volume two deals with "The Christian Story in Four Acts:"  Act I -- Creation  Act II -- Fall  Act III -- Redemption  Act IV -- RestorationEach of these topics are broken up into bite size studies that the reader can tackle and accomplish fairly easily. I particularly like their style of how they break down the four acts. The breakdown is:  High - Altitude Survey  Passages to Master  Facts to Never Forget  Dangers to Avoid  Principles to Put into Practice  Voices from the Past and PresentThey also give you some recommendations for further books and studies you might do from things that have been discussed in their text.Reading through this text I felt that they did an excellent job of breaking down the theological jargon in a way that a lay person will be able to understand. They have gone to great lengths to make the book readable.I would highly recommend this material for any person who wants to get to know God better and put that knowledge and relationship into more practical use in their lives.NOW, for one last bit of advice, for my Evangelical Free Church of America lay people this is a good set of books to read, but you also should purchase a copy of "Evangelical Convictions, A Theological Exposition of the Statement of Faith of the Evangelical Free Church of America." It is the official book to explain the complete Statement of Faith of our denomination. It is also well written and also written in a way that any layperson, pastor or theologian can understand.Enjoy learning more about God as you read through these books, and don't forget to spend time in your Bible as well.

I have loved the Jack Ryan, Jr. and The Campus novels. They have been excellent works in the Tom Clancy fashion. I have felt that Grant Blackwood has been a great asset to the Clancy stable of writers, as I have noted in my other reviews of his work.BUT, this novel didn't really work for me. My first problem is that it really only had Jack Jr. in the story until about 70% of the way through, then finally Dom Caruso shows up in the field. That misses the mark of what The Campus is about. It is not about lone wolf characters acting on their own and not giving The Campus the full story. So, either Jack Jr. has fallen far from the family tree or he is thinking that he can be the lone wolf hero of political events and spy activities.Jack Jr. meets with an old friend and finds that he has stepped into a problem in a country that is going to be facing a Coup in the next couple of weeks. Jack Jr. has to figure out what is happening and who the bad guys are and who the good guys are. His friend Seth appears to be having a bit of a break with reality, or is he?Bottom line, The CIA, British Intelligence and Russian Elite Forces are going to be playing a game of political chicken as the country of Dagestan goes through the upheaval of a political coup as the Minster of Interior takes steps to wrestle control of the country from the President of Dagestan.Jack Jr. will find himself on the side of the Minister of Interior and will not be sure that this is truly a wise move. Jack Jr. comes off looking tentative at times and not as decisive as his old man would have been in a similar situation.Jack Jr. will use The Campus assets but not in the way that they should have been used or were used in previous works.I liked the story, I liked the complex situation with many different intelligence agencies involved, I just didn't like Blackwood taking Jack Jr. and making him a lone wolf on this case.Next time lets stick with the whole team and get them back involved as they should be.

The Trident Code is the second book in the Lana Elkins series. Last years book, Lethal Code, was a thrill ride that seemed so fast paced that it might never stop. Well, the Trident Code starts much the same way. Lana Elkins our Cyber Guru is called by the NSA because of a crisis that they are facing. That crisis is a Chinese group of hackers that they want to weed out and make impotent. So, Lana is going to help.But before they can even start their meetings on this issue a new one comes front and center. Someone has hijacked a U.S. Navy Nuclear Missile Submarine. They have released a gas into the air system that kills the entire crew, with the exception of one man who was able to get an oxygen mask on and vent the gas out of the sub and restore the normal oxygen. Is that providence or is it design?Well, soon it seems design because this sub will be front and center for a cyber attack not just on the United States but on the world. The Cyber terrorist claim they can launch the nuclear missiles unless the world caves to their demands. When the world doesn't cave quickly enough they do launch a missile, but it is not headed towards any major city of the world, instead it is headed towards the Antarctic and the polar ice cap and glaciers. Why?Well, here is where the story might be taking a political / Global Warming / environmental shift to do a bit of preaching while still in the thriller realm. The nuclear missile melts a major portion of a Glacier plus breaks off the ice in such a degree that it causes the oceans of the world to start rising. This is what environmentalist have said will happen with Global warming, but it would happen over a very long period of time. But with this nuclear strike it happens overnight.
