The coastlines of the continents are inundated with a four foot rise in sea level (with the threat that another missile will make it an eleven foot rise). To think of this makes you realize what that could actually mean to the world.Most of New Orleans would again be under water, but it would never recede. The Netherlands would be 60% under water at 4 feet and totally under water at 11 feet. Thousands will drown, economies will be devastated, thousands more will either die of thirst or starvation because of the disruption of food deliveries and water purification.This is huge.The charge to Lana and her team, find out who did this, find out how to wrestle back control of the nuclear sub and prevent the launch of another missile, or for that matter the remaining twenty two missiles.The book is fast paced and excellent reading. So, why only four stars? Well, I thought the ending was a bit to quick, to cut off. While we have had a wild ride it just abruptly is over. Maybe that is real life, but it seemed a bit to quick. I wanted a bit more closure on some topics. But all in all it is a good read.

I gave a five star review not because I necessarily think "A God in Ruins" is a great book, frankly I haven't read that book yet.But this CLIFF NOTES style summary and anaylsis of the book is really a nice thing to have. This is my first Instaread summary that I have downloaded to my Kindle and thus I was curious as to what it would give me.First of all, the Instaread Summaries are very short, this one was about 21 pages long. But they are full of information.They start by giving you a summary of the book. The summary hits the high points and basically outlines the book for you. The only problem that I see from reading this is that at times they can contain "Spoilers." In this case it did give some of the plot thread away that many would say is a spoiler.The next section is the Character's section. They take each character and give you an overview of that character, i.e. are they good, bad, conflicted, narciscistic, etc. I found this very helpful because it helps you get up to speed very quickly on the characters of the Novel. So, if you decide to buy the novel you will have a firm grip on the characters as you start. BUT, that does take some of the thrill out of the read as character development is one way you can tell if an author is good or bad.Finally is the anaylsis of the book. They give you their thoughts on the book, they are not prejudice one way or another, they just state the facts as they see them.In the case of this book, the anaylsis points out that the author jumps back and forth from present to past to future. The author also has some times when you find it hard to follow because of all the movement through time periods and peoples lives.For me this gave me a good idea of whether I would like to buy the novel. I don't particularly like writing that goes back and forth, present, to past to future. I usually find that they are cumbersome and cause some frustration in reading.So, with that in mind it gives me a better handle on the novel, I can now read reviews of the real book and decide with a more informed background whether I want to spend the money to buy the book or not.This summary seems a bit pricey at $2.99 for a Kindle Cliff Notes type of book. But I'm not sure how much they should charge, I would think maybe $1.50, but again, I'm not disappointed that I spent $3.00 to help determine if I might like this novel and author.

Cooper Lindsey returns to Justice, Mississippi, in the early 1960's to set up a law practice in the small town where he grew up. His father had been the pastor of the local community church. Coop had been a local sports star and academic star of the community. He went away to college, married a wonderful woman and returned to Justice to settle down.But what happens will alter the course of his and his families life. One morning a black woman, Hattie Ross, comes to his law office and asks him to defend her surrogate son, Calvin, who has been accused of killing a local girl, Becky Booth. She claims that he is innocent and being railroaded by the "white" establishment to get a quick verdict and end to this grizzly crime.Coop has to decide whether he will take the case. If he does it will mean that the whole town (at least the white population) will turn against him because he is defending a young black man. When Coop goes to the jail to meet with Calvin you get your first hint of the deep racial divide that was embedded in the deep South during this time. Calvin doesn't trust Coop and can't believe that a "white man" would be interested in representing him, unless he has an ulterior motive. Coop leaves a bit unsatisfied and not sure what he will do.Bottom line, Coop decides to defend Calvin because he is convinced that Calvin is innocent. The first two thirds of the novel deals with Coop investigating and doing his best to not only prove that Calvin is innocent but also prove who the true killer is. Coop will find only a few people who will help him. One happens to be the Sheriff, which is unusual but very helpful. The other is the Millionaire White Man who owns half of the town and whom both the white and black people seem to hate. Coop can't understand why John David Maltose wants to see Calvin found innocent.What makes this novel so interesting is that the author grabs the civil rights unrest and unravels the deep seated prejudice that was part of the South. He also brings into play the fact that the "Church" didn't really do much to help. The pastor of the White Church will show his color's as a bigot, and the Black Church will show it's color as a place of Biblical Preaching.But to be honest and maybe spoil a tiny bit of the story, the White Preacher comes to understand more about the truth of the Bible as the story unfolds and will have to face his prejudices head on.About two thirds of the way through the story the trial ends. But the story is just getting started. In an unusual way of writing the author takes us from the hour after the trial to 50 years in the future.In 2014 the grandson of Cooper Lindsey comes to Justice, he too is a lawyer, but he comes for a different reason than his grandfather. He comes to find out the truth of what really happened in 1964 and 1965. But he gets caught up in a new trial, this one is a young white teenager (the son of the millionaires) who is accused of killing a Black teenager. The town has now shifted a bit, the new Sheriff is a Black Man, the new Judge is a Black Woman and the Mayor of the town is a Black man. It seems like the racial tides have turned.Now it appears that maybe the Black township people want to put a white boy on trial as a way of getting revenge on the boys family. What will Grandson Clark Cooper Lindsey do? The answer will surprise you and the solution will also be surprising.Enjoy!

These are probably my favorite KIND bars. I love the Dark Chocolate and the Sea Salt. The flavors blend together really well and provide a nice treat.I use them as a breakfast bar on most mornings and at times will use them to supplement for a lunch meal instead of going out to eat.Finally I like to use them as a snack at night when I use to eat Chips and dip or ice cream. This is a more healthy alternative.Since I started to eat these I have lost ten pounds, not because I eat these, but because I don't eat other more unhealthy snacks.I will continue to eat these as alternatives to other snacks

What a fun children's story book. The story is simple and straight forward and your kids or grandkids will love it when you read it to them, or it is simple enough that young readers just learning to read should have fun trying their hand at reading this story.The illustrations are very colorful and well drawn. There are illustrations on every page, there is text (the story) on the left page and an illustration on the right page. So, these should hold the childs attention as you read to them.BUT, here is the fun part. DOWNLOAD the AR app from either Google Play or the Apple App store (it's free). You can then use your Smartphone or tablet to add some fun to the reading. The app uses your camera on the smartphone or tablet and when you point the camera at the illustrated page the drawing comes to life! The page will show up in 3D on your app, and the characters will become animated. The Knight will climb a wall, the Dragon will fly around the sky, the Cat and Dog helping the Knight will also move their pages. The views will be from high above, but what is interesting is that new items will appear on the picture that you didn't see before. I have no idea how this actually works, but it is really cool.The gist of the story is that a happy village is living in peace until a fire breathing dragon comes along and decides to live in a cave above their village. He sees their happiness and becomes jealous and decides he wants to destroy them.The villagers go the ARBI, the Knight living in a Castle near the village and ask him to rid them of the Dragon. He enlists the help of some friends and they set off to deal with the dragon.There are some good lessons for the kids to learn while having a fun story. The app makes it even more fun as your child can spend lots of time watching the pictures come to life.This is a very interesting concept and thus it explains the cost of the booklet.Enjoy!

Our cats have loved the Bergan Turbo toy, they play with it all the time. The major attraction for me was the scratching pad that is in the center of the toy. The cardboard pad is perfect for the cats to dig their claws into (better than my furniture) and if you pour the catnip into the pad then the cats love it even more.We have several cats so we discovered after about three months that the pad was starting to come apart, it is not because they are poorly made, it is because we have too many cats using it. If you have one cat you probably won't have to buy a pad that often.But the fact to get two pads in one package cuts the cost and gives you a back up pad for when the first replacement finally gives up the ghost.I couldn't be happier with these pads and with the Turbo Track toy for the cats. Oh, and the cats love it as well.

I had not watched the Fast and Furious series of movies and wanted to know what all the hoopla was about. So, I rented this on my Amazon Fire TV and enjoyed the movie tremendously. I also like the ease and ability of getting the movie from Amazon and up on my screen quickly without having to wait for a movie to come in the mail or drive to a Red Box or a Video store.The movie had plenty of action, plenty of thrills and frankly I liked the plot line as well, which sometimes these movies don't have a plot.I went on to watch all of the movies in the series and was not disappointed at all.
Got these for my 8th grader.  He has PE this semester and his All-Stars weren't cutting it.  He loved them the moment he tried them on.  Very lightweight and "bouncy" (his words).
Beautiful beads.  More expensive than they're worth.
Good for MAYBE up to 3mm beads.  6mm beads might fit, but you can only get 4-6 in each container. If you work with larger beads, these containers are too small.
At $.17 a bead, I'm not sure these are worth it.  But, glass beads are expensive, and these are pretty.  A nice way to add a bit of color to your work.

These are not worth 15 cents a bead.  They are ok.  I nice way to ad random color, but I am disappointed.  They are not as beautiful as in the photo.  They are, however, glass (as stated) but some might mistake them as plastic.

My son's favorite colors are orange and green.  So I bought this for him.  He is 13.  This sweatshirt is on the thin side and due to the lime green color he can only wear it with certain t-shirts.  It is also definitely "slim cut."  But, it looks great on him and he was thrilled when he received it.  Perfect for windy spring days.
My 13-year-old loves this.  It is warm and goes with everything. He's worn it to school almost every day this spring.
Very small, but I love them.  Perfect for my son's Confirmation.

These are great!  Love the FLAT evil eye.  They are good for mixed media/decoupage, in addition to beading.  I "glued" a few to a mixed media canvas, along with some other unexpected items (i.e., a penny).  These added interest and a kind of "eye spy" interest to my work.

This stuff is really great!  Super shiny!  Look at how shiny some polymer clay pendants that I recently made came out!  This was my 1st time working with polymer clay, so they are less than perfect.  Still, the shine makes them look good.

Wow!  I LOVE this in the copper color.  Look at the beautiful effects I was able to create on some (less-than-perfedt) beads and pendants I made.  I'm sure I'll use this for a lot of different crafts and will be buying more!

Super cute.  I wanted to put a red flower in each for my son's Confirmation party, but 1 arrived broken.  Amazon is taking them back, but now they are out of stock.Too badâ€¦I know I would have used them for other parties.

This product has serious quality control issues.  I ordered these in 3 colors for my 16-year-old son.  2 in size 30" and 1 in 29", because it wasn't available in 30".  Well, he decided to keep the 2, 30" pairs and return the 29" pair.  Why?  Because, even though he LOVED the color most, it was WAY too big!  Bigger than the 30" pairs!  Huh?!?  Well, at least that explains the previous reviews, some of which say these shorts fit large, others which say they fit small, and still others that say they fit fine.Overall, he likes the style of these shorts:  flat front, straight/slim cut, fun colors.I am glad that Amazon offers free returns on them.  At least to Prime members.  My recommendation:  order the color(s) you want in 2-3 sizes and return the ones that don't fit right.
Love these!  Super cute and work well!

This item has "quality control" issues.  I purchased 2 packs so I could make 48 cupcakes.  Well, the first package I opened only contained 23 liners.  Both my son (13) and I checked all the liners very carefully, multiple times, to make sure none were sticking to each other.  When the cupcakes were done baking, we checked again, and there was only 1 liner per cupcake.  Definitely only 23 liners.Luckily the 2nd pack I purchased had 27 liners in it.  So everything turned out OK.  But I was thinking what if I had needed 24 cupcakes and only purchased 1 pack?  Then I would have been "out of luck."Otherwise, these are SUPER cute and a REALLY good price.  Just be aware that you might receive more or less than 24 liners.

I bought this to try it out.  My son (13) and I made a bunch of molds using sea shells, coral, metal objects, and parts of old jewelry.  We had a ton of fun.  Within ½ an hour we were able to use them with Sculpey clay to make charms and beads.  Don't mix more than you need for 1 mold at a time, though.  It begins to stiffen up pretty quickly.

I ordered these for my 16-year-old son because I know he loves all kinds of pockets, snaps, etc.  And, he likes slim cut pants.  These seemed to fit the bill on both accounts.  These pants were very low priced, so I was a bit wary.  Indeed, you get what you pay for.  Generally, these pants are fine.  My son LOVES them.  However, the first time he put them on, one of the snaps on the front left leg (1 of the 2 small pockets pictured on the pants, right side on the photo, left leg on the wearer) broke.  When he tried to open the pocket, top half of the bottom part of the snap stayed stuck to the top part of the snap.  It completely separated from its back half, and thus the fabric.  I don't know if I can find a similar snap to fix this.  Since the top part of the snap (the part on the flap) is still intact, this doesn't look bad.  But, the snap doesn't work and this is disappointing.  Still, I'm giving this 4-stars because the broken snap is a very minor issue and the pants are still wearable.

I just received this and I am happy, happy, happy!  I love the beautiful cranberry color.  It is perfect with my Chantal red cookware set.  This baker is a great size.  Nice and deep.  Some other reviewers of differently-shaped RR bakers have been upset over the color, so I am going to try to describe it.  I would NOT call this color cherry, orange, burgundy, or wine.  I think it is a cranberry color.  It is the color of some dark, perfectly ripe strawberries, too.  I bought the set of two round bakers as well (3-piece set with lid), and that is where I read the comments about color.  This baker has a rustic, handmade look to it. I know it is not handmade, but it looks like it could be. It is more polished than shiny. It is not glossy.This baker is dishwasher safe.  It can be put into the freezer (though not right out of the oven.)

Wow!  These are beautiful!  I just received these and they are gorgeous!  I find the color great.  I do not think it is an orange like red or that they are not shiny.  These bakers have a rustic, handmade look to them.  I know they are not handmade, but they look like they could be.  They are more polished than shiny.  They are not glossy.  As for the color, I would call them a cranberry red.  I have the red Chantal cookware (pots) set and these are great with them.  They are a bit darker, but not much.  They are not orange, cherry, or maroon.  I would not call them burgundy, either, as that is more of a wine color.  I'd call them cranberry or ripe/dark strawberry.I love that the lid fits both bakers.  Dishwasher safe.  Can be put in freezer (just not directly out of the oven).  Very practical and pretty.

Wow!  This little bird is SO beautiful! It's styrofoam body is completely covered in sparkly or pearlescent glitter, beads and sequins (more on it's back and less on the belly/underside.  Its wings and tail consist of several white feathers (2/wing and 4 for the tail) and plastic "wires" with clear "tube" beads on them.  The wires are capped with clear round beads.  These beads capture and reflect light and color.  Cute little bead eyes and a pearlescent plastic beak.  The overall effect is a sparkly little bird.  I am using this on a wreath of olive leaves/branches for my son's Confirmation, but this would be a beautiful Christmas ornament, peace dove, or whatever you need it for.Note, The plastic "wires" used in the tail and wings are not really wire.  They do not stay in shape if you try to curve them like a tail/wing.  They are made of a clear plastic and are wire thickness, almost like VERY thick fishing wire.

These are great!  I bought these for my son (16) and he LOVES them.  Nice skinny fit in camo.  Skinny and slim camo pants are really in style right now, and he wanted a pair.  He has always loved camo, but the traditional baggy/cargo fit of most camo pants is not on trend.  So, he was really happy to find these.  He has a 29" waist and his inseam is 32".  I bought him the 30" because they don't seem to come in 29" (as is the case with most men's pants/jeans).  They fit just fine.  Only a bit loose.  A belt will take care of it, no problem.  Nice color, fit and style.  Recommend.

My kids like the peppermint hot chocolate and the milk chocolate flavors, but the dark chocolates are bitter and they don't like them.  I wish you could buy just the peppermint, as this is their favorite.

I ordered these in purple for my 16.5 year old son.  Purple seems to be the color for guys at his highschool right now.  My son has a 28" waist and a 32" (and lengthening) inseam.  This is VERY difficult to find.  The best I usually do is 29"X32".  So, I took a chance on these in a 30"X32" and they seemed OK.  Not too baggy as some 30" waist pants I have tried.  He will need to wear a belt, but he always wears one anyway.  And these aren't baggy in his butt.  I am very happy to have found these.  Wish they were a little less expensive, as he will outgrow them within the year, but happy wit the free shipping for Prime members.  My son was really happy to get a pair of purple jeans.  I made him promise that he would not, under any circumstances, wear a purple shirt, or even a tee with purple in the graphic with them.  That would be too much here.

I ordered this in the "purples" color for my 16.5 year old son.  He was bummed because a black and purple plaid shirt he had got to small (the sleeves were too short) and he loved that shirt.  So, I tried to find something similar.  Purple seems to be the thing for the boys at his high school right now.  Anyway, his original shirt was more shades of black with a few lines of purple, whereas this On my way! is pretty much just purple.  Still, it is REALLY nice.  The colors are a lot more subtle than I thought they might be based on the photo.  They are actually quite like in the photo, but you never know.  Something like this could arrive a lot brighter (or pinker) than it looks on the screen.  I also love that the inside of the cuffs, neckband and button hole strip is a contrasting fabric, in the sense that it is a different pattern, but stll purple.  This makes it fun to leave the top button open and/or the sleeves turned up now and then.  The fabric is a nice dress shirt fabric, too.  Soft and smooth.  If I can find the right toe, he might wear this with a dark slim-cut suit to his confirmation in May.  I bet he'll be the only young man in a purple shirt!

I loved thes boots.  They were exactly what I was looking for.  I have a regular width foot, but I have pretty big calves, and these boots were tight just at the very top.  I don't know if they would have loosened up or not, but when I tried them on the top edge of the boot cut into my legs, just below my knees.  I returned them, but am sorry I had to.  Because, as I said, I really liked these boots.  A lot.  They came well packed, too, with all the metal hardware wrapped to prevent scratching.

I bought this as a gift for an elderly AUSTRIAN uncle.  It gets quite cold ther in the winter and everyone seems to wear scarves/cowls.  This is 100% wool, so it will be warm.  Also, it is made in America, which makes it a nice gift especially for someone in another country.  Beautiful colors.  Good price.  Free shipping for prime members.  What more could you ask for?!?
Very cute.  I used this to decorate Christmas tags.  They turned out great!

I bought this as a gift for an adult male cousin.  He lives in Austria and it is REALLY cold ther in the winter.  Everyone (men and women) wears scarves and cowls.  This is 100% wool, so it will be warm AND it is made in the USA, which makes it a nice gift especially for someone who lives in another country.  Nice colors.  Good price.  Free shipping for Prime members.  Couldn't ask for more.

I ordered these in Orange for my son who is 14.  He really likes them.  Orange is his favorite color.  Once in awhile I break down and buy him something orange.  But I refuse to let him wear an orange t-shirt with them!  LOL!  The pants are not a bright orange.  They are more of a dark/burnt orange.  That is how they look in the picture on my computer screen, so I received just what I was expecting.  Not shiny at all.  Also good.  I'm very happy with the price and free shipping for Prime members.  I really wouldn't want to pay more for "orange" pants.

Surprisingly, I LOVE this.  I don't know that everyone would, though.  I love the juxtaposition of the red and turquoise beads/colors.  This reminds me of jewelry you'd find in the Sundance (by Paul Newman) catalogue, but at a MUCH lower price.
These are great.  Large quantity.  Good price.  Fast shipping.  I'll use them for a lot of different projects.

Very pretty.  I ordered this as a gift with a similar purple/silver tone Kenneth Cole necklace.  The recipient loved it.  Glamorous.  Can be dressed up or down.  Great for work or pleasure.  Well priced.
Super cute!  I used it for Xmas tags.
Super cute!  I used these for X-mas tags!

This roll on really worksâ€¦.the solid, not so much.  I don't have an excessive perspiration issue.  In the last 5 years, though, I've started perspiring at night (night sweats).  I like to take showers in the evening, and I was waking up with armpits that really stunk!  I hate taking showers in the morning, especially in the winter.  I also like to let my hair air dry, and leaving the house with wet hair when it's 32*F outside is quite unpleasant.  I really didn't want to turn into one of the elderly women that smells funny.I tried different anti-persperents from the supermarket, and none did any better.  Then I found this.  I ordered this brand in both the roll-on and the stick.  I tried the stick first.  After 3 months (the directions and reviewers say to give it a few months), I wasn't seeing any difference.  So I started the roll-on.  It started working within a week!  Woo hoo!  I am SO glad to have found this.  I still sweat at night, but not under my arms.The only issue I have with this is that it makes my armpits itch.  But you put this on at night and the itching is not so unbearable that I can't sleep.  Then, in the morning I put some soothing lotion on and the itching stops for the day.  Also, after many months of use, I don't need to put this on every night.  I currently apply this product 2-3 times a week.
Bought these to hang my son's knife, sword, and shovel collection.  He collects these items from WWII, mostly.  These are perfect for those items and they come in a variety of colors.
Love them too!  Super cute.  Not too big.  Well priced.  Love the 3 metal tones.  Versatile.
My 13-year-old son has a 28" waste.  I ordered the L because  according to the size chart that would be for a 20" waste.  But it was too small.
My 13-year-old son has a 28" waste.  I ordered the XL because, I assumed, according to the size chart that would be a size 20 (30").  But it was too small.

Ordered this for my boys 1.5 years ago when they were entering 7th and 9th grades.  They are now Â½ way through 8th and 10th grade and this back pack is still going strong.  It fits a large 3" binder plus 2-3 text books easily and you can even squeeze some notebooks in.Chest strap too.Front pockets for smaller items (i.e., a library book, etc.0

Bought this for my sons to attach to their wallets so they can clip it to their pants in case it falls out of their pockets (a common problem both my boys, ages 13 and 16, seem to have).  It's perfect for the job!  Our only wish is that it would be shorter.  If you don't like the chain hanging out of your pocket (down past the end of their t-shirts), as my boys don't, then you need to stuff the entire chain into the pocket which is a bit bulky.  I will go to the hardware store and have them cut the chains.  Then we'll just re-attach the split ring to the shorter length and it will be perfect.  It would be nice if this came in several lengths though, because I can see how this longer length would be good if you were using this item to clip keys to your pants, purse, etc.

This is a great pencil bag!  It is HUGE compared to others.  My boys are in 8th and 10th grade, so I have seen/bought many a pencil bag!  This one has lots of pockets and expands.  It can accommodate a lot of stuff.  It's made of a nice fabric that I think will hold up.  It still looks great 3 months into the school year.

Bought this for my 16-year-old son.  He really likes the scorpion!  He added a grommet and chain so it won't fall out of his pocket (something that apparently happens often to him).  This wallet is a bit thicker than the nylon/velcro one he had before, but I couldn't find a nylon wallet with a coin pocket (which he wants) that he liked.  So, I go this.  It is very difficult to find a men's wallet with a coin pocket.  This wallet has a small pocket that snaps closed.  He puts his coins in there.  It also has a zippered area along the back inside of the wallet.  It runs the length of the entire wallet.  Good for putting things you want to be more secure, but not really good for coins as getting them out is difficult.  Another thing he likes about this wallet is that it has 2 clear slots, 1 for his driver's license and 1 for his school I.D., rather than just 1 like most wallets.  The only negative is that this is a bit thick, but I think, since it is leather, that it will "smash" down and conform to how he uses it.

Beautiful, but comes out of the dryer VERY wrinkled.  I HATE ironing, but it's a MUST with these.  On the plus side, I used them to dress up a darker yellow plastic tablecloth at an outdoor summer party, and they (I bought 2) looked great.  Subtle pattern at the ends.  Recommend, if you don't mind ironing.
My son (13) LOVES this flavor!  We have tried several brands and types and this is one of his favorites.

These are NOT Grommets!  They are Eyelets.  The word "grommets" should not be in the title.  It is misleading.  Grommets are installed with 2 pieces, a front and a back, and you "hammer" the top piece down around the back piece.  Eyelets are one piece, you just "hammer" the back side down.  As such, grommets are stronger.  I ordered these to use on my son's leather wallet.  I wanted grommets.  This is our first time doing something like this, so I am a beginner.  Still, I did enough research to know I wanted grommets.

This is a great bag!  I get compliments on it all the time!Doesn't look like leather, but I don't think it's supposed to.  I love the 3 different textures on the 3 different colors.  This bag took me from spring, through the summer and, now, into fall.  Fits my iPad.  LOVE!

I feel that the previous review is unfair.  1st, you do NOT need to use Avery's online design software.  There is nothing keeping you from using your own desktop publishing software to make these.  However, I have been completely surprised with how versatile Avery's online software is.  There are patterns, clip art, words.  You can insert text in any color and many fonts.  You can change the color of the backgrounds, make stripes, chevrons, and polka dots in a rainbow of color combinations.  You con import your own images, patterns or photos.  this is really great!Nice quality card stock.

These were just perfect for a variety of popsicles I made for a recent party.  I made them small, in dixie cups, then peeled the cup off when they were frozen, wrapped in was paper and stored in freezer.  I served them in a large bowl of ice.

This bag is adorable!  I live in a small town, and could not find a bag this size at the grocery store.  This fits the various items I had to put in it and is SO sweet!  I love how the sides are a different pattern.  Nice and sturdy and thick.

I wanted a fire pit because both of my sons, ages 13 and 15, will be having parties on consecutive weekends in a few weeks. I wasn't sure exactly how this worked, compared to more expensive, fancy, above ground fire pits, with lids, etc. Well, this is just fine. It isn't fancy, but you can make it nice. It comes in 4, ¼-circle pieces, that you put together using black hardware (screws, etc) that it also comes with. We dug a hole down into the ground and put this in. We then put some river rocks that we have as landscaping in the bottom and layered some extra flagstone that we had left over from when she had a patio put in, around the top. We infilled the flagstone with sand. It looks great! I covered some square cushions with cool outdoor fabric to set around it. Voila! Instant awesome fire pit! The kids will be roasting marshmallows and having fun listening to music. I bought some packets that you sprinkle on the fire to make it change colors, for added fun, too, though you are not allowed to cook food over the chemicals. I think the kids will enjoy this. I am very pleased with this affordable fire pit.

These crates are great for your crafting needs.  I painted them red and loved how the original  colors shoed through when I distressed them.  Versatile and a good price.  The 2 dark crates are a lot closer in color than the picture shows.

Bought 3 of these (which is less expensive than buying the 3-pack) and LOVE them.  They are very well made.  The sticks are nice and straight and it's a nice standard popsicle shape.  I only have one issue and that is that these forms did not come with any directions or explanations.  Are they dish washer safe?  Well, I took a risk and washed them on the top rack of my dishwasher and apparently, they are dishwasher safe.  Also, I found it extremely difficult to remove the blue plastic and metal lid after freezing.  I was hesitant to run hot water over it, because I didn't want too much of the popsicle to melt.  But after trying pretty much everything I could think of and not being able to get the lid off, I ran it quickly under hot water.  That made the difference.  the lid popped right off with the popsicles and sticks still in it.  Then I had to jiggle each pop a bit to get if off the lid.I am making a bunch for an end-of-summer party, and I took a previous reviewers advice and wrapped them in wax paper and put them in a zip lock bag to store.  This is perfect, as the "re-"frozen pops ('cause they melt a bit while you're taking them out of the form) don't stick to the wax paper.  Recommend.

I bought these to keep my sofa from sliding back on our marble tile floor every time someone sat on it.  Whew!  These were hard to find!  I kept finding sliders, which are meant to help furniture slide.  After living in our new house for a year, I was tired of constantly pushing the sofa back to were it belonged.  This was practically a daily task!  These are perfect.  They are just the right size and quite unobtrusive.  When I put them on, I noticed that the sofa has 5 legs!  LOL!  So, I'll be ordering another package.  But, even with just the 4, my sofa is not moving around anymore!

I love this!  I bought this over a year ago and have been using it ever since.  I don't know why others say it is flimsy.  Also, I have had no problems with peeling paint.  If you want something red to hold your hose, this is great.  Fits a very long hose.  Bright and shiny.  Lid keeps rain water from accumulating inside.

I purchased this almost 4 months ago.  At first it was great.  Sturdy.  Reliable. But over the last month the connection with my iPad has gotten looser and looser.  To the point were the connection just falls out, which is annoying because sometimes I think it's charging, but it isn't.  Today, for the first time, the connectin is so loose that any slight motion, such as me typing this, causes it to stop and start, stop and star,t charging over & over.  As this lasted less than 4 months, I'm not sure it's a better deal than other "cheap" cables.Update:  since I wrote the above review, I have gone through a lot of these cords.  They are always good for about 6 months, but then have connection issues.  The current cord has only lasted 2 weeks & the connection is loose already.  I am NOT going to buy any of these anymore. Or do I recommend them.

After reading previous reviews, I did follow the directions and put down a nice black bottom coat of polish.  I then applied 2 layers of this polish.  I did not get the results I was hoping for.  In the picture, this looks like a black polish with burghandy/plum sparkles.  Well, the photographer must have shone a red light on it when taking the picture, or enhanced it.  Because, what I got was a mostly black polish with a few sparkles that sometimes (rarely) look plum, burghandy, or reddish.  I am very disappointed.  I am in my 40's and wanted something that looks like the picture, with plum sparkles and highlights.  When I was on my 20's, I would have been OK with this for going clubbing at night.On the other hand, this is a nice quality polish that goes on fairly smoothly, when compared to other glitter/sparkle-comtaining polishes which are often rough or bumpy to the touch.

I ordered these on May 15 and the delivery estimate was June 11 - 27, but they arrived yesterday, June 30.  The seller ( Liroyal-led) is in China. I contacted them about a week after making the purchase to see if I could cancel the order and they told me it had already shipped.  I know things take a long time to arrive from China, but I have received orders from China that arrive more quickly 1.5 months.  So I do not recommend this seller.The birdies themselves are fine.  Nice weight, but then we are beginners.  1 of them didn't light up right out of the box.  I deducted 2 stars for this.

I watched this because it was a free Amazon Prime movie and I recognized the name.  I am glad I did.  This was a fun and funny movie.  Nothing deep, but fun nonetheless.  The plot follows a standard storyline:  Young loner thinks she knows what she wants but finds friendship and love when she wasn't looking.

This movie follows a typical rotating comedy scenario.  On-the-shelf and under appreciated young woman thinks she's in love with her boss, but finds the right man where she isn't looking.  Fun and funny.

This is a very timely book given the current discussions of race going on in the country right now. It opens in the years before the Civil War on a small plantation in Alabama. It is owned by Katherine Winthrop but she defers to her husband in its running. He is not a very nice man for many a reason but it is time when women were not considered smart enough to do anything but look pretty.Katherine has a daughter, Evie, and is friendly with her house slave Delly. Delly cares for Essie a child of the plantation. These four female voices tell the story in alternating chapters. Usually this aggravates me but Ms. Muriel writes in four such distinct voices I felt like I was in the space with each one.Essie and Evie are born on the same night but into very different lives. That doesnâ€™t stop them from finding each other and becoming friends. Life becomes complicated and dangerous as the South secedes and war enters their world. Soon the girls find themselves fleeing the plantation they have always known for Richmond and life changes for them in ways they never could have imagined.I was pulled into this book from the very first chapter where Essie introduced herself. She is an unforgettable character who is far ahead of her time. In fact all of the characters are very well drawn and uniquely interesting. Itâ€™s not always an easy story to read but it is exceptionally well written and it was very hard to put down.  I read it in one short before bed start and then finished in one long read the next day.*I received a free copy for my honest review
This is my third of these baking sheets and I just love them. They hold up well and bake very evenly. I've never been disappointed by anything I've bought from Chicago Metallic.

This is a perfect little floor mat for right by my sliding glass door. It's a little thinner than I maybe would have liked but it's doing the job. It catches a lot of dirt and other ick from our shoes as we come in from outside and consequently gets quite dirty. I bought it because it said it was washable so I gave it that test this weekend. It was filthy so I did put some pre-treater on it but it came out looking brand new!  The cats love to sleep on it so I guess that is a bonus.I am not sure how it would be outside - I haven't tried using it there. I can only attest to inside use.

I love stories that take place in Ancient Rome. This is a little bit later in Romeâ€™s history than I usually read but it was still fascinating to look at the period through different eyes; those of female gladiators. Apparently there were indeed such fighters as Rome fell into its decline. As the Emperors looked for more exotic entertainments for the arena.Two women from opposite ends of the Roman Empire end up as slaves of the same man; Afra from Kush and Cinnia from Britain. Their stories are similar in that they were warriors in their home countries until disaster befalls them and now they find themselves owned by a man who wants to use them as entertainment. In their common circumstance they find comfort, friendship and love.It was truly interesting to visit this time period through the eyes of these characters. They are both strong, unique and well drawn. Itâ€™s great to have a book centering around female characters in Ancient times. Yes, it is also their love story but it is not overly graphic. I was fascinated to learn in the authorâ€™s note that female gladiators were a part of this time. The book is well researched and easy to read.*I received a free copy for my honest review

I am generally not a big reader of murder mysteries but once in a blue moon one will tickle my fancy. When offered Farmed and Dangerous I was intrigued by the setting of this novel â€“ a farm! Of course I would enjoy a tale such as this, right? This is part of a series of cozy mysteries â€“ no blood, no gore â€“ involving Cam Flaherty and the denizens of her small town.In this volume Cam is again caught up in a murder mystery when someone at the local Assisted Living Facility is found dead after eating a meal made with vegetables and other products from her farm. This woman, Bev Montgomery, was an unpleasant woman and she and Cam had a difficult relationship. To cap things off Camâ€™s boyfriend is the state police officer investigating and since she is â€œperson of interestâ€ they canâ€™t see each other until the case is solved.I really enjoyed the farm discussions and the sections about the different vegetables and how to grow things organically. It almost felt like I was in the middle of a conversation with my husband. Books like this are not meant to be deep and thoughtful but rather to be fluffy and entertaining and this one succeeds on that point. Itâ€™s never overly suspenseful but I enjoyed the characters and the setting. It was a lovely break from the heavier tomes I had read a couple of weeks ago. Iâ€™d happily revisit with the characters again.I received a free copy for my honest review

This was a departure for me â€“ Iâ€™ve been writing that a fair bit lately in my book reviews. Itâ€™s been the summer of stretching my reading muscles.  I wanted to read it because I find wolves fascinating; Iâ€™m in the minority in my corner of the world. Most of the people here want to eliminate them but a pack has moved in across the river and listening to them howl at night is awesome.Sadly, The Wolf Border is more about people than wolves. In that I was disappointed as the synopsis led me to believe I was getting a wolf story. While the wolves are central to the story they are not really the focus â€“ Rachel and a very unexpected change in her life are. Itâ€™s going to be hard to write this without giving too much away but Rachel is a well educated zoologist working on a reservation in Idaho studying wolf behavior when she is presented with the opportunity to return home to England to help a rich Earl reintroduce wolves to that country. At first she is resistant but as life throws her a curve ball she takes him up on the offer and returns home .The book is written without quotation marks and this drove me a little bit bonkers as you sometimes could not tell where conversations started and ended. Beyond this the writing was very compelling. I read the book in one day because I really didnâ€™t want to put it down. Despite the story being more about people than wolves I really enjoyed it. I would have liked more about the animals but it was still a very good story.I received a free copy for my honest review

This book takes place in an era and area you donâ€™t often see represented in books; the time of the Rus in the era of the Mongol (13th century/Ukraine, Belarus, Russia). It is narrated by a young princess of the Rus, Sofia and she is a vibrant and very likable character. Her life is all a young woman of privilege could ask. But there is danger on the horizon as her father is facing the advancement of the Mongols into his kingdom.He sends Sofia away to be safe but she is capture by the men he fears the most and her life is turned upside down. Suddenly she is a slave to the Mongol leader â€“ her innocence taken and finding herself living in a camp where she doesnâ€™t understand the language or the way of life. But instead of letting her circumstances get the best of her Sofia instead sets out to make the best of her situation. She learns all she can about her captor and the others in the camp and she tries to instill a bit of humanity into a very inhumane group of raiders.This novel is based in history and I found it to be rather fascinating. It took me a bit to become engaged but once I did I found it hard to put down. Ms. Hazell has a way of bringing the 13th century to life and I did feel immersed in that world. The historical detail is well woven into the story and it really brings the Mongol camp alive. Where it falls a little bit short is in the interactions between people â€“ dialog is not the strong suit here but donâ€™t let it deter you from a really wonderful novel. Itâ€™s the first in a trilogy and Iâ€™m going to enjoy following Sofia on her adventures.I received a free ecopy for my honest review

This is a richly illustrated novella (I will note that I did have a hardback that I won several years ago) about Filomena, a young woman growing up in 16th century Venice. She is living with her sister, one of the cities most famous courtesans. Her sister Tullia keeps her very isolated â€“ she doesnâ€™t want her to suffer as she has.  But Filomena is growing up, she is getting curious. She wants to get out of the gilded cage she feels confined in. Of course every 16 year old girl knows everything and so Filomena seeks to find a way out.She thinks that perhaps her voice is her saviour but then she meets a handsome young man and he makes her a different kind of offer but his family has other ideas for his future that donâ€™t include the sister of a courtesan. But he is not deterred he asks Filomena to follow him down The Loverâ€™s Path.This was a sweet story full of love and loss and the passion of youth. Tullia is not at first a very sympathetic character but as her story comes to light. The novella is written in Filomenaâ€™s voice as as a memoir of sorts. It is  part of a museum dedicated to her â€“ all part of a delightful fiction created by the author to place the book in its time. It is a wonderful escape from heavier reads and the illustrations are just gorgeous.I received a free ecopy for my honest review

This was a book that really pulled at my emotions â€“ on many levels. The history of the potato famine and what it did to the people of Ireland is well known. The British raped that country for what it could produce and let the citizens starve. The rich took what they wanted and damn the poor â€“ it must be their fault somehow. Sound familiar? But Iâ€™m not ranting on todayâ€™s politics but rather reviewing a very well written book that delivers the history and the humanity with equal aplomb.Kathleen awaits the return home of her fiance but he fails to come back on the ship with her brother. As the potato crop continues to fail itâ€™s Kathleen that is sent to find work to send money home. She figures at the same time she can try and find what happened to her love but all does not turn out as she plans. She ends up shipwrecked and rescued by of all things, an Englishman. A man of the country she hates to the bottom of her soul. But he does her many a kindness and alters her thinking that all Englishmen are bad. She ends up in Boston where the Irish are not appreciated and finds her new life very difficult.This was a book that drew me in from the very first page. I had the worst time putting it down. Ms. Ford just drew me into the world she created and her characters truly came to life. It was a horrible time in history for the Irish (confession â€“ Iâ€™m half Irish) and they suffered at home and abroad when they tried to find new lives. This is all represented in the book with a very well defined plot and strong character development.4,5I received a free copy for my honest review

I had no knowledge of the whole YouTube thing that goes along with this YA novel. I am certainly not the demographic that this book is targeting but Iâ€™ll be honest â€“ I really enjoyed it. Itâ€™s far out of my usual reading world but sometimes when I take a chance like this Iâ€™m richly rewarded. Itâ€™s funny, as a rule I tend to really not like paranormal stories but some of my favorite books fall into that realm. Goes to show that you should pigeonhole your reading.Sunshine is a 16 year old girl who moves with her mother from sunny Austin, Texas, to wet and dreary Ridgemont, Washington. The house her mother finds is, as Sunshine calls it, creepy. Soon after moving in she hears things; laughter, giggling and soon starts seeing other manifestations of a ghost. Her mother doesnâ€™t believe her and thinks that Sunshine is just trying to whine her way back to Texas. She sets out to prove to her mother that the ghost exists by taking photos but her mother is experiencing some other issues about which Sunshine has no idea.I was drawn into this story immediately. The character of Sunshine is so realistically drawn and just such a teenager â€“ a little precocious, a little ahead of her time, a little stubborn and a little unsure of her place in the world. She is trying to figure out what is wrong in her house and ultimately what is wrong with her mother while not really understanding why it is all happening to her. She has a friend to help her along the way but even when presented with (her) reality she canâ€™t believe it.The book is written for a teenage audience but it did keep me interested. The other characters are as well developed and interesting as Sunshine and I am looking forward to the next installment.4.5I received a free copy for my honest review

This mixer is a little bit of heaven on earth. It handles large quantities of dough and batter with ease. It's my third KitchenAid and they all sit in a row - this is the largest and most powerful of them. I've made bread (6 loaves at once) cookies (12 dozen) and a triple batch of bundt cake batter. All mixed up beautifully and easily.

This was a hard weekâ€™s reading for me â€“ I had somehow ended up with two books dealing with domestic violence in quick succession. Itâ€™s odd how that happens sometimes. When I accept books for review itâ€™s often months in advance and I have no idea how they really land in my schedule. Itâ€™s not an easy subject to read about.Heavy Weather tells the story of Annie Mac, a woman who has made some mistakes in her life but the greatest is marrying Roy, a very violent man. He lives in a world all of his own and he is king of that world.Annie Mac is living in Beaufort, trying to make a life for herself and her two children when Roy comes barging in with fists flying. He wants his daughter and he is not going to let anyone get in his way. He leaves Annie in a bloody, broken pile but canâ€™t find Katie â€“ her older brother has hidden her well. With her last conscious words Annie asks Hannah, a neighbor, to care for the kids until sheâ€™s better. This leads to a a circle of comfort that Annie could never have imagined.The book is told in alternating chapters â€“ this conceit is getting very old. It seems most of the books I have read lately are doing this. â€“ in the voices of different characters including Royâ€™s. In this manner the reader learns about the circle of people who are helping Annie Mac survive her attack and find Roy to make him face justice.She has trouble accepting and trusting at first but soon realizes that there is kindness in the world. But Roy still lurks. Will law enforcement get to him before he hurts Annie again?This was a book full of friendship, love, suspense and relationships. I am not usually drawn to this type of book but I found myself really enjoying this tale (other than the alternating chapter thing.) It moved right along and the characters were well developed. Iâ€™d go back to Beaufort to revisit these characters again.*I received a free copy for my honest review
These jeans fit me perfectly. I love the weight of them and the little bit of stretch. The color is a rich, dark black. They are comfortable and easy to wear.

I am so very torn with this book; itâ€™s really two stories in one as the author ties the present to the past by way of the town in which the novel takes place. The book alternates chapters between the story of Sarah Brown, daughter of the abolitionist John Brown and Eden, a woman living in the current era who likes to whine.I loved the chapters that shared the story of Sarah Brown. This brilliant young woman was unknown to me and Iâ€™m glad that Iâ€™ve now learned about her. Iâ€™m going to try and find something else to read about her. She was strong in her convictions at a time when it was very dangerous to hold them. Ms. McCoy really brings her to life as she grows from a child to a woman.On the other hand Eden, a fictional character doesnâ€™t come across as well. She is selfish and only concerned with how the world has wronged her. Her way of dealing with life just doesnâ€™t ring true to me. I really didnâ€™t care about the chapters that took place in the present. I couldnâ€™t connect to any of the characters in this half of the book.  They all seemed a little one note where the historical characters were far more developed.I appreciate the intent to tie the past to the present but for me it just didnâ€™t work. I would have been happier reading a fictionalized tale of Sarah Brown and her life without all of the bits of this and that brought in from the future.I received a free copy for my honest reviewRating:  Sections in the past 5, sections in the present 2. Overall rating: 3.5

I have a raging fascination with the history of religions so when presented with books, fiction or non fiction, I dive right in. The historical fiction tomes send me off to the google to figure out the reality from the story but when it comes to a sect like the Cathars who tried to co-exist with the might and power of the Catholic Church at the height of its reign well â€“ we all know that history is written by the victors and what they write is often skewed.  So what do we really know about this band of religious rebels? Not nearly enough to truly understand them but certainly enough to create a novel worth reading.The author admits in his note that he extrapolates from history and from what I could learn he does play a little fast and loose with timelines and real people but that is the purview of â€œpoetic licenseâ€ I suppose. The book is part love story part war story as Pope Innocent III embarks on the destruction of a sect he feels is a danger to his power base.The book is well written with engaging characters. Thereâ€™s a lot of war and the subsequent description thereof but you canâ€™t have war without it now can you? History tells us the outcome of the Cathars but Mr. Craney gives them life for another century to appreciate.*I received a free ecopy for my honest review

If you follow my book reviews you know that â€œfamily dramasâ€ set in the modern era are generally not what I tend to read. There was just something about this bookâ€™s synopsis that piqued my interest; I think that it was the setting in Nicaragua. I donâ€™t know much about the culture of any of the countries south of us and Iâ€™m always looking to be educated a bit when I read a book. This one was very enjoyable â€“ I read it on my flights from Missoula to Nashville and it made the time pass very quickly. Even when my butt was flying out of the seat due to turbulence.It is the story (stories?) of three women in one family â€“ grandmother, daughter and granddaughter and itâ€™s told in alternating voices. The grandmother, Isabela cared for her granddaughter, Maria in Miami after fleeing Nicaragua during the revolution. Mariaâ€™s mother, Ninexin was a revolutionary who lost her husband when Maria was only 4 months old. They tell their tales in alternating chapters and while there is not much change in writing style between the three you can get a definite sense of their personalities from how they present their aspect of the ongoing story.Of the three women I have to admit that it was Isabela I liked the most. Maria did not resonate with me at all. I seem to read a fair number of books with characters like her; wishy-washy, unsure of her lifeâ€™s path, unsure of what to do about the man in her life. A still trying to figure it all out at 33 kind of girl. (Her boyfriend was a bit of a tough character for me as well.) I just donâ€™t understand these characters but they must be popular if I keep running into them. Itâ€™s probably because I am not old enough to be a grandmother (did I just type that?!) and of a completely different generation than these kids today.Despite not being able to relate to Maria her third of the book was integral to the tale and I did enjoy the book. It held  a couple of good surprises that were revealed as the book reached its conclusion. The descriptions of the cities and towns in Nicaragua were very well written and I did enjoy learning a little bit about the culture of the country and its history.*I received a free copy for my honest review

I hadnâ€™t realized when I accepted this book for review that it was a young adult novel â€“ I do read them I just didnâ€™t take particular note when reading the synopsis. This tale of mystery, murder, song and romance takes place in Venice. Our heroine, Isabella, has a remarkable singing voice and longs to sing in public. Her singing teacher, Margherita, has a magical voice and a history. Not to mention a very handsome son, Rafaele. Margherita has never told her son who his father is. She gives him a special gift and promises to tell him his parentage but the next night she is found murdered.Secrets abound in this story and for an adult reader most of them are easy to discern but a younger reader would be intrigued by the breadcrumbs left by the author as Isabella tries to help Rafaele find who killed his mother and then help him get out of serious trouble.It is a sweet tale with a few twists and turns along the way to keep the young reader very engaged. The time period was complicated for political and religious reasons and Ms. McMahan weaves the necessary information into her story well. The ugly aspects of history are handled discretely enough so that they wonâ€™t offend sensitive readers. I read the book on a flight from Nashville to Denver and it made the time enjoyable.*I received a free copy for my honest review

This was not a happy book. That does not mean it wasnâ€™t a good book because it was â€“ at least I thought so. It covers a very dark topic and it is never easy to read about domestic abuse. The story follows three sisters and their mother as they come together to deal with the father who is in a coma. The youngest, Sonya left home many years ago and has refused to come back home but the call from her mother that her father is dying brings her back. Her elder sister Marin is in an arranged marriage with a daughter and seems to be living a perfect life, the middle daughter Trisha seems to have the perfect marriage but all is not as it seems. The three girls disagree on how to deal with their past and all of them donâ€™t know everything.The book unfolds in alternating chapters â€“ the three girls and their mother all share different pieces and it goes back and forth between the present and the past. It was sometimes difficult to remember who was narrating as there was not much difference in voice. Marinâ€™s daughter does play a pivotal role in the story but she does not become a narrator.I cannot say that I enjoyed the book due to its subject matter but it was a book that held my interest and it truly pulled at my emotions. I found myself, more than once, screaming in my head at various characters. The cultural aspects of the book added an additional layer of interest. It was a book I found hard to put down.*I received a free copy for my honest review

This book intrigued for its mix of science, religion, mystery and what might be. It started with a trip to Israel to fulfill the final wishes of Rose Strongin, a scientist, a marine biologist, who was working at the Sea of Galilee in 1974 when she was late back and it caused her to miss her flight which turned out to be fortuitous as that plane explodes and all are killed. Rose never explains why she was late and it causes issues in her life and her marriage.The family that comes together in the present to lay Rose to rest are a mixed bunch; Nathan, the baby is resentful of his father feeling that he knows all that there is to know about his parents marriage and his father is wrong. The two girls have their roles and are more aware of the frailties of both of their parents. All of these feelings come to the fore as they all are together for the first time in quite a while to put their mother to rest.The reader gets to know Rose through a serious of flashbacks in and out of different periods of her past. She is a fascinating well developed character and I loved her struggle with science and otherworldliness (is that a word?) The other characters in the book are equally as well developed. Mr. Kitsakos is also very good at bringing a place to life and setting a mood. This is not a simple book; it will leave you thinking for days after you finish it. Thinking about life, love and death.4.5I received a free copy for my honest review

I readily admit to an appalling ignorance of American history.  My fascination has always been European history and I do most of my pleasure reading in stories that take place long in the past in England, France or Italy. Iâ€™ve gone on jags of reading on topics of American History â€“ just ask me about the Civil War or the Mormons â€“ but for the most part it just doesnâ€™t interest me but once in a blue moon a book will pique my interest. For whatever reason this tale of the taking of iron ore out of Minnesota called to me. There is no understanding what I readâ€¦.That being written â€“ this book was really fascinating. I believe because it was all so new to me and so very well written I found myself completely lost in the story. Itâ€™s really not at all as dry as it sounds. The characters are well developed and darn interesting. The conflict between the white immigrants and the Native Americans was very real and it caused issues all over the country as we well know from history.It was a time for dreamers and for making money. It was a time when if you worked hard you really could achieve the American Dream. At least as it was manifesting in this time period. These men who brought their ideas to fruition were thought to be crazy but they believed. All of that is so well expressed in this book â€“ all of the hope and all of the hard work and yes the failures that went along with it are there in a very compelling read.4.5I received a free copy for my honest review

I had taken myself off of WWI and WWII books because I had read so darn many of them but something about this one drew me in. Iâ€™m glad I did read it as it wasnâ€™t so much a story of WWI as a tale of the effects the war had on people back home. Hazel is a woman of German descent living in Pittsburgh. Her father suffers from headaches and Hazel seems to have a rare ability to heal him. She is being pressured to follow a medical profession but instead chooses to be a teacher. She does this away from Pittsburgh because anti-German sentiment is becoming unbearable.Hazel soon embarks on a journey to find her natural mother which leads her to a very odd place in New Jersey where she finds as many questions as answers as to her heritage. I really liked the character of Hazel and she was well developed. I just think there were too many threads of stories and some of them got lost within the whole and just didnâ€™t wrap up appropriately.Overall it was a very good read about troubling subjects. Ms. Schoenewaldt has a real way with words that does draw you into the story.I received a free copy for my honest review

I found the premise of this non-fiction book to be rather compelling. I have to be honest â€“ I never really gave much thought to the personnel that keep the White House running. These maids, florists, chefs, electricians and others are not paid extravagantly yet they are privy to the personal side of the First Family occupying the house.I did find parts of the book very interesting and I donâ€™t want to give too much away. The people who agree to these jobs are a rare breed; loyal, discreet and very hard working. Many of them stay in their jobs for decades despite long hours and erratic schedules. They all serve at the pleasure of the President as the saying goes. Many of them maintain their loyalties to all of the families they served and didnâ€™t want to talk to the author.  We learn that early on in the book and it is reiterated â€“ a lot. This was my biggest problem with the book, there was  a lot of repetition. One story would appear in several different chapters woven into different narratives but how many times can you read the same facts? It was almost as if the book were a compilation of essays with minimal editing. I did read an advanced reader copy so I donâ€™t know if perhaps changes were made before final printing.The writing style is easy to read and there were many interesting stories in the book and I did learn a bit about what it takes to keep the White House running. I also gained a very healthy respect for the dedication of the employees who work there.I received a free copy for my honest review

My hubby had to give up drinking coffee so he turned to green tea. He then learned of matcha and started drinking it. He discovered the two different types and was anxious to try the ceremonial matcha as he had heard it to be superior to the culinary. He tried the Midori Spring Organic and was very impressed. He said he loved the light, bright true green tea flavor of this product. It was a vibrant, spring green color and powdery as a good quality ceremonial grade matcha is supposed to be. All in all he was very impressed with Midori SpringI received a free sample for my honest review

I have read several of Mr. Krakauerâ€™s books and have found all of them to be page turners. In fact after reading Under the Banner of Heaven I went on a year long reading spree about the Mormons and their history. He just has such an easy writing style. I went into this latest book with a bit of trepidation due to the subject matter but I wanted to see how he covered the material, after all this is my home now. All of the stories of which he writes blew up shortly after we settled here. I read the stories in the news with shock and disgust and who wouldnâ€™t? But what really shocked me was some of the comments in response to the stories that immediately assumed the young ladies were lying because why would these football players need to behave that way â€“ they were Griz and the Griz could do no wrong. Missoula loves its athletes and its football players in particular.The book details several different incidents and details them in all of their horror; nothing sensational in the telling, just the facts but those facts are at times very hard to read. Then the young women go to the justice system for help and find  themselves suffering another type of assault. From police officers not offering support to prosecutors that just donâ€™t seem to care they are left with nowhere to turn while their alleged attackers go on as if nothing is wrong. And that I think was the scariest thing I took from the book â€“ in many cases these young men who perpetrate these acts honestly do not think they have done anything wrong. They think it is perfectly acceptable to have sex with an unconscious woman.There are many more facts and studies woven through the narrative as the chosen stories come to their conclusions. I think itâ€™s an important book for everyone to read. Many people from this area are upset at the title but these stories, sadly happen all over the country and Iâ€™m sure Mr. Krakauer could have written a similar book for every college town. He just happened to land here in Montana and follow some of the rape cases here. The Department of Justice did come into to Missoula for an investigation so there was definitely a problem.  The police department and the university worked with them to create a better environment for assault victims. The county attorneyâ€™s office was not as cooperative with the DOJ at the beginning but ultimately came to an agreement. Itâ€™s all outlined in the book and it makes for a good read.Of course it would have been better if there had not been a need to write this book but there was. Itâ€™s not a perfect book but itâ€™s a good book. It will make you angry and it will make you think.

I am having a hard time writing this review. I loved the writing in this book. I enjoyed the story of young Aurore and her life in Nohant. I also enjoyed the time in Paris when Aurore had left her husband to try and find herself as a writer. What I didnâ€™t like and it really impacted my overall enjoyment of the book was the way the author went back and forth in time with little logic. I would just be settling in to enjoy the story and BOOM the chapter would end and Iâ€™d find myself either backward or forward in time and in a totally different location. It was very distracting and a lot confusing. It completely took away from the book to the point that at times I just put it down and read something else because I was so frustrated.That being written there was a good story here. I didnâ€™t know that much about George Sand before I went into this novel and I have come out of reading it wanting to know more. I figure that I is always a good thing. She was a woman in a time that expected its women to stay home and have children. Aurore had a passion for more. She felt that there had to be more to life than the one she was living in the country and she took a huge leap to leave her family to pursue that passion. She lived a wild life â€“ that is for sure.Ms. Berg has written an interesting book about a fascinating woman. I just didnâ€™t enjoy the way she chose to put it together. Others may feel differently. I just didnâ€™t like the way the book moved through time.3.5I received a free copy for my honest review

These are very nice berries. The hubby has been grabbing them for a snack now and then and I used them in one of his salmon dinners - Salmon on Kale with Penne and Goji Berries. I like that they are organic and non-GMO.*I received a free sample for my honest review

This was a delightful escape from the heavier books I have been reading â€“ I really needed it. Our young vicar wants more from his life than being assigned to a small community in England but that is where he is sent. He figures heâ€™ll do his job in hopes of transfer and then heâ€™ll get his life of adventure. He didnâ€™t count on Cecelia. Nor did she figure on young William.Ceceliaâ€™s mother has grand plans for her daughter that do not include her marrying some vicar that has just turned up in the village no matter how attractive her daughter might find him. She wants her to marry into the ruling family of Amberly â€“ even if Cecelia finds the match boring at best. To her William is the only man who has understood her spirit. But does she want the life he has to offer? And does he want to give up his dreams of adventure to settle down in this little town?This was a fast and engaging read full of all of the quirky characters you would expect to find in a small village in Regency England. And we all love a will she/wonâ€™t she type of romance now and again. There must, of course, be a requisite bad guy and he is the only character that doesnâ€™t fully develop but itâ€™s a small complaint in an otherwise wonderful read. I really enjoyed Cecelia and William â€“ they are a delightful pair and they gave me a respite I needed. I would happily go visit them again.I received a free copy for my honest review

I have to state that I enjoy books that tell the stories of lesser known women in history. A Pledge of Better Times does exactly that by weaving the story of Diana de Vere from snippets of her left in correspondence and other written sources. We meet her when she is still a child and she encounters King Charles II and he introduces her to his three sons by different mistresses. She is the daughter of the Earl of Oxford, a close friend of the king but a noble without a fortune. Soon Charles dies and the kingdom is thrown into disarray as his brother James takes the thrown and the religious issues that all thought were settled soon rear their ugly head. Within in the framework of history young Diana de Vere comes of age and marries one of Charlesâ€™ bastards, Charles Beauclerk, Duke of St. Albans.Complicated history leads to compelling story possibilities and this book was a really good read. It is based solidly in reality as these two characters existed and followed the paths laid down in the book. Ms. Porter brings them to life with with rich detail and a relationship that stood the tests thrown in its way. I was quite taken with both Diana and Charles and found myself rooting for both of them as I read the book. Charles II is always an entertaining monarch so any story with him even as an ancillary character is going to be a fun book.I found that I really didnâ€™t want the story to end. I wanted to continue on with their story and to go on in their lives and the lives of their children. It is written beautifully and full of historical detail. This is not a period I wander into that often so it was nice to visit this period of English history again.4.5I received a free copy for my honest review

I am very sorry to see this excellent series reach its end. I suppose it had to happen sometime but I have to admit to being sad to see these characters find the end of their literary lives. Although there is a bit of a teaser at the end of the book indicating the possibility of short stories to come so cross your fingers fans! Iâ€™ve read all of the books in the series but the first â€“ although I do have it on my tablet. I just havenâ€™t had the time to read it!In this book Alex and Matthew head back to where it all began â€“ Scotland. Matthewâ€™s brother Luke is grateful for the saving of his son so he has sent Matthew a letter giving him back the family home. Since Matthew was forced to leave a country he loved he wants to go back to what he considers home. Alex does not want to go. She doesnâ€™t completely trust Luke, she knows the political situation in Scotland is not good and she doesnâ€™t want to spend all of that time on a ship. Of course all does not go as planned while they are there and they soon receive word that danger lurks back in Maryland so they start the journey back to Maryland.At the heart of all of these tales is family â€“ for good or for bad. Alex has tumbled through time because of her motherâ€™s artwork and that questionable talent has been passed to Alexâ€™s son. He finds himself painting his way to Alexâ€™s time and trying to get back to his own but she has a real disconnect to this first son of time to which she does not belong. Itâ€™s an oddity to a character that loves her children so fiercely. For she does love and love strongly â€“ it is what drives her; love for her husband and her children. Without that there really would be no stories.As with the other books in the series I found myself turning page after page until suddenly there were no more to turn which led to a real letdown. Especially as there will be no more adventures for this couple. Ms. Belfrage can really bring a time period and a world to life and as a reader you find yourself lost in time, much like her protagonist. Itâ€™s not a bad thing at all â€“ especially since you can still take a hot shower at the end of the day.4.5I received a free copy for my honest review

I do love early English history. Many of the books Iâ€™ve read from that time period focus more on the kings and many have told the tale of Harold, Godwineâ€™s son and the last Anglo Saxon king of England but this is the first book Iâ€™ve read that has told the story of Godwine. And told that story for the sake of Godwine not as a back drop to Haroldâ€™s tale.It starts when Godwine is just a young boy and finds a warrior lost in his woods. Even at such a young age he figures out how to take the best advantage of a situation which shows off the sharp wit and intelligence that would carry him through his life as he befriends and becomes important to the Danish King Canute and ultimately becomes the first Earl of Wessex. He walks a fine line throughout his life making decisions that sometimes seem questionable.I dove right in to Godwineâ€™s tale â€“ in fact I read this book in a day. Ms. Rochelle does an excellent job of bringing the reader into Godwineâ€™s world whether he is in that forest with a lamb or on a ship at sea. A great man has been create and brought to life from the scraps left to history. I will eagerly await the next installment in this series4.5*I received a free copy for my honest review

The list of ingredients is a thing of beauty, but our two middle-age cats like but don't love this weight control food option--they will eat it but if there is any other choice they'll go for that first. Still, we humans are pleased by the health benefits of this product for our felines.

Dark, gritty and inventive, I was drawn to this book by itâ€™s premise--robots and humans living together uneasily under Antarctic domes. Throw in a ruined amusement park, exploitation by â€œmainlandersâ€ back in South America, and the fact that the robots are evolving and there was no way I could resist. The world-building is fantastic, but what kept me from loving this story more is the writing style. The author is known for her YA books, but for my taste she tried too hard to make this an â€œadultâ€ book--though it may be that I just donâ€™t enjoy noir fiction.Thereâ€™s not a scrap of humor--no ironic self-reflection by any of the characters and no moments of comic relief--which for me gave it a sort of wooden melodramatic tone that kept me more disengaged from the characters than I would have liked.

If you wanted to create a character for your novel or play, youâ€™d be hard-pressed to come up with someone as interesting and story-worthy as Englandâ€™s Elizabeth I. After her mother, Anne Boleyn, was beheaded Elizabeth was declared a bastard, but she continued with her rigorous education and the hardships she experienced as a result of her demotion helped make her politically savvy, a trait that saved her neck more than once and ultimately put her on the throne. Iâ€™ve enjoyed several biographies about Elizabeth I, but this one has extras that make it stand out.Lisa Hiltonâ€™s premise is that Elizabeth saw herself as a Renaissance prince, and while Elizabeth was happy to invoke the conventions of courtly females when it suited her, she lived in an age when royal gender was more fluid than we might think now. Hilton spends some time describing the Renaissance era and what being a Renaissance prince would mean, which leads her to a discussion of contemporary literature, period attitudes, and Machiavelli. Elizabethâ€™s relatively long life is covered thoroughly, but more space is given to art analysis, cultural philosophies, and intellectual history than Iâ€™ve read elsewhere, which I found fascinating. Iâ€™ve read other books by Hilton, my favorite being Horror of Love about Nancy Mitford, and I appreciate the broad scope and thoughtful scrutiny she brings to her subjects, this book about Elizabeth being no exception.
