Resourceful, optimistic, determined, and unflappable, Miss Marjorie Marjoribanks would make a delightful, though perhaps slightly controlling, companion. While staying dutifully--albeit perhaps a bit technically--inside the closely circumscribed boundaries of what is correct and proper behavior for a young Victorian woman, Miss Marjoribanks is able to manage just about every aspect of life in her little town, including politics, even though she canâ€™t, of course, actually vote.After finishing school and taking a brief tour of the continent, Miss Marjoribanks comes back home to â€œbe a comfortâ€ to her dear papa, a modest and selfless goal she mentions frequently at the most strategic times. Her mother had died a few years back and while her father, the town doctor, finds his life quite complete, Miss Marjoribanks is determined to make it better. She also has a quite a few other things in mind to improve the social life of the town as well, including holding lively and soon beloved Thursday evening gatherings in her fatherâ€™s drawing room, which she had specially painted in a shade to flatter her complexion (she thinks of everything!).Miss Marjoribanks decides sheâ€™ll continue on this course for 10 years, long enough to make up for papa having had the expense of redecorating the drawing room, before she thinks about getting married. But even Miss Marjoribanks canâ€™t anticipate everything that will happen.Some readers and reviewers have remarked that Marjorie Marjoribanks is like Jane Austenâ€™s Emma but less irritating, and I concur completely with that sentiment. Itâ€™s a long book, and it did drag a little in the middle for me, but the story has a wonderful ending and itâ€™s filled with a variety of spirited, humorous, mostly lovable characters.

I greatly enjoyed this sequel and will read any further books about short, nerdy, non-glamorous, observant Dani the author writes--Dani is  one of my favorite heroines--but until the last 25 pages this second book wasn't quite the thrill for me that the first book was. The pacing isn't quite as breathless, the connections between the characters--especially Choo Choo and Dani--don't feel quite as compelling, and the ending, while not a cliffhanger, still left things unresolved, though that's good news if it means there'll be another book.

This entertaining, often enthralling, mix of history, humor, travelogue, family memoir, and no holds barred social commentary reminds me of my favorite Bill Bryson books--especially A Walk in the Woods about Brysonâ€™s (mis)adventures hiking the Appalachian Trail. When Rinker Buck discovered that large stretches of the Oregon Trail still exist, he had romantic visions of a back to basics journey across the western half of the continent and began obsessively and meticulously preparing for a mule-drawn covered wagon trip along the old pioneer route. Since he was divorced and his daughters were grown, why not? Rinker planned to go solo, but even replica wagons have breakdowns, so fortunately for both him and his readers Rinkerâ€™s handy, force of nature brother insisted on coming along too--a brusque, big-hearted, syntax challenged, mechanically gifted giant of a man who has some resemblance to Harry Potterâ€™s Hagrid.Rinker blends the fascinating if fraught history of the mass migration westward into the story of his own journey. Pioneer journals were his guides, and the sections devoted to their lively accounts of trail travel were some of my favorite parts of the book. Rinker also writes movingly about his father, an adventurous, family-centered man who inspired his trip. I found the chapter about the surprising (to me) importance role of mules in 18th and 19th century America--starting with George Washington as a savvy land speculating donkey importer and mule broker--utterly captivating, and itâ€™s a good example of the atypical historical perspectives and insights that make this book so riveting.But The Oregon Trail: A New American Journey is as much about the modern day West and its people as it is about the past, and as an Easterner I learned a lot--Rinker, his brother, and their mule team often spent their nights in open publicly maintained corrals where teenagers gather to hang out and practice rodeo skills, not something we encounter here in the Boston to Washington megalopolis. The writing about the actual trip is detailed but evocative, so I felt like I was watching the scenery and riding along in the covered wagon myself. I wasnâ€™t quite so interested in the wagon maintenance aspects of their journey, but Iâ€™m sure those sections will delight some readers.

My husband enjoyed this shaver and has taken it over from my son, who originally tried using it. My husband tends to use this as a way to quick shave on days that he's running late or if he missed an area in his blade shaving. My older son was never able to get this shaver to completely shave and to give him a clean shaven look. As other reviewers mentioned, it will not really give you a close shave. My younger son who is just starting to shave and doesn't have much hair found this worked fine for him.For a price of $25 (about) it is ok for a beginner shaver who will shave every day but doesn't have a lot of thick hair on his face. That is why it earned a three stars from me. IF you are buying this as a first shaver for a young man who is just starting to shave and doesn't have thick hair- this is a five star, light weight easy to use shaver.It comes with a brush for helping to clean the shaver. It comes with a cord. The charge seems to last a few shaves. It even has a little trimmer on it. The one thing it doesn't have is a docking station so it just sorta lays around on the counter. We found it fit fine in a hair iron stick on the mirror type thing so that is where it sits in the bathroom now.Figure out what your needs are before you buy this shaver.

I was prepared to like this item. I thought it would be perfect for my Samsung Tab.However it does not work. I have tried everything I can think of to make it work. I have cleaned out the connection holes and tabs. I have asked my 16 year old son who understands technology better than I ever will to look at it. I have tried it with other items and it works with them. It does not work with my Samsung Tab.This keyboard DOES work wtih my motorola phone. However, that does me very little good as I generally do not check email on my phone. I wanted this to use with my Samsung Tab.If I figure out what I am doing wrong and how to fix it, I will share it on here.

First, let me share the conflicting emotion I have about this video.Essentially this is about a man (Blake) looking for a movie that will earn him some money and get him started on his movie making endeavors. When who should come knocking but the pizza delivery guy with his fear of and belief in everything alien and weird. So they begin together to explore these 'things'.What I didn't like was that Blake Freeman started this with no clue how it would end and little if any thought of what kind of impact he might be having on LeRoy. In fact, it wasn't until the middle of the show, at a minimum, that he really started to be a friend to LeRoy. Blake simply had the belief that by fighting LeRoy's belief system he would be making LeRoy's life better. And in the end, he had to do more to help LeRoy. And may I say that while I enjoyed the ending and thought it was hilarious, it was a bit chancy and a leaned towards the same fraud he was fighting in the first place.With my conflicting thoughts though, I will say that I loved this show. I laughed out loud at some parts and while I'd love to share some of those parts, this is really one of those see it to believe kind of shows. I loved that Blake was so creative in ways that he was able to show LeRoy the fraud that men and women perpetuate on people in order to make money. (Pet mind reading is just one example!)And despite my conflicting emotions, the ending was the BEST part and made me laugh and laugh.I think Blake Freeman will have a future if he chooses to continue to make documentaries like this. I'd love to hear more about what happened to LeRoy as well.

In light of the fact that the long lost first version of this story is coming out, I have decided to sit down and reread this book. I am so glad I did. What a joy to read, it was like revisiting an old friend. I had the opportunity to refresh my memory in the funny parts and the sad parts and the brave parts and the scary parts.I have always associated this book with the trail and the story of the father defending a black man. This must come from my vague memories of watching the movie in the classroom.However, I realized that I missed this whole 'nother story' of the Boo Radley and Jem and Scout. This sub story really brought home the feel of small town southern life with the fear of the house and the man in the house because he's not known, like everything else around them.Additionally, the details that you can read about in the book that make things seem more real or believable stuck out at me. The flowers in the corner of the lot were Mayelle lives brings home the misery of the small home she lives in and makes everything all that more understandable in some sad way. Dill with his stories of life 'back home' helps bring home how really lucky Jem and Scout are with their father. And many other countless examples.It is things like this that made this book a classic and have kept it a classic. It is the great writing and the story told through Scout's eyes that bring it all together to make this the book that brought home the times and the culture to a nation (and now a generation) who might never have otherwise seen it.Well worth the money and well worth reading and rereading.

I love Justified.First, I find Timothy Olyphant very good looking. So for a nice break of simple eye candy, this show is enjoyable.Mostly though, I just love how he operates. It makes me laugh. This is not a funny show by any means but it has humor.Raylan Givens grew up with a mean daddy and yet through that he learned how to treat women and children right (with great manners and much respect) and how to be honorable and trustworthy. Yet he is not afraid to shoot anyone. My husband and I started keeping a body count during each show just to see how many people he shot. There were those he shot dead and those he shot in the leg (Including his daddy) and those he shot in the hand as they were about to shoot and the list goes on.This was a great series worth watching.

This is probably my new favorite type of candy. I had never heard of Torrone until I decided to try one on a whim. Oh my goodness yum.This chocolate covered torrone is my most favorite. I like the texture and the taste.

These are supposed to help you fight off infections and nasty bug/germs.What I have found is that if I feel a cold coming on, I start popping these on an hourly basis and sometimes I don't get sick. I don't have any other proof that they work than my own personal experience.What you get is a small bottle that will fit into your purse or your pocket easily. It is amber in color to protect the oils inside. Inside this bottle are 100s of little tiny bead like pills. They are not bigger than a seed you might plant in your garden.I like to just let these roll around in my mouth or sit under my tongue until they dissolve. You can easily pop them by pushing them with your tongue into your teeth or roof of your mouth. If you do this be prepared for an intense burst of flavor. It is not a pepperminty flavor but rather it reminds both my husband and myself of cloves, almost as if we had bit into a clove.We use these and will continue to use them. Enjoy.

I watched this while washing dishes over the course of several nights. It looked like it might be interesting. I wasn't disappointed in this video.I am not interested in watching a show that glorifies a criminal but the disappearance of Jimmy Hoffa is one of the mysteries you grow up hearing about during the course of your life. So, this movie interested me.I learned a little bit more about who Jimmy Hoffa was and what he did and why others might have wanted to kill him. I thought the director did a fairly good job of setting the stage of the mystery and in explaining why the public is always interested.I don't know that it was exciting or heart pumping, nor was there a romance. This is a documentary that follows standard documentary format- interview some people, show some interesting shots of the places being talked about, show pictures of the past and so on.If you have an interest in Jimmy Hoffa, even a little bit, you might find this enlightening.

In this case I found the video and then found the books.I can say that if you have read the books and have finally decided to watch the show, you won't be disappointed. The movie accurately reflects the books. Harry Dresden looks like I imagined him and acts as he does in the books. There are a few minor changes, such as the wand he carries in the book becomes a hocky stick in the show. The one change that was big was the character of Bob. In the books Bob is a ghost like being that stays in a skull and only comes out with approval, often using the cat as a body.  In the show Bob is a character that lives and breaths and looks like a human and is not stuck in a skull. Mostly though the show does reflect the books.Because this is only the first season, those who have read all of the Dresden books will be able to accurately say that the books are darker than this show.If you haven't read the books but just wonder if you might like this show, I can say that I completely enjoyed this show. If you enjoy a little bit of science fiction/fantasy, if you enjoy watching shows about the underdog who does well, if you enjoy a little bit of mystery and a little bit of magic- you will probably enjoy this show.Complete fun. Well worth the money. Enjoy.

First, you can tell through a variety of ways that this is a dated show. They show older computer models, older cell phones etc.If you can get over that then this is a great show.I really liked this show. It is obviously pro FBI. It covers an FBI case from beginning to end. It explains how some of the decisions were made during an investigation. For example, why was the press notified about one case but not another case or why certain evidence was withheld from a court case etc.I enjoyed watching it. I enjoyed that they often mixed original phone calls or videos with recreations and interviews with the actual investigator along with interview of the people involved in the case.Overall, this followed the same format over and over again which only is a problem if you binge watch this and sit through six seasons all in one setting. But I really enjoyed watching the show.

I am in a position where I often need to have a card very quickly- sometimes a thank you card, often a happy birthday card or sympathy etc. I was going to the store often paying a lot for cards. This set is perfect for what I need.As other reviews have noted there are prettier cards available. There are also cards made of sturdier card stock available. There are even cards with cuter more meaningful poems inside. If you are looking for one card to a specific event for someone special, then you might want to give this set  a miss.However, these are lovely cards with lots of white space, perfect for writing a long message or having lots of white space for signatures from a group of people. If you are looking to have a few cards on hand for the unexpected birthday you learn about, the quick sympathy note for a coworker etc- this is a fine set.There is a variety of situations covered within this set. I have found it useful and am pleased with the set.well worth the money. Enjoy.

We bought an Earthlite massage support system for my husband to recover from eye surgery. It was suggested that we by these covers as well. We won't use all of these covers as he has recovered and we still have a lot of these covers. However, they were perfect for what we needed. I was able to change the cover daily in order to provide him a clean place to keep his head down. They also kept his skin from sticking to the fabric on the head pillow we bought. Overall, I'd strong advice getting these if you are having eye surgery and need a clean place to rest your weary head and neck while you recover.

What is not to love? These are boxes full of smaller boxes full of yummy goodness. They are torrone candies with three different flavors- lemon, vanilla and orange. They are not a strong taste but rather a delicate tasting candy. These are a favorite in our home now.We like that they are individually wrapped with their own cute little boxes. It makes it easy to use these are small treats or to put into gift bags etc The little boxes themselves are just adorable with their little pictures on them.

First this item came exactly as pictured. It came with a carrying bag and all of the parts and pieces you see in the picture.This took only a few minutes to put together. It was simple to do.We bought this for my husband who had eye surgery. He was required to keep his face down for 90% of the day for three days and then 75% of the day for another 3 days and then 50% of the day for another few days. We were able to rent some equipment but he felt that this might be helpful. I am writing this review based on his experience.A massage table was not comfortable for long term laying on as it was completely flat and fairly hard. (We tried) Additionally, a massage table was big and bulky and difficult to move or adjust.This tucked in under his body and he was able to sleep for several hours at a time using this. One of the things that he liked though was that he was able to use it while we were in the car. He was able to travel to and from appointments and keep his face down with support. Because it was easy to move he would join us in the kitchen while I cooked or while we read in the front room etc. It provided him many more options than a massage table would have for his recovery.One thing suggested is that you buy the covers for the pillow. Otherwise your skin will stick to the round head pillow and that is not comfortable. Another suggestion for recovering from this surgery is to provide yourself with options so that you are not stuck using only one thing. There are pillows that you can lay on that help. We had a wedge shaped pillow that he used to hold himself up instead of being flat on his stomach. There are pillows with holes in them, etc that you can buy. Consider what will make you most comfortable and do not plan on using just one thing to help you keep your head down for that long.welll worth the money.

First the one thing to be aware of in reading this book. This is dated. It is an older book published many years ago. So the mother stays home and cooks breakfast, lunch and dinner. This was written at a time when fewer people drove cars but walked or taxied or bussed it everywhere. This was written at a time when kids left home in the morning, played all day and come home when it got dark. The fact that is dated shows up in a variety of odd little ways.Having said that though, this is a great book. It is funny. It reflects life of a mother who is trying to live within a budget, manage a family of kids and a husband and a personal life. There were many times that I was able to nod my head up and down in agreement. There were times I chuckled and laughed as I saw myself in the same position. I was able to appreciate the stories of her children changing their names and only responding if you also spoke to their imaginary friends and so on.The author writes about what she knows- family life, daily life, mothering, being sick, the refrigerator going out, science experiments and so on. But she does it with humor, a dash of vinegar and it is well worth reading her books.Many of these chapters you may have read in short story collections or if you are older in ladies magazines. Together as a whole though is so much more enjoyable and coherent.A great fun read.

I was looking for some positive book that I could give to my daughter for a little gift. This was perfect.I liked that this book reflects many of the feelings that I have that often my daughter can't hear me say over her teenage year issues.I am hopeful that she will remember the things in this book as she goes through these difficult teen years.It is exactly as pictured. It is bright and colorful and positive. It is uplifting and positive.

We went to Washington D.C.  I looked and looked and found only one silver charm. I brought the charm home, put it on my bracelet and it broke. So I decided to do it right this time. I ordered this charm of Lincoln memorial because that had some vivid memory making opportunities for me on this trip.This charm is sturdy and will not break. It looks exactly like the picture. I was impressed with the detail included in this little charm.If you are a collector of charms then this might be something to consider if you are looking for a Washington D.C. charm.

My daughter who is in her teens and I devoured this book. Once we started it we didn't stop reading it until it was finished.Many have reviewed the plot of this book in much more detail than I will in this review. I will simply share a few thoughts.There is no swearing, no gratuitous sex scenes although there were some hints briefly of prostitution. Additionally, there was attempted rape. However, I felt that it was handled with the best possible way considering the situations. Because of the attempted rape I would say this might be more appropriate for an older teenager (maybe 15 or 16 and above). However, this is something you will need to decide for yourself and your own children.I found the main character to be completely believable. It was easy to see Jayden as a real person and to slip into her life. The setting was just as believable. It was well described and in many ways the setting was a character in the book that added to the story. The minor characters in this book were also well developed. I particularly liked the substory of Jayden and her sister. I appreciated their relationship and the story of their choices they made and how it impacted their lives.Overall, this was a romance but it was much more than a romance. It is a book about family, about the history of the area, and more. It is about trust and pride and love.

There is not much to say. I have an old Nokia phone and recently my charger quit working. I ordered this one. IT came promptly and worked to charge my phone. It is exactly as described and does the job it was supposed to do. I don't notice if it charges my phone faster or slower than previously because I don't pay that much attention to it. It charges the phone.

So bad it's good!There are a few things you need to know about this movie:First the director and his wife wrote this movie. Italian is their first language and they speak poor English (according to IMBD). They insisted that the characters go by the script as it was written when the movie was filmed. Second, ALL of the main characters went into the auditions hoping for parts as extras and were given the main character parts.In this movie, a young boy is hallucinating that his granfather is still alive and trying to help him save his family from trolls. The trolls have managed to turn themselves into human look alikes. This way, when they are hungry, they can go to town and take their pick of tasty humans to eat. Through a house exchange, the Wait family is on the menu. There are any number of ways the trolls can make you digestable for their system, all of which involve turning you into plant slime. Eat the green food and you become green plant slime, drink the green drink- plant slime. And once you are plant slime- you are eaten!This movie has all the earmarks of a cult classic- poor acting, strange creatures that aren't scary, green food, and someone peeing on the dinner table!What makes it even better is that it's so quotable. I have started quoting this movie to my children. "Big Sister, Your a Genius!" It's a Double-decker Bogna Sandwhich." etc.There is very little of redeeming value if you are looking for a true horror movie, a good kids movie, a movie the whole family will enjoy, or really, any kind of movie. Even the gratuitous scenes that show the girl and the boyfriend alone, together- are simply horrible. The only type of person that will enjoy it is those who have an oddball sense of humor, enjoy watching quotable bad movies.Enjoy.

I can see that this book would be appreciated and liked by others, more than by me. There was a lot to keep it interesting. A mystery keeps it going. The characters are true to themselves and only add to the story line. One thing I appreciated a lot was that the setting was almost a character on it's own and seems to reflect a portion of the characters and their lives. I enjoy reading an author that makes the setting be a part of the book.Be aware that this is a parental warning: There are mentions of drinking, swear words (F word) and other teen age drama. This is for an older teen not a preteen.Enjoy

This has been a staple at our house for many years. It is still our go to, easy to fix, camping drink.This is very easy to fix and very yummy. It is a traditional hot chocolate that tastes like hot chocolate with out any other flavors (no mint, no hazelnut etc). I like this size of container because you don't easily run out and if you want a thicker hot chocolate you can mix in more dry mix to make it thicker or less if you prefer a watered/milked down hot cocoa.Enjoy.

Abuelita Chocolate is a great hot chocolate. It smells so yummy and it is just as yummy as it smells. It is not at all similar to traditional hot chocolate that you might have grown up with in the U.S.Abuelita comes in a hard chocolate disk. You melt this in warm milk and it makes a very light colored hot cocoa that smells of cinnamon and tastes wonderful. I believe you are supposed to use the whole disk if you are making many servings. To do a serving for one I believe you use about a 1/3 to a 1/4th of a disk. We have found that to make three servings, if we use about a 1/3 to a 1/2 of a disk that is the perfect ratio for our tastes in our family.Although the disks are hard, they are not difficult to break apart. You can take a kitchen butter knife and put a little pressure on the center of the disk and it will generally break up into several pieces.We do not like to put things like whipped cream or marshmallows in this hot cocoa. It is simply perfect the way it is. It is easy to fix. It definitely has cinnamon in it. You can smell it and taste it but it is not an over powering cinnamon taste.Well worth the money. Enjoy.

We like to make Abuelita hot chocolate which is made with solid chocolate. To do this in a hot pot with warm milks seems to take forever and we have scalded several pots of hot chocolate. With that in mind my friend suggested we try this. What a great recommendation.You can use milk or water. You can use powder mixes, syrups, or  you can use solid chocolate to make yummy hot chocolate. This makes about 4 cups of hot chocolate. It heats it up hot but not scalding hot. We found that we needed to let it sit for a while or add some cool milk to the mixture in order to drink it. Of course, this gives you plenty of time to add whipped cream, marshmallows, etc and it will still be hot. There is an off button and sometimes when we think it is done, we will hit the off button.One thing we liked was that it came with recipes. Some were adult versions but most were easy to make and great for kids. There was gingerbread version, azteca hot chocolate etc. And that got us thinking about other types of hot chocolate we could try in this machine.The milk is spinning around in this machine as it is heated. We did take the lid off to look at it and it did not splash out and spin out. So I suppose if you wanted to check your hot chocolate, you could easily peak and see if it's done. I don't really suggest you do that though.To use solid chocolate such as pieces of dark chocolate or milk chocolate (such as Hershey Kisses), you put the suggested amount into the chocolate basket and add the milk or water and then hit the start button. It is really that simple.Additionally the clean up simple as well.Overall, I would buy this again and I believe this will have a place on our counter during the winter months. yum.

What is not to love about this game?The rules are fairly simple and easy to follow. The set up is very easy and quick. The game play needs you to think and put some thought into your strategy.It is quick and easy to learn and younger children can probably pick up the point of the game quickly. We played with an 11 year old but a smart kid who is 9 or 10 could easily play with no problems I believe.Do you use your pieces to block other players? Do you start to lay down track just anywhere because it might help you in the future? Do you take extra route pieces because then you can pick and choose your routes? How do you use your turn because you can only do one thing- draw cards, play cards to make a route, a pick new route cards?My youngest, age nine, who is a get up and go full of energy kid, enjoyed playing this game with the family. It is not a short game (It took us about an hour to play our first game but the time in play has decreased to about 30 minutes or 45 minutes now).Lots of fun.Well worth the money.Enjoy.

This is needed if you are planning on singing in a production of Handel's Messiah. It is further needed if you are going to highlight the parts you are singing (Also) and asked to fill in and sing a different part (Tenor) and need to highlight another set of parts. It is even more needed if your son is going to sing and needs a book so he can have a book for himself for his part (Bass).If you are able to participate in a Messiah, even if you feel you are not a great singer, but have been invited to sing- you should. This is a moving piece of music. Powerful.

Of the three I have read in this series; this is one of my favorites. The humor keeps the story light and refreshing and adds to the situation.I believe that you can compare this author to Janet Evonovich's early books. They are laugh out loud funny and the character development is perfect and easy to believe. Mrs P. who was a very minor character in the last book becomes a large part of the laugh out loud situations in this book.I plan on reading more from this author.

I have read all of the Dix Dodd mysteries and I really enjoyed them. The characters are enjoyable. The main character is a treat to read. She's not stupid and she doesn't luck into things. She works hard for solutions to the mystery and she works hard at her relationships and the work she does. There is enough of a light touch and humor in these books that they will keep you guessing and also keep you laughing, if not outloud at least to yourself as you read.Well worth the money.Enjoy.
This whole set of songs is super cute. They are good if you are looking for help singing songs with your scouts or boy events. This one was oen of our favorites during Cub Scouts. Enjoy

This is really a very pretty candle holder. It is exactly as it looks. It is heavy and the base is big enough and sturdy enough that it will not easily fall over. The red rose is fragile but it came packaged well and arrived fine. I was afraid it would look cheap or gaudy when my youngest son picked it out to give to me. My husband ordered it and I'm thrilled to showcase it on my dining room table. It does not look cheap or gaudy.

This is a fun game for ages 5 and up -- and I would take that age limit seriously since it is a pretty complex game -- with lots of different kinds of cards and lacking a clear "start" and "finish" line. The design of the game is kind of an endless loop, and you can decide at many spots which way to go -- do you take a shorter route, or stop off at "attractions" on side pathways?The goal is to gather 10 stars first, and you don't have to move very far to get stars. Thanks to the "activity cards" that you can pull on just about all the spaces on the board, you have a chance to pick up a star or some play money on just about every space. So while in most games a 6 is clearly better than a 1, that's not necessarily true here.The real weakness is the spinner that tells you how many spaces to move. It is not attached firmly to the board, and it spins off onto the table or floor very, very easily. How annoying. The spinner was one of the most distinctive and fun elements of the old Life game when I was growing up, but on this new, cheaply made Junior version, it has become a real liability. Very disappointing and it brings down the overall rating from four stars for the game itself, to three stars taking the poor design and quality into account.Overall a good game, but the drive to be cheap has hurt this game more than many others of the similarly cheap games out today.

These are surprisingly nice, very functional all-purpose kitchen towel. As microfiber, of course these are soft. They are also quite absorbent, and we have found they perform well as both dishtowels and hand towels.The towels have a pleasing if somewhat boring print pattern - at least I would say that of the "Cream Lattice" pattern, which is quite plain.  However, there are many other, much more striking colors and attractive designs, whether Yellow Dots or Lime or Orange Slices.The value or money is good, as a single package has 12 towels - enough to meet the needs of a household like ours for several years. They do appear durable - so sign of fraying or pilling even after multiple washings.We are very happy with these and can warmly recommend them for people who are mainly interested in function, and only secondarily in appearance. They look good, but they clearly aren't fancy -- although again, selecting one of the bolder patterns could help quite a bit on the attractiveness front.

We are very pleased with the quality and design of this kitchen towel. It is soft, absorbent, and pleasantly larger than most kitchen towels. Although the coffee pot is screened onto to the towel rather than woven into the fabric, it is still very soft - none of that hard "paint" residue you can find on many towels.We usually have two kitchen towels at any one time - a dish towel and a hand towel. We use this as a hand towel since the dish towels are, in our home, usually more like normal cloth fabrics than terry cloth-type towels. But you could use this either way with great success.The only downside is the price. If you are willing to splurge a bit for a kitchen towel, this is surely a nice one.

My four year old loves this game. Don't be too discouraged by the sourpusses lamenting that this game ain't what it used to be. That's the way things work today. The companies find ways to cut corners and keep things cheap, and we buy them because they are cheap. If you haven't found peace with that basic fact of modern life, I can't help you and you shouldn't buy this game.Judging this game by what it is, and not against some idealized version of the game from our own long-lost childhoods, it's not bad. My boy loves this because of the minions, and he hasn't even seen the movie, and won't for a while yet.We modified a rule or two to make the game easier for a slightly younger crowd - the recommended age is five and up. We did away with the rule that you have to roll a 6 to move your guys out of their base - at least for the first guy. That shaves off a lot of the frustration for short attention spans right at the start, for example.If your kid likes minions and you don't already have Trouble, you could do worse than this one for a pre-K and up board game. Recommended if those two conditions are met.

I like this printer and scanner for what it is - a compact all-in-one that delivers decent results at a good price. It is effective, and the inks are much more reasonably priced than some of the other printer brands (I'm looking at you, HP). I am happy with the printer.The downside is that after multiple attempts using all possible troubleshooting tools and the manual, I could not get the computer and printer to establish a connection over wi-fi through my router. The instructions say reinstall and try over in the event of these problems, and I did that about four or five times. I tried disabling my firewall on Windows 8 and network protection on my AV software (one of the Symantec products). That didn't help. The computer never recognized the printer even though both devices were logged on through the same router. The product's instructions don't get into any more complicated remedial steps than "uninstall, reinstall." Nothing like "create an exception at port XXX in your firewall", or something that would have allowed action to be taken. I wasn't willing to invest the time, after a good 8-10 total hours trying to get setup to work, to find more complex solutions.The "direct" wi-fi hookup worked for me - this allows the computer and printer to communicate directly with each other over wi-fi rather than going through the router. But that's pointless because you lose computer network connectivity - my laptop can't be on the router's wi-fi and the printer's wi-fi signal at the same time.So I use a cable. Who cares? Not a big deal, but as this is advertised as a wi-fi printer with easy installation, it's disappointing.Happy with the product, but it doesn't do what it says it does, so that's not great.

This is an excellent, heavy, cast iron roasting pan that achieves great heat distribution. It has a very attractive enamel finish on the outside and a somewhat "rough" interior that isn't smooth or even quite flat - just like it's supposed to be. I'm no professional, but this pan seems to me to be professional quality. This is the real deal.It requires some care, however, and is not for the careless. No dishwashers - wash it by hand and always dry with a towel rather than letting it air dry (to avoid the possibility of rust). It stays hot for quite a long time after you take it out of the oven, so be careful of burning yourself too.

These are perfectly functional terry cloth dishtowels with a retro design and middling quality. We prefer washing towels in warm/hot water for more of a sterilization effect, especially for kitchen towels where cleanliness is important, but these require cold wash to preserve the design.Why do they need to be washed cold to preserve the design? Because the design is kind of "painted" on to the white terry cloth towel rather than woven into it. So it has that special stiffness you get from painted on designs.I would also call this more of a kitchen hand towel than a dish towel. Maybe that's peculiar to our family, not sure, but we tend to use terry cloth for washing our hands and more straight textiles (rather than towel-like fabrics) for dishes.These are fine but nothing to write home about. The design is middling as is the overall quality, but they do work just fine.

Our boy just turned four and still uses diapers for sleeping at night. We were skeptical about these, since our earlier experience with pull-ups was that they just couldn't handle overnight duty - they would leak.Well, that hasn't been the case with these. We were quite pleasantly surprised. Even though at four he is capable of producing more volume than ever, we have had no leakage or problems.Note the small/medium size has the Iron Man design, but the Large/XL version does not - rather it is just kind of a strange camouflage pattern.

You may have the great experiences others describe with this watch. I was hoping I would. But mine was a real piece of junk that literally fell apart after less than a month of totally normal, non-abusive use.The first sign of trouble was when the watch lost an hour, exactly an hour, one day. I thought it must be some daylight savings time feature and the watch was just confused about when the switch was. I changed the time back.A week later, however, the watch stopped completely. And when I went to change the time, thinking I must have a defective battery or something, I noticed the crown had come clean off. No crown. Nearest I can figure is it must have been the friction from putting my hand in my pocket, or taking it out.This was all on April 28, and my 30-day return window had closed April 9. In addition, delivery took much longer to me, because I have an APO address. So I got maybe a month out of this watch, and only about three weeks of actually wearing it daily.Amazon gives their own two-year warranty, and they pay postage for shipping. I am curious what they are going to do when I send this back without a crown. Will update review based on experience. But I'd recommend staying away from $50 Timexes. I feel like I tried and got burned.

The idea is great and the execution is OK. It is not very easy to really get the hang of this. The main problem was syncing the directionality with my Android phone and keeping it straight. It seemed for a long time that even if I kept the phone perfectly aligned and unmoved compared to a north-south axis, the unit didn't want to move in the directions I was sending it. This gets better with practice but it's not as intuitive as you would think or hope and can try one's patience. If you invest the time to get good at operating it, it's pretty cool but even then it could lose the novelty effect pretty quickly. Good, and if they can make the interface more reliably intuitive it could be really good.

I can't get over how much the animatronic technology of these Sesame Street toys has developed in just a few years. We have the Cookie Monster Count And Crunch, and compared to that, this Elmo toy is a versatile, sophisticated, precision instrument. Our three year old likes it quite a bit, although like with most of his toys, it doesn't hold his interest for more than maybe 10 minutes at a time. But he keeps coming back to it, which is a good sign.We got the Cooke Monster registered above in 2011. It has maybe 10 or 12 things it can say, and the mouth makes little pretense of moving in sync with the words coming out of its speaker. This Elmo is remarkable in comparison - with a much more varied palette of phrases, possible stimuli and reactions, in four different modes - one mode each depending on which of three hats he is wearing, and a fourth, more limited mode in effect when he is wearing no hat at all. (Plus there is a demonstration mode, which I'm not counting.)You can squeeze Elmo's nose, tickle his tummy or bounce him on his behind to get different reactions. Elmo gives directions as to what to do with him (squeeze his nose, etc) and my son likes not following the instructions on purpose. He thinks the sounds he makes when you do the "wrong" thing are funnier than the sounds for doing it right.The downside of the toy is that it won't hold a toddler's attention for too long. But really, what does? Not much with our boy, at least. This Elmo does better than a lot of other toys in that regard, so we are pretty satisfied.

We are replacing/supplementing a worn out five-year-old set with this Rachel Ray cookware and we are basically satisfied. We are casual cooks, however - not pros. This cookware meets our needs well enough and we like that unlike some hard anodized cookware, this is dishwasher safe.On the downside, the metal is fairly thin, which makes for less effective heat distribution on the bottom. And although the orange-brown plastic handles are attractive in their own way, their color and relative flimsy feel somehow add to the perception that this is not a "serious" set of cookware.These pots and pans are working just fine for us and I'm sure they will for several years. We do like the convenience of being able to put them in the dishwasher if we wish. No meals have been ruined in the preparation of this review. If you run an average household and want something simple that will do a good job, these could be great for you. But if you consider yourself a master cook and want top-quality cookware, move along. These aren't the pots you're looking for.

My wife and I are hoping to have the opportunity to Rome one or more times in the next couple of years, and this book is an invaluable planning reference.  It is full of ideas for things to do, as well as maps and illustrations to help you plan and get there.I especially like that the guide is focused on things to see and do, rather than taking up too much valuable space with lodging and dining options. I generally shop for lodging online, and I think Lonely Planet has caught on that a lot of other travellers do too. Regarding restaurants, it probably would be good to plan more carefully to get the best eats, but when traveling my wife and I generally start looking around at the options wherever we are at the time, and choosing a place based on what looks good at the moment. We generally have not gone by travel book recommendations a lot in the past, so I'm glad the book doesn't devote excessive space to this.In general, I think it's fair to say that the "Discover" series is Lonely Planet's alternative for travelers who want to see the sights and enjoy what a city or country has to offer, but who don't need a ton of detail on other aspects, like on lodging or dining. On the disappointing side, history and cultural background can suffer too, but not nearly as much as in other guides, like the DK "Eyewitness" series, which are long on pictures and short on most other things.This book, like others in the "Discover" series, has a great level of detail for the standard, casual traveler. People who are moving to a country for an extended period of time should probably still get the big Country Guide, but if you just want to enjoy a good vacation in Rome for a week or two, this is the only guidebook you'll need. If you'll be in Rome only for a few days as part of a short but larger Italy trip, you might consider the Discover Italy guide.

I have been to London several times over the past few years, usually for a week or so. I wish I had had this guide on these trips, and look forward to using it in the future. It is full of ideas for things to do, as well as maps and illustrations to help you plan and get there.The "Discover" series is Lonely Planet's alternative for travelers who want to see the sights and enjoy what a city or country has to offer, but who don't need a ton of detail on other aspects, like lodging, dining, or (and this is the part that makes me a little sad) history and cultural background.The "Discover" books have a lot more pictures than the traditional, text-heavy Lonely Planet guides. They are definitely geared toward sightseeing. I am pretty sure these guides are LP's response to the DK "Eyewitness" series, which are long on pictures and short on most other things. Lonely Planet hits a much better balance than DK in terms of providing information and background on what you're looking at -- that is something I really value.This book, like others in the "Discover" series, has a great level of detail for the standard, casual traveler. People who are moving to a country for an extended period of time should probably still get the big Country Guide, but if you just want to enjoy a good vacation in London for a week or two, this is the only guidebook you'll need. If you'll be in London only for a few days as part of a short but larger UK trip, you might consider the Discover Great Britain guide.

We like bamboo placemats. We have used many over the years, and among them, these take quality and good looks to another level. They are very elegant-looking due to the blue ornamentation in the center and down the sides. They look terrific, giving an impression almost that they are made of cloth rather than bamboo. But it's nice that they really are bamboo.But make no mistake, these placemats are for look rather than function. We would only really use these for company, and that mainly for friends rather than VIPs, not that we have many VIPs over to the house. These are not placemats for everyday dinners with our three year old.One reason is simply that they don't protect the table from spills at all. Spilled soup or pasta sauce will go right through them to the table or tablecloth underneath. But if you are buying bamboo placemats, you know that and expect it anyway.Another reason is that cleaning them is not the easiest, especially on the cloth parts. You'll be hard pressed to get tomato stains out, for example. Again, this is a problem you'll have with the trim on most bamboo placemats.But for what they are - bamboo - these are great. Perfect for non-snooty company that you still want to present a good impression too. They add casual elegance to dinner. If that's what you want and expect, these are perfect. If not, you should look elsewhere.

We chop a lot of onions in our home - my wife is Hungarian so finely diced onions are the basis for just about every dish. I also enjoy making a good chili, which starts out the same way, browning finely diced onions. That is the key for us - onions. And this chopper is AMAZING for that. Love it!Cheese is also a snap, as are other vegetables we chop a lot, like various kinds of peppers (cut those shiny side down - the blades work best on the uneven inside of the peppers rather than the smooth outside).Where is performs less well is on smushy veggies like tomatoes, which get pretty messy and squirty. Also not recommended for super-firm tubers like uncooked potatoes - I'd be very nervous about the blades and the plastic construction holding up on those.Cleaning is OK, we use a dishwashing brush and do it right after use.So this is perfect for us with our needs for onions, onions, onions plus some other assorted veggies and cheeses. Not a great idea for french fry cutting from raw potatoes or for dicing tomatoes. If that is what you need too, go for it! This thing is fantastic.

These headphones have pretty good sound while still allowing ambient noise to come through. I do like them, but I like many other headphones better, mainly because of discomfort after having them in for more than an hour or so.I have no real issues with the sound of these headphones, which really do sound pretty good with decent bass for this size. (I do not listen to heavy boom-boom music though - if that is your thing, you may find these lacking.)Putting them in your ears is a bit counterintuitive. The basic design is a little similar to the Bose IE2, with funky outer ear half-moons to hold them in. However, the comfort level is far below the Bose, which are made of very soft silicone. These are made of pretty unyielding plastic, and are fairly large. The size and hardness of the phones - even if you select the correct size - make these pretty uncomfortable after about an hour and downright painful after a few hours. That is their main drawback.The noise isolation is weak, but that is a design decision. If you want to hear the ambient environment, that won't be a problem with these headphones.Overall they would be a solid four stars if the comfort problems were fixed. Almost a successful product.

These are terrific freeze dried fruit snacks that pack a wallop in terms of flavor. We actually like them better than the Trader Joe's brand.There is something for everybody here in terms of flavor. I really liked the apple, and the pear was nearly as good. I didn't care at all for the tangerine, but that was my wife's favorite of all of them.  The apple and pear have a very natural taste -- like the extreme, distilled essence of apple and pear. Very intense. The tangerine was so extreme as to be disconcerting, and a bit sour, but she thought that was great. Our three year old agrees with me on the apple.It could get a little pricey - one bag is not enough for any of us, even the three year old, and having a snack of two bags could quickly run into the dough.  But otherwise this is a quality healthy snack, no preservatives or additivesThe tangerine has little broken bits on the bottom of the bag, my wife said these are hard to eat but tasty.

We picked this book after having a good experience with "Pond Walk" by the same author, Nancy Elizabeth Wallace. Like Pond Walk, this book is full of neat things to do for inquisitive young minds. There is one experiment after another that kids can do with water, none of them hazardous.It's an ideal book for kids about 6-8 years old to get them interested in science-type questions. We really enjoyed it.

My wife liked this brush at first, but then realized it wasn't too practical. "It looks great, it feels good on my face," she said. "But when I try to apply make up with the brush it is hard to see the makeup, because I can't apply enough on the brush." She says this is good for real powdery makeup, but not for less powdery blushers and so on.She does say she likes the little bag, it comes with a lot, but will probably not use it too much.

I have to have a timer for so many things, from cooking  to laundry and more, and this timer fits the bill. I leave it stuck to our refrigerator - at first I found it slipped down the side of the fridge, but then I found a place where the Mag ted stick well.It is a bit of a pain to put in the batteries, and you will need a n eyeglass screwdriver for this. Can't be helped as this is necessary to keep the unit watertight, but the screwdriver should have been included because not everyone has an eyeglass screwdriver around.I like the alarm, which is pretty easy to set and has a low and high volume available. The high volume is loud enough to hear from quite a distance. I also like the durability of the device.A simple and effective timer, does the job with some extra durability and a good backlight if needed.

This is really a heavy duty, rugged piece of equipment and the LED bulb offers an intense, bright light. I really like it and find the quality is excellent. The construction is solid and durable metal with rubberized ends that offer some cushioning in case of falls - the company says it will withstand a drop of 20 feet but I haven't tested that claim.It's a plus that the body is not round, so you can leave it on a tilted surface without having to worry about it.falling off. I do regret that it does not have a lanyard connection or a magnetic clip, but overall this flashlight is a good choice for those looking for a heavy duty, bright light they can depend on in work conditions.

This is a much better than the standard, no-frills seat protector we were using to protect the back of our passenger seat from our toddler's dirty shoes in his car seat. We do like it, but feel it is loaded with some features that are unnecessary and just clutter things up unnecessarily.Let's take a look at the features they bill as selling points:- Zips up to hide the mess. We like that we can zip it closed when we want to. We don't choose to do this too often, but if there are non-family members riding in the car, for example, it's nice to be able to tidy up relatively painlessly.- Big stuffable compartments. Well, this is OK but I feel there are too many compartments. It makes the whole thing feel too busy. Putting too much stuff in it can make it look bulky. But it does hold a lot, I have to admit - and that's good.- Tablet viewer. Holds up to a big screen tablet - fine for our small screen (Kindle Fire HD) as well. One problem, which may not be a problem at all, is that unless some special effort is taken, this is best for watching videos but not particularly great for listening to them. The sound gets out but not that great especially in a noisy moving car. On the other hand, if you have a long enough audio patch cord, you can plug the tablet into the car stereo for a good audiovisual experience. We don't do that, but we could.- Attachment system maximizes rear leg room - this is good.- Deluxe wipes case. Huh? Why would we want to take our wipes out of their ready-made, resealable wipes package and put them in this plastic case? I have heard legends of wipes that don't come in resealable packages. If you are determined to save a nickel a box or whatever it is to buy no-frills wipes, maybe this will be welcome to you. We found it completely superfluous, cheapskates though we are.So on the whole, this is a nice product and worth recommending.

The coolest thing about this set is the Flo's V-8 Cafe building itself. That's about it.You put two cars at the starting line and pull the handle to shoot them out of their starting blocks to race. There are then two problems. First, there is a mechanism at the other end of the track that makes a flag come down for the winner and a saguaro cactus for the loser. Problem is, the cactus is set up to actually block the track of the losing car, making it stop dead on the track while the winning car is allowed to speed away.This might be fine, I suppose, if the track were longer. But they give you about a foot and a half or so of track. So the entire race lasts about 1.3 seconds (I made that number up, but it may be less for all I know.)If you modifications to solve both of these issues, it's not bad. First, take off the cactus. Then both cars can go pretty far. Kids can tell which one was faster without having the slow one physically restrained after 1.3 seconds, if they are interested. Second, put in a longer track. it uses standard Hot Wheels-type tracks.Even with the modifications, this is not an essential toy. The "bleachers" for the spectator cars are kind of pointless too. OK but nothing great here.

Wow, this is really one of the worst toys ever, and I feel I am pretty easygoing and forgiving when it comes to toy ratings. Talk about a pointless toy. You put the car on the "stairs" and then push it up to the top and let it go down where a big alligator chomps down on the car which the car tries to knock a piece of "gold" out of the alligator's mouth.Except all that part about the alligator? It doesn't work. Sure, if you manage to hit it just right, maybe it kind of grabs the car, and you're supposed to send another car (not included) to the rescue. That car hits the alligator in the eye to kind of reset the whole thing.If it worked and did something cool, that would be one thing. But it doesn't work the way it's supposed to very often, and what it doesn't isn't cool, it's just kind of pointless.Move along, move along -- there's nothing to see here.

Our three year old was very interested in this right out of the box, even though he hasn't seen the Planes movie. He wanted to assemble the track together with me, and actually we both have a lot of fun flying the little Dusty Crophopper plane around and around the track. Look, this is a simple toy. It's neither difficult nor sophisticated, and maybe bigger kids would get bored soon. But I'd recommend it for toddlers and their dads.It would be better if it came with two planes, but they are very tricky -- they give you one plane and two plane holders that allow the plane to "fly" on the track -- an open invitation to buy second plane. Now we are tempted to buy another plane, because our son wants to play with two.The plane is pretty good quality and sturdy build, but the plastic track itself is kind of flimsy. Don't think this is a toy for the ages, but both my son and I like it.Otherwise it seems lightweight and not very sturdy plastic, so you need to be careful not to break it.

We have been using this for over a month now and we love it. It is just about perfect for our RAV4 -- although not quite since the sun still can hit our three year old if it's shining from the right angle. Still, it is much, much better than our previous sun shade, an Eddie Bauer roller model. A big advantage is that our boy always wanted to pick and play at the rolldown shade, trying to take it off the window. He can't do that here, but he also doesn't seem to want to.The package contains one shade, so it's great if you only drive in one direction. (Kidding -- actually it makes perfect sense since we always want it on the window next to the child seat.)  It looks great and doesn't disturb us when driving. It sticks to the window really well, but also is easy enough to remove. Very nice.

When testing a detergent for a review, I always try to make sure to really put it to the test. Normally I pre-rinse my dishes pretty well to get all the real gunk off them, but in testing these "Power and Free" Finish Powerball Tabs I made sure to leave on as much non-solid nasty junk as possible. The results were very good, I was pleased with the quality of the wash and didn't notice any difference as compared to standard quality detergents -- meaning detergents that do not advertise themselves as containing fewer "harsh chemicals".Overall I would be very likely to use this product again, depending on price. These appear to be about 30-40 cents apiece, in line with other quality tabs. I would happily use these at that price. They produce good results.

A good French press is all about the filter on the end of the plunger. Nothing else really matters. No French press is ever going to make "better" coffee than another. You put coffee grounds in boiling water, and the quality is going to depend only on the quality of the coffee, the amount you put in, and to some extent the grind of the coffee. The only value the French press adds as compared to something like a Turkish coffee is the extent to which it actually keeps the grounds from pouring out into your coffee cup.On that score, I found the Francois et Mimi to be a pretty darn good French press. The instructions for a French press will always say to use coarsely ground coffee, since the filter can keep those out of your cup more easily. I tried an espresso grind as well with this coffee maker, and even that worked acceptably well -- I had to leave the last couple of millimeters of coffee at the bottom of the cup with the espresso grind, but that's not bad.With a coarse grind, almost no grounds are left at the bottom, but a minimal amount of grounds are visible in the coffee when you get down to the bottom of the pot. This French press performs better most I have used.My wife used it as a milk frother as well and got very good results. She also has a dedicated frother that works a bit better, but she said in a pinch the froth from this coffee press is also very good.Nice product, well made, easy to like and recommend!

These are great kids' scissors that really cut paper, threads and other things well. At the same time, they are well designed from a safety point of view -- the blades are not really sharp and they have a blunt tip to minimize the chance of injuries.However, I would say only that it would be difficult for children to cut themselves with these scissors -- not at all impossible. These are real scissors. A kid would almost need to try to cut himself or herself with these, but they could do it.Take the age recommendation seriously. These are five-and-up scissors. The trade off between safety and the ability to cut things well has been managed with skill in this product. I believe they are pretty safe, but still caution is warranted especially with littler kids.

This is actually a package of two different albums: Peter Gabriel's 2010 collection of cover songs Scratch My Back and the late 2013 followup And I'll Scratch Yours, which has (most of) the artists whose songs Gabriel sang on that album reciprocating by performing Gabriel's songs. (A few backed out of the project or declined to participate, sadly including David Bowie, Radiohead, Neil Young and Ray Davies.)So don't expect a single, unified musical experience from this package. "Scratch My Back", which features Peter Gabriel performing with piano and chamber orchestra, is definitely an excellent, high-concept musical experience as the songs all share similar orchestral colors. But like most tribute albums, I found "And I'll Scratch Yours" to be a hit-and-miss hodgepodge with brilliant moments but also less brilliant ones.I like "Scratch My Back" a lot, but as both a popular and classical music enthusiast, I am positively disposed to "crossover classical" music -- things like most of what Sting has done for the last few years, or Tori Amos' fantastic album Night of Hunters. Hell, I even like the orchestral version of The Who's Tommy.What we have in "Scratch My Back" is a lushly orchestrated set of Peter Gabriel music, even if he didn't write it. The atmosphere is somber and wistful overall. Very frequently, Gabriel deconstructs the music so completely that the songs are hardly recognizable, for example with Bowie's "Heroes" and Paul Simon's "Boy in the Bubble", both of which dissolve into lovely orchestral atmospherics punctuated by Gabriel's voice bearing only slight resemblance to the original singing."And I'll Scratch Yours" is definitely a mixed bag, however. (But you can count on two fingers the "tribute" albums that I really like -- they are almost always real hit-and-miss affairs.)I found the brightest spots when the artists did a similarly thorough deconstruct of Gabriel's music as he did in his covers. The late, great Lou Reed transforms the light and airy "Solsbury Hill" into a dystopian, arrhythmic fuzz-guitar fest. I had never heard of Joseph Arthur before, but he actually pulls a somewhat similar feat with "Shock the Monkey". Feist (who I previously knew mainly from my son's Sesame Street DVD, where she sings a wonderful song about counting to four) also does an excellent, stripped down "Don't Give Up".Another highlight is Randy Newman's take on the hit "Big Time". Of course it comes out dripping with irony that was not as obvious in the original. It actually sounds like it could have been written by Randy Newman -- a kind of prequel to his early number "Lonely at the Top". Fantastic.Paul Simon's 12-string guitar take on "Biko" is pretty great too. It kind of felt to me like Simon was getting some closure on South Africa with this one. Steve Biko was an anti-apartheid activist killed by police brutality in 1977. Although he was not a member of the African National Congress, the ANC does recognize him as a hero in the struggle against apartheid. Paul Simon caught hell from the ANC for breaking their cultural boycott of South Africa with his "Graceland" album, and it was actually a pretty big deal at the time. Paul Simon's final reconciliation with the ANC establishment is caught on film in the 2012 documentary film Under African Skies.A lot of the covers fell short for me, though. I'm not too into synth-pop/techno things, and we certainly have some of that here. David Byrne, normally a musical hero for me, kicks the album off with an ironically oriented electronic version of "I Don't Remember" that falls short, as does "Not One of Us", which was like a mildly nightmarish flashback to my 1980s teen years. Arcade Fire does OK on "Games Without Frontiers", but I felt they played it too straight rather than really making it their own.Another thing that stands out is that no one touches Gabriel's ultimate smash hit, "Sledgehammer". I imagine Gabriel asked people not to choose that one. It has been covered a lot anyway.So overall this is a nice package. I like it. I'd give 4.5 stars to "Scratch My Back" alone, and 3.5 to "And I'll Scratch Yours". Recommended.

This set is absolutely identical to EMI's six-disc box set Jascha Heifetz: The Master Violinist, right down to the number of tracks and track lengths.The only disadvantage to this collection as compared to the MP3 version from EMI appears to be a lack of metadata (although I can't confirm that the EMI metadata is any better). Particularly irksome is that these MP3s do not list the composers.Here is my quick list of tracks including composer (I will hopefully be able to fill in the composers for the "encores" list soon, no time to dig now):1-3 Sibelius - Violin Concerto in D minor, Op. 47 - Beecham, London Philharmonic4-6 Tchaikovsky - Violin Concerto in D, Op. 35 - Barbirolli, London Philharmonic7-10 Glazunov - Violin Concerto in A minor, Op. 82 - Barbirolli, London Philharmonic11-13 Mozart - Violin Concerto No. 4 - Beecham, London Philharmonic14-16 Mendelssohn - Violin Concerto in E minor, Op. 64 - Beecham, London Philharmonic17-19 Mozart - Violin Concerto No. 5 - Barbirolli, London Philharmonic20-22  Wieniawski - Violin Concerto No. 2 - Barbirolli, London Philharmonic23-26 Vieuxtemps - Violin Concerto No. 4 - Barbirolli, London Philharmonic27-30 Vieuxtemps - Violin Concerto No. 5 - Malcolm Sargeant, London Symphony31 Saint-Saens - Introduction and Rondo Capriccio - Barbirolli, London Philharmonic32 Saint-Saens - Havanaise - Barbirolli, London Philharmonic33-36 Bach - Sonata No. 137-41 Bach - Partita No. 242-45 Bach - Sonata No. 346 Bach - Partita No. 3, Menuets I & II47 Bach - English Suite No. 3, Sarabande48-68 (Various encores)69-73 Vivaldi - Sonata in A - with Arpad Sandor74-76 Beethoven - Violin Sonata No. 9 "Kreutzer" - with Benno Moseiwitsch77-79 Paganini - Caprice Nos. 13, 20, 24 - with Arpad Sandor80-83 Franck - Violin Sonata in A - with Artur RubinsteinThe quality of the transfers seems great, and the selections are wonderful. There are a lot of great violinists today, but Heifetz is still pretty special. He had my jaw dropping at the Sibelius already. What a sound he got out of his violin -- sweet, intelligent, yet sometimes just fierce. Snap this one up!

I found this old book in a box that I hadn't seen since I was a kid. I read this book now to my two and a half year old son and he really likes it a lot.It is visually very interesting. It involves a kid named Christopher who stands on a sidewalk watching a parade go by. ( I think the parade is actually imaginary, but the book does not state this.) There are airplanes, clowns, camels, elephants, cowboys, pirates, acrobats, astronauts, a marching band, monkeys, a guy in an Uncle Sam suit on stilts, a hot dog vendor and a lot more, all going by as Christopher watches them.As an adult (and a Beatles fan) I appreciate the obviously strong influence of the animation style from the "Yellow Submarine" movie. I mean, look at the cover. All the illustrations are in that style. It's a very nice, hippie-inspired visual book. Good stuff.

We got this for my son when he was just a few months old, hoping it would soothe him to sleep. At first it did help him to get to sleep, but we think it was because he was afraid of this glowing light with music coming out of it. He quickly shut his eyes whenever we put it in his bed, and slept soon after.Later on, from about one year to maybe 20 months old, he had it in his bed but didn't use too much. He wasn't afraid of it but just wasn't interested.Then for the last year or so (he's over two and half now) he has really liked it. He turns it on himself, sometimes with his hands on purpose, and sometime by accident when he pushes it under his hips or legs to sleep. He calls it by name (he calls it "Dobby" for some reason) and it's one of his favorite bedside animals.I'd give it five stars except it has a terrible flaw that would have been so easy to avoid. Like most toys for very small kids, the battery compartment is screwed down tight with small, Philips-head screws. The problem is the screws are deeply recessed into a little hole, into which the screwdriver head fits. This hole is so small that the screwdriver shaft takes up the whole space. That means you can't see how the screwdriver is fitting into the screw. You just push it in, and start turning, Since you can't see the screw, you push the screwdriver a little harder so that it's sure to catch the slots in the screw.You see where this is leading. After about two years and maybe 10 battery changes (especially if, like us, you use rechargeable batteries, which don't last as long as alkalines before they need charging again), the screws get stripped. For us, one of the screws is gone beyond all hope, and the other is almost gone.What a ridiculous and unfortunate design for an otherwise great product. Fisher-Price, just build it so we can see what we're doing when we have to unscrew the battery cover. Is that so much to ask?

We have always liked Seventh Generation products in principle for their lack of harmful chemicals, particularly as our son has eczema and we need gentle products to avoid nasty flare-ups. In practice, we have found them to sometimes fall short -- particularly when it comes to wipes. For example, Seventh Generation Free & Clear Wipes strike us as flimsy and they leave threads behind when they encounter even a slightly rough texture.That's why these wipes are such a pleasant surprise. Man, they are thick. They don't need to be this thick for us to be satisfied. But if you want a good, study wipe you won't get much better than this. These are thicker than just about any wipes we have used.We really like the flip top as well, even though it is not quite in keeping with the environmentally friendly tradition of Seventh Generation -- extra plastic going into the landfill. But we aren't saints. If this were our biggest sin, we'd be doing pretty well.We are very happy with these wipes, and it is nice to be able to say that without reservation about a Seventh Generation product.

We have been using cheapo house brand dishwashing tablets for a while and haven't been really happy with the results. Even after considerable pre-scrubbing to get the worst food remnants off, the dishes were "acceptably" clean at best. We would always see considerable spotting on our glasses, even though we try to keep our in-machine water softener well stocked with rock salt -- the water is very, very hard where we live.These detergent packs really impressed us coming off our negative experience with generic tablets. The difference is remarkable. This detergent handles food remnants and nastiness very well and our glasses are spot-free.The lemon scent is a downside for us, since we know it doesn't come from lemons but from kind of chemical designed to smell like lemons even after a long washing cycle. That must be some strong artificial aroma, and we just hope it is relatively benign. Better life through chemistry, right? We'll try to stay optimistic about that.Overall this detergent does a great job. First rate, no doubt about it.

This is a DK coffee table book. It is not going to be used as a textbook at the Curtis Institute. No one should expect depth here. But if your expectations are for an attractive coffee table book that offers great breadth and a lot of "fun facts" for people who like music of all kinds but don't have a lot of knowledge, this is actually a great choice.I think it would make a good gift for music lovers who don't have a lot of formal training, and who don't take themselves too seriously intellectually.I am not a trained musician at anything but a superficial level, but I listen to a lot of music and read a lot of reviews, program notes and liner notes about a lot of classical as well as popular and world music. I am enough of a dilettante to fake may way into polite and sometimes sophisticated musical discussions. I know quite a lot about music compared to the Average Joe on the street, but extremely little compared to someone like Daniel Barenboim.What I found here was a lot of information presented in that entertaining and informative DK style that seems designed to cultivate just enough knowledge to allow people to show off at cocktail parties. Much of the information here was new to me, especially about early music history -- which is the part I found most valuable and informative.Yes, later on it gets into all too familiar popular music territory, and this is pretty dull. Its coverage of things like jazz and rock is doomed from the start, since so many people have so many opinions and no one will ever be satisfied.Despite being forced to shallowness by the format and concept, the authors do seem to want to maintain at least an appearance of sophistication. I found one omission in the late book very telling. When talking about 21st century "classical" music, they make no mention of Osvaldo Golijov, even though his La PasiÃ³n segÃºn San Marcos has made a greater populist splash in the last 15 years than any other "classical" work. I really enjoy "La Pasion", even though it can easily be written off as pedestrian and unsophisticated. I thought Golijov's failure to even garner a mention on a list of contemporary composers was telling of a certain snootiness, as if the authors were trying to maintain their dignity even while wading through the intellectual shallows.So is this book perfect? Of course not. But does it give most people at least cursory entertainment and some new information they might otherwise never learn regarding music history and the historical and cultural context of different musical developments and trends through the centuries? Damn straight it does.This book does a great job of doing what you should expect from a DK coffee table tour-de-force on music. If that's what you want, you should be pretty happy with it. You will have big problems if you expect something else.

This book shows dinosaurs in various modern urban environments, which is a fun concept. Not unlike the end of Jurassic Park 2 (or was it 3?), when the T-Rex tears loose in San Diego.The pictures are pretty entertaining and the short descriptions of each dinosaur are pretty good, and appropriate for the 4-8 age group that is the target audience of this book.The one complaint I have is the inconsistency in carrying out the premise. If the dinosaurs really were in the situations shown in this book, they would be eating the people around them. It would be pretty bloody and gruesome. I'm not saying the pictures should show people being eaten, just that there is an inconsistency between the realism of the illustrations and the lack of realism in some of the fictitious scenarios. Yes, they do hint in some of the texts that you would need to watch out if you encounter certain of these dinosaurs.You may also have some trouble explaining the concept of extinction to some younger kids who may think dinosaurs are still living animals based on seeing them in modern surroundings.None of these issues merits docking a star, however. It's still a really enjoyable little book.

We like these wipes for their lightness and lack of harmful chemicals, particularly as our son has eczema and we need gentle products to avoid nasty flare-ups.What we don't like about these wipes is their small size and very light texture. They seem a little flimsy, and although I haven't experienced them falling apart, when I tried used one to wipe a stain off my clothes, little white threads were left behind in droves. They are made of a somewhat gauzy, indeed almost diaphanous material that just isn't to our taste.Many other reviewers say their lightness is just what they like about these wipes. So it comes down to a matter of personal taste. Our taste says we prefer other wipes, like the new Seventh Generation Thick & Strong Free and Clear.

I have had these knives for two and a half years now and they still provide good service. After about a year, however, they were in real need of sharpening -- don't think they will stay sharp forever.The good news is they can be sharpened without special worries -- I use this sharpener B007Y15LD4 but any standard one should do the trick. There are no sharpening instructions with the knives, nor is there any on the company's website. I sent an e-mail to customer service and got a noncommittal answer.
