They said the straight-edged knives could be sharpened normally but recommended I buy their sharpener. They also said the serrated blades should be sharpened professionally. I didn't feel the cost and quality of the knives justified the expense of professional sharpening so I just use the serrated blade groove of the sharpener listed above, and that works OK.I really like them and give them five stars for the price -- note the "for the price" caveat, which is important. My wife doesn't care for them and would probably give them three stars. She thinks we should have spent more on a good European set like Henckels. I disagree. I like the colors and think the knives are great for non-professionals, they just will need some sharpening on a regular basis after a while. .However, the colors also have one major drawback for households with little kids. These are the same colors used on plastic kids' toys, and our 2.5 year old son thinks they must be great to play with. We have to pay special attention to keeping them away from him. If they were black and boring, he would probably be less interested.The colors have not come off even after a lot of washing with the scoury side of kitchen sponges -- except the little green paring knife, from which the colors scratched badly on the side of the knife during what I thought was normal washing as we had washed earlier. Perhaps I got hold of a sponge with a steel wool scouring side? Not sure what was different, but once and only once, the color came off badly from one of the knives.

This book stands out for the absolutely fabulous, retro-style artwork by Marcellus Hall. Lush paintings that for me, somehow recall the atmosphere of such bygone greats as Herge's original Tintin books -- even though the particulars of the style are very different.Another reviewer said the book is not for babies, and that is likely true. But, our son started paying attention when he was about one and a half, and he still likes it a lot now at two and a half. It is in regular bedtime rotation and has proven to be a good investment.Again, I can't stress enough how much I love the artwork. Just fabulous.

This is an extremely attractive hard drive enclosure, and I liked it a lot for quite a while. Would have given it five stars for about the first year after buying it, it was my favorite of about four or five different enclosures I have used to keep old hard drives for portable storage and backup purposes.Then, when I went to retrieve it from a drawer about a month ago, it had fallen apart. The screws at the closed end of the drive -- not the end with the connection, had somehow broken the threads and it was impossible to keep the enclosure closed. The back end just dropped off, rendering the entire enclosure worthless. I did not subject the enclosure to abuse, didn't throw it and to my knowledge I did not overtorque the screws -- it was fine for about a year and worked well.None of my cheaper, less attractive enclosures have had a similar problem. I managed to get the screws to stick with a couple of drops of super glue (I didn't have to go anywhere near the drive or electronics with the glue, so that's good at least.)I am pretty disappointed in this product, I don't think it should have fallen apart. I can't recommend it in good conscience despite the attractive design.

We were not aware of Green Toys and their products, made from recycled milk jugs, but they have rapidly become some of our -- and our son's -- favorites. We like the environmental friendliness, outstanding durability and simple designs that hearken back to a more wholesome era. He likes them because they are fun.This is our boy's second experience with Green Toys, after their Ferry Boat with Mini Cars has become an indispensable bathtime accessory. He likes this one and plays with it a lot, but note that although it is rated for kids two and up, it did not make much sense to our two and a half year old at first. Unlike boats and planes and cars, he does not see rocket ships in real life and didn't know what to make of it at first. I told him it's a rocket and it's taking those little guys to the moon, and he could get that -- he knows what the moon is.Love this product, it's pretty great.

We have been using a related product -- Pampers Sensitive wipes -- for a year and a half, and have always been very happy with them. The reason why we like them is they are hypoallergenic and perfume free, which is good for our son's atopic skin.Recently we have tried this new product -- Pampers Natural Clean wipes -- and they are good quality wipes too. Pampers Natural Clean wipes are unscented, hypoallergenic and have a touch of aloe. They are good size, strong, wet (but not too wet), and most importantly they don't irritate our son's sensitive skin.To be honest, we don't have any Pampers Sensitive wipes in the house right now to do a direct comparison, but they seem very similar to us. Looking at the ingredients, the main difference between these and the Sensitive wipes is that these contain Tocopheryl Acetate (Vitamin E) as the second ingredient, while the Sensitive wipes contain Glycerin. (There are some other differences at the very bottom of the ingredients list, but the rest are the same.) If you have strong feelings about one of those ingredients over the other, that will probably be an important factor for you. I am not aware of a reason to have a strong preference of one over the other.Here are the ingredients: Water, Tocopheryl Acetate (Vitamin E), Aloe Barbadensis Leaf Juice, Disodium Edta, Citric Acid, PEG-40 Hydrogenated Castor Oil, Sodium Citrate, Phenoxyethanol, Ethylhexylglycerin, Benzyl Alcohol, Xanthan Gum, Sodium Benzoate, BIS-PEG/PPG-16/16 PEG/PPG -16/16 Dimethicone, Caprylic/Capric Triglyceride, Pentadecalactone, Dipropylene Glycol.

This is a very nice children's winter boot, and we are confident it will keep his feet warm and dry this winter. The initial field tests in the cold November rain have been very successful.We are finding this boot much easier to put on our son's feet than the Sorel boots he had last summer. Those were good too, but they were hard for us to get on his feet and easier for him to kick off. The situation is better with these boots.

I was shocked to read that they changed the formula of Grape Nuts and added soy protein. I've been buying it on subscription through Amazon Subscribe & Save for a number of years. I am obviously not a connoisseur, because I did not notice the difference.I have liked Grape Nuts, at least sort of, since I was a kid and saw the Eull Gibbons commercials on the TV. I have to admit I've always insisted on some fruit in the cereal to give it some taste -- usually I go with a banana.Grape Nuts is a simple cereal, and I do regret the change that they recently made by adding soy protein. I am inclined to suspect, as some others have suggested, that this is the result of some big agribusiness backroom deal with Monsanto. That is disappointing.But it's not the end of the world. Maybe I'm not enough of an extremist, but I am not too disturbed in the end. The taste is still good for me, and I am not very concerned about eating GMO soy (although I do have ethical concerns with some of the tactics Monsanto has resorted to in trying to put the squeeze on farmers who don't use their products).I have made my decision -- I cannot afford to spend the time and energy it takes to fight against inevitable change. I still like Grape Nuts and I'm still going to eat them. I feel a pang of regret that they did this to Grape Nuts, but I'll get over it. Still the best mainstream cereal you'll have a chance of finding on the shelf at a neighborhood grocery store.

We have been using Leveret PJs for our son for well over a year now and we are in general very happy with them. But while we loved these PJs at first, the inside of the shirt, under the embroidered dump truck design, is scratchy.Not at first, because there is a soft piece of backing fabric. But, after a few runs through the washer and dryer, that sheet started to come off, and with every new wash it comes off a little more. Without that backing cloth, the inside of the shirt under the dump truck is going to be scratchy and uncomfortable.Until now we had two pairs each of Leveret Black & Yellow Striped Pajamas and  Leveret Red & Black Striped Pajamas as our son has grown. We love the quality of those PJs, and the fact that they are 100% cotton (important because our son has atopic skin) and aren't doused in flame retardants.My wife decided to get this the last time he outgrew is old PJs, because our son loves dump trucks so much. He is so happy and proud now, and makes sure that everyone knows that he has a dump truck on his pajamas.So he loves these, and we did too at first. They are still OK now. But we can see the day coming when they won't be comfortable any more, and this will probably be after just three months or so of use.

My drink of choice at work is instant iced coffee, but this is a great change of pace. I first came across this drink in a dollar store -- same boxes on sale here. Unfortunately I don't live near that store so now I order them over Amazon.The flavor is unusual but easy to like and actually easy to get kind of hooked on. I really enjoy having one of these every so often in my 1L Camelbak bottle filled to the brim with ice and then with water. It dissolves well even in icy water. I really enjoy it.

My husband has been using this medicated powder for at least 15 years.  He uses it after every shower and swears by it.  He uses Ammens to prevent chafing, and it has never caused him any skin irritation.  He prefers the Shower Fresh scent to the original.  This is not an easy item to find in brick and mortar stores, and this is the first time that I have purchased it from Amazon.  I had been getting it from drugstore.com, but the price is comparable here or slightly better.

July 19, 2014 update:  Tonight I noticed that not only did the lotion leak into another compartment, but the lotion leaked out the bottom as well, all over the counter.  I threw it in the garbage.  If I could, I could give this item no stars at all.June 27, 2014 update:  My rating was lowered to one star because I noticed that the lotion that I put in that well just three days ago had leaked into the well next to it.  This is a manufacturer's defect.  This means that if you purchase this item, be sure to test immediately to be sure that the liquid you place into that well stays there.There are things to like about this soap caddy, which is in my front guest bathroom.  Now I can ditch the undecorated liquid soap container; the lotion well will hold about eight ounces.  The other wells are size versatile; they easily hold my large toothpaste, brush, and contact lens cleaner.  This caddy looks attractive [and not cheap] on my bathroom counter.Note that the items shown in Amazon's picture, i.e., the brush and the scrubber, do not come with the caddy.  What I do not like about this caddy is the fact that the lotion top just sits down on top of the container; it is difficult to seat and has a tendency to move.  I would have preferred the lotion well to hold 12 ounces.  Also, I think that the plastic could have been a little thicker, and the price, at $16.29, is excessive.  After seeing the caddy, I personally do not think the price should be more than $10.

The actual color of this pot, which admittedly is specified in the description as pewter, means that it is really solid very dark grey, definitely not the two-toned, mostly white pot displayed in the picture.  The diameter at the top of the pot is, by my measurements, 15 inches in diameter on the interior measurement and at the bottom only 10 inches in diameter.  There is nothing here that is functionally 17 inches; the height is only 14 and 1/2 inches.  In addition, the raised leaf pattern on the outside of the pot is entirely different from what is shown in the picture.  On the positive side, the plastic appears to be thick and sturdy.  This review will be updated once the pot has endured hot California summers and rainy to near freezing winters.

We rarely shop in brick and mortar stores and then buy the article on the internet.  In this case, however, after going into several jewelry stores and watch fix-it places with no luck, we ended up finding the watch band here on Amazon.  One nice thing included that is not mentioned in the product description is that the seller provides the two metal pins for attaching the band, helpful if you have lost or damaged one.  Of course, it is critical to know the exact mm width of the band.  This band fit perfectly, and it is priced very comparably to what we would have purchased in a watch fix-it store, had they not been out of stock.  That is, the fix-it store would have charged us $29.99 plus tax, and it would not have been leather.  My husband is responsible for the five-star rating, stating that the band is both sturdy and attractive.

My husband has owned this calculator for 15 to 20 years, and it still runs perfectly; he had me buy him a second one for convenience so he could have it handy in two rooms.  He says that this calculator is great at computing mortgage schedules and does full math calculations, i.e., square root and logarithms. It has 10 memories that retain values even when the calculator is powered off.  The calculator runs on two flat batteries that last at least six months with daily use.  His only criticism of the new calculator is that the keys are not quite as responsive as his older one.  Overall, he says that this is the best hand held calculator he has ever used, and the five star rating is his.

Amazon ran these on special about two weeks ago, and I was able to purchase two sets of the blue for about $17 total, which was a screaming deal.  They are beautiful in person; the workmanship is excellent.  I am using them on a sterling chain with my sterling silver grandchildren figures.  They would also be perfect on a sterling charm bracelet.  I am going to place these in my cart in case they go on sale again.

My husband is 72 and plays golf three to four times a week to a seven handicap and estimates that his swing speed is about 88 mph.  He is very picky about what golf balls he uses and prefers Titleist Pro V1 or Pro V1X, Bridgestone Tour 330 RX or Callaway Hex Control balls.  He played two full rounds with the TaylorMade balls, and following is his assessment.The TaylorMade ball is not as long as a pure distance ball such as a Pinnacle or Titleist Tour Distance ball.  However, the TaylorMade ball spins better than a Callaway Hex Control, spinning as well as a Pro V1X.  Regarding "working the ball", these balls "work" well with fades or draws fairly easily, comparable to a premium tour ball, such as a ProV1 or Pro V1X.  The cover appears to be very durable, like the quality of a tour ball.My husband liked best the combination of soft feel and good distance.  He noted that he is the oldest in his foursome, and he was outdriving all of the others with this ball.  I asked him specifically if there was anything that he did not like, and he said there was not.  He added that this ball was as good as any other golf ball he has ever played; yes, he would buy this ball, and the five stars is his rating.

My kitchen sink had, separately, a soap dispenser, plastic scrubber and standard sponge, so this caddy was immediately of interest to me.  It surprised me because it looks much better in person.  The plastic is thick and if it is not, is a double for Lucite.  The matte black finished parts do belie the fact that they are plastic.  The soap container holds between 14 and 16 ounces, which is great because I buy liquid hand soap in large bottles.  The caddy is a little pricey at $22, but it does look good on my new granite counter.  You can research this item online and possibly save up to three dollars on another site; however, I would still like this item priced more around $15.  I know there will be a problem with storing wet sponges in the caddy, but at least the water will no longer get all over my counter and dry sticky; it is a matter of preference, but I would rather have the mess in the caddy.  This review will be revisited as to how it wears and especially how the soap dispenser holds up.

There were two main reasons that I was interested in the Electrolux:  (1) having a lightweight vacuum and (2) a vacuum that would go into tight places.  First of all, I hate to vacuum, mostly due to having chronic pain recently diagnosed as fibromyalgia.  My husband does not mind vacuuming, but he is in his 70's and also has chronic lower back pain.We both used the Electrolux.  My husband's assessment was that he still prefers the Dyson Animal 15 he bought (without input from me) for overall use because he thinks it rolls easier and has a much longer cord (eight feet longer); he thought that the assembly instructions for the Electrolux were written poorly.  He did allow that the suction on the Electrolux was terrific.On the other hand, I much prefer the Electrolux for a number of reasons:1. Both the canister and the handle/head assembly are considerably lighter than the Dyson, making the Electrolux much easier for me to use;2. The canister is readily movable with my foot;3. The controls are all on the handle with the exception of the angle of the handle to the power head;4. I like the bright light on the power head, bright enough that I do not have to turn on room lights to vacuum;5. The vacuum handles all thicknesses of carpet without having to constantly bend over to adjust the power head, whether it was the thin guest bedroom carpet, middle grade master bedroom carpet or very thick high traffic carpet in the family room and halls;6. You can actually adjust the suction power from 1 to 3;7. It runs fairly quietly for a vacuum;8. The dust cap compressor feature works well, releases and reinserts well, even for the mechanically challenged such as myself;9. The power head glides gently across the marble tile in the kitchen, with no worry about making scratches, getting up all debris right up to the wall (the cat makes a continual mess in there with his scratching box); and10. This is the first vacuum I have ever had that would actually go under the beds.The limited warranty is impressive at five years, excluding parts of the cleaner that require replacement under normal use.  Electrolux will at its option repair or replace a defective vacuum.  Do not forget to complete the online product registration.

This is a more formal cookbook than I expected, definitely not done by Betty Crocker and not necessarily for beginners.  The recipes may be scaled back for only two people, but the dishes are just as fancy as any other gourmet cookbook, including ingredients not commonly found in my spice rack, refrigerator or pantry, like feta, fennel, curry, and saffron threads.  Many of the recipes are complicated and/or labor intensive.My husband and I eat a lot of rotisserie chicken, so I went looking for a recipe for leftover chicken.  There are two full columns of recipes in the index.  I tried the Sichuan Orange Chicken with Broccoli, altering as necessary for items not on hand, and we liked it.There are helpful notes about preparation of some ingredients.  For example, I had no idea there was a difference between wet and dry scallops and how to compensate when they are wet.  I also appreciate knowing the proper way to squeeze a lemon, and one can even flame torch crÃ¨me brulee instead of having to put it in the broiler.  These instructions are clearly written and easy to follow.  Nutritional information for some recipes is provided, although one improvement for this book would have been to include full calorie counts for each recipe, since many two person households, like ours, are watching their weight(s).

Although the color is not as pink as in Amazon's picture, these earrings are definitely rose gold and have a great shine.  I placed mine next to a rose gold ring, and they match in color.  The 5 mm size is versatile; it will work in either my top or lower ear piercing.  There is a 14K mark on the earring backs, which while on the smaller side, grip very well.  For the price, at $23.75, given the price of gold, I consider these to be an excellent purchase.January 18, 2014 update:  It took me a while to figure this out, but this is such a good price that my BFF should have a pair for her birthday.  The one thing that could be improved is the gift box because they put two stickers on it which do not come off very well.February 19, 2014 update:  Just another comment, that the length of the posts on these earrings is virtually identical to posts on my other earrings; these posts are not short.

This product is so new that it is not shown on the Rolodex site yet.  Both my husband and I have iPads, mine the original and his being the iPad2.  This stand fits both with no problem.  In fact, the stand will accommodate a device up to .8 inches (20 mm) thick.  There are five different height positions, and if necessary, the stand will lock flat.  However, the two features that I like the best are that the stand is a space saver on my credenza, and that it is very stable; whichever way I choose, my iPad would rest easily either vertical or horizontal.

The picture correctly shows what you will receive, and the dimensions are accurate.  The most important feature for me was that the nap was flat enough so that my bathroom door would go over it without catching.  That said, there is more than enough softness under foot to stand on it.  In my opinion the rug is of quality construction.  I have the rug over a Pergo floor (medium brown) in front of a sink, and the rubber backing keeps it from sliding.  Perfect!  Note that because of the rubber backing, I have learned the hard way to never launder such a rug in anything other than cold water and to just hang it up to dry versus exposing it to dryer heat.

May 28, 2014 update:  I am still using this product, but in order to stop my browsers from freezing, I ended up entirely deleting the Norton Identity Safe program, which is separate from the anti-virus program.  The identify safe program is a password program that I do not use anyway, preferring to use RoboForm instead.It is important to establish a free account with Norton before you try installing this anti-virus.  The program simply would not install, either by online or by disc, until I first established a Norton account.  Once this was done, the program installed easily either by using the disc or downloading from online.The program was installed on 3 different types of computers in the house:  a HP desktop, which is 3 to 4 years old; a Dell Pavilion laptop 1-2 years old, and a Toshiba Satellite laptop 11 months old.  The computers were loaded on November 2, so my experience has been for 20 days.  The installs go very quickly, but applying the updates takes around 5 minutes more per computer.  Note that a computer with a slower processor is going to take longer for everything, especially the full scan the first time through.  While I do notice a slightly quicker boot-up on the HP desktop, the Toshiba laptop seems to boot up much faster than it did before under Kaspersky.  The entire process takes the longest on the Dell because it has the slowest processor; it took several hours to complete the first scan (it ran overnight).So far, everything has been running pretty much glitch free on all computers.  However, in my opinion, the one feature that needs work is the Norton Identity Safe, which puts a terrible drag on the computer.  I ended up disabling it on the HP.

My cat loves Feline Greenies and has been eating them for years.  I really cannot say whether there are dental benefits because Matt just inhales them.  He is an older cat now, 12 years, and 18-19 pounds.  He is a foodie, so we watch what he eats, and he only get about 7 of these a day.  I was apprehensive about ordering this size because of what the expiration date might be, so I was pleasantly surprised to find it to be March 21, 2015 on the three packages I ordered.  Besides, the packages are resealable for continued freshness.  The price, at $2.99 including super saver shipping, is what you normally pay for the smaller (2.5 to 3 ounce) size, making these 5.5 ounce size packages a great deal.

About three weeks ago, I bought this watch to give to my 10-year-old granddaughter this Christmas, but she and her older sister will be getting the next two that I just ordered, which still should arrive in time for Christmas.  This watch is even prettier in person than in the picture.  I especially like the rhinestone markers for the hours and the fact that it has a second hand.  The reason it loses a star with me is because the watch came already running, which other reviewers have noted, and there was no gift box as advertised on the Amazon site.  Even the back side of the watch is cute, with a full Hello Kitty picture, along with the words Stainless Steel Back.  At under $5 with no delivery charge, this watch appears to be a real bargain.  This review will be updated regarding how long the battery lasts, the durability of the watch band, anything that breaks, and whether it continues to keep accurate time.December 23, 2013 update:  I did order two more watches on November 1, and they arrived on November 29.  Both of them are in perfect condition.  Let me share what happened when attempting to set the time so that this does not happen to you.  The stem is pretty fragile, and it only needs to be pulled out slightly and gently to change the time; I pulled it out too far, and the top piece came off.  Fortunately, I was able to put the top part back on.  However, note that it is way easier to wind the hands counterclockwise rather than clockwise.  My original purchase continues to keep excellent time.

This rug is everything I hoped it would be.  I have it in front of a bathroom sink with a wood cabinet below; this rug will never be exposed to water.  The extra soft texture is sublime for bare feet.  The medium grey (toward blue rather than pink) color is as represented in Amazonâ€™s picture, and this rug matches perfectly to the contour bath rug.  Note that it is very important to follow the washing instructions that indicate cold water only; I have learned this the hard way.  Also from experience, I would also suggest using a gentle wash cycle to avoid threads being pulled out of the rug and excess stress to the latex backing.  Personally, rather than try to determine what â€œlow heatâ€ means for drying this rug, since it washes in cold, I intend to hang it to air dry in warm weather.

This rug is a medium dark grey (toward blue tones), well represented by the picture on Amazon's product page, and fits well around the base of the toilet.  The fabric is very soft, and the latex backing does impede slipping, although mine is placed on carpet, which is the main reason I needed to have it.  These positives aside, the rug could be a little wider than it is.  The width is only 19 and 1/2 inches (conveniently rounded up to 20 inches in the product description); the length is okay at 24 inches.  I like the quality so well that I ordered the matching rug, which is 24x40 inches.October 28, 2013 update:  I did order the companion bath rug, and it matches perfectly to the contour rug.  Sheer luxury!

While there is a setup guide included with this mouse, plus plug and play, most of the information needs to be accessed online; I note that the Logitech site is more user friendly with Chrome rather than Internet Explorer.  The software download is a must and is easy to find on Logitech's website, but you have to search specifically on the G602 model to find everything.  After much searching, I can tell you that at present the Logitech site is not set up to register the product; this should be possible by e-mailing customer support. Online there is full information on programming the buttons, specifications, keyboard compatibility, and troubleshooting; profiles have been added for specific games.  There is a three-year limited hardware warranty on the device, but note that the Logitech site says that there are no replacement parts available for this product.  Of course this mouse is perfectly usable for regular computing; the responsiveness, wireless, and battery longevity features are above average.  For my desktop, I really like having the little receiver attachable to a cable so it can be positioned for maximum reception.  The most positive usage factor for me was that the pointer is very precise, helpful not only for regular mouse use but for some games.However, after using this mouse for gaming for over a week, I find that it has maneuverability issues for me, primarily because my hand is not large enough.  In my opinion, this mouse is more suitable for a man's hand or for a woman who has longer fingers than I do.  Lengthwise, my hand measures 7 inches from tip of middle finger to wrist; widthwise, from tip of little finger to tip of thumb outstretched measures 7 and a half inches.  Try as I might, I could not adjust to using this mouse in playing my regular games, and it is not comfortable either.  The thumb rest, while relaxing pressure on tendons on that side of my hand, just adds to the width of a mouse that starts out with a high arch, again a problem for a smaller hand.  Also because of the size of my hand, quickly and accurately reaching all of the side programming buttons with my thumb presents problems.

Back in August, Amazon ran this mill on sale for $6.66, including super saver shipping.  I had just broken my third (yes, third) battery operated pepper mill.  That is because those mills sit pretty tall, and when placed on a kitchen island, I kept knocking into them so that they ended up shattered on my kitchen's marble floor.  So, I decided to go retro with something smaller, less expensive but hopefully effective.This one had me with the 10-year warranty on the ceramic mechanism, which is stated on the tag that comes with the mill, along with only a website.  Going out to the website, under a warranty heading, there is a company address, toll-free phone number and e-mail for Swissmar, an international company with Niagra Falls, NY as the U.S. location.  However, I could find nothing on how to obtain service in the event of a problem; so I e-mailed them.  The prompt response was that they would want an e-mail explaining the problem and either the type of mill or a picture for identification.  Then they would send your e-mail to customer service, which would respond with assistance.  I would guess that you would want to keep your sales receipt as well.The ceramic mechanism works hard, meaning I would not recommend this mill for anyone with arthritis or carpal tunnel issues in his/her hands.  That said, the knob at the bottom really does adjust to whatever grind you want, whether very fine or chunkier.

At 65 and counting, if I am going to eat a meal replacement bar, the very first thing it must do is taste good.  Admittedly, KIND bars are my absolute favorite because they are way ahead of others in terms of taste as well as satisfaction.  With any meal substitution bar, it is important to read the ingredients and determine for yourself whether these fit your particular situation.  Beyond that, the Cranberry Almond bars are packed with almonds, with less of a cranberry flavor, which is sweet, but not overly so.  They weigh in at 190 calories, and they do satisfy; I use them either for breakfast or lunch.  The only quibble I have is that the bars are not only moist, but they are very sticky, making them in my opinion not suitable for eating in the car while on the go.  Recently Amazon ran these on sale at about $1.20 a bar including super saver shipping; this price is significantly better than grocery store prices.  As of this review, Amazon has dropped the price even lower; also, the expiration date is out about 13 months.

My husband and I love flavored coffees and each drink between four and six cups a day.  French vanilla is my personal favorite.  This coffee is as represented, a medium dark roast, not too heavy.  From there, however, it is difficult to find the vanilla flavor or indeed any.  I asked my husband if he noticed the flavoring, and, after another sip, he said he thought he could.  In using flavored coffees, I want to enjoy the scent as well as the taste.  From the bag and from the brewed cup, I frankly could not notice any aroma, which was a disappointment.  From the taste, there is some flavor there, but it is pretty subtle and difficult to identify as vanilla.  Similar to another reviewer who noticed little or no flavor, my shipment has a brewing date within six weeks of receipt.  There are two more bags, and this review will be updated if there is any discernible difference noted in those.  On the positive side, there is absolutely no bitterness or acidity.August 3, 2013 update:  Now that we are midway through the third bag, while the coffee is good, there really is not much flavoring.

My husband and I love flavored coffees and each drink between four and six cups a day.  Hazel nut is one of our few favorites.  This coffee is as represented, medium dark roast with a somewhat heavy hazel nut flavor.  The aromas from the bag and in the cup tend toward an almost artificial amaretto scent, so I was  surprised that the actual taste was more nutty, truly resembling hazel nut, and much more natural.  In my opinion, where this coffee really shines is as iced.  California temperatures have been 105 degrees plus for over a week, so I have been brewing this coffee and then pouring it over ice, and the strength and flavor hold up very well.  There is absolutely no bitterness or acidity.  Overall, this coffee provides a very pleasant way to start the day.

First, note that there is a significant error in the product title.  These bars are 1.41 ounces, not 2.1 ounces as stated.  This review is based upon my having for breakfast the one Think Thin Caramel Chocolate Dipped Mixed Nuts bar sent to me by the Amazon Vine Program.  My initial impression was...nuts, and lots of them.  In fact, the first two ingredients listed are peanuts and almonds; cashews are the sixth item listed.  While the bar contains sugar, it is understated, the dark chocolate on the bottom is a pleasant complement, and the bar really is crunchy.  All things considered, the bar utilizes the 190 calories well.  The thing I found the most impressive was that I had the bar at 8:30 a.m., then went out to run errands all morning, arriving home at 1:30 p.m., and I was not in an immediate hurry for lunch.  Would I buy these bars?  Yes, I would, as a substitute for breakfast, lunch, or mid-afternoon snack, but no way would I pay the current price of $2.42 per bar; about half that amount is what I would pay.

My experience with KIND bars has happened within the past two years, when I saw them in the grocery store and tried some.  They are one of my favorites simply because of the taste.  I decided to try the dark chocolate cinnamon pecan because this is a flavor that I cannot find in our grocery stores.  The dark chocolate is decadent, not too sweet nor bitter.  The cinnamon is just enough to know it is there.  I love these bars for breakfast, lunch or mid-afternoon snack, and because they taste so good, I have been able to forego candy bars and substitute these.  Price wise, at about $1.45 a bar, they are comparable to regular price in my grocery store at $1.50, although there they do go on sale once in a while for $1.25.

May 28, 2014 update:  These glasses are very sturdy.  I always place them in the top rack of the dishwasher, and so far have not broken any of them.Yes, these glasses are classified for old fashioned drinks, but they are more versatile than that.  We use them for drinking anything...milk, water, soda or juice.  I have used the Bormioli brand of glasses for years, and they are not only durable but attractive as well.  The glass in this style is clear, heavy, and will not easily tip over.  They go through the dishwasher (use the top shelf only) perfectly.  Currently, at a little over $3 a glass including super saver shipping, these are a good buy, comparable or better priced than you will find them in brick and mortar stores.  It is always a concern to purchase glass because of possible breakage, but if it happens, simply contact Amazon and use their easy, risk free, replacement or refund policy.  I have ordered these glasses twice without any incident.

May 28, 2014 update:  We have this chair positioned so that it only gets morning sun; there has been no fading, and so far Matt the cat has not deemed it necessary to use it for a scratching post.We needed to replace a 15-year old La Fuma zero gravity chair that Matt the cat has been sleeping in on the patio for the past 11 years.  This is because the La Fuma chair was a gift, and I never found it particularly comfortable.  On the other hand, this Caravan chair is very comfortable for me at 5'3" (okay, sure, my legs do not reach the floor, but my back is comfortable) as well as my husband at 6'1".  It adjusts effortlessly.  The fabric appears to be very sturdy, and the beige color, in person actually has a slightly greenish cast, which is okay with me because my other new patio chairs have light green and beige stripes.Here is additional information on the chair tag that is not presented on the Amazon product page site:  comfortable ergonomical armrests; anti-slip pads for security; finger tip locking system; and weight capacity of 300 pounds.  At $49 including super saver shipping, in my opinion this is a good value.  This review will be updated periodically according to how it wears.

We replaced worn out umbrellas and patio chairs.  I did not do my usual research and thought that Home Depot's price on a 9-foot umbrella was fairly good.  So, this is what I bought.  Hampton Bay dimensions:  106.3" (8.86') W x 106.3" D x 101.2" (8.4') H.  It has a rust-proof aluminum frame, wind vent, weather-resistant fabric (beige color), crank opening, three-position tilt, 11 pounds, and was made in China.  The cost was $97.18 including tax and a cover.  The umbrella comes with a one-year limited warranty.Then I belatedly got smart and checked Amazon and found this.  TropiShade 9 foot umbrella [108" (9') W x 108" D x 94" (7.8') H]; the cost was $69.11 including tax and super saver shipping, a difference of $28.07.  While there is no cover, this umbrella features fiberglass ribs for strength, a wind vent, crank opening, Sunbrella fabric (rust color), three-position tilt, 13 pounds, and one-year limited warranty.  What is covered: 1. Warping, splitting or rotting of wood frame poles 2. Rusting, discoloring of metal parts 3. Broken tilt mechanisms, broken cords, broken cranks.  What is not covered: damage caused from wind conditions are not covered under any circumstances.  TropiShade is a company that has been in business for 18 years; the umbrellas are made in China with some assembly in the United States.A touch comparison of the fabrics in the shades showed me that the Hampton Bay cloth was slightly thicker.  Both umbrellas will be continuously exposed to brutal summer sun, and this review will be updated regarding the degree of fading and overall wear which will inevitably occur.  As a final thought, I did call TropiShade and was advised that insofar as tipping and wind, a 50-pound, versus a 30-pound, base was greatly preferable to avoid damage to the umbrella.September 22, 2013 update:  I have downgraded my four-star rating to two stars because in the four months that the rust umbrella has been outside, it has faded horribly in response to afternoon California sun.  This review will be upgraded again according to whether the fabric deteriorates as well.June 1, 2014 update:  So far, the fabric has not deteriorated.

May 28, 2014 update:  I am not a computer geek and have very straightforward needs for a printer and do not want to spend a lot of time figuring out how to work it.  This is my own personal printer in my office, and after a year, I do love it because it never jams, loads paper very easily, and responds immediately to printer controls, whether from a Word document or from the internet.  This is a real workhorse and very dependable.We are home users of a laser printer, and our last one ran for over 20 years (actually still works but is super slow and sometimes cranky).  The Canon was appealing to us because of the brand and price, under $200 including super saver shipping, and it did not disappoint.  We know from experience with laser printers that it is important to shake up the cartridge before insertion in the printer to insure even printing.  Then this should be done about every 500 copies or eventually copies will become streaked or blurred.Initial setup is very easy when following the instructions and removing every one of the orange plastic parts.  My husband missed one and ran into error messages immediately.  Apparently this is a common issue, and Canon technical support gets five stars for promptly diagnosing and fixing the problem. Although there is an installation CD included, my husband did not use it and instead went directly to the Canon website and downloaded the latest software version.  In either case, until the software is loaded, the plug and play feature will not operate.  If you plan to network the printer to more than one computer, you will have to download the software from the Canon website to each individual computer; each download only takes a couple of minutes.  After that, interface is accomplished through your computer's print protocol and on ours was immediate and seamless.As far as the performance is concerned, printing is greased lightning fast, and the copies are crystal clear.  We tried Xeroxing some documents, and the process is very user friendly, quick, and the copies are great.  If and when we fax anything, this review will be updated.  The energy saving feature is a nice touch, shutting down the display between uses.  The printer's limited warranty is for one year; registration can be done on the Canon website.  A Canon replacement cartridge (rated 4 ½ stars) for this printer sells on Amazon for $73.15 including super saver shipping and yields approximately 2,100 copies.  Remanufactured cartridges are currently available through 4inkjets for $28.79 plus shipping, or buy two of them and get free shipping.

May 28, 2014 update:  After using this keyboard for a year, it has held up very well so far.  It is used every day for several hours.  I remain particularly impressed with the action of the keys, which is smooth, effortless, and will take rapid typing.Having worn out several of the keys on my Microsoft SideWinder X4 Keyboard in less than three years, I was happy to try this Logitech keyboard. Installation was effortless, true plug and play.  After using it for over two weeks, there are several aspects that I particularly like:1.  Depending on the light in the room, with one button I can adjust the backlighting in three ways, none, low, and high.  The blue has been somewhat difficult adjusting to because I was more used to the red in the SideWinder, which for me was clearer to see in pitch dark.  However, this down side is somewhat made up for by the flexibility to adjust for other light situations; the SideWinder offered only the option of permanent backlighting at one level.2.  The very best feature for me is the action of the keyboard, which has the lowest resistance that I have ever seen in a keyboard.  I type very fast and do a lot of daily e-mailing and regular internet browsing, and the smoothness (no sticking whatsoever) and responsiveness of the keys is nonpareil.3.  Regarding the macro keys, frankly I thought they would not be of much use to me because my gaming is not keyboard driven, but mouse driven.  However, I experimented and discovered that the macros will record any keystrokes, not just game moves.  What this means is that you can record, for example, your e-mail address and then be able to enter that with one stroke.  Think about how many times you would type out your e-mail address.  Similarly, you can record a password as well, meaning that the macros will enable you to enter your game sites with two keystrokes.  These can be done using the "recording a quick macro" instructions, which are very user friendly.  Actually, there is a large gaming software download indicated in the product sheet that you must do in order to be able to fully maximize use of the keyboard, including extensive instructions as well as a help and search index.4.  I was already using Logitech's Gaming Mouse G300 with Nine Programmable Controls (910-002358) with my SideWinder keyboard, and now I realize that the mouse is way more responsive with this keyboard.  This goes to show that if you are going to go for a particular gaming keyboard, it makes sense to pair it with the same brand of gaming mouse.Logitech warrants the keyboard to be free from defects in material and workmanship for one year from the date of purchase.  For that reason, it is helpful to register the purchase on the company's website.

A good sized castle to brick together for Minion fans with lots of fun details.  Our children love the Minions; they, like most of us romantics, dream about living in a castle, and they had great fun putting together Lego sets.  So, here's the combo of all those.There are a lot of pieces, especially small ones, so supervision might be in order for little ones.  School aged children should do allright.  These are different than Lego's, and as others have said they fit looser.  There are no decals.  Multi-level rooms and full of nifty Minion themed contraceptions, it comes across as a Minion adventure park.My girls have built Lego's Hogswart's castle, and take turns putting the pieces together, advising each other.  They build it on a smooth square of finished wood as a firm base, and when completed, lay out on the floor to dream up stories.I strongly recommend keeping all the pieces together including the box for future use and posterity(value).  A great family project- one's never too old to build castles or play Minion's!

will  anuther awfull movie that that wasted film on dogs should be the the villain's I mean I like dogs but really cats are awesome I have five cats at home I thought some day they would make a movie where the cat was the heiro and the dog was the villain but nooo... and the point that the animals can talk ugg  it would seem better if their mouths weren't moving . well bad movie I would not see if I were you!!!Note: Ah, a review from my daughter, using my Amazon address.  She's a major cat lover and feels they're poorly represented here.  Actually, I liked the movie, myself.  I thought it was pretty funny, but I'll get in trouble for saying that.  She's got to get her own address.  Woof!

I love this set it is great.  It does not take a lot of work to build it like some toys do.  I love the horse it comes with he is so pretty.  The only thing I didn't like about it was that the person can't get on the horse but I soon found out that doesn't really matter .Note: this is a review from my daughter, using my tablet, and a horse and Schleich lover.  MK

I finally got around to reading/visualizing this one to my delightful surprise.  I have graphic novels of Jane Eyre, Sense and Sensibility, and, also, Pride and Prejudice(of, course!); however, I was put off reading this one because of the caricature-like drawings- mistake.Have you ever gone to a movie expecting it to be a stinker or even just so-so, and then totally amazed how good it was?  Same here.  Grumbling about the drawings for about the first page or two, I soon was immersed in total enjoyment of this fun adaptation of Jane Ausen's classic.  There are an immense amout of frames here, full of the wonderful dialogue and cleverness we've all come to thrive on over the years; moreover, the art work flushes out with all the different angles and expressions, the emotional fun of this story.  By George, it works!I recommend, unless you are simply a total, unflexible realist, to give this book a try.  Go with the flow.  Feel the interactions, teasings and playfulness between the characters, such as Knightley and Emma.  If you've only seen the movies, you're, definitely, going to get a lot more details from this very accurate telling.  Then, go read the real novel.Good stuff.  Capital, capital!

The 2nd largest(437pcs) of the newly released 5 Lego Scooby building toys(Mystery Mansion, Lighthouse, Mystery Machine, Airplane, and Mummy's Tomb.  This one packs of lot of imaginative details in a fairly small space and includes Scooby, Shaggy, suspicious lighthouse keeper, creepy swamp creature and Daphne.  Most of the gang except Fred are provided in the Lego Mystery Mansion; Fred's included in the Lego Mystery Machine.  One can purchase the figures separately online.Here, there's plenty of spooky atmosphere for the heroes to solve the mystery using a speedboat, exploring a skull cave, finding secret compartments, discovering the treasure chest and unmasking the culprits.  Fred and Velma must be off trying to catch the car ferry.There's nice little details like cobweb and spider, swamp creature triton speer, crowbar, oar, bone, skiis, zuped up boat, flippers, key.  The lighthouse has some nifty hiding places, upper deck and red and white motif.Save the instructions, box and all the pieces for future, potential value.  Listed for ages 6-12, just help the little ones.  Our two daughters have built Lego Harry Potter sets since they were little.  They take turns, e.g. follow 3 steps then the other does 3 steps in the building instructions.Great fun, especially for Scooby-Doo lovers.

We love Scooby, have all his movies, and we enjoyed putting together Lego Hogswarts castle, so now Lego offers 5 Scooby building toys including 75901, Mystery Plane Adventures, the 2nd smallest of the new releases, 128 pcs., but still a lot of fun.3 figures, of course Scooby with goggles plus Shaggy and Headless(removal pumpkin) Horseman with sword, bi-plane with chain to dangle from, hamburger bombs, are included.  Solve the mystery, get the golden chalice, report back to the gang- most of the gang minus Fred are in Lego Mystery Mansion; Fred's in Lego Mystery Machine.  Or buy the gang separate online or just make it a Scooby and Shaggy mystery.Save the instructions, box and all the pieces for posterity- "Like, you never know what these crazy things will go for in the future!"Cute, easy to put together.  Listed for 5-12 year olds- little ones just need some direction.

The smallest, 110 pcs., and least expensive of the 5 new Lego Scooby Doo building toys.  This one includes Scooby, Shaggy and Mummy and a cute little layout of a "Zoinks, like that's creepy!" Egyptian museum exhibit.There's not much to it, but what there is, is imaginative: hidden compartment, swinging cover, unmask the mummy to discover the culprit and the jewels.  Our kids and I, having grown up with Scooby Doo, love the cartoons and the characters.  Our girls(9&11) take turns putting Lego sets together, while together.The other 4 sets: Mystery Mansion, Lighthouse, Mystery Machine, And Airplane include Scooby And Shaggy and the rest of the gang and other monsters.  Choose how much you want to spend, but be sure to save the instructions, box, and pieces for the future!

Fred's parking the Mystery Machine, in case you've bought the Lego Mansion and wonder where he is.  This is the 3rd largest, 301 pieces, 4 characters: Scooby, Shaggy, Fred and green zombie, of the latest 5 new Scooby Doo Lego building toys.  It is an excellent choice for those who don't want to break the bank buying the costlier Mystery Mansion.  You won't have the whole gang unless you buy them separately, but the Mystery Machine is sweet.They also throw in a monster tree and lots of nifty details in the van: a central command for Fred, a kitchen for the ever hungry boys including a triple decker sandwich Lego-style, flashlight, camera(Where's Velma?-> Mansion).  Remove the roof to check out the inside.  How the whole gang will fit in there is indeed a mystery.My 2 girls(9&11) love putting these together, taking turns and carefully examining and following the instructions.  Save the instructions, box and all the pieces for the future since these sets go out of circulation and can be worth something later.Fun set, nice colors, rolls along.

For Scooby and Lego lovers both, here we have another 'castle' with lots of fun creepy details and imaginative design.My girls(ages 9 & 11, now) love Scooby Doo and also enjoy building Lego castles.  Over the years, we've collected and put together Lego Harry Potter sets to create a wonderfully involved and fairly good sized Hogswarts with all the characters and creatures.  This mansion with 860 pcs. is good sized, not up to the later Hogswart's castles immensity, but still over a foot tall with 3 main sections that show you front  and back going ons and lots of moving parts.Lego offers their interpretation of various monsterous obstacles for the gang, e.g., man eating plant("Feed me, Seymour!"), ghost, vampire, Black Knight, coffin, webs, evil looking pumpkins.  Solve the mystery, find the treasure, unmask the culprits!The Mansion features a nice purple accent, movable chambers and plenty of cool accessories: ax, magnifying glass, ball and chain, Velma and her camera, food itiems for you know who, map, bat and of all things, a motocycle with sidecar.  7 characters are inclulded.  Yes, Fred's not there- he's parking the Mystery Machine(see review for such),  This is very typical for Lego to not include all the characters in one set.  There are 5 new Scooby Doo Lego building toys including Lighthouse, Airplane, Mummy, Mystery Machine and Mansion. the largest.The way we put it together is to lay it out on a board, follow the directions(of course!), and my daughters take turns putting the pieces together.  They're very good at it.  Once you've done a few of these, you get quite use picking out the various cuts and colors and orientating them correctly. It's quite satisfying seeing the creation grow.  Of course, you'll also know who the crooks are.Super fun, not cheap, and if they take it out of circulation, like Harry Potter, the prices skyrocket if there's a demand(make sure you save the instructions, the boxes, and keep all your pieces together!)  Since we're big time Scooby Doo fans, we've bought all 5.  "Like, that's a lot of extra cheesy-cheese pizza's."  Enjoy.

For Scooby-Doo lovers, this soft sided lunchbox, made by Thermos but without a thermos, has enough room to hold lunch and a small water bottle.Our girls like the cute, all around the container, colorful design with the Gang crammed into the vehicle heading out to solve a mystery.  The plastic handle is padded, and the box zips open without problem.  Best of all, of interest, no matter how you view this lunchbox, Scooby's always smiling at you!Overall, a nice box.  There's also a metal Scooby one offered on Amazon, too, however, this one doesn't clang if you bang it.

Larry Buster Crabbe is at it again, now as Buck Rogers of the 25th Century!  Simple, basic, Art Deco'ish fun, if you like old time movie serials, or Buster, you  won't be disappointed.Our family discovered recently the nifty entertainment of these old cliffhangers.  Good guy vs. bad guy, fist fights, adventure, budget but often interesting sets, these serials offer non-complicated action that our children love.  Here, the dapper, well built(Olympic Swimmer) and ever affable, Buster Crabbe plays Buck, frozen in time along with his young friend, Buddy, only to be discovered in the 25th century- now ruled by a despot, Killer Kane.Having watched the immensely enjoyable, Flash Gordon series, this one was less popular with less imaginative sets and situations; however, it still delivers plenty of fun.  My kids think it's simply an imitation of Flash: Ming the Merciless=Killer Kane, Dale Arden=Wilma Deering, Professor Huer= Docter Zarkov, Buddy=?Happy(FG trip to Mars), Clay People= Zugs(less interesting), and spaceships that sound like noisy fans with spewing sparklers.Only 12 chapters here, but the print overall is good.  Apparently, since the audience wasn't as enthralled with Buck Rogers as Flash, the producers gave up on it and returned with the next show being, FG Conquers the Universe.  I bet Killer Kane, I mean Ming returns as the villain.  (Killer Kane reminds me of a Spanish matador while Ming the Merciless, of Fu Manchu)Buster Crabbe won an Olympic Gold Medal for swimming.  He married his college sweetheart, and seemed to really enjoy his roles.  His friendly, go to it attitude and enthusiam is quite appealing.Get your popcorn and every Saturday night, gather the family together for Family Movie Night, and get ready for some swashbuckling good times with Buck, Wilma and Buddy.

For Catwoman lovers, like our 11 year old daughter, this thin and smallish soft cover book offers an interesting story with colorful pictures and a few twists.Our daughter wanted this story, but oh my goodness, the price!  I quess it's a collectors' piece.  She cherishes it and keeps it with her favorite, special things.  Definitely, a birthday or Christmas item.

Great soft sided bag for our child's full sized 6 string acoustic.  She's 9 and loves the multiple pockets.  It zips up easily.  The zipper and material appear durable.  One can use the handle or the back pack straps(It's about as big as she is!).Nice case, decent price, for storing one's guitar or hauling it around.  I think I'll get one for myself.

A not half bad traditional styled Western about a man about to be hung but set loose only to be hunted by a rich gamesman for the sport of it.Yes, it the old classic scenario, set in the mountains and forest of the old West.  It's a low budget affair, but they make good use of interesting camera angles and pretty good editing and scenery.  The hero while trying to save his family is thrown in jail to be hung after killing a baddie.  A rich old hunter and his martial artist lacky set him loose to be hunted.The acting can be a bit stiff, and some of the forest chase scenes repetitive, but over all it puts together a decent action flick with even a martial arts fighting scene.The hero does meets a single woman, who helps him, while out in the woods, so there's a touch of romance suggested.  Overall, it's a clean flick, really no language, sex, only a very, very brief bathing shot of nudity, and the violence is not overly gratuitious or bloody.  At the start of the film, there is child endangerment.  Probably rated PG-13.Also, called A Good Day to Die.

First, if you're top priority is cost, but you still want a decent phone, tablet, "phablet", and don't want ot deal with the "usual suspects" of vendors and contracts, this Blu Life 8XL is 5 star material, and look no further, at least for now.  Besides the great price, I like it for it's size(I prefer the larger display), long lasting battery(although, it does take it's time fully charging), stylish lean look, and easy to use functionality.I'm not a phone expert or a techie, but I've done such research, and messed around with this phone.  They've enlarged the screen to 5.5" which works for me and my middle age sensibilities, but hey, my kids like it too.  It may be larger and heavier than some, but it sure is thin at 7.7mm.  There's a pretty good size white base, and the camera protrudes out a bit so it doesn't lay smoothly flat on one side.The cameras are up to par with most phones, hold them steady, allow a moment to adjust to the light.  The volume plays loud, and the brightness excellent.  The screen responds quickly  to light touch.  (My kids love the Voice Google).I'm not a gamer, but I've read complaints that it's slow.  For my everyday needs and for basic kid games, there's plenty of storage, expandibility and speed.  It's easy to install the Simm or SD cards.  To fully charge the battery takes a couple of hours.  Volume and on/off buttons on the side.  It comes with a basic display and case protecter.Overall, it appears solid enough.  I've read professional reviews saying the material and workmanship is cheap.  All I know, it works for me, all the main bells and whistles, and BLU makes it affordable.  Affordability is freedom for me.

A not half bad 1950's 12 chapter serial that does its best with a low budget by using pretty good actors, especially Phyllis Coates, and some tried and true Republic Pictures cliffhangers.I discovered the fun of movie serials in the last year.  The kids and I love to sit around on a Saturday night for pure, good guy vs. bad guy in exotic or unusual locations and stunning, "How will they survive?" cliffhanging escapism.  Some of favorites: Spy Smasher, Perils of Nyoka, Tiger Woman, Flash Gordon, and the one this one styled after, Jungle Girl.Serials are on their last leg here in the 1950's, but you'll still get a good fist fight, although not quite up to the Golden Age of Republic fights; jungle setting with some stock animal footage, and a cliffhanger with dynamite, monster(giant crayfish), gorilla( a always love a man in monkey suit), crocs, bullits in the back, etc.The weak spots are the repetitive bad boss/scientist stays the whole time in his office while his cronies report back to decide next course of action; his demise is anticlimatic as is the ending, the giant crayfish is totally lame, but this is the fifities and giant insects and creatures were in; stock footage and I believe some original Jungle Girl shots/ vine swinging were used.  Also, the quality of the film, although fine, is a bit dark.The good points: Phyllis Coates, the consumate, up to any scene, actor is always watchable.  I liked her as the first year, no nonsense, tough Lois in Superman.  Here, whether being held by a giant lobster claw or tied up awaiting the crazy gorilla, or standing and pretending to watch giant crustaceans, she acts with total realism; moreover, she's famous for her screams.  Her Panther Girl is no whimp, frequently rescuing hero(finally gets to play a hero- Myron Healey), she also rides an elephant, swings on the vine, wrestles alligators and a lion(while wearing a headdress).  Only a couple of times does she get knocked out.Overall, not bad if you really like these old time serials, Ms. Coates, or late night, cheesy,1950 style monster movies.

The Sony DSCHX90V/B offers what I've been looking for in a digital camera: 1. Compact for travel, 2. Great Features 3. Big Optical Zoom w/o big lens.  Why use a digital camera anymore when you've got your Smartphone?  For me, I want better pictures with optical zoom and good stabilization for those faraway shots.  Add to that WIFI and GPS, why do I need a phone?  It's just a distraction from capturing a beautiful, moment in time, piece of life.Of course, I'm exaggerating, but sometimes I just want to be totally in touch with the shot and nothing else.  I know basic camera works, I'm no pro.  I have gone through the reviews, talked to photo-freaks, played around with this tiny, really loaded piece of equipment, and have grown to love it.  So, here's my very unprofessional take on Sony's latest.Out of the box, you get a ~4'X2"X 1-1/2" , little more than 1/2#( with battery and card) camera; small battery, plug/cable, wrist band, simple instruction guides including WIFI.  The basic set-up is simple- use the Sony Play Memories App to connect to Smartphone or tablet and settings at will.  Actually, one uses the scroll wheel(on rear of camera) for menu and settings, somewhat intimidating at first because it's quite exhaustive, but I think that's a good thing.  There's a Fn(function) button for 12 settings, e.g. ISO(80-3200 automatic or manual- I usually use auto)), picture style, drive mode, etc.  On-off button on top with snapshot button.I absolutely love the high resloution, electronic viewfinder- it's good sized, and finally gives one something to look at out in broad daylight!  The 3" tilting LCD, that turns up and touted for 'Selfies', allow 3 seconds to take the picture.  It's not touchscreen but its cool.  Video shooting maximum at 1080X1920 pixels.  The GPS pinpoints where your picture took place.  The camera fits in my pocket, no problem, or better yet, buy the Sony case that's made for it, and flips open nicely with snaps and gives your camera a little protection.  Set the aperature and shutterspeed via the scroll wheel or one can use the control ring around the lens.  It moves smoothly without a sound.Now, what about the pictures:  the focus at almost any speed is almost instant.  The color is sharp, brilliant and no 'noise' until above ISO 800.  What surprises me is the stability.  I get great resoultion even without a stand with hand only looking thorugh the viewfinder- like the good old days.  I hold it close and tight to my face.  Optical zoom to 30X, Dig. to 60X.Here's my grades; Size- A; LCD- A for flip, B in general, lacks touchscreen(too small); Features- A, especially the pop-up viewfindfinder-A+; Autofocus-B;  Connectivity-B; Zoom- A(absolutely love the size); Operations/Learning to Use- B(I struggled initially with the menu).  Noise control-B; Stability- A(amazing for size and power).Overall, this is my dream camera that meets my needs of small size, especially for travel, with max pixels and sharp images, stability, super optical power and a lot of bells and whistles.

You have to like these monster machines.  They look fierce, make lots of noies and have moving parts.  Matchbox designed a rescue chopper that flies by being handheld and using one's imagination and offers a cool and a few tricks.A good sized monster, one turns the power with a small switch that allow off-on-demo.  Two circular props turn(harmless); a water cannon propels 6"water"(plastic) bullets in rapid succession by button(harmless), and they include a Matchbox car that the chopper can hook on to or carry inside its body- it can hold three small ones.Looking like a prehistoric bird, the "mouth" opens up to allow the car to drive all the way through.  A nice design with lots of details, it's fun to fly aorund picking up stranded Matchbox vehicles with its talons or transporter hook or heading out to the Sahara(sandbox) for a resuce mission.  It fits on Matchbox's 'Rescue Headquarters'- not included.Runs on 3- AA batteries, nicely included.  It makes helicopter sounds with background communication.  Cool itemVery easy to operate right out of the box.

Smaller and more compact with a fairly strong output, the Holmes True HEPA air purifier will adequately filter a typical bedroom or single living space.We own several other air purifiers including Energy Star germguardian which I really like for its narrow configuration, UV mode and easy to carry hand slot;  the Fellowes Plasma TRUE is easy to use, works well but does not have the UV or timer function on our model and there's no easy way to carry it.The Holmes model has the advantage for its small size, but its heavier for its size.  It blows with sufficient force and is adjustable for time and force.  The twin filters remove easily, and there's no problem with operating it right out of the box.  I wish they would have put a handle or insert to make it better to carry around.  I think it's a noisy at high speed.Overall, it's good for a tight spaces.

The Teach Yourself Instant series are my favorite way to prepare for a trip to Europe.  They are  well organized and only require a short time every day- consistency makes the day.  I have studied Italian, French, Greek and now German.  They absolutely allow me to communicate the basics in just about any situation, and make my vacations much more fun and interesting.Definitely buy the book with the tape.  You need to hear the sounds, over and over.  I'm old fashioned and don't mind using a tape.  Whatever method you do use, success comes with consistent practice, mostly hearing and speaking.  This book starts with a weekly dialogue, list of vocabulary, very lean and basic grammer, a memorization piece, hearing and speaking practice and a written test, which amazes me that I can do what it asks at the end of each week.They also include words and phrases that you can cut out(I just leave them in) and practice frequently.  Follow the steps faithfully, and you too will be amazed.  The 400 words they give you and the basic structures is enough for simple travel.  If you want more get their beginner course, but have fun with it and enjoy using it- it works!

This lightweight, stainless steel B&D toaster performs well, designed for various sized toast and bagels.This one stands slightly taller with wider toasting slots for English muffins or bagels.  There's a simple clean-out trapdoor on the bottom for the crumbs.  The temperature knob turns up to 7, and they feature 3 function buttoms for Bagel, Frozen and Cancel.  So far, it works great.Like all toasters, it gets hot.  There's no plastic element or cover to it, so keep little hands away.  It toasts fast and looks nice.  I'll put it next to my other B&D power tools!

Black and Decker offer this lightweight, stainless steel, counter top oven to cook your 12" pizza of choice.  The set-up is easy, and the cooking is fast.Basically, a high temperature toaster oven, this one delivers heat from above and below.  You need that to get a crispy crust.  We've travelled to Italy, and enjoy the stone oven cooked pizza they serve as the best in the world.  One needs high heat and some experimentation with the ingredients to create something familiar to that style.I actually prefer using a cooking stone over this unit whether in an oven, grill or a specifically made unit.  Here, they feature a ceramic insert which is fine and easy to clean.  What this has as it's advantage is the ablity to cook many different things besides pizza including cookies, frozen snacks, pot pie, lasagna and frozen pizza.  The instruction booklet shows temperatures(375F up to 600F), food item, recommended bakeware(their tray or oven safe cookware) and cooking times.It cooks very well and fast.  It's imperative to preheat before cooking.  The pizza, if the dough is made right, has a nice crispness.  Careful with the machine because it gets quite hot on the outside.  Let it cool and clean the tray in the sink or dishwasher, wipe down crumb tray.My quick and good pizza dough(for thin crust): use the instructions for cooking pizza on the back of a packet of Pizza Crust Yeast except I use a little more sugar and only about 1/5 of the packet of yeast; split the dough in half, and using a rolling pin, roll it out very thin.Overall, this B&D unit is great for cooking other stuff, fast and easy, not just pizza. During a party, while the ovens are busy, we can use this unit to cook appetizers, or cookies, as well.

Travelling to northeast Italy, always like a map even with a gps, this Marco Polo 1:200000 does the job.  It's held in a laminated cover that allows it to fold out and back again without getting all messed up and wrinkled.There's a index book attached and a small kilometer/time sheet showing distances between the major cities.  They feature their Mark It stickers/arrows so one can place them and find them easily on important spots, e.g. the kiddoes want to go to Gardaland.  It's listed, in very small letters on the map right next to Lake Garda where it should be.  Place the sticker, open the map, find it instantly.It's highly detailed including interesting tourist destinations- the index takes a minute to get use to it- multilingual with a few maps of the major ciites.  With Venice, you'll need a magnifier or hawk eyes to make out the streets- pick up a local map when there.  Overall, this is probably the best map obtainable of the region before you go.  Be prepared and happy travels!

For those of us who love these old time serials(way before my time), this one offers everything one could desire: atmospheric setting, lots of action, 15 chapters, thrilling cliffhangers and a pretty good mystery to solve.  Good guy vs. bad guy, entertainment for entertainment's sake only, and besides a good mystery, there are a few catch you off guard twists.Linda Stirling, queen of the serials(our girls love her in"Tiger Woman") and Richard Bailey, I think he does a decent enough job as a amiable hero, head to Mystery Island where Ms. Stirling's character's father/scientist goes missing- kidnapped by one of the 4 owners of the island(which one is it?  Or is it someone else?), who's able to transform himself into an ancient pirate as his disquise.  His plan: force the scientist to create a radium machine that can be used for...world dominion?!The stuntmen/woman do a super job- crashing over tables, diving on each other, flipping around the room.  There's never a bruised, swollen face or scraped knuckles, and even though there's a fair amount killing- there's never any blood.The chapters last about 16 minutes or so, and always include a great fight scene, and of course, a cliffhanger.  Yes, they can be a bit repetitive-best not to watch back to back to back.  Save it for the weekends.  Our kids love watching these.  We have two daughters, and they really enjoyed this one.  Linda Stirling is no sit on the sidelines femme in distress.  She fights, shoots, rescues, flies and is resourceful.

What if we could interact with all sorts of magical creatures(MC)?  Such is the gift of this book's heroine, Pip Bartlett.This 184 page children's chapter book with a few B&W drawings of the creatures is, in my opinion, fun and easy to read.  It showcases Pip's adventures with the unepected.  She stays with her Aunt, while parents are away, a MC vet at the Cloverton clinic for MC, makes a friend and attempts ot solve the mystery of the Fiery Fuzzles.  There are a lot of "Terrible" chapters, but everything is in good humor.My 2 daughters, ages 8 & 11, were so-so about the story.  "I like the cover," the oldest says. "And I like magical creatures...""Me, too."  Says my youngest."But, I dont like that the unicorns have horns that are weapons."  (The book says "the purest weapon in the natural world.")"It's more of a boy's book," says the youngest.  "The creatures are for fighting."Like Grim, a "dangerous predator."  says the oldest.  "Even the duck(emerald duck) has feet for fighting."So, I guess the creatures aren't cute enough; although, our girls play with Batman and Spiderman toys as well as Barbies and Calico's.  Go figure.  They give it a lukewarm maybe 3.Well, I like the concept, and it's silliness.

A basic chapter book that explores Emma Perez' desire to get on the news.120 pages, 14 chapters and Emma's quick, journalism tips with simple dialogue and expressive B&W drawings.  There are a few Spanish words(Que pasa, por favor, Que gracioso, Estoy famosa, ect.) and a lightweight tale of 8 year old Emma's investigation.Our 8 year old liked the gato, Luna, but zipped right through the story in a few minutes.  She said she would read another if the cat's in it, but otherwise, it was too basic for her reading level and interest.  It states for grades 2-5, and, of course, every child reads at different levels; however, I think this fits more into early chapter book.Over all, it's a cute looking reader with smiles and silliness.

Made of cloth with internal spring, this is a very realistic looking and effective turkey.Made in China(of course), once you release the belt snap around it, it springs open, and is ready to be placed on a two piece metal rod.  Position the head and body for the look you want: breeder, looker, or feeder.  You can twist the head in different directions.  The cloth is cut to make it look like fluffing up of feathers.It's large with that beaver-like turkey tail, lightweight and easy to package back in the container.  The kids love it.  In our backyard it scares the dickens out of our chickens.  Amazingly, a group of turkey vultures, which I have never seen near our home before in 17 years, landedand marched about our yard.  They're very similar looking to turkeys- necks and beaks are longer.Fascinating product, should last if put away when not in use.

This autobiography takes one into the bleak and dark existence of North Korea, to escape, redemption and to the abundance of western culture, and it's own sense of soullessness; however, it definitely rings of hope.Starkly and plainly written, the short chapters flow quickly, starting around 1990 to present days.  Growing up, patriotic and loving towards their leader, and taught hatred for the West, the harshness of survival during unrelenting famines force the boy to survive by any means, learn to fight, and eventually, like many, try to flee the country via China.Fascinating, rivetting and sad all in one, the tale brings an undestanding of the day to day life of North Koreans.  He was fortunate to escape where many didn't.  He found meaning in his life through Christian love.  The story finishes with an epilogue of his current life, his success through education and persistence, and he talks about how he still finds Western culture strange and about moral dilemmas which he still struggles with and, in some ways, we all share.

A large, sturdy, water and ice proof cover great for protecting patio furniture for the winter.Our winters are pretty harsh, ice, snow, wind and cold.  Usually, I drag in our patio furniture.  This flexible cover suits well our round table and four chairs.  It's quite huge and well made.  The ties are strong and durable, and the material unlikely to tear.  Fold it up and pack it away for the summer in its simple case with handles.Brass gromets and waterproof sewn seams.  They include cord and cord locks with basic instructions.  Overall, just what we needed- large, strong and simple to use.

OK, ask me why, a DC Super 'Villain' Hall made to confront the Super Friends, appeals to my kiddoes.My two elementary aged girls like this plastic contraption.  It comes with Lex Luther and features an elevator the raises and a snake that pokes out at the base as the red disk(used in many of these Imaginext creations).  Turn the disk at the top with or without Lex's help and presto!, the eyes open up and an eery yellow light from each orb flickers and comes on(turns off automatically).  A great effect in the dark  A speargun rotates around and gently propels the spears by pushing button.  A smaller, curly snake slithers down a tree side pole and a trap comes down on unsuspecting superhero.Our girls pretend it's a video game.  They use their other figures, Batman, Robin, etc. to take turns trying to break into the fortress without getting hit by spears or caught in the trap.  They play against each other, and seem to have a lot of fun making up games.  They already own two Imaginext Batcaves, a Spiderman lair, Joker lair, and, they're favorite, Catwoman- so not just for boys!It sits about a foot high, all plastic, and my first impression was, too basic- they're not going to be interested.  Well, you never know.

Place your devise on this hard plastic, portable desktop.  An insert allows it sit upright, or one can rest their laptop(or netbook, as in my case) directly on top.  Cushion wristpads lay in front, and a mouse pad to the right.  Beneath, two light and fluffy pads provide comfort for the thighs with a slight tilited angle towards you..A lightweight unit with a handle, I find it most useful in the living room or out on the patio.
