One could use it as a passenger; however, its size limits it if commuting, unless you're absolutely dedicated to toting it along.  It appears sturdy and durable.  I like the wrist pads for positioning, but others might not.

Dream, fantasy or allegory, take your pick, Scottish based, Kristy Logan's debut novel evokes a sense of emptiness in a mystic, but not quite fairytale world.Nicely writtten in almost a prose-like style, the chapters flow together with simple but unique descriptions.  Each chapter named after a character with the heroines, Callanish, a "gracekeeper" and North and her bear, the circus performers, the main characters but intertwined with others.The images focus on the water and death, to a degree, and the tale rings with overtones of darkness and lonliness.  It's not particularly graphic but instead, suggestive and threatening.  Don't get me wrong, there are light moments, and I enjoy the descriptive artwork, but I beleive the story drifts along too much in a fog.  I could not grasp and hold on to any of the characters.  They exist too far out, in never neverland, for me to relate to them.In practical terms(per my humble opinion): 2 stars for story, 3 for setting, 3 for characters, 5 for writing, and covers are pretty much meaningless(unless it's a really good story!)- 3 1/2 stars, give it 4 for good debut effort.

The Purell Advanced Instant Hand Sanitizer makes an useful, pump delivered unit that's not too large but still holds a sufficient amount.This plastic unit holds 450ml (a little less than a pint) of sanitizer.  It easily installs on a clean smooth surface.  Simply apply 3 sticky strips to the back of the base, press and hold it on the wall for a moment and then leave for an hour to adhere before adding the top fluid container.  Press the grey front to deliver the sanitizer.  Rub hands together.  Easy-peasy.It gives out the familiar Purell, alcohol-type, smell.  Cool and refreshing.  Hopefully, it still kills the germs.  Our rule of thumb is to hand wash as the main source of cleansing.  Don't drop it or it'll break.This one's great for out of the way places, e.g., in our barn or near the chicken coop before we get back to the house for a proper handwashing.  It might serve well on camping trips or in out of the way places(from sinks) in the home or office.Easy set-up, holds a fair amount, reasonably priced and easy to fill.  We make good use of it.

Fun, nostalgic, serial entertainment from the wartime(1940's), offering 12 episodes in the deepest, "darkest jungles" of South America.First, you must have a inkling for watching these oldtime chliffhangers.  They're made on a low budget, corny, and repetitive.  If, like me, you enjoy pure escapist adventure with lots of stuntwork and romantic, imaginery settings and simple good guy vs. bad guy, then, Perils of Darkest Jungle, aka, The Tiger Woman is for you.Amiable and good to the core, Allan Lane's character goes to the jungles of South America to discover why oil men and local tribesmen are being murdered.  He gains the trust of the Tiger Woman, the region's jungle queen(although white) and soon they're battling greedy baddies.  The episodes run about 15 minutes or so(longer in the first one) and always include a good fight and a "Did they die?" cliffhanger.Linda Stirling, model turned movie serial queen, does a super job.  She's elegant and tough.  Her acting's a bit stilted but she's ready for action and mixes it up with the best of them.  The first crook she fights, she does judo on him and takes him down; another one, she lifts him over her head, spins him around and tosses him.  She rides, shoots, punches, saves the day, and manages to do all that while wearing an outfit that looks like it should come from the "Kit Kat NightClub" in Manhatten: short skirt, gloves, cat hat with ears and hair, coiffured perfectly.  Interestingly, this was her first serial, and she's well known for these, and when she finished her last, she pretty much retired to family life and went to college for a degree and eventually teaching.Even with a small budget, the editing and acting is fine.  The stuntmen and woman are excellent.  They excel at horsebackriding, fisticuffs, and falls.  It's absolutely amazing watching these artist dish it out- crashing over tables and through doors, dropping off cliffs after being bloodlessly shot, and it's in every episode.  They, definitely, took pride in their work- I wonder how many injuries they had?They use a few background mattes and do shoot a fair amount of outdoor scenes.  You wonder on each episode, what cliffhanger this time: firepit, explosives, waterfall, crushing elevator, etc.  And, of course, how they escaped, to be seen on the next.Obviously, no sex, blood, or language, but there's plenty of killing.  The bullet hits them; they grab their chest; fall off cliff.  There's even capital punishment- a murderer being dropped into a firepit/volcano after dancing native girl gives the sign to cut the rope.If you need CGI, complicated characters and story, look elsewheres; otherwise, grab your popcorn, turn down the lights, and let your inner kid travel to dangerous Perils of Darkest Jungle and Tiger Woman.
My daughter loves her monkey family!They came in perfect condition!

Moisturizes but have not noticed any great lip plumping or youthful effect.We received this product without the wand, and based on that(no wand) provided this review.  It hydrates well, and is non-irritating,  More of a gloss than a lip-plumper(again maybe the wand does something, hopefully not just inflame your lips!).  I cannot say it performs better than much cheaper products used on a day to day basis.The ingredients and brand reputation appear good, but the price is limiting.  Buy the wand???

Good size(24X35"), colorful and laminated, it makes a nice wall hanging for the kid's room.Our last paper map became shredded with time and use.  No worries here, and they include a sheet of 56, small stickers: I went on a trip to..., I want to visit..., I've been here!, I want to go here!, My favorite museum, theater, train ride, vacation, etc. that can be placed over, say... Italy, Ireland or Malawi.I believe they list all the countries of the world, but the map is otherwise nonspecific and not detailed.  It's fun and colorful showing typical representations of that part of the world.  4 small metal eyelets allow for easy hanging.

Need a strong tire mount for your trailer that's quick and easy to set-up?  Here it is.There's really nothing to the Extreme Max.  It uses heavy duty clamps/U-bolts, plates and curved carrier.  Determine where you want your spare, front or middle of the trailer(make sure you have enough clearance if front mounted for sharp turns; for middle mounted, make sure tire does not contact road during bumps or potholes.), then follow the simple instructions and bolt it on.Fits 4,5 and 6 lug wheels up to 16 1/2", and trailer tongues up to 3" wide and 5" high.I love and use frequently my 6X10' trailer for hauling everything.  Now, I have a place to hold the full-sized spare tire that came with it, but had no place to put it, when I bought the trailer.

An excellent but not overwhelming scent from Paris, France that works, even for those, like me, who rarely use a cologne or eau.How to describe the fragrance?  Yes, I suppose wood, forest, fallish, spring-like(oh, boy), masculine, although lightly so and not reeking through all one's clothes and closet or house.  I find it refreshing in small amounts.  My wife sprays the air and walks through it.  Hmm.Regarding the masculine aspect, it states "pour home".  "Homme" is man... like hombre, macho hombre.  And "Rochas" I believe means rock(s).  I think that's manly, too.  Then why for goodness sake, did my wife confiscate my bottle of 'Eau of Rocks for MEN'?  She likes a somewhat more masculine perfume/cologne/eau/whatever, and this one appeals to her.  Ok.Unique appealing scent, nice bottle, not cheap, but it will last, and it's from Paris, France.

A miniseries that sounds terrific- mystical, romantic, adventuresome, and lots of special effects- but, at least for me, turns out kind of off beat and boring.Hallmark puts out this multicasted, fantasy-adventure with pretty good special effects and a story that mixes fairytales and various strange kingdoms from another dimension with everyday New York City reality.  The heroine's a waitress; her Dad's a janitor and they cross paths with a Prince turned into a dog, mean Stoogelike trolls and other creatures from another 'Kingdom'.  It's good vs. evil stuff, and it sure must look good on paper, but I have several reservations about the whole thing.First, I found the characters not particularly interesting to a point that I cared about them(very important to make a story watchable).  Most of the humor is kind of sour and repeated, especially with the trolls.  This is not a family friendly film for little ones in the room.  It's Hallmark, no blood or swearing, but there's killing, piking, threatening no end and a fair amount of sexual innuendo.The storyline does pick up after the first few episodes, and is helped with some romantic bantering and interaction with hero and heroine; moreover, there are parts that are amusing.  Finally, there are some very good actors here and excellent sets and backdrops with castles and outdoor shots.Overall, I wouldn't watch it again, and I know there are tons of positive reviews, and I'll get blasted for my lukewarm one, but what can I say.  A nice travelogue through mystical kingdoms, turn off the sound and ignore the characters and story, and I'll simply enjoy the scenery.

This two step toothpaste, plaque remover/whitener worked very well for my teeth; however, my wife, who suffers from chronically stained, maybe genetic oriented, teeth did much less so.My teeth plaque like crazy: so I brush, rinse, fluoride, waterpick, multiple dental cleaning just to stay on top of it.  I'm willing to try a two step process, twice a day, and stick to it.  It definitely made a difference: less build-up, more white.  My wife felt an initial surge of encouragement the first few days, but then felt nothing else happened.There's a certain potency or, may I say, stinging to the cleaning process, but a good rinse at the end with warm water remedies that.  May be too strong for sensitive teeth.  Overall, effective, and I like the way it makes 'my' mouth feel.  Keep it away from children.Clean teeth are happy teeth!

Grace, the latest and greatest AG, and she is appealing, takes an unexpected trip to Paris.  Ooh, la, la, it's not quite what she wanted at the moment, but, come on, it's Paris for goodness sake.The story's a bit tepid at times, but one does get to learn some French and hear about a few sights.  Basic French is provided with lots of pastry and food  terminology in the glossary- macaroon, Napoleons, Ã©clair, etc. C'e bon!  Our girls, ages 8 & 11 like the dog, Bon Bon.  Our 8 year old likes the book, but prefers others with more adventure.  She favors Samantha, Josephina, Kit and Addie.No pictures, nice cover, about 190 pages of fairly easy reading, nothing too stressful or threatening, with the fun of looking up the French words.  The author apparently travelled to France with her grown daughter for the research.  That's nice.This is the new AG of the year- maybe a movie is forthcoming?

These three colors, green, blue and red, of dry erase markers, go on and come off easily. One can keep track of remaing ink and the cap stays on solid.Our children use a lot on several different white boards for writing, math and drawing.  Sometimes they like their work so much we're not permitted to erase their creations for months(that's why the extra boards).  On white background, the colors stand out, and we're able to erase them, even the red, without much ado.

A nice looking polyester material that has reinforced eyelets and is easy to install.6'X6' and with enough weight to keep it from sucking in or flapping out.  It doesn't tear and stands up to cleaning.  My wife prefers it as a liner, which we use it as, along with a cloth, decorative curtain.  No stains or strong smells.Overall, works for us, reasonably priced.

Imagine Jane Eyre as a bear.  Ursula the new governess comes to the Vaughn estate to teach their cute cub; however, secrets abound and all is not as it seems.Katherine Coville takes off wonderfully with a classic Victorian-type tale of mystery, sinister threatening forces, romance and enchantment.  I found myself forgetting frequently that these are bears, only to be reminded by interjected words such as, paws, fur, ect.  Humans exist in this story, too.  That's where the enchantment and fairytale realm enters with the likes of a sarcastic, teasing mirror-mirror or, of course, the well known blond girl of Three Bears fame and others.Very well written, with short chapters that fly by and always end with one wanting to read more.  Actually, I'm  having to share the book with my 8 and 11 year old daughters.  Well, I know the book is really written for them. A shame, not really, because I'm reading it, too.  I just have to sneak in to get it.This book has lots of great vocabulary and a classic but fun style.  My kids are voracious readers and eat this stuff up.  They've read all the Harry Potter books, Jack and Annie books, Little House on the Prarie, Alice in Wonderland, WIzard of Oz and just about every other type of young reader and many of the Classics that are out there.It may not be the taste of some, but, one must admit, it is well crafted, and a big thumbs up from our family.P.S. Any book that uses the word Stygian to describe darkness(I haven't seen that word since my days of reading Edgar Rice Burroughs' books) has my vote.

What a great device to quickly mount on a door or window and produce an instant alarm or chime on opening.This small handy-dandy alarm took me <5 minutes to unpackage, read the instructions and stick up!  It runs on 4 watch-like batteries, included, and sounds with a loud and sharp alarm or a single loud chime.  Just clean the area chosen with alcohol, apply the sticker patches and match up the arrows on the alarm and sensor, and the job's done.The simple controls lay under the easy to slip off, plastic lid in front.  "Alarm-OFF-Chime" plus a Test Batteries button that lights a tiny green light to let one know power's available.  The 4 LR44 batteries sit below.  The two parts of the alarm must be within 15mm(little more than a 1/2") which worked fine with all our doors and windows.We already use an security system that chimes when people go in and out and also has surveillance by an alarm company(Simplisafe).  It's nice to know where the kids are and who's going in and out in our home.  This one we use in our garage for the door exiting to the backyard garden.  The chime can be heard in the house.  Set the alarm, and it blares.We love it: an easy, cheap way to have, at least, a basic alarm/warning system.

Well, how about some mystery/thriller themed escapism to the Southwest, a la T. Hillerman, but with a Christian viewpoint.At first, I didn't plan to bring up the Hillerman comparison, but it looms over any novel of this genre, so I addressed it.  Let me just say, Lisa Carter does a quite admirable job writing in that 'looming comparison'.  Her story flows nicely and with characters that one cares about.  One finds mystery, excitement and romance.  Romance striking big here.The story splits immediately into basically two tales of two times: !906 and a missing woman, who after the first page we learn, "Her scalp prickled.  He lunged.  She screamed..." and present day, heroine who seeks the answer to her disappearance and finds attraction and conflict, and potential love, with a Native Amercian policeman.  It may sound a bit corny, but the plot develops well and holds one's interest.What I'm looking for here is a well-written Christian novel with romance, some adventure and a neat background.  And it delivers.  It balances on a difficult edge between getting the Navajo/Hopi cultural elements right, offering enough of the Christian message and themes, dealing with relationships between Believers and non-Believers, and providing enough realism and romanticism to satisfy us and still make sense.You can't please everyone, but it pleased me.  Yes, but any criticisms?  I'm of the Zane Grey mode of loving great descriptions of nature,  It flushes out the surroundings and enriches the mood and setting.  Ms. Carter uses a lot of dialogue, which is great, especially in a romance; however, her descriptions tend to be more matter of fact and short, e.g,  "Icicles hanging from the eaves of the dome-shaped hogan dripped, the snow tucked only in higher elevatons... the pass was almost clear.  The spring thaw had inexorably come."  Ok, I've got "just the facts, mam."  Definitely, crisp, clear writing.  Some may prefer that, but for moi, inspire me; make my imagination run wild.Discussion questions included plus excerpt from author's Under a Turquoise Sky.

This is a lightweight plastic, easy to use and nice looking air cleaner.Placed on a firm surface, it stands about 3 feet high.  Plug in, turn on, select 1-5 speeds(speed 1 is  quiet; the other  speeds are audible but not overbearing), turn on/off UV-C. Finally, they offer a timer to run the purifier up to 8 hours.There are filters and a UV bulb  replacement indicators.  The filters remove easily from the back by a lock and release button.  They're made up of a HEPA filter and a simple charcoal filter that thinly attaches to the the HEPA to form the so-called combination filter.  The filters are stated to last for~6-8 months and then need to be replaced.  The charcoal filter can be cleaned with a vacuum brush.  When the white HEPA filter turns grey or black(that doesn't sound good) they recommend replacement.  They list a 1-866# or their webstie for new ones.When UV is on, a blue circle lights up.  It claims to kill staph, flu, rhino and pneumonia viruses and to trap 99.97% of particles down to .3microns.  I'll have to take their word on that..Size of room recommended: closed room up to 199 sq. feet, e.g. a 10'X20' room.We love it because it's easy to move around with an insert for one's hand and very easy to use.Replacement bulb pulls out from the back, size LB4000 and costs $35 and the HEPA Filter C ~$40-> as listed at their website.

This Sony subwoofer provides a quality, rich bass with easy set-up in a solid box.  This meets my expectations for space saving and a great sound.  It brings out not just the deep thrills but the mid-range notes as well.They provide one audio connecting cord for amps that have a mono out, a mix out, a subwoofer out, or a super woofer output jack; otherwise,  follow the simple connecting diagrams for amps with single or double sets of speakers.  One needs to buy further connecting cords.  For the best sound, they recommend 2 subwoofers, but one works great for us, and not to place anythng on the woofer; moreover, they warn, that it could discolor sp ecially treated flooring(e.g.waxed or polished flooring).The sound comes across solid with no distortion.  I can hear the voices and individual instruments so much clearer now.  I find that moving it around one can find the idea placement for the best, fullest sound.  They include a small pad of foot cushions to decrease vibrations.  Besides a Power Save switch, there's a Cut Off Frequency knob that goes from 200Hz-50Hz- this matches up with your speaker's size; there's a Volume Level control to up the bass sound a little more than before;Basically, set-up the  connectons, plug them in, turn on the amp, press power(green light) and play.  Adjust the sound by using the Cut Off Frequency, Volume Level and choosing the phase- normal or reverse polarity.  For me, it's a matter of trial and error, i.e.,where to place the box and which adjusment makes it sound, to my naive ears, the best.  Rock on.

This aluminum caddy is easy to set-up(30 seconds), lightweight and convenient.The aluminum is soft, malleable and could be broken if one is rough with it; however it sits nicely over the shower head pipe without any significant weight.There are three trays: bottom for soap, second level for smaller bottles, and top level for a couple of tall containers, e.g., shampoo and conditioner.  Hang a wash cloth or a sponge on the 2 protruding ends/arms at the bottom.A rubber liner protects and holds the unit over the pipe, and they include 2 suction cups that snap on behind the piece to secure to the shower tiles.  Pretty brainless to put up and use, and it looks nice.

A strong drill bit set with black oxide finish in a compact hinged case.10 1/4" shank bits: 1/8"(2), 9/64, 5/32, 11/64, 3/18, 7/32, 1/4, 5/16, and 3/8" are included.  They list the metric equivalent beneeth the inches.  The tips are sharp and start easily.  They feature what they call "Turbomax" tips; they look kind of bronze/gold in appearance and appear durable and long lasting to hard work.The small, molded case folds up with a latch and a straight pin as the hinge.  So far so good, drills well, just needs a 1/2", and I'm set.

A nice compact, fits in your hand, staple gun great for quick jobs.I own several staple guns including a 'club, that you swing down to staple; however, this is the first compact one, and I really like it.  I have skinny hands with long fingers made for playing the piano.  This grip handle suits me just fine.  It doesn'r require a mega-squeeze to staple, and for the most part, staples flush every time.  Of course, this is always dependent on what's being stapled and technique.Clip it on your belt, and you're off to handle 90%+ of the jobs around the house.  I use my bigger guns for putting up tar paper or shingles for the treehouse or coop since this one can't hold the 9/16" staples I prefer, and has limited staple space, but for quick jobs for me or my wife, it's right on.  They include box of staples.  Durability?  Seems adequate, time will tell.

A three bag, of various sizes, travel organizer that works well for light travel.My family travels light, and we're always looking for items to help pack smarter and lighter.  My wife likes these cubes.  As shown, navy blue with zipper, very lightweight and breathable.  The largest will hold shirts or light pants, the next size, undies, socks, t-shirts, the smallest, accessories, socks, hygiene.  Good for a few items you want to keep fairly neat.Stuff them tight but not to the point of stessing the zippers or having to stomp/sit on them to close them up.  Nice style.Myself?  I prefer vacuum packs.

Myra Johnson provides a well written novel of romance and finding oneself in periods of change.This is a Christian fiction piece by an accomplished author.  As a amateur writer, I enjoy following how other writers put a story together.  Storyline, characters, descriptions must flow together in a balanced way, and here they do.The setting is post-WWI.  The heroine returns home after the heightened experience of wartime  France.  It is definitely a bittersweet place for her, and she must find work and deal with family matters.  On the opposite spectrum, is the man she meets.  Stuck back in the US during the war, and living in the shadow of his brother, he strives to establish and make something of himself in the business world.Can two very different personalities find common ground to sustain a mutual attraction?I like the period setting and the gentle flow and development of this story.  It doesn't necessarily sweep one away, but still maintains one's interest.  I have not read any other stories by Ms. Johnson, or in this series, but would read more of her work.  "Every Tear a Memory" stands alone, and I had no trouble following the story.  She includes a dicussion chapter and an excerpt from "When the Clouds Row By", the first in the 'TIll We Meet Again Series'.

She's a rock star for our 8 year old who finds homes for all kinds of dolls.Nice, thick, long, almost braidable(with a little patience) hair, cute features and freckles, articulated joints, and, I believe, big heads are in right now. It doesn't matter with our girl; she has AG's, Barbies, Monster Highs, a few Brats, and others, of unknown, to me, names.  She says she's 'cute and friendly looking, not too bratty or fancy, kinda punky but fun'. Band accessories available.  She wonders when the movie's coming out.  Hmm.So, I"ve got to assign it 5 stars for appeal to our particular child, and...for me, it's less expensive than most.  Thank you.P.S. My joke- "Hey Sweetie, do you know what you get if you take a Bratz and mix her with Bellatrix(sp?)?"  Daughter- ignoring me."Well, you get a Beatrix, of course!""Oh Daddy."

This is a top notch electric razor that offers a good shave, compact size and a travel case.I've used Remington shavers all my bearded life in conjunction with regular blades.  I have a large face and a heavy beard.  I can easily shave three times a day or more.  Most of the time I use regular blades- usually quicker and a closer shave; however, the Remingtons have worked well for me when I want to mix it up, and this one is definitely the best I've seen.Of course, they now feature different, decorative designs which I can take or leave.  What I really like here is 1) very lightweight, easy to travel with unit, 2) fits and feels nice in hand 3) the floating, contouring heads are the best yet especially with those 3 all metal precison heads.  Now, my old  Remington SR9130, which I liked a lot, is bulkier(it would indicate time remaining) but with a larger cutting surface area and a larger trimmer, it was less gentle on the face than this one.I follow the instructions and use in the shower: wet face, apply gel, rinse often under water.  Try not to press hard- that's a definite for most electric shaving.  For cleaning, daily: pull the rotary face off and tap or blow out shavings and rinse.  My old shaver had a nice push button to open that I like better.  Weekly: a more thorough cleaning plus lubricate with houshold oil.  I find if one complies with servicing the machine lasts a lot longer.  Usually, I get 2 years(which is the warrenty here) or so out of a machine if I use it regularly.  After that the blades don't cut well enough on my beard or the motor's weak and the trimmer doesn't work.Now I own the XR1340.  After the initial 24 hours of charging, they suggest a full 4 hour charging time for about a 1 hour shaving time.  It does have a small low battery/charging indicator and will work worldwide for voltage.Overall, with that flex head, it's probably the best out there; however, as before, for my ultra-thick beard, blades still work better.  This one is amazingly light and compact for travel and neat to use in the shower.  Finally, it is very cost prohibitive, but I've noticed that the price has been coming down.

An easy to apply cutting clamp edge that has amazingly sped up my building projects.I'm a DIY at home 'carpenter'.  I use that term lightly so not to offend real carpenters; however, over the years from simple desire, I've constructed a treehouse, a chicken coop with run, a chicken tractor, sandbox, swing, teeter-totter and various other nice concoctions using only, for cutting, a circular saw and a jigsaw.  I say this not to brag, but to indicate my love for basic backyard building.  I could do it all day, eveyday.  I know there are bunches of other dads, husbands, men, and women who have the same drive to create.I'm always looking for the latest gadget to simplify or ease up my projects, and this Bora clamp edge meets the need.  It's lightweight, nice, smooth  aluminum material.  There's not much to it(whick I love). Lay it down, up to 50"; the underneeth clamp slides to fit your piece of wood; set it up and simply ffold the end clamp down to hold it in place.  There's a hole at the end to hang it up on the wall when done suing.In the past, I've used wood planks as guiding edges, but now, quickly, I can lay this one down, and I'm ready to cut.  It says one can add an extension of 50".  Hmm, that's an interesting idea- from an extraordinary, project point of view that is!  Thumbs up.  Happy safe cutting.

I love and collect the Countdown to Christmas movies by Hallmark.  This one had the good Hallmark production values, nice Christmas shots, good actors, and some romance; however(and it's a big However), the script in one particular but very important part soured the whole movie for us.The heroine(expressively played by Kellie Martin) mourns the loss of her beloved husband.  She wants nothing to do with Christmas traditions, other than making yummy cookies.  Ornaments hold a special meaning for her(thus the title).  She meets a tree shop owner who hits it off with her, and she starts to open up to life again.  It's all done nicely, gently and very sentimentally.Ok, now my issue ***SPOILER ALERT***  Nearing the end of the movie, after she's started to open her heart to him, his beatuiful, model-like ex-girlfriend, who left him and broke his heart, comes back and wants to start up again.  Fine.  He withdraws from the Kellie Martin character- they don't go skating together like usual, he's cold and distant- and she doesn't know what's going on.  That is, until she happens to see them together.  He's apparently trying to figure out what he wants, so he pretty much blows her off.Nothing happens between him and said old flame, and, of course, he realizes he wants the new girl.  In the meantime, she's heartbroken, throws out her Christmas tree, and accidentally breaks an important ornament.  He returns to her with an attitude of pretty much 'What's the matter with you?'.  She tells him what she saw and that she can't handle the relationship.  He, more or less, chews her out, instead of apologizing for his insensitivity, and storms off.  Later, she runs back to him, after receiving a 'sign', and apologize profusely to him.  Ta-ta, Hallmark happy ending. ***END ALERT***Well, the whole thing left a bad taste in my mouth.  The movie, otherwise, is alright, and up to typical Hallmark standards.  Perhaps, they needed a woman screenwriter on this because it just doesn't sit well with me. Or perhaps, they wanted to show what happens in real life, so just get over it. I don't think so.Please, with all the great reviews, somebody convince me that I'm off base here.

We love to do Christmas traditions, and this one really appeals to the kiddoes- an Advent calender with milk chocolates.The calender is lightweight, simple and inexpensive with individually wrapped (they look like litte Christmas presents) 24 chocolates.  Open the paper door for the respective day, push the chocolate foward a bit from behind to pull it out- it's held in a cheap plastic tray.The box shows a basic but cute Nativity scene.  Each door offers a rhyme(non-religious).  The Madelaine chocolates get a thumbs up from the children.  They take the leftover wrappers, fold them back neatly, and use them as presents in their miniature dollhouses.Merry Christmas!

For me, you can't beat a live production; moreover, I'm old enough to remember and have enjoyed the Mary Martin TV production, and these two are different but the spirit's the same, and here, you get great sets, fun dance numbers and, I think, overall good family entertainment.There's a lot of work put into this show, as can be seen with the included "Making Of" featurette(I love those!).  We really liked the Sound of Music(SOM) last year, and the same NBC group orchestrated this one.  I favor SOM much more than Peter.  The music's better, but here they do offer some very good dancing scenes, neat imaginative sets and terrific stage special effects.The actors do a super job- especially Allison WIlliams as Peter.  She becomes totally boyish, self-centered and magical in her role.  Watching her in real life, discuss and rehearse the role, she's beautiful, a talented singer and fearless- especially- with all those wire scenes. Fun Christian Borle returns from last year's SOM.Of course, then there's Christopher Walken... maybe terribly miscast... but you got to love him(or hate him, I guess).  Christopher Walken is Christopher Walken: A little bit of that accent, a little bit of tongue in cheek acting and always, always, a little soft shoe.  He makes me laugh.  He's in his 70's doing his thing, take him or leave him.  In his bio, he say he loves doing comedy, harder to do, even though he's remembered for those dramatic if not creepy roles.OK, looking at the some of the negative comments: the kids are too old, they shouldn't be sleeping in the same room, their clothes are too neat and clean, their treehouse too nice, Christopher Walken "looks like Fu Manchu"(Hmm, yeah, I guess he does.) and so forth... come on, this is a fantasy.  There are a lot of talented people busting their rear ends to put all aspects of this show together including some really good child actors.  It may not be the way we remember it or imagine, exactly, the way we might like it to be, but still, what an eyeful of spontaneous showmanship and creativity.We look forward to, hopefully, NBC returning next year with another Live show!

This USB 3.0 memory stick is about 2 1/8" long, 3/4" wide and 3/8" thick. It's a classic design where the memory stick pivots inside a protective housing. The housing features a ring so you can attach it to a keychain.Performance tests on my MacPro using BlackMagic show exceptionally good performance, with consistent 65MB/s writes and a superb 200MB/s read rate. Obviously, you will need a USB 3.0 connection to achieve these speeds.Not much else to report -- it's a memory stick! But so far, it's one of the fastest I've tested, and the price is remarkably low for this level of performance. Highly recommended.Disclaimer: I was offered this product at a discount in exchange for an unbiased an honest review.

The arch comes in two very easy to assemble pieces: the arch just plugs right into the oval base and stays there.My 15 lbs orange tabby tomcat keeps coming back to it and loves it; before that he used to rub up against a wall corner, which was getting all dark with skin oils. Now that he has a more interesting place to leave his scent on, the wall corner stays clean.On the other hand, my friend's cat showed interest for it only once: to pee on it. So, as they say, YMMV, but at this price it's worth a try.

This is a very nice open tablet for hobbyists. Unlike most commercial tablets, which come with a pre-installed OS and won't let you install the OS of your choice, it comes without any OS preinstalled. That means you'll have to pay for a Windows license if you choose to install Windows. It comes with a CD of drivers for Windows 8 and 10.The tablet arrived with the battery completely discharged, and it took a while for it to have enough juice that it would start up. I was worried the battery was dead or the tablet was defective, but it's fine. So, when you receive it, it's probably smart to plug it in and let it charge overnight.It took me a while to figure out how to get it to boot off external media; I was stuck on the UEFI prompt until I realized I needed to hold the ESC key as it restarted to access the BIOS setup screen. At that point, if you have bootable media installed on the USB connector or in the microSD slot, it will appear in the Boot section. Make sure your installation volume is at the top of the list, save and restart.I installed Windows 10 without a problem, and it recognized most of the devices; I only needed a couple of the provided drivers. Windows worked smoothly and without a hitch.I then wiped it and installed Ubuntu. While this OS is not exactly ready for tablet prime time, it runs well and as long as you have the keyboard/trackpad for the tablet, it makes a very capable little Unix laptop.PROS---------- It's not an ordinary tablet, more of an open/unlocked laptop with touchscreen in a tablet format.- You can easily install the OS of your choice- Great specs for an entry level product (64GB SSD, 4GB RAM, 1366x768 11.6" display)- Thin and lightweight- USB 3.0 port- microSD slot- built-in easel- Comes with US, EU and UK cords- InexpensiveCONS---------- Requires installing an OS, unlike most computers these days it's not ready to go out of the box- No documentation and I couldn't find any web site dedicated to it- Screen contrast and viewing angles are good but not great- Proprietary power connector- Does not support 5.4GHz WiFi bandsCONCLUSION--------------------There are a lot of Atom Bay Trail Windows tablets in this price range; they're usually 8" or 10", feature a 1280x800 screen, 1 or 2GB RAM and 16 or 32GB of SSD -- and you can only run Windows on them. This tablet offers a larger screen, a comfortable amount of RAM, a larger SSD and the capability to install any OS of your choice. The extra RAM ends up making a big difference.If you're only interested in running Windows, and have little patience for installing an OS and tinkering with drivers, you should probably go for a more traditional Windows tablet. The lowest end Surface Pro 3 is clearly a better product -- it also costs three times as much.If you're a tinkerer in search of a low cost customizable tablet, you just found it.

First, a disclaimer: I was given these headphones to review by the manufacturer.A very classic design, these bluetooth headphones consist of two earbuds connected by a noodle style wire. The electronics (battery, microphone, control buttons, microUSB charge port) are located in a small pod near the left earbud.The controls couldn't be any simpler: three buttons, plus, minus, and action. Hold the action button for a few seconds for power on/off, short press for play/pause or answering calls, same with +/- which control the volume and double as prev/next buttons.The headphones come with a short charging cable, a set of ear tips of different sizes, and a set of ear inserts of different sizes (these little crescent shaped pieces that keep the earbuds in place). The box also contains a short USB to microUSB charging cable.The external part of the earbuds is adorned with a large squarish shiny magnet, and they can attach to each other. It's great to prevent them from tangling up in a pocket, or to keep them from falling off your neck when the earbuds are not in your ears.I left the best part for the end: the sound is great and the battery life fantastic. Previous generations of these tiny bluetooth headphones strained to deliver 4 hours of continuous play, but these last almost twice as long (7 hours). If you're happy using the headphones bundled with your Apple or Samsung phone, you will not miss their sound quality. These sound just as good... without a cord. Five stars, because they sound surprisingly good for the price, they're durable and convenient. Recommended.

Of all the solutions in search of a problem, this one takes the cake... And it was very expensive when it was first released, too.Since I already own a Wink hub (I'm extremely pleased with it, by the way) when I saw that these were being liquidated in a fire sale I thought what the hell, why not give it a try...Now I know why it's being liquidated. It doesn't work. It never accurately detected the presence or absence of eggs, so it's completely useless. And then one time someone forgot to close the lid, which caused it to drain the batteries...Probably the worst product Quirky ever came up with. It would be borderline stupid if it worked... But it doesn't. The only good thing about it is that it makes a pretty good "dumb" egg holder.

This is the traditional French butter keeper, revisited. Unlike ordinary butter dishes, the butter is stored upside down into a small cup of water. The water provides an airtight seal preventing the air from oxydizing the butter: it lasts longer and tastes better (the water does not touch the surface of the butter).The water should be replaced every few days.You can keep the dish out on the counter even in summer, so your butter is always soft and ready to spread, instead of fridge-hard.The long shape is more adapted to our US butter sticks, and the dish comes with a simple explanation of how to refill it:place a stick of butter on a cutting board and cut about 1/2" from each end. Place the two pieces you cut off on top of the stick, and press the container down onto the butter which will fill it up.Finish by smoothing it up with a spoon.The glaze finish is of very high quality without any of the imperfections and pores you always find with low-cost crockery. Easy to clean, convenient, looks great... And it's made in the USA! Highly recommended.

There is already plenty of information on this machine out there, so I thought that instead of yet another boring review It might be interesting to just include my notes on what makes it different from the Silhouette products I'm familiar with.The CM350 is the latest generation of the Brother ScanNCut product line. It includes a full color 300dpi scanner that uses the same feeding mechanism as the cutter. The CM350R includes the rhinestone startup kit (sample materials and rhinestones as well as a code to activate the rhinestone design option on the ScanNCut Canvas online software)The CM350 can be used as a standalone cutter, either with the built-in fonts and artwork, or with the built-in scanner. It can also cut files created by the ScanNCut Canvas web application, a free app available at http://scanncutcanvas.brother.com. This application runs inside a browser and also works well on iPad and Android tablets (no need to download or pay for an app). You can download the cut files to a USB stick and plug it into the ScanNCut, or send it directly to the ScanNCut if you purchase the $50 ScanNCut Online Activation Card. Unfortunately, you cannot purchase the code online; you have to actually buy a card, scratch it, read the code and enter it manually. Still, I like the fact that the software supports SVG in its free version (that will set you back $50 on the Silhouette).The CM350 has a big brother, the CM650W. It comes with more built-in designs and fonts (not very significant if you prefer using your own designs), the online activation card (a $50 value), but it also supports PES (embroidery file) import for appliquÃ© work, and the larger 12"x24" mat. Unfortunately, these are features that can not even be purchased and activated later, which makes absolutely no sense considering this is essentially the same exact machine. So, if you want to work on 12"x24" mats or do appliquÃ© work, skip the CM350. Note that Silhouette offers embroidery format import as a $25 upgrade to Silhouette Designer (it's called "Designer Plus"). User Fawn pointed out that 12"x24" mats are supported for cutting, just not for scanning.As a vinyl cutter, the Cameo is a clear winner since you can directly feed 12" wide vinyl and cut designs up to 10 feet in length. The CM350 limits you to 12"x24" (you can use the 12"x24" mat or feed the vinyl directly without a mat, thanks Fawn for pointing out my original mistake)Where the ScanNCut really shines is with its built-in scanner feature and the many ways it leverages it:- automatic cut line detection: scan artwork, isolate a section and let ScanNCut detect the cut line, and cut directly without even changing mats (you can do this on the Silhouette using the optional PixScan mat, but it's a much more cumbersome process)- background scan allows you to perfectly place the cut on your material, perfect for cutting patterns in just the right spot without guesswork, or reuse scraps of materialWHO IS THE SCAN N CUT2 FOR?The ScanNCut2 will be best for anyone with an allergy to computers. It does about as much as a standalone machine can possibly do, and does it extremely well -- and the ScanNCut Canvas software is available for free whenever you need to access more advanced features (the $50 online option buys you the capability to transfer the cut files from the web software directly to the ScanNCut over WiFi, but if you don't want to pay extra you can always use a USB stick). It's also a must for scrapbookers who do a lot of die cutting, as the scan and cut feature is incredibly easy to use and quick, unrivaled by any competitor.WHO IS THE SCAN N CUT2 *NOT* FOR?- Advanced computer users familiar with Illustrator or Corel Draw are likely to feel constrained by the limitations of the online Canvas software- Vinyl cutters: the 12"x24" work area makes the Silhouette Cameo a much better choice with its 12"x120" vinyl capability- People who need 12"x24" scanning or the embroidery PES import feature should avoid the CM350 and look into the CM650W instead (or the Silhouette Cameo with Designer Plus software, a less expensive option)This is really a 5 star machine because it's so easy to use, and while as a computer expert I feel much more comfortable with the Silhouette products, I know many craft enthusiasts who still are intimidated by computer software but desperately want to move away from the constricting cartridge-based Cricut; the ScanNCut will be a perfect transition machine for them.I took away one star because I am really mad at Brother for creating this confusing set of models out of what is essentially the same machine, making it difficult to choose and even understand what it is you're buying, and arbitrarily locking you out of upgrading to get these new features.As long as you know what you're getting into... It's a very powerful and well made machine.

These bamboo frame sunglasses come in a nice cylindrical bamboo case with a soft fabric carry bag and a cleaning cloth.The frame has a classic shape and gradient tint polarized lenses. The tint gradient provides a small clear area towards the bottom so you can more easily see your dashboard, read a map, etc... as you look down, while still darkening most of your field of vision.While the frame's material is unusual and innovative, these are not novelty sunglasses: the lenses are of excellent quality, similar to what you would find on expensive brand name sunglasses: high quality polarizing, no optical distorsion.An unusual product that is getting me lots of compliments. Recommended.[sample provided in exchange for a fair and unbiased review]

I had previously been extremely disappointed by the trackpad on the Logitech TK820 which is wobbly and vague, so I was very interested to see if Logitech had corrected the situation with the K830.The K830 is smaller than the TK820, which is about 1" wider and 1/2" taller. The K830 is a little thicker but does not have the bulbous area of the TK820 which is necessary to house the AA batteries, since it runs on a rechargeable battery for weeks.The trackpad area is only 3"x2" instead of 4"x4" on the TK820, but it has separate left/right buttons which work much better than the TK820's wobbly built-in click. There is also an extra click button on the edge at the top left of the keyboard.Along the same edge, you will find the microUSB charge port (cable provided) as well as the mechanical on/off switch.The keyboard layout is great and while the keys are slightly smaller than standard, it's hardly noticeable. Typing is very comfortable and matches the quality level usual with Logitech keyboards. The backlighting works well. The black matte finish looks great but is a fingerprint magnet -- don't expect it to stay matte very long.The keyboard comes with a Logitech Universal receiver USB dongle as well as an extender cable -- good thinking. By default the keyboard connects to the Universal dongle, but if you press FN+Del it becomes discoverable on Bluetooth (and disconnects from the Universal receiver). It paired effortlessly with my Surface Pro 2 tablet running Windows 10.The dual Universal/Bluetooth support is extremely useful, although it would have been even better to be able to toggle between the two, allowing you to control two separate products like a HTPC and an Amazon FireTV for instance. Unfortunately, there is no convenient way to switch.PROS--------- Rechargeable (microUSB port, cable provided)- Logitech Universal dongle (provided) *AND* Bluetooth support- Quality construction, pleasant typing, trackpad tracks well- Key backlightCONS---------- Can't toggle between Bluetooth and Universal to easily control two devices- Thick in front and no angling feet so prolonged desk use could be uncomfortable (it's a lap keyboard)- No cover- Black finish collects fingerprintsThis is a great keyboard and by far the best keyboard/trackpad I've ever used -- and a huge upgrade over the lousy TK820. While it's a great HTPC keyboard, you may find out that it's also a great everyday keyboard for your computer especially if you don't have a lot of desk space.Expensive, but worth it. Recommended.

This unusual toy consists of the "hologram" base and a bluetooth brainwave headset. The base, once assembled, takes up quite a lot of space, which is all the more irritating because the white part at the bottom serves no other purpose than to raise the black imaging part at the top to optimal viewing level. It would have been nice to be able to remove it and even use it as a protective case; unfortunately the current design does not allow that.The pompously named "hologram" is really... a teleprompter. Clear plastic windows angled at 45 degrees reflect the image displayed by the upside-down tablet held at the top, and also let you see through. There are three windows, a large one in front and two on the sides, providing a more convincing effect and allowing for a better viewing angle. The tablet is held by a clip on its edge and must not be in a protective case, which is taking a bit of a gamble for a kid's toy.The bluetooth headset runs off a single AAA battery (not provided). It paired easily to my iPad (the game requires a 10" tablet, iPad or Android), and I had no trouble downloading the free game from the App Store, although a QR code would have been nice.After the easy setup, I was able to play. The instructions are very minimal, but it does work surprisingly well. The different levels use all sorts of Star Wars imagery, characters, props and music, which make the game very immersive. Unfortunately, no amount of licensed material can hide the reality of how limited your input is: you're just controlling (not that well) an intensity. That gets very boring very quickly to a generation used to 3D immersive first person shooter games and controller pads with buttons everywhere.My biggest gripe with this toy is that it offers only one game, which requires the use of the huge base for its gimmicky "hologram". It demos well, but being able to use the controller with other games would add so much value to the toy. As it stands, it's a one trick pony with a beautifully executed but boring game, and takes up way too much space.

This small charger, barely bigger than the iPhone's standard charger, has enough "oomph" to charge an iPad (or other tablet) at full speed -- at a fraction of the price of the official Apple charger. Works great, the only minor gripe is that just like on the iPhone charger the prongs are not foldable.Great charger, recommended.[sample provided]

These sports bluetooth headphones are made of just the two earbuds tethered by a noodle-style cable. One earbud features power and volume controls, the other the microUSB charge port (behind a protective door).The headphones come fitted with the medium size earbuds, but the box contains a larger and a smaller set, as well as three different sizes of ear crescents to hold the earbuds in place. The volume controls double as previous/next track buttons (with a long press). The power button picks up incoming calls, or rejects them with a long press. You can also invoke Siri (or Google Now or Cortana) with a long press.Voice prompts notify you of power on/off, pairing, and connection. On iOS devices, the battery status is indicated by a bar next to the Bluetooth icon.The sound quality is top notch, and I had no problem getting the promised 6 hours of music playback.Excellent product, recommended.[sample provided]

This selfie stick is so simple, lightweight and small: less than 8" folded up, only 5oz, yet it extends to 34". The handle features a comfortable rubber grip and a single action button that falls right under your thumb. At the bottom, a microUSB charging port (cable provided). Pairing is easy and quick (the device shows up as "Soviifone" in the Bluetooth list). No on/off switch: the stick turns itself off automatically to save power and turns on when you press the shutter button.The non-removable but adjustable smartphone holder fits devices up to 3 1/2" in width -- more than enough for my iPhone 6 Plus in its big ZVOLTZ battery case.Other selfie sticks offer multiple mounts (camera thread, smartphone, GoPro...), a threaded base, removable triggers, longer reach... But they're more expensive, heavier, and more complicated. If you want the smallest, simplest possible bluetooth selfie stick, you can't go wrong with this one.Recommended.[sample provided]

This string of 200LED lights runs about 72 feet. It's very minimalist but sturdy. The strand ends with an electric cord capped with a weather-resistant power plug which connects to either the solar unit or a USB adapter. The USB adapter can be plugged into any USB power source, like a phone charger or a power bank. The solar unit can be attached to either a stake or a screwable mount (screws are provided).The back of the solar unit features two switches: on/off and flashing. When on, the light comes on automatically at dusk. Unfortunately the small panel does not generate enough juice to provide more than a few hours of illumination out of a full day of sun, but that's plenty.These lights can be used as holiday lights, tree lights, but their very simple and bare nature also makes them ideal for creative projects. The USB adapter makes it also very easy and convenient to power them off an inexpensive battery pack to get extra long illumination times on long winter nights. Recommended.[sample provided]

This is an 8" x 5" pouch made of heavy clear soft plastic. Think of a super ziploc bag with triple zips where the top folds up and is held together with velcro, attached to a belt with quick-release fastener. The belt is adjustable but only extends up to around 44" -- then again you can always wear it around your neck.If you ever go near a pool, or to a park with water rides, this is absolutely indispensable to protect your valuables from splashes or accidental falls into water. It will hold a large phablet and a wallet without problems, and you can still operate the phone fairly easily through the plastic.Make sure to get one before your next trip to Disneyland... Splash Mountain has claimed a few smartphones!Recommended.[sample provided]

I recently purchased an Apple Watch and realized that a charging stand is a must, not just because it keeps the cord and watch tidy, but also because it keeps the base and cord in place when the watch is in use.This bamboo stand is beautifully finished and comes with a holder for both the Apple Watch and a phone. There are grooves to run both wires to the back. My Apple Watch charging base fit perfectly, and the groove makes it obvious to see how to run the cable.I use an iPhone 6 Plus with a ZVOLTZ battery case and it fits (barely) standing up straight and being plugged in, although a phone with a thinner case will be more at ease.The bamboo looks really beautiful and the finish is very smooth and pleasant to the touch.If you have an Apple Watch you need a charging stand for it, and this one is an excellent choice I recommend wholeheartedly.[sample provided]

These are the RFID protective cases you've seen everywhere, offered on deal a day web sites or handed out by banks to their top tier customers. They contain an accordion separator that holds up to seven credit cards. The separator is glued but can be removed to turn the case into a holder for other, more interesting things such as memory cards.I verified RFID shielding by placing my office pass inside and attempting to scan it -- no dice, I had to take it out to gain entry.A good standard RFID wallet at a very attractive price (this is a set of 6 sold for barely more than most vendors charge for a single RFID wallet)Recommended.[sample provided]

A set of two nice business card holders. One corner features a metal embellishment convenient to apply promotional branding. Both sides of the holder are lined with a fairly thick (about 1mm) pleather layer. A very nice and inexpensive business card holder, but if you're good at crafts like engraving or stencil etching you can make really nice personalized gifts with these!Recommended.[sample provided]

I have a RFID identity pass for work and they provided me with a really lousy pull-string holder that broke within a couple of months. We're supposed to have our IDs visible at all times and it was very inconvenient to deal with the pass without the retractable holder. This one came in really handy! Unlike the cheap plasticky standard-issue holder, this one has a metal case and extends by about 2 feet. The clip is also metal and hangs nicely off my belt. All my coworkers ask me where I got mine! Recommended.[sample provided]

Like many people these days I'm a sucker for those cooking shows where experienced chefs explain to you how important it is to have a high quality knife and keep it sharp. So, of course, I buy quality knives and keep them sharp. And every single frickin time I sharpen my fancy knife and start chopping vegetables I end up cutting myself.A while back I saw that the sandwich making person at Safeway used a chainmail glove and lined it with a thin plastic glove, so I bought one. Unfortunately, I could only find one size and it was a little tight. Also, it's quite heavy and somehow restricts motion and "feel".These gloves are completely different: they come as a pair and in a variety of sizes, and instead of being made of metal they're simply made of a cut-resistant fabric. They're much more lightweight, and maintain the feel of what you're doing: they're just a good protection, and it's just like wearing very lightweight thin wool gloves. If you're a klutz like me, they're absolutely indispensable.One thing though, I strongly recommend wearing thin plastic gloves on top, depending on what you're doing, so you don't get them dirty (although they will go in the wash)Highly recommended.[sample provided]

These sports bluetooth headphones feature two small ear pods connected by a day-glo noodle style tangle-free cable. They come with three different sizes of ear buds, three different sizes of loops and three different sizes of crescents -- you can adjust them to every possible ear configuration, so they're comfortable and stay in.The left ear holds the microUSB charge port (behind a protective hinged rubber plug) and the right has the power and volume controls. A long press on the volume control triggers previous/next track, and a short press on the power button play/pause or off-hook when a call comes in. That is basic functionality, but basic is perfect for sports headphones -- you don't need to be figuring out where all the controls are.A female voice indicates power on/off, pairing, connection. Battery status is reported via Bluetooth (visible next to the bluetooth icon on the iPhone).Sound quality is excellent thanks to Apt-X and AAC support. Music playback at reasonably loud volume is a solid 6 hours.This is a quality product that looks and sounds great, at a very reasonable price. Recommended.[sample provided for review]

I live in an area with pretty crowded airwaves and never had much luck with FM adapters, and I've tried a lot of them since the early days of the iPod, so I was curious to see the performance of this one. Earlier models required locating an unused area of the FM band, which is a tall order around here.The Mpow Streambot is comprised of a long cigarette lighter adapter (about 3") which also doubles as a USB power adapter, a clever idea; and a control unit at the end of a 3" gooseneck.The control pod features a ring to set the FM frequency (displayed numerically on the red LED readout), track +/- controls, a volume control ring (U00-U16 is displayed on the readout when adjusting the volume) and an action button. Pairing is easy, the device appears under the name "MPOW" in the bluetooth device list.The action button triggers the phone's vocal assistance feature if available. The microphone for hands-free operation is located to the left of the LCD readout.Just out of curiosity, I set the frequency to that of a powerful local radio station, which is likely to be the worst possible operating conditions I'll ever encounter. To my surprise, the radio broadcast went completely silent and my music played loud and clear, without any interference. The sound quality is really good, with practically no background noise or hiss, just a slight hint of over modulation sometimes, characteristic of FM.STRONG POINTS-------------------------- built-in USB power outlet for a phone- simple design, small and easy to remove- music playback and hands-free speakerphone features with easy to access action button- well designed control, easy to operate without looking- Surprisingly good sound, overpowers even strong FM signalsLIMITATIONS-------------------- It's an FM transmitter -- the audio quality, while excellent, is no match for an auxiliary line input, but FM is the only option on many older vehicles.- The design requires a cigarette lighter outlet in a location easily accessible from the driver's seat -- usually not a problem on older vehicles which are the very ones that also happen to lack an AUX input.CONCLUSION--------------------By far the best FM transmitter adapter I've ever used; actually, the only one I ever used that actually works and works well. If you want to add bluetooth functionality to an older car that lacks an AUX in jack, you can't go wrong with this one. Highly recommended.[sample provided for review]

This waterproof case is lightweight and adds minimal bulk to the iPhone 6 Plus (only 1/2" thick) while maintaining access to all the buttons and ports. The Lightning port is protected by a hard plastic flap, the headphone port by a rubbery plug, volume +/- and power buttons are extended to the shell with , and the mute switch (the hardest one to do since it's not a push button) is taken care of by a clever up/down toggle.The plastic film protecting the screen allows excellent tracking (despite the added thickness of the tempered glass screen protector I had already installed), and even better, the film on the TouchID button preserves the fingerprint scanning feature, which works beautifully.The case comes with a microfiber cleaning cloth, a screw-on headphone cord pigtail should you wish to use the headphone port, a wrist strap that can be attached to the bottom right corner of the case, a very clear instruction booklet, and a puzzling hot pepper-shaped red plastic thingie.You discover what the red pepper thingie is for when you try to open the case... it's sealed tight. You can use the plastic tool as a wedge at the bottom right of the case. Mind you, a quarter will work just fine too, but you have to admire the branding flair. Nice touch.The case is made of only two parts, front and back, which assemble with satisfying "snap" sounds. You must verify the silicone gasket is not damaged before closing the case. Note that you can't assemble or disassemble the case if the Lightning port protection flap is closed.The manual recommends doing a test run by immersing the case and maintaining it underwater for half an hour. I kept mine in for an hour, and the interior was perfectly dry, so I know my expensive iPhone will be protected.HIGH POINTS--------------------- Adds minimal bulk to the phone- Easy to install and remove- Preserves access to all buttons and ports, including fingerprint recognition on TouchID- Compatible with an ultra-thin tempered glass protector- Short, clear and well written instruction manual- Wrist strap, can be used to attach a keychain buoy- InexpensiveThis is a perfect case if you're going to use the phone near water: water rides, boating, at the pool or hot tub... A small price to pay for peace of mind.Highly recommended.[sample provided for review]

This 12,000mAh battery comes with fairly standard features (one 2.1A port, one 1A port, charging via microUSB). There is enough juice to refill an iPad Air 2 and still have enough left to recharge an iPhone. The case is very thin (only 1/2") and 3" x 5 1/2", and lightweight (8.7oz). Both sides are made of a smooth, textured hard plastic, and the edges have a chrome finish. It's beautiful and fits easily in any pocket, and its rounded corners and smooth shape will ensure that it doesn't damage your clothes.There's no need to look for the power or charge test button: a little shake does the trick and illuminates the 4-LED ramp.According to the manual this is also needed to turn on the power, but in my experience just plugging in a device was sufficient -- YMMV, as they say.It takes about 8 to 10 hours to restore a full charge once the battery is near depleted (only 1 LED left) using an iPad power adapter.I like the finish, capacity, small size -- and the low price! An excellent value.[sample provided for review]

This bluetooth speaker has a convenient size (about the size of a kid's juice box) yet it delivers a nice, crisp, well balanced sound without much distorsion at reasonable volumes (it's loud enough for a bathroom or a dorm room). It also has a hands free speakerphone feature.The non-replaceable battery is recharged via a micro USB connector (cable provided). There is also an AUX stereo minijack input (cable provided). And it even comes with a wrist strap so you can hang it from a hook or your bicycle handlebar.Playing at reasonable sound levels, you can easily get the promised 8 hours playback time and more. The speaker is waterproof, so there's no problem with leaving it on a bathroom countertop, or taking it camping or on a hike.I like to listen to internet radio on my phone in the morning, but the built-in speaker is not loud enough. Now I can leave my phone charging on the nightstand and take this speaker with me to the kitchen and the bathroom, and listen to the news while I have breakfast and shower -- I can even answer a phone call with wet hands without worrying about damaging my phone.This little speaker delivers a lot for the money.  Long battery life, speakerphone, decent sound, small size, waterproof, and even better -- it won't break the bank.

This battery packs enough juice to recharge a fully depleted iPad Air to 100%, and have plenty of power left. That's no longer an exceptional feature, and neither is the convenient built-in LED flashlight.However, the three USB ports are an unusual option (most batteries only offer two ports) and even better, they are "smart ports" so you don't have to squint to figure out which one is the high current port for your tablet: all ports can adjust to the needs of the devices that are plugged in, up to a total of 3.9A -- essentially, one tablet, one smartphone, and one accessory.The really great feature of this battery is the fast charge port: most external batteries recharge using 1A current, but this one can take advantage of a more powerful 2A (like what an iPad charger provides) to charge twice as fast: 8 hours is enough to recharge an almost fully depleted battery.With its huge capacity, fast charging and very reasonable price, this battery is a must have tool for the road warrior -- it makes a great stocking stuffer.Recommended.

1:04 Mins This natural wood aromatherapy diffuser is beautifully finished and runs very quietly (you can check on the attached video, I captured both segments using the same settings so you can get an idea of how much noise it makes)Fill it up using the cup provided, making sure you do not overfill it, close it up, plug it in, press the button and presto! a calming scented mist emerges from the stack (I almost expected Barbara Eden!)There are two buttons hidden in the back: the top one turns on the mister, the bottom one the lights.On the bottom of the lower part towards the front are two very bright LEDs, one red and one blue, to indicate power and light function.The light function turns on colored LEDs inside and cycles through a constantly changing color, fixed colors, and off. I assume the original designer intended for the mist to serve as a light guide and provide a beautiful light show. That's a great idea, and maybe my mister is defective... I can clearly see the light changing by looking down the chimney, but even in the dark, the mist doesn't carry the slightest amount of visible light. It's a little disappointing to have included this feature if it's not going to work... I'm assuming it's because the same mist engine part is being reused in a variety of misters, but it's confusing to have this button that does not do anything detectable.Apart from this minor gripe, I'm thrilled with this product. It's useful, quiet, but also very beautiful and quite a conversation piece.Since some people mentioned difficulties opening it to refill it, I included a segment showing how to do that in the second part of my short video, I hope it will help.An unusual mister that works well and looks great. Recommended.[sample provided for review]

The specs on this battery are very ordinary: one 2.1A USB port, one 1A port, LED ramp power indicator, microUSB 1A charge port. The 10,400mAh is high, but there are higher capacity batteries on the market.The FP10 improves on its competitors on two points: size and quality.- Size: using Lithium Polymer packs instead of the more common Lithium Ion cells, it stores the same amount of energy in less space. The case is only 4 3/4" x 2 1/2" x 3/4"- Quality: The case is made of extruded aluminum, which gives it a sturdy and posh finish. One end features all the ports and switch, the other has a mirror and white finish with all the technical information easy to read, as well as a QR code that will take you to the manufacturer's product page (it works! I tried it)It comes bundled with a very convenient short noodle-style "octopus" cable (USB to microUSB, microUSB 3.0, Apple 30 pin and Apple Lightning) which should take care of all your charging needs, and a very nice lined fabric drawstring pouch with an external pocket for the cable.A battery that is not only convenient, well built and well thought out, but also impeccably finished, so it also makes a great stocking stuffer for the road warrior.Recommended.[sample provided for an unbiased review]

This car adapter is not much bigger than the ones I've had before, yet it packs an incredible 4 ports, clearly labeled (two high power tablet ports, two 1A phone ports). The pictures don't do it justice, it's actually much smaller than I thought -- which is great, because I needed to use it in a spot that does not have a lot of clearance.It's very well finished and looks sturdy. It has no problems charging my iPad, iPhone 6 Plus simultaneously while also powering the dash cam and the satellite radio receiver. Yup, it's a keeper. Recommended.[sample provided for an unbiased review]

This 2.6ft long noodle-style USB to microUSB cable features a MFi-certified microUSB to Lightning adapter secured to the microUSB tip by a springy plastic coil, so it can be used to charge pretty much any phone, tablet and modern electronic gadget you have. The MFi certification guarantees that you're not going to get an angry message from your iPhone saying that you're using an incompatible device: it just works like an OEM cable.This is an ideal cable to keep in your computer bag or travel bag if you're a road warrior: it's short and doesn't take a lot of space, the noodle-style makes it easy to wrap up, you can use it to charge and sync anything, it's the cable you want to have handy at all times.For some applications a longer or Lightning-only cable may be better indicated, but you can't beat this one for convenience. Recommended.[Sample provided for an unbiased review]

This flea control ingredient combination for my 5 rescue dogs just has never worked. This is the same formula as Hartz & other over the counter flea control which is absolutely worthless in the hot flea infested summers in the South. (see my specific ingredient info.)I also have never liked that you had to place this type product all up and down the dog's back.Frontline and K9 Advantix are more expensive unless you buy the generic Frontline, which I have been doing but they do work!!  I do not see where the ingredients are posted on the product's web page here and there is no close up of the pkg available to actually READ what the ingredients are. I just assumed (should never do that) that because of the high cost, it was the same ingredients as Frontline....Not so.....A reviewer incorrectly stated that this product is the same as K9 Advantix. IT IS NOT ! The active ingredient in K9 Advantix is imidacloprid.It is NOT off patent so there can be no generics made. This product's main ingredient is permethrin which is the same as Hartz, Sargents and any other cheap flea control you can buy at your local grocery store. This just has more applications in the pkg.I'm trying to return the unopened packages now.

For some reason, it's not working as long on my pets as it has in past years. It barely lasts a week so I have had to go to topical flea control. Last year, this was all I used and I had no fleas. I don't know if the fleas have built up an immunity or what but it's just not working this summer. When I saw on the label that it's supposed to last up to a month, I thought that was a stretch. So for the money, I think I'll skip buying this next year and stick with the topicals which do seem to last longer. I'll just use this as a back up for spot control. BTW-My cats hated this....the dogs not so much but the felines ran for the hills which I picked up the spray bottle. It doesn't have a pleasant odor about it, unfortunately.

The reason that I gave this case just 3 stars is that it does not have the port covers that the ULAK for less money has. I just don't think protects my phone as well as the ULAK case does and I also think it's important to cover the ports to keep the dirt out. I knew this case didn't have the port covers but I thought based on the great reviews that it would be a good back up cover in case I didn't like the ULAK case, which turned out not to be the case. So I'll keep this one on hand but I much prefer cases that cover the port openings.

Initially I didn't care much for this cover. It was hard to get on and off but since I have dropped my phone several times on my driveway and the phone was not damaged, I think this is a terrific cover for the price. Yep, it is a bugger to get on and off....No double about that. Broken finger nails speak to the difficulty. But it does what it's supposed to do: it protects the phone. I installed my own glass screen protector so I'm happy with the way the case performs for the money. I especially like the port cover which are working way, way better than an Otterbox case that I had. So yes, I do recommend this case for the money and the all around protection.

I would not use any other kind of vacuum bag ! Ever ! I have several models of the Windtunnel upright vacuums ranging in age from old to almost new. I first tried the Hoover paper bags and was over come with the dust that the vac put out during the vacuuming process. So when I discovered these bags through GoVacuum I ordered them and have never looked back.  I am a long time animal rescue volunteer so I always  have multiple animals in my home at any one time. Currently I have 5 dogs and 6 cats. That is a lot of hair and add to that I am highly allergic to dogs and cats and I must have a vac that has good filtration. These bags do the job! If I had to say anything negative, I would have to say that sometimes I don't think they get full enough but animal hair can be very deceiving in quantity so I have to squish the bag to ensure it is full and needs to be changed....plus the light on the vac tells me to change the bag.  So I highly recommend these over the paper bags with the pleats on each side and are oblong. They just do not do a good job of filtering the air for me and I think they are harder to attach to the vac.  So this type of bag is a 5 star product for me !

This just sent me to the ER: I was vacuuming my stairs and was on the 3rd step and the vac was on the landing. All of the sudden out of no where, the vacuum came down the stairs, the handle jabbed me in the throat and chipped my collar bone !!!  The vacuum fell on top of me and I went down the stairs with the vac on top of me.... Thankfully I was able to grab on to the hand rail to break my tumble.This vac has a terrible center of gravity and this is not the first time it has fallen over while I was vacuuming from mildly pulling on what is supposed to be a stretch hose.....NOT so.....It is way too tightly coiled to be of any use.This is going to the dump. It's too dangerous to pawn off on someone else. I am done with Hoover vacuums until they design them to be better balanced. I do not have this issue with the Eureka that I use in my lower level. The hose easily pulls out and the vac never ever tips over !!!

SLOW, SLOW, SLOW....I'm on my home network and my Nokia 635 has already loaded the weather channel local forecast. This phone is still loading....To restate other reviews: terrible viewing angle, despite adjustments to sensitivity of screen finally on the 55th tap, the screen responded to request....it seems to be hit or miss.....and this phone is just not up to USA phone standards....I'll probably be returning it altho it is a great looking phone !Other than making or receiving calls, this would just pretty much be a paper weight. I have to wonder about all the 5 star reviews....They sound mysteriously very similar in their language style and choice of words and phrases which makes me wonder if they are in fact valid. This is a perfect example of "you get what you pay for".....NOT MUCH !!!.UPDATE: August 20, 2015: I am so impressed with the Customer Service of this company ! I received the nicest e mail regarding my comments asking me if there was anything they could do to make my purchase right ! What company actually has personnel in customer service who READS the reviews of purchasers??? Apparently they do ! We have e mailed back and forth and it turns out that they had a newer model that is probably more of what I had in mind for a smart phone and I'm going to buy it. I also suggested that they update the product information on this product that is woefully lacking in tech information. I am told that is in the process of happening also.So I am updating my review to 4 stars because of the fabulous responsive customer service of this company and the fact that this phone may be right for someone who does not have the exact requirements in a phone that I do. I'll give them the benefit of the doubt based on the other reviews, which I was absolutely assured were valid, honest reviews from purchasers. Kudos to Shawyn & this company !!!

I ordered this phone and a Nokia 920. I have lost so many cell phones that now I want to have 1 in my purse and leave 1 here at the house. Maybe then I can keep track of at least 1 of them.This little phone is my first smart phone and I do love it. I am just now learning how to operate all the bells and whistles.
