So, decided to bite the bullet and pay more for the Samsung brand original one....and that did the trick.  Shipped quickly and is still working well!!

It works as long as you don't put anything heavy in it.  Its cheap plastic that is not durable.  It also stains easily, so watch out for tomatoes, chili, spaghetti sauce, etc. getting on it.  When something is heavy, like a crockpot insert, it will bend the plastic and look as if it is going to break.  Maybe fine to use for a strainer in a camper but everyday use with heavy plates, bowls, etc. it has not held up well.  I have always used the wire ones before, and would not buy plastic again.  The wire ones held up to everything and lasted a long time and never stained.

I read the reviews for this book prior to purchasing it and it seemed many purchasers commented on how great this book is.  After I purchased it and received it, I was disappointed to find the information in it was stuff I already knew.  I was expecting a more advanced level of material and advanced levels of exercises.  I have a reverse cervical curve in my neck and its difficult to find books that discuss this issue specifically.  I know this method does help, but I was hopeful it had more info in it about my condition.

I purchased one similar to this one a few years ago and it lasted nearly 5 years...the one I purchased was a bit heavier in construction, so I was hesitant to think this one would do since the price was so much cheaper....but its working fine.  It is not as heavy as the other one and a bit more flimsy, but as long as you don't use it as a baseball bat, I think it will hold up fine!  The bristles are soft and less dense (compared to our other one) but they cleaning the vehicle just as good as our old one.  The great thing about these units is that they telescope and when the brush wears out, you can simply purchase just the brush part and attach it to the unit.  We love how the water will flow through the handle.  Really creates more suds to get that deep dirt and mud off the vehicles.  Works better for us on the tires since the brush head bristles are softer, they will go through the rims better than our other one that was more stiff.  Really cannot go wrong with this brush and the price was terrific!!

SEVEN SEAS TO CALAIS (1962, 99 minutes) is a fun, sword-wielding swashbuckler of a movie with my favorite Rod Taylor as Sir Francis Drake, on a secret mission to get South American riches for Queen Elizabeth the First. It is a colorful, fun and humorous film that gave Taylor a chance to stretch all of his considerable muscles.I was deeply moved by the portrayal, since the 1960s wasn't the decade for biopics--but it was a Sir Francis any kid would be interested in learning about, fully. There were little touches between Sir Francis and Queen Elizabeth that rang true: she did give him a ring, he may have had a warm friendship with her, and the idea that she intended to execute Mary Queen of Scots is thrown into question as she admits to Sir Francis that the death warrant was meant as a warning only.The only thing they left out was the debacle of Sir Francis using the Drake coat of arms, which was an issue because he was questioned about his right to bear it. But the queen set him up with his own armorial bearings anyway. Too bad that wasn't in here. Instead there was a dopey on-the-side romance having nothing to do with anything significant.You'll howl when you see the queen eating a potato for the first time and asking why it bore such an odd name ... one of the many pleasures I leave for you to discover here. The greatest pleasure is Rod Taylor, who was in my opinion badly underused here. It's all great fun in any case, and the queen is simply hilarious.When interrupted by someone at a bad time, her normal reaction was to growl, "Whaddaya want!!" Just pure old fashioned fun. Get this movie and enjoy a little forgotten period in cinema history. The Elizabethan age never looked so fun.

WRIGHT'S SILVER POLISH, LIQUID, 7 OUNCE BOTTLE is simply the only silver polish you need. It is nontoxic, a pleasing consistency/color, easy to use and better than you can imagine. I use it for my rings, and nothing compares. You wet the silver, put a bit of the polish on a soft dry cloth or towel, buff the silver with it. Then you thoroughly rinse your silver, buff it dry and the silver life is sweet.Wright's always amazed me because it strips dirt and tarnish like nothing I ever saw. I recall cleaning a blackened antique ring with Wright's ... in record time.  Without that acid we used to use, and if not for Wright's, that ring could never have been polished as it was.Old Joshua Wright, I think it was, lived at the start of the 19th century. His prize cow had lost her prize silver bell, and he could not find it. Returning much later in better weather, he found the bell, buried in mud but otherwise unharmed. The thing that stunned him was the high polish. That bell, Wright concluded, had been gently, brilliantly polished by Mother Earth's best mud.Wright set out to duplicate that, bottle it up and get rich. Thank God he succeeded, and Wright's is still with us. If you own silver and care about it, you can't live without Wright's. And I don't see why you'd want to do so. This is excellent for other metals, but it does leave a safe protective coating that fights tarnish: good for the silverware. You can literally polish, then eat with, your silverware in one fell swoop ... IF you use Wright's.

SIGNET/MONOGRAM RING, STERLING SILVER by BLING JEWELRY is not a terrible alternative in a market where a plain silver ring can cost up to $500. The signet ring, one of our oldest traditions, does deserve a better treatment than this overly thin, hollow-backed style. The trouble is, this kind of cheaply cast ring is a must, in order to keep costs affordable.I detest such cheaply cast rings only because they always tend to have sharp edges. You can rely on a cheap ring to have a sharp/dangerous feature of some kind, usually its edges. All my life I have worn a signet, but I had one of these cheap rings as a teen for daily wear. One day I got my hand caught in a door and that damnable thing cut right into my finger. So as this product's first reviewer said, it's a shame the ring is not solid or comfort-fit. Buy at your risk.Also, you really can't get much engraved on a thing like this. A nasty little line-drawn monogram is as far as you'll get, because the bezel (the face of the ring) hasn't enough metal to accept proper, deep intaglio engraving. Therefore I specifically label this style a monogram ring style because there is no way you'll get an emblazon, coat of arms or even a decent personal cipher on it. However, I've seen lots of young people wearing these without engraving, and they look marvelous.In summation, a simple reminder: you get what you pay for or, better worded, keep in mind the cost of this item. Sure, it may be well made considering the style, but remember a crummy silver band can cost you around $100. If you like Bling Jewelry's offering, then go to it.

APOCALYPSE: WORLD WAR ONE (a.k.a. APOCALYPSE WWI, 2013, 5 parts, approx. 1 hour each, Canada) is one of those pure, excellent documentaries which it infuriates me to see omitted from the usual dvd canon of (bad) war documentaries. This seemingly humble work is the pinnacle of the genre: it is the opposite of bad.With the intelligent, gentle narration of well spoken, multilingual French Canadian actor François Arnaud (ne FranÃ§ois Barbeau), this features a no-chicken-bones approach to the war, in five parts. What stunned me was not the exclusive WWI footage, which comprises this entire film. What stunned me was the perfectly restored clarity of that footage--and the beautiful colorization of it. No talking heads and no need for any.Such quality in every detail is the thing I love, that rivets my attention and holds it firm. As a scientist, I love seeing clean, accurate footage of what the people wore, how they comported themselves. The only thing I find unnecessary is the foolish addition of sound effects to footage that sees its centennary birthday, and therefore has no sound. Color is one thing, and I applaud it. The Foley artist, on the other hand, has no place here anymore than a reenactor.This is so wonderful I was furious I could not find it on dvd. I will simply have to drink in all I can while I can see it on television. I feel my eyeballs will fall out after seeing face-to-face those bloodcurdling Socialist Russians who killed the Tzar and his family. But then this made me wonder why the series says nothing about Jews.Imagine my astonishment, then, to see film of Prince Faisal bin Hussein, accompanied by Lawrence of Arabia, just a few weeks away from becoming the King of Iraq. I had never seen film of Prince Faisal, let alone of Lawrence. I had no idea there was film of that campaign. This whole amazing documentary is like that--the annoying rapid jerkiness of century-old film is slowed to natural speed and full of surprises.What this show accomplished was to give a clean, sometimes quasi-anecdotal account of World War One, a war which I think is undertaught today. This program is so very worthwhile.The messy sales here are mind boggling. This is billed as "season one" even though it is a simple tv minidocumentary in five 1-hour episodes. As I review it I see the title of only one episode, "Fury". It isn't sold as a dvd set, as God intended, instead being sold in some weird way which I for one do not appreciate. It doesn't help that there are dozens of things out there that are similarly titled.This review I dedicate not only to that brave generation of a century ago, but I dedicate it also to France ... as I grieve with my French siblings, I watch this series with gravity, reflection and hope.

EVELYN PRENTICE (1934, 76 minutes) is one hell of a crime/courtroom drama. William Powell and Myrna Loy play the Prentices, John and Evelyn. John is a busy, hotshot criminal defense attorney with seemingly little time for his wife or small daughter. When Evelyn gets herself mixed up with a vicious gigolo, things turn horrid.Even worse, the gigolo turns up shot dead. This is the drama of a seemingly innocent woman accused of his murder ... and a deeper plot that explodes at the end in the courtroom scene. Powell and Loy are dazzling, modern and riveting in these final scenes. Not only does the sad truth emerge: the movie also becomes a lesson in self defense, why it is and how it is.No lover of classic movies, no lover of crime drama, can afford to miss this. I am irritated that this can only be had on dvd if you buy the Loy/Powell collection, but you can get it on VHS for whatever that's worth! In any event, see the proof of one of my favorite sayings: they did it all, and better than anyone, in the 1930s.You'll finally see how crime drama ought to be done ... by seeing the granddaddy of all crime dramas.TECH NOTE: I battled with myself about asking this in a review ... since I'm not a tech-head, I wonder if I'll ever find the reply. Aside from remastering, I always noted the films up to 1932 are sort of oozy and fuzzy. After that time, they are as crisp as a 1950s tv series. Was it budget or a leap in film stock quality? This film under review is as clear and awesome as anything can be in black and white ... but take PRIVATE LIVES or any other smash hit from just a year or two earlier and you have a creepy mudfest!

MR. HOLMES (2015, 103 minutes) is the finest Holmes film and story I've ever seen--and I've seen 'em all. Sir Ian McKellen gives an Oscar-worthy performance as a 93-year-old Holmes, nearing the close of his 35-year retirement in sight of the white cliffs of Dover in 1947. The beginning of Alzheimer's, which Holmes calls "senility", is rearing its ugly head. Or is it?His only real contact with humans is with his grumpy housekeeper and her wonderful young son. At one terrible point, Holmes famously writes on his shirt cuff the name of the boy so he won't forget it. Another name written there brings back a painful memory of his recent trip to Japan in search of a memory cure, but the film makes one wonder if Holmes is just a very tired old man, struggling to forget a trauma--or else being haunted anew when he thought he'd finally escaped it.McKellen's startling performance will frighten you at first: he really looks badly aged and that is stunning acting. He looks every inch like a nonigenarian. Everyone else in his life is long gone and his acting even conveys that. The intimacy and richness of this film will bring a tear to your eye. It is a quiet, masterful piece about a lonely old man facing his regrets before he dies. Perhaps more importantly, it is a story about how the very young and the very old need each other--a lesson our society flees as from a swarm of wasps.It is the deeply resonant power of McKellen alone that reminds us this is THE Sherlock Holmes.The Holmes makeup deserves mention. I saw Sir John Gielgud in McKellen's makeup and bearing, which only added to the delightful power of his presence. So powerful is he that he reduces everything else to mere background. Few actors have that power, and it will intoxicate you. In this era of stupid and/or modern portrayals of Sherlock Holmes, it is lovely to see what is easily acceptable as the real thing.Little touches also tell us who this character is: a beautifully understated gold aristocratic pinky ring (incidentally identical to Harry Truman's), an exquisite walking stick, a fine fountain pen, an unfailing Victorian manner. Whether you are a Holmes fan, McKellen fan or simply love the best of film, this one is a film to add to your collection. It is one of those creations that is a total objet d'art, yet one feels as if one is living it. There's nothing like this kind of living.

HAT, "WALKER", POLYWOOL BLEND BY STETSON (WALKING BUCKET CAP), is a nice, wonderfully made wool "walking cap" fedora. In my day a gentleman went to the hat shop or haberdashery and asked for a tweed hat--this is what he'd get. Today these hats have so many names, and all that fuss for a stingy-brim (1.5") trilby fedora!It was good enough for Inspector Clouseau, and I like it well enough. The blend is brilliant, as the wool won't shrink thanks to the polyester. This design is like any other tweed, though I admit it is "crafty", combining a herringbone pattern with a windowpane check. The lining seems like standard cotton, very thin, and the sweatband is polyester grosgrain.The hatband is 100% matched-n-attached, bearing the little Stetson brass rivet-stud.What has to be addressed without omissions is a list of things this hat features--things that may or may not please you. The design of these really is more like a paper cup than a bucket: they narrow quickly toward the crown. The crown is way too low, so this gives a strangled feel. Also the materials are stiff as a board.This one in particular feels too tight ... it isn't, but it feels that way. A lot of quality work (and so-so quality material) went into this hat, so I wonder at a company like Stetson manufacturing these in China. The people of China I love; it's the communists I despise and they run everything there in case you did not know. So let me ask you, how would you like Al Qaida, ISIS or the Taliban making your socks and underwear?That's just about what America is doing when making deals with the communist devil. For that, and an annoyingly tight fit, I deduct two stars. It's a good buy ... however, I say buy at your own risk. The devil drives a harder bargain than you think.DEDICATION: One man who never made deals with devils was my father, who died on 23rd March 2007, aged 98. Pop had one of the first Stetsons made in this "walking" fedora style. It was not a tweed, it was a dark blue plush, if you can believe it. When he wasn't wearing it, I'd swipe it--this was back in the early 70s. That hat gave us decades of loyal service. So ... for you, Pop, for U.S.-made, and for "Old Blue"!

PONY BEADS, ACRYLIC, 9MM X 6MM ~These fantastic, nontoxic and indestructible craft beads are the best on earth. Whatever type of "beader" you are, you must know about these. If you've never used them, I suggest you find an excuse.Going back to one of the sacred arts of my early priesthood, I just laid in a supply of them for making rosaries. They are indestructible and I string them on 2mm Paracord. This makes for an indestructible finished item--whether it's a rosary, jewellery or some other craft.I'm pretty big on the durability part because when I began making rosaries, I mainly used only these beads. I have had old students tell me they still carry their rosaries after decades of use. That is what the right materials will yield. I get mine in brown, which is the color of my religious habit.And I am a Buddhist, by the way. Hindus and Buddhists invented the rosary as we now know it. In spite of my deep fondness for the Orthodox Christian prayer rope of knotted wool, I love to string my own simple rosaries. They are well used, believe me, and I mainly love to give them as gifts.This bead is so tough it is used in the military. At the same time I began doing Buddhist rosaries, a clever Army sergeant made a Catholic rosary with these. Thus began the Rosary Rangers and Rosary Army, whom you may have heard of ... and whose volunteers have provided the military with rosaries since the early 1980s. Even non-Catholics beg their chaplains for one.It may sound boastful, but it is not: great minds think alike! Get some of these and see!WARNING: Avoid this rude, unprofessional seller and get your beads from someplace reliable.

This was truly a film I never expected to see; the franchise was one I thought to be deservedly dead. I was wrong. Here we have parallel introductions, two young brothers, two sisters, a hunky velociraptor-whisperer, a terrible supersaurus and Jurassic World, which I saw immediately as based on Sea World.The rest is a clever homage to JURASSIC PARK--that is, when it's not a Godzilla movie. The director was able to pay deft homages to Spielberg--who produced this--and to my massive annoyance paid too much homage to J. J. Abrams. The acting was what I'd expect: I call it quackting and always blame the director. He wanted every male, regardless of age, to be either John Wayne or Chevy Chase. He wanted every female to be a mix of every female stereotype without any of the charm or charisma Spielberg always got from his actors.The effects are top-notch and nothing less could be expected. This is the garish, nightmarish world envisioned by the original character of John Hammond, and prophesied by Malcolm the Mathematician. Wish I could say more, but that's it. A fun, rousing action film and popcorn viewing garnered this its 4th star. The rest was frankly a waste of time.The depth, the humanity, of Spielberg's original is absolutely absent here. The messages he conveyed to a riveted audience in the mid-1990s are drowned out here, by the endless growls of dinosaurs and screaming victims. I was only glad this did not descend into the land of pure gore--the violence was bad enough. Call me grumpy but I expect more than half-baked acting covered by clever CGI. In a project overseen by Spielberg, I expect him to shine through and show us he still cares about what goes into, and emerges from, a movie.The truly great stuff just wasn't here.

OUR QUEEN (PAL/Region 2 UK format, Dir. Michael Waldman, Narr. Sarah Lancashire, 2013, 90 minutes) is a rich and splendid look at Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II of England. While this covers all the ground and then some of the beautiful Andrew Marr documentary THE DIAMOND QUEEN--but this was done the following year during the Jubilee Year--it too is a must-have and it has some spectacular treats.I was deeply moved by the dinner Her Majesty held for all crowned heads, many who of course are her cousins. Queen Margrethe and Queen Beatrix clearly have sister-like relationships with Her Majesty. Actually witnessing that bond in a documentary is a GIFT! It is also stunning that this documentary could follow DIAMOND QUEEN, on the very heels of its conclusion. This is for almost all intents a sequel.As I have indicated, this is even richer and more special than anything done previously. DIAMOND QUEEN did not have the personal access to Her Majesty that this film has achieved. I never learned how Marr gained access, and this documentary sheds no more light on the subject. But it is marvelous.As an example of the closeness the viewer can feel here, the Jubilee events are revisited--Her Majesty, with the saddest expression I've ever personally seen on her face, had to navigate the Jubilee without His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh. He was in hospital with a bladder infection. The worry is written all over Her Majesty's face.It may have eased things a bit when Prince Charles called her "mummy" during the formal address at the Jubilee, and urged the crowd to cheer loudly enough for Prince Philip to hear them. I do not mind admitting I wept many times during the Jubilee itself, and this film made me squeeze out a few more tears.The documentary follows all the post-Jubilee activities, especially Her Majesty and the Royal Family. The damnable thing that has me in a tizzy is that this is not Region 1 NTSC. When are we going to stop this asinine delay--which in some cases is a hopeless wait! When are we just automatically going to get the dvds available ASAP?!

Prayer Rope, 100 knots, wool, "soft barrel knot" style~Since I have been reviewing rosaries and prayer ropes on amazon, as an avid collector and rosary user, this grey rope seemed good to add. This wool is fine quality and holy Orthodox Christian monks in Macedonia make these every day. This is not the cheap, tightened wool rope you may be familiar with, but a soft heavenly way to tell your beads.Once, I was asked why a Buddhist like myself would want this. Buddhists along with Hindus invented the rosary. Buddhists of every order use rosaries daily. I used to make rosaries in every religious tradition, and now I collect the best ones on earth. The prayer rope, a.k.a. komboskini, is my absolute favorite and always will be. Naturally I respect all sacred things, but it'll shock you to know the Orthodox share the Buddhist tradition in that they see the prayer rope as a tool: nothing more.This particular wool quality and knotting style is my favorite, very common in Eastern monasteries. The skein of wool yarn is like Merino, held and knotted a certain way with great care. The finished rope is spongy, comfortable, joyous to hold in prayer/meditation. Best of all, the rosary is a lifeline that could, ideally, unite the world in peace. Whatever your taste, remember that.Also remember Vodocha Monastery in Macedonia. It'll take the post a few weeks to deliver your rope--and in a few awful cases you'll never get it at all. But don't give up on them because the price you pay supports the monks and that should mean something. Their devotion, lives and souls go into these ropes--and so should yours.

LIVE FREE OR DIE is the story of Episcopalian Bishop V. Gene Robinson, New Hampshire. Bp. Robinson, the first openly gay man anywhere to be ordained a bishop, is a most delightful and fascinating subject. This marvelous Independent Lens production follows Robinson to the Lambeth Conference in London, the annual Anglican bishops' do, to which Robinson was pointedly not invited. Despite death threats, he went anyway but did not participate at the behest of Archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams.There are so many touching scenes and powerful scenes, but there is one that stands out: it is the bishop, alone at some refectory or cafeteria. He complained in an interview that in London he had not only been totally frozen out of Lambeth, he couldn't even eat with his fellow bishops. In the scene, dressed and looking like a lost schoolboy in a simple striped polo shirt, Bp. Robinson glances placidly--yet so sadly--around the room.As a cleric, as a person, I too have been treated like that just for being gay. In that and several other scenes, Robinson charmingly demonstrates what anyone would feel: the deeply wounded child every one of us carries, that early version of ourselves which we remain no matter how old we get. What I loved also are the scenes showing what a fantastic priest Robinson really is. He has a character and charisma akin to that of the Dalai Lama."I wish I could have talked to more people," Robinson says wistfully about his disappointing trip to London.I recall very well when Robinson first hit the media ... which culminated in an under-publicized schism in the Episcopalian Church. My feeling was in concert with the bishops who said the Church needed to end the paradox of prejudice against gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people. Robinson is one contemporary I'd love to meet. This documentary made me all the more anxious to meet him and his wonderful husband.With his fantastic courage, childlike smile and warm heart, Bp. Robinson is one of the most interesting and cogent voices in today's spiritually confused world. I suggest we listen, because this was never about gay marriage or even the consecration of an openly gay man to the Anglican bishopric. It has always been about putting an end to hatred and the use of faith as a battering ram.The Right Rev. V. Gene Robinson is a Senior Fellow at American Progress. He was elected bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire on June 7, 2003, having served as Canon to the Ordinary (assistant to the bishop) for nearly 18 years. He was consecrated a bishop on All Saints Sunday, November 2, 2003, and was invested as the 9th Bishop of New Hampshire on March 7, 2004. I also recommend his book!

Being housebound and crippled, I thought Dell was the best company for a laptop. Laptops had been in my dreams forever, because I would be able to sit in my customary spot and do all my work. We are even paying a colossal monthly charge for wireless. Boy, was I wrong. About everything.From the first day the laptop was screwy. Certainly it works, but takes a lot of training to understand it fully, if you're an old person/laptop virgin like me. The thing is, it never worked quite right. The set-up was a nightmare even though I had an unpleasant slob of a tech come out to do it for me. He was more interested in trying to convert me to Christianity than setting up my PC system correctly.Just under a year after it had all cost me a total of $1,000, the thing gave out on me. No one had ever said I needed to call Dell, so I had it carried to my repairman. The problems with that laptop were beyond the repair team. So I began to tangle with Dell--that is when the true nightmares began.I got a troubleshooting clown from the Philippines, nice enough, smart, but rather useless and a little too giggly for a professional. Then I somehow got handed off to an even bigger idiot, who totally ruined everything for me. Finally I ended in Advanced Escalation, with a rude, obstructive Indian. You see, they are all in India. And they do not want to do anything for the customers.You need to be aware: you buy anything from Dell, and need a little help, you'll get shunted to the Philippines. If things get worse, they'll pass the buck to India. You will never escape whatever Indian person has got hold of your case, and Dell has ground rules that are vaguely reminiscent of Nazi militarism. You'll get nowhere and lose all your money. At this very moment I am still tangling with the brute from India, though I have refused to deal with him further.Philippines and Indians are lively people. They work hard and I am no racist--nor can I afford to be. But I think Americans deserve the honoring of the law of getting what you bargained for, and I never bargained for an obstructive foreigner to ruin my life.What price a computer, dear friends? What price?

EQUAL is the only stuff I use, and I jumped at the chance to lay in a supply. The price for this, for a thousand packets, is spectacular! This is a health issue for me, and I can't afford to lay in supplies of blue agave. But at this price I can have my Equal and keep it handy. This is not for my beloved coffee: I need this for my medications, which I have to make into an oral suspension because I can't swallow pills. I've loved Equal ever since it was first introduced. It's now going to be able to stay that way without worry.

STAR TREK: ENTERPRISE SEASON 4 (final season) was a set I had to buy for the coveted Vulcan trilogy of episodes and of course, for the legendary joke of a series finale, which I am going to assume you know. I really miss this show terribly, but especially this last season in the hands of genius Manny Coto. It only showed what ENTERPRISE should have been--and was, in this final season that almost didn't get made.There are other story arcs here that span more than one episode: the odious racists who tried to take over our Martian colonies, the virus that the Klingons gave themselves, Dr. Arik Soong and his repugnant "augments". In the hands of Manny Coto, the Enterprise and its crew really got to soar. Too bad it was definitely the final season, and the revolting Rick Berman even ruined the series finale, swooping in to wrest Coto's job from him to achieve it.It is clearly hard for me to review any of this without the bitter Berman legacy that has nearly ruined STAR TREK's chances on primetime network TV. When other lesser series are now entering their 11th, 12th and 13th seasons, the heart aches for ENTERPRISE, which had at least a good decade potential had it not been for the enemy, Rick [insert expletive] Berman.

REVELATION: THE END OF DAYS (2-part TV special for History Channel, 2014, approx. 3.75 hours)This TV special was too good to pass up--for anyone. For an ex-Christian, it was pretty spectacular. In short, a goofy reporter and his cameraman find themselves at "the end of days", funnily enough occurring in Louisiana. The antichrist, U.S. President Brandon, has the world as his oyster, with this film cleverly working in all that eerie stuff you may have heard from the New Testament Book of Revelation. My guess is the action is set in America because of the budget (and setting it in Canada would have been laughable).One of the most clever usages of news footage was delicate borrowing from Europe and the Near East. Some of this is like a video diary and the effects are stunning, marvelous, believable. TV footage and even snippets of film--such as CHILDREN OF MEN outtakes--are expertly woven into the story of Armageddon and the Second Coming of Jesus. Of course there are chilling moments here, such as the twisting of Revelation passages and the terrorist-like actions of the Christians. This is nothing new, as the LEFT BEHIND series had some of the same.The acting, innovation, cleverness in this weird Canadian two-part film is all very good. It is a thorough twisting of Revelation, but then a good myth deserves some good rewriting, as the original writers of the New Testament knew well. I think they would have liked this adaptation. That is, had they not closed the canon--and in some cases made the Revelation of John a deuterocanonical book.However, this film was great to watch for what it is: pure cinematic art. How I'd love to congratulate the producers and makers. I seriously doubt they'd want to hear it from an old Buddhist who is descended from Jews and was educated by Jesuits. Ah well â€¦ the film makes up for all that. Just don't expect any deep Sunday school lesson.Which is part of the beauty of this worthwhile show. It will also tell you some of the weird flotsam that floats around in Christian heads.

ME AND EARL AND THE DYING GIRL (2015, 106 minutes) is an incredibly deep, hilarious and tear-inducing film that will redefine teen angst for you, whatever your age. Thomas Mann (a Michael Angarano lookalike) plays Greg, a gorgeous but painfully self-loathing Pittsburgh high school student. His only friend, Earl (first-timer R. J. Cyler) is one of the coolest kids ever--he and Greg have been making hilarious home movies together since childhood.Greg's mother informs him that an acquaintance from school and near neighbor, Rachel (Olivia Cooke), has been diagnosed with leukemia. She essentially forced Greg to go visit Rachel--and a deep friendship blossoms. While Greg can't quite catch it, he and Rachel are incredibly alike. Through this relationship, Earl is ever-present and is yet another teacher for the audience to avail themselves for friendship lessons.This is an artful, sensitive film and is the first time I have ever felt so close to high school characters--as if an actual high school kid directed it. The humor is subtle and fall-down funny, while the drama is real, pointed, sharp just as it is in life. Thomas Mann and Olivia Cooke are two of the brightest young stars I have seen since the kids from HARRY POTTER. The adults in the film are well fleshed out, not just parodies, but they achieve performances that parody adulthood. (Catch that wonderful principal, expelling the kids from school!)The director has a feel for ambience and a gifted eye. He favors narrow, claustrophobic hallways because that reflects high school, but the characters' homes are lovely. Greg Gaines' house is actually the director's childhood home. Therefore, the only film I can compare with this is THE SASQUATCH GANG, and I am obviously loathe to compare them.This film has homages and witticisms you'll miss on the first viewing: I guarantee that. It won't matter, because you will be riveted by this film no matter what. It is going in my collection, and THAT is saying something.

ETERNALLY YOURS represents the sad ending of the great comedies from the 1930s, which I always say are the best ever made. Here Niven is a rush-seeking magician based on Harry Houdini, with Loretta Young as his assistant and later, his wife. The conflict comes when Niven thinks Young still loves him long after she divorces him (plus a surprise about their divorce).Few people would recognize great actor Broderick Crawford as Young's 2nd husband Don, an ex-football player and appealing, gentle soul. I love Crawford from Fellini's IL BIDONE and as a baby boomer, I love Crawford from TV. In fact it is Crawford who brings a ton of great comedy to this--and as usual is bypassed by most critics. But he gives Niven a run for his money both in the dramatic and the comic scenes. The film is also a good example of Niven's early comedy work.Often this film is panned for its corny, derivative script--though I may partly agree with the criticism, this also has a very modern feel to it. The banter is understandable to a modern young audience, the comedy not overdone and the acting is on the level as well. I think the heavy pall cast over this comprises the end of the great 30s comedies, the start of WWII, and in a lot of viewers' minds will be the loss of Harry Houdini just a decade before this film was released. Even Niven's talent (he was a skilled amateur magician) seems to add to the weight of sadness that just permeates this film. That phenomenon needs to be understood.Don't deal harshly with this. Soon Niven and most of Hollywood would be off to the war. Hollywood would lose all its steam and require a couple of years to get it back. Look at the film as a refreshing time when the people really were most like people are today, and you didn't need stupidity or crudity to do comedy."WATCH-FOR" ALERT: the scene when Niven shows he's a martial artist!

CANE, "COSMOPOLITAN", WOOD WITH METAL COLLAR is an absolute favorite. When I had the chance I neglected to buy several of these. Now they are nowhere to be had, and I'm crying the blues. The unique sickle-shaped handle and extra length add to the strength of this superb cane. It is an inch or two longer than the standard 36", and that really helps. It is quality through and through, lightly stained, not painted and durable as the promise of hell. I never walk without it because I was lucky enough to buy one when I should have gotten two. And I wish you luck finding even one!

GHOST HUNTERS: THE COMPLETE FIRST SEASON is a three-disc set that is clumsily transferred, slightly incomplete and partially non-functional. The bonus specials do not even work--not that I would have really wasted any further time trying to see what the bonuses comprised. It was bad enough going back a decade in time and seeing these dummies when the entire group was dopey and excessively young.Since I always appreciated their copying PARANORMAL STATE yet trying a new direction with that genre, I always watch GHOST HUNTERS for a relaxing laugh, but this is just too emotionally dark and drama-queen oriented. I've always said Jason Hawes gets old fast, but to see him once again with his inability to speak proper English, his bad temper (but he never shouts), his endless bullying of Grant Wilson for no reason â€¦ yuck.The extremely irritating presence of Brian Harnois, who has had his share of troubles in the last few years, was also a horror to relive. As stupid as he was, I could neither understand why Hawes kept him, except they were old friends, nor why they didn't try to be nicer and help him somehow. Combine the bickering with ridiculous scenes showing Hawes and Wilson at their old Roto-Rooter day job ... what a trip back in time.And it is a bad trip.My poor little wifey, knowing I like to relax watching this type of mindless paranormal hunting show, found this for me at the Goodwill for 88¢ â€¦ bless her goodwill, kind heart and now how does the poor thing get her 88Â¢ back?!

LOAFER, SUEDE, RUBBER-SOLE, HUSH PUPPIES "WALTER THORPE IIV" (either black, grey, or khaki, made in India) seems to be getting little to no attention so I thought I would wax poetic about this, a combination of my two favorite shoe styles. First off, these are loafers and I don't care what anyone says. They are "slip-on" shoes but a loafer IS a "slip-on"! However, with the thick flat rubber sole, these shoes are also an iteration of my favorite Chinese kung fu shoes (known in America as "Winos" or "skaters shoes").Make a note that these shoes in particular are not only undersized, they are somehow mismatched in widths. My left shoe fit like heaven and my right shoe ... no deal. I had to give them to my wife because they were so badly undersized. So order a size bigger and wider than you think you need. After the "giving-to-the-wife" debacle, I then ordered these in a size larger than I wear. There is, with that pair, STILL a bad fit with the right shoe. What do these folk have against the right shoe? Hausch Proppers seems intent on stealing my right shoe!One thing I noticed the last time I wore these: somehow, instead of looking like nice loafers they looked like house slippers. I was in the grocery store and I felt ashamed. If a shoe looks a certain way, then it matters little how nice it is--if it looks like a slipper well then it IS a slipper. Be careful that this shoe looks right when you wear it. On me it looked bad.Sadly, Huish Poopies everywhere are not quite true-to-size. I reckon they run too narrow, therefore way too small. Another pair of Horse Poppies I own are very oversized. In fact the oversized ones I bought are almost exactly the same dimensions as the undersized ones. How did they accomplish that?! So really, you can only do so much when it comes to knowing your correct size.One thing you can remember is your feet do get fatter (wider, that is) as you get older. No one escapes that fact. Cartilage grows, so as you age, your nose, ears, hands and especially feet actually grow. However, all you can do in the end is hope the cobbler made the shoes right.SELLER NOTE: Seller "ShoeMetro" (if they are even still listed in the future) sells on eBay under another username and pretends ignorance of it. They don't expedite with any courier other than FedEx (which I deplore), no matter how much you beg them. That is just rude and bad business. They are not entirely capable, and are far from professional in handling emails/complaints. They are also not entirely honest about their shipping practices and this is amazon's fault because one can't know what method of shipping is used no matter how much you pay for expedited shipping. While the weirdly undersized shoes get 4 stars, the seller was lucky to get 2!

HUSH PUPPIES "CIRCUIT" LOAFER sold by God-knows-whom is a shoe I decided to add to my reviews because it is the closest to the old formal "pumps" of my youth, and also matches the model "CRAWLEY" by Giorgio Brutini. Actually to be much more precise, these are loafers without any strap or other adornment on the instep. Hush Puppies are made in India (at least this batch). The leather, as to be expected from Hush Puppies, is buttery soft and quite handsome. Their colors for this model vary according to size: they have black, tan and grey suede that looks like it was made from mice. This shoe looks a tad more formal than a penny loafer.The "insoles" are weird, being a sort of half-sole at the heel, ending midway, with the rest just the sort of cloth bed I'd expect to find UNDER a shoe's full insole. I guess that is due to the disgusting habit of wearing loafers on bare feet. The soles remind me of "Croclite", the material used to make Crocs clogs, but they have one hell of a grip. These run not quite true-to-fit [size] because mine are 11EE and I have measured the insides--their 11EE is actually a 12 EE. Oh well. I can still wear them, all I need is to put some Spenco Rx Comfort Insoles, Women's 9-10 / Men's 8-9 insoles in them. (The Spencos come in larger sizes, do not be put off by the listing, see my review.)I hope I can help all you bone-headed shoe shoppers out there, first by saying the biggest boneheads are the darned shoe companies. They just do not adhere to the quality they once offered: Hush Puppies is already lousing up true-to-size fit, as I can now attest. No matter, since it is essential to have one's correct shoe measurements and know the correct sizes to start with: length and width (length is in numbers, width is in letters but you need to measure your feet properly and consult the chart to get the right size for you).YOU need to understand: your feet are 3-dimensional, not just some flat linear measurement or misshapen flat foot-tracing. Feet need room to breathe, flex, work and live--just like you do! WIDTH is the most vital measurement, and it's the one everyone gets wrong. Most men average a width of E, which is now called "wide". You're nuts if you think your feet are "narrow", and the older you get the wider your feet become. Lots of people go limping around in pain, stupidly thinking they can "break in" their shoes but you can't change a finished shoe. They either fit or they don't, but they sure won't "break" and if you keep on with shoes that are too tight you may end up breaking your hip.Though it is my relief to be able to say I never fell because of bad shoes: I notice a lot of amazon reviewers are having severe shoe problems. My feet are exactly size 11EE, and there my grave error started: long ago, I listened to one expert too many and was wearing FIVE sizes too small on their advice. I was wearing size 9 shoes in a C ("medium") width. It is little wonder, then, that I never checked on the horrid state of my feet. They were in constant pain with some awful swelling. One fateful day back then, I simply could not get my feet into any of my shoes. They seemed swollen very badly. But then inspiration came a-callin' and I measured them, checked all over the net and found my correct size. The rest is history, and so far, Hush Puppies have remained in that history. I can't say how long that will last.Hush Puppies will give you fine, gorgeous leather uppers and safe soles, but only you can give yourself the correct shoe size by learning and measuring. For years I actually wore a size 9C, out of negligent ignorance. How stupid is that?? Then I wised up and measured my own feet, triple-checked everything and am as happy as a clam with feet, and shoes that fit! (Well, fit better than they used to, anyway.) Shoes are our best friends! So take your choice: know your size/style, don't compromise--or else just buy Crocs right now and get it over with.

INSOLES, PLAIN BY SPENCO SIZE #5 12/13 (40-212 #5) [MEN'S SIZES 12-13] simply must be reviewed. I was lucky to find these again here on the 'zon ... I had forgotten what the company name was and hadn't owned any for a few years. Insoles ought to be a quality affair but a simple one. Spenco has always been the best deal for the best insoles, high quality, long-lived insoles that won't break your heart or the bank and won't disappoint when you slip them in your shoes. Spenco has always specialized in that best of insole: a good, completely flat foam rubber made like Kryptonite and a sturdy (trademark billiard-table green) cloth layer that helps with perspiration trouble. Best of all, Spencos are designed to fit on top of or beneath orthotics, and are extremely easy to trim if need be.The reason I bought new Spencos is I really needed them: I bought a pair of Hush Puppies Men's Circuit Slip-On Loafer (read my review) and for some weird reason they have no insoles. They had a sort of half-sole then the rest was the normal cloth lining I expect to find beneath an insole. Must be due to the disgusting tradition some men have developed of wearing loafers on bare feet. When I tried them on, I realized I was going to need a pair of insoles and quick because Hush Puppies sized these wrongly! Some memory-diving and a little research helped me find my Spenco babies. Spenco has a myriad size range, which I am going to give you straight off the package, so pay attention. You need to buy one size larger than your shoe size so you have the width (and because Spencos insoles do run short-to-size):0 = ladies 3-41 = ladies 5-62 = ladies 7-8 & mens 6-73 = ladies 9-10 & mens 8-94 = ladies 11-12 & mens 10-115 = mens 12-13 (I wear size 11 extra-wide so I bought these, did not need to trim them and they are a dream)6 = mens 14-15When you see Spencos listed commercially, you'll see a slew of numbers indicating the size but all you need is the Spenco size number...and I just gave them to you. Remember, you should automatically choose the next higher size when buying Spencos for assured true fit (well I wear an 11EE and bought the #5 for 12-13 and didn't have to trim them). Nothing's so handy as a pair of sharp, long scissors for insole-trimming. I have a special pair of scissors just for this job. The Spenco insole is perfect and without peer for any shoe you find that is just plain flat and disappointing on the inside.My parents bought those dead-white, crummy, flat "air pillow" insoles for years (1/16" thick only when new out of the package)--my mother used to sigh and proclaim that it would be better if she cut out her own insoles from posterboard. I must agree. That flat little flimsy insole is still sold on here starting at $10. A disgrace. Or you may choose those overpriced extraterrestrial-type gel monstrosities that absolutely gross me out and are 1/2" thick. Finally you have the $50 "orthotic" insoles, which I can't feature anyone buying without the guidance of an orthopedist MD. You spend less on the cheerful green Spenco insole, and they'll last pretty much the life of the shoe unless you are a swine or a puddle-jumper.Now for some fun. I give you the "official" Spenco spiel, having no idea whence it originally comes, but it sure tells it all:"Spenco RX Comfort Insoles features full length insoles that cushion and comfort from heel to toe. The "Spencore" material's exclusive cushioning ... absorbs shock and impact to provide maximum comfort .... Spenco provides 7 sizes [#s 0-6] for good overall fit, allowing you to find your ideal size. The 4-way stretch fabric with "Silpure" antimicrobial helps prevent blisters while controlling odor. These are lightweight, washable, trim-to-fit with scissors. Heel-to-toe comfort makes any shoe or boot feel like an athletic shoe."

SOAKED IN BLEACH (2015, 88 minutes) is a bare-bones documentary about private investigator Tom Grant's involvement with the search for a missing Kurt Cobain in April of 1994. Grant was hired by Courtney Love to find her estranged husband, who had left a Los Angeles rehab center after Courtney Love had been badgering him there by telephone. Love first turned to Grant to find her husband, possibly to track him, and report back to her. Grant, while employed by Love and searching for Cobain, chanced to hear the news of Cobain's death on the radio. After some additional deep investigating, Grant realized he might be looking at a cold-blooded murder.This documentary is an excellent, stunning exposition of facts but I find one or two things deeply irritating in this case. Grant is either hiding or unable to expose certain things that give his relationship with Courtney Love any sort of coherence. Grant was working for her, certainly, and he continued to work for her well after Cobain was found. This documentary will leave you asking a lot of questions about Grant and not about Cobain's death. As to that, it seems quite obvious the Seattle police did stupid, sloppy work with Cobain's death. It also seems obvious there was foul playâ€”and I often point out that this makes it a legal case not to be bandied around or judged by the public-at-large but by authorities.The other big problem I have with this film is that you don't really need it. Whatever is shown in this film, you can get it from Tom Grant's website. It has the recordings which Grant alleges are his conversations with Courtney Love from April of 1994. On that website, which I read in its entirety, you will see almost what amounts to a transcript of the documentary under review here. Take the time to read Grant's website and you won't need this movie. While I enjoyed the artful and restrained reenactments of Grant's meetings with Courtney Love, I did not think those scenes necessary to the message. The message being that this case must be reopened and investigated to the full, properly, and with an eye on appropriate suspects.We are now just past the 21st anniversary of Kurt Donald Cobain's death. The supposed suicide note he left has been at least partly exposed as potentially suspicious. Courtney Love has made sufficiently weird comments in public. We know Grant worked for Love for an indeterminate length of time after Cobain was foundâ€”Grant does not tell us what sort of work or why he would go so long working for her. He does claim he did this in order to keep her in his sights, but somehow that doesn't wash with meâ€”and it may be mere ignorance on my part, but it seems Grant waited an awfully long time to come forward. Chalk it up to the fact that I'm an old man who reads/listens closely to the news, and I do know the media was blocking Grant, IF he tried to come forward. It is very hard to believe a man of that stature would be utterly ignored by the entire media. It's used as such a common excuse it is hollow coming from Grant.Two posters (originally just one) under my review, with ZERO evidence, tell me Grant came forward in 1994. Well, I was there, following the news all these years since, and have only just heard of Grant. That is somehow wrong, that Grant's name was completely unconnected with Cobain's case, though I can't judge whose fault it may be.I am deeply moved and I ask my questions because I liked Cobain very much (just not his music). It bothered me so much when I heard of his death and as the story leaked out slowly, it struck me right away that he must have been murdered. My friends and I wondered why no one came forward with more information, why the media dropped the entire thing and bought into the suicide story, why no one said a thing except those of us who believed Courtney Love had something to do with it. As I say, no Grant coming forward to save the day, not that I recall. Grant is a hard person to forget and not to be ignored, so where was he? That is based on what I was hearing at the time, and that is all I have to say about what I was hearing.Well, at least Grant spoke, explained what he has regarding this case; at least there is his website and that's free. This is a fine documentary with enough fact in it to be worth buyingâ€”I won't dissuade you. It will help Grant, who I notice is still working and charging the public for his time, but I would definitely read Grant's website first. It's totally free and it will tell you everything this documentary tells. May I also say, the website is as "entertaining" as the film. Grant has done a noble, necessary thing, but I have to wonder whether it will make any difference at this point. Without an authority to reopen this case, no suspect will ever be scrutinized, no arrests will ever be made.A REQUEST: My review/view is clearly enough stated, so please do not come here to post that Grant has been public since 1994. He wasn't around in 1994, is all I recall about him. It is the case of that dog barking last night: you didn't hear it, because it wasn't barking. I did not believe it the 100th time I heard it and I'm not sure I ever will believe it without a citation. And I have commended him amply for finally coming forward with such publicity now.

A GIRL IN EVERY PORT (1951, 86 minutes, PAL Region 2) may very well be the last film in which Groucho got any attention--and it seems to my memory to be the first post-WWII "screwball" comedy. Groucho plays a sailor who is a brilliant small-time crook with 20 years under his belt. He gets mixed up in a silly horse scheme with twin horses and more than one bimbo (what would Groucho be without his babes hanging around?). This film is great for several reasons: it is purely sans pretense of the cinematic bent and in general is just plain bent. The humor is excellent, though Groucho had a tendency to recycle a lot of material. It was difficult since Buster Keaton wrote for him when Groucho wasn't ad-libbing.The thing that gets me is not only the humor of the period, which by the way brought back childhood memories--it is also watching the public death and simultaneous birth of a special type of comedy, the post-Marx Brothers group comedy. The gags actually seem fresh, one of the costars is laugh-out-loud even in scenes with Groucho, and there are lots of street scenes. The older a film is, the rarer the street scenes and it is wonderful to see it from 1951. Then there is Groucho: this was his last starring role, after which he descended into the madness of occasional cameos and TV garbage scows. Personally I was never impressed with his TV quiz show.Before this film, a screwball comedy hardly existed as such--the ones that had been done were always centered around WWII or at east the military. They got stale quick and they were not funny. This film is the granddaddy of those nasty cheap films. William Bendix as Tim, Groucho's best friend and fellow conspirator, gives some laughs that almost made Groucho crack up...and Teddy Hart plays a squeaky-voiced mobster whose voice will make you laugh no matter what he says.  What struck me as funny about the movie was the massive number of stars who went uncredited for some weird reason. The hilarious lieutenant of the Navy, one of the funniest actors I have ever seen, was a total mystery.Get this as part of your "it was a cheapo and I coulda done worse" dvd shelf. As for me, whenever I see a movie like this I simply think, "I'm already spoken for, but...I'll listen to your proposition." Or in Groucho's other immortal line, get it to kill two birds with one stone because there is a shortage of stones.With the talents of Don DeLore, Gene Lockhart, Dee Hartford and Percy Helton.
