MALA (a/k/a JAPAMALA, BUDDHIST ROSARY), PLAIN CHINESE STYLE, BEADS APPROX. 6MMThis is a product with which I am all too familiar and I once owned over a dozen. This is one of the most common gifts I enjoy giving, but these days....This mala is advertised as "Tibetan sandalwood" and it is neither. Oh, Tibetans make these as quick knock-offs to make money, for sure. However, beyond geographical distinctions, this is no more Tibetan than a cup of Nestle cocoa. This is the "plain Chinese style" with 108 beads, a larger "guru" bead that has a little Dharma Wheel instead of a tassel.The wood, the species of which I am not going to begin to guess, is NOT sandalwood and that is the main point of irritation. To the practicing Buddhist, materials matter when it is the difference between sandalwood and not sandalwood. Whether or not it is Tibetan is of absolutely no matter, but I say it is dishonest to call it what it is not. So two strikes against this thing. However, as malas go, it is a very fine one in and of itself. The trouble is certain practitioners in America get pretty picky about their rosaries.As a former rosary maker in all traditions and as a collector, to say nothing as a Buddhist priest, I find some of the mala listings to be downright alarming. A few malas have been pulled because their descriptions stated "sandalwood" and they were plastic beads. Others got pulled because their descriptions lied in similar ways. This has a fine, strong cord (some customers say it is elastic which is the wave of the future) and the Dharma Wheel is a little plastic thingie wrapped in the same cord they used to use to string the beads.So at this price and with beads this size, I can't complain about the price. However, I always advise customers to return something that is not what the description states. Amazon should be notified about such practices also, because rosary dealers are an unscrupulous lot. As a curator of old, I know this all too well. My preference is for the Orthodox wool "prayer rope". At least with that I know exactly what I am getting and it serves me the same as a crummy string of chipped wooden beads.A final warning: although I applaud this seller for coming right out and saying these are shipped from Hong Kong, which I support in and of itself, beware that anything coming from China is going to take a LONG time to be delivered. The seller's honesty in this matter earned them their 4th star. Try to get expedited shipping of some sort and get a tracking number. I always recommend getting the seller to use Air Mail. They don't like it in China, but it speeds up, protects and insures your shipment.

OKABASHI COPENHAGEN CLOG (a/k/a OKABASHI CLOG) ~ This is one hell of a clog no matter what kind of high-muckety-muck you think you are. This excellent, simple one-piece rubber clog is categorized as a "gardening clog"--for obvious reasons. I wore these for quite a while in the wrong size (a terrible, long and stupid story I will not relate here). Even so, they served the purpose. These one-piece rubber clogs are excellent in summer (nice ankle-length white cotton socks recommended by me) and quite warm and cozy for winter. Even though I typically wear such things as house slippers, these are obviously made for serious running-about-town.Some say Okabashi paved the way for Crocs and I agree. The Crocs Women's Cobbler Clog strikes me as a direct descendant of these Okabashi Copenhagens, but then what do I know. Okabashis were my go-to sandals until I was seduced away by Crocs. Naturally I was the first clog/mule nerd in my state to buy Copenhagens when they were first introduced. However, the awful difference in prices between the two brands is painfully evident. I just bought two pair of Okabashi's Copenhagen Clogs for the price of one measly Crocs Cobbler Clog.Well, aside from the plain-jane Croc, what shoe can give so much comfort, have so much life in it, AND be hosed in the yard or washed off in the shower?--I ask you! Now for just one tiny bit of practical advice: unlike Crocs, Okabashi's unique rubber formula means a slight sensation of stickiness when they are new. Do not fret as that goes away fast--only be advised. These clogs are basically the best for the money, for the purpose and then some. I ask you to please appreciate and invest in a couple of Okabashi's Copenhagen Clogs. Try the sandals too, but beware of those: their quality has slipped in recent decades.A few final words of advice about these clogs, if you're not yet familiar with them. First of all, they are not easy to just kick off your feet. Part of their wonder, an Okabashi trademark, is their structured and textured interior. That will grip your feet, and many gardeners or sporting people like to wear these without socks. Just so you know, they will sort of grip your feet somewhat. Secondly, be aware that these are very heavy. I believe these are the heaviest shoes I own, and I have fine loafers, canvas kung fu shoes, lots of Crocs--nothing is this heavy. It is because of the special rubber Okabashi uses.A final word of warning: there is apparently no quality control employed in the sizing of these shoes. You may get a slightly longer or wider than expected pair--but I tell you, they'll fit well wither way. What, you thought you were getting Italian hand-made-by-mountain-peasants shoes here? These are rubber-mold gardening clogs! All the more reason to give yourself a bit of leeway and order a size larger, if you're doubtful. I did not have to do that, but I ordered two pairs in one go: one pair is most certainly wider than the other but I can still wear either pair satisfactorily.

THE COMPLETE FATHER BROWN MYSTERIES (2013 edition) is certainly a Godsend for the Kindle or in hardback for a rainy dark weekend or a stuck-indoors scenario of any kind. Chesterton's brilliant Catholic priest, who solves mysteries because he knows what criminals are like, is on full display here. I know Chesterton books can be found as limited titles and as crummy old paperbacksâ€”so I am grateful I could get this edition on Kindle for 99 cents. However, I don't really know what they mean when they say it is annotated or has "rare" material. It has nothing of the sort. That cost it a star.It's fine by me: I love reading about the world's greatest detective, who in the stories is actually the Chief of Police of Paris, Valentin, who in the very first story literally says with regard to Fr. Brown that he wishes to bow to his "master". Nothing beats Chesterton and what everyone says is true: whatever you find in the well-known detective canon was first conceived by Chesterton. In a way, Chesterton foresaw what readers in the future would want from a good mystery; no shock there since it was the same in his time. But there is something about the tiny, gnome-like, large-headed, round-faced and stupid-looking Fr. Brown that Chesterton knew was pure magic.As a priest Brown is apparently absent-minded and sometimes seems a little derelict. He has a way of arranging himself that is like an old lady fussing on a train; he is forever losing, or planting like a conquering flag, his sturdy old English umbrella. He seems glued to his shovel hat (what we know today as a "parson's hat"). But he is always on fire in his mind, always looking, always solving. He knows crime inside and out, from the petty to the vicious. Chesterton has a way of writing--I love the way he describes Valentin's working methods and philosophy for example--that tells me he was a student of the great early 19th century detective Eugene Vidocq. However, when Father Brown waxes poetic (and theologic) it is spellbinding prose.Let me give you a taste of Chesterton's famous riveting simplicity, which has a message that, as Chesterton always does, rings true as ever: "In the heart of a plutocracy tradesmen become cunning enough to be more fastidious than their customers. They positively create difficulties so that their ... clients may spend money and diplomacy in overcoming them...." Another example is when Father Brown himself compares ghosts to beggars. Chesterton has this simple poetry in his writing that makes these mysteries so beautiful and enjoyable to read.This is a must for any lover of reading. This edition is complete Chesterton and that's the main thing. Especially with Father Brown of the Church of Rome, there is a continuity that Chesterton wanted his readers to follow, to make all the stories seem as they ought: sequels of each other. If you know Chesterton's work, then this is the edition I strongly recommend. If you don't know his work at all, what the heck are you awaiting, a divine calling?!

HOMBURG, STIFF WOOL FELT, NOT CRUSHABLE BY BAILEY'S OF HOLLYWOOD is a supremely fine, well-crafted felt hat. As my title says, it is the "prince of men's dress hats" (in fact it is the king) and I love that compared to the odious "godfather" name this hat was given decades ago. This hat by Bailey's of Hollywood is a bit stiff in cost, but it is well worth it really at this level. You will not find a Homburg anywhere else in this price range, because if you do it won't be a true dress hat but a costume hat.This has good stiff wool felt, I'd grade it no more than XX and that is being generous but it is of no real consequence. I've had mine for years and it still looks brand-new. The sweatband is a beautifully comfortable, cushioned yet very thin cotton fabric. The model I have is lined with some sort of colorful, really well-fitted lining and I'd say the crown indentation (the "gutter") is no more than about 4.5 inches at most. The total crown height must be around 5.5 inches. The brim is a good 3 inches or thereabouts, and curls to perfection. You just do not know what "class" means until you have seen one of these. Best of all, you can wear this hat with any style clothing. Remember, this is a type of fedora and a fedora is THE men's hat.A word about the fit: a Homburg is meant to look like it sits a bit higher on your head than you may be accustomed to seeing. It is perhaps the most comfortable of dress hats, but it is meant to perch a bit high on your head. The last thing you want is this hat bending your ears like some kind of goofy elf. This is not a "high hat" (that is a top hat) but it is meant to be worn when a top hat is not needed. Well today, top hats aren't needed. Do not worry about looking like a gangster either: this hat has class and it is of royal blood for a reason. If you want mob boss-looking hat get a wide-brimmed Borsalino fedora, ya dÃ©classÃ© bum.But the Homburg is the Prince. Here is why I keep saying that: when King Edward VII was still the Prince of Wales, he enjoyed visiting Germany and seeing his relatives there. In the city of Homburg, he spotted a lot of gentlemen wearing this, a type of fedora he had never seen. He bought a few dozen of them, being a great hat lover, and created a fashion. That very same year the world was flooded with Homburgs and Homburg knock-off styles. In fact this modern style, which is our generation's true recension of the original Homburg, is as genuine as it gets. The original style was somewhat larger in dimensions and had a flatter brim.It makes no matter, said the hatter. All you need is to look at this and see it is, in reality, the KING of hats. Whether going to a wedding or some weird folk art festival, this is all you need. Just remember one final bit of advice: this is stiff hat-wool, so keep it safe when you must remove it and get a HAT-STAND for it to keep when at home. This is one hat that will make you weep bitter tears if you crush it (nah: it can be reblocked which is a sign of quality). And there is one final, wonderful thought perhaps only I could have given you. Anyone interested in detectives or mysteries should know every great literary detective wore a Homburg. That's right, from Poe's C. Auguste Dupin to Sherlock Holmes to Hercule Poirot, they all wore a hat like this on a routine basis.So what if Ms. Marple did not wear one? So what if Chesterton's short-lived Paris police chief Valentin committed suicide and left his collection of Homburgs behind? So what if "the cheap detectives" of the 1930s and 1940s only wore giant fedoras? Get a Homburg and you, too, will cut a memorable, dashing and classy figure! You won't even need to solve anything except, perhaps, why you never wore a Homburg before.

NEWSBOY CAP ("WINNER" MODEL, made in the U.S.A.) in Irish linen by Emstate is another classic example of that affordable wonderful newsboy style. This cap is made of Irish linen (it may be a tad warm for some people since linen is made out of flax) with a 100% polyester sheer lining. It has an elastic sweatband (which I don't like that much) so it's a one-size-fits-all and the front of the cap, per tradition, snaps to the brim. I don't like that feature on a newsboy either, but there it is so I'll live with it.One thing I have to address is some complaining I have seen about this cap being way too large in its outer diameter. They are supposed to be that way, ignorant folk. I saw oceans of these when I was a boy. They are bÃ©rets with visors, that's all. This way you could move it around and let the cap settle where you liked it without having to tilt the angle of it on your head: that is to keep the visor in place. Squared on your head, facing forward.To that end I must complain about the elastic sweatband. Everything is quality and the linen is beyond reproach (the Tartan-patchwork model is exquisite), but I just hate an unstructured sweatband especially of elastic. My head is very large and these just fit me, so I suspect they'll do well for nearly everyone--but it might be a bit large for you. As for myself, I had to trim little notches in strategic places to relieve the tightness of the band. In my view that's where Emstate cut corners in order to offer a good price. It's a pity, but this is the way our economy rolls now.If you are a goofy pre-middle-aged fashion-plate wannabe, I suggest you try this out and determine if it is your look or not. These newsboys, which are known by half a dozen other names, are not for everyone. This style is much softer than newer-type models, with a softer material for the visor and the elastic sweatband. As I said, picture a bÃ©ret with a visor and go from there. Lots of men love this style and really don't care how big the cap is, but if you are expecting a baseball cap fit, then get a baseball cap!These caps appeal to a fashionable old Buddhist monk in his declining years, not just to keep my bald head warm (yes, for some of us it gets cold in summer too, hence a linen cap) but also to keep me looking awesome! And if you decide this is your style, get a couple in wool for fall/winter. There are better sales/selections in the wool models--then you can be comfy in the right cap and look awesome like I do, all year round! So if it does not cause a minor revolution, allow me to present yours truly wearing the Tartan patchwork model--and please forgive the grainy quality. Now you have an idea what these caps really are!

CAP, "NEWSBOY" by Broner (a/k/a CABBIE, APPLE, SPITFIRE, GATSBY, IVY) has only one true name: "newsboy". It has various monikers that include the name "New York" (as in "New York Apple", "New York Cabbie") but as the British say, you knows 'em when you sees 'em.This marvelous linen cap is made of 8 panels with a large button on top, a short, broad visor and according to its accurate description is fully lined with lovely cotton material and a fully padded sweatband. All of those things, I might add, are de rigueur with a newsboy cap. Some of the unlined abominations might as well be (YUCK) baseball caps.These are in their finest form nothing more than bÃ©rets with visors. This is great because you can adjust the direction your cap slouches, but I'm afraid nowadays the diameter is somewhat lacking. When I was a kid, these things were the size of a bÃ©ret. Today they are more like a Greek Fisherman cap or a puffy cricketing cap. I don't mind those but I happen not to like this hybrid as much as I love the old floppy newsboys I saw so much in my youth.It was that great actor David Suchet (you know him as Hercule Poirot) who got me hooked on these caps. I had a friend who always wore one and he just looked stupid in it. That always put me off. Suchet, who always wears one to keep his pate warm, really got me hooked on these because he had a fine, stylish one that looked amazing. I resemble Suchet so I thought that comfy-looking newsboy might be a good solution for my bald head, too. And it is! I own several in cotton for the summer, and with a longer visor they give excellent protection from the sun.Best of all are the wool models for fall/winter. They really have become the classy, go-to cap for nearly any occasion, are comfy as anything you could want, and are not nearly the hassle of a hot, unlined wool bÃ©ret. The visor prevents them from being rolled and stuffed into a pocket but then you need never remove it for very long. Tip your cap as etiquette demands, yes, otherwise leave it where it belongs. It's a great buy--I've seen these going for upward of $55--and is nice, well-fitted and versatile. I wonder how I lived so many decades without one.A word about size: this should fit any normal adult male quite comfortably. This specific style has a bit of elastic sewn into the sweatband at the back, which will expand for you if your melon is bigger than a melon. Usually I warn against such elasticized caps, but this is reliably true-to-size and well-made. However, if the elastic is better suited elsewhere, it is easy enough to rip the seam that holds it in place and slip it right out: I have done that several times, no problem. If I am not careful I am going to wind up with two dozen of these babies!

WE STEAL SECRETS: THE STORY OF WIKILEAKSThis slightly outdated 2013 documentary, for all its music-video attempts at being "hip" and addressing a young audience, I found to be dispassionate and objective. Bearing in mind that Julian Assange refused to take any part in this whatsoever, I watched it with great interest to get at least a chronology of events and an understanding of the WikiLeaks nightmare. At just over two hours, there's not as much here as you might think but it is an easy watch if you can surmount the problem of people mumbling (which I put down to bad production).As a well-read reviewer on amazon, I want to be clear about my stance: I believe in equal justice for all, I know the justice systems around the world are somewhat broken, and I do not ever tolerate a witch-hunt. That is all I have to say about this matter. As to a deeply personal opinion, I have never liked the persona of Julian Assange as I have seen him over the years. He seems like a snotty, antisocial hacker and nothing more.This documentary exposes him as a cad, a liar, and generally a scumbag. It stops there, of course, because all that is based on the interviews with his friends. His enemies don't seem to have been interviewed but the stock media clips and other bits address that very amply. Pfc. Brad Manning, who leaked 250,000 classified documents to WikiLeaks in 2010, is summarily dealt with--rather too summarily I think. Guess I'll have to wait for Manning's story in the future, IF it is ever made into a film or written as a book. In case you wondered or forgot, Manning was sentenced to 35 years in prison in 2013, with credit for the 3.5 years he spent in the hole, held by the Marines in the brig at Quantico.The value of this documentary is its concentration on the intel related to the Iraq War which Manning gave to WikiLeaks. There is further material, in which even President Obama is accused of "war crimes" in the Iraq War, which I found totally bizarre. You'll have to watch this and see for yourself--but do not judge too rapidly, because this is a legal case and not a public opinion bath. As for Assange, I can state that he remains sequestered in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London, unable to complete his asylum-seeking under refugee status. He is not being allowed out of the embassy by the British authorities, and if he could get out, he'd flee to Ecuador.The whole thing is a mess and a headache. What this documentary did show me is that there is a witch-hunt being perpetrated against Assange, some of it thanks to his own arrogance, but I have already made clear what I think about that. America, the UK and in some part Sweden are all in this witch-hunt together, according to the reliable news this documentary is quoting. Assange has been in the Embassy for some years now. The internet is rather silent as to anything new, and as for Manning, he was hoping for a pardon from President Obama as of 2013 when he was sentenced but there is nothing newer.It is of interest to note that Assange did cooperate fully with two new film projects, one I only know as his story (I think Benedict Cumberbatch plays Assange) and one other film about which I know nothing. Get this documentary and forget the others who say you can't trust what is in it. People are speaking to the questions put to them, and you need a proper mind/attention span to understand that. Those who put Assange on a pedestal need to recall that even Mother Teresa wasn't Mother Teresa. Our Founding Fathers were liars, cads, skirt-chasers and God knows what else.It is the actions of a person that count, and really nothing else. I cannot think of another person in history to compare with Assange. All that can be done is to find a frame of reference--we may not like what we learn about the Founders, but look at what they did. Look at what Mother Teresa did. Look at what Hitler did. I leave you with one thought: those who commit great evil could never have done a thing without the many who support them. Hitler, who is always named solely in mentions of WWII atrocities, could not have killed over 6 million people had it not been for the other 6 million who helped him every step of the way. Let us not forget that--and please don't accuse me of comparing Assange to Hitler. Another lesson I learned is to be very precise and careful when comparing anything to Hitler...it's better not to do it at all, and I didn't do it here.

I KNOW WHERE I'M GOING (Dirs. Michael Powell, Emeric Pressburger, 1945, 91 minutes) is the delightful yet somehow weirdly Scottish-foggy story of English about-to-be-wed Joan Webster (Wendy Hiller, a stunning Oscar-winner of her era who drooped into cameos). Ms. Webster, from a respectable well-off working-class English family, plans to marry the wealthy middle-aged industrialist Robert Bellinger. They plan to hold their wedding on Kiloran Island in the Hebrides.Trouble (and film plot) begin when Ms. Webster gets trapped on the outer island of Mull, due to the gale-force storm surrounding the islands. It is this that delights me more than anything in the film; I am too young to recognize most of these actors for the most part but they speak some darned good Scottish Gaelic, fluently and frequently, peppering the film with one of my favorite languages. That canna be faked, ladies and lassies! It is in fact the only film I know of to feature the Scots Gaelic spoken by my own ancestors. Seeing the men running about in their flat caps or Scots bonnets, rain capes and island coats, a few kilts here and there...it was HEAVEN.There is even a local castle--the typical massive Scottish ruins, that is--and it looks just like Urquhart Castle on Loch Ness. HEAVEN.That's right: it's a Scottish movie, no way round that, and it loves and respects Scotland as it should! Ms. Webster meets the local laird and chieftain, Torquil MacNeil (Roger Livesey) with whom she naturally falls in love as they are much thrown together on the Island of Mull. One is cradled and warmed by the gentle, natural eccentricity of Lord MacNeil, along with his goofy pal, local falconer Col. Barnstaple (played by Capt. C.W.R. Knight, F.Z.S.).A stunning sequence that I love is a desperate moment of weakness when Ms. Webster, fearing the worst, talks a young fisherman into taking her to her final destination in spite of horrid gale-force winds and a nasty legendary whirlpool (Corrybreckan, the second largest whirlpool in the world, located in the Strait of Corrybreckan, between the islands of Jura and Scarba, off the western Scottish coast). Lord MacNeil shows up to assist, they sail...and almost die. The sequence is eye-popping because they are on the edge of the whirlpool just as Lord MacNeil saves the day and sails them back.Well, this is a sort of forgotten classic, and Wendy Hiller sadly is best remembered today as the elderly Princess Dragomirov from Murder On The Orient Express (see my review). A pity as I say, because she is also memorable for her fantastic turn as the tough hotel owner in the beautiful Terrence Rattigan movie Separate Tables [Blu-ray] (see my review). The sheer beauty, the genuineness, the unusual respect for a culture other than British or American, it all conspires to give us a film worthy of cinema history.No matter what manner of films you love, you can't miss this wonderful, rather weird and incredibly funny movie. The humor is natural and occurs as it would in real life--no strain is seen anywhere except in the attempts at Scottish accents by a few of the actors. I have a feeling extras may have been Hebrideans due to the way they speak, lapsing in and out of Gaelic. This was filmed in Argyll and Bute, Scotland, so one also must respect the classic, incomparable effort.Finally, let us never forget Wendy Hiller, who sank into somewhat degraded or cameo television roles even though she landed a good part now and again in films--after her salad days were done. I can't even find out why she fell from that uppermost celestial star sphere of Oscar-winning women where she kept Katherine Hepburn company. A woman of that magnitude should never be cast aside. This film will help ensure that she is not!

REVERSI (A/K/A OTHELLO, IAGO, REVERSES) by AI FACTORY LTD. is a brilliantly animated, quite spirited game. It should get the full rack of stars. It should cause gushes of joy. There's just one problem with it:IT CHEATS. Don't believe me? Just watch for it the way you would watch a live opponent who cheats. AI has programmed this game not to seize all its legally won pieces when it should; that's a foul right out of the rulebook. Instead it perpetrates an infinite whammy by making a clever move against you then NOT seizing its legally won pieces when it should. It leaves those in play in order to execute its overall plan. There are unscrupulous players who develop bad habits such as this immediately disqualifying tactic--which is what has happened over at AI Factory.The rulebook for this has always clearly stated that seizing the captured pieces (that is, flipping them over) must occur immediately or it's an immediate disqualification. Think about it: that particular cheat defeats the entire purpose of the game. But this game will do precisely that. I played it determined to watch exactly when the game will kick into cheating mode: it does it whenever it is in danger of losing a match.  That is a total deal-breaker. Don't waste your money on thieves like AI Factory Ltd.

SCOTS BONNET, "BALMORAL" STYLE, PLAIN RIBBON TRIM, RED TOORIE POM-POM is a must-have for the inveterate cap-wearer. It is also a sort of crossover item because any bÃ©ret-lover will love a Scots bonnet. However, the Balmoral is of a slightly different make. Whereas a plain bonnet is just a bÃ©ret, the Balmoral is somewhat different. This plain model will be more comfortable than the ones with the wide checkered trim known as "dicing".But the cap stands up a bit, since it has the classic cockade bow on the side and is structured upward a bit from the trim unlike a typical bÃ©ret. These caps are fully lined, great quality materials including the wool, and just very dashing as a fall/winter cap. Do not forget to order in your precise hat size because the adjusting ribbon at the back is a mere decoration. I own two of these and believe me, on a cold night, even indoors, it is nice to have one of these at hand to help keep warm. It is a fine fashion statement, looks dignified no matter what anyone says, and I just don't understand why these are not becoming normative in America. Better to see an ocean of these than the universally God-awful stupid baseball cap!

GLENGARRY, FINE NEAT BLACK RIBBON TRIM WITH RED TOORIE (POM-POM) simply must be reviewed. You should know by now that this is a Scots bonnet that has been folded in half--it is said the lazy men of the Glen of Garry abused their bonnets this way--and I trust you've seen these on regimental and pipers' heads. This is a quality, fully lined cap made of the finest thick wool with the lining and ribbons/trimming in polyester. Pity they quit using 100% silk in the lining and ribbons. This is a supremely comfortable cap and it really looks fine on anybody. Be sure you get your exact hat size because the drawstring ribbon at the back is fake: they're just sewn on these days and that is NOT a sign of low quality. It would be, in fact, very hard to find a Glengarry of low quality. So at this price, why wait? Get one and see how wonderful it is for the fall and winter.This is in fact the type I wear because I do not care for the wide checkered trim known as "dicing". It is beautiful and comfy, my wife says I look like a Catholic priest wearing a biretta, and it draws compliments every time. There is no debating the overall quality of these caps and thank heavens we can now get them fairly easily here in America. You don't have to be Scottish, a piper or in a regiment to wear one of these and get envious stares! Best of all is the comfort of this cap--I compare them favorably with a plain bÃ©ret.

GLENGARRY, RED-DICED TRIM WITH RED TOORIE (POM-POM) simply must be reviewed. You should know by now that this is a Scots bonnet that has been folded in half--it is said the lazy men of the Glen of Garry abused their bonnets this way--and I trust you've seen these on regimental and pipers' heads. This is a quality, fully lined cap made of the finest thick wool with the lining and ribbons/trimming in polyester. Pity they quit using 100% silk in the lining and ribbons. This is a supremely comfortable cap and it really looks fine on anybody. Be sure you get your exact hat size because the drawstring ribbon at the back is fake: they're just sewn on these days and that is NOT a sign of low quality. It would be, in fact, very hard to find a Glengarry of low quality. So at this price, why wait? Get one and see how wonderful it is for the fall and winter.

SEPARATE TABLES has always been my personal favorite of Terrence Rattigan's plays. When the Oliviers were approached for the film and agreed to take on a double role each, well, let's just say thank heaven they didn't go through with it. And thank heaven for Burt Lancaster stepping in as producer--which saved us from the presence of the Oliviers. Since so many have reviewed this excellent film, I can weigh in with my little eccentricities as I see fit. Firstly, this is a stunning and marvelous portrait of a gathering of hotel-dwelling English folk (Lancaster and his old flame are the only American characters, with the addition of a young Rod Taylor, an American playing a Brit).It seems to me this film has always been a most generous and understanding display of common humanity in the face of far more common human frailty. Each and every person here has demons or struggles to battle and conquer--most of them are frightened by something or other. Badly frightened. When nearly everyone pitches in to whatever degree they can to assist each other, this becomes more than a Rattigan play. It is a tour de force for David Niven as the Major, who is discovered, after four years' residence, to be a fraud. He is nothing more than a lieutenant with a respectable WWII record in a West Indian office--certainly not the desert fighting hero he has claimed to be, and to top it all off he's a "dirty old man". He's my favorite character.This film's setup may seem odd to the audience of today: who lives in hotels for years at a time? What sort of ordinary, normal people go looking for companionship in a lonesome situation such as that? It was very common in the old days, and I recall such places from my youth. It seems far more common in England for some reason. Rattigan's powers of drama are in the deep, hidden things, the everyday battles, hatreds, bigotries and lies. The little white lie that harms no one and in truth is most hurtful, bordering on evil. The monkey on the back, the demon raging inside because there seems no other option, the innocent weakness in the face of dominance. Rattigan understood politics and governments, all right, but he presented his rhetoric in everyday people we can still identify with today.The moments of humor are subtle and natural. Nothing is ever forced, and life unfolds before our eyes until it suddenly strikes us that each and every character is a version of the same, single person. A youth, filled with hopes and desires, working hard for the future while paying no heed to the dangerous obstacles out of innocence, an innocence that vanishes leaving one wondering when and how it all happened. When did it pass us by, when did it all go so terribly wrong? Even in one's autumn years, living only with painful memories about to erupt and never quite erupting, the truth is we all want love. Compassion, forgiveness and understanding come with that--it is truly a single, simple thing. No one could grasp it and write it like Rattigan.Rattigan simultaneously shows us what is the matter with generalized political concepts. The exaggerated English archetypes, the two American archetypes that seem to frighten the British the most. These speak to American and English politics in an intimate way, even referencing socialism and communism without any prejudice. Is the hotel not a commune, with a socialist air about it? Even the owner, the tough English woman who must keep her cool, keep it all pulled together, smacks a bit of the "benevolent" dictator. That is all I have to say. This is a timeless classic, and while you may find it unbearable, boring or just plain silly, I still say you need to watch it at east three times. I have seen it a dozen times, and each time for me is the first time. Each time, I see something new, I learn something different.Rattigan grows on you then changes with you as you grow, and SEPARATE TABLES is his finest testimony to humanity.

MONSIEUR VERDOUX (Writ./Dir. Charlie Chaplin, based on an outline by Orson Welles, 1946, released in Sweden et al., 1947, 124 minutes) represents one of the very few times I have actually studied a film before viewing it. This approach is a personal old habit of mine but as I say, I almost never do this--I don't even like seeing reviews of films I am about to review.Set in France in the 1930s, we find Msr. Henri Verdoux, a banker who is fired after 30 years excellent, dedicated service. It is almost a persecution, as all such firings are--it unleashes a monster. Verdoux, very much in love with his wife, realizes the only way he can support her and survive is to marry then murder wealthy women. He manages to find the most repulsive women, and for Verdoux, as he says it himself, it is "business", not murder. Verdoux's argument: if you murder some, you're a murderer; murder millions and you're a hero. His condemnation of war and other forms of genocide such as starvation and prejudice: "Numbers sanctify."The Hitchcockian brilliance of this film (which undoubtedly inspired Hitchcock) lies in Chaplin's ability as a director to get exactly what he wants, every time. A smooth tracking shot up a twisting flight of stairs, a sequence at a nightclub where the dancing couple is yet isn't the primary thing in the scene...all brilliant. When Verdoux meets a young woman who is somewhat like him, he takes a shine to her. When she succeeds in life by marrying a munitions manufacturer, Verdoux gives himself up, and off to the guillotine he goes. In that closing scene, as he walks away with his back to the audience, we see the Tramp one last time. it is Chaplin reaffirming to the audience that it is he.A great deal of this truly sad film is about what might have been, what could have been, and not so much about murder. Alec Guinness got his huge break from such a film, Kind Hearts And Coronets (see my review). The trouble is the film was instantly hated in the U.S. No one was willing to give it the slightest attention, and perhaps it was a blunder of Chaplin's to expect Americans to get the point. Verdoux IS Chaplin: suddenly kicked in the behind after years of dedication and hard work. A man soon to be thrown from the U.S. A man heckled and hated by McCarthy's witch-hunt. Even Welles, who pushed for the credit, pawned it off on Chaplin in an act of personal cowardice.This film is well worth seeing precisely because it is so out of character. Chaplin had been deeply immersed in the idea of resurrecting Verdoux somehow before his wife Oona convinced him to do A King In New York/ A Woman Of Paris instead (see my review, but only for KING). I'm not certain in what way Chaplin might have "resurrected" Verdoux, so the story might be scurrilous. If anyone could have done it, it would have been Charlie Chaplin. Verdoux meant so much to him because Verdoux's feelings represented the way Chaplin really felt, and Chaplin easily identified with this serial killer who was based on two real-life murderers.Martha Raye, who plays an American woman, represents the ideals Chaplin admired. She is the woman he cannot kill and she really steals the scenes she's in. What I feel is completely missed by everyone here is the concept that a decent, ordinary man has been changed into a monster--in other words, driven insane. The idea that murder-for-gain is "business" paints a picture of a horror that could happen to almost anyone. Martha "The Bigmouth" almost saves him from himself, but it can't be--it has to be something else that finally moves him to hand himself to the authorities.Even unto the bitter end, he hasn't regained his sanity. He goes away knowing he continued to do whatever he had to do to survive. The love for his wife was no excuse, but the profound reason for his murders. Chaplin was feeling this role, that's true, but the film is a warning. The Tramp wants to get the last word and remind us that we make every one of our own monsters. Then who should we blame?

THE SECOND BEST EXOTIC MARIGOLD HOTEL was a pleasant two hours of basically reliving a beautiful original film (see my review The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel). Since there are no doubt wonderful, detailed reviews I will keep mine uncharacteristically simple. I want to start by wondering aloud why this film was made at all: the original film was a perfect, whole universe to itself. It was not a film one would have ever thought would be used to produce a sequel.As sequels go, this moves powerfully with its cast (sans Wilkinson of course, and with the asinine addition of Richard Gere plus a wonderful cameo by David Strathairn) and smoothly with its rather anemic story. The original film left us with that indescribable magic of being able to extensively imagine a sequel for ourselves without ever expecting--or, indeed, wanting--an actual sequel to be produced. This movie is, in that sense only, the worst sequel I have ever seen. It tells us nothing, short-changes every single character in it, and actually has no decent or coherent storyline.Yet I loved it. Oh, not half as much as I love the original MARIGOLD, but I love it just the same. It certainly caught my eye and I took the proper time I love to take to fall deeply into a film. The cinematography is spectacular; the acting I have already vouched for; the scenery is more comfortable and less crazed than in the original movie; the dialogue is actually so funny it is sweet. Yet I ask again: what was it all for, why make it? My first and last impression was they simply must have had lots of leftover footage (I can't prove that naturally but the stupid Bollywood number near the end rather convinces me), contrived a storyline and threw this together.I can promise you this: it is not close enough to the perfection of the original, and you will need to watch the original before you see this. Not only because they were naturally forced to do this in "sequel shorthand" but also because it is otherwise pointless to waste time watching it at all. It is as if everything left to our imaginations from the first film got crammed inelegantly into this sequel--it is one of those events that leaves you with a single, nagging word echoing in your mind: in this case the word is, "unnecessary".If you decide to just hit it cold watching this film, I recommend you give it a couple of viewings: the sound is dreadful for some reason and the dialogue is spit out at astonishing speeds. It adds up to making you feel you are truly losing your hearing. And you don't want to miss salient details early in the film which you will if your ears blink. There are mighty, classic moments at the beginning: Dame Maggie Smith's explanation of tea and the way Americans louse it up is Oscar-worthy; you also do not want to miss the clever way Bill Nighy has settled into his new job, or the brilliant newest job Dame Judi Dench is able to land. The saddest part of the film itself is the annoying distraction of Dev Patel's upcoming wedding--just not at all interesting.Let me end on the note that it was lovely to see everyone again, all gathered in Jaipur and having a blast. If this charmed you and you can find no fault with it, then here's the final positive note: don't be surprised if there is a second sequel. They left the doors wide open and that, ironically, was this film's biggest weakness of all. I always say: magic once is the stuff of dreams; more than once and it is old leftover pizza.

DAVID ATTENBOROUGH'S RISE OF ANIMALS (2013, 3 parts, 50 minutes per part, PAL REGION 2 NON-U.S.A. FORMAT) is the one Attenborough nature series I decided to review, rather than driving myself insane trying to review even a sampling of Sir David's lifework. In this, probably Sir David's last really active and stunning documentary, addresses life in several logical, beautiful sections. The three main episodes comprise this lovely mini-encyclopedia of evolution.The parts (the titles escape me at the moment) consist of the invertebrate, vertebrate, and mammalian animals--subdivided into the earliest creepy-looking little tadpoles to the massive mammals of ancient America. This wonderful, beautiful series teaches us the true and simple facts about evolution, life, and the reasons why life evolved as it did. My only complaint on that score was the poverty of the CGI animals. After all, one sees skeletons everyday, but it is a whole other matter to see a representation of the living animal.The miracle of evolution, of life on earth, and of Sir David Attenborough. I have watched him whenever he has been on television for almost my entire life. I remember him when he was young. He had an impact on my entire family and it is no hyperbole to state that he was teacher to us all. We learned things from him we never heard anywhere else, and this mini-series proves that as he addresses everything from weird little snakelike fish to gigantic rhino-type American animals, all extinct now. He shows us how and why, as he discusses the first fossils of feathered dinosaurs. His wonderful, melodic voice and manner of demonstrating his deep love for life is THE treat of modern TV.I am starting by reviewing the British PAL format (Region 2 DVD) and I see there is a Blu Ray version, which as yet I do not know--I only know a plain NTSC Region 1 DVD has yet to be released here. I am so tired of America doing this: we have been deprived of a lot of Sir David Attenborough's work. In the past there were good reasons for this. Today, there is no excuse at all. Or is the teaching of the FACT of evolution being blocked? Is Sir David getting held back by some because he is the new Ultimate Teacher? I don't know. All I know is I am tired of begging for scraps that end up costing much more than I anticipated.Sad that a review, of one of my most favorite shows by one of my most favorite scientists, is peppered at the end but it has to be said, again and again, until someone develops (I need to say "evolves") the brains to make all quality film and shows widely and easily available. I think Sir David would agree with me 100%--in fact, he DOES.

CAP, NEWSBOY/APPLEJACK CABBIE, COTTON TARTAN PATCHWORK by ANGELA & WILLIAM, SOLD BY TITFUS (tight fuse, get it?) Is a fine summer cap that has quality cotton materials in its make plus a very fine seersucker full lining. There is a cloth-covered button atop this cap, as you might expect and it is surprisingly well-fitted because it is lightweight (I'd say the button is a cloth-covered plastic disc.) My head is extremely large and I usually wear a size 59 (that's a 7 3/8 U.S.)--and I get headaches from hats that are too snug. This cap is perfect.I got this because it was made in the same way and with the same materials as the Epoch Hats flat cap, see my review for that: Men's Summer Preppy Tartan Plaid Front Snap Flat Golf Ivy Driving Cap Hat Brown. As such, it does more closely resemble a flat cap (or a Greek Fisherman or a painter's cap) than a "Newsboy". It didn't matter to me if it was a full Newsboy style, but I am happy it is a bit more like a Greek. Disappointments, see below:A few details give this cap a down-side, unlike the Epoch flat cap: if you examine the photo, you'll see this cap fully articulated and that's fine. Just like a regular Newsboy. In actual fact the cap is much closer to a Greek Fisherman, and I don't necessarily like that bait-and-switch inaccuracy. I was actually counting on a generous diameter and I get something that is, well, rather weird. This cap is not meant to have a snap on the visor like the flat caps do, but it comes sewn down along the visor which gives it the odd appearance you see in the main photos. I was easily able to rip that seam and fully articulate the cap--it looks OK. Just not the way I expected. The visor deserves extra kudos here: it is a full, square-shaped visor and not so much a duckbill. Good eye shade.Mainly, I did not expect this style to be sewn or otherwise attached at the front, because its diameter should be large enough to allow it to naturally fall that way--but I often call this style a "bÃ©ret with a visor", which it is. As such, it ought to have enough diameter to it so I can shift it around a little. If you examine the photo I have attached, which is one of the listing's photos, you'll see a more or less properly made cap but it just doesn't exactly pan out that way because the photo model's head is abnormally small. That always disappoints me, but I did not pay much for this, it is quality (just not quite on the same level of quality as an Epoch cap), and the fit, though snug, is adequate. For a general size LARGE it is far too small in general.This was sold to me by TitFus, an unfortunate name and a rather rude seller (ignores emails). It is fulfilled by amazon. Well, I can't complain too much given the price and the fair quality of this--even though it is not quite what you expect it to be and nothing in the description says they sewed the cap to the visor. Most will find it quite useful, if this is the kind of thing you like. My real love for this, aside from its light cotton make, is the patchwork that reminds me of my grandmother and mother. I do recommend it as a terrific summer cap, but it will never merit the glowing praise I feel for my Epoch flat cap.Final note: don't bother with paying extra for "expedited shipping", which on amazon should mean "Priority Mail". Mine was shipped parcel and they are truly just lucky it got here on time, but then it was sent from a bordering state. I did receive a refund on the shipping, and that is as it should be. Enough with these people pulling those kinds of stunts when a customer pays $10 in shipping. That is as expensive as UPS.

FATHER BROWN (season 2, starring Mark Williams title role) has comprised a series of fun 44-minutes-each of viewing when it is on PBS here. It angers me that Williams, along with Julie McKenzie's Agatha Christie's Marple, Series 4, are rarely seen in the American Midwest. It makes me ache as per usual at the idea that we're not getting a fraction of good British TV over here.Mark Williams, of HARRY POTTER fame (he was Mr. Weasley) rather chops up and squirts out his performance of Father Brown of the Church of Rome in an odd, almost haphazard way. He often says nothing for very long stretches and makes very weird facial expressions that puzzle even me. Since I always love watching Williams and have been a top fan from "day one", I find it tough to fathom why he seems so mediocre in this role. Perhaps he only seems that way: I find mediocrity to be the fault of the director every time.It puzzles me in the face of the beautiful, artful production value of 1950s England in the Cotswolds. The mysteries, of course, are really excellent per se; it is everything else that is awry with many of these excessively short episodes (many have the feel of the old "half-hour special"). The characters have no time to develop at all, and therefore the whole of Father Brown's English period becomes a puppet show. When that is combined with some serious acting and disturbing issues--as it usually is--plus very little humor, it gets explosively boring. It's as if Fr. Brown is just there, and nothing more, until he confronts the guilty parties.As an example to the contrary: it was brilliantly funny and warm to see Fr. Brown invited over for lunch at a favorite parishioner's home. The way Williams leers and sniffs at the "famous dumpling" dish and rolls his eyes--worth a million sterling! Then he simply says, "Ohhh, heavenly" and we are, for an instant, as transported as Fr. Brown is...and sadly, it is exactly this kind of thing that is so lacking in these episodes. I'd rather watch an entire story built around Fr. Brown's taste in food, if that is what it takes to breathe more life into this series!Even so, I do love the tea-cozy mystery and I want to collect these, if nothing else than for their value as an oddity--and because I love Mark Williams. They are worth having because they were so very worth producing ... and that is my problem with the lackluster performances by  Williams.

FATHER BROWN (season 1, starring Mark Williams title role) has been a fun 44 minutes of viewing when it is on PBS here. It angers me that Williams, along with Julie McKenzie's Agatha Christie's Marple, Series 4, are rarely seen in the American Midwest. It makes me ache as per usual at the idea that we're not getting a fraction of good British TV over here.Mark Williams, of HARRY POTTER fame (he was Mr. Weasley) rather chops up and squirts out his performance of Father Brown of the Church of Rome in an odd, almost haphazard way. He often says nothing for very long stretches and makes very weird facial expressions that puzzle even me. Since I always love watching Williams and have been a top fan from "day one", I find it tough to fathom why he seems so mediocre in this role. Perhaps he only seems that way: I find mediocrity to be the fault of the director every time.The mysteries, of course, are really excellent per se; it is everything else that is awry with many of these excessively short episodes. The characters have no time to develop at all, and therefore the whole of Father Brown's English period becomes a puppet show. When that is combined with some serious acting and disturbing issues--as it usually is--plus very little humor, it gets explosively boring. It's as if Fr. Brown is just there, and nothing more until he confronts the guilty parties. This is a role crying, begging, pleading for expansion in all directions and it simply isn't getting it.Love it all anyway because, thanks to the crew of this series, I cannot get enough and never will. I want to collect these, if nothing else than for their value as an oddity and because I love Mark Williams.

DESTINATION TRUTH (Season 3 of 5 total, 2010) ~Josh Gates, who talks almost exactly like an evil Kermit the Frog, is certainly able to deliver on the silly humor and cast/crew-oriented paranormal excursion format. Gates, who must be one of the most grating, irritating and smart-alecky of all the crap-TV hosts, has to be given credit for getting out there, traveling and making an ass of himself in general. I chose season 3 since I am presently amusing myself watching it on the Syfy Channel. Unfortunately I am all too familiar with this show from its beginning to date.This, though a few of the same dummies are in the show (meaning YOU Jael Pardo), is nowhere near the horrifically cheesy HAUNTED HIGHWAY (see: Island of the Lost Souls). It is actually closer than I just led you to believe. Here the season hops along from Yeti hunts in Bhutan to leprechaun hunts in Ireland. The globe-hopping is sort of fun, and if anyone had been smart enough, this could have been a respectable travelogue with a paranormal-folklore slant. In other words, it could have been good. Instead, aside from interminable yakking by Gates, who must have had it in his contract to hog the entire show all the time, this show distinguishes itself for establishing Jael Pardo as the dumbest, jumpiest and "screechiest" of any paranormal field investigator.What saves the show from getting one star by me is the combination of travel, humor (pathetically little of that) and the cute guys Josh Gates seems to insist on having around him like a harem. Well, at least the man is good for something! The investigations are the usual combination of incompetence, nincompoopery and squirrel-headedness. In other words, just perfect for the audiences of today who bother to watch such programming. It would not surprise me to hear fans of this garbage heap try to compare it to PBS programming. Which of course they would never be capable of watching anyway.In all fairness, now that I can lay aside most of my sardonic critique, I honestly do not know who or what moves producers to actually make shows like this. Entertainment is fine. Beefcake is more than fine, even if it has to be enjoyed through heavy expedition gear or bad weather in a wilderness. The girls on the show must, as ever, surrender to the superior hotness of Jael Pardo, I guess because the other girls on the team seem like truck drivers compared to her. OK, it can't be helped, I am back in full sardonic-sarcastic mode.Mainly the sour attitude is because this show, as with all others of its ilk, is dying to be mocked, begging to be witch-slapped. It could have been really funny (as the momentarily serious moment in Ireland when Gates is claiming he saw a box of Lucky Charms). It could have been, as I said, an anthropological-folklore exploration of our world, a show that as far as I know has never been done seriously at all. Instead, it's a bunch of dummies looking for every single paranormal idiocy you could imagine. If this show was not canceled, but I think it was, I am just waiting for them to start hunting for Sheepsquatch next.But if I must listen to Gates' interminable Kermit-yapping or Jael screaming her lungs out for no reason, I am going to complain to my congressman. I am a darned good letter writer, Gates! Just don't you forget that! ô

SCANDAL (Dir. Akira Kurosawa, 1950, 80 minutes) is one of Kurosawa's early films. Actually set in the fall of 1949 and continuing on through 1950, this oddly short yet somehow dragged-out drama features a young Toshiro Mifune as an up-and-coming "bohemian"-type artist. A chance encounter with a famous though reclusive singer--totally innocent of course--leads to a cheap popular tabloid ("Amour") defaming both parties with a scurrilous story of an affair. In this early film, Kurosawa questions, as always, the inner morality of each individual, what I call "the nun in the belfry". Are you who you say you are ... really? Are you honest? If somebody defames you, well, in some odd way isn't that karma? Kurosawa was always good at showing how karma has a ripple effect: it's not just "thee" and "me".Kurosawa managed to address the proper legal side: the innocent couple is guilty of nothing. A crappy though popular magazine has defamed them in an illustrative way that reminds me of the famous American case, in which an elderly man and his elderly girlfriend were hung out to dry in what must be THE textbook definition of defamation--and the couple won their case. It strikes me that Kurosawa may have been trying to tell a Japanese version of that story since he was always famous for doing that sort of thing. In a way, this film, then, is based on a true story. The dishonest lush of an attorney hired by the couple soon puts their feet deeper into the fire. This is a film you have to watch to appreciate in full what happens next.What American audiences may never be able to understand is the complexity of Japanese life, justice plus the fact that this takes place during reconstruction. Remember, it is 1949-1950. Japan was emerging from a horrific shambles and I cannot imagine the horror they faced wondering if their nation would survive at all. For example, Kurosawa addresses the pure evil of the cancer epidemic that swept the nation as a result of the bombs in Ikiru (The Criterion Collection); here as in a few of his other "contempo" films he is addressing basic morality, delicately quivering beneath the Sword of Damocles forever poised in the Japanese sky. If you are interested in the history of modern Japan, in cinematic history, or just a Kurosawa fan, I highly recommend this film as a study of early Kurosawa. If nothing else, it was his launching pad and a good showcase for his stars.

THE BAD SLEEP WELL (Dir. Akira Kurosawa, 1960, 135 minutes, U.S.A. release 1963, Japanese with English subtitles) is one of the weirdest, most depressing of Kurosawa's "modern" films. The legendary Toshiro Mifune plays one Koichi Nishi, secretary to the vice president of the Japanese Public Corporation for Land Development. I do not know anything at all about the Japanese reconstruction period or how the illegal kickbacks worked on construction jobs, but this film is exactly what a corporate whistle-blower's nightmare might be like!The level of murder (in the form of bullying to suicide which is seen as equal to murder in Japan) and the ruthless couple of top dogs making all the money is simply sickening. Once you see a bit of Nishi's "other side", you too will be sucked into the emotionally painful moral abyss that this film so baldly lays before us. I have always said Kurosawa is at his weakest when trying to do modern social statements, but this film ranges far beyond all that, addressing the idea of corporate corruption, priorities in life, and of course, defines the very evil, wicked definition of "kickbacks".The innovations and power in this black-and-white film obviously inspired everyone from Hitchcock on down the line. I have no idea how many it inspires today, but it says something that the film and the story are so fresh and startling even now. The lessons never change, the mask of goodness worn by evil never varies. This film teaches us how we manage to fall for it every time. This film has one hope: the one pissed off, half-loony righteous crusader who just might have a chance at dismantling the total corruption. In a word, this is about the one person who just might be able to cease the ripple effect of bad karma.And humorously enough, it reminded me of Luke Skywalker being the only one who could bring down his father and the Emperor. No doubt it was an inspiration for George Lucas.Yet I find it necessary to mention my feeling Kurosawa is at his weakest because he always seems to have his hands more than full with these modern-day fables and parables. On the one hand he presents a clean, no-bones-about-it slate upon which he then writes his moral lesson. On the other hand one cannot get rid of the feeling he would rather be making a samurai jidai geki. His apparent struggle with the courtroom scenes is an example: Kurosawa just can't get a dramatic courtroom battle--but I think he might have wanted it that way.The true shout-out goes to the great Toshiro Mifune. Here he is all business, buttoned to the brim in his fine business suit and thick horn-rimmed glasses, the emotionless picture of Japanese business efficiency. Even so, he sends shivers of awe through the viewer. It will always escape me how Mifune did it: I have loved him all my life, he was the Japanese Olivier; exactly how and why still escapes me. Perhaps it is pure talent: how does one describe a force of nature? How does one describe Kurosawa, the greatest director in history? It is easier to describe this film: one man, as close to a superhero as you could get in real life, fighting evil to the death just to avenge the rotten father who was as bad as the rest. If you love cinema, and Kurosawa IS cinema, you have to get this. Even if he is sort of 'idling' a bit with this movie.For fun and games, I highly recommend two Kurosawa films I love and have reviewed: Scandal - 1950 - Akira Kurosawa for an early peep into his sophisticated early reconstruction Japan and High and Low (The Criterion Collection) for a peep into his later super-sophisticated, reconstructed Japan.

BALL OF FIRE (for all you mugs out there a "ball of fire" meant a passionate bombshell female back in the day) is a Barbara Stanwyck/Gary Cooper vehicle that is often compared to "Snow White and the Seven Dwarves". I'm not certain where THAT comes from because, aside from the hilarious little homages to DWARVES, this film is not a version of it at all.Gary Copper is Professor Pott, one of eight academics working for years on an ultimate encyclopedia. When it is realized the "slang" section under "S" is 20 years outdated, Prof. Pott seeks to find a remedy to the situation. While gathering notes about the latest slang (some of it is so funny and I had never heard of it, i.e., "meatloaf") he meets a girlie-girl named "Sugar-puss" (properly called "Shug" by her gangster pals, played by Stanwyck). When she is subpoenaed for some nasty gang business, she agrees to help the professors and moves in with them.See, they live together under the stipulation of the grant money to do the encyclopedia. Only one of the elderly scientists was married, now a widower. The rest are bachelors. What is cool about them is the way they mirror the great scientists known to that time: one is an Einstein-type, another is supposed to be like Max Planck. When the bad guys finally get to the scientists, there is a truly horrible moment when two of the thugs hold them hostage. To me, that was a profound message about the terrorism inherent in crime.The rest you must see for yourself--it is so worthwhile even if Cooper is badly miscast in this. The humor is subtle and to be heard, not seen, in the clever dialogue. It is argued that this is the last of the great pre-WWII comedies, but I disagree. This is also stupidly described as a "screwball" comedy, which it most certainly is not. It may be the granddaddy of the screwball comedy, but that is as far as I'll go. Personally I think the Marx Brothers early material, written by Buster Keaton, is the very definition of "screwball comedy".But this movie does represent an end to the fun and humor of the pre-WWII era in film. What is a miracle is these stars (they're all great, you'll certainly recognize most of them) and the studios went on to do stunning work post-WWII. Get it for the fun, then remember the sacrifices made in WWII so that we could be here and free to enjoy this today!

HERE COMES MR. JORDAN (Dir. Alexander Hall, 1941, 94 minutes, based on the play Heaven Can Wait.)Robert Montgomery - Joe PendletonEvelyn Keyes - Bette LoganClaude Rains - Mr. Jordan [God]Rita Johnson - Julia FarnsworthEdward Everett Horton - Messenger 7013 [The Angel of Death]James Gleason - Max CorkleThis hilarious yet metaphysically challenging story is the original idea by Harry Segall, as done in his play HEAVEN CAN WAIT. Before I get launched here, let me remind and caution any younger viewers about the film that is NOT this original film based on the play: Heaven Can Wait also found here: Heaven Can Wait. That film has nothing to do with this original film based on the play--but a lot of people erroneously think it is the original film.The famous Joe Pendleton, boxing champ, gets snatched by The Messenger just before his plane crashes due to The Messenger suddenly feeling sorry for the suffering he is certain is awaiting Joe. Trouble is, Joe was due to pass away at a ripe old age in 1991! In heaven, he has to see "Mr. Jordan" who is actually God--surely he can fix this unholy mess. So he does, by deciding Joe can return to earth in another freshly deceased body, that of millionaire Farnsworth.This film is a most wonderful, skillful and (once in a while black) comedy about who we are, who we are meant to be and how God considers the human body something like a "coat" and nothing more. That "coat" is not what matters to him, and somewhere in the film there is a line about previous incarnations that struck me as odd. The entire metaphysical message is supposed to be that the person we are is all that matters, not the body. Yet it is Mr. Jordan's comforting line to Joe that literally has changed my own outlook: when Joe is angry about the order of things, Mr. Jordan tells him "no one gets cheated." I don't mind saying it was a challenge for an old Jesuit-taught Jewish rabbinical student who ended up being a Buddhist priest! Suddenly the idea that "it'll all work out in the end, no one will be cheated" gave ME a new philosophical understanding of life!This film is showing, in its almost cold, analytical way, precisely that truth. It begins to nag the viewer, making one wonder why one feels cheated all the time and why the universe seems so cold and unjust. It struck me that Mr. Jordan will always be infinitely more than he seems, telling us it will all be OK and no one gets cheated. I tell you, it has changed my perspective and I don't even understand why it changed me! Frankly the film doesn't really seem that deep.And if I can't really encompass the thing in my mind, I suggest you don't try either. It will all work out in the end and no one gets cheated. While it is all so facile and breezy, Claude Rains actually gives the role of the Almighty quite an impish spark of fun--too fun, sometimes, as he coldly looks upon the universe he loves, which he made, and almost seems to grapple with the destiny he also created which he can't seem to change a whole lot. At times he gives an impression of desperation, yet all the while he knows it'll all work out for the best. No one gets cheated. That ultimately comforted me, because in spite of my own weird backstory, and several brushes with death, I had never considered things in this light until today.This film ends up teaching a super-positive, uplifting premise that even 1947's The Bishop's Wife (1947) utterly failed to do. There, by the way, is another film that stole from MR. JORDAN.That is how deep this silly comedy really is. As a multi-Oscar winner, it was remade, of course, and I am not going to bother with any of that. It is enough that I told you which old film is NOT this film. You can't miss this, not Claude Rains as God, and never in a million years do you want to miss the now-forgotten James Gleason as Joe's manager Max Corkle. That Max is a comic genius role, and I can't fathom why this film is one of those half-forgotten beauties they made in the 1940s. Of course if this isn't enough for you in the life-after-death department, you can always do as well with Spencer Tracy's A Guy Named Joe (see my review; frankly I think JOE, made just two years later, was a rip-off of MR. JORDAN).Just don't miss out on this all-time classic either. It may ring corny now, but that is how life was and I just loved the gentle shades of my own childhood listening to those boxing people yakking back and forth.Joe: "I was in the pink!"Mr. Jordan: "That is becoming a very obnoxious color, Joe. Don't mention it again!"

THE BOY WITH GREEN HAIR (1948, released 1950, 80 minutes, RKO Pictures) was simultaneously one of the weirdest, most prophetic and somehow ahead-of-its-time movies I have ever watched. I'd never heard of it before--and you'd think with that title it would be a classic by now. A very young Dean Stockwell plays Peter Frye, a boy who awakens one morning to find his hair completely green. Not just any green: a gorgeous, grassy-emerald green. To heck with the Joker, THIS looks like truly green hair!Peter is an orphan, left with his kindly, retired Irish magician grandfather (Pat O'Brien) because his parents apparently died in the London Blitz while saving children during World War II. (It escapes me why viewers and critics call the old man unrelated when the gentleman is called "Mr. Frye".) At his school, Peter looks at the stunning, heart-wrenching posters of war orphans with a sadness that is palpable, even though we can't see his face in that shot. Once his hair turns green, Peter runs away--in the glade he encounters the spirits of the orphaned war children who tell him he must use his attention-getting hair to spread a message.That message is that war must never happen again, and to prove the point, he is to call attention to his hair as a sign. I think I'll stop here, because you can imagine what he's going to face under the circumstances. I do wish to point out that this colorful, well-shot film really brings the era to life, and it wasn't all that different from the here and now. I think you should remember that. Peter's message, or rather the heart of it, is "war is very bad for children."HISTORY: I think the uneven, oddly comical quality of this picture (and it is, sadly, referenced as a comedy) was due to the harsh and near-insane meddling of Howard Hughes, who took over RKO when the film was partly shot. Wishing to sabotage its pacifist message, which is indeed powerful as performed by a 12-year-old Dean Stockwell, Hughes did his best to louse up the rest of filming. He even went so far as to bully young Stockwell, screaming at him about the necessity for arms superiority. Stockwell would not back down about his own personal anti-war feelings, and glared defiantly at the crazed Hughes. (Ironically, one of Stockwell's greatest cameos is as Hughes in Tucker: The Man and His Dream--see my review.)The crew who worked on this film were later blacklisted and it is a miracle the thing got released at all. My nearest guess as to the parable nature of the film is that the stupid people were so obsessed about Peter's green hair they did not listen to his anti-war message or his warnings about the children's futures. What is so creepy is the power of the message STILL does not get through even to this day--and I do not think it is due to Stockwell's green hair. This is decades after the hippies and the punks, so we've seen it all. No ... it's that we do not listen at all. Perhaps that was the intention of the film all along, since I could not really find a parable in it or anything else metaphysical which I could grasp.However, it is direct enough: I defy you to laugh (you won't, you'll get shivers) when Peter looks directly at the viewer, green hair resplendent, and says sadly about war, "They think everyone has to die." He says this because he had heard some ladies speaking about the outcome of an atomic war. He was visualizing all the dead children and he managed to convey that very thought--as if it were a true ESP moment with the audience.Perhaps in the end it was no more than a testament to how crazy Howard Hughes was. But you'll love this if, for no other reason, you like weird old films or are as stricken with the breathtaking beauty of Stockwell as I am. I've seen Stockwell (during his child star years) in such films as Song of the Thin Man--and of course his stunning, Oscar-worthy turn with Gregory Peck in Gentleman's Agreement of the same year as GREEN HAIR, 1948 (see my review). Stockwell knew how to break hearts and did it expertly. In fact in this film as in GENTLEMAN'S AGREEMENT, he made me cry. ... and perhaps THAT was the true aim of this film. If you saw a 12-year-old Stockwell weep, you'd devote the rest of your life to ending war and saving all endangered children.

WOMAN IN GOLD (Dir. Simon Curtis, 2015, 110 minutes (with 10 solid minutes of end credits), BBC Films, in English & German) ~Maria Altmann - Helen MirrenRandy Schoenberg - Ryan ReynoldsDaniel BrÃ¼hl - Hubertus CzerninTatiana Maslany - young MariaHenry Goodman - Ferdinand Bloch-Bauer (Maria's father)Jonathan Pryce - Chief Justice William RhenquistCharles Dance - Attorney Sherman (uncredited?)Bruno Ganz - uncredited voiceoverMaria Altmann was a lucky Jewish lady from a fine Viennese family. Along with her young husband, she escaped Nazi Austria just in time though Maria lost her family (except for her sister). She lived in Los Angeles. This film tells the story of Maria and the famous painting of her beloved aunt, Adele Bloch-Bauer. We all know it well, as "Woman in Gold" by Gustav Klimt. I studied that work countless times as an art student. Well who knew! Mirren gives a plucky, humourous performance as Maria, who embarked on a quest to be recognized as the painting's true owner, which she was. Austria was in possession of hundreds of millions' worth of her paintings, stolen from her father by the Nazis at the start of WWII.This is the abbreviated "short-hand" story of Maria latching onto attorney Randy Schoenberg, another descendant of a Viennese family: that of composer Arnold Schoenberg. She chose Randy because she had known Arnold and needed a good Jewish lawyer she could trust. Maria was going to get all her family paintings back from Austria, and they were not just going to gladly hand them over and say auf wiedersehen. Told in a rather hurried and may I say occasionally sloppy manner, it is a film within a film, the modern story (set from the late 1990s to 2006) being dogged by the WWII-era story of the Bloch-Bauer Family. Sometimes it is beautifully done, sometimes it is annoying the way a scene is abandoned for the next scene.Quite a head-turner, whatever way your head is originally oriented. The performances are not exactly powerhouse, but they needn't be. The competence and emotion will carry you along as it did for me. In the flashbacks, a great example of the emotional power is when the Nazis eyeball Ferdinand Bloch-Bauer's Stradivarius cello. The way Ferdinand grips a candlestick in each fist--powerful stuff. The cello is his devoted love and the Nazis are about to take it. Like candy from a baby. Mirren gives some fabulous moments as she and Reynolds bounce off each other, almost like mother and son. The trouble is, this film was in certain ways handled amateurishly, and the first thing one notices in that regard is the way Mirren mirrors her performance as Queen Elizabeth. That was a great error. The visits to the concentration camp were nothing more than blurs. In fact, at one point, six months pass, then later, nine months pass.You will literally miss the time gaps if you blink.I will add this: the Supreme Court sets and cinematography are FANTASTIC! Sadly, the acting is not, but they managed to flavor it a little with the peppery back-and-forth between justices and counsel. But I did recognize, significantly, the only side of their bench shown, and could identify Justices O'Connor, Thomas, Scalia, Breyer and Kennedy--all of whom are unnamed and uncredited as far as I know. Significantly the two conspicuously absent Justices were Ginsberg and my personal hero Stevens.So my final verdict is it is a quality film, excellent in so many ways, the soundtrack doesn't meddle, no swearing at all, nearly everything is perfect but it is hastily and sloppily dealt with. The subtitles in this format are horrific (I hope you can at least catch some of the German). Too much information is done in the typical caption form, which is the reason it could be missed on the first viewing. I had to watch this twice to get everything. The story, as I said, is truncated, so do not expect to ever fully know what it all means until you have read up on the real-life events.REAL-LIFE BACKGROUND: Maria Altmann always intended only to gain recognition and attention regarding the Nazi thefts and other atrocities that were not commonly known. This was a thing I loved in the film, since it has a you-are-there quality without the hand-held camera crap or anything else amiss. Her family, her home, everything was stolen by the Nazis then later illegally acquired by the Austrian government. But Maria and Schoenberg fought the Austrian government like David and Goliath. The painting of Maria's aunt ("Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I" but changed to "Woman in Gold" due to anti-Semitism) is widely known as "the Mona Lisa of Austria". And Maria was already in her 80s when she decided to take on this fight!The paintings, all of them Maria's, hung in the Austrian Galerie Belvedere. After the first suing of the government, Maria was on a crazy roller coaster ... never really expecting to win much. She wanted to educate the world and, as a good Jew, exorcize some demons along the way. Maria was surprised when she actually got the wheels of justice turning, losing each time to the Austrian government and the Belvedere Gallery, but inching closer to victory. She won her United States Supreme Court Case in 2006 (Republic of Austria v. Altmann, 2006)--a case that granted her security under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act of 1976. That has to do with an American suing a foreign government, and the USSC said Maria could, indeed, sue Austria because the meat of the case was whether or not the FSIA was retroactive. Which they ruled it to be. Maria could sue Austria with that decision in her back pocket.Austria v. Altmann holds that the law is retroactive, and Maria ended up getting her case arbitrated in an Austrian court to her favor in 2006. She won all of her paintings back and then decided to sell the "Woman in Gold" to Ronald Lauder--EsteÃ© Lauder's son. (EsteÃ© had also been a good friend of Maria's, and Lauder made sure the painting hung where all could see it) All in all she made almost $500,000,000. Her biggest dream: to finally buy a dishwasher. And she lived into her 90s, passing away in 2011 and of course, leaving the bulk of her fortune to good charities. All of this is the true heart of the film, which shows very well what the war, the Nazis, did to the Jews BEFORE they incarcerated/incinerated them. That was the most relatable aspect: it made me cry because of similarities with my life, and I am nowhere near Maria's generation.Austrians were rude and evil to poor old Maria. Someone actually said to her in Vienna: "You people never give up, do you?! Not everything is about the Holocaust!!" Maria knew everything IS about the Holocaust. That was the whole point. She had to live with the knowledge that her aunt's portrait hung at the Berghof in Hitler's personal possession, long after her parents and everyone had died in the camps.
