However, I think we Jews, everywhere, are deeply conversant with this kind of horrible, unspeakable loss. So much was put into this film in spite of some sloppiness because there is a double-edged Jewish sword, and I for one am happy to wield it: we People never give up, and we never forget. Wielding that, especially as Jews, is an OBLIGATION.

PALEFACE (Writ., Dir. Buster Keaton, 1922, 25 minutes) is a classic silent short by none other than Buster Keatonâ€”the man who pretty much invented everything that has ever been any good in cinema. Here BK is an innocent butterfly collector who stumbles into a tribe of Indians. About to lose their land to the evil, greedy white man, they decide to kill the next white man they see. It is of course BK. This is so important as part of the document that is American comedy on film. It is an early BK masterpiece, a slightly longer short (shorts were usually 13 to 17 minutes long), with stunning special effects that are nearly inexplicable today.But always funny as hell. A tumble off a cliff, a change of wardrobe: no one could do a thing that held a candle to BK's best work. This film belongs in your collection if you truly love comedy. The 1920s, black and white film, silent film, none of it matters when you watch Buster Keaton. He was such a genius and fantastic ad-libber that he will be forever funny to the point of stopping your heart for you. Aside from the slightly racist attitude toward Indiansâ€”and several of the actors were Nativesâ€”this is a classic that will have you laughing while your eyes are glued to every second. A lot of the humor is in trying to figure out how he shot certain scenes.That is a thing about BK no one can appreciate without watching his films: he was a true magician, trained, some swear, by Harry Houdini himself.

CAP, "FLAT"/"DRIVER'S", RED PLAID (VARIOUS PATCHES), 100% COTTON, GENERIC SIZE LARGE (ONE SIZE FITS MOST) BY EPOCH is an amazing thing. Needing a summer version of this cap style, I went for this very attractive-looking fun Epoch version. It was one of the best buys I've ever made in caps/hats. It is cool, perfect for summer no matter what you plan on doing (I would avoid getting it wet, because it will shrink a tiny bit). I am a sucker for tartans and this reminds me of one of my favorite tartans, the Royal Stuart. This has the perfect mix of plaid patches. As a cap, it is superlative 100% cotton!This is fully lined with 100% cotton, a very pretty mini-paisley that reminds me of an old bow tie I used to love. It is extremely comfortable and the sweatband is the same material, with an inner lining that wicks away any sweat. An excellent, beautiful bit of headwear which is what I expect from Epoch anyway. I wish the seller had stated in the listing that it is an Epoch cap. Then I would have had zero doubts. This is also a truly snap-front cap, an important detail because so many companies are just gluing the front of the cap to the visor these days. I just love this and I'm only sorry I'll probably not get to buy a second one.Epoch, based in New York City, has been around since the 1990s. That is when hat crazes began among the young, but Epoch was dedicated to totally excellent headwear at very affordable prices. I own three of their felt porkpies for the winter: among the best hats I own. As to this cap, which I always call a "Braque" cap: it was invented in its streamlined modern form by Cubist creator artist George Braque. He called it a "casquette" and had his tailor use his design to make two caps: one black, one white. So aside from Cubism and his inspiration of Picasso, Braque also gave us this cap. And THIS Epoch cap stays true to that beautiful design. It isn't weirdly or stupidly designed like some of the newer models I see.An Epoch hat is always distinguished by its beautiful fit. Some think Epoch makes hats too large, but that is because most people don't rightly know their hat size. This cap has a beautifully finished, well fitted bit of elastic at the back. It fits my huge head and the size I got was close to a size L, but it fits wonderfully. I'd say if you get one of these, be aware that it will probably fit anyone from size 56 to 59. And if you don't understand that size system, you'd better learn it quickly. It is your head's diameter in centimeters, rounded up to the next whole number. Measure your head and write it down--and be sure to check hat size charts. My size is 59 which is 7 3/8 inches = U.S. hat size 7 3/8.The seller is listed as SK Hat-Shop, with whom I have dealt in the past. But I ended up trading with a seller called We Buy We Sell. I'm glad about the seller, who is in West New York, New Jersey; only hoping this is not a mis-listed seller. One final detail: if this doesn't quite look like your style, I recommend you try it anyway. You won't believe how well these caps look and how nicely they fit, because Epoch knows what it is doing. They made these caps to be sleek, attractive and comfortable--like all their headwear. Braque was an artist of many talents. I always love the fact that he created a new garment which is something Picasso never did!Epoch and Braque: the only better combination idea would be a Scottish bluebonnet and Matisse!

CAP, "FLAT"/"DRIVER'S", BROWN PLAID PATCH, 100% COTTON BY EPOCH is an amazing thing. Needing a summer version of this cap style, I went for this very attractive-looking fun Epoch version. It was one of the best buys I've ever made in caps/hats. It is cool, perfect for summer no matter what you plan on doing (I would avoid getting it wet, because it will shrink a tiny bit). I am a sucker for tartans and brown is my color. This has the perfect mix of brown-based plaid patches plus has beautiful red, white and blue variations in there also. As a cap, it is superlative!This is lined with 100% cotton, a very pretty mini-paisley that reminds me of an old bow tie I used to love. It is extremely comfortable and the sweatband is the same material, with an inner lining that wicks away any sweat. An excellent, beautiful bit of headwear which is what I expect from Epoch anyway. I wish the seller had stated in the listing that it is an Epoch cap. Then I would have had zero doubts. This is also a truly snap-front cap, an important detail because so many companies are just gluing the front of the cap to the visor these days. I just love this and I'm only sorry I'll probably not get to buy a second one.Epoch, based in New York City, has been around since the 1990s. That is when hat crazes began among the young, but Epoch was dedicated to totally excellent headwear at very affordable prices. I own three of their felt porkpies for the winter: among the best hats I own. As to this cap, which I always call a "Braque" cap: it was invented in its streamlined modern form by Cubist creator artist George Braque. He called it a "casquette" and had his tailor use his design to make two caps: one black, one white. So aside from Cubism and his inspiration of Picasso, Braque also gave us this cap. And THIS Epoch cap stays true to that beautiful design. It isn't weirdly or stupidly designed like some of the newer models I see.An Epoch hat is always distinguished by its beautiful fit. However, they try to be distinguished with their concepts. What really drew me to this cap is that it reminded me of my aunt, my grandmother and my mother. They all had stashes of bits of fabric. They could make anything from sheets to shirts to caps to pillowcases. When I saw this cap, it instantly reminded me of home. Actually owning it and studying its beauty makes me feel at home. Epoch Hats will do that--their porkpies give me that happy, comfortable feeling too. But I don't mind saying, I wept a gentle tear when I saw this cap in my hands. Before I put it on to try out the size, I said a short prayer for my mother, my aunt and my grandmother.It's weird, what certain things can do to us! I think it means that we really are sensitive and truly have hearts.The seller is listed as SK Hat-Shop, with whom I have dealt in the past. But I ended up trading with a seller called We Buy We Sell. I'm glad about this seller, We Buy We Sell, who is in West New York, New Jersey; only hoping this is not a mis-listed seller because I dealt exclusively in the past with SK Hat Shop. SK carries Epoch hats of all types--We Buy We Sell is reliable and carries nice hats but I just can't figure out the different names, one in the listing and the one with whom I actually dealt. This happens on amazon a lot, the listing being one name and the seller going by another name, so I hope that did not happen here.One final detail: if this doesn't quite look like your style, I recommend you try it anyway. You won't believe how well these caps look, because Epoch knows what it is doing and these caps were designed to be sleek, attractive and comfortable. Braque was an artist of many talents. I always love the fact that he created a new garment which is something Picasso never did!Epoch and Braque: the only better combination idea would be a Scottish bluebonnet and Matisse!

*Dayenu means in Hebrew, "It would have been sufficient for us."HIDDEN INHERITANCE: FAMILY SECRETS, MEMORY, AND FAITH by Rev. Heidi B. Neumark (2015, scheduled to be published in October) is one of the more satisfying and personally touching books I have ever read on one of my most favorite subjects: a person suddenly learning they are Jewish. Or at least sort of Jewish.Lutheran pastor Rev. Neumark was startled by her daughter one day almost a decade ago; her daughter had discovered--on Wikipedia of all places--that their family, that is, Rev. Neumark's father, had been Jewish. Rev. Neumark, as leery as I am of the swamp called Wikipedia, dismissed her daughter's claims. Then on a sort of whim, she began digging. After ceaseless digging she had unearthed the ghost of a titanic family secret: her Jewish father had barely escaped the Nazis but her grandparents on one side and many other relatives perished. Coming to America to start a new and very respectable life, Rev. Neumark's father left the Jewish behind.This story is a deeply touching one. While most of us do not have the money and resources Rev. Neumark had--to research endlessly, take endless trips to Germany and Switzerland, to track down and visit unknown relatives--it is stunning what one can find with just some searching. She never seems to tire throughout the entire book, telling how her daughter found everything on Google. (She makes a reference by naming one of her chapters "Googling Moses", the name of an ancestor who was a rabbi.) The trip can be exasperating, since Rev. Neumark is determined to work in some sort of memoire that in my opinion is unrelated to her main story.This stunned me in many ways. I also am a Jew, one who learned about it very, very late in life. I also despaired during a visit to a cemetery in Mexico and not finding my grandfather's or great-grandfather's graves. I also suffered from many family secrets, and I too am a priest of another religion who had to come to terms with my "new inner Jew". While I rather resent anyone who tries to tie Judaism into Christianity, I can empathize with someone like Rev. Neumark, who after all had no choice. She did not try to convert, as I did, in order to be "officially" Jewish and according to Jewish Law, she is not Jewish on any count because her mother was not born Jewish.The latter points matter little. This book is a fantastic, direct and sometimes overly frank account of that new breed arising: the New Jew. For all family members and even friends, I highly recommend this. Unlike other books I see newly published, this is well written and intelligent, with gracefully flowing prose and intelligent reasoning. A bibliophile could not ask for more ... not even a Judeao-Buddhist bibliophile.

Rarely do I waste time with 100% trash here, mainly because amazon requires I rate at least one star then spend the entire review defending/explaining myself to nasty readers with nothing better to do. So let's get right to it: Deborah King is some sort of a snake oil saleswoman of the lowest order. Oh, at least her message can be, at times, maybe half-positive. Mostly she is as full of herself as she is of hot air. This book, part self-promoting biography, part new age nonsense, is proof to that.I should have thrown this down when King kicked off the book by bragging about how she exorcized a Chinese student who was possessed by an ancient Chinese dragon who was once a power of good, but had turned evil, apparently with the eternally sought-after goal of possessing a poor young Chinese woman. Can you guess what I decided King was full of, at that moment in my reading?--and of course it got worse, with babbling about chakras, body-mind and the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, an unfortunate individual about whom it is best to know nothing--and try to forget anything you might know already. So what is left? A little of this, a little of that, some psychobabble that always makes the patient/victim/spiritual casualty the ripe sucker because it makes that person the guilty party.Is that all, you may be asking, that would set me off like the Manhattan Project? Not by a long chalk: King has somehow garnered herself a reputation for being able to magically cure cancer. I wish I could incarcerate every such person, who preys on the bereaved, the ill, the dying and the disabled. She describes a friend who eventually died of pancreatic cancer and at least she did not try to heal him--she just tried to psychobabble him into a negative, self-blaming place while he was on chemo. He died miserably, King suggests, because he had talked himself into it as his father had also died of cancer, in terrible pain.Well, this is the type of garbage you can expect here. King's emotional/psychological manipulation of those in the worst shape is the thing that creates my animus. It enrages me. I gave it two stars because my original 1-star, it seems to me, was keeping people from reading this review. It is stupid; it is also true: people won't read 1-star reviews. What little good--and I do mean LITTLE--there is in this waste of paper can be found in any of His Holiness the Dalai Lama's books on compassion and right living. He is a fine and worthy teacher and has helped so many more people, with a glance and a smile, than King's endless bragging will ever help. Since I run into too many of this type of book, and this type of phony-baloney shamanism, I'm going to tell you not to waste your money on this useless waste of paper, save my light energy and end this review right here.

BAR SOAP, BY PRE DE PROVENCE, WITH SHEA BUTTER is a pretty fantastic and luxurious scented soap that will leave you feeling like a French aristocrat. And no guillotine required. This lathers well and cleanses in a rich, weird way because I am not accustomed to such things in general. My mother used to have such things for the family but I am a very plain, simple person. So I have to express how much I love items of this nature. Anything from Provence has my vote, the fragrance of this is unbeatable and you'll leave your bath feeling like a monarch.

APRON, 100% COTTON, ONE SIZE FITS MOST by Flirty Aprons was a weird thing to select from the Vine, but I happen to require an apron in the kitchen even if I can hardly stand. This looked good to try out, so what can I say?--I'm going to try it out and see! It is a typical apron, 100% cotton twill, with good pockets but is a bit slender at the breast. The neck strings are untied so it may be adjusted to the height you like best; the usual apron strings in this case are a sash, extremely long so this really will fit nearly anybody. It probably would be safe in the washer, but the instructions say to hand-wash and hang dry. I suspect they fear our washers and dryers in America are garment-chewing monstrosities.This is made in China and I see, more and more often, things being designed totally by the Chinese. They have no idea how we live or anything in general, so one must live with occasionally silly things like instructions to hand-wash a tough cotton twill apron. It'll be fun and really useful, and I do not mind sharing one final secret: this will help save my clothes when I eat certain foods.

JUST ADD WATER: A SURFING SAVANT'S JOURNEY WITH ASPERGER'S by Robert Yehling & Clay Marzo (2015) is a rather weighty biography of surfing sensation Clay Marzo and his struggle with Asperger's Autism, most commonly known as Asperger's Syndrome. This attracted me because I have Asperger's, and am always so happy to read and hear about the triumphs and successes of others afflicted with this form of high-functioning autism. So here, then, is a biography extraordinaire of a successful, wildly popular young Hawai'ian surfing star that delves deeply into his past, his family, his current girlfriend and his success of living life daily with a frankly weird condition.This is a truly deep biography that amazingly allows Clay to speak for himself--I can only guess Yehling recorded extensive interviews with everyone he could, but the idea that Marzo "coauthored" this beyond fully cooperating with it is a bit laughable. Also, the interviews could really stand some expert editing. Yehling has a way of droning on and on, most unseemly for a good biography. And that is the misfortune with this book, because if you have not the slightest interest in surfers, there is no way you can get to the true marrow of the valuable information about a successful person with Asperger's.That is not the only thing wrong with this effort. Yehling is more than careless about delineating AS, how it differs from person to person, and doesn't even offer very clear or concise explanations which are necessary in such cases as this biography. No AS person is exactly alike (Einstein, it is believed, suffered from it and he was hardly a surfer). The book is simply too narrow and for what it is, I commend it; for what it lacks, I criticize it. A final massive pet peeve is Yehling himself. I know he is a surfing journalist, but this book often reads like a 13-year-old enthusiast wrote it. When I settle in for a biography I expect far better than this.I can't knock a well-intentioned, thoroughly researched biography, which makes this review tough--I have to knock a book that prattles for pages about essentially nothing, and a writing style I'd be ashamed to get from a junior high schooler. Now you have the skinny, and you know my own opinion, you decide. Overall, this book is no more and no less than a thorough biography of Clay Marzo. So much of his life is ahead of him (one sincerely hopes and prays) so it is a bit of a fluke to have a bio of one still so young.For those with an interest in Asperger's, I suggest better reads such as Tony Attwood's The Complete Guide to Asperger's Syndrome and even my own book, No Duty To Retreat: The Stories of Tourette's Syndrome and Asperger's Autism ... just DO NOT pay $100 for a copy if you can find one for $7!

HAT, "FISHING" a/k/a "BOONIE", BY MEGA CAP is a pretty awesome hat for what it does and look at the price for heaven's sake! This is what a lot of folks call a boonie hat, used in the military (you can easily get a typical khaki color and look like a fisherman if you prefer), a/k/a fishing hat a/k/a bucket hat. When I started wearing these it is because I saw them on Henry Fonda in On Golden Pond (Special Edition) and began wearing them that very year. Nothing like a middle-aged man trying to look like Professor Norman Thayer (or David McCallum as Ducky from NCIS: Season 5 for that matter). His was an old fishing hat, but I got boonies more often for the wider brim and tougher build.Well here's a perfect hat: it's both a boonie and a fishing hat. It has a snap on either side of the brim so you can snap up the brim on the sides of your head (good to keep it out of the way sometimes and streamline the hat shape). You can just jauntily snap up one side only, which would then turn it into yet another style called a "slouch". Boonies and slouches originated in Australia, where the heat is super-nasty, sub-Equatorial and therefore those guys are all about sun protection. This hat is 100% cotton, so be aware of that. It WILL SHRINK, but not a whole heck of a lot. I usually put mine through a beating every other year in the wash--they come out just fine. I own a dozen different kinds.This really great, broad-brimmed, comfy and cool Mega Cap boonie is just what the doctor ordered for high summer, low summer, spring and early autumn.

CAP, FLAT DRIVER'S, LINEN BY JEANNE SIMMONS is something I simply have to review. These beautiful caps used to revolt me to no end 20 years ago. Today I can't fathom why. Originally I got a couple in this style as winter caps, and really love them. In the summer it is just as vital for me to have a few caps, but it is weird how summer seems to call for a wider hat variety. This linen flat cap really fits the bill. The sun protection is unparalleled, the linen may feel a bit stifling when compared to my normal go-to hat which is a straw fedora. But this type of cap is indispensable, whether you just keep one handy in the car, closet or you wear them as a rule (like my wife's grandfather). The fit is excellent with no adjustable nonsense and no nasty elastic rubbing on one's head.I have noticed how sad it is this isn't called the "Braque cap". It was common all the way back to the 19th century to see caps very similar to this, called a "Newsboy" capâ€”but those were of gigantic diameter. The British and Irish cut the diameter down but then they based theirs on the Scottish bonnet which is no more than a beret. But then, artist Georges Braque, master of Cubism, took the newsboy style and really streamlined it in the end of the 1930s. He worked out the details with his tailor who then made him two: a black one and a white one. Braque named his cap design "casquette" and I don't even see that name used. Oddly enough, Braque designed it with the usual snap on the brim (which dates back to the end of the 19th century) but his design could be worn with it unsnapped ... and he designed it for summer wear, in linen. So this Jeanne Simmons cap is closest to the original thing. I really love that aspect of it.Like I said: the Braque Cap. There is only one bugbear and it really bothers me: beware of caps that have the front of the cap GLUED to the visor. I absolutely despise that yet even the Scottish cap-makers are doing it now for some stupid reason and it is infuriating. Doing things on the cheap like that will get you no customers and lose you a lot of pals too! So let the shopper beware, live with the glued visor if you must and get yourself a nice, cool flat cap in linen for the hot months as well as the early fall.

THE CASE AGAINST 8 (2014, 113 minutes, for HBO) is a truly riveting documentary that seems to have been at least five years in the making. California's proposed anti-gay equality legislation (Proposition 8) was and remains at the forefront of the story. Two wonderful, well-adjusted gay couples (Kristen Perry and Sandra Stier; Paul Katami and Jeffrey Zarillo) became the stars of our era's civil rights issue when they agreed to head the lawsuit against then-Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger and Prop 8. Perry and Stier each came from failed straight marriages and each had two sons. They are all delightfully intelligent and strong people. So Rob Reiner, president of the American Foundation for Equal Rights (AFER) helped get the best law firm (it is full of gay lawyers) and then pulled a real coup. In fact a double coup.Reiner, very much behind the scenes, got himself one of the most gifted, powerful attorneys on earth: David Boies. The name you might not recall but you'll definitely recall him when you see/hear him. He argued for Al Gore in the USSC case Gore vs. Bush (2000). But the stunner was when they approached Ted Olson and landed his help too. Olson had been for Bush in the USSC case and had been Boies' adversary. The two became good friends during that case. So ... with everything in place, here we go round the mulberry bush. The AFER "dream team" won their case to the boiling anger of the fascist evangelicals and Olson basically lost his golden boy status in the Republican party.So this is the story of the legal back-and-forth nightmare from the defeat of Prop 8 to where we are today. If I am not mistaken, Olson is the one arguing this case in front of the USSC in behalf of the gay community. This very case is the ruling we are now awaiting from the USSC: the ruling that would make gay equality the law of the land. It took over four years for the team to arrive at this point, but when they win (I can't envision us losing this) the world will win. It's a HUGE score for democracy. And if you think this will be some dry recitation of facts, just watch it. The documentation, the shooting, is smooth, riveting, and sometimes fun. These are all super-intelligent, charismatic people and the humor zings around like no one's business.What is important to recall is this legal team and the two brave couples already got to the U.S. Supreme Court for last year's ruling that struck down Prop 8 for California. (The other case ended with the USSC striking down the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA).) This documentary, while not leaning on that timeline too hard, covers it with ease and thoroughness. With that under the justices' belts in 2014, no one can seriously believe they will rule against gay equality in a few days time. I have my party accessories ready! Do you? I am going to party like it cost $19.99 when the final ruling comes in a few days' time. â˜ºOne of my favorite scenes is the mock supreme court practice trial with several law firm members trying to trip up Olson. That is like trying to make a silk purse into a sow's ear! Lots of great humor punctuates this story of two brave couples, two brave lawyers and one hell of a brave law firm fighting for all our rights. Another scene I love is seeing Paul Katami and Jeffrey Zarillo attempting to get married after they had won their case. It took the Attorney General of California to make a direct phone call to the courthouse to order them to issue licenses to all gay couples immediately. That was so awesome I wept with joy.If anyone sees this as an "agenda", they have no brain. What begins here as a fight for equality will end with true, honest, hard-won equality. FOR ALL. This DVD is an important historical document. Few issues could be as important. You must see this and understand that the events at the beginning of this short timeline are about to explode in a fireworks finale--in a few days, the USSC will announce its 2015 ruling. (Again, paired with this ruling will be another of equal weight: the ruling on "Obamacare".) This is so important a document that I am buying it as soon as I can.Two more films, documentaries, I highly recommend:Valentine Road about the evil cold-blooded murder of a transgender eighth-grader from Oxnard, California; see my review.The New Black [HD] about the successful, horribly controversial struggle in Maryland to fight homophobic legislation; see my review.

If you are a PBS-head you have heard, once in a blue moon, the brilliant adaptation songs of John D. Boswell of Washington State, better known as "melodysheep". He has taken footage of people from Julia Child to Fred Rogers ("In the Garden of Your Mind") to Yoda ("Feel the Force") and turned them into awesome, cogent electronica-dance songs. What Boswell does is hear the melody in people's spoken phrases, then puts them in order, sets them to music, and in my mind that makes him the greatest composer in the world. My wife and I have seen/heard his work on Julia Child ("Keep On Cooking") and Bob Ross ("Fluffy Little Clouds")--which made us weep with emotion.The "looping" of spoken words which are then turned into a song is a concept invented by composer Steve Reich back in the 1970s (Reich's best work: Reich: Different Trains, Electric Counterpoint / Kronos Quartet, Pat Metheny). I did a tiny bit of this myself in the early 1970s, and it requires composition skills that are indescribable. To hear then notate the natural music of the spoken word simply cannot be done by most humans. Boswell can do it with ease, but it is extremely hard work. You'll hear all of that in his songs. Best of all, Boswell pays homage to every subject for whom he composes. Just do a search for videos of "melodysheep" and pay close attention to the PBS stuff he composed. You can readily hear the entire pieces for yourself. They are usually just under four minutes long.Boswell's videos are as vital as the music, but you don't really need the videos. When I heard his treatment of Yoda ("Use the Force") I wept with pure joy. His take ("Let Us All Unite") on Charlie Chaplin's The Great Dictator (see my review of the film) will send shivers up your spine. (Don't confuse it with Hans Zimmer's rather pathetic music video of the same nature.) Get as much as you can of this young man's work. He is the next big thing and he is happening now. He reminds me of Wendy Carlos recording Bach back in the 1960s on a Moog. That is important and will change the world, note by note.And if Boswell/melodysheep doesn't make you appreciate the skill of a true composer, nothing can!RECOMMENDED OTHER WORK: Midnight Sun and you can find much more in MP3 downloads (you will not find any listings of "music" albums by melodysheep and that's a damned shame since he has done several albums).

DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES has a packaging that appears a bit corny, and a rather anemic-looking start ... but wait a few seconds. This 100% better sequel to James Franco's Planet of the Apes take is so astounding and so stirring I thought I felt the shivers I got from the original Planet Of The Apes (1968) [HD].This film simply picks up on Caesar living in what is left of the old park 10 years after the original movie (Andy Serkis in yet another Gollum-like motion capture appearance that would never let you guess what he looks like, but Caesar does have his eyes). He is surrounded by ape culture, some of them can speak and all of them can understand English perfectly. Thanks to the chimp-carried virus that humans invented and managed to spread, the apes think all the humans must be dead. Until they run into a few--cue the human-ape war.The effects here are stunning, and surprisingly moving. I was as involved and interested in the apes as I ever was with any film characters--and far more interested in them than in the humans. The ape sounds are perfect and the ones who struggle to mimic--or shall I say "ape"--spoken English are absolutely perfect too. I wonder if WE began talking like that. Every other ape merely signs. Just don't be too fooled by their ape-status. They are basically humans in chimpanzee form (with a tiny scattering of gorillas and one, exactly one, Orangutan named "Maurice"). This film is filled with subtle homages and I challenge you to two things: spot each homage and spot the "cameo" James Franco makes in this film. I'll give you one homage right off: the music, which pays tribute to the original PLANET OF THE APES movie.It never occurred to me that I would want to see this. It took them nearly five years to come out with it. The original was stupid, to be honest, and sequels are usually an ill-thought-out egregious error. Not in this case. And there were so many of us who wondered what the sequel might be like. Its only weakness: if they are sticking to the canonical storyline, we already know what happens so they can stop making any more of these right now and quit while they are ahead. Yet this film actually could promise a few more well-made sequels, that is, if the money and fans' patience don't run dry.You'll be glad of having seen this and want to watch it again--but my opinion as to that is two viewings will be enough. Get it for your "rainy day" DVD shelf, that is for sure. At a few minutes over two hours, this movie whizzes by really fast. One final thing is for sure: you'll never again doubt humans are truly ape--no matter who you are!

PROJECT ALMANAC (Dir. Dean Israelite, 2015, 106 minutes, Prod. by MTV Films) stars Jonny Weston as Atlanta teen physics wiz David Raskin. When David, his sister Christina (a stunning but too-little seen Virginia Gardner) and his two goofy genius friends (Allen Evangelista, Sam Lerner) decide to stir things up, they really stir. Poking around David's basement, they decide to investigate the laboratory of David's late father. What they discover is David's late father worked for one of the spookiest government agencies imaginable--and built a time machine for them.And glory of glories, it's hidden under the basement floor in a special compartment. No spoilers here, but can you guess what a bunch of impossibly cute teen nerds are going to do with a time machine? You won't be surprised--at first. Then you will be at the edge of your seat as this changes from cute teen comedy to something like a quasi-horror movie. Filmed in a clever way I have seen before but never with such smooth, stylish cinematographic genius, this is entirely from the viewpoint of the kids' camera. Most of the time Christina Raskin is doing the shooting as a way to help her brother's documentation, but there are occasions when some of the characters take the camera and film themselves. There is a BLAIR WITCH PROJECT feel to it and it will nauseate you if you don't take regular breaks.The thing about this film aside from its pure vintage 2004 digital camera shooting is the talent of the cast. Though much of the heavier stuff is heaved onto Jonny Weston's adorably thin shoulders, everyone here is absolutely top-notch. The humor, and this does start out as a comedy, is unbeatable and I wonder if some was ad-libbed. All the kids are pitch-perfect and loveable. This is no Disney time-travel movie, but it isn't PI and sure isn't BACK TO THE FUTURE or anything else though it is a remake of 2004's Primer [HD] (see my review) with lots of The Butterfly Effect [HD] thrown into the mix. Aside from the really fantastic humor, which you have to really pay attention to catch, there are several little homages to most of the time travel movies I know.In fact I am a time travel film connoisseur, having seen pretty much every single one with a few rancid exceptions. PROJECT ALMANAC (the title itself is a double homage, did you catch that?) is going down in history as one of the very best of them all. While it is plainly a remake of PRIMER, it is a fantastic, touching and thrilling update making it relevant for young adults, which PRIMER didn't quite achieve. I highly recommend this, but as I said, it has rules: pay close attention to every second, take frequent breaks and I recommend a second viewing within a day or two of the first. Really, this is the only time I know that an entire film is presented as camera footage that is deliberately shot as a record for the audience to view.Naturally you are more than just a "voyeur" here: it is like being part of that team of kids. After that, watch as a perennial favorite at your leisure. It seems available only in Blu Ray which is a poke in my eye, but I'll bet a normal DVD version will be forthcoming. This film is going to end up being THE TWELVE MONKEYS of this new young generation.

THE NEW BLACK was a stunning documentary which seems to date to 2012 and deals with Maryland's vote to legalize gay marriage. Somehow, and I really do not know why other than the huge percentage of black population in Maryland, this issue got immediately cast in a racist sort of light. The message to the entire country seemed, at least for a short time, to be the very concept of gay equality resting purely with the black community. Of course gay equality does not rest purely with the black community and this documentary beautifully shows the tension, the pain, among Maryland's black community. They were starting to feel exactly what the title of this film says: gay is "the new" black.It's a stupid concept pro se. Within the context of the documentary, I think that the black religious community and its leaders were right about many things. They were seething angry about the gay community comparing gay equality to black equality--and in some strange way I support that view. It could be the simple matter that gay isn't a skin color, we were never slaves over a two-century period, or slaves at all, and aside from Stonewall and the medication push for AIDS we never had to have violent civil rights-defining moments. A very obnoxious Queer Nation march in the 1990s is not the same as Selma. Or is it?In this film the viewer is presented with that and other salient, important questions. Two people jumped at me from this film: one, a random young man spending time with his homophobic friends was approached and he angrily said the state had no right to tell anybody whom they could/could not marry, to the grim shock of his friends. The other person who tugged at my heart is the young black girl who has a sweet, wide-eyed enthusiasm that one day she'll be happy with the woman she loves, a job she loves, and full equality. Once I saw those two young people, I had my answer. Gay has always been a form of "black", just as women understood this about themselves, and did not need John Lennon to write a song telling us what a woman means to the world. (Do you all know that song? Lennon uses the "n" word most effectively.)So I counsel a cool discretion and a clear mind when seeing this and watching, listening, with those skills. This nation is not a theocracy, and someone in the film, a very important personage, speaks to the public and says equality, civil rights, all matters of justice, should be free of any dictates of religious dogma. He slapped down the mandarins of orthodoxy and slapped them good. The problem is, as this film also teaches, too few people are willing to listen, care or share of themselves when it comes to the torments and travails of others. The unsupported young gay black people in this film wonder where their families went, why they suddenly got abandoned for being gay, when the referendum came up for the vote. It made me cry--and not because "the perverts" were trampling the name of Jesus.That kind of straw man argument was used by racists in the mid-20th century. Let us not forget that!This will make you think very hard, and will make you cry too if you have any sense of justice. They say Rosa Parks sitting at the back of the bus really wasn't the true issue back in the day. I was there and recall it very well. It WAS the issue of the day, and it was Rosa Parks who made this nation wake the hell up. Watch this documentary and ask yourself who the new Rosa Parks is. One thing is for sure: the gay Rosa Parks will never emerge from among the dum-dums who hide in churches behind their pews and their choirs. Rosa Parks did not hide that way. It's the kids, it's your kids, it's everyone like it or not.And as a good loud spoiler, as we all know, Maryland did pass that equality law by such a razor-thin margin it almost looked like the fascists were going to take it away ... that is where you will learn another lesson from this film: how the evangelical white folks are using the black churches to spread their hatred.

CLAWS OF STEEL a/k/a Last Hero in China (see my review for that version, Orig. title Wong Fei Hung V: Tit gai dau ng gung, 1993, 111 minutes) stars Jet Li (credited as Lin Kit Li) as Wong Fei Hung in a super-paced comedy that has far better comedy than kung fu.When Wong loses his undersized school lease, he moves from Foshan to a better place only to become embroiled in a kidnapping scheme that somehow involves the British. While the quality is somewhat between what we grew to love post-1995 and the crap they used to put out in the 1980s, the comedy here is at its finest. Do not forget the film you are watching: the Chinese government was still pushing hard at this time to discredit Buddhists, especially the Chinese Orthodox and the Tibetans. In this film they slip it in no problem.This film amazed me simply because I had never seen nor heard of it before. While knowing what to expect--subpar kung fu and the usual communist messages--its comedic slapstick combined with sophistication really floored me. The wire-fu is barely visible and obviously Jet Li had some fun playing Wong Fei Hung here. He would go on to play the legendary Wong Fei Hung a few times with his last being Badges of Fury in 2013, after having played him famously in the series Once Upon a Time in China Multi-Feature (Once Upon a Time in China / Once Upon a Time in China II / Once Upon a Time in China 3) (that film series would go on without him though he returned to the Wong Fei Hung role almost immediately to star in this film under review).My gut feeling was Jet Li was not only lampooning the film industry and Wong Fei Hung character--but also poking a lot of fun at himself. I also think this film inspired Jackie Chan's fantastic turn as a young Wong Fei Hung in the legendary and beautiful The Legend of Drunken Master from 1994. Of course that very year Jet Li was busily worrying his own spectacular Wong Fei Hung-style spoof Legend of the Red Dragon a/k/a THE NEW LEGEND OF SHAOLIN. (See my review of both those.) CLAWS is also somehow a spoof of all his films up til that time. In fact the film is kind of like a spoof of his whole career--and I can't fathom why he did it at all. I've heard he has a great sense of humor and he certainly has a flair for a kind of dignified, high-brow comedy only the Chinese can accomplish.But then he has a large family in China and no doubt has been kept on a short leash his whole life. Anyway, martial arts connoisseur and fans should see at the very least this silly, rollicking film for the comedy if nothing else. I've seen far worse than this from the famous "Chinese Golden 90s", though I was surprised to see Jet Li in something apparently so demeaning. However, I have always felt Jet Li is a kind of unwilling puppet of the Chinese communist propaganda machine, and this film is but one piece of proof to that.

LAST HERO IN CHINA a/k/a Claws Of Steel Aka Last Hero In China (English Subtitled) [HD] (see my review for that version, Orig. title Wong Fei Hung V: Tit gai dau ng gung, 1993, 111 minutes) stars Jet Li (credited as Lin Kit Li) as Wong Fei Hung in a super-paced comedy that has far better comedy than kung fu. Before I go further here, let me advise that this version may have soundtracks in Chinese as well as English, and the earlier release had subtitles only--but you never really know with Chinese releases. I happened to see this for the first time dubbed in Spanish and I LOVED the way it worked so well.When Wong loses his undersized school lease, he moves from Foshan to a better place only to become embroiled in a kidnapping scheme that somehow involves the British. While the quality is somewhat between what we grew to love post-1995 and the crap they used to put out in the 1980s, the comedy here is at its finest. Do not forget the film you are watching: the Chinese government was still pushing hard at this time to discredit Buddhists, especially the Chinese Orthodox and the Tibetans. In this film they slip it in no problem.This film amazed me simply because I had never seen nor heard of it before. While knowing what to expect--subpar kung fu and the usual communist messages--its comedic slapstick combined with sophistication really floored me. The wire-fu is barely visible and obviously Jet Li had some fun playing Wong Fei Hung here. He would go on to play the legendary Wong Fei Hung a few times with his last being Badges of Fury in 2013, after having played him famously in the series Once Upon a Time in China Multi-Feature (Once Upon a Time in China / Once Upon a Time in China II / Once Upon a Time in China 3) (that film series would go on without him though he returned to the Wong Fei Hung role almost immediately to star in this film under review).My gut feeling was Jet Li was not only lampooning the film industry and Wong Fei Hung character--but also poking a lot of fun at himself. I also think this film inspired Jackie Chan's fantastic turn as a young Wong Fei Hung in the legendary and beautiful The Legend of Drunken Master from 1994. Of course that very year Jet Li was busily worrying about his own spectacular Wong Fei Hung-style spoof Legend of the Red Dragon a/k/a THE NEW LEGEND OF SHAOLIN. (See my review of both those: I think RED DRAGON kept Li out of DRUNKEN MASTER but not out of the role of Wong Fei Hung for very long.) CLAWS is also somehow a spoof of Li's whole career--and I can't fathom why he did it at all. I've heard he has a great sense of humor and he certainly has a flair for a kind of dignified, high-brow comedy only the Chinese can accomplish.The very fact that he played some goofy nobody in NEW LEGEND OF SHAOLIN/RED DRAGON while Jackie Chan got the plum role of Wong Fei Hung in DRUNKEN MASTER in the same year shows just how perverse the Chinese industry can get. But then Li has a large family in China and no doubt has been kept on a very short leash his whole life by the government. Anyway, martial arts connoisseur and fans should see at the very least this silly, rollicking film for the comedy if nothing else. I've seen far worse than this from the famous "Chinese Golden 90s", though I was surprised to see Jet Li in something apparently so demeaning. However, I have always felt Jet Li is a kind of unwilling puppet of the Chinese communist propaganda machine, and this film is but one piece of proof to that.
